reviews.review: The Frick Collection. I visit it last year. It is a master piece. We anjoyed it very much. It is a must. Do not miss it you won't regret.

An elegant oasis. If you are an art lover this is definitely worth a visit.
Old masters in elegant surroundings and a good walk to get there.
very interesting museum. its not the best value for money,but its smaller and not as crowded is the bigger museum , without long lines and you can't take pictures in most areas of the museum.
Fabulous Frick. The Frick museum is filled with portrait art and landscapes housed in a mansion that faces Central Park. It's a beautiful gem of a place, small and intimate.
One of my favorite museums in New York. Great permanent collection; also, good temporary exhibits. Beautiful building that houses the collection.

Great place to take young adults. For an introduction to art the Frick combines a wonderful collection of masterpieces with the experience of a home, in which people lived and enjoyed the art on the walls. It makes the experience more personal and for those with relatively short attention spans keeps the museum tour to an hour or two. Kids like to move about the rooms, knowing someone lived in that sort of splendor.
Amazing collection in a lovely setting.. What really needs to be said? Go for the Rembrandt self-portrait, stay for the courtyard, and try to notice how nice that damn house is!

Artistic gem for art lovers who only have 90 minutes. You can overwhelmed at The Met or MOMA or The Whitney with the number of exhibits and the breadth of their collection. Not the broadest collection of European art but a stunning selection of paintings by some of the world's greatest European painters (Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Boucher, David, Degas, Vermeer, Goya). You're in someone's mansion, not a museum, so you'll find smaller rooms with decorative art and period furnishings to complement the paintings. You won't be sorry you visited.

Wonderful collection of art. I had been wanting to come here for a while and so glad I included it on this trip. Having visited many cities and the art galleries, this one is a breathe of fresh air. A small but well put together collection of art from around the world with thoughtful commentaries available from audio guides included in the entry fee. Beautiful rooms, with paintings often from only one or two artists (like Gainsborough or Whistler) help you appreciate how a collector would arrange works of art in his own room. Unfortunately, on finding out how Frick made his money, for me some of the gloss comes off the home and the collection!

Intimate Collection. This is a must see in New York, especially for those who are easily overwhelmed by the larger museums. This is an intimate, mainly private collection, housing some of the greatest paintings in any private collection. Many of the paintings are displayed as they were when the house was occupied by its owner.

Great Art Collection. The Frick is one of the great small art museums in NY. It has mainly european masters. The house itself is also beautiful, representative of the Robber Baron/ Gilded Age.
Some of the staff are way overzelous, bordering on the ridiculous (don't stand here,don't stop there, etc...).
A must see.

Beautiful!!!. The building is as beautiful as the art. Lovely. We used the New York Explorer Pass for our entrance. FYI, they say you don't have to stand in line with a pass, but everywhere we went, you still had a line. I like the museum because it wasn't so big it was overwhelming, and not so weird you were left scratching your head. We went specifically to see the Vermeer paintings and they did not disappoint.
loved it. I am a student of art and a museum-lover..this time I had a date and we went to this museum...this museum you saved me from feeling I wasted my day with a boring date..thank you

Unique Museum. This 5th avenue mansion (at 70th street) used to be a private house and now it's an art museum. There is a permanent collection and some temporary exhibits. On top of the art exhibits, it is fascinating to walk throughout this huge house while looking at its architectural details, the design, the furniture. On a nice day, it is wonderful to take a break and sit on one of the benches in the house's yard.
A great hidden museum of NYC. Great art tucked away off of central park east. Art for my taste, great painting, you won't find art like: "2 beers stacked on each other"
Fine Museum, small, atmospheric. A great museum, with wonderful atmosphere, fine cafe andArt that is truly interesting-without being overwhelming.

Frick Museum - First Friday. What a treat to be able to visit Frick Museum as part of First Friday program - exquisite experience - every detail of the house deserves attention - obviously the art collection but also every detail of the interior - design, fittings, colour combinations, ceiling detail, flooring, and furnishings as well as wall coverings - divine.

A mansion of art on 5th Avenue . Gorgeous 5 th Avenue mansion was the home of Henry Clay Frick, and offers a showing of both special exhibits, and exquisite art, furniture and artifacts.Paintings include beautiful examples of Rembrandt, Vermeer, El Greco, Whistler, Turner, and many others.Very Highly recommended.

Fantastic little museum!. After walking for hours and hours at the MET - which is an amazing museum - it was lovely to visit the Frick collection who, albeit smaller, has fantastic pieces, a lovely relaxing indoor patio and all around great atmosphere. In you're in NY make sure not to miss it!

A Little Jewel. This is my favorite NY museum - and one of my favorite museums period. The architecture and moldings are as noteworthy as the incredible collection of paintings and bronzes. Just to sit by the fountain or gaze at the stunning gardens is a marvelous experience.

A Must See!. View masterpiece works of art in a sumptuous, yet relaxed setting. The collection is all on one level and the acoustic self guided tour is really excellent. You can push a button in front of the painting and hear a short beautifully concise explanation of what you are looking at. I was there on a rainy Saturday afternoon and it was not that crowded!
A Must See. This is such a beautiful museum, with an amazing collection of art. The guides are very helpful, if you need them. The building itself is also a work of art.
a jewel on 5th Avenue. beautiful art collection in a stunning building, tucked away on 5th Avenue. Wonderfully tranquil, take time to sit back and enjoy the art, estate rooms and atrium

Very high admission price for an ok collection . Visited today and was not very impressed. Some great paintings but it was hard to tell what many looked like as the facility is very dark. Admission price is high for the volume of paintings exhibited. Once was enough. Don't take any small children (under 10)they won't be admitted

Worth a visit. This collection is very good, with a wide range of items of interest. It is small, so you can see it all in half a day.The art, ceramics etc are first rate, but the layout is a little quirky. Unless you take the audio guide, you get bit lost navigating and the written labels are small and hard to read.Also some of the paintings suffer from lighting reflection.Good, but frustrating sometimes - must have the audio guide.

Amazing collection of art in a beautiful house. The perfect activity for an overcast or rainy day in NYC. The Frick boasts a collection of old masters (Reynolds, Gainsborough, Constable, Velasquez, Goya, Ingres) , impressionists (Turner, Renoir, Manet, Monet), porcelain, sculpture and a beautiful inner courtyard garden with pond and seats. A great way to while away time! Please note no children allowed (teens are fine).
Breathtaking and lovely.. A stunning collection in a home environment. Beats a painting hung on a white wall. Will definitely be back!

Well worth prioritising. I was surprised more than a view times by some of the paintings I came across. I recommend the Frick Collection if only to see the Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell facing each other as they do. You can see which enjoys the sympathy of the artist, and which does not when you're next to them. There is so much more besides.
STUNNING COLLECTION. Closed to the Met, this place is more quiet but the collection is beautiful, and the architecture is amazing.

Outstanding collection in a superb setting. Think of the best examples of old masters or sculpture or ceramics in a suitable non museum like setting and this is what the Frick collection gives you, it's not stuffy or anything like the Met as its small and compact

Immersed in culture. The Frick is an intimate experience that I had wanted to experience for some time. The place is small with small rooms that open into tall galleries for the bigger works. you can get really close to the pictures and see the brush strokes but still get enough distance to appreciate the complete work. The place seems unhurried and i sought out and found work I was most interested in.Definitely a place to revisit.

A Gem of a Gallery. If you are in NYC and have any interest in art, history or culture, this 'gilded age ' mansion is an absolute must. The setting is perfect, the atmosphere calm and reflective and the collection of paintings is stunning. The Metropolitan Museum of Art is almost overwhelming but the Frick Collection is just perfect for a two hour visit. The staff are courteous and knowledgeable. Go early, as soon as it opens at 10am.

A superb experience. Art galleries are a matter of taste. I love the Frick because it is small but nevertheless has an extraordinary collection of paintings, furniture and ceramics. They are set out as though they were a personal collection representing that person's individual choice - which of course is exactly what it is. I have been lucky in my visits over the years as it has never been crowded; I can imagine this could be a problem. For this reason I would avoid the times when they have a cheap entrance fee option. For UK visitors the portraits of Thomases More and Cromwell, the large collection of Gainsboroughs and the wonderful Constable painting of Salisbury Cathedral are of particular interest. Allow 3 to 4 hours.

Allow around 4 hours.. What a hidden gem! Lots of well know paintings. One of my favorite is a portrait of Thomas Moore on one side of a fireplace facing Oliver Cromwell on the other side of the fireplace. An El Greco of St Jerome was in the middle.

Another Must See in NYC. This very impressive collection and building, which was actually the home of Frick, is a must see when in NYC if you are a lover of history and art. The building itself is fascinating, just opposite Central Park, but the artwork collection is incredible and a great dedication to the person who collected it and allowed it to be for public use. Frustrating that you cannot use a camera, even without flash, but the guide books are worth buying. The audio guide is included in the price and is very good and informative.

My favorite museum in NY. This is my favorite museum in NY. It was the private mansion of an art collector, Frick. It's very cool to walk around, as you get a glimpse into a private world you wouldn't normally see. Sunday 11-13 is "pay as much as you want". There's an audio tour that accompanies the visit. There's also an app, which I didn't use.
The love of my trip!. Amazing building filled with awe inspiring art work. This truly was my highlight of a two week visit.
Some of the best art in the city. The atrium is one of the most tranquil places in the city. You will want to come back more than once.

A wonderful way to spend an afternoon. This was the first time I've ever experienced the Frick. It is a much smaller collection than the Met, but it is the perfect size to do in an afternoon and feel like you have had enough time to appreciate it fully. The portraits are fantastic, and the audio guide is superb and highly recommended. If you like 18th and 19th century art, this is not to be missed.

So many masterpieces in one place I felt dizzy. The collection is distributed throughout the house in a manner that is similar to the way it was when Henry Clay Frick lived. For such a small museum you can find masterpieces and paintings so emblematic that I originally assumed they had to be in Europe. Among the jewels there is the a portrait of Oliver Cromwell by Hans Holbein the Younger, and perhaps the most representative pieces of the roccoco style by both Boucher and Fragonard. Its important to note that unlike most museums, no photography is allowed and there is no place to eat within the building.

Ideal if you'd like to see old masters up close without having to walk miles. Henry Clay Frick compiled a mind-boggling collection of priceless paintings, clocks, ceramics and artefacts during his lifetime. It was great to be able to see everything up close. We also loved seeing his house, particularly the central atrium / pool and garden which made a lovely tranquil oasis. Tip: Download the app and borrow headphones to do a self-guided tour.
Unexpected. A wonderful collection of art in a very impressive, understated, early 20th-century east-side mansion. A very manageable size, which makes it really good afternoon or morning outing.

THE FAMOUS FRICK. this is the best private collection of art in new york........located on fifth avenue at 70th street, it contains many unique portraits and
masterpieces art lovers will recognize from the 15th to the 19th century displayed in Frick's magnificent mansion on central park

An unforgettable experience. I don't live in NYC, but I've been here over 20 times since the late 1960's, and consider it an artistic tour de force. There are simply few other places in the world to experience such lovely and special esoteric hours. Go here, and leave 2-3 hours later, and you will remember it forever. The Louvre, Hermitage, Uffizi and Met all have their astonishing displays, but for a pure concentration of beauty and specialness, here is where you should go.

Frick's Summer Home. Fellow Pittsburghers would feel a connection with our friend, Mr Frick, visiting his summer home in Manhattan, now turned museum. Photos are only permitted in the former driveway, now an interior fountain illuminated with daylight, but definitely worth a trip to see collections of artwork acquired by Frick during his lifetime and afterwards by his daughter. The museum has a short movie worthy of your time to give a back story that will make you appreciate the collections even more and enhance your knowledge of how much he appreciated fine art and what his intention was upon building this magnificent structure. So happy someone has the money to salvage this art and allow it to be viewed by the public.
Beautiful home and decor. Very interesting collection of paintings and furnishings. Art covers a variety of time periods and events in history.
If in NY you must come here. Fantastic art and history here that you don't want to miss. Takes about 1 hour to see everything at a medium pace.

A real eye opener. We thought this would be a good way of spending a couple of hours - we were wrong. There is so much to see in this wonderful house that several hours are needed to pay it justice. Every piece of art was of great quality and to see a room decorated with panels by Boucher was amazing. There are also two great Holbeins, well worth the visit. I should add that the Frick Collection app is just brilliant- the history of every piece of art in the house.

It's really neat but you can't take photos inside. We got here very close to closing time so we did not get to see everything but the collection we got to see was very impressive! El Greco, Goya, Corot, beautiful furniture pieces. I did not like that we were not able to take photos, since other museums do allow it.

Poor collection. There is little here which is exceptional or noteworthy and is small. If art work like they display is of interest then visit but for most people there is little to get excited about here. The Vermeer and some other works are of note but little more. For most people this place should be a 'Don't bother'.

must be see. This museum is very unknown but the collections are so important for ancient european arts.
The building, a former private house, must been visited.

Beautiful House and Art. We enjoyed the Frick a great deal. It is a little hard to get into if you are in a wheelchair although staff is very helpful. Artwork is amazing as is the home. Audio tour was very good as well.

One of the top two museums in New York. Most people bypass the Frick, and they're wrong. It's the opposite number to the Wallace Collection in London, in that it's a personal collection housed in a beautiful 'domestic' setting. It's outstanding for the portraiture, and for the architecture of the building. It's also one of the nicest places to spend time in New York. Do go.

Fricke Museum. This is a beautiful mansion museum! The collections range from traditional American paintings to various current exhibitions. There is an exquisite indoor garden where you can sit and relax and enjoy the view of lovely water fountains in a serene setting. . It is so peaceful and relaxing!
fantastic art collection. This once private home, built around 1900, houses one of the world's most exclusive art collections.
Impressive in many ways. Apart fro the exquisite artwork and artefacts you get a glimpse into a world of enormous wealth and privilege. Frick's story Is the classic American Dream .

An intimate escape from city rhythms--or is it?. A friend and I took in the Frick Collection on a Sunday, between 11 and 1. Those are the free/"pay as you wish" hours. I wish we had come during regular hours.We started out early in the "free admission" time, when the galleries had fewer than 7 to 10 people each in them. But within an hour the crowding was beginning to bother us. We loved debating what was happening in "Symphony in Flesh Colour and Pink: Portrait of Mrs. Frances Leyland, 1871-74" by James Abbott McNeill Whistler. Why was she so close to the wall? Or was she? What about that magnificent gown (which looked quite like a dressing gown--so was she partially undressed?). Had they been lovers? We loved comparing her to the other Whistler portrait, "Harmony in Pink and Grey: Portrait of Lady Meux." So there was time for contemplation. For a while.The giant Veroneses took me back to Venice, and one of the most wonderful things about them is that you can see them "up close and personal." If you love color, don't miss the master's "Wisdom and Strength" and "The Choice Between Virtue and Vice." Simply breathtaking. I could have looked at them all day.The interior pond, flanked by a most modern guardian angel, became crowded quickly. Several people at once vied to take pictures of the frog fountain. People were closing in on our reveries. It started to feel like the subway, handbags bumping us and people cutting in front of each other. Soon we each reported having a headache. It was time to go.The gift shop was mobbed. It was almost impossible to get the attention of staff, and one clerk, clearly full of himself, was downright rude to my friend. There is no necessity for that. Yes, it's crowded, but if you can't handle your job, please quit. I think Mr. Frick would have fired him immediately. While there is no restaurant, Cafe Laduree is around the corner on Madison, for good coffee and pastry. Apparently the powers that be at the Museum plan to dig up the lily pond and garden to the East of the home--a true place of silent repose--to build over them with offices and a cafe. But they plan no additional gallery space. This is a deplorable plan. I think Mr. Frick would roll over in his grave. The Museum has done quite well without these things for decades. This garden and its pond are composing, one of the few places left in New York where you can truly find peace. (Shaking my head.) Do try to see it while it's still there. Free, to the right of the entrance.

A Frickin good time!. More like a British National Trust home with various works of art, furniture, sculptures etc. Very good audio guide which is free. Difficult to believe that it was like this when lived in. Catch the short videos and the atrium garden. Not allowed any carry ins like drinks!

Don't miss this collection1. Well worth the visit, especially Free Friday's! Outstanding collection, many of the great masters, be sure to use the free electronic headset, it allows you to go at your own pace and in any order you want. The house is amazing in itself also.

Enchanting. I found the Frick Collection to be much quieter and more intimate than other art galleries in New York. The paintings were exquisite, the (free) audio commentary was very informative, and it was lovely to look at art in the plush setting of Mr Frick's mansion. The staff were also very welcoming and polite.

Amazing collection,amazing building. This collection is a very good introduction to European art. Easy to get to on the Museum mile so it can be combined with Central Park or another museum on 5th Ave. The building itself is a monument to the wealth of some New Yorkers!!

Delightful museum. This is a lovely museum which apart from the beautiful art collection also gives an insight into the life of the wealthy in NYC early last century. Definitely worth a visit if you have time.

Lovely exhibits and courtyard. I can add nothing to the many wonderful reviews. I love the place! I find this museum just marvelous and exactly the right size for a tired tourist to comfortably enjoy. A plus for me turned out to be Ann Jaffe in the Museum Store who knew exactly where to find a photo of a table I liked. She knew where it was in the Decorative Arts book. It is nice when personnel love their job!

It's in my memory forever!. I've been to most of the larger museums in Europe and the US and I must say that I am left absolutely stunned and impressed by this collection. The grandeur, opulence and detail is unparalleled and the experience left me feeling happy and rich in knowledge for Mr. Frick and NY society in the early 1900's. History and art buffs alike will appreciate this sophisticated collection. The navigation through the collection was easy, and the audio guide was great in providing explanation for the paintings, furniture, sculptures, and other pieces scattered throughout. As others have mentioned, this is not a place for young children, and don't expect the Met or MoMA size-wise. Visit for peace, reflection and admiration of masters amid a setting that I know Mr. Frick would be very proud of today!

A Can't Miss Gem. I have been a member of The Frick Collection for a number of years. No other museum on New York gives so much instant satisfaction as The Frick, or can so reliably amaze a visiting friend. I suppose you could say it's a small museum, occupying Mr. Frick's mansion on perhaps the most valuable stretch of real estate in New York. But the collection is anything but small. It is the densest assemblage of masterpieces under one roof excepting perhaps the Courtauld in London. If you're after modern art, The Frick is not for you, and "modern" includes the Impressionists. There are minor paintings by Monet, Manet, and Degas, but they are an afterthought. You come to The Frick to see "Old Masters" and there are so many great paintings it's hard to describe all the highlights.The paintings and sculpture are displayed in fabulous rooms where Frick and his family once lived. In the first main room you come to, the Living Hall, there are two Holbeins, one of them the famous painting of Thomas More, staring warily across the fireplace at his nemesis, Thomas Cromwell. There is tremendous drama created by having these two Holbeins together in one room, 500 years after the events of Wolf Hall. Two Titians on the other wall show the master at his best: they are very different portraits but each overflows with its own emotion. Romance in the Portrait of a Young Man Wearing a Red Hat and power in the burly form of Pietro Aretino. Titian getting started and Titian as master of the art world: almost as dramatic a juxtaposition as the two Holbeins.But the star of the room is the magnificently preserved St. Francis in the Desert by Giovanni Bellini. An observer could devote an entire visit to just this painting, and indeed, there is a large book devoted to it for sale in the bookstore. It's so full of details, drama, and religious fervor, but without looking like a 15th century religious painting. The look on Francis' face as he receives the stigmata is one of complete bafflement, what a real person must have felt in the circumstances. There is a donkey standing nearby, looking very real and oblivious. The plants growing in the rocks, his sandals, and even the string doorbell are rendered with a naturalism that could be 19th Century. But Bellini painted this in the 1470s. Before DaVinci, before Michaelangelo, before the true High Renaissance. This truly is one of the world's great masterpieces. You'll have to rip yourself away so you can get to the main room.Here you will be overwhelmed as you look down the West Gallery and see highlights every 3 or 4 steps. Everything here is worth spending time with. Rembrandts including The Polish Rider. Hals, Velasquez, El Greco, Goya, Claude Lorraine, a magnificent pair of Van Dyck portraits of Frans Snyders and his wife, magnificent Turners on opposite walls. And at the end of the gallery, framing the door to the pre-Renaissance collection, two unforgettable and enormous mythological scenes by Veronese. Once in the collection of Rudolph II, these are unquestionable Veronese masterpieces, and with a partner painting just up the road at the Met, you can see Veronese at his best in three canvases.The far room - the Enamels Room - has Pieros, a Duccio, and even a Cimabue - the only one in New York that I know of. It's a small quiet room stuffed with very religious - looking paintings, all of the first quality. And JP Morgan's priceless collection of Limoges enamels.There's a room of ravishing British paintings, a Gilbert Stuart George Washington, one of Ingres' greatest paintings, a charming room of Boucher childrens' panels, a room of Fragonards, a perfect Bronzino: it goes on and on. When you need a rest, the Garden Court may be the most luxurious place to sit in all New York.What have I forgotten? Well, there was something else i should have mentioned, but with so much to see at every turn you'll need to come back to truly take it all in.Advice: Get the headphones and take the tour. There are no descriptions of the paintings on the walls, as there are in most museums. And buy a book to keep with you. You'll be glad you have it later as the Frick does not publish its pictures widely. If there is a restaurant there I am unaware of it and affordable lunch won't be easy in nearby streets, as you are now in the poodle district. Fortunately, Central Park is right across the street. Get a hot dog. All your senses will be glowing from the visit back to another era, when rich people were really rich and further back, when artists were truly Masters. The hot dog will taste delicious.
Excellent.. Look for the pipe organ under the stairs. Often there are concerts given in the afternoon. The rooms are very special, and reflect how live was lived in NY by Mr. Frick (from Pittsburgh).

A well preserved Gilded Age Mansion. A fabulous collection of art on display in a gilded age mansion. View at your own pace and imagine the Fricks living here at the turn of the 29th century. A fabulous experience.

Sunday mornings are pay what you wish. Worth going if you get in for a reduced price/free on a sunday. One of the lesser known attractions in NYC and worth a visit if you have time, but if you're in a rush you should spend your time elsewhere. Charming building, lots of beautiful art. Not too big- I was done here in an hour. Take some time to think about how this was actually someone's house and the kind of life they must have led- that was the more interesting part for me, having already been to some other art museums! NB cameras not allowed except in central garden room.

oasis in a concrete jungle. We returned to the Frick collection 12 years later. We found it even more beautiful this time. What really amazed me this time were the huge amount of paintings from Legendary artists. This is an architectural gem in the city a must for the traveler that has more than 2 days in the city for sightseeing.

An amazing museum for those who can appreciate it. Personally, I love the Frick, and have visited numerous times - it's like visiting an old friend - but I realized recently that it's not to everyone's taste. Read up on it before you come.

An oasis of calm in Manhattan.. The Frick is a high quality collection set in the original 5th century robber-baron mansion of its original owner/collector, Henry Clay Frick. Less popular than the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guggenheim and MoMA, it is a much more contemplative setting for viewing art, and it has some gems in its collection.

Stunning. A truly wonderful collection and a stunning example of what life was like in that era. The home has been beautifully preserved, the art is exquisite and it was very peaceful. A great place to visit on a rainy day or a hot afternoon. Worth a visit. Small and intimate compared to many museums/collections.

Beats similar venues in London. An amazing private collection for art lovers. This surpasses the private collections of London. Surprising that this quality of art could have been accumulated for a personal collection. This is a perfect addition to a trip to the Met...but not on the same day.
Overlooked Gem. Worked in the area for many years always passed this up until this spring. Beautiful small, focused art collection and grounds.

Fragonard Room & Boucher Paintings!!. The Frick Collection truly is a gem. The Fragonard Room is awesome! There are so many masterpieces in this collection; well worth the visit. They don't allow photography, but they do have a nice book that have many of the pieces for a good price.
A peaceful spot in a busy city. The house itself is worth seeing, and the art collection is amazing. If you need a peaceful moment, find the atrium in the middle of the building. Relax, enjoy.

One of New York City's Treasures!. Touring the Frick takes you back to the robber barons' halcyon days of copious consumption in decor and architecture. It's an incredible and amazingly well preserved structure in a beautiful area.

Impressive Collection in a wonderful house. If you are a lover of the 18th and 19th century, this museum is of course a must go to. You feel like pushed back in these times by walking in the beautiful rooms and looking at the paintings and art objects. By learning more of the history of the building and the collection/collector you even love the place more.

NYCs Jewel Of A Spectacular Collection - Absolute Must See. It wasn't until we had been to NYC dozens of times that we finally got to the Frick. As many others have commented, this is indeed the jewel of NYCs museums. Not only are there world class paintings on display, but the way they are hung among 19th century furnishings in an incredible upper east side mansion.....wow! Among the paintings we love the Cromwell and Sir Thomas More portraits by Holbein and what is probably Rembrandt's finest self portrait. There are also Titians, Goya, el Greco, Constable, Turner, Gainsborough, Degas, Monet and Vermeer, But we really love Dieppe Harbor by Turner. There are also excellent collections of sculpture, Limoges enamels and porcelains. As several others have pointed out, the best way to do the Frick is Sunday brunch time.....it's pay what you wish on Sundays from 11am-1pm. A really spectacular museum that everyone on the planet should see. You will never forget it.

Historical, Wonderful art, Matinee. How can I say this..? The Frick Collection is for adults. This is a museum for those who appreciate creative exploration of architecture, of furniture, painting, and most importantly, the practice of collecting and displaying art. The collection houses Frick's personal favorites, so don't be 100% shocked if they're not yours.

A collection and setting not to be missed. Away from the bustle of 5th Avenue the Frick collection and the building which houses it is an oasis of calm and culture. This is a classic art collection not to be missed.Hi points? to see portraits of Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell in the same room and to discover the peaceful, elegant courtyard reminiscent of an ancient Roman villa.

A quiet paradise of the best European art and American decor. A quiet paradise of some the best European art and American (19th décor although no photos allowed its a bit mean as you spend at least $17 to get in.

Interesting for both the house and the collection. A small but extremely good art collection, but for me the most interesting thing is to see the interior of the house. Sundays 11-13 admission is voluntary.Kids under 10 are not allowed, as the objects are easy to reach, without any kind of protection.

Interesting Place. Passed this place for many years, final went. Not for everyone. Do not bring small children or babies. Young teens and up really. This is strictly for those who love history and or architecture. Do not plan your entire day around seeing this. Get there early for opening, see website for details on hours, days open. Really only 1 visit is needed to see this. We did like and we are glad we got to see it.

Definitely worth a visit.. This museum is the former home of the Frick family. It's a beautiful house with a lovely center atrium and many beautiful paintings, sculptures and decorative arts. The museum can be seen in its entirety in about 2 hours. Get the free easy to use audio guide to help you understand what you're seeing.

Depends what you're into. I don't like art, but I really liked the building & the story of the Frick family was also interesting. I would have liked to have been able to photograph the house, but you can't because of the art.

New York's Jewel!. The Frick is New York's version of London's Wallace Collection but on steroids. It's a beautiful block sized building full of great art from art worlds greats. The collection also includes one of a kind furnishings most of which was collected by Mr. Frick.The museum is normally very quiet and offers a peaceful heaven from New York's hustle and bustle. It's a place one can spend a whole glorious morning wonder its magnificent rooms. Definitely worth the U$22 entrance fee.

My favorite small art museum in the city!. Always a wonderful day when it's spent at the Frick. The collection is wonderful and showcased beautifully in this intimate setting, you won't be disappointed.

Superb collection in a wonderful environment. Wonderful opportunity to get a sense of life in the Gilded Age while enjoying an outstanding art collection that includes some extraordinary pieces. The audio tour is very well done.

Proper art. The Frick Collection is stunning. Not only does the collection feature works by some of the greatest artists who ever lived, it features some of their greatest work. There are iconic images of Cromwell and Sir Thomas More by Holbein, 2 very powerful portraits by Titian and arguably Rembrandt's finest self portrait. But for me the star of the show is the huge painting of Dieppe Harbour by Turner. It is simply awe inspiring. The art is displayed to show each piece to best effect. Set in harmony with fine furniture, sculptures and porcelain within elegantly designed rooms, the collection must surely be one of the most sumptuous in the world. Forget the pretentious splodges of paint at MOMA. This is proper art. There is creative vision in the compositions and technical skill of the very highest level in order to bring that vision to life. And I do mean life. The artists represented here don't just paint what they see, they paint what they feel. Such is the artistry, that in viewing these pictures we then sense the very soul of the sitter. And as for Turner's "Dieppe Harbour" - just WOW! There is more vision, creative genius and technical accomplishment in this one painting than in all the works in MOMA.

OMG when I gazed at the self portrait of Rembrandt it was so beautiful and moving I cried. The Frick collection was amazing! I enjoyed it more than the Met. All the masters were displayed in beautiful large galleries. It was simply stunning! A must go to for art lovers!
Imagine Being Mr. Frick. Imagine not being able to sleep, and coming down to your living room at 3 AM on a winter night in the early 20th century to look at your art collection. Wow.

The most amazing small museum in the world. Crack open any art history book and you will find the Frick inordinately well-represented.
Three Vermeers! That's almost ten percent of his known output. Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Turner, El Greco, and many more grace the walls of this splendid Fifth Ave mansion. Frick himself may have been a robber baron; but he did have taste.
A beautiful jewel.. Not huge like the Metropolitan, but such incredible art in a small space. The house is also a work of art.

Outstanding art collection in a marvellous house. If you like European art from the 17th and 18th centuries, this is the place to visit! Each room is filled with furniture, paintings, ornaments which make the Frick Collection so different than a usual museum. At the same level of perfection as Nissim de Camondo's house in Paris.

Amazing collection!. What an amazing collection this family had! It is a small museum in comparison to many, but on view inside are some surprising finds! It also is not as crowded as some of the huge museums. The cost of admission is high for the amount of time you spend there and that you can't take personal photos of anything, but it supports the museum, and they do have one day a week Sunday that they have a pay as you like day to help make the museum accessible to everyone.

Favorite NYC museum.. This is an amazing collection in a unique setting. You can see it all in a few hours and the free audio guide give background and insight into many of the special works of art. Located on the east side of Central Park on 70th street it is easy to get to. My wife and I have visited this museum many times and see something new with every visit. Well worth the time.

Amazing. So impressive, shouldn't be missed while in NYC. I want to go back and will asap. They show a great video of the history of the man that created this amazing museum, the man had great taste....

Hidden Treasure of New York. Nestled in what feels like suburban Manhattan (if there is such a thing) and shadowed by central park, the Frick collection offers a peace and tranquility which was thought to be an alien concept in New York City. Meandering around the collection it has the air of viewing a late Victorian plantation house rather than a museum. This collection is for art lovers rather than the casual follower with mesmeric pieces by the great masters. Quality over quantity. Recommended.

beyond expectations. I've visited many art museums around the world, but this is probably one of my favorites. It is a small but remarkable collection displayed in an unusual way in the Frick mansion on Fifth Avenue. I don't know that I've seen art displayed in such a personal way, and it is a fabulous collection. The works of Vermeer, Rembrandt, Holbein, El Greco, Renoir, etc., were stunning. The interiors are also beautiful in their own right, and showcase the art. The room with the El Greco, Holbein, and Titian paintings may have been one of the most beautiful rooms I've seen. It was not especially crowded, and the audio guide included in the US$22 ticket was a nice resource to have. The film on H.C. Frick was also good for background. After the Met, I'd put this at the top of the 'must see' museums.

Favorite New York Museum. This is wonderful. Just the right amount of quality art showcased in a former estate, along with an exquisite porcelain and other collectible collection. Loved the three Vermeer's. Pick up the free audio to enhance your experience. Takes a couple hours to really listen and appreciate the artwork. This is better than MOMA and Whitney and just a shade above the Met because of its intimacy. Not to be missed.

A Delightful Jewel in New York. A wonderful way to spend a couple house enjoying art in an exquisite setting. The collection of Henry Frick is world class - set in his beautiful home. Best to visit in the afternoons - when the crowds tend to be smaller. Do not miss this beautiful museum.

Great collection. A great collection housed in an early 20th century home, you are able to get a taste of the lavish interiors of that time. The collection houses a number of famous artists amassed by the collector and despite being small, there are a variety of different mediums presented.

Great collection, excellent ambience. When trying to hide from most of tourist traps while seeing great art and enjoying your time, Frick collection is one of the best places to be. Alas, Frick was no fan of impressionist art, hence you'll see very little of it.

A Less Crowded but Excellent Museum. The Frick is both a museum and a look at a turn of the century Manhattan mansion. The collection is excellent, it's not packed with people and the rooms are beautiful. An excellent diversion.

In a city of museums - this is still ma favourite. Part of enjoying the Frick is being able to cast your mind back to the early 20th century and appreciate what this building and this collection mean. You are walking through a family's house. A half city block of Manhattan facing central park. A mansion - built when a NYC mansion was truly a mansion. The art collection is very nice in absolute terms - spectacular in the context of being amassed by a single collector. The central pond area on a Sunday with your copy of the Times de rigeur for the full experience.
A gem. This museum is a gem. A small collection, but filled with masterpieces. And the way it is housed gives it a unique charm and calm (compared to the overrun but incomparable Met).

Beautiful house and nice collection. The Frick Collection is a very nice private art collection with paintings and art works. The house itself is also magnificent with the all the decorations and furniture.

Really interesting to benefit a private collection. We visited today and we were amazed at what we found. This was a private house and you feel like you are in the life of the Frick family as you walk around enjoying his private art and treasures collection. You get right up close and personal with the Titian, Monet, Constable! Van Dyke and many other recognisable masters without overbearing security. The house is beautiful and a sight to behold and it will s full of history and treasures including paintings, furniture and pieces of art. An absolute must to see and experience.

A must see for art lovers. I was most impressed that this was a man's house. The architecture was amazing, both inside and out. On top of the beautiful design of the house, it was filled with great displays of art and furniture. It isn't as big as some of the other art museums, so I think we stayed about 2 hours. We enjoyed having the audio tour to help describe the art and furniture to us.

The greatest little art museum in the greatest city in the world. The Frick has a small collection but each piece is the best of the best. The Fragonard room is a delight, as are the portraits of the bellest belles dames in England in the 17th and 18th centuries, but to my taste, the Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell facing each other in the office are beyond compare.
Awesome smaller art museum . Not an overwhelming museum. This is great if you only have an hour or hour and a half. Great displays that are informative. Get the audio guide

One of New York's finest pleasures.. If you like great architecture, fine art, and all kinds of beautiful things, you'll love the Frick. It's not a huge place, and as museums go, it's different. Because unlike the Metropolitan, the huge museum just up 5th Avenue from the Frick, it's really a house, but what a house! The Fricks were super-collectors, and the house has been preserved much like they had it--their taste, and their treasures. H. C. Frick was a Pittsburgh industrialist, and he built this "Gilded Age" mansion at 70th St. and 5th Ave. to house his collection of paintings, sculptures, and bric a brac before he died--with his own plan to leave it for all to see. Yes, it was more than just a grand house, and was built with galleries for the family art collection, and what a collection it is: Rembrandt, Vermeer, El Greco--almost every big name in Gilded Age collecting. But the real appeal of a visit is to imagine living in such a place. Overall, the impression is light, intimate, and the rooms in the living quarters are highly decorated with art in the styles favored by the Frick's. I came away with an impression of lightness, delicacy, shown so clearly in the Boucher room. Obviously, Mr. Frick was a big fan of Francois Boucher, and that room is filled with not just wall paintings, but furniture, bronzes, and porcelains by Boucher, the French master of the Rococo. You can walk through and imagine how it must have been to live among these things, since these are the rooms where the Fricks lived and entertained. His vision of planning has given us a perfect example of a high-taste lifestyle during the Gilded Age---the architecture, the collection and even the furniture, rugs, china, and the rest. It's truly like going back in time, and my God, what a time!!

one of New York's gems. The Frick was the private home of Henry Clay Frick and his wife Adelaide that was made with the idea that it would one day be an art gallery... It is lovely... no! It is breathtaking from the moment one enters the foyer.. One feels like a guest of the family. The auto entrance was enclosed and has become a beautiful enclosed garden with a lovely fountain... one walks from room to room and through corridors where the incredible Frick collection is displayed... some in rooms that are exactly as they were in the Frick's time... I have been to several temporary exhibits there including a wonderful exhibit of Vermeer's work including The Girl with the Pearl Earring... One of my favorite museums... a minimum of 1-2 hours ... 3-4 better... free audio is great... would highly recommend...

Only visit here if your time in NY is not limited. I'm a member of the Frick but I would suggest that tourists only visit if they happen to be in the area and have already spent a lot of time at the Met. The Metropolitan is way more amazing and should not be missed!The Frick is a sweet, but quite small museum, and can be quite expensive to non-members, especially if an entire family is visiting.

small but must-see museum. wonderful collection of European "Old Master" paintings, also European sculpture and decorative arts. You can tour their collection online to help you plan your trip. Be sure to check the schedule for interesting lectures, concerts and events.

Small jewel of a museum. Wonderful exhibition of paintings in former home of Henry Clay Frick. There are also some temporary exhibitions from time to time. Definitely worth seeing. Traditional art, not modern art, museum.
beautiful place. It's small but charming. Don't believe Sundays the entrance is free. You will feel forced to "donate" something anyway but it's a nice and interesting place.

Sheer class and pleasure. A personal collection adds interest in selecting works in more individualistic ways than major public collections. This has a fascinating and comprehensive selection of works in a glorious setting. It was not so big that it becomes overwhelming and there is room for quirkiness. If you like this then also try the Phillips Collection in Washington.
Lovely smaller museum.. If you want to see a beautiful house as well as fine art and not have to wait in lines or deal with the regular museum crowds, go here. I love this museum.

What a delight. This museum is incredible. Its small enough to be accessible, and 2 hrs is enough to see most things. The quality of the art is fantastic- almost every work is a masterpiece. The building itself is beautiful and the Frick story is really interesting. A must.

The building is the star. As often is the case with me, I enjoyed the building more than the art inside it. Frick only lived here for about 5 years before his death in 1919, but filled it with fine art acquisitions by artists nearly every art lover has heard of. His collections of all sorts of art are likely without equal among private American citizens, and his daughter continued to add more stuff after his death. So even though his collections are not really to my taste, I have got to say that this site is excellent for the house itself and the breadth of what is on display inside.

One of the Most Underrated Museums in NYC. I'm partly hesitant to write about this museum because it is a great hidden gem. Surprisingly, not too many people know about the Frick. Most people fight the crowds at the Met and Moma (which is understandable because these two are amazing museums worthy of a visit), but the Frick houses some fantastic Flemish/Dutch works as well as from Rococo. It's laid out in a manageable and aesthetically pleasing way without unbearable crowds. If you just want a relaxing day at the museume where you can spend a couple of hours strolling through what seems like a real luxury townhouse in the Upper East Side and head to brunch afterwards, then this is the place. It's pay what you wish on Sundays from 11am-1pm so the timing couldn't be better for it.

Delightful!. This beautiful collection on the Upper East Side is housed in Henry Clay Frick's beautiful Fifth Avenue mansion which was converted into a public museum after the deaths of Henry and his wife Adelaide. It is an absolutely wonderful way to spend an afternoon, reveling in the beauty of the paintings, sculptures, furniture, rugs, and fixtures of yesteryear.

Hidden gem, a must for art lovers. On 5th avenue so easy to find, shows the collection of Frick which is truly astonishing. All the greats of pre20th century art are represented; Vermeer, Rembrandt, turner, well worth a visit. Good value as well, very low cost and personal compared to other NYC galleries.

Awe-inspiring. We recently visited the Frick Collection and it was, in a word, amazing. Henry Clay Frick, a self-made millionaire of humble origins, amassed a world-class collection of artwork in his Gilded Age mansion on Fifth Avenue, just across from Central Park. His preference seemed to be for 16th- and 17th-centruty pieces, although there were other periods represented. In addition to a huge display of oils, the collection includes sculpture, Limoges enamels and porcelains.As I left, I felt I was suffering from sensory overload. So much great artwork, so much to absorb, so little time.The collection is almost entirely of European provenance, with but two 19th-century American artists represented (including Whistler). I was personally most taken by the pieces by Goya, el Greco and Vermeer … your tastes may vary.The Frick Collection is a Don’t-Miss excursion, even if you have to skip the Broadway thing.
Very nice museum. Very nice museum with fine furniture and beautiful clocks. Admission is pricey but on Sundays, pay what you wish from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m.

My favourite museum.. For me one of the most memorable experiences of our trip to New York was the visit to the Frick Collection. It is absolutely superb and I cannot speak highly enough. The collection is fantastic and the residence is so peaceful and beautiful. My favourite!

A BEAUTIFUL HISTORIC MANSION.... We visited the Frick Collection with a group of friends from Pittsburgh. The Frick Mansion is architecturally beautiful. The art collection is extensive for a small scale museum. We all had a wonderful time.
Obscure must see art museum. Art patrons all know about the Frick. Many regular travelers do not. This is an intimate collection of art assembled by the former CEO of Carnagie Steele. Must see.

Lovely. The Frick is a lovely museum that can be covered in an hour to an hour and a half. I wouldn't recommend it for families with children or even most teenagers. I also wouldn't put it on my top ten list for a first visit to New York. That being said the Frick is a beautiful museum and perfect when you only have a short period of time.
Oasis near on Fifth Avenue.. It's lovely to walk through this mansion and look at the beautiful collection. Very relaxing to sit in the garden room with the fountain.l

Outstanding jewel of a museum. This is an outstanding collection of paintings, sculpture and furniture - much from the 1700s with a sprinkling of other periods. Other reviews I just casually glanced at say more on the basic outline of this museum, a former residence, so I'll just add my two cents. It's an incredibly worthwhile visit - just enough to satisfy, especially with the audio guide included in your admission. Sundays are Pay What You Wish from 10am-1pm so come early (though the line moves relatively quickly, at least for us). But for an art lover (or even someone who wouldn't consider themselves as such, but has a curiosity), the general admission price is well worth it. The Met is huge and takes several visits to really digest and so while the major museums of the world are fantastic to visit, there is something delightful about visiting a robust and richly decorated space filled with many notable works that can be adequately visited in a few hours. That being said, the Frick is the kind of place you could visit several times over and continue to focus on different pieces in deeper ways, discovering new little quirks and favorite pieces (or just visiting the rotating special exhibits). Do make a visit!
So glad a friend suggested this museum.. Old mansion was such a contrast to MoMa which I had gone to the day before. Beautiful art. Beautiful place.

Don't Miss This One!!!!. I adore museums. But I truly adore museums that are small enough to see in a two to three hour time slot and come away with a new view of art. This collection is one of the best in NYC and yet it is contained enough to be seen in an afternoon in a beautiful setting.

Incredible collection!. This museum was one of our favorites in NYC. Definitely not to be missed if you love art. The collection contains old Master and nineteenth-century paintings, sculpture, and decorative arts and is housed in a beautiful Indiana limestone mansion next to Central Park.

Beautiful gem of a museum. Although we have traveled to New York several times, we had never visited this beautiful museum collection. The mansion was built with the idea that the house would be converted to a museum showcasing the owner's lovely art collection. Paintings, sculptures, furniture, porcelain, books, are all represented--mostly 18th and 19th century. We especially loved the four large Fragonard murals, which have an entire drawing room devoted to, and decorated around them.

An exquisite art museum . The Frick is the personal art collection of a turn of the Century industrialist who donated his mansion and contents to the city. His taste was exquisite and the rooms reflect his sense of design. The Masters represented are remarkable - Goya, Rembrandt, Constable, Turner, Gainsborough, Degas, Monet, and the list goes on. Each is displayed in harmony with the other rather than by school. The paintings are complemented by sculpture, porcelain and furniture. The collection is broad yet intimate. This is one of New York's jewels.
Such an intimate museum. This is my favorite museum because the home setting - even if it is a mansion - makes it feel personal. The courtyard is beautiful and peaceful
Serene. If you are going to New York for some culture please go here. Well presented and the information given was superb

Nice Small Museum. When I went to visit the Henry Frick museum in Manhattan NYC, the paintings are nice, but it is the house and the building that I am interested in. My favorite is the fountain garden in the middle of the mansion.
Beautiful museum . Lovely collection, beautiful space. Some really important pieces and an excellent piece of New York history. Also a nice manageable size

A beautiful oasis in busy NYC. I was a member of a team who performed service at the Frick, so I got to see a lot more of it than is usally open to the public. I had the chance to meet some of the staff, and tour behind the scenes as they restore pieces of art. The house itself is so grand, so majestic. The furniture, lighting, rugs, and books set a beautiful venue to display so many masterpieces. I felt like I was stepping back in time, to a lost era when everything moved more slowly, with more luxuriance and opulence - when time was a precious thing to be savored rather than conserved. I highly recommend a visit

A "don't miss" for art lovers. I try to get to the Frick every time I return to New York, and urge any and all with an interest in art - and in New York City life the way it used to be - to make an effort to get there. The collection is small compared to the "big" museums, but that is part of the Frick's charm - the art is displayed to savor and not feel overwhelmed.

a beautiful collection, splendidly organized, superb special exhibits.. The Frick is a collection based on the collecting of a millionaire railroad entrepreneur named Henry Clay Frick. The permanent collection is superb, but one of the things that makes this museum a must-visit in NYC is its special exhibitions, which are superbly curated, balancing just the right number of art objects with just the right amount of explanatory text labels and catalogues. This is a memorable museum in every way.
Stunning private collection. Wonderful and intimate art gallery, very easy to spend the afternoon just gazing at the art. A fantastic collection of some of my favourite artists. Highly recommended :)

Beautiful and intimate spaces.. Visited the Frick to see a Van Dyck exhibit. I hadn't been to the museum for over 25 years. I should have been visiting whenever there was a show of interest to me, because this is the kind of place where you can calm down and really focus on the art. And I'm no egghead, but I love to see art that I have come to know through reading or magazines, or art history classes back in the day at college. The bigger museums are sometimes to hectic-feeling, that it's hard to relax and enjoy. Not so, here at The Frick. There are many quiet spaces, and you'll feel as if you're actually visiting some very rich friend, who just happens to own a billion dollars worth of great art! This is a great place, and right off Fifth Avenue, so great before/after a stroll in Central Park.

Wonderful alternative to the MET.... but unlike The Met, no photos (even without flash) are allowed. The museum does encourage sketching, however, and I saw a lot of younger students setting up drawing stations. I wish I had grabbed one of the audio guides as it would have definitely been beneficial, what with the super quiet atmosphere in comparison to The Met and the number of displays that also included historical furniture. Shame the second floor was not opened to the public.
A hidden Treasure. This is a fantastic gallery, I could have spend hours just sitting, admiring the collection. In fact walked around 3 times in case I missed anything, Well worth it and a great find
An elegant oasis with artistic masterpieces. Look at the magnificent art collected by Mr.Frick.Rest in the quiet fountain court.It is a quiet, elegant oasis on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

Amazing Collection in the home of Gilded Age Baron. The collection brought together by Henry Clay Frick in his palatial home is a public jewel. The Veronese paintings - allegories featuring Hercules hold pride of place by the main doors in the principal viewing room. I love the Venetian school and these two are also my favorites but they are joined by Turners, a Velazquez and other masters. Moreover, the building itself abutting Central Park on 70th street is a Gilded Age palace. The central courtyard, the only place you can photograph is a beautiful space and a statement of late nineteenth century opulence. These are other paintings throughout the building. I was able to view a series of paintings focusing on 18th century military life by Watteau which was very interesting. Don't miss the Frick when in New York City.

Great place to visit. I enjoyed this museum because it had some very interesting stories to tell and the fact it was family owned. It is in the family home which makes it more interesting. You can Imagine what it would have been like when the family was living there. Another bonus is you don't have to pay extra for the audio visual machines which most places charge you for. Well worth a visit while in New York.
A Don't Miss Museum. OMG! This was one of the best art collections in the City. In addition, the furniture and room decor were beautiful. Small enough to see in a few hours. Should not be missed.
Just the right size. If you get easily overwhelmed by large museums like the Met, try to Frick instead for some stellar art and a sense of how the wealthy once lived on Park Avenue.

A lovely surprise. Having visited all the big galleries, this was the last on my list but probably my favourite. The house is interesting enough but the collection is out of this world! Make time to watch the film about Frick and the collection.
A great place to visit!. The Frick Collection is a wonderful collection. There are paintings by Van Dyck, Rembrandt and some great paintings by Whistler. Certainly worth a visit!

Collector's edition. The 'no photos unless you are in the garden' policy is a bit weird, but as soon as you step inside your attention gets pulled towards the art and the building and you get pulled into the experience. The room where all people in the artwork are children/youths was a first for me and worth the entry fee alone. Walk slow and let your eyes wander and you'll have a great experience in every room.

See this collection!. I went to the Frick Collection on Sunday morning as between 11am to 1pm, you pay what you wish. It is stocked with great art and sculptures in a beautiful house.Remember to take the audio guide which is free and tells you all about the art collection and the history of the rooms

Great historic building with anice selection of art.. Small venue as NYC museums go but worth an hour or so. Free on Sunday's between 11-1. Right across from Central Park so stop on the same day you visit the park.
A gem of a gallery. A gem of a gallery. Small enough not to be overwhelming but still offering a lot to see and enjoy. A must for anyone visiting NY.

Beautiful museum. If you have interest in Gainsborough paintings or just like good art, or want to see how a rich New Yorker lived and spent his fortune in the past, this is the place. And it is easy to find on the museum mile

The Best. I am convinced that the Frick is the best museum I have visited foot for foot. Each object is a treasure and speaks for the founder Henry Clay Frick. It is not an encyclopedic museum, but more on the order of a house museum which at the end of the day is the most enjoyable. i have been retourning for 30 years and have never been disappointed. The shop is exceptional, with items you will never find elsewhere. Don't miss the small quiet unassuming exhibits, the scholarship is exceptional. Five stars.

Fabulous!. My friend and I love art and have been interested in the Gilded Age. We were able to combine both of these interests with our visit yesterday to this wonderful museum. Since this was the lovely home of an Industrialist millionaire, the collection was intimate and intriguing in a personal setting. I kept imagining what it must have been like to get up each morning and take a cup of coffee and enjoy a Vermeer or Van Dyke! The informative video in the music room was very helpful as were the audioguides as neither of us are art experts. The women in the gift shop where also helpful in giving us ideas for a yummy lunch at the cafe in the nearby Asia museum. All in all, we both thoroughly enjoyed our day at the Frick and plan to return!
A treasure chest in Upper West Side. This collection is really amazing. What I liked the most is being able to wander in a private (and extra ordinary) home on the Upper West side.
Our Favourite NY attraction. . We loved this building and the collection within that was pulled together by the Frick family and left for all of us to enjoy.

Great collection in a great setting. The building housing the Frick Collection was built as both a residence and a museum to house the collection. It is one of the nicest art museum settings I've ever been in, with well-lit, wood-paneled galleries and a beautiful garden room.The collection has some great works from artists I've never seen in private collections and most American public collections, including several by Goya and a Velazquez. There are works by Monet, Rembrandt, Turner, Whistler, and Degas, and the famous painting of St. Thomas More by Holbein. Almost everything in the collection is before the 20th Century. There is also a collection of porcelain, some pre-Renaissance church artwork, some sculptures and ornamental clocks.The artwork is all of very high quality, although there is not a lot of variety - most of the paintings are portraits or serene landscapes and cityscapes. The collection is not that large, so you can see it all in a few hours.

Best small art museum in NYC. It is centrally located and just the right size. Budget 2 to 3 hours unless you are an art history or architecture buff in which case you could live there. This is the actual home of Henry Frick and his personal art collection. See not just the art but also the furniture and architecture. Note the number of fireplaces. Great place to visit. Just the right size.
Hidden gem. One of the less knows NY museum but a true gem. It is not as crowded as Met or others, and it has a beautiful collection of art, furnishings and sculptures.

Majestic. One of the most special and best, yet least known museums in Manhattan, if not the U.S. So beautiful, rich, and brilliant in every facet of its decor, architecture, history and art to be able to step into a former residence of opulence. This is a treasure not to be missed.

A glimpse into all things beautiful. This museum is awe-inspiring in its total commitment to beautiful living. The architecture, the interior design, the stairs, the marble hall, the manicured garden and exquisite courtyards, the wrought iron gates, the plants, the attention to detail that display clearly what good taste and abundance of wealth can achieve. And I have not even mentioned the exquisite pieces of art works. the Chinese porcelains depicting the interpretation of beauty of the time somewhat resonated tru out the museum. Goya,Van Dyke, Turner, Constable, Monet, Manet gathered in this mansion over looking Central Park.What is truly amazing is the viewer connection with these arts. Many are not enclosed by a show case. They lay bare for my eyes to enjoy, without any intermediary. Its rare to experience such joy. The moment when art, a true pure expression of beauty and a peasant like me meet. Exquisite. Say a prayer to the Fricks for their gift of making these stunning mansion and its content accessible. Inspiring for years to come.

Perfect atmosphere for some great art. I've always really appreciated the atmosphere (available to even us "regular folks") you can experience when visiting a museum that's a converted mansion -- that sense of intimacy is very calming/comforting. The Frick is top notch atmosphere and world class art. My review/advice: Go.

Favorite museum. Thoroughly enjoyed walking through this collection. Less crowded than many other museums. Very enjoyable to see the art collection along with other pieces of his stork furniture in this setting. Highly recommend as you can browse the entire collection in less than two hours.

An Intimate Gallery in a Historic NYC Mansion. Similar to the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia, the Frick Collection has some incredible and historic art displayed in the Pittsburgh industrialist Henry Clay Frick's Gilded Age mansion on Fifth Avenue. The museum features romantic and impressionist paintings as well as some amazing sculptures and time pieces. Claude Lorrain's Sermon on the Mount and Gilbert Stuart's Portrait of George Washington are definite highlights. The real unique feature of this museum, however, is the house and the architecture. Mr. Frick was an American industrialist who oversaw the Carnegie Steel Foundation, getting a glimpse of this home is like going back in time.

Private art collection near Central Park. Go there to admire the collections with a lot of masterpieces, but also for the building itself.It is a private collection with various artists of perido from the Renassance period to the 19th century.I really enjoyd this peaceful place, early on a sunday morning.

A Step Back in Time. Ever since I first went as a teenager with my dad, I've gone back to the Frick every time I'm in New York City. The art is exquisite are the furniture, carpets, and porcelains. Going through takes you back to a time gone by when fortunes were being made and those who could shared their love of art and fine things. The mansion Henry Clay Frick built was always intended to be a museum to house the collection. Go there; take a step back in time; admire the architecture; revel in the fine art!

Must See to Believe. Condense a great museum to its best and exhibit it in an unbelievably rich setting and you have The Frick. No googling half-known artists to see if you should who they are. Here it is Rembrandt, Bellini, Whistler, Rubens, Vermeer, Watteau. Masterpiece after preeminent work. So naturally displayed. Give this some extra time you will be rewarded.

Just The Best... I've visited The Frick just about every time I've been in NYC, and never fail to be impressed. To display such beautiful works of art in such inspirational surroundings makes The Frick an oasis of peace right in the heart of NYC. I will visit again and again, and would recommend The Frick as an essential stop for every NYC art lover.

Quiet, Cool - Unique. I am not a big Museum/Collection fan, but this was very interesting. The many, many pieces of art, sculptures, etc., and the fact that this place is both quiet, and cool in the summer, was a plus. You can get the audio tour for free, and stay as long or as short as you like. There are places within the Frick Collection to stop and sit, ponder and think, and just enjoy the space. It was not very crowded the day we went, so that was a plus also.

Lovely Collection. This is a house that was built for Mr. Frick (steel industry) and then upon the death of his wife was left, intact, to NYC as a museum. The house and the architecture are very interesting and there are some amazing works of art in the house including some Fragonards I had not seen before. Sadly, they do not let you go upstairs to see the bedrooms and the rest of the house, which I would have truly enjoyed. However, It's not too big and can be done in an hour or so and well worth the admission; it's also only a short walk from there to the Metropolitan Museum of Art if you want to try to combine both in one day.

Treasure of art and architecture. The Frick was highly recommended to me by a friend who once lived in NYC. I now strongly second his advice. The house itself is well worth the trip just for the architecture and furnishings and the art collection with pieces by many of the masters is a cannot miss. The indoor garden was a pleasant place to stop and relax on a very hot and otherwise busy day in the city.

Well worth the visit. There were two interesting aspects to visiting this gallery: one was the range of Dutch/Flemish portraits of public figures from past centuries, several of them outstanding, and the other was the lovely, gracious home that the pictures are presented in. I felt I knew the Frick family by the time I left. The film in the theatre was informative, too.

Beautiful. The art collection is housed in a former mansion, the house its self is beautiful but the collections of paintings, sculptures and more are just grand. Children under 10 are not permitted though. If you love history and fine art this place is worth a visit.

What a gem. Beautiful collection of art in a small quiet museum. Felt like invited to someone's house to spend the morning admiring his art collection.  Not many visitors so it was nice and quiet and we just spent time understanding the paintings via the free audio guide. The garden court is peaceful and plenty of places in the rooms and around to rest and admire the exhibits.  The portico gallery had beautiful porcelain collection too.Do not forget the basement with the soldiers depiction. There are magnifying glasses just on the right of the entrance to the room to enhance the details of the tiny defined drawings.

My FAVORITE place to go in NYC. The Frick is SO amazing - This beautiful Estate is a gift to all man kind. The Estate itself is a work of Art. Then here comes the BONUS and I do mean BONUS!!!! There is hundreds of beautiful Art and Beautiful Painting's and Collections. They have a soothing indoor pond and fountain. The Gardens are BEAUTIFUL. Everything about this place is BEAUTIFUL! I'm in Love
Private Collection. It is and exquisite private collection, an amazing library, I recommend the indoor fountain for a moment of meditation.

Delightful small Museum. The Frick is wonderful. Located in a beautiful mansion with lovely gardens and great exhibitions. You can stroll through Central park and then enter the museum. They have some amazing paintings in their permanent collection. Works by Rembrandt, El Greco, Goya and so many more artists in their 16 galleries. Perfect for a museum visit when you only have an hour or two.

Relatively small but stunning exhibition.. This may be one most underrated galleries in the whole New York City.Housed in a beautiful old residence, the collection is amazing and well worth spending the about one hour that it will need.

A gem not to be missed. Stumbled upon this as we walked past. We'll worth going to,? It is a beautiful,private collection with Numerous famous artists featured. Includes some antique furniture fit for a palace and lovely porcelains.
house and art collection. A friend recommended this to us.Fabulous art collection with an audio guide provided with each ticket.The house alone was worth the admission!
Must see!!. I loved this kind of wonderful exhibition of art and architecture. Really a enjoyable visit. The mansion is amazing and the collections are great. Must visit!

A gem. There is more extraordinary art per square inch in this museum than one is likely to find in 99% of the world's great museums. Because it is compact, you can savor every last work and marvel at what you have seen for years to come.

reverse psycology. This is irrelevant but also true. The Frick is probably too good for you. Yes, the level of taste is so high, 99% of average people would have no idea what they were looking at. It is incredibly boring for the disney crowd. One of the finest museum collections in the world.

Fav museum in NYC. Reasons it's my favorite = it's like a time capsule b/c you get to see how Frick lived during America's Gilded age. Fantastic and interesting architecture + original furniture. PLUS the paintings! Frick was an original collector and has tons of Eng art (Gainsborough, Turner!!, HOGARTH!), Northern Renaissance (Bruegel bros, Vermeer, van Dyck), Renaissance (El Greco, Goya). You can also spend 2 hours here and see if all without FOMO.
Gem. One of the most intimate, terrific and charming gem in the city, with a great collection, truly a treat not to be missed!!!

Wonderful Architecture and extensive Art collection. This museum is a must see. If you go on a Sunday between 11:00 AM and 1:00pm admission is pay as you wish. So, if you are on a budget while visiting NYC you can enjoy the beautiful home and art at a great price. An audio guide will provide you with background of the owner, the home and art. Allow yourself about 3 hours if you want to listen to most of the audio guide. After visiting 3 other museums, the Frick Collection was my favorite.

Magnificent. A great art collection which is quite impressive. More interesting than most of other museums on the 5th avenue. Staff were equally knowledgable and eager to help. The atrium is just superb!
The best small sized museum in NYC. The old masters and especially the Vermeer are a must see while visiting NYC - Entry fee but worth it- Great gift shop with unique items worth purchasing

Exquisite museum not to be missed in NYC. The Frick is in my view the finest small art museum in Manhattan. The variety of exhibits and the décor wondering through the rooms and wonderful patio of this once private house is really an experience. The diversified collection of Vermeer, Van Eyck, Rembrandt, Klimt , El Greco, Van Gogh, Bellini and many many more is simply breathtaking!

Amazing small museum. The Frick is fabulous and well worth the admission fee. The building itself is a piece of art, and the collection is wonderful. Small and easily done in 2-3 hours, you can see a small collection which includes Vermeer, Rembrandt, Manet, Monet, Degas, etc. Really beautiful. Definitely pick up the free audioguide - it has great information and is easy to use.

Frick'n Awesome. Some museums might beat the Frick in breadth but it is easily the best place to relax and contemplate art in the whole city. Refusing to categorize it's art by time period, the Frick encourages you to wander around and look deeply at each work you see. Attend any of the "talks" you can as well as Summer Nights. Both are great/easy ways to learn about art at the Frick and share in it with others, too.

Small but stunning collection. We were walking from the Metropolitan Museum and decided to stop at the Frick, which we've enjoyed a few times before. It is still impressive and well worth a special trip.
Watteau's soldiers are a joy to see.. This is one of my favourite museums in the whole world. I never miss a chance to pop in when I am in New York City.

A jewel of a museum. If you are in New York, definitely put this on your list. The modest size of the museum gives intimacy. The collection is spectacular. Don't miss the Vermeer--and other treasures. Would definitely suggest audio tour.

Amazing collection - beats most major art galleries!. The collection is remarkable in its scale and quality - some wonderful pieces of art alongside sculptures and furnishings to create a wonderful atmosphere in this "private home collection".
Just look up the list of exhibits on line - you'll be amazed.
And if you visit on Sunday, you can pay as much as you want for entry.
Great organization. The gallery is perfectly organized and the paintings collection is very rich. It was pure pleasure being there.

Beautiful Museum. I thought this place was really great. It's not as crowded as all the other museums in New York, and there's some great art there.
