I thought it was a little expensive for a ticket, so if you have a student ID don't forget it. It's not very large, so you won't need much time to get through it. The building itself is a beautiful work of art, so definitely recommend this if your in New York.

Perfect Size with Children. This is a small museum and I think worth going to - not only for its artwork collection, but for the design of the building itself. It is the perfect size to go to with children without them getting bored too quickly and not big enough for them to complain how much longer they have to be there. I look forward to going back!

A Time Machine. Walk though the doors of this magnificent private home from the Gilded Age, and see exactly how one of the fabulously wealthy (i.e. Henry Clay Frick) lived, 100 years ago.His art collection is staggeringly beautiful, and it is wonderful to see it all in the original domestic settings.The Fragonard Room is justly famous, but everyone will find some art to please them here. This is a very relaxing and soothing place to visit.
A museum gem. This is a wonderful museum. There is an impressive collection of fine art in a beautiful setting.We really enjoyed spending a relaxed couple of hours here.
Fine private collection . Small elegant collection in a private home. Easy to digest. Very interesting history of the man himself. Just as if wandering through your hosts home.

A peek into the Gilded Age. This has been my favourite art museum in the world ever since I lived in Manhattan from 1996 to 2000. It was a regular stop on my walk home from work in Midtown to my apartment on the Upper East Side.The collection is primarily composed of the personal collection of Henry Clay Frick--a one-percenter of the Gilded Age. The collection presents an eclectic range of art from the early Middle Ages through to the 19th century. The Hans Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell are particular favorites of mine--glaring at each other across the fireplace in the Living Hall, as is Mistress and Maid by Vermeer (of which a character in a favorite film once said, "There's more painting going on in this corner than all of Soho combined."The collection is not overwhelming in the manner of the Met, and is invariably calm and quiet. The team of docents are knowledgeable, enthusiastic and friendly.
Not just a great museum. The Frick is one of the most majestic former private residences in the city. The architecture of the building alone is worth the trip.

Amazing how rich people live. Beautiful museum showcasing the Frick collection. The library was beautiful and the courtyard was beautiful and relaxing. I could just live in that room. The collection of paintings are beautiful and the presentation is done well. The audio sets are a must so you can hear in detail information about each picture. Some paintings are missing the codes though, would be nice if they were updated.
The Best Museum. Frick has got the best of the best (but that's only my opinion) amazing art and building definitely worth a visit. Wouldn't go to New York and not visit this place.

An art museum I can appreciate. I was very pleasantly surprised by this, it's a mix of an art and history museum, which I love. I'm more interesting in the history of a place, and historical figures. A lot of the art highlights that. Also, I've always wanted to see a 5th avenue residence, and this is about as close as I'll get to seeing the inside of a 5th avenue mansion back in the day.The art includes paintings, furnishings, and the building itself. It's also relatively small compared to some other museums so you don't have to devote a whole afternoon to it (although you certainly could if you wanted.)

A Delight. The Frick Museum is one of the greatest delights in Manhattan. It is a wonderful collection of art in a delightful setting. An oasis of peace and tranquillity in the heart of New York. A particular surprise was to discover a work by the British artist George Romney who is buried in the churchyard at Dalton in Furness in Cumbria, my home town.Every time I go to New York I find myself drawn to the Frick and it never fails to delight.

My favourite museum. Lovely house full of outstanding art. No crowds, quiet, no kids under 10 allowed. An oasis in the chaos of Manhattan and well worth the time and money. The audio tour was free and quite entertaining.
One of my favorites. The Frick is one of the few museums I enjoy returning to. It's a quicker walk through than most, but it's a beautiful building.

I wrote my master thesis about the most powerful families in the USA: Rockefeller, Frick, Vanderbilt, ..... In 1983 I wrote my master thesis about the most powerful families in the USA, e.g. the Rockefellers, the Astors, the Vanderbilts, the Waltons, the..., the FRICK family.In 1985 after I finished my studies of engineering and management/ business at a German Technical University, I travelled my first time to NY City.I worked half a year for training as a broker (stocks, options, bonds, commodities, financial futures) at one of the Wall Street giants.I lived half a year near to the Grand Central Station, and I enjoyed to vist many interesting places in NY City. One of my favourite places was the Frick museum.After my broker licence in 1985 I travelled all over the USA, I didn't work as a broker, but worked as a management consultant in Germany.I fell in love to USA and I have visted USA several times in the last 35 years. Whenever I'm in NY City I enjoy to visit again and again the FRICK collection.It's really worth a visit! I strongly recommend it. You won't regret it.

A great find, art collection with a difference.. Was told about this by a friend and it was brilliant. Amazing private house with amazing artwork but the house itself is as much the showpiece as the art. Stunning rooms with beautiful furniture. No photos except at the internal garden/pond area which is fair enough.

Pre-eminent small art museum. Visited the Frick Collection, an art museum located on the Upper East Side in Manhattan, New York City at 1 East 70th Street, at the northeast corner with Fifth Avenue. It houses high-quality collection of old master paintings and fine furniture housed in six galleries which are the private collection of industrialist Henry Clay Frick. "The Frick" is one of the pre-eminent small art museums in the United States and we paid what we could afford as we visited on a Sunday between 11 am to 1 pm, otherwise had to pay 22$ standard entry fee which is a little steep!

Wonderful exhibits. There are always special exhibits on display, which enhance the permanent exhibits.Currently, Jean-Antoine Watteau (1684–1721), who is known as a painter of amorous aristocrats and melancholy actors, painted a number of scenes of military life. They were produced during one of the darkest chapters of France’s history, the War of the Spanish Succession (1701–14), but the martial glory on which most military painters trained their gaze held no interest for Watteau. Instead, many of these paintings and drawings reminded me of Goya, who painted some of the most iconic scenes some of that terrible war.As usual, the Frick also has a number of special discussions by experts both during regular hours and during the evenings.

Art and History. Loved it! Well organised. Use the free handsets. Provides great insight to the history of the art and rooms. Simply stunning. Broad range of art. Rooms retained in original state. No photo's permitted in the museum, although one can take a photo in the central courtyard - no selfie sticks. This limitation suited me, as it enables one to enjoy the art. My favourite To Do in NYC!

Beatifically organized: Art and Archtecture. The building itself is special because was planned to be a residence and a museum. The pieces of art are organized in the rooms that keep the original display, which bring a special flavor to the visit. Besides, the artworks are top quality, from XV to XIX centuries.Get there walking trough the Central Park to enhance the experience and enjoy the visit.
Exquisite. Deftly curated. This collection can be seen in under 2 hours. Even a one hour visit will yield a feeling of happiness and beauty that lasts as you re-enter the bustle of Manhattan.

My favorite museum in the world. The Frick offers an accessible collection of some of the great masters in a setting that is both serene and interesting in and of itself. It is never crowded, allowing the visitor to sit or stand and enjoy each work of art in a peaceful atmosphere. A free audio tour really brings each object to life as well as explaining the use of each room during the time that the museum was used as a residence. The house (which was the residence of American industrialist Henry Clay Frick) is beautifully outfitted and features a large garden court where one can sit and read. The individual rooms contain furnishings from China, France, Italy and elsewhere -- all of which only enhance the beauty of the masterpieces on the walls. Because there are 18th century Chinese porcelain sitting on tables and bookshelves, children under 10 are not permitted. I was delighted to return to NYC this summer with both my children over 10 so that I could take them to my favorite museum in the world.
A Must See in NYC. Fabulous collection and an absolute treat to be able to see it all in such a beautiful setting. If you're in New York make sure you allow a couple of hours to go to The Frick.

Must see. If you have only a couple of hours to explore museums, this is the one. It gives you some history, great pieces of art, and all together you get the feel of how people lived around the late 1800s/early 1900s. I was so impressed with Mr. Henry Frick that I bought a book about him.

Splendid looking house with great contents. Situated opposite Central Park this opulent mansion houses a wide collection of artwork which is still set in a residential mode. It has a beautiful courtyard which gives a sense of tranquility. Worth a peek into the way the wealthy lived in the early 1900's.
nice collection for art lovers. nice collection, small though .. but worth visiting.. grab your best friends and enjoy a nice relaxing day full of art .

Spectacular art, special Van Dyke Exhibit. This private room/art museum is always a plus. We have been fortunate enough to catch special exhibits so be sure to see what they have that is not there all the time. The furnishings are exquisite and the paints are ALL stunning. Not a lose in the whole place. The courtyard is a charming place to stop and enjoy the ambiance.
Nice Collection. Above average collection of art that is available for a slight fee. Nice way to spend an hour or two in New York.

Amazing private collection. Great collection of mostly European painters in the private mansion of a coal baron. You can spend several hours here -- not as overwhelming as a large museum. Highly recommend, they have some Rembrandt, Van Dyke, Goya, and others. They also have two beautiful Whistlers.

Lovely small collection. this is a small museum located in what was once the home of a very very wealthy person. His own collection is there. This small palace has a tiny pool, lovely places to sit, and great art.
great collection. there is a great collection there, but just to go and visit the building it is worthwhile. it is easy to get there and if you like art you must go there.

amazing. It is amazing how New York was in old times. Mr Frick is one of the "rich" who loved art. You can see New York life thru Mr Frick's eyes, but don't misunderstand me. It is not his art, it is art he collected while living in NY. Hard to believe NY had such people around at that time.

Historial and art gem for folks over age 10. The Frick is both a house and an art gallery - note that children under 10 are not allowed. This is understandable due to the unique arrangement - all furnishings are as they were and one can walk anywhere on the first level. The most serene part of the building, the courtyard (and the only place photographs are allowed) was actually open air and not part of the original home! Take advantage of free audio tours and free talks that provide more historical context for this Gilded Age mansion.

A "small bite of art" in the BIG apple. At times Manhattan and all of of NYC for that matter can feel rushed and cramped...and meanwhile, this is a museum where I felt at peace...it is a restful and serene space--and the garden is especially lovely to visit in the late Spring/early summer. This is one of the "lesser known" NYC museums, but certainly not to be missed!

Sight Seeing. This is a must see unique museum which contains an impressive private collection of art. An ideal place to escape the hustle and bustle of NY and cool off in the hot months but the items and paintings displayed are exquisite.It will require a lot of standing since there are only a few exhibition rooms with seats.There is not photographs allowed except for the beautiful central courtyard.

Beautiful collection of art. I really enjoyed seeing this collection of art and glad we were able to squeeze in some time during our itinerary to make it here. Only downside is you can't take photos of the collection, the only place photos are permitted is in the garden court.
Great museum!. We came here on Sunday when there is "pay what you wish' day and this was my second time in this museum. It's worth visiting and it's not too big, so you won't get tired here.

Quiet Opulence in the Lavish 5th Ave Mansion. This museum is much as the home Henry Frick built on a full square block across from Central Park. Lavishly decorated period rooms and an impeccable private art collection. Enjoy the splendid isolation from the bustle of Manhattan as you pad across expanses of Persian rugs on creaky wooden floors in these otherwise silent rooms.

A gem. A unique place which gathers Master pièces in a beautiful mansion on 5th Avenue. Each painting deserves attention. Each room provides emotion.
Allow 2 hours for a complete visit.

One of the best!. My husband and I loved the Frick. We used the audio hand-held device and it was very easy to use and informative. The building is gorgeous. If you don't know much about Mr. Frick, you will want to after a visit to this impressive museum.

BEAUTIFUL BUILDING WITH MASTERPIECES. The Frick is a beautiful former home on museum mile which houses some world famous art by Vermeer, Renoir, Turner etc. If you are an art lover this is a must see.

Gorgeous mansion with gorgeous art. The Frick Collection presents a wonderful video that introduces Mr. Henry Clay Frick the collector and industrialist, and how his magnificent collection came to be. Highly recommend that you watch this video before you tour the museum, just to give a perspective and a greater appreciation for the art. Stunning masterpieces that are presented in a much more intimate way in the setting of a private home, rather than laid out in typical museum fashion (genres, schools of art, etc.) Note: no children under ten are allowed and Sunday mornings from 11-1 allow 'Pay as you wish' admission, so it is naturally much busier at this time.

Most of the masters and an orderly, confined and quality experience.. I would strongly advise visiting this collection and within a two hour time period you would feel like you got the entire collection in your visit. The hand carried devices allow the visitor to hear and understand all of the major works and are simple to operate. It is a must see and much easier than spending a day at the Met (which is also well worth the time if you have it).

Who doesn't love the Frick?. Every time I go into the Frick, I want to go back in time, put on a gown,, and relive the golden years in NYC. The collection is magnificent, the house and grounds are delightful, and there is some new "aha" with every visit because you cannot see everything the first time. If you've been there, I don't need to tell you to go back. If you haven't been there and love art, it's a must.
Jewel in the crown. What a collection!!! The museum is not too big, just the right size to give you the opportunity to enjoy the wonderful collection.

A different experience. I have been to a lot of museums but this was a combination of learning about a way of life and having the opportunity to see some amazing art and collectibles. One of the best features was the audio recordings that described not only the piece of art, but how and why it was collected, or where it was placed in the house originally. The stories were fascinating and then add in the stunning paintings by Rembrandt, Monet, Manet, Constable, Turner, etc., I prefer the impressionists, but was still in awe over the beauty and size of the Dutch painters and others. Also, the size of the building is a bit more achievable in an afternoon compared to the Met.

Excellent private museum on Central Park . Frick is a gem. Gorgeous mansion on Central Park with excellent art collection. Not crowded. Must see for art lovers!
Will go back again.

Beautiful building. I really enjoyed viewing the art and properties at The Frick. There is a small theater showing a 12 minute biography of Mr Frick himself. I found this able to make my visit more knowledgeable about the history behind the collection. Highly recommend for a 30 minute visit.

Amazing Museum in a private home.. A beautiful way to display such wonderful and impressive artwork. The home is magnificent and all the furniture and décor is original. Each room has an incredible range of paintings and sculptures and the natural light enhances the works. A special museum in wonderful New York City.

Bizarre Museum. This is the by far the srange state museum I have visited and yet I am always drawn here again and again. It is said hat family members still live above this museum and I would believe that to be true nothing quite like this place
Overwhelming art collection. In this museum you con see how the rich and famous lived. Everbody must have a hobby. But collecting rembrands is a whole different level. Glad to have seen this.
It is different. If you like residences where people lived their lives, where you can feel the past, this is right place to go👍

If you love art, this is a MUST!. I would rate this as one of my all time favorite things to do in NYC. Seeing countless priceless works of art in an actual "home" (a mansion, rather) is just mind blowing. It was amazing standing in a room with several huge Rembrandts, Gainesboroghs, and the furniture...I can't say enough!! Even as a lover of modern art, this collection and it's significance was highly enjoyable. I loved hearing the history of the home, the family and how these pieces were acquired. The Fragonard room was breathtaking! Don't miss it!!!!

Gorgeous. This is my favorite museum in New York City thus far. The Frick Collection brings a bit more to the art appreciator than other museums or galleries in the city. There is a more personal and elegant touch to how the art is presented. Much of this has to do with the architecture of the building itself and the way each room has its own feeling and ambiance. You must see this place and fall in love with the art it holds and the walls that keep them up. Please also do not forget to sit in the beautiful garden area with the fountain to relax a bit.

Down load the app. The Frick collection’s app has information on more than 1000 works of art; they have free Wi-Fi at the Museum so you can down load it there. Remember to take your earbuds. This is a delightful Home, full of beautiful arts works; it is not overwhelming like the Met, We went on Sunday as they, have pay what you wish form 11am to 1pm, the queue was along 70th Street and 5th Ave it took about 20mins to get in. The place had a very relaxed feel.

A wonderful way to experience art. I have made the Frick a stop on every trip to New York. Somehow it seems like I am dropping by and old friends lovely home. That is if my old friend with an extremely wealthy 19th century industrialist. I love how the art is presented, it seems so accessible. The courtyard is a very special place.

Fabulous Experience. Loved visiting The Frick, the home itself is a wonder as much as the art located inside. It was kind of sad no photos allowed, but it was also nice to not seeing folks snapping constantly. A must see in NYC, even if just one time, to see how they lived in the gilded age of new york.
Classy Collection. This building is one of our favorites. Lovely architecture and nice collection make it a pleasure to visit.

Magnificent!. This should be on everyone's To Do list. I was entranced by both the paintings and the building. The collection is astonishing - far better than the Thyssen-Bornemisza museum in Madrid. One great work after another. And the setting, oh my goodness me, the setting. What a fabulous afternoon, and thank you to Mr. Frick for leaving it to the world.

Lovely collection. This is a lovely collection! The Frick family started amassing their collection in Philadelphia and eventually moved to its current location in NYC. Over the years Frick collected hundred of pieces from the medieval era, Baroque era, Rococo era, and Neoclassical era. In his will he left it to the city of New York and eventually after his widow passed, it was converted into the museum it currently is. When walking through The Frick, you view the pieces in each room of the Frick household as it was when they lived there. The architecture of the rooms is very much in the Victorian era and you go back in time while walking through. While I was there, there was a very small porcelain special exhibit. It was nice but very small and not a reason to go visit the museum, unless you are very into porcelain. There is a GORGEOUS garden area with a fountain in the middle. It's really peaceful and a lovely spot to just sit back and relax a bit. Insider tip: there are outlets right below the benches if you need to charge your phone. This is also the only area in the museum where you can take pictures. This is a pricer museum but they do have senior and student prices. It's worth coming to once when in NYC.

Little Gem. This museum is formerly the home of Henry Clay Frick, one of the great industrialists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It is filled with beautiful furniture, excellent paintings and sculptures, and some very lovely enamels. In addition, there are beautiful interior and exterior gardens. The architecture of the building itself is also a work of art. Perhaps one of the nicest things about this museum is the fact that it is not overwhelming. One can spend a very pleasant afternoon taking in the entire collection without worrying that you missed something.

The perfect size for a museum!. I'm surprised that the Frick isn't well known for all the amazing art it houses. A short walk away from the Met, this place is very charming and very doable if you only have a couple hours on your hands. The pieces are laid out over a single floor, and that makes it easy to walk around and take everything in. The central courtyard is breathtakingly beautiful! If you're in the city and looking to kill a few hours, this is the place to go! And since it's right across the street from Central Park, you can also go there before/after. Definitely recommend it!

Wonderful Art. We enjoyed the house with it decor and marvelous collection of paintings. Many important artists are represented in this collection. The audio guide is well worth listening to as it not only mentions the art but the rooms and the context of their use at the time Mr Frick lived there.
A relaxing oasis in crowded Manhattan. The Frick is wonderful. So much to see everywhere you turn. No crowds, no rush , no baby strollers. Best art museum we've seen.

Quick Museum Visit. If you are in the museum area and don't want to wait in a long line at either the Guggenheim or the Met, then this is worth checking out. The entire museum can be leisurely walked in about 1.5 hours and has some neat art with a cool covered courtyard in the middle.
A Real Gem!. Special, approachable museum with an approachable collection. Architecturally and historically a beauty. A hidden gem on the upper East Side.
Beautiful collection.. We popped in to escape the polar vortex happening outside, and were pleasantly surprised with collection. The audio tour was extremely helpful while navigating the facility.

More like a gallery than a museum. It's a very small place comparing to other museums in the city. It feels like more a gallery than a museum but if you enjoy antique european paintings and furnitures then you will still love it here. It is not as crowded as the other museums so that is a plus. It is 'pay as you wish' for the first two operating hours on Sunday if you want to save a few bucks.

A perfect small museum. My wife and I visited the Frick Collection during a recent vacation in New York City. We wanted, in particular, to see the portraits of Thomas Cromwell and Thomas More by Hans Holbein, but we spent a couple of hours admiring the many other beautiful works of art: paintings, sculptures and furniture.As the guide book notes, the Frick Collection is not organised by theme or era, but rather, each room contains a mixture of styles and kinds of art which nonetheless form a harmonious whole.

A Gem. If there's such a thing as a 'boutique' museum, Frick Collection is it. It is very serene, soothing, invigorating all rolled into one. Good place to be inspired by the artworks and not be bothered by the crowds.

Wonderful Small Museum. This is a wonderful spot to visit for an hour or so...or of course to linger longer. The collection is beautifully curated and just the right size to be able to take it in without being overwhelmed. Don't overlook this gem!

A trip into the Golden Era. The Frick is a wonderful collection and was once the home of Henry Clay Frick. When you enter the grounds it is like stepping back in time. At the Frick you can stroll through the common rooms of the house and see masterpieces by artists such as Renior, Rembrant, Boucher and Goya as well as decorative arts and exquisite period furniture. Some of the larger museums can be daunting but you can see the entire Frick Collection in an hour-two hours. Looking at art in the setting of a home vs an institution such as a large museum is an experience you should not miss.Tip: there are only 34 known paintings by Johannes Vermeer and the Frick Collection has three. If you cross the street and walk up to the Met you can see 4 more. That is 7 of all the Vermeers' in the entire world in an 11 block section of fifth avenue!

More interested in the house. The Frick Mansion is my main reason in going here. The artwork, though interesting and had famous artists, was not my main reason. I did enjoy viewing the art though. The exhibit at the time I visited was Van Dyck portraits. The house itself was great. I could only imagine how living there was like. I was disappointed that the upstairs area was off limits. Not sure though if the area is not available to the public year round. It would've been so nice to climb the stairs and see the bedrooms also.

Fabulous House Museum. We love "house" museums and have visited some really great ones, like the Jacquemart-Andre and Nissim Camondo in Paris, and the Borghese in Rome, so were excited to visit the Frick. We arrived in time for the short docent introduction which was a fortunate happenstance as she gave us background and details we wouldn't have otherwise known and fleshed out Mr. Frick and his family. We toured each room and listened to the information on the audio guide which was well done. We loved this museum. It is beautiful maintained like when Mr. Frick and his family lived there. He collected wonderful works of art (including 3 Vermeers), furniture, decorative objects, even books. It's an outstanding museum; we look forward to visiting again on another trip.

Fascinating museum.. Reasonable cost to get into this museum bequested to New York by one of the city's benefactors for the appreciation of art in all it's forms.Smaller than the blockbuster museums and it could be visited in a couple of hours. But there is so much top class material to experience. All are masterpieces of whatever medium is presented in this private collection. Whether it is painting ,pottery,furniture in their appropriate room settings or statuary. Expect to see only the best. Apparently Mr Frick was a ruthless business man but he had a taste for only the highest quality art that the world had to offer and he made incredible purchases for himself and future people to appreciate. He bought half a block in New York to build a house and gallery to store and exhibit his collection and made sure that they would survive after his death by making sure sufficient funds were available to secure and even add to and improve his gallery Go, see,discover and be awed by his legacy!

Not just an art collection. We visited the Frick collection mansion on a pay-what-you-wish day and never regretted it! Not only is the art collection magnificent, but the mansion itself is a wonderful piece of art and history. Enjoy!
Incredible house & collection. Visited with my 80 something parents. What a treat. Thoroughly enjoyed the audio commentaries and collection of master paintings. Not crowded on a Wednesday morning.

A beautifully curated and presented art collection which is unforgettable. Recommended by a friend to seek out the Frick Collection on my recent visit to NYC this lovely gallery set perfectly in a repurposed mansion on the outskirts of Central Park. We went on a warm Sunday in June (pay what you want when you enter between11am - 1pm) and found this oasis just the place to feel calm and be transported to a time past. The extensive selection of artwork and statues is delightful and happily situated for perfect viewing and enjoyment. The gift shop is lovely and please note, unlike many galleries these days, you cannot take photos.

A Pean to the Golden Age. The only question one is left with at the end of the visit is - Which is a bigger mind blow - the building or its contents. The Frick, fronting on Central Park, is a living testimony to days gone by; when captains of industry, unfettered by unions, government regulators or conscience, created, lived, and defined the American Dream. Dedicate two to three hours to visit the stately residence replete with Rembrandt, Fragonard, Holbein (senior and junior) and hundreds of other artists of varying degree of importance and fame. The art is very well curated and when you're done ogling the oils take a break to visit the courtyard. The reflecting pool and surrounding statutory is grand but as a fan of orchids - spectacular.

Must visit. I would say this is a must visit place in Manhattan.The building itself is a beautiful architecture. Their collection is astonishing. van Dyck, El Greco, Rembrandt, and others. And three paintings by Vermeer.

Outstanding Collection. We went on a Sunday which is "pay what you want" rather than the normal $20 fee. As a result, there was a half-hour wait on a nice Sunday morning. The wait was worth it as we saw a beautiful collection in a amazing building. Get the audio tour--it's very helpful.

An absolute must do for anyone who loves art. The Frick collection is a great size needing only 2hrs to view it, more if you have the time. How one man could collect so many wonderful pieces of art is phenomenal. If you are interested in history he has the original Hans Holbeck portraits of Thomas Cromwell and Sir Thomas More. Amazing

Mind blowing. This is an amazing collection. There are pictures in the collection that are so familiar it was really interesting to know who owned them. I can highly recommend this collection and I would add that for anyone interested in how mr. Frick managed to be one of the richest men in the world and was able to buy these incredible pictures, drop by the museum shop and pick up a copy of the book titled "Meet You In Hell" which tells you the full story and just to warn you - it isn't a nice story. The collection is one of the best museum visits in New York in my opinion.

A New York gem. The Frick Collection is a gem hidden just below the radar of the large names of art galleries in New York City. It's amazing. The experience rivals some of the large galleries in Europe, not due to its size (which is not small), but rather due to its history and intimacy.I loved the fact that this was the private collection of a New York resident, in his home, where he lived. It gives you a glimpse into life at the top of the pile in those days, but the art is the real wow factor.It's clear that the collection was a deeply personal one, and one can only imagine the deep meaning that each work carried for the family.What I love is that this gallery is "just enough" - not like some others where the art is overpowering. This strikes the perfect balance between quality and quantity.
Outstanding collection of art. This was recommended to us by a friend and it did not disappoint. Wonderful collection of art and sculptures in an historic mansion close to Central Park.
A beautiful mansion with beautiful art. This is a wonderful museum, both for the art works and the mansion. The old masters are especially nice. It is such a nice change from the huge, crowded MET.

Forgotten gem on the Upper East Side. Once the private mansion of Henry Clay Frick, a coke and steel baron, this charming museum houses Frick's own collection and pieces that have been added since his death in 1919. While the Met, MoMA, Guggenheim and other museums are often crowded with visitors, the Frick always seems to be less crowded and provides a calmer venue for appreciating its fine collection. There is an excellent audio guide which is included in the admission price. Don't miss the enclosed atrium garden which was added after Frick's death.

I love the Frick. The Frick is a museum that should not be missed in NYC. The museum houses a lovely collection, but what makes this so special is the beautifully historic space that it is shown in. The garden room is one of the most peaceful places in the city. The museum website is worth perusing prior to the visit to enhance your appreciation. This posts times for docent talks, which are well worth taking the time for (they are free with admission but may be limited in size).
The Best. We loved this museum. It is a fabulous collection.Very well done and user friendly. The setting is a home worth seeing all by itself.

Frick is a beautiful visit. We were advised to visit the Frick Gallery when in NY and very pleased we did. The building is absolutely lovely in its own right and the exhibition was also much enjoyed. We arrived early and had no problem with queuing.
A Wonderful Collection and Building. A wonderful building with a more personal collection than the Met. Visit on pay-what-you-like days will save you a bit if you like.

Great for European Art. I love the Frick Collection! If your into European art, particularly within the past few centuries, then you have to check out this museum. It's in a lovely building with a tonne of beautiful painting, both well- and lesser-known.
The House itself is worth a trip. This is our favorite small museum in New York. Great collection , and wonderful house to see how the Guilded Agers lived.

I loved this place. I not a great art fanatic, but even I was awe struck at some of the painting in this collection.The highlight for me was the Turner's 'The Harbor of Dieppe', however there are many great paintings to suit all tastes.This was my favourite gallery of the ones we visited in NYC.

Interesting. The Frick Collection is a smaller museum and therefore has its own appeal. It has some well known painting by the greatest European artists, major sculptures, furniture and artefacts on display.

An undiscovered gem. If you are short on time, skip the big museums and visit this little jewel. We loved the Van Dykes and the Vermeers. The garden court must be one of the most serene spots in NYC -- the perfect place to find some solitude in this 24/7 city.

WHAT A COLLECTION OF ART....MUST SEE. Per Trip Advisor recommendation we made a point to attend this museum on a Sunday when the price is whatever you feel you want to contribute, however, expect crowds, but the art is unbelievable for a private collection. Be sure to watch the movie before viewing the galleries for a great history of the collector.
Incredible collection. Highly recommend. Incredibly, history, art and architecture. Loved the free audio tour-really added to the experience.

Great hidden gem. The admission price is a bit high. The art collection is impressive and the architecture is lovely. There weren't many visitors while I was there on a Tuesday afternoon. Worth a visit.
Frick Collection. Wonderful museum. Well worth going to see. We had lunch at the museum restaurant which was excellent and the service was superb.

Small but potent. The Frick museum is definitely worth a visit. We made a special visit to see it and came away very pleased we had made the effort. It is small and doable in a couple of hours. Visitors carry a device that allows them to dial in a number associated with a piece of artwork. That little extra made the trip all the more worthwhile. You won't regret detouring through this wonderful attraction.

Appreciating great art. Attending the Frick museum was our friends idea but so glad he knew about it. Learned about great art pieces displayed in the home of Mr Frick. He left a legacy of beautiful art in his home in New York. Several ways were available for hearing and learning about each piece displayed. There is an app for your iPhone or an audible guided tour was given to you as you walk through this beautiful home. Plan for at least three plus hours. You can take a break across the street at Central Park. Re entry during the same day is permitted. There are kiosk locations for lunch or a snack just outside the park. Bathrooms and a gift shop are also available in the Frick museum. There are three beautiful gardens. One is located in the center of the museum. A theater location provides times through out the day providing information and history of the Frick museum. Staff also provides group guided tours periodically.
Historical European Art. Beautiful building with a great collection - just note that its very small and that they dont allow photography!

My all time favorite museum. This museum is breathtaking. I love the architecture as well as the collection. It's not so big, so you can really spend time with the art without feeling you have to rush around to see everything. You really feel like you're going back in time. The gardens are nice to just sit and relax during a busy sight seeing day.

a beaiutiful mueum with terrific art collection. Don't miss this jewel of a museum. It is not very big , but the quality of the art work exceeds anybody's expectations. They have 2 Vermeers that I know of, and many , many more masterpieces.. Don't miss it when you are in New York.
Well worth a visit. The building is beautiful and the artwork is stunning. It is worth a visit even if you only have a couple of hours to spare, but it warrants longer if you have the time.
Beautiful. Lovely elegant house and a good collection of works of art, very well displayed. Worthwhile going to see .

A must see for any art lover!. This exquisite house museum is filled with some of the most well known paintings and sculptures in the world. In addition, the house itself is furnished with wonderful antiques, so in every respect this is a must see for any art lover. Hands down my favorite museum in NYC and one of the best house art museums in the world. You can also see the entire house in three hours, so it's not overwhelming.

Wow, wow, wow. There are few art galleries set out to give you enough space to see works of art at their best, normally because there are too many people. This was just fantastic. For a private collector to have had such art to live with is incredible. As good as any gallery anywhere in the world - with works of art to justify that comment.

Exceptional!. I tried three times to visit here and I'm so glad I persevered. Being a frugal traveller, I try to avoid museum fees first time around if possible, until I know it's worth it. Many museums/galleries in New York City offer 'pay-as-you-wish' times and The Frick's is every Sunday from 11am-1pm. When I arrived at 12.30pm on a rainy Sunday in May, the line was already wrapped around the building and I was worried I'd miss out, but, thankfully, I made it with five minutes to spare. Once you're in, you can stay until closing and I nearly did. This is an absolutely amazing personal collection amassed by a man who had excellent and eclectic taste. He even purpose-built the house knowing it was going to be a museum after his death. Strict 'no photography' rules apply.TIP: if you download the free Frick Collection App, you can use their free WIFI to navigate and listen to the audio tour.The Frick Collection is worth the full fee and I very highly recommend this attraction in NYC!
Very special museum. Small, elegant, and well curated, this is a special experience. The home of one of the "robber barons" who had the good taste and money to collect extraordinary pieces of art.

Great little museum. Wonderful, small museum located in the upper east side of NYC. Easy walking distance to our hotel and other museums (Breuer, Met,..) Great collection of European art from the 14th to late-19th century (including several Vermeers, Rembrants, Bouchers,..) and even a Duccio. They also had special Van Dyke exhibit that was worth spending some time with. The free audio guides were helpful and I would highly recommend them; even with listening to most of the narration you can complete a visit in a relaxing 2-3 hours. Relatively uncrowded. Small gift shop but no restaurants/coffee shops located inside.

Fantastic audio guide for a beauty of a gallery. What a nice discovery! This beautiful find makes me miss NYC a lot. The audio guide was particularly well done and the house housing the collection is just wonderful. Nice internal court yard should one wish to rest. A pity no restaurant or cafe in the museum. It would bring the whole into a whole new experience
Fun to see. If looking for a different place to browse, this museum is nice. Its not overwhelmingly huge, enough to see in a few hours.

Wonderful collection and a peaceful ambiance. Have gone frequently to this oasis on the upper east side of Manhattan. Has a couple of Rembrants and Vermeers hung in relatively small space. I like to just go a sit and relax and soak in the art!

Don't skip it. It seems I always head for "the biggies." I decided that this trip I'd head for the things I'd skipped before. If you only take one trip to NYC and you are near Central Park don't skip the Frick. The collection is outstanding and the museum is just beautiful.
A miniature Versailles. Beautiful, easy up close access to priceless and magnificent masterpieces and other works of arts in a non crowded elegant setting - this is fabulous.
A Must Go. Absolutely worth going! A small museum with excellent quality painting and fine furniture. The grounds are beautifully manicured and we had thoroughly enjoyed our visit!

The most amazing thing I saw in NYC. The Frick is gob-smacking in its quality, variety and beauty. The house and gardens, including impressive covered courtyard with marble fountain would be incredible enough, but the art! There is one of everything, an example of every tenant of human creative achievement in the western tradition. Porcelain, old masters, etchings, impressionists, Dutch masters, British Masters, Italian Masters, Spanish Masters, French Masters, Italian Masters, religious icos, gorgeous furniture and interiors. Impressive Van Dyke retrospective was on

Robber Baron home and collection. This home belonged to Henry Clay Frick, contemporary of Andrew Carnegie. It's a collection of art, architecture and fine items which show how wonderful life must have been for the Fricks. The beauty of the collection is that it is arranged largely as it was when he lived there. There was a special exhibition in the lower floor as well. Rather than spend the day in the Met (which is also wonderful), spend a morning or afternoon here and see how the art and architecture and priceless objects were actually displayed in a home where the occupant/collector lived. I've been several times and continue to enjoy this gem. You could get there on a bus or by cab and then walk leisurely to the met or through the park.
Truly unique. I believe that if there is one gem museum not to miss in NYC it is this one. Each time I get back to NY, I try to visit and feel again this unique space and art collection.

Jewel in the city. We read about this on our last trip and decided to check it out. Definitely worth a few hours of your day. I would recommend taking a docent tour over (or in addition too) the audio guide for a more comprehensive understanding of Frick's collection. It is a lovely way to spend an afternoon. Then walk over to Lex and 75th to EATS for a beverage and a meal.

An historical gem of a museum. A more low key gallery compared with the extensive and arguably more important collections in some of the better known museums but the charm of this collection lies in the location in an former mansions on the Upper East Side - giving a glimpse of an unconverted property and early 20th century living for the wealthy industrialists in NYC. Go just for the building.

Wonderful!. The Frick, which was once a private home, has a magnificent collection of paintings. I never realized that some of my favorites- Holbein's Thomas More or Bellini's "Saint Francis" were there. A must see in New York.

What a fabulous museum!. We sent several hours exploring this mansion very close to Central Park and had a lovely time getting to know the artist work's. Every room has a wow factor that leaves you glad you took the time to learn about that room or that artist! Wonderful time!
Wonderful House Museum. What a great small museum full of masterpieces....not for little kids but an absolute must as a visit to NYC and not as big as the Met so easy to do in an hour or so....

Fabulous and exexpected. Did not know that this would be so wonderful and have so much to offer. We went principality to see the Vermeers but were happily looking around for much longer than expected as there is so much to see. Holbein for instance - both Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell's portraits! Fantastic.

Pleasantly surprised. On a recent trip to New York while walking to around the Central Park vicinity, my husband and I decided to visit the Frick Collection. We are so glad we did. This was an incredible art collection for the size of the museum which was once Frick's home. There were Gainsborough, Monet, Van Dyk renderings individuals of the period, done in beautiful colors. Recommend to anyone looking for a museum experience that can be done in a couple of hours or so.

Wonderful!. This is a great rainy day activity or on a good day walk through Central Park to the museum. The building alone is worth seeing! I would suggest seeing the film to hear the story of the museum. The exhibits are breath taking and the enamel exhibit is beautiful. Also you can visit the Met which is close by! If you are there for any of the lectures or activities be sure to go.
the bomb. If you want to see how rich industrialists lived, and what awesome plunder they got on their walls, this is the place. a great way to learn a lot about new york city.

Inspiring Collection of Fine Art. For art and architecture afficiandos, The Frick Collection must be added to your New York City iteninary. Before visiting The Frick, a reading of Henry Clay Frick's biography is helpful in understanding this complicated man. Both revered for this collection of fine and rare art and reviled for his business tactics, the contradiction is striking when considering the gift of the The Frick Collection by Henry Clay Frick.We were lucky to visit during the Van Dyck Exhibition and view the sketches and paintings of Van Dyck in the lower level, including self portraits, and we enjoyed a guided tour of the Van Dyck Exhibition. Afterward, we were inspired by the vast works of fine art collected by Henry Clay Frick, including Monet, Renoir, Vermeer and many others.Check the website for special events you may be able to attend or events causing the closing of the museum. On Sundays, there is a period to enter in the early afternoon at no cost. On the Sunday I checked, the Frick was closed and not to reopen until Tuesday. Fortunately, our schedule allowed the Tuesday visit and we enjoyed an educational, instructional weekday visit. Several of the paintings were on loan from other museums. Photography was allowed only in the garden court and photography was not allowed in any of the other rooms or galleries. Photos of the garden court fountains, sculptures and tulips in the outside gardens captured a memory of this extraordinary collection. Very highly recommended.

One of my all-time faves!. Incredible to believe this was someone's home- Henry Clay Frick. The central courtyard is great for sitting. Film about Frick & his collection runs frequently. The Van Dyck Portraiture exhibit is phenomenal. Great gift shop too!

Perfect way to spend 2 hours. If you do not have time to appreciate the Met, but love art from the Impressionist and pre-Impressionist eras in Europe, this is the museum for you. Several Vermeers, Monet, Goya, Rembrandt, Cimabue - all the big names are here, and because of the lack of crowds, you can spend as much time as you want with each painting. The beautiful setting enhances the experience.

A superb mansion full of superb art.. A wonderful experience if you like art. Not too crowded, we bought our tickets there. One drawback - you can't buy drinks or food there so we had to go out to have lunch. We were able to return afterwards.

Quality all round.. I popped in here with my son as we were passing, the place is full of high quality art, Degas, Monet, Manet, Gainsborough, Watteau, Van Dyke, and even 3 Vermeer (rare as less than 20 worldwide), to name but a few. The attractive dark haired lady at the gift shop till, then told us all about the bowling alley down stairs, which was in the film Let there be Blood, which made the trip much more interesting for my son. I could have sat down for dinner with her and listen all night, but we had to go !

Elegant. You must see the house that Mr Frick had! Great ambiance for quite an extensive and impressive collection of paintings. Well cared for paintings and showcase. Lots of antique home furnishings as well. Beautiful indoor garden. Many Van Dyck paintings. Recommend highly. Not crowded
Old Maters. Large 1900 mansion full of large famous great European paintings especially van Dyke. Needs 4 hours.
Early bird gets the worm. If there's an exhibition going on, and there usually always is, get there early. Check out weekend concerts.

Amazing Collection - Allow plenty of time!. Sure, see the MOMA, The Whitney, the Nueu Gallery, BUT dont forget to go the Frick - the collection is truly first class and set in a classic 5th Ave mansion. We only allowed coupe of hours - what a shame we needed at least double the time.

Excellent collection of paintings, furniture , inside a very impressive house. You need to be interested in art to fully appreciate the Frick collection. I downloaded the app prior to going which was a real bonus, as it not only described the art/ furniture, but rooms and relevant history of how the collection was established. Not all art was on show however( no Whistler's currently) . Amazing to be able to get so close to the art work. No photography allowed of art work.

Good for a couple hours on a weekend afternoon. Sweet museum right next to Central Park. Stopped by for the Van Dyck exhibit, which had some really interesting portraits. A nice surprise was the painting of Sir Thomas More, which looks much more impressive in real life than it does in a textbook.

Very Interesting Private Art Museum. The art collection of Henry Clay Frick is exhibited in a residential setting amid the furnishings of his opulent mansion, which provides a glimpse of how the extremely wealthy lived in New York's golden age. It is an exceptional group of painting and sculptures from the Renaissance to the early 20th century. Frick died in 1919 and his daughter converted the home as it was always intended to a museum in the 1930"s. It features Manets, Monets, El Grecos, Goyas, Van Dykes, Turners, and at least one Rembrandt self-portrait. I confused Holbein's famous portrait of Sir Thomas More with similar portrait of Erasmus. Frick himself was (nearly) as interesting as his museum. Frick (1849 –1919) was an American industrialist, financier, union-buster, and art patron. He founded the H. C. Frick & Company coke manufacturing company, was chairman of the Carnegie Steel Company, and played a major role in the formation of the U.S. Steel Co. He also financed the construction of the Pennsylvania Railroad and Reading Co. and owned extensive real estate holdings in Pittsburgh and throughout Pennsylvania. We remember him from the PBS TV special.In 1871 Frick, invested family money to acquire low-priced coking fields and build fifty coke ovens. Within a decade, H. C. Frick Coke Company would operate some thousand working ovens and produce eighty percent of the coke used by Pittsburgh's burgeoning iron and steel industries. Shortly after marrying Adelaide Howard Childs, in 1881, Frick met Andrew Carnegie in NYC while the Fricks were on their honeymoon. This lead to a partnership between H. C. Frick & Company and Carnegie Steel Company, the predecessor to U.S. Steel Co. This partnership ensured that Carnegie's steel mills had adequate supplies of coke. Frick became chairman of the company. Carnegie made multiple attempts to force Frick out of the company they had created by making it appear that the company had nowhere left to go and that it was time for Frick to retire. Despite the contributions Frick had made towards Andrew Carnegie's fortune, Carnegie disregarded him in many executive decisions including finances. He was a lifelong opponent of organized labor, and his refusal to allow union workers at his mines led to the infamous Homestead strike of July 1892, in which ten men were killed and sixty wounded. The same month, Frick himself was attacked in a failed assassination attempt by a twenty-five-year-old Russian anarchist. He cabled both his mother and Carnegie: "Was twice shot, but not dangerously."Frick had started to collect paintings seriously in his late forties and began to focus on his collections even more after his move to New York in 1905. In 1913, construction began on Henry Frick's New York mansion on Fifth Avenue costing nearly $5,000,000, including land. Frick died in 1919. In his will, he left the house and all of the works of art in it together with the furnishings ("subject to occupancy by Mrs. Frick during her lifetime") to become a gallery called The Frick Collection. He provided an endowment of $15 million to be used for the maintenance of the Collection and for improvements and additions.
Another must see. Agree with the others amazing collection of different art and decor, interesting life story of Mr Frick. Wish there was a way to see the entire residents.
gem of a museum. Our favorite place when you know you have limited time and want to see a special exhibit OR the collection. Its mostly on one floor and never crowded. The Van Dyke was spectacular.

A 'must see', and conveniently located next to Central Park. You get two attractions in one in this mansion turned museum... all a methodical plan by industrialist Henry Clay Frick who had an incredible passion for collecting fine art. Considering some of the masterpieces that you'll see, not to mention the architecture, it's well worth the $20 entry fee. Take advantage of the headset tour (part of the admission price) and plan on spending at least 2 hours here. I recommend that you start by viewing the film that covers Frick's life and how he came to amass this great collection. Make a day of it and wander over to Central Park when you're done or beforehand. The entrance near 70th Street is one of the more interesting areas of Central Park including the boathouse where you can have a casual lunch or cocktails outside or in.

Amazing collection... to be enjoyed without walking miles. A concentration of fine art in a beautiful setting. This collection of the finest of fine art includes some wonderful Gainsborough, Rembrandt (including a beautiful self-portrait), Whistler, El Greco... Be amazed as you pass from room to room at how many fabulous works are housed in this relatively small villa.

One of a Kind Museum!!! A Must See!!. I was unsure of what to expect from this landmark that I'd heard so much about but I could not have had a better experience. This is one of the most intimate art museums I've ever experienced because it's literally in a home! This is both an art museum and a history museum as it's in a pristine Gilded Age mansion. There aren't enough words to explain how much I love this place. YOU MUST GO!!

Great building and art collection in one place. Plenty of interesting artwork on display in a beautiful setting. The building itself is worth the entry price alone with wonderful masonry work in the central courtyard and the staircase areas. The free audio guide tour is comprehensive and well worth making time for.

Beautiful, such an amazing collection. If you like your art then you must do this. It's a real gem of a gallery and whilst less well known than other NY galleries it was my favourite by far.Housed in what was Henry Clay Frick's home, built especially for his art collection this beautiful Victorian mansion is lovely in its own right, but with the collection of masterpieces it really is amazing. Expect to see works by great artists such as Van Dyck, Titian, Holbein, Gainsborough, Hogarth and Vermeer.. the Hans Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell glaring at each other across the fireplace were beautifully placed and a real privilege to see. As a Tudor history geek I felt a little emotional by them! As well as paintings there are vases, bronzes and porcelain to see. All beautiful and well curated. Make sure you get the free audio guide, which whilst a little flowery sometimes are very informative and as there are not info signs on all paintings is invaluable.Staff weren't as cheerful or helpful as in other places I have visited, they were efficient in managing the queues, if a little abrupt and noone directed us to the audioguide, we had to find them ourselves when we noticed other people using them. Don't let that put you off though, it's still very much worth seeing. We arrived just before opening at 11am on the Sunday and there was already quite a queue, and as there is limited space we noticed a few people waiting outside when we left for people to leave before they were allowed in. Again, if you have to queue it's worth the wait!

Favorite museum in NYC by far!. If you're going to make time for one museum in New York, the Frick Collection is it! The architecture of the house itself is stunning, not to mention the furniture and the incredible art pieces. Still blown away when I think back to my visit and recommend it to anyone who goes to NYC.

An intimate collection. The Frick Collection is housed in what had been Henry Clay Frick's New York mansion. (Frick was a Pittsburgh industrialist in the coke and steel industries and a partner of Andrew Carnegie.) As a result, the collection is both the personal gatherings and furnishings of Mr. Frick as displayed in the public areas of his home and later acquisitions and physical renovations that followed the conversion from home to museum.this is a rather intimate personal art collection and certainly not on the scale of a major museum like the Metropolitan Museum. But, it does showcase the wide range of art interests of Mr. Frick. It is a very worthwhile visit.
My new favorite . The residence turned museum is spectacular. Full of priceless art. Small enough to enjoy all details in one afternoon. Great documentary. I most definitely recommend!

A Must Do for art lovers. We attended the Frick on the 'free entry' Sunday ticket. Normally, entry costs twenty dollars but this would still be excellent value. The house is magnificent and takes up a whole block opposite Central Park. This used to be Frick's home and you can still get the feeling of it having been one. The layout, organisation and information is outstanding but this is nothing to the pictures, sculptures and porcelain. The history is amazing and the indoor garden must be seen to be believed. I'm not into art as a rule but I would revisit this magnificent museum time and again. Brilliant.
Nice, quiet place. After the insanity of Times Square it was nice to come here and wander around in the cool, quietness of this museum.

Beautiful paintings in a beautiful home.. This is your chance to see art as it was meant to be seen. This beautiful home from the "golden ages" of railroad magnates and monopolies has been preserved, along with the art collection of the former owner. Both the art and the home are remarkable and worth the price of admission. The audio tour is included with admission and offers a ton of information - definitely make the most of it!

One of the Highlights of our Trip . I owe a big "Thank You" to the TripAdvisor contributor who warned that the Guggenheim rotunda was closed when we planned to visit & that it would be better to go to visit the Frick Collection instead. That turned out to be fantastic advice! Our group of four adults loved everything about this museum including: the beautiful mansion that would be worth seeing even if it were empty, the impressive art collection & furniture attractively displayed in every room, the relaxed/uncrowded atmosphere (we went on a Friday afternoon after a morning walk around Central Park), the manageable size of the museum (you can see it all in a couple of hours), the lack of crying/bored children (children under ten are not permitted in the museum), the free coat check (note: no beverages/water bottles or photography allowed in the museum - leave all your stuff at the coat check), and the tasteful selection of items in the gift shop including unique items such as scarves & mugs inspired by artwork in the collection. There is also a special exhibition of artwork by Van Dyck that is worth seeing. I highly recommend The Frick to anyone who loves artwork, old homes and/or architecture. Make sure you pick up the audio tour to get the most out of your visit.

Two For One!. The great thing about the Frick Museum is you get to see a Mansion that the rich and powerful lived in and you get to see an amazing art collection. Every room is filled with the Old Masters. Rembrandt, Titian, Van Dyck and Gainsborough. Beautiful pieces of art at every turn in an intimate setting. I enjoyed the Frick Museum way more than the Metropolitan Museum of Art. I would definitely recommend this museum for the art lover and the art novice.

Favorite art museum in America. This is by far the most unique and special museum in America. To walk through the home and see the collection takes you back in time and has you feeling like you're a guest at a party. From the furniture, to the room decor your eyes were pleasantly surprised the entire time.

Beautiful and tranquil. I popped in mainly to see the two original portraits of Sir Thomas More & Cranwell. OMG I was overwhelmed with the magnificence of these two portraits facing each other. Being a huge Tudor period fan I was so touched that this American Industrialist should have the foresight to bring them together. Even though I think they should be in a London gallery they were in one if not the most beautiful collection I have seen. It is a fantastic place and a moving account of one mans vision. Thank you Mr Frick!

Don't leave this one out of your trip!. A shame on me. I left the Frick Collection out of my NYC trips for a very long time. Only to realise that I was so wrong. If you're on a very tight schedule and don't have the time to visit the Metropolitan or MoMa, head here. You'll be thrilled by the amount of incredible masterpieces maintained in this relatively small space. A no-brainer.

Gorgeous!. A meseum in a gorgeous mansion setting. The art work is amazing with my favorite being Monet's Vétheuil in Winter. My teen recognized immediately that a James Bond moving had been filmed here.
Worth of visiting. Visited here with my wife. We had only litlle more than an hour and that was absolutely not enough, two hours is minimum for this place.
Transported to a Different Time. If you don't have a lot of time in New York City and would like to soak up New York History and amazing collection art and antiques the Frick House is a must

A Dream Come True. Having wanted to go here for years and having it all live up to my expectations was a likely a tall order but it was met. On a family vacation my daughter and her husband came with us for this visit to the Frick. They are modern artists interested in installation and photography and I am an art historian of the early Renaissance. Our tastes can be worlds apart but here we were all thrilled by masterpieces set in a fabulous mansion. While staff were not warmly welcoming or overly helpful, they were coolly proficient. Easily the highlight of a less than stellar vacation in New York.

exceptional museum collection. In a city with a lot of museums of all types, I love the Frick the best. Small enough to go in an see the collection and any special exhibitions (this past one was Van Dyck and was interesting as it had both original sketches and the finished paintings) without committing too much of your day. You feel amazed that someone could a) be rich enough to have all these wonderful things and b) good enough to leave it for all of us to see. definite recommendation

Wow! 3 Vermeers, Thomas More and an extraordinary architectural gem.. This is an exquisite collection and setting. Surprise finds in every other room. I regret I only had two hours to spend. I would have lingered longer in many of the rooms, soaking up the atmosphere and imaging I was a Frick living with all that beauty and culture.

Beautiful mansion and great special exhibit. Went to the Frick to mainly see the mansion. The mansion is beautiful and worth the visit alone. They has a special exhibit on Van Dyke. It was well curated and I enjoyed it immensely. Unfortunately it was packed with tourist so I skipped the permanent collection. I am will be going back.
A world class art museum. Just the right size and with a tremendous collection of art. I appreciate small museums that are not overwhelming.

A visit to The Frick. I had the chance to see the Van Dyck exhibit at the Frick recently and it was wonderful. The paintings were first class. It was a bit crowded when I went but there were plenty to see if a particular painting had many people standing in front of it... you can just move to another and then come back. From the parts that are open to the public the Frick home is spectacular. I admired the wonderful rooms as I walked through time. For a sneak peek at what's there go to the website and take the virtual tour it's great. It is definitely worth a visit.
never disappointing. No visit to NYC is complete without walking into the Frick, Wonderful private collection of paintings not to be missed.

Frick Collectio. A jewel of a museum! When we went there was an exhibition of van Dyke's paintings, etchings and drawings. Together with the permanent items, this made for very pleasantly cultural experience.

Rating based on queue not collection. We decided to try and visit the Frick on Sunday morning - it doesn't open until 11am and this meant a huge queue wrapping round the building. My mum finds standing difficult so we sat on a bench watching the queue for about 30 minutes hoping it would decrease but unfortunately it didn't. I don't know if its like this every Sunday or at opening time but would suggest you avoid these if you can.My rating is based purely on the length of the queue and not on the collection as my Mum decided that she didn't want to go in.

A soothing respite of art, architecture, gardens, and light.. Whether there visiting for a special exhibit or to once again see the Frick Collection, one can be assured of hours of perusing that are highlighted by beautiful architecture, elegant family rooms from another era, and a desire to capture artistic joy for the ages.

Beautiful mansion with priceless art. I was expecting a museum and should have been more prepared! Clearly the Frick family had great wealth and were able to accumulate some impressive masterpieces. The exhibit is laid out well. Expect to spend about 2 hours perusing the paintings, sculptures and furniture of a family legacy.

A NY jewel. This is a fantastic Collection in a fantastic scenery.We didn't know so much about this place and we ended up there not really knowing the magic that was awaiting us!It's like going in the past and walking around Mr. Frick's fabulous residence expecting to meet him in one of the rooms!Independently from his fortune, it's amazing the taste of this man that put together so many fantastic works of art, all of a level of excellency.
CITY MUSEUM TRIP. Great building and wonderful art collection. Definitely worth a visit. Military gets in free and seniors are $15. A must see if you are in that area

Not to be missed. Definitely the best private collection, in the best location.
The house itself is amazing, and so is the art collected by the Henry Frick.
Sunday morning is pay as you wish.
I had only 2.5 hours, but could have stayed for one more hour.
Frick Yea!!!!. Gorgeous museum. I love to just sit and soak in the flavor. I feel like I am living in another time when I come here.
Perfect sized museum. Lovely surprise museum in an elegant mansion. Not overwhelming as the Met and still a good collection of primarily Western art.

Amazing house and collection.. Wow, its a must see and must to return to. I was a bit confused as to what you pay, as there appears to be a fee but you can really pay what you want. It is an amazing piece of architecture and interior design. The collection is out of this world. The security staff are a little bit over the top but understandable. No photos apart from in the atrium. A sign saying as much would have been helpful. Again was way too crowded to appreciate the artwork or the house, so a return visit it on my plans.
Top private collection. It is most definitely the best private collection of classical art in the world. Do not miss it if you visit New York City.

Sumptuous location and collection. Another museum not to be missed both for the robber-baron era building with fabulous interior court and the toppest-drawer collections. Don't miss the French Boucher panels.

Understated wonder. If you travel to NY looking for an opportunity to enjoy it's considerable art scene you are probably more familiar with the big museums and galleries such as The Metropolitan, MoMa or the Guggenheim and understandably so. They are fabulous institutions, absolute Titans of the art world although the first two are in a different league.The Frick is more modest in size occupying as it does one of the few remaining mansions from the so called gilded age in mid town Manhattan built by its namesake Clayton Frick. This collection packs an unbelievable punch as it displays the fabulous collection of classical works including Vermeer, Goya, Rembrandt and all set in the mid 19th century opulence of an industrialists mansion. When the thought of two days at one of the great galleries seems too daunting, take the morning and go to The Frick but whatever you do don't consider it a compromise of time or quality - it's neither and while art is so deeply personal it belongs in NY's top three.
Visit and Learn. Who ever heard of Frick? What a great story of one man's life. A true metamorphosis.A house/mansion/home that is beautiful adorned with art.

Something a little different. Very lovely house-wish you could see more of it! The gallery is lovely really and I would have liked to have seen some of the permanent exhibits but many were stored for the Van Dyck which was excellent but I had seen it already in Amsterdam! Still worth a visit especially to get away from the noise and crowds of many other city sites
Beauty and Serenity. One of my favorite places in NYC. The Court Garden is a place of beauty and true serenity. I could stay in that one place for hours, let alone all of the magnificent art.

A gem!. The Frick Collection is one of the best ways to enjoy an intimate view of high society New York lifestyle of the 19th and early 20th century. The collection of art is sublime, and it doesn't take all day to visit. My favorite painting is the Vermeer. Highly recommended!

Calm on Museum row. A beautiful personal art collection in a beautiful home ok it's a mansion. But it can be an oasis of calm compared to other museums in row. Like coming home to your own collection after a long day and just taking pleasure in what's on the wall. I've been here numerous times and never tire of it.

Stunning nothing le. Van Dyck exhibition going on - fits excellently into ambient of the Frick - lots of room to hang big portraits and yet still see smaller more in time panel of food too - a place to return to often ..

Good Things Come in Small Packages. The Frick is not a large museum. It does not overwhelm visitors with room after room after room of zillions of pieces of art (like the Met does). Instead, it is a collection of some of the most wonderful art in the world from Rembrandt to Gainsborough to dozens of others, every piece is a masterpiece.In addition to the paintings, the museum displays numerous statues and lots of wonderful furnishings. The best part os the free app that provides visitors more than they could ever hope to want to know about everything the museum offers. It makes a first-rate experience even better and will be a real asset to anyone enjoying the museum's impressive offerings.
A step back in time. Ever time I walk in the door, I fantasize that I am visiting my aristocratic aunt. The home and gardens are beautiful as is the art. My favourite gallery in NYC

A smaller and more manageable art museum. The Frick is a beautiful way to see some fine art without becoming overwhelmed by the larger museums. It is set in a beautiful mansion which is a sight to see by itself.
One of the best picture museums that I've ever seen.. Paintings of an enormous quality, without many people and in a very relaxing atmosphere. What a contrast with nearby Metropolitan!

Pure delight!. Please make every effort to see this superlative collection featuring Old Master paintings and other outstanding works of art from Europe. Situated on Fifth Avenue, the Frick Collection is housed in the former residence of wealthy industrialist Henry Clay Frick, and is now an important museum. The architecture, the interiors and the art collection itself are all magnificent. During our visit, we viewed an exhibition entitled: "Van Dyck: The Anatomy of Portraiture" which consisted of sumptuous portraits by Anthony Van Dyck. You will be transported by the beauty and grandeur of this wonderful collection!

A Hidden Jewel of an Art Collection. Set in the House of the paintings owner, he always had in mind to Show the pictures as a Collection. Walking through the rooms Looking at the Art i couldnt help thinking this is the Type of Art i Would have bought. What i mean is he bought what he liked not what was in Fashion. I spent a few Hours Looking at this Collection and thoroughly enjoyed it. People often miss this place going to the "famous" galleries but if you appreciate Art then go to the Frick Collection you'll love it.

Smaller than I expected. Beautiful house but it was smaller than I expected. Enjoyed my time and the views and the art. The reflection room (pictured above) was very tranquil and I wished I had more time to just sit in there and think.

An overlooked GEM. The Frick isn't as well known as the Met, Whitney and MOMA but do not miss this little gem in a beautiful building with a wonderful array of paintings and decorative arts. They have THREE Vermeers! Enjoy the beautiful courtyard for a few moments of rest!
They've also got one of the best mobile apps for museums around.

Tiny and Glorious Gem. Simply spectacular collection and housed in a beautiful mansion on 5th avenue. It is NOT suitable for children. The beautiful thing for me on my first visit was to see so many masterpieces that I remembered from my high school art history class. It's a special place and shouldn't be missed, especially if you are an art lover.

The Best Small Museum in the world. This museum was set up in the expanded former house of Frick, a very rich steelman from the 1920's. Every piece in the collection is the Best of the Best. If you visit only one art gallery in your life, make it this one!
Wonderful museum. So many wonderful paintings, furniture and artefacts all beautifully displayed. The Frick really does feel like a private house. We loved our visit and can't wait to go again

Wonderful museum. Loved this place with its extraordinary collection of the art of a variety of media and periods - it's easy to imagine this as a private collection, albeit of someone extremely wealthy!

Exquisite small mansion museum on Fifth Avenue. I love this museum. Thank goodness they dropped a plan to build out over the garden. As an art history major I always find the exhibits fascinating and the interior courtyard a peaceful refuge from the noise of Manhattan.

A look into the past of a wealthy NYC family home. My husband and I so enjoyed touring this home/museum. The art work and architecture is so beautiful and it was a family home that occupied a city block. A unique museum that gives one a look into the life and luxuries that one family accumulated and then choice to share with future generations.

Fantastic Building. What a home this must have been! We were misinformed about the type of art housed at the Frick and though we appreciated it, the house was what really bowled us over. The atrium is spectacular as are grand room after grand room, not to mention the furniture. We went with friends who love the style of art that is housed at the Frick and they spent at least twice as long as we did.

Stroll on down here after some time at MMOA. I love visiting the Frick when I am in the city. I am a huge fan of its small, but extremely impressive collection. From El Greco and Rembrandt to Vermeer and van Dyck it has one of the great collections of mid-17th century portray art. And the museum, a former mansion, is one cool place to see how the better half lived when the city wasn't all skyscrapers and taxi horns.

What took me so long to get here!?. I would have come to this art museum every trip I've ever made to New York (and that's a lot) if I'd ever managed to get here before. The building alone would have held my interest. And the courtyard. And the phenomenal art!

A quiet respite on 5th Ave.. Great museum whether you are looking at the permanent collection or a special event. Wonderful window into the past of early NYC and how the wealthy families lived.
