Would recommend a visit to anyone who visits NYC. It is in the neighborhood of the Metropolitan Musuem of Art. The works of Art in the Frick are spectacular and well worth a visit.
See how the very rich used to live. This is a stunning exhibition in the home of an old member of the NY elite. If you love European painting, don't miss this.
A personal collection. A small but interesting personal collection. Not too crowded. Nice pieces. A quick quiet respite in NY
A wonderful, urbane and elegant art experience. Pay what you want Sunday mornings 11 to 1. Free audio guide. No museum has any better. Lovely pool room just to sit in.

Never dull. They're keeping the inner garden! Yay! Van Dyck exhibit was a 10. It was the largest collection of his huge paintings ever. FYI, he painted Charles I before he parted with his charming beard...and head.

Great collection of Art. The Frick Museum houses exquisite collection of paintings,sculptures and other fine works of art in the former mansion of industrialist Henry Clay Frick. The estate and gardens are magnificently well kept. Its quite popular and it can get quite crowded during peak hours, never the less this should not deter you from visiting the Frick Museum

Our favorite museum in NYC. What we love about The Frick is .... everything. Unlike other museums it feels "manageable" rather than overwhelming. It's unbelievable that one man could actually own so many masterpieces. Almost every painting is one you've seen in a book, And you can walk right up to it and admire. And then there are the special exhibits. We saw Vermeer's "The Girl with the Pearl Earring" a few years ago. We were alone with the painting for about 5 minutes before other people came over. That was an amazing experience. And the Turners and Rembrandts and the Manet and Renoir and .... on and on. We also love the relaxing areas where you can just sit and .... relax. It's a must-visit for anyone who loves art. Oh - there are also clocks and sculptures and other stuff but mostly I don't know what I'm looking at. Even so, they're also amazing.

Breathing Room. Visiting the Frick is a perfectly delightful, relaxing way to spend an afternoon. The elegant former residence of the Frick family houses an interesting and eclectic collection of European paintings including works by El Greco, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Gainsborough and Turner. My favorite by far are the portraits of Thomas More and his nemesis Thomas Cromwell by Holbein that hang on either side of a stately fireplace. Stunning. There is also sculpture, Chinese and Sevres porcelain and a large collection of Limoges enamels.
Gem, not too crowded. This is actually a rare gem in Manhattan. World class artists, extensive collection, especially of the Spanish masters, without the excessive crowds of other nearby museums.

Great collection in a beautiful home. We went on a weekday afternoon, and could get in in a few minutes, with practically no line. Currently (through early June) there is a Van Dyck: The Anatomy of Portraiture exhibition, which for lovers of the genre is a rare opportunity to see this extremely rich collection of the work by the Master of Portraits. The permanent collection boasts some rare masterpieces. All this in a richly decorated home, and not in the sterile atmosphere of a regular museum.

Want to skip the crowds at the Met and MOMA?. The Frick gives you plenty of elbow room and plenty of world class art. A must see for Renaissance art lovers. Most of the visitors were sophisticated New Yorkers.

Calm & Perfect Art Retreat. The setting is stunning, the furniture is remarkable, and the art collection unlike any in the world. Classic masterpiece portraits and landscapes each a study in perfection. Highly, highly recommend.
A charming and delightful museum. The museum has a gorgeous collection of art and furniture. This used to be the Frick family's residence and all the rooms are so beautifully decorated.
Stunning........ Great building and great art. The Van Dyck sketches at the beginning might seem a bit tedious at times but stick with it, you will be rewarded later in the main gallery.

A haven from the world of commerce. The Frick Collection is set out beautifully within a New York town house. There are two large Turners in one room and just viewing these alone makes the entry fee worthwhile.

An amazing tribute to the taste (and money) of one man. If you have not been to the Frick collection and you like art, drop everything and run. This is a private collection that was assembled when money was able to source great creations of the best artist of the Western World. And this is not just a collection of names like some of the more recent American museums that were made by the super rich. You see best paintings by El Greco and Tiziano, Ingre, Rembrandt, Goya, Turner, Duccio, Piero della Francesca, Corot, Vermeer and who not. In the present visit there was also a temporary exhibition of Van Dyck, extremely well done and highly worthwhile. Run!

Absolutely beautiful museum. This is a small museum in the Frick mansion, so you get exposed to art on the walls and in sculpture but get exposed to the beautiful architectural designs inside and outside of the residence, now gallery.We went on Sunday where admission is what ever you would like to donate. We 'donated' the full entrance fee but we can afford it:-) The lines to get in the day we went wrapped all around the mansion outside, so if you go on a rainy day, you may want an umbrella.The art work the day we went had a special collection of van Dyck, which was nice. There is a great showing of many noted artists there within the museum.Worth going to - especially to see more classical art. It would be worth repeat visits to see the special exhibits.
Lovely setting. A nice way to spend a rainy Sunday afternoon. Long line to get in but it moved fast. Gift shop is nice.

Amazing collection of Anthony Van Dyck!. You can save $$ by going on Sunday and paying what you like (like the Met...) That said, the collection of Van Dyck sketches and paintings was outstanding. It was pretty crowded on the Saturday afternoon we visited (this past Mother's Day weekend), but we still had an amazing time. Be sure to view Frick's personal collection of history of art books in the main drawing room/living room. He had to be a die-hard collector. Still amazed that he was able to "bury" the Johnstown Flood incident, and that he could rise above all his union-busting activity. So study the man before you visit him home and personal art gallery/collection.

wonderful collection. There's a movie about Frick at the end of the visit . Interesting ..He made his fortune subjugating miners and hiring mercenaries to beat them back to work. so we could see probably the best private art in the world. Moral dilemma..discuss....
Wow!. This place is amazing. Plan on spending a good amount of time here. The art work is amazing, but so is the hours.

Interesting art in an intimate setting - worth seeing. Visited the Frick Collection on my final day in New York, so had about a couple of hours to look round before heading to the airport. Like the Met, it's pay-what-you-like, and you get a free audio guide included in the price of admission.It's set in a beautiful mansion by Central Park, and there's some interesting pieces of work here, really well explained by the free audio guide. It's mostly older European paintings (forgive my non-technical description), with quite a lot of portraiture but there's enough here to make it worth coming to. It feels a lot more intimate than the bigger museums, and was certainly less crowded, even on a rainy day.It didn't seem like there were any cafes / amenities, so bear this in mind if you're planning to spend a bit of time there, but there's only probably enough to spend an hour, perhaps two if you check out the temporary exhibition, here anyhow.

My fav gallery of all time!. I love the Frick because it has wonderful content and a manageable size. The history of the house, the collection itself (heavily European, classical painting and sculpture), and the ambience make for an unparalleled experience.

New York's Art Jewel. Look no further if you want to combine the grandeur of a 1900's mansion with a unique art collection in NYC's best location opposite Central Park.Take your time to absorb the uniqueness of all the different masterpieces and watch for the details in the house on the ceiling, furniture and corners. My favourite after Fondation Beyeler in Basel, Switzerland

Gorgeous and luxurious. We absolutely loved this museum and art gallery that is housed in an old mansion. There are lots of great portraits by some of the best known portraitists such as Reynolds, Gainsborough, and Romney. There is also a handful of Vermeer paintings - unexpected outside a major public art gallery. The mansion itself is worth a visit. It is so luxurious and filled with antiques, sculptures, and collectables.

Wonderful collection. Frick on a Sunday afternoon had a bit of a line to get in. We waited about 20 minutes. They seemed to be ensuring not too many people were inside at one time so that you can move through the rooms. Early on Sundays you can "pay what you wish" to enter, so it must get quite busy. The art is set up as it was when it was a residence in a way that was pleasing to the Fricks, not by artist or genre or period. No pictures can be taken except in the central sitting area. The gift shop has all sorts of books on the collection so no real need to take pictures. The furniture is also pretty cool and the books scattered throughout amazing. Spend the 15 minutes for the video about the collection. Plan on spending 1.5 hrs.

Missed our favorite Whistler this time .... On our occasional trips to NYC, my husband and I always try to stop by the Frick to see one of our favorite paintings -- Symphony in Gray and Green: The Ocean -- by Whistler. Alas, it was in storage to make room for the museum's Van Dyck portraiture exhibit. A docent we spoke with said that a lot of other folks had been asking about the Whistler too. The Van Dyck exhibition wasn't my cup of tea, so I spent time looking at the wonderful regular collection of Turners, Chardins, Corots, Gainsboroughs, and so forth. A wonderful feast for the eyes.

Comparable with the Wallace Collection in London. A wonderful collection of art and artefacts brought together by a 19th century NYC magnate. Contains one or two widely-known and iconic paintings. A MUST visit.

Always Been my Favourite. This time there was a special exhibition of Van Dyke's drawing and the relevant paintings. However, I still visited my old favourites, the two Vermeers, and the room with paintings by Gainsboro, Turner, and other old time British painters. The center garden is a beautiful spot to rest between the different exhibit halls. A wonderful, aesthetic and inspiring experience.

It will beat some museums endowment!. This collection represent s the true American spirit that made our nation the best, safest and most equal opportunity place in the world. The legacy is impressive. I am handicapped and had absolutely NO PROBLEM gingerly wheeling around the premises. The staff is TOP NOTCH!

Beautiful setting to be up close to magnificent artwork. Second visit to the Frick and enjoyed it all over again. Viewing Art without barriers in a beautiful home is a treat. The free audio at the door is a must to help guide you about the artworks and the home. The shop can give you guidance on nearby eateries. Both recommendations I have used have been on point. Ensure you go into the basement if an exhibition is on. Allow 2 hours to enjoy this visit. Outside is a lovely area of New York to walk to a lunch spot.

Bygone era. The art is just half of this magnificent destination. The building itself, completed in 1914, speaks of what the area around Central Park would have been like before they tore down beautiful mansions and replaced them with faceless apartment buildings. So go for the priceless art collection, but also go for a glimpse of old New York.

Perfect way to spend an afternoon. I'll admit I have only a 2-3 hour attention span for museums. The Frick is just the right size to see the entire collection in a few hours. The collection is eclectic in artistic periods and styles but the subject matter is principally portraits and landscapes. Do not miss the opportunity to examine the objets d'art, furniture and book collections, too.We were also pleasantly surprised by the pay what you want Sunday admission policy between 11am and 1pm.

Well Worth visiting on your Way to or From the Met. This is a beautiful home by itself not to mention all of the lovely art and ceramics. The docent tour of the collection is nice as you get a good idea of the history of the family and how the Frick came to be. The current Van Dyke exhibition is really worth going to see - there until June.
Unbelievable. This small museum is pound for pound an incredible experience. You cannot believe the art in this place! Download the app, it is incredible.

Gilded Age Beauty. If you like the mansions in Newport you will love visiting The Frick. The wonderful European art on display is an added bonus. Henry Frick bequeathed his home and art collection so the public would always have access, and after the death of his wife, it opened to the public in 1935. Much of the furniture is in place and the art is hung as it would have been in the home, eye level and without barriers. It’s wonderful and intimate; a very relaxing way to enjoy such beautiful old masters.

Great smaller museum. The Frick Collection is absolutely worth a visit while in NYC. The collection is stellar, and the setting is quite special. The day I visited (a Saturday in April) it was crowded, but not excessively so. There was a great Van Dyke show as well, that I enjoyed as much as the permanent collection. Will definitely visit again in the future.

Amazing collection in well-restored mansion, no photos though. We really enjoyed the Frick and found the setting and artifacts in excellent shape. It is definitely worth a visit and close to the Met and Guggenheim if you're planning your day. The house is from an era that no longer exists so it is interesting to see how people lived at the high end in that era! The only complaint is that they disallow photo taking completely except in the center garden area. Really, it would not be injurious to the house to allow non-flash photos, so we didn't not agree with this policy. Otherwise, it was fascinating and a worthwhile stop.

Its the building that's the impressive part.. To be frank neither my wife nor I were take with the huge art collection for the most part, but the building itself is what's so interesting and impressive. Its hard to imagine that a single self made man today could be a whole block on 5th Avenue, design, build, fill a museum and leave a legacy for it to continue long after he's gone. That's what Henry Clay Frick did with the vast fortune he built at the end of the 19th century.
A little gem. Just masterpieces. You can spend hours in this museum. Has an incredible collection of just masterpieces. Not to miss

Great place to visit.. This is a jewel of a museum. They have high quality art and high quality artifacts in a beautiful mansion type atmosphere which is large enough to house the collections but small enough to feel more intimate than a large museum. Highly recommended.

Great Art in a Beautiful Mansion. I first went to the Frick Collection 55 years ago as a young man and have continued to love the collection over the years. The Frick was collected primarily by Mr Henry Clay Frick (1849-1919), one of America's richest entrepreneurs. After his wife died in 1931, the mansion was altered and enhanced to become the museum of today. The mansion has many treasures in the arts including superb paintings by the world's best artists as well as many sculptures, clocks, furniture and various oriental vases. But it is the art where Frick holds the true classics. For example, on the north wall of the West Gallery, there are three Rembrandts, two Franz Hals, a Velasquez, a Turner and a Vermeer. All of these paintings are superb. In the Living Hall, there is a superb El Greco of St. Jerome. Next to it is a wonderful Hans Holbein the Younger of Sir Thomas More. Opposite is a superb Bellini of St Francis and, incidentally, to each side is a Titian! Then, there is another El Greco in a smaller room and two Vermeer's in a hallway. There are probably less than 30 of Vermeer's paintings in the world today. The Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam has at least five, probably the most in the world. The Frick has three! There are also other interesting paintings including a Bronzini with a man wearing a codpiece, lots of portraits by van Dyck, Gainborough and others, and a wonderful indoor garden within the house. In the old days, the Frick was free. Now it costs $20 for an adult (only $15 for us senior citizens and only $10 for students). This is still a reasonable amount for one of the world's most enjoyable art museum experiences and a must for those interested in the arts.

Wonderful visit. we enjoyed this museum with its art work, with the original furnishings...amazing to believe this was a private home once. We used the audio tour which was a wonderful guide, however both of the handheld device were very sticky, I would hope the museum wipes them down with sanitizer after every use. There is also a lovely gift shop

A Must See. Managed to see this gallery and former home for the first time. We were Impressed to see the level of art collected of old masters and more. Easy to just relax and admire while sitting in a few rooms and indoor garden. Worth pausing for the information video on the history of Mr Frick.

Into the Maws of the Robber Baron. If ever there was a true scoundrel of an individual, it was Henry Clay Frick. If ever there was a true scoundrel with impeccable taste in art and elegance, and an appreciation of the best of the old Masters, it was Henry Clay Frick. The epitome of the robber baron, friend and business partner to the great industrialists and bankers, heartless employer, heartless speculator, HCF was very much a man of his era. His tastes were classical, unadventurous, and opulent but, he managed his art collection as he did his business interests, prudently and slyly, counting on the classical "blue chips" to make his name. A fantastic El Greco of Saint Jerome with the saint's elongated fingers on the Bible stops the visitor's eye as do the Vermeers. The palace on Fifth Avenue proposes a serious, sometimes even solemn visit, the type one thinks it's one's duty to make but it is well worth it and it blends into the eclectic architectural melange on Manhattan's Museum Mile,

Rainy day at the museum. The building itself is spectacular! One can just imagine what is was like to live in a grand old house in NYC. The artwork is also beautiful and explained with a free audio guide.
Beautiful Building - Great Collection. I think this is a wonderful museum and if you have friends or family in town who are art lovers, this would be a great place to take them.

The founder was a scoundrel, but the museum is a treasure. A classic small New York Museum with wonderful old master paintings. Love the Fragonard murals, the Holbein painting, the Whistler and Rembrandt portraits.

Visit on Wed April 28, 2016. My wife and I had wanted to visit the Frick on previous visits to NYC and just never seemed to have the time. We made sure to visit it today and it was incredible, one of the best art museums ever visited either in the U.S. or Europe. It is easy to get to and very inviting once you walk in the doors. The staff from entry to exit was very helpful and genuinely seemed to enjoy working there. The collection is superb, every piece, even those not on the audio guide is first rate and presented in a very inviting manner. The building itself is breathtaking, you really get a feel for the Frick and his age. I had read a biography about him before the visit and like all preparation for a visit it helped me understand the man and appreciate the collection. We arrived shortly after opening at 10:00 and thought we would be finished by lunch. Wrong we broke for lunch (they do not have a cafe or snack bar but there are a number of excellent places with various price ranges to eat nearby and we came back after lunch and did not leave until after 4:00. The ticket is good for the entire day so re-admission was free. Bottom line: you need to visit here for an incredible art museum experience.

Loved the Frick!. After going to the must see "big ones" in NYC, I appreciated the size of the Frick collection even more! Seeing everything in this mansion is doable without being overwhelmed. Meander through Mr. Harry Clay Frick's mansion to see pieces which had been on display while he lived there and get a sense of the man. The west gallery and the living hall are highlights. He was a visionary (building his home with the intention that it would someday become a museum)! Lucky for us.If you can, consider seeing the 12 min. "Introduction to the Frick Collection" video in the Music Room or online at the Frick Museum website before touring the house to learn history about Mr. Frick as well as the house. Wish I had watched it ahead of my visit to allow even more time to appreciate the treasures

Art Gem: Not to Be Missed. Housed in the former residence of Henry Clay Frick, the Frick Collection is an art museum in a circa 1910s building. As we moved through the collection, we felt as if we were in someone's home, looking at their private art. It was a wonderful experience. The collection offers paintings, sculpture, furniture, enamels, and rugs, all accessible and arranged by room. It took us several hours to do a preliminary visit, and we could have spent a much longer time there. We will definitely go back for another look the next time we are in NYC. Please note that children under 10 are not allowed into the Collection, due to the ready and close access visitors have to the art objects. The Frick is a gem.

Just the Right Size!!. Love this art museum! It is housed in a beautiful old mansion near Central Park on the Upper East Side. It has an incredible collection of paintings, sculptures, drawings, china/porcelain and period furniture. It's nice because it's not huge and the collection is displayed in the various rooms of the mansion. There are many works from very famous European artists and they had a special exhibition of works by Van Dyck. Highly recommend a visit to this museum. They don't allow children under the age of 10 because it is smaller and they don't have the room to rope the art off.
Lovely museum. A museum in a mansion makes it a lovely place. Permanent collections and temporary ones, a lovely garden. Another way to enjoy museums.

Travel back in time. Travel back to a time when what is now the upper East Side was still open fields, and individual mansions like the Frick, were just then being built for captains of industry. Besides having a wonderful art collection, I made believe I was back in those days and this was still a private residence, and I had the privilege of walking around in this beautiful place.
Architecture. I love seeing the way people used to live in Manhattan. A house the size of a city block with the original furnishings. The art is beautiful but the house was breathtaking.

great art and architecture. the collection at the frick is excellent....small enough not crowded and not overwhelming and exhausting like some museums...not only is the art great, the layout makes it so enjoyable and the courtyard is so relaxing....do the audio tour to get the most out of your visit....good explanation of the major pieces in the collection....you will come out of this museumwith a smile on your face....

An afternoon at the Frick. I have often heard of 'the Frick' as a museum and was vaguely aware of a Mr. Frick who was a business partner of some sort of Andrew Carnegie - this is a mansion, a home of Mr. Frick that has been turned into a museum. Its amazing to stroll through this 'home' and see the massive amount of art he, Mr. Frick, collected over the years.
always something new in history. every time i go there there is something new - wonderful exhibits to focus. a little gem in the middle of the city.

An Oasis on Museum Mile. We went to see the temporary Van Dyke exhibition but stayed to enjoy the excellent permanent collection. The rooms are beautifully laid out without being overwhelming, and the courtyard is so relaxing. Also worth seeing the short film about the history of the place.

Excellent Museum!. The intimate vibe at the Frick museum allows for a unique experience for visitors. The place it immaculate and does not get too crowded. I loved the Van Dyck collection they currently have on display. A must see when in NYC!

Lovely space, interesting but limited collection. This is one of the most beautiful museums in the city. The art itself sort of takes a backseat and ultimately, I end up coming here more to enjoy strolling the grounds than to enjoy the exhibits. Definitely worth exploring.

Simply superb. In some ways this is a more manageable museum than the Met up the road, but the art on display, together with the furniture and porcelain is certainly not second rate. There are some very famous paintings here - Holbein, El Greco, Constable, Gainsborough, Turner to name but a few. Most of the famous artists seemed to be represented here. Labelling is minimal (as befitting a residence) but there is a free audio tour included in the entry price or a Frick app if you have a smartphone. Probably as well we didn't take the audio tour as we would have spent all day there. A bonus was the special exhibition of Van Dyke paintings, drawings etc - the most comprehensive assembled anywhere in the world. Only downside was the (understandable) lack of a cafe but we would have no hesitation in returning next time we are in New York and spend longer there.
What a beautiful Collection. Well worth a visit. There are beautiful pieces of Art, Furniture etc. Almost left as Henry Clay Frick had left the house. Great little museum.

Excellent collection in a beautiful setting.. The house alone is amazing to see, let alone his amazing collection. We went on a Sunday morning and waited about 10-15 minutes outside to get in. They offer an audio tour which is great as it tells about each piece and each room as you stroll through the house. Id' highly recommend to art and architecture lovers.

Another Great small Gallery. The Frick is another of New Yorks finest. Only a small gallery but well worth it. About 3/4 hours to go through it is great. Reminds me of The Isabella Stewart Gardner in Boston. If you appreciate art - dont miss this.
Love the hand held devices!. Stunning personal collection and home. The free hand held devices help to understand each piece of art as you stroll through the mansion - at your own leisure.

Sunday Morning 11am-1pm Pay what you will. If you are on a budget you can go to the Frinckon a Sunday morning and as long as you enter between 11am and 1pm you pay what you want. It is not free but $1 is OK. It is a woderful museum and once you are in you can stay as long as you like.The headphones are also free so pick them up once you are inside.

all I have to say is OMG!!! The girl with pearl earring is my all time favorite painting I actually cried tears of joy!. You HAVE too see this collection, it is phenomenal,, especially the clock collection. VEREY handicapped accessible and friendly staff.
Amazing to see such art in home situation.. Beautiful artworks in a house setting. Such a wonderful collection of artwork in one place. Not to be missed on a visit to New York.

Beautiful collection in a pleasant and beautiful newyorkese house.. Definitely a surprising place both for the atmosphere and the richness of the paintings exposed. A place no one should miss in a 4 days tour in the City.

Lovely museum across from Central Park. Decided to start our day of sightseeing here before heading to Central Park. They had a nice quality audio self guided tour that allowed my family members to look at the pieces they wanted and move at their own pace. Enjoyed the art and history behind the pieces. Gorgeous architecture inside and out.

Unexpected highlight. This is a gem of an art gallery. Not huge like its neighbours down the road, but the quality and catalogue of artists is amazing.
The van Dyke exhibition was very well done and gave a great insight into the artist and his period.

Love the home and the collection...tour tips below...do not skip this!. This is my second trip to NYC and we went (4 girlfriends) to the Frick on Sunday for the "pay as you wish" hours. When we arrived at 11 the line was to the end of the fence but once it opened it moved quickly and we were let inside within 5 minutes. You must coat check your coat here or wear it. No photography. When we left at 1:00 the line was double and they were only letting in what was coming out so I highly advise being there prior to 11 to be in line!We LOVED the collection. The house is beautiful, the audio tour (also free during this time) was awesome. Each painting has a number and you just press the number you're interested in hearing about and hit that. One thing to note which we thought was good info on the audio tour, is when you walk into a room there will be a number on a free standing stand. This tells you about the room, etc. Also I think #4 told you about Mr. Frick himself which we tried to find but didn't see much until we asked. I would listen to this first.Don't skip the statue of Diana at the end in a rotunda down the windowed hallway that overlooks Central Park. Something to note is this statue was made from terracotta and is all still in one piece. Amazing. (Down at the end of the Portico Gallery)Also, one thing to note is there is only one painting of his wife in the Boucher Room. It's on the desk and it's a watercolor of her.There are some gorgeous Vermeer's, Degas, tons of Van Dyck (downstairs as well), van Rijn, El Greco, etc.The collection is absolutely amazing in every room. I especially loved the Fragonard Room which had these large paintings called "The Progress of Love". Definitely listen to the audio on this one (the one for the room). Do not skip the Frick! I wish we had done our first round to NYC so my hubby could have seen it. This time was a girls trip. We will be returning.We started our day grabbing a bagel from "Pick A Bagel" just off the subway and then walked 3 blocks west to the Frick. Yummy breakfast beforehand.After we walked through Central Park and walked down to our broadway show which started at 3. We grabbed soup from The Soup Man and grilled cheese sandwiches since we needed something quick. All in all a perfect afternoon!
worth a visit. After a short wait of 10 minutes I visited the collection. The combination of the art and architecture is breathtaking. Highly recommended.
my favorite mansion. I always enjoyed going to Frick. it's a place to enjoy by yourself or with friends. to see the Mr. Frick's collection.
Van Dyck. A visit to this jewel of a museum is always fabulous. The current Van Dyck show is a special treat .

Do you like art? Come this way!. Not usual place, it cannot be called an ordinary collection because the house itself is an exhibit and a repository of great historical heritage and cultural values. Professionalism of custodians is compleat.

small, excellent collection in grand 5th Avenue home. This museum has it all--beautiful works of art in the charming setting of the Frick family home. View the short film in the rotunda and take a docent tour if available. A chance to see the old masters without the crush of the larger museums.

Fabulous Art Collection. When you don't want to be overwhelmed by a huge art museum and want to see a collection of incredible art by the different masters, this is the place to go. The collection is housed in a beautiful mansion and has an eclectic array of fine art hung with no particular theme in any one room. The antique furniture off sets this amazing collection. The museum was not crowded and gave the space to enjoy the art without hoards of people.
A Beautiful Personal Collection. What a morning I had here, Slowly taking in the beautiful work collected. Take the free audio guide and experience every work in detail!
Collection. We visited the Frick on a rainy day and found ourselves walking around a collection of European masterpieces. I'd recommend taking one of the guided tours.
Always a Treat. If you love old mansions, fascinating history, antiques, and paintings - visit the Frick. We marvel over the workmanship and collection one can view here.

Beautiful collection, beautifully displayed. There are many museums in Manhattan, but I think this is one of the better ones. It is a smaller museum (compared to the Met, Guggenheim, or Whitney), but it has a good collection of art from many famous artists. Don't miss the Renoir at the base of the stairs that lead to the 2nd floor!

Very good gallery. Can be a bit overwhelming like most art galleries but this one is not huge so can be managed in one visit. Excellent exhibits and carefully displayed in logical layouts so everything compliments everything else. The garden area in the middle is lovely as well. Not enough seats in the gallery rooms so it is not great for sitting and looking at exhibits. Wonderful building.

Doable in a Couple of Hours. Love the Frick. It holds exquisite art, from instruments to furnishings to portraits to landscapes. It is small enough that you can literally see everything you want to see within a couple of hours, and it's location is good if you are spending the day exploring Fifth Avenue from mid- to slightly uptown. There is a lot of history to be learned, and it is beautifully maintained. A definitely favorite NYC museum.

A less popular but splendid museum in NYC. This museum is beautiful; the space is unique, the pieces are amazing and the whole experience leaves visitors with a renew sense of enjoyment. Great for a rainy or very hot day. Although is just steps to the Metropolitan Museum, this one should be giving a special time and date - you will not want to rush it.
Hidden Gem. Wish I had known about this before! beautiful building with an impressive art collection. Wish the rest of the house was open for viewing.

Wonderful museum. I didn' even know about this place. But this steel mogul Mr. Frick who first amassed a fortune, then amassed an incredible art collection including some Dutch master and impressionist originals, which are set in his grandiose former home. Lovel setting. On Sundays starting at 11, you name your own admission price.
Favorite Spot in NYC. Frick Collection is my favorite spot in NYC. It is not large but has so much to offer. The antiques and paintings are very unique.

Wonderful . Take a step back in time to the Gilded Age. This is a beautiful museum and used to be a home so you get a truly enjoyable and accessible experience. I brought a book and sat reading in the centre forecourt. This is nyc's answer to English stately homes. Not quite on the same level but beautiful nevertheless. There's a van eyck exhibition on now, not to be missed with some rare paintings like that of his mistress Margaret lemon. The videos on the history of the Frick are great too. A very enjoyable must visit for those on the museum mile. More personal than the bigger institutions.

A Lovely Collection. This is a collection easily seen along with other things on the same day. The home is fabulous and there is a wide range of art located in several rooms. The staff is friendly and helpful, but the art is amazing.

Other Museums Are Higher on the LIst. This collection is housed in an incredibly beautiful building, which is worth the visit alone. The art collection itself is obviously outstanding, but this should not be visited after spending a long day at The Metropolitan Museum of Art. You will be pretty tired and all of the painting start to run together. I am embarrassed to say that because there is such beautiful art at the Frick. The staff (including security) seemed a little snooty and were not very friendly. Cameras are not allowed, which was disappointing to me as a photographer. However, I do have to admit, that it does provide for a serene environment. We enjoyed the Frick, but would only recommend it after seeing the larger New York museums (just not on the same day).
Frick. This is a wonderful small museum where you get to see both a great collection and a terrific building. I always bring guests here and everyone raves about it.

Wonderful home turned into museum. Great tour with interesting art and history of the Frick family, easy to get to with cafes nearby. The museum shop will print out a list of restaurants if you ask. Loved that!
A Gem. One of the most beautiful museums in new york interesting art and objects and beautiful architecture

amazing building, great history, good art. only to see this mansion is worth the visit. Every room, the gallery, to know about its building and owner. Do not leave NY withour visiting. It wont take much time, the staircase is fabulous ,what i suppose the ball room impressive. The shop is nice.

an absolute must, even over the met. a people size museum with some of the most beautiful and famous works of art in the world. just about a perfect size and the management is great at keeping the crowds down so a visitor can really enjoy. just be prepared that you might be one of the folk made to wait outside unti some of the current group leaves. and, try to forget what frick did to get his treasures.

Wonderful! Amazing! I don't know how we never visited before!. The Frick is incredible. I have no idea why we hadn't visited before. The presentation of the artwork and artifacts is wonderful. Everything is in the open, as the Fricks displayed when the house was a residence. It is encouraged to be close to the artwork, but please don't touch! The Fricks wanted their treasures to be displayed as they lived, and it's a wonderful concept to experience. The artwork, on top of all that, of course, is stunning!
Alternative to large museum. Seeing a rich painting collection located in a past living home should not be missed during a trip to NYC.The Van Dick exposition is to be seen .

Stunning gallery. A stunning mansion-cum-art-gallery, truly unique. I hadn't realised I'd entered the main gallery when I'd already passed two Vermeers. Every time you turn a corner, you are liable to stumble upon another masterpiece. The highlights include the stare-off between Hans Holbein's Oliver Cromwell and Thomas More, with El Greco's St Jerome the referee overseeing, and a typically unflinchingly brutal Rembrandt self-portrait. The only slight negative is that the paintings at times feel a touch staid (particularly some of the English portraits) but overall a stunning gallery.

Wonderful!. Henry Clay Frick may have been partly responsible for the devastation and death caused by the great Johnstown Flood and the murderous assault on workers in Pittsburgh's Homestead Strike, but he at least partially atoned for those sins by leaving his magnificent NYC mansion with its splendid interiors and art to the public. There is a small and reasonable charge (which includes an excellently done audio-guide), but you can easily spend a whole day here (leaving for lunch in one of the pleasant nearby eateries and returning).
Fabulous Frick!. This was our favourite art museum. It is a beautiful mansion with an amazing collection of art and sculpture set out like a grand home. If you are short of time don't miss this..

Charming Museum. A gem of a museum, the collection is amazing. This time I saw a van Dyck exhibit and it was well worth it. It should be noted that this private collection includes one piece by Piero della Francesca, the only one by this artist in NYC (perhaps even in the US?)

The most neglected beauty of the museum mile. The problem of this museum is that it is too close to the Met and does not do a lot of advertising. It does not have a lot of modern art, but if you love European classical paintings, Baroque, Rococo, Realism, Mannerism, etc. you will not want to miss it - even of you are tired after the Met. This will be a great hour spent!

Super Concentration of Fine Art. You like the fine art, but not the endless hallways of the Met? Then Frick is your place. Don´t expect much from the last two centuries, though. I mostly missed the impressionists, but they are in abundance in other museums of the city.

Quite impressive private European art collection. This Upper East Side mansion belonged to a 20th century millionaire; upon his death, he left instructions so that his private estate and European art collection would become a museum, where you can see pieces by Van Dyck, Ingres, El Greco, Boucher, Constable, Turner, Corot, Goya, Renoir, Titian, Vermeer, etc, as well as appreciate the house itself with its beautiful inner yard gallery and fountain

Nice. This is a beautiful house turned museum.The collection is quite interesting and the house is phenomenal.It is nice to meander in the house and look at beautiful art,I also enjoyed seeing the dining table the indoor garden the different bedrooms etc

So Beautiful!. I had been here once before, but to see a sensational exhibition of Van Dyck portraits in this beautifully kept 5th Avenue Mansion is well worth it! The entire house is glorious and a lovely place for an alternative to the fantastic, but busy, Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A Hidden Treasure Not To Be Missed. You might just walk past this beautiful "stately home" opposite Central Park. Do stop! This museum is a "must". The rooms are all absolutely beautiful. My 16 year old grandson and I were fortunate to see the Van Dyke Exhibition showing many sketches and finished pieces by the Master.The star of the whole building has to be a Rembrandt which gives you goose bumps just looking at the exquisite brushstrokes. You want to reach up and stroke the fur on the old gentelman's fine coat!!!

Great Sunday before you return to the airport visit!. Tired of subways and NYC commotion? Enjoyed your visit but heading home? Try the Frick on your way out of town. They have a Sunday "whatever you want to give admission rate" before 1pm? And it includes a free walking recording (fascinating commentary). Even "non art lovers" will enjoy a visit! And then take a walk in Central Park; what's not to enjoy.
A wonderful collection of art. The Frick collection is about the best the robber barons left us with. A wonderful collection of art. Shame it was built on the labours of many.

Amazing Museum. The Frick is a beautiful collection in an old house, filled with grandeur and sophistication. If you like art museums, The Frick will not disappoint; and don't skip it in favor of the larger museums! It has an equally impressive (although smaller, yes) collection. There is a coat check and no photography is allowed except in the terrace area. Plan to spend about 1.5-2 hours. If you know any art history you will recognize most of the artists.

A must see for art and architecture lovers!!. This place is a former private home with an incredible art collection. There are several Dutch masters on view. One of my favorite places is the fountain/garden room. Beautiful sculptures and plants surround a fountain with a skylight inside the house.

very interesting collection. One of my favorite museums in NYC is located in stylish building and very stylish inside. It is real home for the family and similar to Yussupovsky Palace in St/Petersburg in Russia.A lot of paintings of Geinsboro. Unfortunately it is not allowe to take pictures there, only in atrium.

Gem of a museum. We went to this museum on Easter Saturday. It has astonishing paintings, Holbeins, Gainsboroughs, through to early Turners and Monets. They are beautiful and interesting. Possibly the best thing about the museum, though, is its modest size and the lack of crowds. It still has the feel of a mansion. We really enjoyed strolling about looking at the collection as Mr Frick no doubt intended. If we return to NY then this museum is a must and i would urge anyone else to go there.

Fantastic as always.. Definitely worth a visit! They always have an interesting exhibition and seeing how a collection is curated in a private (or used to be private) residence is a novel experience. The audio guides are free too.

Art Collection Gem. I have visited the Frick Collection 3 times - it is my favourite Manhattan Gallery. An excellent collection in an interesting setting. Representative art from most periods and artists including Holbein, El Greco, Vermeer, Van Dyck, Rembrandt, Monet and many more. Excellent audio commentary is provided free of charge. Free coat check. Allow at least 2 hours to see the collection.

Beautiful Integration of art and Architecture. Recently, I had the privilege to introduce my friend from London to Manhattan. No visit is complete without a visit to the Frick Collection. The beauty of this museum /gallery is that it seamlessly integrates magnificent works of art into the property's sumptuous architecture. This is a wonderful window through which to glimpse life of the East Side before the mayhem began. The building and appointments are beautiful and for those who appreciate fine details, allow plenty of time to gaze and enjoy. The art is lovely and well curated. One of my favorite places in NYC! I recommend this to anyone who appreciates or wants to learn to appreciate beautiful architecture and art. Not suitable for young children unless very well, behaved and/or managed.

A jewel of a museum. Don't miss it.. We love the Frick, and try to get there annually. It's a lovely combination of historic mansion with the excellent art collected by the Frick family. It's close to the Met, and the only drawback (and in light of the venue -- not as large as the halls/rooms of a building destined to be a museum -- totally understandable) is the minimum age of 12, but that makes getting to go to the Frick a little special for the kids.

Happy Place. So much of the art here is just nice to look at! It makes me feel good. And in such a gracious setting. I first saw the Frick as a teen and now realize that the reason I dislike many English stately homes is that, instead of displaying their art, they just load it on walls. The Frick is my idea of the perfect home.

Van Dyck Exhibition is Awesome. Hurry, hurry, hurray! This wonderful exhibition isn't going to be here very much longer. The Museum itself (Henry Frick's former home) is beautiful in itself. However, this exhibition is really something special in its curation.
Fabulous. The Frick is stunning. The works of art are abundant and beautifully displayed in the rooms open to the public. Frick acquired an astonishing collection and this is a great place to visit.

Van Dyck exhibit. A good Van Dyck exhibit is until early June. Oil paintings are in two rooms on the first floor, drawings, sketches and his early portraits in the basement rooms. The sketches are very interesting (one was hanging upside down but hopefully they rectified that by now).

Beautiful Art, Good Size. The art on display is really beautiful, but more than that, the actual home and garden is stunning as well. The museum will take you about a couple of hours to go through. So, it's not enormous or a whole day activity. If you want to add a museum to your itinerary, this is it. You will have plenty of time to explore other things that day.

Awesome at every Level. We had never been to the Frick and intended to view the amazing permanent collections and stunning building. Imagine our surprise when we found out there was an incredible Van Dyck exhibit going on as well. We barely made it out of the basement floor where the sketch studies of famous works were on display. Of course, the Frick is a must-see for any art museum junkie although I might suggest NOT going on a Sunday morning when admission is "suggested contribution" before 11 AM. There was a long line waiting to enter and it was quite crowded in all the galleries. Kudos to Henry Clay Frick for compiling such an impressive collection and housing it in his home....and then donating it all with an endowment for all to enjoy.

Gorgeous. Just loved the Frick! Superb collection of paintings in a very intimate space - the setting really enhanced the experience. It was also not very crowded at 10.30 on a Friday, so we could linger over paintings, which is sometimes hard to do at other galleries. So if this is a bit of a secret, I'd like to keep it that way, but on the other hand, I'd love for everyone to visit such a lovely place!

French art. If you love your art classical, white, curlie-cues, in a rich guys house overlooking Central Park, this is the place for you. No photos except in the fountain coridor, the Frick family have an amazing classic collection. If you pay attention closely you can might find a "pay what you wish" window of time to attend eith greater affordability. They also have events, recitals and other scheduled diversions.

A Message of disappointment to Mr. Ian Wardropper. Dear Mr. Wardropper,I visited The Frick this past Sunday with my teenage daughter, her first time. We arrived around 2:15 p.m., with a plan to go through all of the art rooms first and then close our visit with a relaxing sit down in your Garden Court.However, much to my surprise, the Garden Court was closed to the general public by approximately 3:30 p.m.ish, before we were planning to enter and LONG before the museum was scheduled to close at 5 p.m.I asked the security guard why it was closed: "A private event," she barked at me. When I said to my daughter that it should not close before closing time, that security guard interrupted by starting to say "who are you to decide that..."; I walked away before she could finish of course.I was surprised - and very disappointed - at the Garden Court closing because when we were purchasing our tickets at FULL price nobody told us that we would only be getting partial value due to the Garden Court closing early.And given your institution's Mission (see your mission statement), which is all about the visiting public, why would you close to all visitors a central attraction in the Museum for the benefit of a select few (the private event attendees). I'm guessing they are "important" folks (donors perhaps?) who in the museum's eyes count more than the hundreds of visitors who were excluded from the Garden Court that day.Here are two suggestions. DO NOT close to the visiting public parts of the museum during regular hours for the purpose of private events. Schedule the private events and do whatever set up AFTER regular hours.If the museum must cater to the private event crowd over the visiting public, then at least instruct your museum staff to inform folks upon entering/paying that there may be some change to your regular offerings. For example, the person who sold us our tickets could have informed people coming in that the Garden Court was closing early and that we may wish to consider going there first so as not to miss it entirely (like we did). Then, discount the tickets because nobody should pay full price for anything less than the full experience.My daughter loves art, and still enjoyed her visit there. But I was SO disappointed I did not have a chance to have the moment with her in the Garden Court. I know I can come again, but I don't think I will - at least until I believe that the Frick is a place that considers all patrons important and not private event attendees more important, as evidenced by your museum's actions the day of our visit.Also, while visiting your gift shop, where my daughter made a purchase, I noticed that your two staff members in there only looked up from their smartphones when they had to process a transaction. No smiles, no greetings, only grunted minimal replies to questions.Hope you will consider the feedback because The Frick itself is a great place that can only be ruined by the actions and decisions of those working there, from top to bottom.
Visit. It was really nice exhibition of many old and beautiful paintings and statues! Worth seeing! Everything was great, but I couldn´t take the photos.

More masterpieces per square foot than anywhere in the world. Henry Clay Frick was a controversial 19th century industrialist, but he used his fortune to build a home on Fifth Avenue in the early 20th century for an art collection that he wanted seen by the public in time. Every room is filled with incomparable treasures from Rembrandt (including his late and greatest self-portrait), Vermeer, Constable, Turner, Ingre, Franz Hals, Degas, Van Dyck, Holbein (his iconic portraits of Sir Thomas More and Sir Thomas Cromwell, George Romney, Renoir, Whistler, and so much more. Most of the original furnishing are in place along with sculpture, clocks, porcelain, and silver. This is my favorite art museum in New York--grand galleries, intimate rooms, and an indoor garden/fountain. Get the audio guide that is free with admission to learn all about the art. The museum is pay-what-you-wish on Sundays if you get there by 1 PM, but worth the $20 admission. Nice small gift shot, but no cafe. The Frick is all about the artwork. There is a film that runs all day in the Music Room providing history background on Mr. Frick and his collection. The special exhibitions (no extra charge) have been sensational in recent years.
VanDyke Exhibit does not disappoint.. Enjoyed the vandyke exhibit. There is an App you can downhold to your phone before your visit. The frick is one of my favorite museums in the world.

The Frick. If you like great art in smaller doses, this is absolutely one of the true gems of NYC and the art world. The entire building still feels like a home, but everything from the architecture to the furniture, artifacts and the magical paintings is a testament to great taste. One of our favorite places to visit in NYC!
Amazing building, wonderful collection. A gallery like no other... a family home immediately east of Central Park, which is a delight to wander through - particularly on a bleak New York day.
The Van Dyke exhibit was HUGE!. We have been to many museums all over the world, and the Frick is one of our favorites. We love the setting, the curators are geniuses and the collection is wonderful.
Small collection in lovely building. You will not need more than two hours (at most) for this visit. For me, a large part of the attraction was the building itself, the interior courtyard...
Peace and tranquility. Stunning collection of art covering many genres, a throughly enjoyable way to spend 2-3 hours. The mansion itself is fabulous.

Don't Miss the Van Dyck Exhibit at the Frick!. Besides the amazing permanent collection at the Frick, which is always worth seeing, the current Van Dyck exhibit is not-to-be-missed. You will see his development from a talented young man to the best portrait painter in Europe. And seeing his initial sketches and unfinished paintings is a glimpse into his genius! Well worth your time if you love beautiful classic art and want to see how Henry Clay Frick lived during the American Gilded Age.
A gem. A gem of a museum -- not that large so you can see it all quickly -- many special events and exhibits -- kind of pricey but worth a look
Lovely place to visit. I was more interested in seeing the building rather than the artwork, but i found both very interesting.
A lovely surprise. The building itself is a treasure and makes it worth a visit even if art and history isn't your things. It's like a hidden museum and a brief escape from the crowds.
Nice quiet museum after a walk in Central Park. Nice quiet museum after a walk in Central Park with friendly supervisors and I think volunteers who loved to be in this building helping others

Great little gallery well worth the effort if you like this kind of stuff. As a fan of Vermeer this was a go to gallery for me as he had three of them hanging on his walls but the gallery has way more to offer than that and a great way to pass a couple of hours strolling around somebody's house granted a very large house looking at some very nice old masters

Amazing experience!. This is an absolute must in New York! A perfect place - the architecture, the furniture, the lay-out of the art work in a totally natural order - not by artistic periods - the whole concept is wonderful!

Wonderful collection in wonderful surrounds. The permanent collection is wonderful, in this house of a wealthy person that has been turned into a museum. When I visited there was a superb van Dyck exhibition as well, which was fantastic. Thoroughly worth the entrance fee.

New York's best kept secret - a must see. There is nothing like the Frick anywhere in New York. The collection is housed in an historic mansion that lends a European elegance to the place. The artwork, some of which changes over time, is fantastic. Old masters, modern artists, well-known artists and under-known artists fill the rooms.

Frick Collection -- One the finest of the Gilded Age. The Frick Collection is a lovely museum on 70th off of Madison Ave. I went to view the Van Dyck exhibit which run through June 5 2016. The home of Henry Clay Frick lays out what you would expect from 1900s NYC mansion. Each room contains wonderful (mostly portraits) paintings Thomas Gainsborough, Jan Vermeer to name a few. I wasn't aware during this time there are paintings being loaned out, so a couple of paintings I wanted to see were not there. I'm particularly drawn to the day-to-day items vases, statues, dinnerware, porcelains. I love the craftsmanship of common objects during this period. The heart of the home (my opinion) is the enclosed courtyard, where you can sit and just enjoy the wonderful fountain. It's not a large museum, yet I spent 3 hrs there and was satisfied. Watch the film on the history and conversion of the Frick home into a museum (run continuously). Admission is $20, with pay-as-you want on SUNDAYS from 11-1pm. There is free street parking if you can find it, otherwise you can park on Madison but you have to feed meter every hr ($3.50 per hr). There are parking garages but I find them expensive (2 hrs $30-40). The museum allows you leave and come back, which is what I did. After your trip to the Frick Collection walk around the corner to Ladurée, the french pastry shop (there will be a line) and enjoy a french macaroon. Central park entrance not far and end the day there. Enjoy.

Fabulous colleciton in a beautiful building. Visited on a discounted admission day and loved the collection! There was a special exhibit that day so the line was around the block, but it was worth the wait. Hope to go back someday and spend more time when it's (hopefully) less crowded to truly enjoy and appreciate the beautiful surroundings and the art.
No NYC visit is complete wothout a "Frick Trick". One of my favorite NYC retreat rain or shine! A gem not to be missed! Not as big as the Met. and yet GREAT.

The Frick is Fabulous. Visited the Frick to see the Van Dyck exhibit. He's not a painter I know very much about, but I learned a great deal from the exhibit's explanation of how his drawings and prints evolved into his portraits. He became the model for British portrait painters such as Gainsborough to later follow. The Frick does not have a lot of room for larger exhibits, so you need to begin in the basement. Space used for the exhibit also necessitates some of the regular collection having to be removed from view.The Frick mansion itself is a showplace. Since the Old Master paintings are so fabulous, don't neglect listening to the audio commentary for the individual rooms. The Living Room in particular is probably one of the greatest single rooms in the world because of the paintings it contains--Holbeins' s Sir Thomas More, Bellini's St. Francis, and two Titians. (A slight negative is that the museum's sculpture collection is not especially noteworthy.)The Frick also has a Velasquez, a few Rembrandts, the only Piero Della Francesca works in America, and three Vermeers. In addition, the Venetian palazzo with a water pond in the center of the building is not to be missed. If Old Master paintings in an old world setting are your cup of tea, then the Frick should be at the top of your list of things to see in New York City.

Worth a ONE Time Visit. After a tour of NYC Public Library, my family and I walked down 5th Ave to the Frick Museum. It is a worthwhile tour if you are interested in mansions and art. Staff is very strict so be wary. Would be nice if Do's and Don't's were listed on brochure so you are forewarned. Also I thought it was a bit rude that with FIFTEEN minutes left until closing time, a couple was not allowed to continue their tour that they paid for because the "museum was closing." As a teacher, I understand rules, but staff did not leave a good impression. Make sure you get the free audio device because staff doesn't initiate any information.

I can talk about this.. Everything about it is a veritable trip through a garden and mansion of yesteryear. Paintings of great artists (Velasquez, Vermeer and so many more) are placed in enormously comfortable and quiet rooms with beautiful ceilings, rugs (I think), places to sit. The ambiance is calming and restful. Come and enjoy. If not, on their website is a veritable viewing of the paintings!!
Beautiful collection. Such a gem! And surprisingly uncrowded! This was one of my favorite places we visited in NYC. I will be returning the next time I visit New York!

Fabulous. The Frick is a gem among museums. Originally a private home, it's small enough that you can go through most of the rooms without rushing. It is so beautiful that you will want to visit frequently, whether you're a tourist or a New Yorker.

Stately Home cum Old Masters Gallery. Housed in a Fifth Avenue mansion built and furnished by a steel baron, the Frick Collection is not just a stunning array of Old Master works, but the fully-furnished rooms themselves. You should start with the movie which recounts a bit about Frick and how he got started collecting. It's interesting and informative. No need to start at the beginning; just start watching at any point and loop 'round.The mansion interior is just awesome, possibly the best remaining example of how the ultra-rich lived during the Gilded Age. The art is impressive and covers a lot of ground (it's a BIG mansion): Rembrandt, Constable, Reynolds, Lawrence, Fragonard, Turner, Holbein, others.But I have two complaints. First, photography isn't permitted (whereas just about everywhere else in Manhattan it is), which I have always maintained is just unthinking mean-ness, since your handheld snapshots aren't going to deprive it of any income. (For some reason, photos are permitted in the large covered garden, which isn't part of the original structure.) Second, using an app, you can listen to explanations of selected works; but in many cases the descriptions are perfunctory.
Must see - an amazing house and gallery.. We keep going back again and sharing it with people from out of town. Great art collection and an amazing historic house.

The Frick. On our first visit to NY we naturally did as much as possible in a week and decided that venturing into the Metropolitan when tired and stuffed too much on 'culture' would be a waste,we bypassed it for the Frick,and what a good decision. Our brain calmed,our stress reduced and we just relaxed. This time,October 2015, we allowed ourselves a day for the Metropolitan and were and ready. Oh,we also went back to the Frick as it is such a jewel.yes,Utah is the product if a robber baron but he did gave taste to match the cash.
Amaizing. Do not miss this small museum if you are an art lover. The building itself is an architectural pearl and every room inside is a gem.

Tranquil oasis in a sea of busy galleries. The Frick is a delight. It is probably the least crowded of all of the major galleries in New York. Yet, it is filled with wonderful paintings, sculptures, furniture and clocks -- and a splendid courtyard. The mansion's architecture is charming. I only wish they still allowed access to the upper floors. Saw the Van Dyck collection -- a nice bonus.

YES! one of the best art collections in the world!!. I absolutely loved the Frick Collection. A great spot for out of town visitors. Quiet and a nice spot for small kids too. We spent a full two days exploring the Frick collection and was so worth it.

Great collection. Enjoyable Sunday afternoon at the Frick - some fine masters to be seen, Renoir, Rembrandt, Hans Holbein, Vermeer, Constable, Turner. A great collection housed in what was a lived in mansion -made it nicer than a purpose built museum

Top-notch!. Our week in NYC was capped by visiting this fantastic museum. It is a manageable size and amply repays any time spent here. The collection of artwork is amazing. A Van Dyke exhibition was on to enhance his works in the permanent collection. His drawings were stunning. Vermeers, Rembrandts, and even a Velasquez (rare outside Spain) are awesome. You MUST go. Free on Sundays from 11-1, but worth the admission anytime.
Wonderful presentation . So tastefully done. Wonderful art in serene setting without crowds. Unhurried. Participates with many other museums for entry.

Old Masters and well-curated temporary exhibits. Right now, you can see wonderful Van Dycks from all over the world to add to the Frick's own. The downstairs gallery is full of wonderful drawings, and the fountain garden is a wonderful respite.Remember you can't carry your coat - you must check it or wear it

Beautiful Art and Architecture. Thoroughly enjoyed both the special exhibit featuring Anthony van Dyck studies and sketches (preparatory for many of his paintings), plus the regular exhibits which cover a fairly wide range of artists and artistic time periods. However, what I really loved was the house itself and the architectural features! So while the art is worth appreciating, be sure to absorb all the details of the house as well.
Amazing Museum...a must see in NY. Probably 1 billion dollars worth of ART, and maybe more. Amazing architecture and this museum should not be missed. I am sure I will visit it again, it was so good.

A beautiful museum in a former private residence, it is not to be missed!. This little museum showcases the private collection of Mr. Henry Frick. He was an avid collector of art and in 1935 his residence turned in to The Frick Collection, displaying art from all over the world from major artists.
Wonderful small museum.. Beautiful architecture, great collection. Interesting to view this onetime home of HC Frick. Plan to spend at least a few hours to absorb it all.

Great small museum. With a small, but rich collection of art, this museum offers all a magnificent museum experience, without the overwhelming atmosphere of the large museums. The art is fabulous, and the surrounding of the home where it is displayed lends a cozy but elegant place to appreciate it all.

A lovely place to view fine art. I visited in March 2016, to see this wonderful museum again, and to see the Van Dyck exhibit. It is always a pleasure to visit the Frick - a beautiful setting to see wonderful paintings, furniture, and household items such as ceramics - and they always have a great visiting show - such as the Van Dyck that is currently in residence there.

Bad staff person not normal status for this fine museum.. I just visited this wonderful museum around the same time ILUVUNYC did and did not encounter any "terrible" staff anywhere as ILUVUNYC reported in a recent review. In fact, I found most of the staff quite neutral and unobtrusive, with a few actually being friendly. I was born in NYC and have lived there as an adult. I have been to museums around the world and have rarely if ever encountered such "terrible" behavior in a NYC museum.Having lived in NYC, I have been to the Frick Collection many times. In particular, I like its permanent collection, but I often go there for special exhibits and even concerts. I like the Frick in particular because although it has an incredible collection, I find it still has a rather intimate atmosphere. I am not doubting ILUVUNYC's recent unfortunate experience with one of the staff there, but I'm guessing that it was an unusual and random occurrence rather than the rule.The special exhibit I attended was focused on portraiture, particularly that of the Flemish painter, Anthony Van Dyck (Antoon van Dyck), and others of his time. In a lower, basement-like gallery, most of the exhibit was composed of sketches or drawings done prior to the artist's tackling of the final product, usually a painting or often etchings, which were at the time a common method of producing a larger number of printed likenesses of the same subject. A lot of historical information was presented with each of these drawings, and often the finished work was referenced in small, pictorial form. The head and torso of a particular subject might be shown in original sketch form and then a side panel would show perhaps where the likeness of that one person was used in a larger painting of a group of persons. I'm interested in portraiture, so for me it was very interesting, and I spent considerable time before going to the upstairs gallery where many of Van Dyck's finished, full-sized paintings were on display. It is my understanding that the Frick Collection has quite a number of Van Dyck's paintings, but for this exhibit, I believe several were borrowed from other collections around the world as well. It was a beautiful and fascinating exhibit, but I'm not sure that it would be for everyone. Portraiture is, like still-life painting, a rather focused genre, and I can see that many museum-goers would quickly tire of looking at drawing upon sketch upon drawing of so many faces from the same time period done by the same artist or those like him. Fortunately, one could easily obtain relief by looking at any of the many other wonderful paintings and art objects which the Frick maintains, and after awhile, that's exactly what I did, which is why I've been here so many times.In short, the special exhibit on portraiture was very interesting, but the Frick has so much to offer that anyone with any interest in art in any of its many forms could easily spend a very pleasant and inspiring afternoon here.

Fantastic gem, must see. Absolutely wonderful, educational visit to see what one man created and planned to pass on to future generations. Well worth the time to walk through and see the exceptional artwork.
Great Small Museum. Some incredible art in an historic home on museum mile. Outstanding work by Vermeer and others of the era. Broad based, well chosen collection.

Royalty Lived Here. What a beautiful estate to walk around, view terrific art and sculpture, dream about the former residents holding state dinners or dances with elegantly dressed guests in ball gowns of the times. Thus is a must see on the Upper Eastside!

Surprising. You don't feel in a museum as you're nose to nose with the works of art; yet it has an amazing array of great masters. After the Met, the second best museum we visited in New York. Will go back again.

My favorite NYC museum. My favorite museum in NYC because it's so compact and do-able in one visit, but also breathtakingly gorgeous. Hard to believe it was once a private home (same with Frick's downtown friend JP Morgan). Astounding paintings, masterpieces from 15th thru 19th century, plus sumptuous, unique home furnishings.

Just watch out for some of the staff. We might have just gone on an 'off' day but there was a lady in the first room of the special exhibit which was so terrible to everyone who walked in the door that people were walking out!! She yelled at people and was absolutely hideous to anyone who asked questions. I have never seen any staff person behave like that at a museum. I don't know if it was tolerated (it was witnessed by other staff people) because this is not a typical museum, but it was terrible and really ruined the experience for us. It is a lovely home and the special exhibit was nice but I don't think I'd ever go back again.

Soak in the Riches, hard to believe a family lived there!. Whenever I'm in new York I visit the Frick Mansion. Built in the time when wildcats got rich building America, all along 5th ave, the Tycoons competed against one another to see who could build the bigger and most elegant mansion, who bought the best art work and antiques from Europe, whose child had the best tudors. They did this because a some of the Tycoons had little education and upper class breeding. Mr. Frick built one of the best Mansions, go vist soak in the rich atmosphere.

a gem of a manageable museum. My wife and I have been visiting the Frick Collection for over 20 years, and like it because it's possible to see great art with ample time to look at each piece carefully in less than two hours' time. And you get to see paintings you won't see elsewhere because steel magnate Frick specified that they should not go out on loan. There are several important Rembrandts and what's more four Vermeers--out of a couple of dozen in the world. And you get to walk around in Frick's beautiful but not ostentatious Fifth Avenue with a no-charge audio guide
Lovely Collection. A beautiful mansion in the middle of Manhattan. Great architecture, and a vast collection of beautiful Art. Really worth visiting.

A Must Visit for Art Lovers. This is a very manageable museum to visit as it is in reality a mansion of an industrialist, Henry Clay Frick. It was constructed just before WW1 and designed to be a museum for Frick's collection of art, mainly paintings and furniture. Amazing!

A cultural gem. This was the cultural highlight of our recent visit to NYC. We went early on Saturday morning and spent an engrossing couple of hours going from room to room in this beautiful house, filled with the most stunning works of art. What an enterprising collector Mr Frick was! I would thoroughly recommend this. It is beautifully curated and the staff are very knowledgable and helpful. We also appreciated the audio aids which were versatile and simple to use.
Favorite NYC museum. Great collection. Come on your own and do the audioguide for two hours. So peaceful in there and not crowded like the other museums.

An Art Collection Very Worth Seeing. An incredibly extensive eclectic collection of art by the Fricks set in their wonderful stone mansion across from Central Park. During our visit in March 2016 the Anthony Van Dyke 16th century portrait collection was on display.

Walking Through an Architectural and Artistic Delight. Walking through the Frick Museum is like walking through a friend's beautifully architecturally designed home filled with antique furniture, objects d'art and room after room of marvelous paintings by famous artists. Yet one always feel relaxed. The center court is a restful gathering place with benches and you are surrounded by green plants if you choose to sit and enjoy the quiet. An elongated pond sets in the middle. One never tires of this haven of beauty.

Exquisite small museum. It's outstanding any time with the marvelous permanent collection in this jewel of a once private house but right now there is a special show of paintings and etchings and drawings of van Dyke.

If the Met tires you out try the Frick. A marvelous, relatively small museum, that is well worth a visit even on a short trip to the city. The collection is very fine and you won't be exhausted when you leave.
Museum Guide for New York City is Excelent. I go with my wife . She is so much happy for this visit place And she told me she will go there next

Great Gallery. This is a great gallery. First of all the art on display is very good. Secondly it retains all the atmosphere of when it was a private house which is really interesting. Well worth a visit

Nice and beautiful art collection. This is one of my favorite places to visit while in New York. The ambience is perfect because is not a big museum and they controlled the access so you can relax while watching the art. The collection is variable and selected. If you are on an budget trip, you can visit it on sundays from 11 to 1 pm, because os free.

Calm and Beautiful Museum,. Located it the most beautiful Villa on fifth avenue, this haven has a very impressive collection, especially the room with the Wistler's portraits. a lovely place to wonder easily away from the hectic city.

Worth visiting. We arrived at the Frick Gallery, and there was a large crowd already there, and so when we got in we were surprised, I believe the entry price is around $20, but on a Sunday from 11.00am, you can pay what you like, a couple of dollars or even nothing, hence the crowd forming, lol.

Beautiful Collection. I went during the almost free (pay as you wish) time and I paid $1... and the staff was nice enough to not shame me too bad for that. But it was a nice collection - it is not as famous as the other museum, therefore less people to navigate around. But the collection was fairly large, but not overwhelming like the MET. It was easy to walk around and impressive to imagine that one man was responsible for such an impressive collection.
Steep entrancenprice. The price is steep for what's offered, however if you go on Sunday before 1pm the price is pa what you want.
Excellent as always. A small but exquisite collection of the major Western European artists, and a visiting exhibition of Van Dyke and his school made it a wonderful afternoon in NYC.

Finally Made It To The Frick. This is a small treasure off of 5th avenue. The collection is excellent and the building and the rooms in which the artwork is displayed would be worth a visit on their own. This will remind you of some of the great European palaces in the way the building is designed. There is much to admire in the collection including some true masterpieces that are Somewhat randomly distributed through he house.It took me quite a while to get here but I will be back. Highly recommended for lovers of art, and classical furnishings.

Astounding. This is my favorite place in NYC. The intimacy of the museum and the grandeur of the collection make it special. The audio information sheds light on much of the family's history and how/why many of the pieces were acquired, which is very interesting. Also, there is a short film that illustrates the progression of the property from a home to a museum. Love the Frick.

Mesmerizing collection and museum/home. I cannot decide which I liked better, the art or the home. Mr Frick had the right idea for someone of his wealth. Collect incredible art and build a house to display it which was set up to revert to New York as a museum upon his death. This benefits so many people and the collection is breath taking.

Beautiful Small Museum. The house is beautiful and gives you a different way to view art and period pieces. It also has a beautiful indoor garden. You are given a recorder to learn more about the artwork and that made the experience even better.

Perfect for the busy art lover!. This is a crazy beautiful mansion featuring some of the greatest artists and works of art in the world. The museum is just the right size for a visitor with an hour or an hour and a half to spare.
