The museum features some of the most famous rococo and baroque paintings (by such names as Fragonard and Boucher) in existence.

Amazing museum / mansion. One of the great small museums in the world. Three of the only 36 Vermeer are here. Rembrandt, El Greco, etc. There is nothing modern. It's all the traditional masters. Yet it is a stunning collection in a stunning home. The design and ornamentation of the home itself are a big part of the draw. As you walk in the 6000ft2 ballroom, it's hard not to imagine what life would have been like for these folks 100 years ago. Don't forget to look in the libraries as well. The book collections are tremendous as well.
A Treasure. This is a truly;y lovely, serene space with a splendid collecting and splendid exhibits. It is a gem--an historic mansion and a splendid high culture experience.

Arguably the finest private small museum on earth. Gorgeous architecture and interior design combined with the choicest private collection of paintings anywhere--incredibly high level of quality and a matchless feast for the eye of the connoisseur. Above all, just the right size for a sumptuous survey in a couple of hours. Always wonderfully life enhancing, never exhausting, and now with exquisite small special exhibitions for dessert, to compliment the amazing permanent collection.
Beautiful home.. A great museum. Wonderful private collection of art. Very doable. Not a lot of walking or stairs. Very senior friendly.
An absolute must in NYC (but kids are not allowed). Outstanding collections in a precious setting; a unique opportunity to see a fifth avenue mansion in an elegant and quiet way.

A hidden gem. A majority of tourists might be inclined to skip this museum which would be a mistake as it houses one of the finest art collections in the city. Light and airy displays in one of the city's must see attractions.
Old world NYC. A wonderful escape from the hustle and bustle of the city to calm, beautiful art and a beautifully maintained home.
A jewel. Find myself returning here often thru the years. Such a beautiful museum and such art! A selection of some if the very best of classic works.
just wow. if you love art and museums - you have to go, the building itself is great and you feel awestruck walking through it and then all the great painters - it's a must see

Classic tastes in a fine setting.... Sure, this is old school, Rembrandts, Vermeers, Fragonards, etc but what a balance to the rush and stumble of NYC. Well stated house/museum, diffuse light garden... when the avant garde gets a little too avant this is the place to re-center in a setting of good taste

It must be nice to have a Vermeer in your hallway!. An excellent art museum in the former home of Henry Flick located just east of 5th Ave and Central Park. A nice range of paintings from Holbein, Vermeer and Whistler and many other important old master artists plus an impressive furniture and porcelain collection. A little steep at $20 per ticket but then it's in New York.
not worth the time or the money. Rude staff, boring portraits and china, so Not worth $20 and twenty minutes, go to the Metropolitan instead.

Unique museum. Wanted to see this on my last trip but just got there this time. We listened to a 15 minute talk by a docent in the garden. Nice background on Frick and the house. The collection is beautiful.

My favorite place in NYC. . The Frick collection is absolutely magnificent. I don't know why more people don't add the Frick to their list when visiting the city. Goya, Vermeer, Whistler, and so many others are on display. It's a nice escape from some of the busier museums and galleries in the city.

A View Inside the Life of the 1% of 100 Years Ago. I am ashamed to say that I have been to NYC many times but never heard about the Frick Collection until this trip. The art was breathtaking but the opportunity to actually experience the lifestyle of a steel baron from the early twentieth century was eye-opening. From the gracefully curved staircase to the very feminine dining room covered with frescos about the stages of love by Fragonard, to the library with bookshelves up to the window sills to leave room for the art, each new room took my daughter, her friend and me to another world. The huge ballroom was covered with Rembrandts, Vermeers and other Dutch Masters all acquired by the owner before his death in 1919. It appeared as though he scoured all the castles and great houses of Europe and came home with some of the best art in all of them. All the great taste that money can buy--with a nice view out the front window of Central Park and the world passing by on the sidewalk.

A special place. Choose the right exhibit and this is a 5. The Goldfinch and the Girl with the Pearl Earring made this the best experience of 2015 in NYC. Alternatively, no matter the exhibition, the museum must be seen as it always is beautiful as a space and with its collection.
Hidden Great Find. Quick dash through museum turned in to a stroll. Great architecture and gardens with some nice art. Good surprise.

Mind blown.. I don't know why I waited until my fourth visit to NYC to visit the Frick. I have known about it for forty years, and am familiar with the artists and works therein from a long ago art history degree but it is not until you get there and walk through, periodically picking your jaw up from the carpet, that you realize how dense, how distilled, how intense the collection is. Constable. Turner. Vermeer. Hals. Rembrandt. Monet. Manet. Cimabue. Duccio. Reynolds. Fragonard. Gains borough. Bronzing. Holbein. El Greco. And many more. And they are all hanging there in the Frick mansion, very intimate, beautiful decor and interiors unlike the usual galley beige. The whole house is art. More than the sum of its parts. A compact and intense experience. If you can see only one museum in New York make it this one. The Metropolitan can be intimidating and unless you have studied beforehand, hard to get to the things you really want to see. You can get through the Frick in about two hours, including the 15 minutes to see the film about Frick's life and times, and a few minutes to sit quietly and decompress in the fountain atrium. That's about all you can take, or all I could, anyway, before getting to the 'brain full' state.The Frick does not admit children under 10. It is not really a place for younger teens either. Security is rigorous. Check your coat. No photography except by the fountain. You won't need pictures anyway as most of the artworks are in the leading survey textbooks of art history.For $20, this is the greatest bargain in New York city. There is no on-site cafe: I would suggest that after your Frick experience, walk over to Lexington where there is a variety of reasonably priced (by nyc standards ) eateries.I will go there again next time I am in nyc.

A favorite spot for contemplation. This is not just an art museum - it is a wonderful chance to experience a peaceful afternoon in the city. The beauty of the elegant surroundings is worth the admission. Don't rush, but sit with a book, or reflect on the history of this building and the Frick family.
Surprising gem.. A wonderful gallery with a surprising variety. It was great to see it laid out more randomly, not in galleries only by period or artist. Lovely.

A smaller museum with classic style. Love this museum. Most of the collection was purchased by Frick before his death in 1919. So, Dutch Masters rather than abstract artists, a few impressionists, some Renaissance choices.The setting is Frick's house and, in addition to the paintings and sculptures, a central courtyard that is beautiful with statuary and a fountain and beautiful water feature. Takes a couple of hours with a free recorded tour. The recorded tour does not establish the choices but rather you find something you want to know more about and, if it has a number, you just punch it in to the guide.Nice two to three hours visit.

An under the radar museum in the city. A small, but interesting museum. I enjoy the actual building almost as much as the exhibits. They say no cameras, but I did manage to take a picture of the main hallway, when no one was looking!

A New York highlight. This lovely gallery housed in a mansion on the eastern edge of Central Park has a large and eclectic range of artworks, including Holbein, Gainsborough, Constable, Corot, van Dyck, Monet, Sir Henry Raeburn and many, many others. It is uncrowded and peaceful, we passed a couple of hours here quite happily enjoying the art. Highly recommended, this was one of the highlights of our time in New York.

One of the best art and decorative arts collections in the world. We hadn't been to the Frick for many years and, as it's a permanent collection, we thought "been there, done that." We are so glad that we decided to pay a visit to one of the premier art collections in the world. We were reminded what a truly remarkable collection this is. Set in the Frick mansion, a visitor gets to see not only the architecture of a classic Fifth Avenue mansion, but the decorative and fine art mostly as it was displayed during the Frick's tenure there. And what a collection it is!! Masterworks of almost every era and style; no expense was too great for acquisition of the world's greatest art. I would even say that if a visitor has limited time in NYC, then go to the Frick and skip the Met. Less crowds, less hype, less craziness. There is no cafe, but it is conveniently located (just a few blocks south of the Met). I do not know if the audioguides are always included with admission, but they are a good little bonus as you can key in the number of whatever piece you are admiring and hear a little about it. A classic of New York in every way.
Fabulous small musem. Just think, as you walk through this boutique museum that at one time, a family lived here! Small beautiful art collection. Worth the time.

An oasis in the City!. I enjoyed a fantastic couple hours in the Frick and was so glad I chose it over the larger museums nearby. The collection's breadth is stunning, but it feels intimate because of how the art is displayed in the mansion's various rooms. The free audio guide was helpful. I'm a member of my local museum and was able to enter free as a reciprocal member.

Exquisite Small Museum. The museum is shaped by the tastes of one family who had a great deal of money. Their taste in art was excellent, and in a world with very few Vermeers, they managed to own three of them. The museum's collection doesn't include much past 1870 or much before 1300. There are several Turners, a collection of Sevres porcelain, and two rooms with portraits from many eras.On Sunday morning, customers are allowed to pay what they want.
My FAVORITE. This is my favorite museum anywhere. Love it. Love the building, the layout, the art. I could wander in here for hours.

Must See Museum. The Frick Museum is a "blow your socks off" collection of art. Quite simply: If you are visiting New York City, go to this museum. An impressive collection of Turners, Constable, Vermeer, Holbein and more, and beautiful entire room paintings by Fragonard. The house reminded me of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, complete with a beautiful courtyard at its center. Stunning rooms, a fabulous afternoon visit

Amazing pieces. Beautiful collections at the Frick, the art the home and the history are stunning. This is a favorite place to visit. Great for solo travelers and couples seeking a peaceful stroll through a museum,
One of the lovelier museums in NYC. Savor the Frick slowly, and between the diffrent room, sit around its courtyard and enjoy the peaceful feeling this jewel imparts.

Well worth the 20 year wait. I have visited NYC many times but somehow or another I have never gone to Frick even though I wanted to. It was wonderful. We went when it was cold (0) and windy so no so many folks as I would imagine it has normally. Well arranged, great art, furniture, accessories and the building itself is a masterpiece. Did bring to mind the 1%. Frick has given us a present and it is well appreciated and taken card of.Take your time - maybe go through twice to see what you missed the first go around

Terrific space for magnificent art collection.. The Frick Collection reminds me of the Gardner Museum (without the restrictions on placement and additions). Beautiful buildings and grounds (would like to see the grounds in the spring rather than dead of winter). Be sure to sit through the 15ish minute film on Mr. Frick, the building and his art collection

Dutch masters. Portraits and paintings by Rembrandt and Vermeer along with several by English painters. Nice collection of carvings, sculptures, and pottery as well. Located at corner of 5th avenue and 70th street adjacent to Central Park. Audio guides available to supplement your experience.

Heart warming collection. My friends and I spent about three hours in the museum. It is the house that clearly reflected the personality and preferences of the owner: his idea was to surround himself with beautiful pieces of art. Even the women in the paintings were attractive. The only problem I had was the lack of benches in every hall.

A gem of a museum. Tourists always head to the big three museums, MOMA, Metropolitan, and Natural History. Each great and vast. For a less overwhelming museum experience, nothing beats the Frick. A modestly sized collection of astonishing quality and significance, housed in the grand turn-of-the-century Frick mansion on upper east side. You won't be crushed by tour bus crowds at the Frick. All together a serene and lavish art experience.Nice cafe on site, and Central Park is just across 5th Ave.

An English country home, but smaller. A bit disappointed to be honest, it was a bit like going around a country home at home (UK), but with the States being a bit younger (and I do not mean that to sound patronising) I can see how the history of the items appeal to Americans. Lovely courtyard entrance hall. With regard to the question about recommending to traveler - on a budget - all the museums we visited in New York had an entrance fee. All the Smithsonian in Washington were free.

Beautiful house and collection!. Beware...Sunday afternoon visit results in a lot of people as the exhibit fee is by donation from 11-1. Did not know this and would have preferred less crowds. Beautiful mansion and quite a collection of art!
AH! What a museum! Classic!. Small enough to digest it all in one visit. All classics. Whatever you think of who these people were, Frick and Co., they sure knew their art.

Very accessible museum. This is a fascinating museum, it's not too big but gives a great insight into the time. Some lovely paintings and pieces of furniture. Easily doable in a couple of hours. The central courtyard is a very peaceful place to relax after the busyness of New York.

Remarkably well preserved mansion and art collection. It's fascinating to see how wealth that was made in the late 19th century turned into this magnificent mansion. As well, a portion of the art that was collected then remains to this day for us to enjoy. It was good to see this and learn about it.
Chamber museum. Excellent collection in a great mansion - a must "multiple" visits for either a tourist or a local. Great garden too!

Not to be missed. This is a fabulous museum with a feeling of a grand house, which it once was. Home of The Goldfinch, 1654 by Carel Fabritius (1622-1654), which is the central theme in Donna Tartt's novel, The Goldfinch.

One of my absolute FAVORITES. We love small art museums and the Frick is without doubt one of the very best in the world. Its collection of European master paintings and furniture is unparalleled. You see superb Rembrandt, Vermeer, Canaletto, Hals, Ingres, della Francesca, Goya, Bellini, El Greco, van Dyck and Fragonard (to name just a few) literally steps away from each other. It makes me laugh to see Holbein's Sir Thomas More and Oliver Cromwell, mortal enemies in life, hanging near each other. I don't feel exhausted or defeated afterwards. You can easily spend an entire day visiting museums like the Met or the Louvre and feel you've only seen a fraction of what they have and absorbed even less. Instead, I feel elevated, energized by this heady dose of great art. I also love seeing these paintings hanging on the walls of what used to be a private home. It satisfies my fantasies of being extremely wealthy, living in a magnificent mansion on Fifth Avenue, being able afford masterpieces and having the taste to buy the very best.
Incredible house. The building is pretty and for me more intersting than the collection. It is a little bit expensive, but a must see in NYC.
A pocket of wonder - almost a secret haven. Sometimes you are the only person in one of these rooms. Such an amazing place and extremely romantic!

A Masterful Collection. Set in a beautiful mansion house opposite Central Park, this previous home has an El Greco portrait above the mantelpiece, flanked by Holbein's portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell. As well as numerous paintings by grandmasters, my favourite a self portrait by Rembrandt, the furniture, sculptures, collections of Sevres and Limoges were just breathtaking. This is a remarkable collection in a wonderful setting. It is possible to get very close to the artwork, and spend time enjoying and reflecting on the pieces. We spent a very enjoyable three hours and will definitely go back again, highly recommended.
Gem of an exhibit. Treat yourself to a unique art experience in a former railroad magnate's home. Classic art. Quiet, calm surroundings. A sanctuary in the city.
Of Course!. Savor a special small museum! The Frick is sumptuous, historic, and digestible. Visit and revisit as often as possible.
Beatiful architecture. It was on my top list, one of my favorites paintings is there. Sir Thomas More by Hans Holbein. Beautiful museum, the Garden Court its breathtaking

Nice stop for a short visit. Nice refuge from the city on a cold winter day. A few areas were closed to visitors, what we did see was nice, with a sprinkling of works by big name Renaissance artists.The building is beautiful, the furniture did not excite me. How much gilded wood can one person want?It was about a 1.5 to 2 hour stay, but we didn't do the audio tour. Nice, but not stunning like the Barnes in Philly or Walters in Baltimore.

Somewhere you just have to visit. Better than the Guggenheim, better than MoMA. If you're in NYC you really do need to visit the Frick Collection. The art is breathtaking. I had visited before, but my work colleagues who joined me on this visit were left open-mouthed by this wonderful collection. Don't miss any of it, but especially don't miss the Holbeins.

Interesting, but nothing spectacular. It´s worth a visit, specially to get a glimpse of the mansion and lifestyle of the top 1% in the 1900´s, but the collection in itself, albeit with some interesting pieces, didn´t draw a lot of my attention.

Must see!. Our New Yorker friends recommended us as no.1 the frick collection. So we went there,it's cosy and small and beautiful,absolutely wonderful!
They have small collection and they are great and also the beautiful garden!! And the house ,the collection itself is worth to see..
I loved there!

A Quiet and Magnificent Refuge. It was twenty years or more since I visited before, the shock of its tranquility in the buzz that is New York wasn't diminished by time, it is one of the most extraordinary houses I have visited anywhere in the world, quite surreal even, and thrilling if you are interested in Art. Two of my favourite paintings in the whole world are in this house, one a Holbein, tucked modestly to the side of a fireplace in one of the main reception rooms; which, by the way, has an El Greco over the mantle. Do not miss a visit to this exceptional building, with its superb collection of paintings. No cafe, and I loved that about it also.

The last great mansion on Fifth Avenue. The Frick Collection is important for the outstanding collection of paintings, sculptures, porcelain, and furnishings in the last great mansion still standing on Fifth Avenue. It's quite an experience to see works of art exhibited in much the same way they were when the Frick family lived in the house at the turn of the twentieth century. At his death in 1919, Henry Clay Frick turned over the mansion and it's entire contents to New York for a museum. Open since 1935, the Frick Collection and the mansion are carefully preserved and thoughtfully presented. One of my favorite museums in the City.

My favorite museum in New York. I love the Frick. The Gainsborough's are amazing as well as the fine furniture and ceramics Henry Frick amassed for his collection. The Atrium is a peaceful area to sit and absorb the beauty of this collection. Free on Sundays at certain times.

Intensely personalized collection. It is always interesting to see a collection chosen by an individual and in the setting for which each piece was chosen. The building itself is incredible, and the library in particular has a very livable, even homey atmosphere. The art collection is high quality and the positions of the paintings are perfectly chosen for balance, power, and in the case of those in the library, a bit of irony. The full-length portraits in the oval room are spectacular. The complimentary audio guide is well worthwhile giving interesting commentary.

One of my most favorite museums in New York. One of my favorite museums in New York for sure. It is not huge, unlike the Met, but every single item on view is a masterpiece. It is usually not too crowded and you can enjoy this amazing museum at your own pace.

Amazing. The Frick collection was absolutely amazing. Walking in you are instantly taken back to the turn of the 20th century. Amazing and stunning artworks by Turner, Vermeer, Constable, Van Dyke and many many more! The building itself is absolutely breathtaking. Would highly recommend paying a visit!!!Sunday admission is pay as you wish from 11am-1am!

One of the best attractions of the city. A small but not modest site. A heavy art collection of a huge value. One hour tour in a period of glamour. The villa is beautiful, the location is Confortable and it is reasonable to visit the museum with kids that refuse to go to museums.

Well worth the $20 admission. Extraordinary private mansion on 5th Ave next to lower Central Park, purpose built in the early 1900s to display a first rate art collection. Many unique and influential works of art, including the top half of Edouard Manet's "The Dead Toreador," the bottom half of which graces the National Gallery in DC. Multiple El Grecos, other gorgeous renaissance pieces and an extraordinary Rembrandt self-portrait. Budget 2 hours to see the whole thing. Cost is $20, half that for students. Price includes audio guide, which works very well and is tremendously informative about individually numbered paintings and decorative arts/furniture. No photos allowed except in the central court, which is a pity because the whole place and the collections are so unique and beautiful.
Wonderful Winter Respite. The Frick is a delightful place to spend an hour on a gray chilly afternoon. The atrium with its plantings is a soothing place to get away from the hecticness of NYC.

Beautiful art in a beautiful surrounding. This is a stunning collection of works in an absolutely beautiful setting. It's a little expensive though. I think they should make it slightly cheaper so that more people can have access to enjoy.

A preserved industrialist billionaire's art-filled mansion. Going to the Met is like opening a giant tomb and leafing through different ages, eras, continents, items, philosophies, and collections from numerous viewpoints - the History of Art. We see portions of much larger collections, and it's a tasting menu from all over the world from various centuries. It's essentially the mainstay of being an art-savvy New Yorker. However, the Frick is the preserved and expanded private collection of a key figure from the Industrial Age in the US. The paintings, sculptures, furnishings and housewares are among the best of their times, and the focus is the Renaissance through the Impressionists, as selected much by Frick himself. This is much smaller than the Met, and it's a jewelry box of great works - by comparison, a nifty photo book versus the weighty tomb. If you are touring the great private smaller museums of the US, the Frick is on the list with the Getty, the Wadsworth Atheneum, the Isabella Stewart Gardner, and the Barnes. It's a must see for any enthusiast of 16th-20th century European fine arts.
Just perfect in every way. We only had 1.5 hours to visit a gallery and this was just a perfect place. Easy access, no queues, stunning art and sculpture and easy to navigate.

Stunning collection . Worth the visit - even if you don't appreciate art the style and story of the house and its owner are fascinating enough. Enjoyed a couple of hours here on a Sunday - if you go between 11-1pm you pay what you like.
Beautiful art intimate setting . Thoroughly enjoyed the art and architecture. Haven't experienced another museum like this in NYC. I highly recommend it.

Beauty and elegance, an art museum for even those who don't think they would like an art museum. If you want to see the way the other half lived 100 years ago, this is the place. Hard to believe someone actually lived there.

Lovely artwork and property. This was a great outing for family with 3 adults and 3 teenagers as it was cultural, but the museum is small enough that we were able to enjoy it in 1 1/2 to 2 hours. That is about as long as they are willing to humour us! We enjoyed some of the lovely artwork in this collection and the building itself was beautiful. A very nice afternoon and also a lovely neighborhood surrounding it.

Wonderful collection in an intimate setting. I love the Frick Collection. I've been many times. They have a really nice, small collection, mostly collected by Henry Clay Frick, one of the robber barons turned philanthropic. Among their varied collection are two of the fewer than 40 Vermeers on public display.The setting is intimate and the pace is relaxed.

A former home has become a tranquil sanctuary of art. The former home of industrialist Henry Clay Frick, is an elegant sanctuary, a brief respite from the hustle and bustle of the city, and a repository of some of the most important European masterworks to be seen in New York. Strolling through this stately mansion, in which many of the furnishings (carpets, tables, lamps, etc. of the late 19th and early 20th century) fill the galleries in which the paintings are arrayed (never crowded, always arranged in the context of the rooms) is a graceful, relaxing process. There are some remarkable examples of paintings by Holbein, Vermeer, El Greco, Rembrandt and Titian regally installed. A lively Rococo room with Boucher paintings, delightful Impressionist works and a good selection of Flemish paintings are found as you stroll, In the center of this palatial space is a lovely little garden with foliage, benches and a fountain. The words luxurious and tranquil come to mind. There are also special, temporary exhibitions on view, typically held in the lower level galleries. I've been to the Frick too often to count - and I honestly feel that a visit to New York is incomplete without a visit to this magical little musum!
lesser know but incredible. Not as well known as some of the other art musuems in New York City but very interesting and even has the rare Vermeer here and there.

NYC Frick - Very Enjoyable. We really enjoyed our trip to the NYC Frick Collection. The collection is wonderful and the mansion is the perfect venue. I enjoyed the mansion tour almost as much as the collection. The information provided with the headsets were very informative for each piece and not overdone. I would definitely recommend a tour to both history and art lovers. The video was interesting as well. On our next trip to Pittsburgh, we have the original Frick Mansion on our list.NOTE: If you are on a budget, you might want to stop by on Sunday mornings when they offer donation payments for admission.

Lovely Small Museum. We went first thing Sunday morning. There was a small line-up but it moved very quickly. Suggest visiting Sunday from 11 to 1 because you can pay what you wish. Unfortunately, we should have visited this after the Met - but anything would be let down.The museum is lovingly preserved and all the guards are friendly, knowledgeable and keen to please. The courtyard is a beautiful oasis in a busy city. For me, seeing the Renoir from afar on the staircase (unfortunately cordoned off) was worth it.

Solitude In The City. I've been a member here for many years. It's a special museum because it's small and intimate. Any time of the week or day is good to come, but I prefer during the week when there seem to be fewer people. I highly recommend taking a slow stroll through using one of the provided audio devices.

Best Small Museum in the US. This is just a great museum. I have been coming here for years and am still amazed, thrilled, enchanted. The diversity of art and the genius of the collection just nourish my soul.

Astounding array of paintings. The Frick Collection is astounding in the sheer number of works hanging by all the masters. I thoroughly enjoyed the Frick, but my only criticism, and it's a weak one at that, is that there are perhaps too many works hanging in too close proximity to each other and the experience becomes a little overwhelming.
Simply Stunning!. Such a beautiful place to visit. You feel as if you're stepping back into an elegant age. A must see!

An extraordinary gem of a gallery. What a fabulous gallery, one of the highlights of our trip. The variety, quantity and quality of art works in such an intimate, personal setting is really quite breathtaking. We happened to visit during Sunday's 'pay as you wish' period and I would gladly pay full price to go back again - it's worth every penny (or cent).
Wonderful. You simply can't go wrong going here. The space is amazing and the collection is expertly curated. Always a gem
Gem on East Side. The collection is superb yet small enough to spend time with and really enjoy! Felt like an oasis after spending the morning at Natural History Museum and Central Park.

Fabulous paintings in a sumptuous setting. The Frick Collection offers an amazing collection of paintings in very beautiful surroundings. The house is a work of art in itself and the audio commentary was both interesting and informative. Well worth a visit!

Lovely quiet sanctuary with stunning art collection.. It was lovely to revisit this collection. Haven't been for a long time. Definitely take the audio as part of your visit, as it is extremely worthwhile. A quiet sanctuary in the middle of Manhattan.

100% Delightful experience. This is visit number three and every time is different. It is hard to leave the building as the atmosphere is so tranquil and the art commanding! Full of priceless masterpieces and many with a story behind them. Brilliant to see so many treasures housed in this one time home of the man himself.
Our favorite art museum in New York. A wonderful collection. We've been there several times. It's got great art set in an interesting and beautiful mansion.

Beautiful mansion w excellent collection European paintings and decorative arts. This is a museum that has an extensive collection of art collected by Mr Frick (who made his fortune in steel in the late 1800s). According to the movie shown there every 15 minutes, he built the home around 1916 planning for the home to be a museum.And what a collector he was- a Cimabue and Duccio (early Italian Renaissance), Della Francesca, Titian, Vermeers, Rembrandt, Monet, Goya, el Greco, etc. admission is $20 (free on Sunday's). No children under 10 are allowed. There are free audio tours available.
Filled with History. This home is beautiful and the art collection just cannot be compared. It is really awesome the way the rooms were left exactly as they were when inhabited by Carnegie.

Beautiful Museum!. This is one of my favorite private collections in NYC! THe centrally located indoor fountain with garden is such a lovely area to sit and reflect. It could be fun to have a private party in this space!

Magnificent x Two. The Frick Mansion is a tour unto itself apart from the superb art collection found therein. Together it makes an experience well worth the price of admission. The self-guided tours enhance the visual feast with explanations and details of the house, its artifacts and spectacular collection of significant works of art. The collection reflects Henry Clay Frick's personal taste and runs well within a type. Portraits abound largely of one period of time and with only one American painter, Whistler. There is a small room of early Italian art and enamels on metal. Furniture pieces are art objects also. Take advantage of the twenty minute film giving the biography of the benefactor as well as information about the mansion and the collection. It is directly across the street from Central Park on the Northeastern side. In good weather the trip can include activities there. We were just there, winter of course, and it was still a wonderful use of time.

Favorite Museum in New York. If you are a fine art lover/ enthusiast but are overwhelmed by enormous museums come to the Frick. This transformed Upper East Side mansion is now one of the premier art destinations in the city offering both a fantastic collection and beautiful setting. The museum typically has interesting temporary exhibits and events. If you are short on time, the majority of the museum can be visited and seen in less than two hours. The museum is affordable compared to other attractions and activities in NYC.
what a gem.. I have never seen such a diverse collection of art in a private collection. It was incredible. Well worth the price.

Small, well-planned, well-explained. The Frick Collection remains my favorite "doable" gallery. The admission fee includes an audio guide which provides excellent explanations for each numbed object. The explanations usually start with the story of the image itself, then about the artist and its creation and finally a note about how or why Mr. Frick obtained it. I particularly liked the pairing of paintings bought for the collection with the explanations juxtaposing them. At first, I was disappointed with the no photos policy; however, this forces us to spend more time with the artworks in a meaningful manner. Well curated and an oasis amidst the hubbub of NYC life.

Permanent collection of masterpieces does not change...but,. the new addition gives more room for other pieces. The former home of Mr. Frick, a steel magnate and partner of J.P. Morgan an d other such men of that era. Definitely worth a trip

Best small museum in the world !. Frick collection has everything a art collection should have ! Turner, Constable, Degas,Goya, El Greco, Vermeer, you name it the Frick Collection has it. Wonderful manor house where everything seems to be in the wright place. A must see in NY
Beautiful Art Gallery. This place is a must see for any lover of art. The Frick is a wonderful collection of classic art in a marvelous setting. A person could spend several hours here.
The Frick Collection. The Collection is housed in a building that was the home of the Fricks. It's a great combination of paintings by well known artists as well as furniture and decorative arts.

An Amazing Collection. Each time I come here I'm always delighted and astounded by the wealth of the Frick Collection. This is a must do if you only have limited time to visit a museum on NYC. One of the finest collections in the world of fine art.

My favourite museum in the world. This museum has the best painting of every period selected. Where on earth can one find 4 Rembrandts, 2 Turners in one room? This solarium holds about 30 paintings, I'm not sure. I love the Fragonnard salon, and the private library and study of Mr. Flick. Can't say enough good things about this museum. It will not tire one, or overwhelm one as do th Louvre, or British Museum , or even the Met Mus.
nothing like being rich if you want to collect art. wonderful museum for art aficionatos. contains masterpieces of european artists. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful collection. A must see in New York city. Loved the fine china collection. Not a huge museum, so take your time to really soak it in.

My favourite museum. The collection is mind blowing and so is the history and the story behind the construction of the building/home and is intimate and beautiful. Highly recommend and enjoy the beautiful art and atmosphere. Satisfies art and architecture lovers.

Unbelievable. Private collection of amazing paintings, sculptures and even the detail of the rooms themselves. Definitely use the audioguide to get the most out of the visit. Not for young children at all.

What a great collection. A remarkable collection, both in terms of the number of works as well as their quality. The audio guide is quite good too: it gives the right level of detail but is not too long.
Beautiful building, timeless art.. I went here for an alumni function. It is a beautiful place, gracious and peaceful. The art is timeless.

Wonderful. You will truly get the feeling that you are living the life of the Frick family. The art collection is stunning. The floor to ceiling murals are magical. Go - You will find some perfect inspiration.

A gem. We live in New York and we visit the Frick about once a month. It's like a home a way from home. We come to visit the paintings that have been hung in the space spaces for decades and see the wonderful exhibitions. If you are visiting it is a much more pleasant museum than its larger neighbors.

Frick is my cup of tea. We have been to art museums all over the world and while $20 is a bit steep, it's NYC where everything costs more than expected. I loved the relaxed atmosphere and house setting backdrop in which to enjoy the widely varying Frick collection. Each room was a surprise. Wish I had known about the Frick App before I went. While we didn't have time to take the docent tour I did walk by one, and the guide seemed well versed, easy to hear and understand and I was a bit jealous of the participants. Like the Freedom Trail in Boston which seems to be a tourist thing that locals ignore, many NYC folks have never been inside the Frick and don't know what they are missing. I made the quick trip to NYC specifically to enjoy the Frick and was not disappointed. I will go back another time for the bigger establishments. They need to lower the price for the 60 plus crowd. 65 is too long to wait. I almost missed the view of the painting and stairwell to the second floor. Beautiful wood work and details. Can't wait until the next level opens to the public -- hint hint Frick Folks!!

My favourite npNew York museum. My favourite. A beautiful building with a wonderful collection, and a chance to see how the nineteenth century industrialists who created these wonderful collections lived.
Amazing museum. This museum is much, much smaller than the other high-end museums in the city... But this one is second to none. Great small collection in a beautiful building. .

Classical art in a classical setting. The Frick Collection lived up to my expectations. I chose to go there by myself to enjoy a peaceful surrounding in NYC. Entering the museum I sat down in the green garden area, listening to the water sprinkle in the fountain. A quiet, beautiful green lung in classical surroundings. Later I walked down to the little gallery downstairs and looked at the impressive rennesainse illustrations exhibited there. Amazing!

Only Highlights. Beautiful museum to spend 1-1,5 hours.Plus:- beautiful building and collection with only great painters represented (Rembrandt, Monet, Goya, Degas, Vermeer, Titian, Van Eijk, El Greco, Turner, etc.)Minus:- no kids allowedBit of a strange collection though. Apart from the big names it's hard to find a connection between these works. It's a bit of a Highlights-through-Art-History-Tour. But beautiful indeed.
Delightful. We try to visit here during each of our annual visits to New York City. Small but delightful collection in an amazing building. A don't miss museum.

My favourite gallery in New York.. I love this place. The setting is beautiful and there's a lot of space to just sit and observe the work. The definite highlight is the drawing room which was renovated to accommodate the Fragonard collection of boiseries called “The Progress of Love". This set of 4 in the Rococo styles is widely considered to be Fragonard's best, and some of the best work of the 18th century. If you look closely at the last painting, The Lover Crowned, Cupid's quiver has no arrows, because his work is done :)

Transport Yourself to Another Time. This is a beautiful, sprawling museum with so much to see. I find the Frick to be intensely romantic...filled with lush art and a sensual courtyard where one can ponder life in another time. There are a few Vermeers here and many Dutch masters, but my favorite little piece of art is a trompe l'oeil painting by Jean-Étienne Liotard. You might not notice it....but it's outstanding. I've posted a photo of it.

Beautiful Building. I guess you can never run out of museums in NY. This was one we had never visited before. It is located in the former Frick mansion on Fifth Avenue. You can go either for the building or for the art collection, but enjoying both together make a worthwhile afternoon.

Do not miss the Frick!. After a disappointing 45 minutes at the Guggenheim, we walked the 18 short blocks south and enjoyed a fascinating and wonderful visit to the Frick Collection. Admission includes an audio player and most of the ample artworks, furniture, rooms, sculpture and pottery have accompanying commentary that is extremely informative and entertaining. We were there for about 2 1/2 hours and enjoyed seeing art by world masters: Rembrandt, Vermeer, Gainsborough, Manet, and many, many others. Several of the pieces are world famous "I know this!" pieces, and the commentary gives the back story and/or speaks of various historical and artistic elements within the painting. The Frick mansion is impeccably preserved and it gives you the feeling that you are stepping back in time. This is a MUST SEE if you are in NYC! If you've enjoyed to the Barnes in Philly, you'll love the Frick.

A wonderful museum setting. The mansion is beautiful and makes for a wonderful setting in which to view the art. Each work is numbered and you learn about it from an audio device you carry. See the short movie first to get the history of the place. It is interesting that Frick (a Gilded Age robber-baron) mandated how the art would be displayed with works from different periods and styles intermingled. A clever idea that works, thanks to Frick's eye for fine art. Wonderful way to spend an afternoon, and the atrium is a lovely spot to relax as well.
A Must See. Of course, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is a first priority...but don't miss the Frick Collection. Thinking of all the art and this home as part of personal collection is mind boggling.

A museum not to be missed.. The Frick was built by a wealthy industrialist who acquired some of the most renowned paintings in the world. This had been his home before it became a museum after his death, so you can feel that you are visiting a private place. It is not too large and very doable.

Good small museum and interesting insight into great wealth. This is a fine small museum with some excellent pieces. It should not be compared to larger museums or museums with specialized collections. It has a bit of everything and all of high quality. What I found most interesting was the building in which it was housed, which was an individual's home. Flick must have been extremely wealthy for his era to have had such a palatial home. Amazing.

Fabulous collection for art lovers. The Frick houses an amazing art collection put together by a late 19th century robber baron. Magnificent work, well organized, well-cragged audio tour. What a treasure!

Interesting afternoon.. The Museum is very unusual in that it was built as a house, but with the intention of turning into a Museum. One has to watch the documentary about Mr. Frick and his love for art, to understand what you are looking at. It is wonderful.

Surprisingly large collection & without the Metroploitan's crowds. We were staying on 63rd street on the east side and had walked past the Frick a few times without even realising it was there (including the day we walked up to the Guggenheim, ironically!)I would argue that the Frick collection is better, though unarguably the Guggenheim appeals to a greater variety of tastes and, of course, there's the building's own architecture.But the Frick appeals on a number of levels too. As an Australian not familiar with New York architecture, I found the display rooms fascinating in themselves! And to the painting-buff (there are more paintings than anything else) there is very much a European bent - I'm getting the idea that Americans don't think very highly of American artists?! Not much weird modern art either, which suited my taste.So if you want to see a lot of Van Dyck, Gainsborough, Boucher and the like, there are some jaw-dropping rooms where you feel surrounded by artworks all demanding and deserving of your attention, because there are not that many people in there to provide it to them!You need to allocate at least 3-4 hours to do justice to the collection, then grab lunch after you leave at one of the cafes on the upper east side, as the Frick is not a tourist hub by any means and you can't eat there.Finding the Frick was a serendipitous discovery and perhaps my highlight of the trip.

the epitome of galleries. quiet , intimate and loaded with treasures. the original house is beautiful restored and decorated. a small queue to get in but worth the wait and fee, the garden is very pretty and they allow sketching in the galleries

My Favorite New York Museum. Having lived in Manhattan, I often went on excursions with visiting friends. One of the places I told them not to miss is the Frick Collection. I would say that if you're uptown and don't have a lot of time to spend, this would be the place to go if you want to see a fabulous collection of masterpieces all in one place. It's a gorgeous mansion on 5th avenue, and it has a fascinating history. You'll find Rembrandt, Fragonard, Romney, Turner, Whistler and other great artists represented in a beautiful setting. Yes, I give it 5 stars.

Very good collection and interiors, we did enjoy. I do recommend to visit it. The collection is really good and the building and interiors are impressive too. As opposite to Met the museum is not that large but very atmospheric and the collection is more focused. On Mondays there is pay-as-you-wish admission till lunch time. At least it was in Jan 2016.

Exceeds expectations both in art and its setting.. There are only 34 authenticated Vermeer paintings in existence; three of them are here. The rest of the art is a who's who of most major European painters. But even if there was no art the building itself would be well worth seeing. Of course, the art is there, and the free audio guide provides excellent info in just the right amount of detail. A thoroughly enjoyable experience.The only criticism: there is no food available inside or anywhere immediately nearby. Go after a meal.

Great restoration and collection. It doesn't get 5 stars, because if you only have 1 afternoon to do something, go to the Met or the MoMA or the Museum of Natural History, but if you have extra time, this is a great example of the opulence and lifestyle of New York at the turn of the last century, and the art collection is very impresssive.

Pretty cool. Needing to wash hands first.. If you like looking at how "the other half" live, then this is a place to start.Very old and swanky stuff that you simply MUST NOT TOUCH.Some great historical pieces of art and decor that's bound to bore the kids.If you do decide to feel how smooth the table is, be sure to distract the security guard... there is one in each room.... they are ready and willing to pounce.Still, worth the visit, if not for just an hour or so.

Wow long line for pay what you will 11-1pm Sunday. Apparently well known gem as we waited in a line for 30 minutes but well worth it. Just exquisite pieces - especially the Rembrandts, Gainsboroughs, Titians, Van Dycks, and more. Don't miss it. My favorite museum in the US!

For Museums Lovers. The more authentical collection in a incredible mansion.
To do list.
Important tables and perfect for specialists
Nice break from the Met. This is everything that the Met is not. When you get tired of the crowds and vastness of the Met, come here for a quaint authentic art experience.

Just wonderful. A two storey townhouse on Central Park? Hard to believe but true; and what a place! The exhibits from Constable to Fragonard, El Greco to Gainsborough utterly superb, but you cannot ignore the porcelain or the exquisite bronzes. Not a huge museum but enough to keep you happily occupied and then want to g back for more. So why only 4 stars you may ask? An almost total lack of seating in the major rooms to allow you to tarry awhile and just enjoy with a modicum of leisure some of the masterpieces. Oh my aching feet! However, a must see while in NYC. Oh, and it's free on Sunday mornings - result!

Must do if you're an art lover. What a great discovery! We left the Frick as an option in case we had time to visit... we are glad we did! More than a collection, it's also a stunning house that takes live with every piece of artwork. If you have time, watch the video about Mr Frick's live.A total must!

DO NOT MISS THE FRICK. The setting is unparalleled, with gorgeous galleries, and gardens to match. It's a beautiful place just to walk by on the street, when you find yourself in the neighborhood. ...but go inside. Go inside, and walk through the beautifully converted mansion and find bronzes, Chinese porcelain, Rembrandt, El Greco, landscapes, on and on. You will feel as though your inside a magical place that seems much bigger on the outside than it is inside.

A hidden gem. A visit to the Frick collection is a must. It is an amazing experience. The collection is mostly displayed the way mr Frick left it when he died in 1919. The house , artworks and furniture are truly amazing. There are paintings by Rembrandt, Degas, Titian, Monet , Manet, Constable, Renoir, el Greco and lots more...some wonderful examples of European furniture with original tapestry coverings . The mansion is magnificent and probably the last one standing in the centre of NYC . It is well worth spending two hours here to soak up the artwork and environment. The visiting Sarto exhibition is fascinating as well .... It is wonderful to leave the hustle and bustle of this dynamic city and immerse oneself in the wealth and beauty if s generation past ...

The Amazing Art Treasures of a Gilded Art Railroad Baron-A MUST SEE. The Frick Collection is housed in one of the remaining houses of America's railroad barons of the Gilded Age that once lined Fifth Avenue. Henry Clay Frick built the house and its collection. It is largely preserved as it was during his lifetime, and presents a rare chance to see the taste and power of a single figure. European art is the high point here--and this a great place to see three Vermeer works (only 40 are known in the world) as well as Gainsborough, Holbein, Rembrandt among others. Each piece is outstanding. American art is represented by some huge Whistler portraits. An absolute must see in NYC.
Exquisite. The quality of the collection and its tasteful presentation matched by the dignity and classical order of the museum. Invigorating...
loved it. spent an afternoon at the Frick. A highlight of our trip. Add it to your list of galleries (we loved it WAY more than the Guggenheim) But we love renaissance art. Incredible collection

Iconic art - beautiful building - not crowded. This is my favorite art museum in NYC. It's got a nice mix and it's not overwhelming. Fewer people so you can inspect some of the art closely without feeling that people are waiting for you to get out of the way.
Wow. This is the most beautiful collection of art i have ever seen. Each room is different but all so incredible. The decor is breath taking. This is the only "museum" worth going to in NYC.

A must see for art lovers.. Often overlooked, this amazing historical house has one of the best collections of classical European paintings you'll see in America. Don't miss the short movie about Frick whose money made it all possible.

The Best..... The Frick collection is wonderful! Because it used to be someones residence makes it all the more 'real' unlike some larger museums. The exhibits are top class from paintings by the Masters to beautifully preserved timepieces to fabulous porcelein. Absolutely stunning!

What's not to like?. As I have written before, the Frick is one of my two favorite museums in the world, The Hague's Mauritshuis being the other, and no visit to New York is complete for me unless I've paid a visit to the Frick. This time there was a very good special exhibition of works by Andrea del Sarto. The permanent collection is not to be missed, of course, and as usual I admired Holbein's portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, the three Vermeers, Bronzino's young man, Hobbema's and Turner's landscapes, and other treasures. This time I saw for I think the first time Van Dyck's full-length portrait of Sir John Suckling, my favorite among the Cavalier poets. Had it been stored away for a time? Never mind, it was good to see.

Beautiful small museum with private collection of the Masters. The Frick Collection is a unique, beautiful and small museum with everything of excellent taste. Sometimes there is an interesting special showing but the permanent art collection itself is a rewarding experience.

Small but Amazing. The Frick collection is one of the best in the world. In the former mansion of Henry Clay Frick on 5th Ave overlooking Central Park you will see some of the most spectacular portraits anywhere. A haunting picture of a young John the Baptist by Andrea del Sarto was my favorite. Well worth a visit!

Lovely museum. At the moment there is a wonderful exhibition at the Frick on Andrea del Sarto, which was the reason we made sure to go there on this visit but I always enjoy the collection and I love the building.
Great museum . I'm not a huge art fan, but this museum was really interesting. If you like art and portraits that are part of history, I totally recommend this collection!

A very unique experience.. This is a quiet and unique place, with a very interesting story behind it. We enjoyed the collection very much, then stopped and heard the story about the mansion and Mr. Fricke. The back story just added to the experience and we went through again. We also asked questions of the collections staff, and they were very knowledgeable, especially about the Huntress sculpture (which is beautiful).

How The Top 1% Lived. The Frick is located at 70th and 5th Avenue across from Central Park. The building is basically the former home of the Frick family and much of the collection was theirs and was displayed in their home. The home stretched from 70th to 71st along 5th Avenue. Whether you like the art pieces, it is fascinating to see how this family lived and collected art. Include the Frick are your tour of NYC museums.

A&R in New York. Maybe my expectations were too high because I was a little disappointed about the exhibition. Nice paintings and drawings, some interesting paintings from Rembrandt, Hals en Vermeer but based on advertisement, I expected something more. Also no explanations besides and about the artworks, sometimes not even the artist name. Museum crew was really impolite, if it was an honor to visit the museum. The shop was also disappointing, because there were no cards for sale from the special exposition about the drawings from Andrea Del Sarto.

Best collection of art i've seen. The building itself is one of the biggest draws. One of the few remaining old mansions on the upper east side it is beautiful with a courtyard in the middle. The amount of famous artists in the collection is staggering...even if you only have a rudimentary knowledge of art and artists you will recognise the names. I liked art pieces like the clocks and statutes.Frick at least left behind a legacy that can be enjoyed.

One of the best private collections in the world. An expansive art collection set in an equally expansive private home of the Frick family, converted in the 1930s into a museum for the public. The Frick Collection ranges from portraits of beautiful women by Gainsborough to more personal statements by Goya, Rembrandt, Holbein, el Greco, Hals, and Vermeer. It truly leaves an impression for the paintings, sculpture, and even ceramics to be seen in a home setting, largely displayed as they were at the beginning of the 20th century. During my visit, there was also an excellent exhibit of sketches and paintings by Andrea del Sarto, which was worth cost of admission by itself.Though the Frick collection has grown since Henry Frick's death in 1913, the artwork he purchased is specifically stipulated to stay in the home at all times, meaning you see at least most of the original collection at all times. There is a large indoor courtyard, built onto the home in its conversion to a museum, that is an excellent resting place for reflection. I highly recommend the tours throughout the day, which are led by knowledgeable and enthusiastic guides. Audioguides are included in admission and also highly recommended as most of the art does not have descriptions on the walls.Note that there is a small giftshop, but no cafe or food on premises. There are several restaurants nearby, including Maison Laduree, Via Quadronno, and the food stands in Central Park across 5th Avenue.

Very interesting place. Audio guide included in $20 entry fee. There is an app that you can download instead but my IPad mini kept dropping the wifi signal so I used the museum's audio guide instead. No pictures can be taken outside of the courtyard, so having the app will give you access to pictures and audio to enjoy later.

Good small collection for some astonishing paintings . This is definitely worth a visit. A beautiful town house with a truly astonishing collection of paintings and porcelain. Easy to 'do' a huge number of impressive paintings in a very civilised surroundings.

Little Gem. The Frick Collection is a worth a visit. We were very lucky visiting at the time of the 80 years celebration. We heard a lecture from he Director which was fantastic to get a review of the past 80 years and where things were headed. The building is a worth seeing and also the paintings.

Great collection - some staff shocking!. The building, paintings,architecture are amazing and it's quite unbelievable the amount of first class pieces there are in a private collection.What's sad was the miserable staff in some areas particularly the cloakroom - rude beyond belief to customers who are supporting this.This is the supposed land of "have a nice day" and not surly staff who literally throw your coats at you.

Blew me away. This was my first time at the Frick. At first I have to say I thought it was a bit like somewhere trying to be a National Trust property in New York not very well. However once I got to the room with the Holbeins in I was absolutely smitten. I could have looked at them all day and the collection maintained that peak. Overall wonderful.

Outstanding Cultural Experience. It's fair to say I take a passing interest in art at the best of times, but this collection blows you away. If you come to one gallery in New York, this has to be the one. The gallery is an intimate atmosphere and size, with an amazing array of superior works of art on display. From Titians to Turners, Rembrandts and Goyas they are all on display to be admired and enjoyed. Thoroughly recommended.

Beautiful, sedate, and eye-opening about the rich. At one time there were 3 people who lived in this mansion, not counting staff, even though it is the size of a museum. The building is itself beautiful, and the collection contains some truly first rate works of art. It took me a long time to visit, but I enjoyed it enormously.

Best art museum in the world?. I love the Frick! It is small enough that you can get round and see everything without feeling exhausted, and the collection is outstanding. And the building itself is very lovely, with so many period details that just to walk through is a treat. Possibly my favourite attraction in NYC.

What a gem!. I have heard of 'The Frick" my entire life - and when I found myself walking in, I could hardly believe it! This one-time home was planned to hold and present this amazing collection to the public. And it sure does. Not only is the collection simply amazing, but the house itself and its adaptation into a venue for Mr. Frick's collection are just beyond! I did worry about the carpets and floors in this home-turned-museum. They were taking the brunt of dirty shoes, wearing them to splinter and fray. I would like to have seen more protection of those elements of the facility.But to see this magnificent place was a lifelong dream and I was spellbound at every turn! Thank you to the team at The Frick!JG

Art lovers's heaven!. I went to the museum with a friend not expecting much to see since it did not look big outside. I was wrong. I had such a good time appreciating the paintings, furnitures and architectures. It is such a beautiful place to spend a day. I usually don't like everything a rich people collect but this rich person really has good taste. I like almost all the painting on the wall. Every single piece is a candy for your eye. Knowing he did not has much education I wonder who helped him collect all these art work. It is worth your money to visit it.
Relaxing trip. This is a very nice change of pace from other museums in the city. There's a nice garden in the middle, and places to sit and reflect. The building itself is gorgeous.

How the really rich lived plus a superlative art collection. Housed in a magnificent mansion on Fifth avenue is one of the nation s premier art collection--Rembrandts, Vermeers, Turners,-- a magnificent Bellini of Saint Francis and across the room a Holbein of Saint Thomas More and an El Greco portrait of another Saint. Also rooms of French art and furniture as well as English. Not to be missed if you like art or historical houses.

Relaxing and magnificent selection of art. Photos in the Frick Collection are only permitted in the central garden, hence why that's the best known part. The rest of the collection is absolutely wonderful. The current special exhibit is Renaissance art, showcasing preliminary and planning sketches of several pieces. The furniture is also curated, which helps reflect that this was a personal residence at one point.

Worth Your Time. This small museum on Museum Mile is full of the old masters in a mansion that is a work of art itself. The art speaks for itself and in a few hours you can view Rembrandt El Greco, Gainsborough, Turner, and Van Dyke to name a few. Take the time to study the drapes, the upholstery on the chairs, the fireplaces and the beautiful garden court.

Must see. If you've done with all the big museums, take a relaxing walk through the magnificent mansion now museum. For fans of the Golden Era of upper Fifth Avenue, you can see a small part of what it meant to live on Millionaire's row. And, see some of the greatest art of the Western World. If you're really lucky, you might catch a concert in the music room.

Interesting small museum. Mr Frick was very probably not a nice man, but regardless how he amassed his tremendous wealth, he put it to good use. His former home (interesting to see, even without the art objects) is now the museum. He concentrated on European masters, and today this small museum is a great place for a 2 or 3 hour stroll.

Amazing place and don't miss it. Recommended by a local and what a treat to see such an amazing collection in such an amazing venue. Constables and Rembrandt mixed with El Greco and Monet..........where else could you see this outside of the Met? This is a feast of amazing collection of old masters and special furnishings and enamels and and and.............. The best value in NYC.

Beautiful Collection. This is a really interesting museum to visit. It is located in what was once Frick's private home, so you get to see both the art and the first floor of the home. I would recommend a visit.

a must see collection. This must be one of the unmissable collections to see and reminds me of the Wallace collection in London in that it is diverse and fascinating.Particularly fond of Lady Hamilton by Romney.Worth a visit just for that.

Easy-in, easy-out. My visit to the Frick Collection was painless as they get. No wait to buy my ticket, and only $10 thanks to a student discount. On Sundays they offer "pay what you wish" for admission, but keep in mind this will attract large crowds. It's not a large exhibit, and I only spent about 1 hour or so going through everything. Sit down and enjoy the peacefulness of the Garden Court or enjoy the Goya, Vermeer, and Bernini artworks. It certainly does not offer as much as the Met, but it is a nice hidden gem in the Upper East Side of New York.

worth the trip. amazing colection of art, porcelain and statues, wonderful home, wish you were allowed to take pictures without a flash, free audio handset most items numbered and short film about mr. Frick's life was interesting. Great for the rainy day we were having you can see it all in under 2 hrs.

For Art Museum Post-Grads (and Cosby Voyeurs?). After you have been to the Metropolitan Museum and/or MOMA a dozen times you will want to start taking in the Frick, the Whitney and then start Gallery hopping.Aside from the gorgeous collection and building, the Frick Library is renowned for its Provenance research so you may want to pop in and talk to some librarians - they have access to some balconies with good views of Central Park and on the back side you can see onto Bill Cosby's brownstone.

Great museum, free on a Friday morning. A museum of just the right size, you can see everything in a morning and go for a stroll in Central Park afterwards. Great artwork, fantastic building and furniture. Incredible views of the park.

World class art collection in a gilded age mansion. Former residence of Henry Clay Frick, contains some of famous artworks, including a couple of iconic Holbein pictures of St. Thomas More and his nemesis Cromwell. 2 Vermeers, Several Turners, a famous view of the Salisbury Cathedral by John Constable. Alas during my visit, my favorite Ingres portrait of Comtesse d'Haussonville is on loan to the Prado for their Ingres exhibition. Nevertheles, still a lot of beautiful artworks to vies, and since this is a private home, you can see these works at leisure and afterward, you can rest at the beautiful atrium. What impressed me, all the antique clocks in the house actually works! An impressive look of how the 1% lifestyle then.

One of the greatest museums in the world. There is no sense criticizing the Met. It is a world class museum, but the Frick is a jewel. This is a manageable collection in a relatively small space (for a museum, not for a house which it once was). And the artwork is extraordinary. Henry Frick had impeccable taste in art, furnishings, tapestries etc. This is a must see.

What a beautiful setting. It was my first visit to the Frick even though I have been to NYC many times. Besides the collection and the exhibits, the setting is beautiful. It was so interesting to wander around this incredible mansion.

A museum for non-museum goes. Very approached museum with magnificent works. It is a house, a private collection in private setting right across from Central Park. This is one that is not overwhelming and so easy to get through. Francois Boucher collection of lovely works to name just one. I would do it again and enjoy it equally as much.

Worth the entrance fee.. Became one of my favorite museums in NYC. It is different than a normal museum, because it feels like you're just visiting someones home. If you go on Sundays from 11am to 1pm you will pay what you want. The setting alone is nearly as impressive as the art collection. If you're an art lover you cannot miss this museum.

Smaller intimate collection of art. It is not the Met, but it doesn't claim to be. It has a wonderful collection and it is an easier space to navigate rather than the larger museums. The special exhibitions are a joy.
Small but fabulous museum. Share the opulence of the robber baron age. Fabulous collection. Small, manageable with plenty of places to sit down.

Glimpse of yesteryear. Another art collection In another mansion turned museum. Been to several but this, as most, continues to awe me. The building is fantastic (just wish more was open to the public) and the art collected by the Frick's is impressive. However, what was even more impressive was the visiting collection by Andrea del Sarto...his studies are simply amazing. Unless you want to rush through, plan about 1 1/2 to 2 hours to wander the rooms. Is it worth is? Probably not quite but what else can one do in NYC for $20?

Oasis of art-loving intimacy in the hectic Metropole. I am still wondering what I like the most: the well chosen collection of Belgian, Dutch, Spanish and other mainly European Grand Masters in the Fine Art or the impressive Home of the former New York richness, surrounded by tall concrete. The Frick collection breathes history without a need of words & is worth a visit if you have any imagination. You do not enter a museum, you set foot on a piece of New York history. This small and intimate garden of art is a huge contrast with the overwhelming but oh so busy MET.

This used to be someone's home!. A art gallery housing so of the world's best art in an stunning uptown former residence. Couple this with a visit to the Guggenheim or the Met and you've mad your way down the museum mile.

Oasis of culture and calm. a beautiful setting, with unique traveling exhibits. Setting is the repurposed mansion of one of the friends of Andrew Carnegie, one of the millionaires on THE AVENUE of the 20th century NYC that made New York the dream city it became. This part of Fifth Avenue has not been degraded, the way the shopping monster between W 57th and W. 42nd Streets has become. Here, in the E 70s, you get a sense of calm and opulence, tastefully done. Go to this part of town to slow down. Use the Frick as a quiet station for relaxation. There is a wonderful concert series during the year, but you should go on the website to get the schedule and order far in advance of your visit, to make sure you can get in,.
Lovely museum. This is a beautiful space, well laid-out and peaceful. I enjoyed the exhibits and the atmosphere a great deal.

A taste of 19th century Robber Baron splendor. The star of the Frick collection is not so much the art in the 19th century mansion, but the mansion itself. it is a joy to walk inside, the very model of English Style restrained splendor. The paintings themselves consist of the best of English18th and 19th century panting, including many gainsboroughs. The sculpture and ceramics were very interesting and eclectic. My favorite paintings were the murals made to mockingly reflect the artwork on the walls in a few of the chambers. This house was partially designed to house Frick's collection, so it is a perfect setting. One is not allowed to see the living quarters of the Fricks, which is a real shame. If you're not a fan of 19th century English art or fancy Robber Baron manors, you might want to give this one a pass.

A must-see. For anybody who's interested in great art, furniture and porcelain, but above all, just to see how the industrial greats of 19th and early 20th century North America lived and spent their vast wealth, this is an absolute must-see. Intimate, with jaw-dropping art, it's like walking round a friend's house, albeit a very wealthy friend! Highly recommended.

Endlessly wonderful. I go every time I am in New York. At this point I only visit my favourite paintings, but there are so many of them. In my experience, this is the best small collection in the world. Mr Frick had an eye to match his substantial wallet: he bought the best and installed them in a lovely setting.

A must see attraction. The Frick collection takes you back to the days when titans of business competed to see who could buy the most high-end artwork and biggest house on Central Park. One of my favorite museums on the east coast.
Lovely museum. Really lovely little art gallery / museum. Easily done in an hour or so with great artwork and good location to do with other museums
Art displayed in a naturalistic setting. Have been a member for years. This is a museum to go if you want art in small doses, but high quality. Nothing like going to the home of a mogul...

The best museum in New York. For a moment, imagine what it was like to live on Fifth Avenue in the home of Henry Clay Frick. Imagine what the combination of limitless wealth and pitch-perfect connoisseurship could produce. Actually, there is no need to use your imagination, as this is what is on display at the Frick Collection. Opinions will vary, but in my opinion this is the best museum experience in New York.

Small gallery...but magnificent in value!!. This collection is in a great old mansion when all 5th ave. was only by mansions, just the building itself deserves the visit. The art collection is fantastic ...without a doubt is one of the BEST attraction in NYC in terms of Art and Architecture.

nice small museum. I like this museum best when there is a special show that I want to see. It is a lovely building and a nice experience. I think that out of town visitors with limited time might opt for other museums, but if they have time should definitely be on the short list.

One of My Favorite Places in NYC. If you are an art lover, and have the time (you can't do everything and have to prioritize), the Frick is a jewel. Located in the private mansion of the robber baron who provided coke to the steel industry in Pittsburgh, the setting alone is nearly as impressive as the art (think Vermeer, Vermeer, Vermeer...).

Little Jem East of Central Park. A 'small' collection in compalrison to the sprawl of the Met /MOMA etc. Incredible collection of art and artefacts collected by a single family and housed in a beautiful building that was their home in the 1920-30s. Not usually as busy as the main stream museums but worth a visit
A CLASSIC JEWEL. Every year we make sure that we visit the Frick. It is a lovely venue and the artwork is fantastic, from Vermeer to Turner to El Greco and many more. A CLASIC
A museum that give you great art. And a glimpse of life in the Gilded Age. A You get to wander around Frick's home, decorated with beautiful furniture and some of the finest art ever collected.

A must visit if you like great art in a home setting. The Frick is a wonderful museum. Now featuring the works of Andrea Del Sarto, but full of notable art from the great artists of Europe. Photos (even with Flash off) not allowed which is a shame, but all else was great. Don't miss a visit here! And yes, they honor North American Reciprocal for Museums. From Vermeer to Gainsborough, don't miss it.

Superior collection in an intimate setting!. World class paintings,sculpture,and decorative arts abound. Gainsborough's astound, Whistlers amaze, Boucher, Rembrandt , and Vermeer.....and many more. And even though this was a mansion of the Gilded Age....the setting is on a human scale....its just a jewel!
Enjoyed the afternoon visit. We enjoyed the Frick collection and found the history of the family and house to be very interesting. Be sure to watch the 20 minute video and then enjoy the art.

Managable. I lived in NYC for twenty years and went to the Frick often. It is one of the best art museums in the United States and is not as overwhelming at the Metropolitan Museum of Art which is further up Fifth Avenue. If it was good enough for Henry Clay Frick it is good enough for me.

Like viewing art in your own home. This is my favorite art museum in New York. Maybe anywhere. This was once a private collection and it is displayed in his home like he would have displayed it. Rooms are decorated in the time period and the art hangs on the walls. The art is by we'll know old world artist, many pieces recognizable by non art students. You won't find contemporary art. This museum is doable in a few hours. The Frick is not one of the art museums that is listed on many must do in New York City books, but it is a better choice for those looking to spend just an afternoon in an art museum and to view a variety of recognizable artist.

The building alone makes the visit worthwhile.. Limited time allowed one art gallery visit this trip and we chose the Frick because we heard it was smaller that some. But still the number of great pieces was almost overwhelming for us. A great experience!

Awful man Amazing art. When in NYc I always visit the Frick . if only just to see the portraits of Thomas Moore and Thomas Cranmer in the same room. Imagine owning them!! And putting them in the same room. They detested each other! The horrible misanthropic Frick had an amazing eye for art. And the money to indulge it. The house looks small and in consequential from outside,but when you go in. Well it is breathtaking full of french decadence Holbein and Romneys!!! Truly worth every penny. Lovely indoor garden too. Shame Frick such a ........
Don't miss. If you love art but hate the crowds, this might be the place for you. Small and intimate, a gorgeous home built with exquisite craftsmanship. The art is astounding with many great pieces.
A must. We have tried before to go to The Frick, this trip we made it! A definite must for all visitors who like art and history, what a family and what a gift to the world a real treasure.....

Nice gem between the Met and MoMA. As you stroll around Central Park, or are covering those giant museums - Met and MoMA - this is a place you shouldn't miss. A private collection from about a century ago which is open to public. Lovely collection of Goya, Boucher, van Dyck and great Rembrandt's. One of the best collection of European master's.
Great Museum to enjoy the day. Lovely home museum. It is comfortable to wander around the museum, find a piece that strikes you, and sit with it.
The excitement of visiting . I was excited, and I'm eager to visit the Frick Collection. It is quite small museum, which interesting designed has works of Rembrandt, Renoir and El Greco.

Small museum with world class art. Not overwhelming like the Met can be, but very high quality pieces - good for family with teens bc you dont need a ton of time to see it, and it's got both art and beautiful rooms of old furniture and decor

Don't miss this charming museum. Compared to the Met, the Frick Collection is tiny. However, most cities would love to have it as their only art museum.
