Frick, a partner of Andrew Carnegie, designed his house with the long term view of converting it to a museum. It gives the visitor a chance to see how the wealthy lived and at the same time presents an incredible collection of art. I was amazed that three of the known Vermeers are here. (The Met has five) Rembrandt, Goya, El Greco, Fragonard, Turner just to name a few of the works. Even a Cimabue. The tour by a knowledgeable volunteer docent is well worth it. And definitely use the electronic audio guide.
Excellent collection. Very well organized collection of art. Beautiful paintings. Location on the 5th avenue makes it easy to visit.

See world class art, don't get exhausted in the process. The Frick is a wonderful, manageable museum. It is rarely super crowded, and isn't so big that you are overwhelmed by the experience. Instead, spend a leisurely few hours in a magnificent old mansion viewing some very important art. There are often live music performances, which makes for an added bonus.

Worth the time. This was truly an education learning about the history of the house and the owner and his love of art. We truly enjoyed the time spent wandering through the house and listening to the self guided tour. Not sure we even captured everything in one trip. May have to go back!

An artlover's delight. This unique and eclectic collection is presented just as one would at home if ever so fortunate as to have the resources. I loved it and found the suggested route and the audio added immensely to my enjoyment
Quiet and mesmerizing. One of the best museums in New York City. It's picture perfect quiet and the art pieces are exemplary. My favorite are the Rembrandts.

Imagine what must have been like to live in the Golden Age in New York City. The museum is located in the upper east side of Manhattan and it was a beautiful building that used to be the the Frick home. I was imagining how it must have been like to live there, it was huge enough to find your own corner when the weather outside is frightful. I'm glad Henry Frick, who collected all these art pieces for forty years, decided to share them with the world. I would spend no more than an hour here.

A Must See For Art & Architecture Enthusiasts!. Finally took time to visit the Frick Museum and so happy that we did. Wonderful collection of old masters in such an elegant setting. Loving historic residential architecture I was glad to see the Frick home although a bit disappointed in the starkness of the layout. Some changes have been made in recent years to highlight museum pieces, done with such exceptional taste that it's very difficult to see where they've been carried out. Grand staircase is absolutely stunning with pipe organ built in. We specifically went to see the oil paintings by Turner purchased by Frick from the Sir James Dunn collection from New Brunswick Canada. Staff told us Frick purchased 3 Turners plus 3 other paintings from the Dunn collection but 'Dieppe Harbour' is the only one they can point out by name. We highly recommend a visit to this museum. Easy 20 minute walk from the Plaza Hotel or Bergdorf Goodman's.

An absolute delight.. Although (literally) a stone's throw away from Central Park, The Frick Collection is an oasis of civilisation and charm amidst the bustle of 5th Avenue. Inside all is cool and calm and the collection is truly wonderful. The atmosphere is so familiar I have to keep looking out of windows to see yellow cabs driving by to prove to myself I'm not in a National Trust property back in England. It's hard to pick out favourites, but the chance to see three (count them!) Vermeers in one permanent collection takes a bit of beating. A real joy.
House . What a house! I liked some of the art. But I really liked the house itself. Right across from Central Park. Makes for nice walk.

Stunning museum!. The Frick is small, but a place not to be missed. The collection is mostly of European masters. They have three Vermeers, a room with a number of Gainsboroughs, Rembrandts, Goyas , El Brecos, Degas, and the incredible list goes on and on. The home itself is worth seeing as well as it is in incredible shape and decorated in a fashion that only people with real money and taste could have accomplished.Well worth a visit!
NYC sites ti see. Terrific museum and a wonderful house just off Fifth Avenue. It is different than other museums because it was a former home.

An amazing collection. We visited on friends' recommendation and loved it. How astonishing to see such masterpieces in what was essentially someone's sitting room! My favourite painting (Cromwell bu Holbein) is right there by the fireplace when I'd always thought the original was in London's National Portrait Gallery!
Taking in the Frick Collection. The Frick's collection of world-class paintings is a treasure that I have enjoyed twice and would take in again if/when in NYC again.

NYC November 2015. We toured the Frick Collection on a rainy day along with many other folks and found it to be surprisingly delightful. The Frick family were such collectors of very fine art, and the displays were beautifully done. We found the lower level display of etchings by an artist whose completed paintings were upstairs to be particularly fascinating.

Good, not great. I love art and have been to lots of museums.This is a must do for art lovers but overall I think other museums are better in NYC so if you have to chose, skip this.It's very very crowded, though most museums are in NYC but this is in a house so there's a lot less space.The best works that I saw here were actually in the exhibition that they had going on. I'm glad I went but I doubt I'll feel the need to go back.
A little jewel in Manhattan. A perfect place to spend a few hours, very similar to the Wallace Collection in London and the Musee Jacquemart Andree in Paris. Not overcrowded and full of treasures..

See the Vermeers. Excellent collection of fine art, including a few Vermeers, in the Frick mansion. The art is great but it would be worth a visit just to see how the upper crust lived in NY in the early 1900s.
Small is nice.. This is one of my favorite museums. The galleries are beautiful. There is an enclosed garden. The art is classic.

Lovely Art Collections within a Magnificent Setting. The Frick Collection was one of the most spectacular privately-obtained art collections I have ever seen! Rembrandt, El Greco, Holbein, van Dyke, and even more! Absolutely stunning and spectacular! HIGHLY RECOMMEND for any art enthusiast!

Intimate Collection by a Romantic. The house contains an intimate collection of personally selected art of a wealthy businessman. If you realize you are viewing what was once a private collection, you'll really be amazed by what's here: Degas, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Holbein, Greco...and much more. You can tell Mr. Frick was drawn to the innocent, the virtuous, and the natural. He's a romantic and the art and house together really show more of his wonderful taste, and taste usually comes from virtue (or lack therof). I wish Mr. Hearst in California was influenced by and took pointers from the collection at the Frick instead of decorating his castle with trashy goth stuff. Frick did it right and you'll still feel welcomed as a guest, even long after his death.

little place packs a big punch. I"ve lived in the NYC area and just went to the Frick for the first time earlier this year. It has amazing art of all kinds and is much less crowded than the MET or MoMA. Nice garden in the center also. A definite gem amongst the goliaths of NYC.
Beautiful. Beautiful building, nice collection and a real good atmosphere. It's worth a visit if you're in the neighborhood!

Small, but interesting Private Collection. This is a small museum, which house the private collection of Mr. Frick, a coal magnet.If you are looking for the impressionists, you will be disappointed, as they only have a few. There are some lovely Gainsboroughs and Turners though. Worth a look.

Beautiful--so much to see. This is by far, my favorite museum I've been to so far in NYC. There is so much to see here and the building itself is gorgeous. It just drips "New York rich." The paintings, the porcelain, all of the other items--this museum is just so well done, elegant, and gorgeous. I'm so glad I had the time to go!

Human size museum with a wonderful collection. Usually I am overwhelmed by the size of famous museums, but I love to see good paintings. Frick Collection is perfect because a) it was somebody's home, beautiful but human size; b) it gets different exhibitions and if you are lucky you get two great experiences by seeing the exhibition and the main collection. The original collector was a bit of a magpie in terms of different schools of painting and artists but the result is brilliant.

Stunning. What a beautiful place! The building itself is wonderful. Make sure that you have an audio guide, as this makes the experience even more special. The paintings are exquisite. My favourite place in NY. The staff are so nice and the garden court is lovely to sit and read. Bliss!

Lovely Little Museum. I loved this Museum as it is not overwhelming and is wonderful to go from room to room feeling the time period of the art and the residents. Lots of French artwork!! Loved it as I was just in Paris and France and visited the biggies there.
Another must do for art. Small but extremely worth it. Art of the highest standard well curated. Not far from the MMA. Will amaze you if you are interested in this sort of thing as we were

Best Masion with great Art for Sunday--pay as you go. Enjoy a past glory of railroad tycoon's wealth and taste in Ast and home--all in middle of best location of Manhattan. Best for leisurely Sunday enjoyment with museum special of "pay as you wish" entrance.fee. Unique museum in NYC, nice art works to allow up close inspection and study. Wander around a great preserved mansion of Gold Gilted Years of tycoons. Those were the Days!

Former residence of Henry Clay Frick. The collection preserves the ambience of Frick's home and includes paintings, sculpture and other works of remarkable quality. Be sure and use the free audio guide.

An incredible, intimate, museum. Unmissable.. It is hard to remember now that this was once a private house - the dwelling place of an incredibly rich man and art lover. It houses a priceless collection of paintings and other works of art in a small (by museum standards) space. Having the opportunity to see the original Holbein paintings of Sir Thomas More and Cromwell on either side of Frick's fireplace is worth the entrance fee alone. For anyone who finds the scale of the Met too daunting, I heartily recommend the Frick collection.

A less well known gem. It is incomprehensible that this very large space was actually the home of a person. Andrew Carnegie must have paid his senior managers very well, because in addition to this estate and grounds is a private art collection belonging to the museum collected by Henry Clay Frick that rivals any private collection anywhere (though I guess that it is no longer technically private). What is astounding about this place is that for years it was free to the public--now it is not, but still worth the admission price at least once. I have thought many times about how much it would have cost just to heat and maintain the place.

Awesome for art buffs/Free audio tour helps art "noobs" a lot. I'd been to this museum around 1986 and remembered barely knowing what I was seeing. I figured I'd get more out of it this time. I did. First, if you're not someone who enjoys hearing somewhat snooty commentary about Sevres porcelain or the history of exquisite writing desks, about 1/3rd of the audio tour will be somewhere between uninteresting and slow torture. But stick with it because I learned a lot - particularly about Fragonard and Boucher - Rococo artists whose works in the Frick are amazing. The commentary on the audio about what the artists were up to in each picture made sure I got more out of the visit. I also had an "Oh my God" moment when the audio mentioned that two Veronese paintings had once been owned by in the 1600s by Queen Christina of Sweden -- very strange to be in the same room with something that belonged to a famous royal hundreds of years ago.I have two new favorite paintings from this visit. The Wool Winder by Jean-Baptiste Greuze (had never heard of him before) and Winter by Francois Boucher. The museum is stuffy and a little hard on the feet. Since the commentary is so thorough, take breaks in the refreshing courtyard by the fountain if you're getting tired. There's also a film about the history of Henry Clay Frick and the collection that makes for a good rest.

Awesome museum. This is one of my favorites museums in NYC. It is different than a normal museum, because it really was the house of Frick, and most of the pictures and furnitures are part of his collection. If you go on sundays from 11am to 01pm you will pay what you want.

Small and Intimate. Great museum. Wonderful art. Its free on Sunday mornings. Hard to believe that once this was a family residence. I also enjoy they that allow art students access for research. One of the true gems of NYC.

Absolutely charming with stellar collection. The Frick has an amazing collection of paintings and sculpture displayed in an old New York house. It has a wonderful ambiance. You could spend hours there and not be bored.

Amazing collection. The massive amounts of historical archives housed in this location was mind boggling! When my wife and I visited there were an astonishing sample of Vincent Van Goghs' work. The only drawback was rhe amount of people in and around the artwork. It made it virtually impossible to get a great look at the work. The atrium and pools were spectacular! I highly suggest that you visit the collection whenever you are in the area.

One of the best NYC museums!. We come to NYC often and have never been to the Frick until this visit. The collection is spectacular and the home that Henry Frick built and furnished allows you to enjoy the art comfortably. It was a calming experience...If you've been to the Barnes in Philadelphia, you're in for a treat here.

No cameras or selfie sticks!. The Frick is absolutely refreshing. It's a calm, uncrowded gallery space. There are no cameras or tourists taking selfies beside the paintings.They have a high quality collection of paintings, furniture, pottery, and sculpture - Rembrandt, Vermeer, and Turner to name a few. It is a perfect space to sit and reflect without technology being shoved in your face.

Great Art Collection and an Elegant Mansion. You sort of get two attractions at once at the Frick Collection: a great art exhibition of old masters and a visit to a large mansion that faces Central Park. One can't even dream of the wealth that Mr. Frick must have had in his day. The mansion is on par with the Vanderbilt Mansion in Hyde Park, NY but not quite as large. Some of the furnishings displayed reminded us of the Winterthur museum in Wilmington, Delaware. However, the real reason to visit is for the art collection which is very impressive. The various originals are fine examples of some of the well known classical artists including Durer, van Dyck, Goya, Rembrandt, Vermeer and others. The West Gallery was most impressive to me with its paintings easily accessible to visitors. Two Holbein paintings grace the Living Hall and are easily recognizable by most people-- a portrait of Sir Thomas Moore and another of his archrival, Thomas Cromwell. Again, you can walk right up to these painting to see the amazing detail. Entry fees for the museum are about what you would expect for a museum of this type in a major city. They do offer reciprocity with many other art museums across the country so if you are a member of reciprocal museum, you will be admitted for free. You can also get a senior discount. Sunday mornings they offer free or pay-as-you-wish admission depending on the time you arrive (must be before 1PM however). It is a smaller museum so it does not require reservations or timed tickets plus, it is a delightful respite from the noise of the city. I would highly recommend it even to first time visitors to NYC.

Unique Mansion/Unique art collection. After you have seen the MOMA and the Metropolitan Museum of art I would suggest going to the Frick! It is just down the street from the Metropolitan Museum and both the house and the excellent collection are rewarding.

Best Museum in NY. I love Mr. Frick taste in art :) There is not a single painting that does not move me. What a wonderful gift to and legacy! A great place to bring the children to - it is small and powerful. The docent tours are great.

Beautiful piece of history . Great museum and wonderful works of art on display. Highly recommend this to anyone with sting appreciation of art, and history. Thank you, Dr. Frick for turning your home into a museum.

Great Place; What a Miserable Person Frick Was!. WE went to the Frick especially to see the Girl With a Pearl Earring Exhibit. The painting was OK. The museum is very intriguing; however, we decided that we wanted to learn about Frick. He was a horrible person, a dedicated capitalist and misanthrope. That is why I entitled my review as is.

Impressive Collection. We chose this gallery based on reviews and recommendations and we were not disappointed. The temporary exhibition on Andrea del Sarto was both informative and beautiful. The audio tour included with the admission price was well presented and well paced. The integration and planning of the exhibits with the architecture enhanced the experience. A good mix of well-known and lesser known artists.

ok but .... I went here for the del Sarto exhibition. Expertly curated, must have been a monumental effort to get pieces from the Louvre, Hermitage, Berlin, Prado, Getty, Uffizi. The house itself is gaudy, stuffed with show-off pieces (Ming vases, Sevres/Limoges porcelains you get the point) but one cannot get around the fact that Frick managed to collect some of the world's absolute masterpieces - Rembrandt, Velazquez, magnificent de la Tour, perhaps the best Piero della Francesca in the country. Another thing i liked was the mixing and matching of artists and often, periods. The contrast relaxes the mind and helps it appreciate art better - something that the Met should learn about. What I did not like was the steep entrance fee ($20) - for what? Are they scalping college students in order to maintain the house? Acquire new Rembrandts? Aesthetically, the place is somewhat oppressive, especially the decadent central courtyard - compare it, for example,with the lightness and tastefulness of the Getty. And one cannot escape that these pieces were amassed purchased by the guy who hired the Pinkerton guns-for-hire (for Carnegie), who massacred the workers who were asking for better living wages and conditions. In other words, we are talking robber barons at their most hypocritical - art was paid for with the blood of the miners/steelworkers massacred so that Frick could walk through his hallways at night and gaze at the Gainsborough ladies and own auto portraits. If you like art visiting here is a must. But without being aware of the larger perspective - one keeps perpetuating the ignorance and denies art its very message.

An exquisite collection. A stunning collection of art beautifully displayed in this elegant house near Central Park. I just wanted to stay and soak it in, particularly because no photographs are allowed in the house.

Engaging and relaxing. What a wonderful place to make it all about you. When you go in, try to shake off the museum mentality and absorb the serenity and pleasantry of this environment. Take a few extra minutes, slow down and appreciate the architecture and serenity. One of my favorite "public" places in NYC.
Prepare to be amazed. Art and culture mix well here and worth the time and effort to go. The place is neither too conservative nor too artsy fartsy.

Best museum in NYC. This is my favorite museum in New York City. Located in the Frick Mansion on 70th and 5th, the building houses a wide range of art and a large selection of the masters. You can walk through the whole building in 1-2 hours and know that you have seen a tremendous collection. The building and collection are breathtaking.

Amazing collection of fine art in a beautiful residence.. A must do on the list of Museums in New York. Watch the short film on offer to get a greater understanding of the history of the once residence and insight from the staff that work there.

A True Gem!. Frick was an industrialist at the end of the Nineteenth Century, making his fortune from supplying the Carnegie steel mills with coke. He moved to New York city and built his home on 5th Avenue, opposite Central Park.His life-long passion was collecting art and after he moved to New York he focused on European old masters. Visitors today are the beneficiaries of Frick's passion.Perhaps the outstanding feature of the collection is the scale. Other museums such as the Met, just "up the block" from the Frick are overwhelming, particularly to visitors who may have limited time. The Frick Collection can be enjoyed in a single day, while giving ample time to appreciate the art.The Collection consists of porcelains and small bronzes, and the star attraction which is a marvelous collection of old masters: for example, two Rembrandts, several wonderful Vermeers, Titian, El Greco, Turner, Reynolds, Goya, Constable and many others. In addition, are several excellent impressionists such as Renoir and Degas. The gallery itself is worth the visit. Several room are furnished with original furniture. The central atrium is a quiet and impressive retreat.There is a small gift shop with a varied and interesting selection of Frick souvenirs and items with a broader perspective.There is no outlet for food or drink, but "in-and-out" privileges allow one to find sustenance in the area. We were directed to Lexington Avenue, three blocks east, where we found an excellent cafe (Corrado Bread and Pastry) for an excellent and reasonably priced lunch.Entry fees are a very reasonable $20 ($15 for seniors) and docent talks and an audio guide are free.The Frick is a "must see"!

My Favourite Museum. This is my favourite museum to visit. I love the fact that it is small and intimate and can easily be visited in a few hours. So many other museums are overwhelming but this collection is just perfect. I have read that there are plans to expand the museum and while I accept that change is probably inevitable I hope that they manage to retain the unique features of this wonderful collection.

An Uptown Oasis. I go here not just for the art collection, but for the gardens and the quiet, peaceful atmosphere. The Frick is an intimate, otherworldly place. It's perfect for a rainy day or if you need a break from the razzle and dazzle of NYC. It's a short walk from the Met, but not crowded and grand like it. Its grandiosity is subtle and sophisticated, something like having one delicate and amazing petit four for dessert, instead of the chocolate mud cake.

Beautiful art and design. Frick is a beautiful collection of art and period furniture in the mansion which was the home of Mr Frick, one of the leading industrialists of 19th century. The collection and his house are amazing. Free/ included in the price of tickets - Audio tour really makes it very interesting and there are so many interesting stories and facts to learn and enjoy. Sunday 11 am to 1pm is pay what you wish. Children under 10 are not allowed and no photography in the museum. Photography is allowed only in the garden court, which was added later on when house was being converted into a museum. Do recommend the docent tour of the dining room. No food cafe here but one can walk and get to places to eat and then come back to enjoy the museum, as reentry is permitted with the ticket stubs. Make sure to watch the 15 minute film about Mr Frick. Plan on around 2 hours to see the place but one can easily take more time to enjoy this beautiful mansion.

An oasis of calm and culture. The Frick is a hidden gem on New York's museum mile. Unlike in a large museum, you have time and space to enjoy the art work which is in every room. And what art work. Everything on display is worth examining and admiring. Not a wasted moment. The admission of $20 per person is a little steep but, in a hectic city, it does mean you have an atmosphere of quiet calm to nurture your soul.

Special attraction from the building, art, and enjoyment. Have you tried to take in Met??? Did it tire you out??? The Frick is a gem of equal quality in art, but consumable in 3 hours - and worth every minute. Best was an excellent free audio tour that covers an outstanding selection of great art. If you aren't into portrait art and related history, skip the art and just enjoy a great NY mansion.

Jewel on the upper East Side.. We enjoyed a recent visit to the Frick museum. It reminds us of the chateau's in the Loire Valley, France, on a smaller scale. It is impressive to see how many art treasures were amassed by one wealthy man who generously gave it all as a museum after his death. It is a small quiet space compared to the other NYC museums we have visited. The Sarto exhibit at this museum , which will be temporary, was very impressive as were the pieces of dresden china. Take a couple of hours and enjoy the atmosphere of this museum!

dont go looking for the Goldfinch. Although it is listed on their website, it does not reside a the Frick. Its a great collection of interesting pieces that resided in an incredibly restored mansion. Well worth the visit.
Art at its best. Excellant, Excellant, Excellant. Wide ranging presentation. Very educational and family friendly. Staff extremely knowledgeable and friendly. Would recommend to all as a must see.

Enjoyed the art and history. Gem. Enjoyed the walk thru the home. Paintings and furnituredisplayed were beautiful. Great location near Central Park.Great way to spend a morning, walk the park and get a wonderful meal. Would like to revisit on our next visit to NYC.

Great little museum. Ducked in here because of the rain and found this to be a little gem. Free audio guide with the entrance fee and 80% of the art works it seems, is covered by the audio guide so you feel like you had an intimate access to this private collection. My favourites are the Vermeers.

The Gilded Age. This is an art museum with a personal touch. Henry Frick was a rags to riches story who left his home and art collection to the public. The paintings glow and some have hung exactly where he wanted them for over 100 years. I came for a look at the lifestyle of the gilded agers and I was not disappointed.

Just awed!. We've tried to visit the Frick collection before. The lines were long; we ended up having to leave. Going on a weekday mid-morning turned out to be out best choice. No walking traffic with "excuse me" and "pardon me."Having "Collection" in its title is totally appropriate. While visiting museums is nice, perusing the furniture, tapestries, moldings, material usage, lower level exhibit, ... was incredibly entertaining. Posted guides noticed if you had a special interest in a particular facet and some even approached you to share additional information or to point out "be sure to check out..."What a special treat! We even enjoyed the store; such an eclectic and useful mix of ideas. Be sure to give yourself time to appreciate the rooms. The movie near the end was more meaningful having seen the different rooms beforehand; in fact, we went back to a few places to revisit missed moments.

Wonderful museum, well kept secret?. Frick Collection is located within Museum Mile at 6th Avenue , New York. Has a wonderful Collection of mainly European impressionists paintings and Fremch china. There no were no lines to get in the two times I visited. I wonder why ?

unique off-path museum. kids are not allowed in this museum, so my mom and I went there when we happened to visit NYC without my little ones. I was pleasantly surprised - this is a mansion turned into museum and there are a lot of interesting details. Allow a couple hours for you visit.
Small and full of BIG art. The Frick Collection is one of my favorite museums in NYC. Small museum but the artists and artwork are HUGE! Must visit when in New York. Nice activity for a rainy day.

This is really an outstanding museum.. What a beautiful museum. A great collection. Hand held audio guide is included in the entrance fee. The guide gives wonderful insight into the art work. Sunday mornings the entrance is an at will offering. What a bargain. But it is not an overly expensive museum like some of the others in NY anyway.

Better than MOMa. This is not our first visit but we were again stunned by the quality and variety of objects on display. The two Holbeins of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell area personal favourites. These images are so well known and reproduced, it's hard to believe you are standing in front of the originals. Unrushed, quiet and with a good audio guide, I would highly recommend you give this collection at least 4 hours.

Fabulous Art in a Fabulous Setting. I finally visited the Frick Collection when I was last in New York. It is an amazing collection of art in a gorgeous mansion. The rooms are beautifully furnished highlighting the wonderful paintings, sculptures, and ceramics. There is a bit of everything from a Rembrandt to El Greco to Japanese statues to silver and enamelware.Each room held a new surprise including the Singer Sargent portrait of a lady in the hallway near the stairs. It's incredible to see so many paintings that you instantly recognize as a masterpiece of so many artists.
A little spot of peace and quiet in a busy city. As young children are not allowed in, it is a very peaceful museum, defiantly a quality over quantity museum, small for New York but so peaceful.
Island of beauty. Incomparable art collection in a beautiful human-scale building makes you forget you're in NYC. Try to come in off-time as it's best enjoyed when few people are around.

Amazing architecture and collection!. The Frick was like an oasis in the hustle and bustle of NYC. The architecture and gardens of the house are amazing, as is the collection of paintings and sculptures. The collection is small enough to allow you to take your time and absorb each piece, unlike many of the larger galleries and museums. Get there early to avoid crowds, Highly recommended!

"Oh that's here". Do not miss this gem and if you are a lover of art up to the nineteenth century you will find something to please you. Constable of Salisbury Cathedral - here, Holbeins of More and Cromwell - here, Turners, Vermeers, Gainsboroughs, Piero della Francesca, Bellini the list seems endless and all displayed in a Fifth Avenue mansion giving an insight into how the gilded generation lived at the turn of the Twentieth Century.

WOW - what a building; what a collection!. The Frick Collection is housed in the former residence of Henry Clay Frick on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. It is a beautiful architectural building as well as housing an amazing collection of European artists, sculptures, furniture and porcelains. Give yourself the time to slowly wander and absorb the amazing pieces around you.
Amazing. A very interesting building architecturally. Has a perfect collection. Should be visited if you love European paintings.

One of the best -. I loved visiting the Frick. It helped being a sunny warm day and across from Central Park.They have a wonderful collection, and the building is a manageable size in a lovely setting. I loved the FIVE Turners on display.I was thoroughly delighted to find that the gallery has a pipe organ.I will for sure return on my next visit.

What a jewel! Even better with the audio tour.. It was a special treat to walk through the Frick Collection, enjoying the extraordinary art and the architecture. The audio tour is wonderful, really adding to the appreciation of everything you see (and included in the admission fee).

One of the best collections ever......... We enjoyed a few hours wandering the halls of this mansion and viewing the outstanding collection of artists. We particularly liked how Mr. Frick arranged his collection - his way and the way he wanted rather than by artist, period or style. The mansion itself is a work of art and the transformation from a home to an exhibition is something to behold.

AMAZING Museum. Honestly, had the concierge at the hotel not suggested this, ,I would never have gone. It is the perfect scale, not crowded, with more Masters than you can imagine. Far and away our favorite museum in NYC
Wonderful art stop!. We really really enjoyed this stop. Big enough, yet small enough to get through it and not feel overwhelmed. Liked the on demand self guided tour - a must have.

Jewel Box. Words cannot describe how much we enjoyed our afternoon at the Frick. It is a wonderful collection, housed in an exceptionally beautiful building. The family home, and it's art collection, are lovingly preserved by a knowledgeable and friendly staff. Be sure to take advantage of the docent led tours. Our favorite art experience amongst our many adventures in NYC.

In perpetuum. A tasteful yet eerie legacy of one man's desire to own art that he knew he could not take with him. Instead he left it for future generations to enjoy in a perpetual trust. It's not often one leaves a museum touched by this degree of generosity. I was moved!
Beautiful House, wonderful Art. The home, its furnishings and artwork with different mediums and periods were exquisite. A great venue in a great part of New York City
Leave your camera at home. No photography allowed at the Frick indoors, but that only forces you to pay more attention to each painting. Some wonderful paintings there. Well worth the visit.
highbrow. The mansion is beautiful. The works showed are only fair in my estimation. There is a very personal taste of Frick in selection of the paintings but it is not mine

Lovely collection in a lovely setting. This is a great collection of very manageable size in a beautiful building. The permanent collection, of European masters, covers a range of periods, and there are periodic special exhibits. The art is easy to view. Worth the visit.

Wonderful artworks and beautiful building. So many famous artworks in the most fabulous building. I had seen many of the paintings on TV programs but seeing them up close in the setting they were meant to be enjoyed was just stunning. Learning about the history behind the house and how the collection was established made the visit complete. Would recommend even if you are not an art buff as I am not either and still loved it.
Astonishing. This is a world class collection in a stunning setting. You don't need to be an art buff to be impressed. Extraordinary, not to be missed. If you do one museum in New York do this.

Small Museum Gem on NYC East side. The Frick is a wonderful building and the collection offers the visitor an array of art. The two Vermeer's and Rembrandt self portrait offer an experience to rival Amsterdam's offerings. Mr. Frick left behind an important collection of art, housed in his former mansion, for others to enjoy.

Exquisite Art in a Gilded Age Home!. Henry Clay Frick, one of the gilded age robber barons, left a wonderful collection of art, along with his stunning home, to be enjoyed for all posterity. The art alone is worth the trip but its display in the Frick Mansion adds another dimension to the experience. The rooms are appointed with exquisite original furnishings from Persian carpets and ornate furniture to Limoges enamels and classic, valuable artworks from all the masters. They are arranged and displayed in the original manner of their day. As one strolls through the various rooms, one can enjoy the works and get a feel for what it was like to be a "have" in a real home, during the gilded period.If you've got a few hours to spare, the Frick Collection is a must.

Perfect place on a snowy afternoon. The Frick is always a pleasurable place to visit. I always see something new -either because it has been moved to a new position or because of the light. I highly recommend taking the time to visit this small museum.

First time here, what a fabulous gallery. I had never been to the Frick, but am so grateful I finally got to go. The whole place is filled with fantastic art and decor that you wont' see anywhere else. It was a great visit.

Beautiful collection. Very happy we chose to visit the Frick, while in NYC. Small enough to get a feel for the architecture and collections in one visit. Much prefered to some of the other, bigger museums.

Wow, what a collection!. This collection was started by steel baron Henry Frick. The private home is now a museum. The collection has been enhanced by family donations. Something to see if you're an art lover.

So worth it!!!. I've been to NYC many times and never visited the Frick Collection. It was amazing! A small museum all on one level. Very few people compared to the Met or MoMa. The home itself is an unbelievable work of art built in 1913 by Mr. Frick after he left the steel industry in Pittsburgh. Many rooms make you feel like you are in the Palace of Versailles. The collection is extensive and impressive! Many works from the Old Masters - Manet, Rembrandt, Gaugin, Titian, Turner, Van Dyke, Degas, Renoir, and so many more!!! Plan to spend around two hours which will give you plenty of time to see everything. Cost is $20.

outstanding collection. In a beautiful area and setting you will find some beautiful top artworks from the 13th to the 19th century. Of course the paintings of Johannes Vermeer will draw the most attention but take all the time you have because the whole history of the Frick collection is worth visiting and exploring. The galerie is of course the highlight, don't miss this treasure.

One of the Most Enjoyable and Great Art Museums in the World.. The Frick is a New York City mansion housing a collection of top notch art, primarily paintings. The setting is magnificent and comfortable. One is not overwhelmed. Free headphone comes with admission. No food is available. After several hours, I exited the museum for a break, and returned. Just keep up with your entry ticket.

The Frick building is beautiful and its furnishings and photos are beautiful.. At the Frick, as some of us New Yorkers like to call it, you can see architecturally a beautiful building from the outside. You go in and you feel like you've been transformed. Every part of the building and every bit of the collection is beautiful. I believe it's got late-1800s furnishings, if I remember the date correctly. One can hear all about the different areas of each room in several languages via headphones. A must-see when you're in NYC.

NY Jewel with slight reservations. A museum packed with great artists like Turner, Titian and Vermeer. Its past as a private house is evident in the way the rooms are designed but also in the curatorship that sometimes feels over crowded and inconsistent, which is tiresome. Overall you get a few ours of beauty and interest visiting the museum. This is a real NY jewel.

Hidden Gem of a Museum. This is one of my favorite museums of all time. A fantastic collection of art and furnishings in the middle of Manhattan. Usually uncrowded and no lines this museum should not be missed. It is a "residence" that was made into a museum. This is how the Titans of Industry lived over 125 years ago.

A gem on 5th Avenue. We walked down 5th Avenue after visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and were highly impressed by the much smaller, quieter and more intimate experience at the Frick. First, the setting is very impressive. The artworks even more so. Three Vermeers, if you can believe it!! In any event, this is a highly recommended and worthwhile stop for both the casual and the serious art aficionados.

Astonishing collection. This was our second visit but the collection is enthralling. It's intimate but the works on display are just astonishing. To see the Holbein portraits of More and Cromwell staring at each other across the fireplace in the drawing room is spine tingling. Perhaps the finest collection of its kind in the world. A must see.

Captivating place. I absolutely loved my visit to the Frick Collection. What an amazing, beautiful and captivating building. I am no art expert but I loved walking around what was once a family home admiring the collection of art and furniture. It really was a haven of peace and tranquility in the madness that is New York. The room with the plants and the pool was just so beautiful to sit for a while and take in the surroundings. A wonderful place which I would very much recommend.
exquisite site. simply beautiful building with some amazing pieces of art. Located on a particularly lovely stretch of Fifth Avenue it is an oasis of sophistication and taste.

Architecture is as beautiful as the paintings. What makes the Frick rare is that the architecture of the 'museum' is as beautiful as the collection of paintings that reside in it. The Frick is a collection of paintings that once belonged to Henry Frick, and they usually also have one featured painting (from a visiting museum). I highly recommend anyone who appreciates great art to spend some time at the Frick Museum - the collection is predominantly European artists.The mansion itself, located on the UES, is beautiful and grand - take some time to enjoy sitting in the garden to embrace the majestic ambiance of the place.

An EXTRAORDINARY experience. I had to keep pinching myself to believe that this extraordinary place and the extraordinary collection once belonged to one man. The Frick Collection showcases a place and time that we are very very lucky to still be able to view. A wonderful way to learn about New York society, art and much more.

A taste of Old New York. A family home across from Central Park, Mr. Frick had the house designed with the intent of becoming a museum after his death. Designs were made later to the home giving us what we see today. What an amazing gift to future generations. A marvelous collection of the "Old Masters," furniture,& sculptures. Worth the time to visit & see the treasures.

Peace in the city. I'm no art copnaisseur but spent hours in here on my last visit. The house is amazing and its history is fascinating. I sat in the atrium for ages and read. Loved it. It was snowing outside and very atmospheric

The best art money could buy. Housed in the estate of a steel tycoon, the artworks in this museum rank among the world's finest. Lining the walls of this home are works by Titan, Gainsborough, Hals, Rembrandt, Van Dyck, El Greco, and others. You can get close to the paintings and sculptures to marvel at them and there are no great crowds to interfere with your viewing. Children under ten are not admitted.

My new favorite NY museum. They had three, count them , 3 Vermeer's on display when we visited.To think that one man built this house and actually lived in it before turning it into a museum.Un-Imaginable wealth.Beautiful architecture and gardens. Fill your belly with art and then walk across the street to Central Park and enjoy your bologne sandwich with a thermos of coffee. All the while watching the joggers on the jogging path.One does not need millions to enjoy life or beauty. One needs only good health.

Beautiful & romantic experience in this manageable oasis of art/architecture!. The special music room with their concerts is a MUST experience!What a lovely way to spend a few hours exploring the beautiful architecture and art collection of the Frick. I feel as if I'm whisked away to another era of living...For those who may find the Metropolitan Museum of Art a bit overwhelming...the Frick is SO manageable and yet awe-inspiring - a few hours or less is all it takes.One of my favorite things to do in NYC!

Perfect museum - great works, in a space you can see in 90-120 minutes. There are great works here - my favorites are Titian and Rembrandt - and many others. Not only is it large enough to house lots of great artists, but small enough to really enjoy it end not feel you've missed something. If I were to choose one museum in NY to visit it would be this one.

Great value...on a Sunday. To mirror other reviewers, the Frick Collection houses an excellent selection of fine art.Standard admission for an adult is $25, however on a Sunday between 11am and 1pm they host a 'Pay What you Like' where we saw some patrons hand over ONE DOLLAR for entry.

Favorite place. Are you happy today? Maybe blue....go to nthe Fricks collection, enjoy the mansion, perhaps it will make your blues go away and bring a smile to your face... Enjoy the book in the inner garden, soft music. Come for the concert....One of the best spots in NYC.

Great Museum, just the right size, just the right art. Forget the CRAZY museums in NYC where you can't see or appreciate the art because of the throngs of tourists. A critical part of an aesthetic moment is your ability to connect with the art in the right state of mind and with the right context. The artists who made these pictures did not intend them to be shown in a circus or Disneyland, they meant them to be seen in a private residence, in a socially rarified atmosphere. That is what the Frick delivers. We loved it.

A surprise. The building itself is wonderful. And the collection is amazing: because its in NY, we didnt know about that museum, with all the other cultural attraction. In most other cities, it would be a major attraction. Because of that, we didnt plan enough time to see it though: we suggest at least 3 hours...

My favourite museum of all. This museum is a bijou and has so many lovely paintings assembled in it and collected by the very interesting Henry Clay Frick. You walk through the house and feel that it has been lived in and that it is not only a place of exhibition.

excellent. Small but first class art collection located close to Central Park, showing Vermeer (Mistress and Maid), Van Dyck, Rembrandt, Turner, Hals paintings, and many others. I could even find one painting of my beloved Monet. Unfortuntely, they have pretty strick photo policy, so I could not make photos for my friends. Pity...

We visited the Frick Museum.. The museum was previously the residence of the Frick family and was designed to be a museum after Mr. Frick and his wife passed away. It is a magnificent museum and certainly worth a visit.

Andrea del Sarto at the Frick. The exhibit Andrea del Sarto, although small, helps illustrate the creative process by presenting a variety of sketches done by del Sarto as studies for three paintings. As always the Frick had done a great job with this exhibit. The attention to detail is wonderful, and the hand held magnifying glasses that are provided by the museum ensure that the viewer can see clearly these wonderful sketches.

A must see Museum. You can see this museum at your own pace. I loved the enclosed garden to sit in. There is an elevator if you need one. This museum is in a house and is full of furniture, dishes, and art. There is also a theater that shows a film about the museum and what to see. It has places to sit so even with the walking you can rest when you need to and just enjoy the art and magnificence of this museum. I didn't feel as rushed to see everything as in a larger museum and also could enjoy the exhibits without waiting a long time for people to move along. I would go again because they have special exhibits in the basement and I would like to enjoy the museum again. There is a very nice shop in the museum too.

With an actual yard that faces Central Park, what a house this must have been!. An actual families home, the beautiful low building with a yard facing Central Park is a hidden gem often overlooked by tourists to New York. I lived in the neighborhood many years ago, and visited this museum often. I return to it often. Some of the paintings aren't stellar, but the setting overall is what amps up the charm factor.

Not really my taste. The collection is laid out in the villa of the Frick family. Nicely build and decorated. The collection contains many paintings of very renown painters. But to my taste it is too much, it is over the top.

That painting is in New York!!. Wanted to see the Holbein portraits of Cromwell and Moore and it was amazing to see them together. My only complaint was that when I was talking to other visitors about the paintings the room steward insisted that we be quiet. What is the point of displaying so many iconic works of art if you can't talk about them with other visitors?

WOW!!. Clearly the rich live a different lifestyle. But, so wonderful of the Frick family to share their collection with the public. The house is amazing, and the artwork breathtaking. Worth the admission price.

A small treasure. Museum mile on 5th avenue has many musems to choose from (and crowds to navigate). To see a beautiful collection, an historic mansion (imagine when all of 5th avenue was lined with homes like this!), and enjoy the lovely atmosphere. If you don't want to battle the crowds to look at some spectacular art--make your way here.

A New York City Favorite. This was my second visit to the Frick. I love imagining what it was like to be Mr. Frick and actually live here. He loved collecting art and would go downstairs in the middle of the night just to sit in one of the rooms and look at his "pictures." The building itself is magnificent.

A true trip into "The Gilded Age ". This was a pleasant surprise . Though I had read about the Frick before Zillow went sometimes things just don't sink in . This is the very personal collection of Henry Frick now kept and displayed in his home more or less as it all was at the time of his death . Quite extensive and quite eclectic but very much a private collection now on display ., I gather Frick himself was quite a villain ( key bad guy in the Holmestead Strike) but his collection is beautiful . Amazing that one man could isn all this . I loved the Rembrandt,self portrait . I have seen others snd they always have an effect on me . They say this is the most powerful and maybe it is . The display is great . Very manageable in a couple of hours . The audio tour is first rate . The staff were fairly helpful ( though one fellow that I asked about which room I was in , didn't seem quite sure ) . The suggested route is very helpful . The video was quite good . On the day I went ( a Tuesday in October ) there were people around but not crowded at all .. All in all a very pleasant experience . The senior's price of $15 was fine .

Wow!. A stunning collection of artworks housed in a beautiful building. We went on the morning when entry fee is 'pay what you like': there was a long line but we got there early enough that we were close to the front. There is also a souvenir shop. An enjoyable hour or so.
Amazing collection of famous artwork. The Frick is located on Manhattan's east side and offers a great collection in a wonderful space. I would recommend going on days other than Saturday or Sunday.

Serene space with good collection. I was really impressed by the space where the art was housed. I also liked the fountain where one could just sit and relax away from the bustle of the city. You can get a complimentary audio guide which is good and gives the listener an interesting take on the collection. If you're a student, they also give a student admission price. All in all, good space to visit

Beautiful gem. I have visited the Frick many times over the past 30 years. It is a delightful oasis--not large, but packed with interest in paintings (my favorite) and other art forms. Highly recommend.
Lovely. Beautifully put together. With the bonus of the remainder of the museum, a world class place, afterwards.
tranquility in the centre of town. Great escape from the hustle of New York , a typical UK stately home in the middle of the Big Apple , well worth the visit to see this amazing collection and house.

Wonderful!!!. This museum which was a mansion on park Avenue at the turn of the century is a hidden gem. Everyone goes to the met but this is rather small and on a quiet side street fronting park. So many unique things to be amazed at that this is a must see. I lived in nyc for 20 yrs and used to go here every few months.give yourself a treat.
So beautiful!. Waited in line for the Sunday morning opening. The Frick is a must on your museum list! Take the complimentary audio offered and watch the movie for a great introduction.

Fine modest collection beautifully presented. Great place for a morning visit, modest collection that you can view in about 90 minutes, the audio tour is informative and not too wordy, pieces are interesting and the presentation is classy, very reasonably priced, nice short walk from mid-town

Amazing collection. Three Vermeers!. The three Vermeers are worth the price of admission, which, for an old-timer like me, was $15. And it's clear that the top one-tenth percent surely knew how to live. The house is amazing, with several rooms reminiscent of the great castles and chateaux of Europe. But the art is the draw here, and it's the greatest hits of the past three or for centuries. Old man Frick had a great eye for great art. If I lived in NYC I would become a member just to go and look at those jewels hanging in the wall. Do NOT miss this museum.
Love the Frick. This is one of my favorite museums to visit. Great collection of European art. It is free on Sundays in the AM, a nice surprise when I visited.
Beautiful building and interior with tons of great works. Spent a few hours here touring and used the audio. Not cheap but worth it for the amount of visual stimuli. Watch the movie first.
Beautiful. Another one I was reluctantly dragged to by my wife but came awaking thinking how remarkable it was. If you have 2 hours spare you must visit. The collection and the home are remarkable

Well worth a visit. Beat the guggenheim by far. Amazing collection beautiful home. We'll worth the $20. Have a cheeky rest in the inside garden and don't forget to download their app with their free wifi.best app st an art gallery I have found

PARIS IN NEW YORK. When one enters The Frick, the hustle and bustle of NY disappears and one is cast back into an era of New York opulence reminiscent of a French Chateau. The specialty exhibits change periodically and are terrific, the permanent collection of, furnishing, art, etc. is simply amazing. An absolute not to miss NY experience.

Worth the Price. My wife had read a book on Frick and his art collecting, so we had to visit the Frick mansion/museum. A lot of beautiful art, but not so overwhelming that the average person (me) can't appreciate the pieces. On the Saturday we were there, the museum was busy, but never seemed crowded. The $20 per person admission fee we paid was appropriate.

Lovely. A lovely collection. We used our NARM membership which was very nice. There is a wonderful Renoir, Le Promenade. You won't be disappointed. We went here before the MET. It was a good order to go in as we were unsure how long we would spend in the MET and the hours at the Frick were shorter.

Favorite place in NYC. There are galleries with larger buildings, bigger collections, newer facilities, but none with the sweet ambiance of the Frick. A beautiful, PEACEFUL, gallery where you are never hassled or rushed. Sit in the inner courtyard and just relax. Enjoy the Rembrandt like it was in your own home. If you love art....don' miss this one.
Retired Sculptor

More artistic genius on display per square foot than anywhere I have visited. The quality of the art in the Frick collection is unsurpassed. Highlights:Rembrant self portrait - among his bestJan Vermeer Interior - small but perfect and I mean perfect.Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas Moore and Rchard Cromwell - yes they are the originals and great paintings as well as historic icons.Outstanding set of Gainsboroughs - not an artist I much care for but these are eye openers.Iconic Constable.One nice Renoir and 2 Whistlers. There is almost nothing which is not among the best of its kind, though I am not sure why he bought the Raeburn.It was worth going to New York for the Frick alone.

Another 'must see' in New York. If traversing the Met is daunting, at least the collections of gems of furniture, painting and other objets d'art found at the Frick are more manageable. No pictures are allowed inside, except for the fountain court. But the amazing items collected by Mr Frick are displayed much as he had them when this building was his home. The portrait of St Thomas More by Holbein is so penetrating that it could have been painted yesterday, and that is only one of the scores of pictures in this wonderful place. There is no point in trying to summarise the treasures to be found here. You must go and see them.

A Home or a Museum?. Having travelled through Europe, enjoying all the ehibitions and galleries on offer, I was not prepared for the quality of art on display in what was (apparently) intended to be primarily a family residence. The building is hugely reminiscent of Renaissance homes in Italy (a perfect example of the privileges enjoyed by the few during the gilded age) but contains awesome examples of Rembrandt's talent, Renoir and Veronese, to name but a few. The bronzes are impressive and, although personally not a fan, the porcelain collection is impressive!!

Excellent collection in a real home. This is an excellent collection and it made for a horrible and cold afternoon where Guggenheim had only a few rooms open and available for tourists and the MoMa was WAY Too busy. This is a great private collection. Enjoy everything there and take your time.

Beautiful Little Museum. Great place if you only have a couple of hours and want to experience some of the beauty of NYC museums. Beautiful property and artwork - loved the lapis lazuli tripod table in the Fragonard Room. Be sure to rent the audio tour - well worth it. End your tour with a few moments of quiet contemplation in the beautiful Garden Court . . .

Beautiful collection of classic Masters in this special property. Fabulous collection of incredible artwork and sculptures in the Frick former home.The West Gallery, Garden Court and Fifth Avenue Gardens with stunning magnolia were my personal favourites.Definitely worth a visit on any trip to New York!

My favourite gallery.......so restful. The Frick is my favourite gallery, not just because it contains so many fabulous paintings.....my favourite Rembrandt Self Portrait, an Ingres to die for, Constable's White Horse, a fabulous Bronzino, Holbein's Thomas More, delicious Lady Peel and gorgeous Emma Hamilton to name just a few, but these marvellous works are shown in thoroughly restful and civilised surroundings. I look forward to every visit and I am never disappointed. And what a fabulous bonus the Andrea del Sarto exhibition is, a sheer delight!

Worth visiting. Fabulous collection of the art including many grand masters - and furniture reminiscent of century old castles - in an exquisite setting in the nicest area of Manhattan. Just off 5th Ave across from Central Park (on East 70th St), this gorgeous building was once a private residence. Visit here - you'll feel like you're in Europe.

Breath of fresh air. Choice items, informative film, enjoyable docent tour (and only 15 or 20 minutes long, too short to begin yawning!). How very lovely after crowded museums with so much from which to choose to spend time in this Fifth Avenue mansion, savoring as you wish the various rooms replete with paintings and decorative arts of other kinds. So glad we went.

A unique setting for a collection of the classics.. We spent about half a day while the Girl with the Pearl was on display. A pleasant surprise in terms of the conversion of the home to a museum. Great NYC upper east side neighborhood.

Impressive Collection!. You certainly do not have to be an art student or afficienado to appreciate the Frick Collection. The fact that an individual was able to amass such a vast collection is noteworthy. The collection is diverse including Old Masters paintings, sculptures and interior design. The house, its own story and architectural design definitely adds appeal.A self-guided audio tour is included in admission. This provided a wealth of information. In order to operate the device, you will need to input numbers that correspond to specific pieces. The numbers next to each piece were not printed very large, so if you are low vision/visually impaired, you will definitely need some assistance.Allocate approx 2-3 hours to view the collection. If you like house museums, the house itself is not really available for touring. The collections encompasses the first floor only. Nonetheless, the house itself is interesting to compare to those of other robber barons and captains of industry.If you are a DOCENT from any museum, bring your staff ID - admission is waived. I forgot my ID and had to pay but it was worth it.
Unexpected beauty. Hadn't gheard about this place before and it was a surprise to see how beautiful the exhibits are and how interesting

If you life design and art . This is a perfect place to see how the rich and wealthy people of New York City lived . You can feel this Vibe all around the house. Is a good way to see the lifestyle and the chance to be in one of the mansions of the city. T he art of area is very beautiful. But mostly the furniture and architecture are the main attractive of the house .
An amazing slice of the 19th Century. Such a special museum. A gem and a window of wealthy life at the turn of the century. The collection is amazing. Not to be missed!

Most amazing small collection of mainly European art. The two Holbeins of Thomas More and Cromwell each side of the fireplace are worth a visit in themselves. Even if you know nothing about art you will recognise some of the works here. Lovely building in a great location on the edge of Central Park.
One of the best!! A must see!!. It was wonderful to see this collection in such an intimate space and in the place it had been when the owner was alive. A truly beautiful collection. A must see!!

Should be on everyone's must visit list.. I only learned about the existence of this museum by chance & planned to spend about an hour. I was so impressed by the caliber of this art collection that I spent three hours there. So many paintings and works of art from the highest echelon of classical masters any accurate description sounds like hyperbole. One of the best attractions in New York City.

Lovely Exhibit. i likes the collections here. It was a bit stuffy when we were here, but my daughter who is an art major loved the collection and was able to bring it to life for me with her knowledge. i saw David Crosby and his wife here that day! what a rare extra treat.

What a find. So pleased we were told about this museum. The array of art work was amazing. All the top artists were displayed....Holbien, Van Gogh, El Greco etc. No photos allowed however there is an indoor grecian type pool you can rest and take a photo. In a way some of the paintings were better than the Met

Amazing colection of art. An amazing collection of Art in a beautiful setting. The house itself is worth a visit, but the art collection itself is amazing. Take enough time to really take in all there is to behold.
Must See. A must see in NYC. Wonderful layout and integration of fine art with the surroundings of a beautiful mansion.

Wonderful - a must do when in NYC. The Frick Collection is a outstanding well maintained museum within the beautiful Frick mansion. The collection of original old masters is amazing as are all the sculptures and pieces in all the rooms.
Be sure to pick up an audio which comes with the admission fee and don't miss the peaceful indoor garden.
Marvellous. Not crowded like the Met or MoMA. Wonderful painting, very well displayed in a beautiful setting. Marvellous.

lovely jewel box of a museum. outstanding collection in a grand but intimate beautiful city-mansion which was the old home of Henry Frick - an outstanding combination of elegant interiors, outstanding artwork and gracious architecture. Ideal place to stroll for an afternoon. Look for special exhibits.

Wonderful art museum in a city of museums. The Frick museum has many elements that make it a wonderful place to visit. The museum was once Mr Frick's house. The house was designed to be an art museum featuring his collection once he died. This gives the museum a more inviting feel, instead of the sterile feeling you can get from some museums. The architecture and interior design alone makes this a worthwhile visit. The collection is varied but not disjointed. The collection has more classical art; for what I can remember there are no art pieces that fit the board category of modern art. The museum is moderate size, which allows you to take the time to enjoy the art pieces, without overwhelming the senses.

A rare gem. The Frick collection is a rare and special gem of a collection of artworks and installations. I particularly loved the indoor water space with luscious green foliage. I went on a Sunday where you make a donation to enter.

Must see for art lovers.. Great, although when wandering around this superb building and magnificent art collection I started to wonder how many ordinary workers suffered for one man to become so wealthy. Answer = lots. This is mentioned in passing in the video presentation about HC Frick (greatly hated in Philadelphia, back in the day, we are informed). Despite that, the Frick collection is a must see for art lover visiting NY. If you go between 11am - 1pm on Sunday you can pay as much as you want for admission, $20 at other times. It's worth visiting on another day just to miss the crowds.

an amazing museum with wonderful art. This museum was actually a private home (mansion) and has an amazing art collection. It is easily accessed by subway and bus and should not be missed by any one visiting New York City.

A Tremendous Legacy from Frick. The Frick collection is housed in the house built for Henry Clay Frick. It is an astonishing collections of old masters and small bronze sculptures. Even the building itself is noteworthy. The audio guide was also very well done. It is just a bit sad that photography is not allowed. The Frick is just up the road from the Met and worth the visit.
A gem. A must stop when visiting NYC for those who love art. It is quite interesting to see works of art in the rooms where they are meant to be displayed.

Amazing house; nice art collection, too!. As an "Art Gallery" the selection is minimal but what is there is of the highest quality. Many renowned artists on display. In particular the statuary is exceptional. The house itself is the real masterpiece. Great history. Great opportunity to see into the 20th century life of a very, very rich man.

A New York Gem. This is one of my favorite museums in New York. Small, elegant and an outstanding collection of masters, it is not to be missed when visiting New York. It doesn't take long to see but you have the urge to linger and appreciate not only the art works but the building as well.

THE FRICK Remains One of the Jewels in the Art Crown of New York City. Visiting the FRICK COLLECTION recently was a wonderful experience; but, the presence of the Frick in my cultural life, and as a premiere cultural foundation of the city, is more important than any individual study-experience there. The modestly sized Frick Museum is located right down Fifth Avenue from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and makes for a pleasant add-on to any visit to the Met. The Frick was developed from the elegant Victorian mansion built for Henry Clay Frick and the sense of personally visiting his home is appealingly resonant during any time spent there. Velvet ropes cover the massive staircase in the receiving hallway, but one certainly hankers to mount the stairs and meet the man in his study—properly dressed for the occasion, of course. This last time I was visiting the Frick in order to view Frederic Leighton’s startlingly beautiful “Flaming June,” on special loan from the Museo de Arte de Ponce in Puerto Rico, a museum developed by a dear friend of mine from many moons ago. This large canvas with a striking square aspect-ratio depicts a young red-headed maiden dozing in a diaphanous tangerine gown on the ocean-viewing veranda in some Classical Greek paradise. You can smell the fresh blossoms and hear the distant sea.“Flaming June” was displayed in the open grandeur of the Frick’s Oval Room, which also houses four other full-length portraits by James McNeill Whistler. It was simply breathtaking, set off as it was by the muted tones of velvet wall paper surrounding it, and the subtle palette of its tall, elegant neighbors not curled up asleep.The Frick Collection is also a special treasury for Fragonards -- in both oils and tapestry -- chief among them the delightful series, “The Progress of Love.” I’m drawn more, though, toward smaller canvases more intimate in their charms. As a mere dilettante, it’s good for me to be reminded that the experience viewing many of the featured masterpieces has been enhanced by significant restoration projects, particularly of the lighting -- not only of the galleries themselves, but also in subtle LED sweet spots upon certain paintings, among them the peerlessly austere beauty of Bellini’s “St. Francis in the Desert.” Although they no longer serve high tea at the Frick, there are numerous pleasing cafés right nearby. BUT BE WARNED: part of the security for these fragile treasures housed in a real residence is that they want purses to be quite small, and mine doesn’t make it in. I don’t like checking it, so just as in museums and mansions in Russia; I change bags to a mini before coming.

Art, architecture, culture and high living. I'm not much of an art lover, but I do love history, this house has both. It's a great place to taste how the rich and famous lived at the beginning of the previous century. A pleasant stroll through the house gives you an eclectic assortment of old masters, and pretty rooms. There are audio guides included in the entry ticket
Great collection. Beautiful collection in an incredible setting. Tight budget so came on free opening day of the week, come 1h prior with a book, line up and enjoy, it is worth it.

Look what all that steel money purchased..... A nice experience. I tried to imagine what it was like when Frick lived there with this collection. The art is spectacular but don't miss the experience of being in the Frick home, too. Definitely worth the time to see it.
comfortable. I am not sure which element made this such a great experience; the collection or the venue, but I wll just say that this was a really nice way to spend a few hours.

Best Museum in New York!. Brilliant staff ~ gracious and helpful.Mr. Frick's collection is exhibited wonderfully well ~ so many well known paintings displayed admirably.Great audio guide ~ probably one of the best I've used.Also, good 15 minute film of his rise to financial fame to support this.Every room held a delightful surprise ~ excellently well done
Amazing Collection. Most amazing private collection of art, furniture, china all housed in an exquisite building. Enjoy with self paced audio. highly recommend.

Beautiful, stunning collection and house, a must see for art lovers. Incredible museum, beautiful artwork, very surprising at the quality of artwork its truly an extraordinary collection. The history behind the museum and the house itself are both wonderful. I have recommended it now to everybody I know going to New York as a must see.

A memorable experience. Walking around Frick's house is a memorable experience with the sheer volume of art work as well as 3d and furniture to see. The rooms remain as they were or have been curated to display the pieces in their best light. The breadth of art is in itself impressive with many familiar famous names such as Turner, Rembrandt, Titian. To fully appreciate this you need at least an hour, ideally 2 and make sure you pick up the audio guide which offers insight into the rooms and pieces. The collection had a constant flow of people but was not packed to the same degree as other nearby museums.

A superb oddity. Have you ever wanted to pretend you were hobnobbing with the elite? Your wish is fulfilled. Wander about at your leisure, in the refined air of this Fifth Avenue palazzo. Look at all the little people pass by from your vantage point in the dining room, where the highest of high society once gazed longingly into each others' eyes. I came for the Vermeer, and stayed for the atmosphere.

Don't miss it. If you haven't been to the Frick, go on your next trip, especially if you have teenagers whom you are trying to interest in art. The collection is much, much smaller than the Met, and choice. My personal favorites are the contrasting Holbein portraits of Thomas Cromwell and Thomas More.

Truly Great Gallery. You have to really pinch yourself as you wander around this great gallery. The Grand masters you are looking at are not copies but the real thing. An amazing collection of very well known masterpieces which is well worth the twenty dollar admission fee.
The Frick. A lot of great paintings and vases. The grounds and garden are nice as well. Definitely one of the more decadent museums in NYC, definitely worth checking out.

It's incomprehensible to think that people actually once lived here at one time.. The Frick is often overlooked in favor of the well known museums that tourists flock to when they're in New York City and that's a good thing and abad thing depending on how you look at it. It's less crowded (though word has been spreading) here and a bit more sedate,which is nice,though on the other side of that you say to yourself how can people not know about this place? The Frick mansion itself is worth a visit here alone,it's an architectural wonder and even has a garden courtyard and fountain in it.It's incomprehensible to think that people actually lived here,the Frick mansion is tike something out of the Great Gatsby. The collection includes paintings,sculptures,clocks,bronzes,furniture,ceramics,enamels and works of art by Rembrandt,Turner,Piero,Vermeer,Hals,Van Dyck,Goya,Bellini to name a few of the artists that are exhibited in this awe inspiring wonder of a building.

Worth visiting the last of the great houses on Central Park. Henry Clay Frick was the brilliant and ruthless business partner of the robber-baron Andrew Carnegie. They made lots of money in the late 19th Century when money was really money. And, along with their contemporaries, they built fabulous homes on Central Park to show off their wealth. Only one of these homes survives. The Frick mansion which houses the Frick collection. Which is fabulous (money buys a lot of art). If you love architecture, history, art, and a great location it's worth a trip. If I were visiting and I had to choose, I'd skip the MOMA and the Guggenheim for this.

Limited Visit to see Woman in Gold. The museum was closed, except for one room - the one with the Woman in Gold. Very wonderful to see it in real life. The texture of the paint makes seeing the piece "live" worthwhile. Beautiful building. The bookstore was a pleasant surprise. Will return on next trip with the entire place is open.

Jewel of an exhibition space. I haven't been in a long time, but the Frick is an enchanting space with amazing work, especially when a special curated exhibition. Things were a little crazy in New York after 2001 (I visited the Frick once in 2002 and the staff was totally on edge), but with things calmer and more prosperous, it's a jewel of a place.

exquisite collection. A small but exquisite collection. Amazing paintings, worth the wait if there is a line outside. The guards do have an attitude ( can take a course from those at the MET) but a true artistic gem.
Superb concise collection. This is a very manageable museum with many gems, but without taking the entire day. Check out the Whistlers.

Step into the past as it was left.. I really like this kind of museum it feels intimate and gives you an insight into Frick as a person as he was meticulous about the art he collected. The museum is a manageable size for a couple of hours in comparison to the massive Metroplitan museum. $20 each can be a bit pricey for some but Sundays have a pay what you can policy. The video of Frick's life was intriguing.

A Memorable Experience. The museum was a delight to visit. The European art is exquisite and well presented. The audio devices provide good descriptions. The video presentation is well worth watching. The tours are very good. The small size and the tranquility of the facility provide a nice respite from the New York City bustle.

Lovely Musuem. Just outside the Central Park is Frick Museum. Frick Collection is a lovely house turned Museum and it has a fantabulous selection of paintings and sculptures. A must visit for all art lovers. You have to pay around 25$ for entry. Photography is allowed only in the patio. Children around 10 are not allowed.
Frick Collection. Not to be missed! A beautiful mansion and art collection. This should be right up with the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Interesting, beautiful collection. Quintessential NYC experience. The collection and mansion are both extremely impressive. We enjoyed each room - surprises around every corner. Classic oil paintings and realism dominate the collection.

Arguably the best museum anywhere. This year has seen the Thyssen, Tate, National Portrait, Met and others but this is just spectacular. Seemingly everything is a jewel, they don't bother filling up the room with stuff but possibly because of the size of the building every single item is stunning, beautifully curated - a joy to visit.Go!

Small Museum With Some Paintings. I personally find art incredibly boring unless it's modern so unsurprisingly found the Frick collection as tedious as ever to look around. Mr Frick wanted everyone to have access apparently so i'm sure he didn't have in mind the $25 or whatever it was over the top entry price!! The central courtyard is very peaceful and it's a quiet and peaceful atmosphere. I can imagine arty types loving it so they can spend hour upon hour gazing at the complexities of some painting but not for me and TOTALLY beyond me why this scores above such amazing things to do such as Empire State Building or Intrepid which are a million times better than this place with it's contrived atmosphere.

Walls lined with masterpieces. Thr Frick Collection is one of the gems of NYC. It has three Vermeers. (Remember that there are only about 35 Vermeers in the world.). Everything is well displayed and well labeled. The free audio guide is comprehensive. (Well, only two of the Vermeers are in the audio guide, but two for three isn't bad.)Frick was a robber baron, so the money to buy the paintings and precious objects came from his vicious business methods, which emphasized brutal strike-breaking. However, Frick is long gone, so we may as well enjoy the collection he amassed.Don't miss this museum when you're in NYC!

The Frick a Museum Gem. This is one of my favorite art museums. Housed in the former residence of Henry Frick, the building alone is worth the admission.
