The audio guide and movie make the paintings even more accessible to visitors. It's limited size makes it an optimal choice for first time tourists.

A Small, Fabulous Art Museum and Home. My favorite museum in NYC. On Sundays from 11:00-1:00pm it's pay what you want to enter the museum. With an adult fee of $18 normally, I pay $5 on Sunday and spend a pleasant hour enjoying Vermeer, Holbein, El Greco, Renoir, and many others. The museum itself is Henry Frick's home and his art collection. His home is beautiful and just so enjoyable. Just a great time here.

A great day for art.. Before entering you think to yourself just how good can this be? However as you enter the mansion you soon discover the great masters of the world and their wonderful works of art. Which then leads to be curious about the collection and the owner who procured just treasures. The bottom line; go spend the day enjoy yourself.

A small but focused art collection in a beautiful space. I particularly like the portraits on display. There's a Bronzino, one of my favorite artists, and Lady Hamilton by George Romney.The entrance fee is stiff - $20, but there is a pay as you wish time slot on Sunday.

Exquisite. I spent the day at the Frick and was both calmed and dazzled by the collection. There was a special exhibit of Leighton's Flaming June when I was there, which was so much more beautiful in person than any reproduction, it took my breath away. The whole collection is wonderful, and the stories of the planning and construction of the home, the building of the collection and the amassing of the fortune that funded them were fascinating.

A Jewel of a Museum. While Fifth Avenue in the 70s is not off the beaten path, a visit to the Frick is special because it is not on the list of usual places that tourists flock to. Get there on an off hour and the home is yours. Relish the alone time with the exquisite paintings and furnishings.
Amazing collection!. An amazing collection in a wonderful house! Small enough to seeing a short visit. Great for a rainy day

Everyones favorite museum. Unquestionably,most peoples favorite small museum.Masterpieces by many old masters are housed in Henry Clay Frick's old mansion.The interior courtyard is also a beautiful space

Spectacular private home robber baron style makes a great museum. One of the most extraordinary museums in New York City, this should be on everyone's list of activities, especially if you are an art lover. The small scale provides an intimate viewing experience matched only by some of Europes fine house museums, like the Linley Sambourne House in London, or the Musée Jacquemart-André in Paris.

Nice (private) collection. If like old master paintings in a homely setting, this is the museum for you.
Good museum if you don't want to walk endlessly from one room to the other

Very opulent private library. We were able to attend a free viewing (check date and times). Saw a Beethoven original piece of music, a Guttenberg bible and lots of other interesting artifacts. If you are in the area and love books, check it out
Simply stunning. Amazing display of old masters collected by Frick. Incredible house... Now a museum. Ams do if you are into art or architecture.
I go every time that I am in NY. Small but eclectic, every piece a gem. A beautiful setting in the upper east side, and a spot of tranquility is a very busy city
Excellent. A unique trasure trove in a unique building. A must see for those who value history and art. Not great for kids.

You MUST visit The Frick. A jewel of a gallery.. If you only have time for one Gallery in New York, make it The Frick. A preserved mansion of a multi millionaire art collector whose collection has to be seen to be believed. Rembrandt, El Greco, Turner, Goya, Fragonard. The list goes on. A very manageable collection - allow a couple of hours. $20 most days. Closed Monday. Sunday opens at 11am and you can pay whatever amount you choose but you'll need to queue for maybe 15 mins. Worth it.
Boutique museum. Such a rare find! Feels like you are a guest at a mansion! Really felt very warm and very welcome, not to mention the art collection.
An amazing art museum.. A truly fantastic art museum in a very approachable setting. Not to be missed. Great Masters in an intimate setting. Very approachable.
Frick Collection. Love this collection. Definitely worth a visit. The museum is very manageable. If you feel overwhelmed by larger museums, this is a great place to visit.

The Frick is a must. My favourite art gallery..."The Frick" was the home and private collection of the Frick family. The 5th avenue mansion has been converted into a treasure trove of fine pieces. As you walk from room to room you really feel you have been whisked back to the turn of the century.

Great NYC Museum. The Frick collection is a superb Museum since it is located at the impressive new york mention of a person who loved art, was wealthy enough to collect it and wished to share with the public.To top it all his taste in art suits me perfect so I can understand and love those grand master pieces.The Museum is located next to the Central Park which makes it ideal for mixing art and nature in the middle of this great energetic city.

Stunning Gallery. We are not really into paintings but a friend at home in UK suggested we would like the Frick. WE DID! It is in a grand house off 5th Avenue near the Met. The staff were welcoming and we were fortunate to be there when a lady was giving guided tours which were really worthwhile. The audio tour gives a lot of information about the paintings, many by well known artists.I was surprised at how well I responded to this place and would give it a strong recommendation.

Worth a visit for any art lover.. Very interesting collection of paintings reflecting the personal taste of Henry Clay Frick who lived there until 1919. I went specifically to see the Holbein portraits of Thomas Cromwell and Sir Thomas More. Very peaceful relaxing setting

Great find. We had been advised by a friend to visit this art gallery and we were so pleased we did. It was absolutely beautiful. The art collection was amazing and the history of the place interesting.

Amazing!. This collection is clearly cultivated by one collector and is really one of a kind. The aesthetic is unique and elegant. It was fun to imagine the man behind the collection and to appreciate the lengths he went to to acquire and display everything in just the way he wanted. Do yourself a favor and see it!
Worth a visit. We had such a great time , wonderful place , it should be on anyone's list visiting New York . Loved the architecture of the House and the Art collection .
The ideal museum. A perfect way to spend a morning viewing an astonishing variety of amazing art, manageable in size, not too crowded, lovely surroundings.

Great collection. Our family visited the Frick on our last trip. The collection far exceeded our expectations. It was pleasant tour, very typical of many galleries but when you realize this was a private collection it is quite amazing.

Just Wonderful!. Luv this museum. There's a surprise around every corner. Love the Thomas Moore & Thomas Cromwell portraits facing each other...so amazing. The building is beautiful and the museum is so well designed.
Architectural marvel. This is an architectural marvel from the olden days. Lots of interesting woodwork and the various art pieces on display are lovely

Wonderfull. Having been to many museums over the years, I have had no pleasurable experience to better the Frick. It is small enough to cover in half a day, but will just as pleasurable to visit again and again.What once was a wonderful home contains some great works of art. I am not greatly into paintings,but even I recognised some of them.The furniture, the porcelain, the bronzes, and particularly the silver, were collected by a man of great taste.NOT TO BE MISSED

nice small museum. If you are done with huge museums and crowds, this is for you. The building is beautiful, exhibits amazing and rooms are small. Very conveniently located across Central Park. A bit pricey ($20)

Good varied collection with some gems. This is an eclectic collection that represents one man's choice, but has some real gems. The El Greco paired with two Holbein's (Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell) gets my vote of the best wall ever in a room! The Whistler collection is good. The cloisters is a real surprise - a pleasant place to sit.

My favorite museum in NYC. This is the best small museum in NYC. It is located on the upper east side in a turn of the century mansion built by Henry Clay Frick. He made his fortune in coke manufacturing pl and built this lovely home with a plan to donate it to the public. He had a great eye for art and amassed a beautiful collection of paintings, sculture, porcelain and enamels. This is a carefully edited collection including Rembrandt, Vermeer, Whistler and much more. There is a lovely garden inside the home which all rooms surround. This is a must see and you will not be disappointed.

Exquisite Collection. This lovely and personal collection is housed in a gracious mansion built both for living and displaying art. Paintings from many genres, sculptures, porcelain, Sevres, Limoges, and whimsical clocks decorate the rooms, which still contain furniture as if the Fricks were still in residence. The ideal museum for a person who appreciates art but is easily overwhelmed by the size and crowds associated with large-scale museums. I hope it never loses its charm and quiet corners where one can simply gaze upon the objects of one's admiration.

Art Gallery in an Historic Fifth Avenue Mansion. This is one of my favorite places to visit in NYC as it like visiting a mansion and an art gallery all in one perfect package. It is wonderful to see how a gallery collection is curated when it is predominantly done by the owner of the home. Sunday visits from 11 am to 1 pm are "Pay as you Wish".
I'm not an art buff but this is something else!. I loved that it's set in a house and you can get close to the paintings to look closely which I need to do as I forgot my glasses! Fabulous paintings
title says it all. very rude staff thats all i wish i didnt have to use 100 charaters for this review im doing that sucks
Really worthwhile. Wonderful for art and building itself. Not too busy. Will definitely return on next visit to NYC and that is from someone who never does something twice!

Art Lovers & Historians - Must see!. If you are an art lover the Frik Collection is a great experience....if you're not the $20 admittance fee may be a little steep and you might get bored. I personally loved it and found it fascinating to see works of art from around the world dating WAAAAAY back. Absolutely beautiful and grandiose.
Frick Collection. Hidden treasure! Very manageable little museum in an elegant mention. Includes European masters painting, sculptures, porcelain. Frequent place for special collections to enjoy!

Amazing art I architecture. This is another gallery. not to miss in New York City. Not only is the artwork comparable to what you will see at the Met, the house is an amazing example of early 1900's homes.

exqusite art collection. The architecture and atmosphere of the Frick mansion is worth a visit in and of itself. The paintings and art objects are particularly exquisite. There is also an interesting film about Frick and his era. Don't bring your kids; I don't think they're allowed in. The neighborhood (70th and Fifth Ave.) is also very beautiful.

Good collection, lovely setting. The collection is quite good and I enjoyed them. The most important aspect is the setting, they managed to create a particular ambiance and to put you in a different era and place, right in the heart of Manhattan

A museum full of atmosphere. A very nice museum which gives you an idea of the house as well of the different art types. I personally loved the Renoir painting at the stairs. It's good to visit if you have only 1-2 hours to spend.
2 hrs well spent amongst some of the worlds rarest things. beautifully reconstructed rooms, amazing sculptures and porcelain side by side with old masters, European furniture and stunning art work.
A 'must' when visiting NYC. Terrific collection of wonderful art and furniture in a beautiful house. An oasis of calm and beauty adjacent to Central Park.

Marvellous museum with very good collection!. This is a museum that you can visit and have the feeling you have a good overview in about 2 hours. Very fine collection with some famous works. Especially dutch old and renaissance masterpieces!

The Frick is a must.. If you only see one museum make it the Frick. It's not on the NYC pass, so is not as busy as some of the others. Beautiful mansion, beautifully maintained, small but marvellous collection. Saw Leightons Flaming June here, beautiful.
One of the best museums visitors don't know about. I was years ago but this is one of the most under-rated museums in NYC, definitely worth the trip when you are in the area!
The Frick collection: a must to visit. in less than 3 hours, we were able to discover such an exceptional collection of masterpieces of european

Magnificent museum.. If you are in New York or even near New York you must visit the Frick Collection. It is an amazing collection of paintings to suit all tastes. The guides are excellent. You can hire ear-phones, and for the disabled, wheelchairs are free. We loved it.

Fantastic period house / museum. Beautiful and amazing to walk through these rooms knowing that it once a home - and that the collections and furniture are still arranged as Mr. Frick enjoyed them. We spent over a hour, which was not enough time to wander around and get a real sense of the place. We did watch the film overview before beginning our tour, and I would encourage that to get the background of the Fricks and the building of the house.Note that no photos are allowed, and it is not a venue for small children (think they have an age limit).

A gem. Absolute must! It is an old friend and I always try and visit ever time I come in from London. Magnificent collection of paintings displayed in a drawing-room fashion, rather than by age, so everything ''fits.''
What the Frick?. What a lovely little know treasure, I'd never heard of it and my friend brought me. It wasn't real crowded and you could spend time appreciating the whole place.

Amazing collection. Mr Frick had a gift for collecting unusual works of art, his home which has been made available for all to enjoy and is a real treasure for the public to enjoy. The building itself is full of beautiful fittings and designs of times of old. It is unlikely it could be produced today. Sunday is free admittance however a donation is expected.

Classic artwork in an attractive and quiet setting.. The Frick is a unique museum with exotic Chinese porcelain pieces, sculpture and paintings, all of which were collected by steel magnate Frick for his home, with the understanding it would eventually become a museum. The audio guide is included in the entrance fee, and has somewhat longish descriptions of the pieces. You can easily see everything in about 2 hours.

Beautiful Art, Architecture and design. This is a wonderful museum visit to see the Frick home built in 1914 and later converted to a museum in the 30s. Mr. Frick's art collection is beautifully displayed throughtfully with the architecture and decor in many original room designed around these magnificent works: Gainesborough, Rubens, Vermeer, Degas, Goya, and so many others are joys to see. There is a terrific movie about the building's history which is helpful to view. I highly recommend joining the docent's tour of the dining room for amazing insight into the room's design, artworks, history and stories about the Frick social dining.

Sophisticated viewing of art treasures.. We always love the collections and the exhibitions of fine European art. When you are here, it is like being in a fine home, one you might have read about in a Wharton novel. Docent tours are excellent. The atmosphere virtually demands that everyone be respectful and quiet. An experience like few others.

Amazing Collection And A Must See for Art Lovers. Visited the Frick Collection and was amazed. Here is a collection that spans from early Renaissance onwards. Mr Frick amassed the collection over 40 years and it displayed in his magnificent mansion on 5th Avenue. There are enamels from Limoges, Renaissance bronzes and painting by Bellini, Vermeer, Whistler, Turner and many others.

Best small but beautiful art collection in the center of Manhattan. Our absolute favorite spot to enjoy beautiful art in the very upscale and cosy setting. Very quite most of the time, so you can take your time to sit and admire...
Beautiful collection of happy art. One of the "hidden treasures". He collected a great many happy pieces well worth the visit. Even the house is beautiful.
Best Museum in New ayork. My favorite museum in New York. Small but beautifully done. Important pieces of art, plus a look at how "the men who built America" lived.

Go on a cold snowy day. I've been to the Frick a few times and right before I left NYC, I went on a snowy day and it was absolutely beautiful as you wander through the collections with the courtyard all moody.
Lovely setting for viewing art. Outstanding collection showcased in an old mansion. Love to visit this museum whenever I have a chance on my NYC trips.

One of the best collections. This is a great museum with some of the most impressive and greatest masterpieces!
The museum is the former mansion of Henry Frick, in the upper east side
A Making and delicate private collection. Well worth the subway trip and the walk through the snow, an amazing, beautiful and delicate private museum collection-not to be missed

Come look at the garden, with flowing water and the lovely artwork. A lesser known, but well loved art venue.. A gem by anyone's standards. The gardens, the paintings. It's like being in a friend's majestic, yet approachable fine home - albeit a friend with a Holbein portrait of Henry VIII!

5th Avenue Splendor. This is a gem of a museum harkening back to the Gilded Age when people could live like royalty. The architecture and rooms are sumptuous and the art collection though eclectic, is very fine. Favorite part was just seeing the building as a home.
Frick Museum. A truly great museum. My favorite in NYC. A wonderful collection in a magnificent setting. It is small in comparison to other museums, but it is well worth a visit.

A small museum with rich history. This is one of my favorite museums in NYC. It is housed in Frick's mansion which is, architecturally speaking, beautiful. Then, you experience magnificent American and European art! The patio with the reflective pool/fountain is gorgeous.

Beautiful Collection of art!. Going to The Frick Collection is a lovely way to spend some serene and romantic time in NYC. Each room in the house holds art and furniture of mesmorizing beauty. It's a smaller museum so only a few hours are needed to fully enjoy your time. This is also a great spot for artists to sit and sketch. The Frick is always a favorite!

Stunning in every way. The Frick collection features beatiful works of art in an equally amazing building. Due to it's nature as a private collection the variety of works makes for an interesting experience where one can wonder about the thoughts going into the purchases and the work that went in to assembling the collection.

Fantastic Art Collection. I live near and used to work in New York. I never visited the Frick Collection until now. It was a fantastic collection and I thoroughly enjoyed my visit. There were paintings from all periods, sculptures, furniture and much more. I remember the painting Flaming June which was very interesting. The price at 20 dollars for entrance is OK. It is well worth it.
Smaller museum. This is a wonderful smaller museum. Every picture is a masterpiece. There are places to sit and enjoy the pictures and the wonderful building they are in.

The most exquisite collection of old Masters. It is not the biggest collection , 2 or 3 hours will see it all but the quality is fantastic. It is predominantly old masters but a few impressionists are there just to surprise you , boy it was good. Amazing to think this was one mans private collection quiet obscene really, It is not the most well known place but it is worth seeking out
Serendipitous discovery. Wonderful private collection given to the public and housed in an original mansion just off fifth avenue.

Simply Beautiful. My husband brought me here on one of our first dates. I love the collection of artwork in this museum. Also, the architecture of this building is beautiful and the gardens are so serene. It's definitely a place to visit if you appreciate art.
Small, but quaint. If you've visited the larger museums in NY, do see the Frick. It's a small museum where you can spend time and enjoy each room

Make Time to Go to the Frick Collection. So wonderful. Small, easy to see in relatively short time. The collection is amazing, the mansion beautiful. Be sure to view the film offered every 20 minutes or so for a history of the collection and the man who made it all happen.

Lovely, Interesting and Intimate. My husband and I visited here after reading Tartt's THE GOLDFINCH. We were not able to see that particular painting because the oval room in the museum was closed for cleaning. Everything else was wonderful, and the short video in the music room explains a lot about Frick's passion for art and how the museum emerged from his once-private residence. If you can, watch the video first, at the start of your tour. Especially interesting were two Hans Holbein the Younger paintings.

Great Collection!. This is a lovely museum on the Upper East Side. Well worth a visit and look out for times when entrance is free - even better! Look out for "The Girl With the Pearl Earring" a brilliant masterpiece.

Interesting. Very interesting building, but not good value for money compared to the neighboring museums. Make sure you watch the 20 min movie about the history of the Frick BEFORE you start your toor through the collection.

A Small Jewel Of A Museum. In a city packed with museums, this is one of the finest small collections you will find. Located on the stretch of Fifth Avenue known as the Museum Mile, it is about 10 blocks south of the Met. Housed in a beautifully designed grand home built just prior to the start of World War I, much of the collection is still displayed as it was when Henry Clay Frick lived there.The core of the collection, approximately two-thirds of the total, was acquired by Frick. His intention from the start was to have the house transformed into a museum and that the collection would be a living, growing one. The remaining third of the collection has been acquired by the museum since his death in 1919.The most impressive part of the collection is the wealth of Old Master paintings that line the walls. Such is the quality of these paintings that I suspect you will recognize one or two of them. There are also fine examples of 18th century furniture, terracottas, .bronze sculptures and porcelain pieces.The audio guide is quite good and is free with admission. The museum doesn't have a restaurant, but you'll find plenty of places around the corner on Madison Avenue and on the side streets.Helpful Hint: Admission on Sunday between 11AM and 1PM is whatever you wish to give. There was a small line waiting to get in when I went on the Sunday before Labor Day, but in New York you'll find longer lines at bus stops.
Frick Museum in New York City. This is our favorite museum in New York. It has some great names in art but the art is also matched to the rooms in this mansion. It has lots of personality.

Top museum in NUC. One of the most unique museums in the world. Styled as a icing place and not a museum. You are actually getting the feeling that someone might still be living here. Great collection of art. Worth spending 1-1.5 hours

great museum. have visited here several times. always love it. very peaceful and beautiful. an oasis in the city. because it is just one floor, it is perfect for people who get overwhelmed by large museums. A truly beautiful collection. and everyone loves sitting in the middle room by the water.
Beautiful art collection. I needed more than the 1 1/2 hours I allotted to this beautiful museum and art collection. The audioguides were especially helpful.

From Frick with love. Frick had quite negative reputation among some people when he was alive. All those people, Frick and Frick haters are long time gone. However, it’s the legacy of Frick that became immortal in this wonderful mansion that was turned into the museum. Thanks G-d no one was obsessed with an idea of Frick's wealth re-distribution and that's why I could bring my family to this fabulous bastion of art.

An oasis of culture on the East Side. This wealthy industrialist's house on upper 5th Avenue couldn't have been put to better use than for it to be a gallery to house Mr Frick's extensive collection of the best of European art and artefacts. It's a calming oasis amid the Avenue's relentless traffic, and one encounters many gems of paintings that you know from books, but never realised they were here. I particularly liked Holbein's 16th century portraits of arch-rivals Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell facing each other grimly, but separated by a large fireplace. The Frick house itself (at least the ground floor and garden that I saw) is very fine and lavish in the style of late-19th century multi-millionaires. My only cavil with the institution is that it lacks a café, which on the 90-degrees day that I was there would have been a great asset, not to say money-spinner.

One of the US best art museums, the Frick Collection includes a number of masterpieces of different artists and eras. This is one of the best art museums in the US. We have enjoyed the masterful collection which is remarkable for the breath and range of artists and artistic periods of time. The building -the mansion of one of the U S richest men--beautifully displays these paintings in an intimate setting.

Hidden Gem. On my third visit to NYC I finally made it to the Frick I had been wanting to visit for a long time & was not disappointed. It's just as if you are visting their home but they are out, but with many amazing pieces of art in such a marvellous & peaceful setting. The audio guides & film give all the information needed for anyone remotely interested in art & beauty this is a must see, there are many masterpieces to view it truely is a fantastic & tranquil place not far from the bustle of the city, go you will not be disappointed.
Good location, but in disrepair. Very small museum. A few of the rooms were closed. $20/person is expensive for just a few rooms. Audio tour makes banal comments.

Amazing. Painting after painting from your Art History Textbook is to be found in this fabulous and extremely accessible collection. The Met may be the best but everything at the Frick is a masterpiece.

A MUST SEE OF NYC. If you like museums and you like art, this is a must see in NYC. It is on 1 East 70 st, just in front of Central Park.It is an amazing house, owned by Frick and now is a museum with all the collection of paintings of his owner (Frick).It is very well organized, they give a kind of telephone were you go around checking the painting and sculptures you are interested in.Also there is a good explanation of the rooms, very detailed.It is for sure a place to visit.The admission fee is 24U$D

Excellent, as usual. The collection is always attractive. But the staff can be blunt, something tourists do not deserve. The shop is always interesting. Gardens are a place where to stay and do nothing but think or write.
Good to see only if you have spare time.. Great collection. easy access. Dont miss it if you have time. But don't go there right after Metropolitan, unless you are an art connoisseur.

Beautiful Museum. Such a beautifully curated collection, and the perfect size to peruse in an hour or so - not overwhelming. The Frick has been on my list for quite a while, so it was a must while in the city with friends. The home, artwork and ambiance certainly did not disappoint.We went on a Sunday during the pay-what-you-wish window from 11am-1pm.

How the One Per Cent used to live and maybe still do. Excellent museum, furnishings, architecture, sculpture, paintings, clocks, carpets, you name it. The staff are largely very helpful and friendly, even though the place gets very crowded

A little gem of a museum and art collection.. The Frick Museum is conveniently located, walking distance from the Met (Metropolitan Museum of Art) and is exquisite. It is of particular interest if you love the paintings of Vermeer, of which it has a significant number of those in existence anyway in the world. Moreover, the setting gives one the feeling of being back in the world of the great industrialists ( Carnegie, Vanderbilt, Morgan, Frick, etc).
Loved visiting the Frick. Wonderful art, amazing to think that people used to live here, great museum without feeling like a museum

timing is important!. I went on a sunday - there is a free classical concert in the evening, and they provide wheelchairs so I could bring my husband. To visit the museum, view the artwork then settle in atrium hand in hand to hear the music was bliss (except for the ad loudspeakers!). It is not often we could enjoy such simple pleasures - a feast of and for the senses - together.

An Incredible Collection With an Unfortunate Staff. This is such a wonderful (and very manageable) art collection right near all the other NYC biggies (the Met, Guggenheim, etc.). This is a museum where you can truly zip through the collection in 25 minutes, or you could spend all day. It is housed in the old Frick Estate (which is half the reason you should come) and has a much more warm and personal feel as opposed to other major museums. With that said, the admission is steep (and NOT suggested... except for on Sundays between 10am-2pm, where you can pay as you wish. Most people throw in $5 per ticket), and the staff is very cold and unwelcoming. Go on a Sunday. Drag the kids (because this is a museum is small enough to avoid tired meltdowns). Pay $5.

The Frick Museum in New York in a must see for museum lovers and those who appreciate art and history.. Having visited the Frick in Pittsburgh I was very interested to see the Frick Collection in New York. I was with my 13 year old granddaughter on this trip. The Frick is easy to find either with the metro or bus. The building is wonderful and was built by Henry Clayton Frick for his family but with the intention of having if function as a museum. Some House...the rooms are opulent and very spacious. The collection is wonderful and both my granddaughter and I loved the painting "Flaming June". Both the original small sketch and the very large painting adapted from the small one are on display. The colors and subject are beautifully done. My granddaughter was disappointed not to be able to take photos as she loved this painting..this is not unusual in a museum however. Sometime after the Fricks died and left the museum there were changes made to the building. The most impressive in my opinion was creating the garden and inner courtyard area that had once been a road. This is the only area in the building where picture taking is allowed. It is a peaceful and serene area and great if you need to be rejuvenated and rest your feet. The cost to see the collection and the building is reasonable and because it is a small, intimate museum it can be seen without consuming most of a day. Seeing this museum really added to my knowledge of the Frick family and the legacy they have left both here and in Pittsburgh. Highly recommend.

A Wonderful Experience. Far and way my favorite museum in New York. While the collection is not as magnificent as the MoMA or the Metropolitan Museum of Art, keep in mind that it was collected by one guy! More importantly, the museum isn't as crowded as others, which means it's a better experience and you can enjoy the art and furniture in a more leisurely environment.

Always inspiring. Visited with out of town friends. Have not been there for a few years. Beautiful museum, a pleasure to browse slowly spending time in front of unique works of art. At the time we also saw French tapestry exhibit, amazing pieces. Wonderful place to spend a few hours with magnificent art in a historic NY setting without crowds and feeling overwhelmed, especially if you do not have the whole day.

YES! If you love art, history, architecture!. Though this was going to be boring? OH MY WAS AMAZING!!!Such a lovely glimsp into the rich elite old money, the foundation roots of NYC. The collection is superb. The audio tour acted as nice guide. Highly recommended
Great little known site in NYC. Great venue for a an extraordinary small, Impressionist focused collection. The beautiful Upper East Side Mansion in which it's housed contributes to the experience.

A gem. Henry clay Frick mansion in 5th avenue is a gem not to be missed. The art collection especially of European art is second to none. Eapecially great is Hobleins the younger portrait of Thomas Cronwell,and Thomas Moore. The mansion and the furniture make time spent here different from the other museums in Manhattan. You have thus not only the art but also the mansion to savor.
Nice exhibition. I had the chance to visit the Frick collection while there was an El Greco collection. Very nice museum
Wonderful museum. This museum is a find. Wonderful old mansion with an amazing art collection. Well worth a visit. Very good audio guide is available.

Great private art collection in fashionable mansion.. I love to see art work in private home/estate settings. It is much more personal than a grand museum. The Frick collection had works that I was interested in, many I was not, but over all a good experience.

A choice collection. Henry Clay Frick knew what he was doing when he built his house on 5th Avenue to display his amazing collection of European paintings and works of sculpture. He had discerning taste and the art, hung as Frick and his guests would have seen it, reflects this. Admission includes an audio guide which keeps the museum very quiet and sedate as visitors are listening rather than talking. The overall mood is almost reverential. The other noticeable feature of this gallery is that there are no children. Under 10s are not allowed.

Rude people. I have been to many museums and art galleries and generally I do not have a problem following the rules, and in some places, there are a lot of them. I get the idea that you should not cross the lines painted on the floors and not to touch, but the tour guides, or should I say, guards, take these rules to a new level. My wife was told that she should move away from the windows and not look out, I am serious. When asked why, she was told it was a rule. What should have been a wonderful experience, and in some way it was to simply to see the art work on display and the building itself, was marred from the attitude of the people was look at you. We were also followed around, us middle aged tourists must be seen as a threat. Would I go back, NO!

Very nice small art museum. Really nice little museum with great art - It is the former home of Henry Frick so it's nice that you can see in some of the rooms how he lived and in other rooms just long galleries of art. I like it because it's small and you can stroll through it in a couple of hours leaving plenty of time to do other things.
A jewel in NYC!. A jewel in NYC! Must see. Next to Central Park, fine art, architecture, paintings, sculptures and rugs.
Favorite NYC art spot. This is the spot to see a beautiful collection of art without the intensity and lines of the big museums, but definitely in the same caliber.
Exquisite!. A real gem. The art is spectacular and the building itself is beautiful. You can easily spend hours there.

Just Go to The Frick. The Frick is a lovely intimate art museum with a lovely collection. Whenever I go there, I feel like I am visiting old friends. The Frick adds tremendous character to the city and I am glad it is there so I can go again and again.

A peek into a personal collection. This is a small personal collection in what used to be a home. And because of the size, it can be visited in just over an hour without tiring. Previously free, it now charges an entrance fee, but the audio equipment is free. An interesting video explains the history which adds a backdrop to the man behind this place. The house itself is a big part of the tour, although only the ground floor misnomer to the public.

Must-See Mansion, Excellent Collection!. Smallish yet breathtaking collection with emphasis on American artists, though several Rembrandts, a Monet, Manet, multiple Picasso. The setting is unbelievable! What a stunning place. The staff could have been a bit friendlier, but overall this is a place to which we cannot wait to return!!

Beautiful artwork in stunning mansion. This hidden gem on the Upper East Side, a mile down from the Met, is not to be missed. Beautiful artwork in every room provides a peaceful respite from the hustle and bustle of Manhattan. The ban on young children ensures a low-key experience.

Very special museum experience. There is no other museum in New York quite like the Frick. The quality of the works on display coupled with the integrated setting make this house museum the perfect place to visit.

A Small Museum--Compared to the Met, Perhaps..... The Frick is a great museum to visit, especially if you have just an afternoon instead of a full-day--or a week. There's an excellent array of Old Masters, including a couple of Rembrandts, Turners, and Vermeers--it doesn't get much better than that. The collection reflects Frick's personal preferences, rather than those of an art specialist, but overall is remarkably good. Seeing these things in the context of Frick's own late 19th-century mansion adds to the experience, though you'll find nothing to match the charm and quirkiness of Isabella Stewart Gardner's Venetion-style "palazzo" in Boston. The collection includes four Whistler full-length portraits--probably the most recent items the Frick owns. Well worth the cost of admission.

A Magnificent Little Jewel in the string of museums on 5th Ave.. This is just about my favorite museum on earth. Small enough to handle in a couple of hours, a great mix of mostly European periods, that reflects Frick's taste in really interesting ways. When you stand before the two portraits by Holbein - More and Cromwell, you will understand what makes art great, and history too. This should be your first stop in NYC. Every time you go.
Outstanding gallery.. The Frick Collection gallery is highly recommended. Amazing building, the mini tours are worth hanging around for to get some history of the building and the collection.
Must do!. We loved the Frick experience, to see inside such an amazing house was very special not to mention the art!

Beautiful mansion, superb collection. The steel baron had an eye for excellent art. The predominantly European collection in Frick's NYC residence is excellent. Many large masterpieces and of a much higher quality than in other private collections. Also many beautiful ceramics. The Fragonard room was impressive. The two large JMW Turners dominate the long room and are very special. Will take a couple of hours and worth the visit. Check for times such as Sunday morning at 11:00 when admission is whatever you want to pay, but get there early as the line can grow long.

My favourite gallery in NYC. I really enjoyed visiting the Frick Collection. It reminded me of my trips to Eruope. The gallery presents many of the best dutch 'clasaical' paintings. If you like that style. You should go! The museum is well organized, have a free audio guide and a very pleasant staff.
Love the frog on the pond . Beautiful museum and collection with "pay as you like" policy on Sunday mornings. Long lines that move quickly, so do not miss it!

Big Collection. This was something I heard about and always wanted to do. So I finally stopped here over the weekend. It was definitely worth coming to besides the collection the place was beautiful the detailed moldings, furniture, indoor garden. It was $20 to get in, that included the audio guided head set. Which is worth it. There are so many beautiful paintings through out and some of them date back to the 1400's. A lot of them have biblical references. I really enjoyed coming. They do have a coatroom if you have stuff you want to check and not carry around during the tour.
OH YES !. Enjoy this beautiful mansion, great art collection, lovely inside courtyard...a true delight any time you visit NYC.

Hidden Gem. This collection is as close to perfect as any collection I've seen - and I've seen a few. The settings of the art works, the use of space and arrangements of the paintings themselves hold the attention like few other exhibits I've been to.The galleries are littered with classic masterpieces and old masters. And these world class paintings are displayed to be as beautiful as possible. And they are...they are...

Outstanding Paintings from the best artists. The Frick Collection is my favorite museum ever! It is smaller than many, but absolutely exquisite. Mr. Frick's art preferences completely align with mine! I visit the museum every time I go to NYC! Don't miss it!
Impressive. "Flaming June" is gorgeous! Not to be missed! Take the audio tour. Make sure to spend time in the beautiful garden. Savor the moment....
Incredible Collection. a small boutique collection in a quiet, turn of the sentry mansion. A little harder to get to, but worth the time and trouble to see these masterpieces up close.

Stunning collection. This is somewhat of a hidden gem, compared to the huge art museums in the city. But you will find some of the loveliest artwork that you have ever seen. It's a former home of the Frick family, so you will go from room to room to view the collection. Not only is the collection breathtaking, but the home is beautifully decorated as well. A must-see!

Overrated waste of time. If you like Rococo art this is for you. Otherwise don't waste your time. Also after reading about the Frick history, I wouldn't want to support this place more than I already have.
Great Masters, elegant setting. If you like art you will love this collection. Rembrant, Titian etc. The Mansion is exquisite. There are beautiful pieces of furniture as well as bronzes.

Historical, must attend, just watch your breathing. If you don't go to see the art, go because the history of the building and family is another American example of focus and determination. Make sure you see the documentary movie so you understand the building and what art to look for within the rooms. The gift shop is small but at the same time has wonderful books and pieces to purchase as a reminder of your visit...and the ladies in the shop are smiling and very friendly. My only caution to anyone how has breathing problems is that certain rooms caused me to have breathing issues due to a moldy odour. My lungs are very very sensitive to mold/mildew so I can tell when it is in the air. Not all rooms so don't be scared off. I still recommend this museum.

How the 1% lives. I have always loved the Frick Collection. When I was growing up here in NYC there was no charge for admission so I would visit it every week when I got my dental braces tightened just around the corner. It is still worth the price of admission. Walking the rooms, experiencing the art Henry Clay Frick bought for himself is a special experience. Check out the film on the Collection which I believe still runs every half hour or so. It enhances your experience of the place and gives you interesting background history. I have seen it many times but every so often I watch it again. Or, just walk and enjoy the art and the lovely rooms. On a hot day, sitting in the fountain courtyard is a good way to catch one's breath and slow down in this fast city.
Great architecture, not so great art. Great house and interesting architecture, not so grat art. A bit Pricey for the experience. I also hate that pictures are not allowed at all.

Unique Experience. The art in this beautiful mansion, is displayed in the manner of a private collection, in a private home (rather than as a large, open, museum gallery). This is quite unusual in The United States, much more common in Europe. There are very famous, beautiful works of art, in this collection. Don't overlook the breathtaking,small Vermeer's.
viewing general collection. My favorite Museum in New York City, top notch paintings and sculpture and easy to navigateJust wished there was a café there to refuel

Go if you can spare the time, it's FRICKin' awesome. I always though that art displayed in a less formal environment then that of a museum was a much nicer way, plus you get to see art not in a massive way you actually forget it all since it's so massive.Make sure to check the hours( closes early) and that you check for their temporary exhibitions too. It's a very short walk from Central Park, so you can always take a stroll there right after, or continue to museum mile, it's all right there. That Henry Frick person was surely some art collector. Enjoy that different kind of a museum!

Interesting collection, but with so much else to see in NYC.... I enjoyed this, but the Met has so much more to offer that I would recommend spending a few days there and then if you have time left over, yeah, go ahead and go the Frick.

A thing of beauty. Mr. Frick once lived in the magnificent home. This is a place where art can be viewed in a comfortable, non- threatening atmosphere. It does not feel like a museum but rather someone's home with a great deal of art pieces in his collection. One can really take art in for what it is. Appreciate the beauty of creation of some of the world's most famous and in some cases, not so famous artists. Just sit in one of the rooms or take in the beautiful garden, that was once his driveway. Try to imagine carriages coming down the driveway in a time when life was simpler without internet, wifi, or cellular devices. Put your communication device away and take in the beauty of the art provided at the Frick Collection.

These sort of houses are a dime a dozen in Europe. We came here last week, it was a lovely large historical looking house. It cost about $20 to get in per person, although on Sundays 11am-2pm (I think that's the right time) they do pay what you wish. It's full of historical art and sculptures. It has about 6 large rooms of art and a courtyard. Alongside a theatre with a film showing you critics of the art work. I found this art gallery not to my taste. I thought it was small for $20 and I felt I had seen it all before in many stately homes in England. It may be more appealing for Americans if you're into this era of art.

A home as an art collection. A very different experience in the vicinity of the Metropolitan Museum of Arts: a small, specialized collection that has a rare advantage: Several of its rooms look exactly the same way as they were since the original residence was built and let decorated by the industrialist: a home. Mostly European paintings, most of them reflect a special taste (e.g. a love of Fragonard), but you go there for the atmosphere. The Frick regularly organizes excellent temporary exhibitions, check it out at the website.

closes early---be aware. building is beautiful-----art is---well--we didn't have much time---turns out they tell you they close at 6 pm--but they start pushing you out at 5:45----very unfriendly staff
Serenity on the Upper Eastside. Beautiful, serene venue in the middle of the Upper Eastside. A fairly quick tour and an educational documentary available while on the grounds.

Enjoyed a few key pieces and moved on to other museums. I'm sure the collection is great if this is your thing. We were happy to use the reciprocal admission from our hometown art museum, and had a look at the portrait of Thomas More before attending the excellent Wolf Hall plays by the Royal Shakespeare Company. We enjoyed seeing George Washington's portrait as well, but the majority of the paintings and furniture just weren't must-see pieces for us.

Frick-n' amazing!. Fabulous collection in a space that's intimate and manageable enough to fully appreciate in a day, unlike many of the cities mega-museum spaces. Beautiful garden/court yard space with an excellent cafe.

Small jewel in the big city. Another jewel in New York showing great artist in a smaller beautiful setting. The mansion of Mr. Frick on fifth avenue facing central park shows you how those Gilded Age tycoon lived. 20 century artist are no represented, but The Vermeer collection is great, you can see masters from many countries in Europe, but as far I can remember 2 or three American artists. Check the painting of the Countesse d' Haussonville I love it

Pay-What-You-Like Sunday is worth the short queue.. We visited on "Pay What You Want" Sunday, (not to be confused with "Free Entry Friday at MoMA, they do still make you queue and 'purchase' tickets, so you feel guilty if you try to pay too small an amount!) but didn't stay for long and didn't quite feel it would be worth $20 each seeing as none of us are big fans of art. However, with an Audio guide to take around with you with commentary on at least every work of art and extra on the rooms plus 2 short films shown in the music room, it would be easy to spend a whole day here! However, there is no where to eat lunch. We just popped in for the morning and were particularly keen to see a few distinct paintings. Luckily a guide was able to direct us to the correct rooms to save our time and we were impressed by all the works of art, and by the story behind the collection. It is very rare to walk through a gallery and find something to see in every piece hanging; there are no cast-offs in the Frick Collection.

Amazing collection. We went specifically to see Flaming June, on loan from the museum in Puerto Rico, but now I know we'll be back. This is an amazing home that was built with the specific intent of the owner to have it become a museum after his death. There are some wonderful works of art, including paintings, china, furniture, and pen and pencil drawings. I would highly recommend a stop here on your NYC trip or tour. And for those of you (like us) who are but a train ride away, it's so worth a day trip!
beautiful art. private home with many artwork from impressionists.it is definitely worth the visit!! interior courtyard makes you travel through time
Lovely Art Oasis. Beautifully displayed art collection in a serene setting. If there is a line, buy a membership if you can. Saves time and supports a good cause.
Museum lover's mecca. Perhaps the most gorgeous museum for adults only (you must be of age) in a glamorous location. With easy access to Central Park.

Worth the trip. I enjoy some art, primarily impressionism, and this collection had enough for my interest. I spent about 1 and a half hours touring the collection and it was as much a tour of the mansion as it was perusing the art on the walls. I do not appreciate art enough to spend too much time at a gallery, but the mansion itself and history of it's inception made it very interesting. Strolling along Central Park up Fifth Avenue on a nice summer day is wonderful too. The price is $20 and it includes the audio tour which is most useful and I was very pleasantly surprised that it was included. I am very glad I went.
Perfect day with intimate collection. Gorgeous collection of great art,best museum in NYC,no crowds,no kids under 10,I think. Wonderful audio tour!
Top small museum in the city. Not only do you get to see a really wonderful collection of art and sculpture but the setting is in an 1800's mansion on 5th avenue-a treat in itself.

Favourite and perfect gem of a museum in NYC. This museum houses one of my favorite paintings which is Thomas More by Holbein - I could just look at this painting for hours, it's so alive and sympathetic.The fact that these fabulous works of art are presented in what was Frick's private residence makes the experience more intimate and rewarding than other museums in NYC for me. There are enough quality paintings, sculptures, china, furniture etc to keep you occupied for hours even though the museum itself is quite small scale. I liked that he often chose to display matching paintings together such as a husband and wife or the Thomas More Holbein opposite Holbein's Cromwell - arch enemies eyeing one another for eternity!There's a good audio guide.At the centre of the museum is a beautiful plant covered courtyard
A must museum in nyc. This is a beautiful meuseum in a beautiful structure. It's amazing to walk inside and take it all in a must visit in nyc
Must visit. Can't believe we waited so long to come here. Wonderful collection of art displayed in such an enjoyable manner.

Always something interesting. There is always something interesting to see at the Frick. The regular collection is the main feature but there are temporary exhibits of a variety of things which are worth a quick visit even if you have seen the main collection many times.

Crime pays. I walked in the door of this house/museum and the first thing I thought was who did Frick rob to get all this beautiful art. The answer is probably everybody. That being said the collection is first rate and the short movie doesn't begin to tell the true story of how Frick stole and killed his way to the top

A masterpiece. An amazing museum!! Much more intimate than the Met or Moma. Location is wonderful and the mansion itself is lovely! The personal collection includes Rembrandt , Goya, El Greco, Velazquez and many more masterpieces. Highly recommend!!

Don't miss this highlight of NY art museums.. I've seen classical art collections all over but this one has to rate as one of the very best. Jaw-dropping in its comprehensiveness and number of truly great (and even famous) pieces. The fact that it's in what was a private home on Fifth Avenue is almost unbelievable.

Park it!. Very clean and well maintained park. Many things to see and do at the park. Take a carriage ride, go to the children's zoo, or just enjoy the walk through the beautiful park. I would love to go back in the fall and see the park in the fall.

Amazing!. I'm not a museum lover, but this beautiful masterpiece is a definite exception. Their curated programs are a must visit if you're in NY for a longer span. But ensure to book it prior, as they generally go sold out. :)

A quick walk into Frick's personal collection. The Frick Collection is a personal collection of different artifacts. I was expecting to see a museum but it's not that. The objects are grouped together based on what looks good together. I found it ironic seeing chinese porcelain with italian paintings and other european furniture.Not much information was given on the exhibits but books are available at the store.It feels very comfy like a home rather than a museum.
fantastic museum. Fantastic place, you can see some old piece of an important museum. Is better than Met o Moma. I suggest!

Visiting the Frick is a must.. The Frick is a gem; it is an impressive, old mansion that has been perfectly conserved and which houses an outstanding collection of art. It is small and will not overwhelm you like some of the larger museums in NYC, but you can easily spend 2-3 hours enjoying both building and art. The central covered patio is a cool oasis where one can rest and admire the beauty of the place. Go on Sundays when there is no admission charge.

outstanding. Just a lovely museum, quiet and interesting. You can sometimes feel all alone with the works. They also have pay what you can on Sundays. Easy walking distance from the subway and the Met and Guggenheim. A must in any Museum tour.
Favorite museum in NYC. This small but stunning museum is definitely worth a visit. Doesn't take long and it's just a jewel.
Worth the Time. Although by no means the MET or MOMA the Frick is a place to visit for every traveler who has already hit the big museums. Enjoy!
cultural Oasis of Peace & Quiet. Oasis of peace & quiet in the hustle and bustle of NYC!Great Flemish/Dutch collection, great building, great atmosphere!

Henry Clay Fricks exquisite collection and gorgeous home. You can do no better in a collection of art from medieval to Whistle. Gorgeous gorgeous collection in his remarkably beautiful home. I just love it. This is my fourth visit. My family's first and they were utterly amazed. Galleries galore in this private home, exquisite gardens to bring your lunch by the fountains. This is a museum home designed to make you feel a part of the old world elegance. One of my top three in NYC.

Such exquisite and beautiful arts. In a splendid mansion overlooking 5th avenue, you have to look everywhere, from the floors to the ceillings and especially on the walls. Beautiful furnitures, statues, paintings and porcelaine vessels. Everything is in the same place as the owner put it when he bought it. Stay for the short movie, it explains very well how Frick acquired these beautiful arts. Take the audio guide. They are for free and no explanations are given for the different objects.

Excellent collection curated in the original setting of the owner.. The collection is stunning and an opportunity to view works of the great artists without too many crowds. The collection is superb for whiling away a couple of hours without feeling overwhelmed by the number of paintings presented.

Excellent art mixed with much average. Perhaps the very high quality art museums in Fort Worth in which almost every piece on display is among the artists very best work has spoiled us. Many outstanding works are on display in the Frick. However; more are lesser works by some great artists or are works by lesser artists.

Great museum no one visits. Great art collection in former private residence.
Only American artists is Whistler. Great furniture.

One of my favorite art collections in the world!. I visit the Frick Collection several times per year. The paintings inspire me. It is not as crowded as going to the Met and having to fight to see the art. Enjoy listening to the audio descriptions of the art work including the three Vermeer works.. I really love the inner courtyard with the serene flowing water. When there are special exhibits, it only adds to the pleasure.

Absurd entrance rules. We came to this museum to enjoy its art collection but at the entrance we were told that kids are not allowed. As a mom I felt myself really discriminated. Art should be accessible to all. And it's very strange that such absurd and discriminative rules exist in a country where democracy is the main principle.

A favorite. The Frick Collection feels like stepping into the right kind of past. It offers a wonderful collection in a gorgeous building (with places to sit!) It tends to be less crowded that the other NY museums. The staff is friendly and informative.

Breathtaking. What a wonderful surprise. The building itself is a masterpiece and the artwork displayed inside of it made my knees weak. It's probably the loveliest setting for art that I've ever encountered.

Great collection and less crowded than other major museums.. Enjoyed a few hours touring the Frick collection. The beautiful house that is the museum adds to the enjoyment as many of the paintings and furnishings are where they were when the museum was used as a home. Amazing variety of artwork, including 3 Vermeers! The entrance fee includes the use of a handheld device that helps explain many of the pieces; very enjoyable and interesting.

Jewel of a museum: Mansion, gardens, inner courtyard, stunning permanent collection & top-drawer exhibitions!. The intimate Frick Collection may seem "old-fashioned" (yet always tasteful & elegant), but the institution has pioneered the "one-work" mini-exhibition. Many times, including this summer, one work is "imported" from a far-away fellow museum, and highlighted along with related works from the Frick's own collection, or other loans.Don't forget the downstairs galleries for visiting larger exhibitions, as well, and on your way out, stop by the mostly-paper-based gift shop...
Charming Museum. A small and charming place, with a great collection and exhibits, all inside a beautiful building thats worth going just for the architecture!

Lovely small museum with exquisite collections. beautiful museum...very small in comparison to others but beautifully displayed inside a once privately owned house. Enjoyed its magnificence but would have liked a commemorative photo or two!

Great Collection in its original setting. The Frick Mansion on 5th Avenue at 70th Street looks like a suddenly unknown angle view of the Trianon had landed gracefully there garden and all. Amazingly enough, but inside it gets better than Trianon.Mr. Frick's Collection is the best of the famous robber baron fortunes. It as miraculously assembled and perfectly displayed: There is a French room all covered with Fragonard panels, matched by the beauty of the French furniture and porcelain collection. In our age of Conceptual and Investment Art it is very difficult to think that when people had money they actually could live surrounded by all this great objects that have authentic quality, great provenance and that actually look perfect with the paintings.Close by there is another room also with panels by Boucher that were specifically done for the infamous Mme de Pompadour, mistress of Louis XV, a dilettante with interest in art only as a means of self promotion and personality projection, she would have felt right at home in this room though at the time they were finally finished she rejected the works because the fashion had changed.There is an English Chippendale style dining room with a great collection of silver and portraits by Gainsborough including the beautiful Mrs. Elliot, mistress to the Duc d'Orleans that voted for his cousin's death (Louis XVI) and was guillotined himself shortly after, yet Mrs. Elliot who was in Paris at the time was not, because she was a British subject and eventually went back to England.The collection has a grand gallery that displays two truly wonderful Turners, a Velazquez portrait that is open of the best he ever painted of Philip IV, two fabulous Veronese allegories, a very impressive self portrait by Rembrandt, Van Dycks, Frans Hals, Tintoretto, Corot...and around the room there is a great collection of Renaissance bronzes and cassonne in case you may need respite, the paintings spill over other rooms: Three Grecos, Four Goyas, THREE Vermeers, each one better than the last one, and that's about 10% of the ENTIRE output of Vermeer! a great Bronzino, A Bellini of St Francis that is as radiant as the saint's spirit, two great Titians including the great Aretino, the first media genius and playwright. There is the portrait of St Thomas More by Holbein that is illustrated in all the books on Henry VIII, and next to it across the fireplace the chancellor that succeeded him and was also beheaded and also by Holbein, this amidst an extraordinary gathering of Boulle furniture and Chinese porcelain.There are also French Renaissance enamels, in a little room, recently restored where there is a Duccio that is twice the size of the one at the MET, and treasures by Piero della Francesca and Cimabue among others.Although better known for the Old Masters housed there the Frick has quite a few masterpieces of Impressionist art: Renoir, Degas and Manet all have great paintings there and Whistler has several, including a seascape and the famous portrait he painted of the Baron de Montesquieu, who inspired Proust's character the Baron de Charlus in his famous Remembrance of Things Past.The central court garden and fountain is one of the few rare public spaces in NY that is peaceful, serene, and restful, there are sometimes temporary exhibits around this garden and also downstairs in a two gallery space that can be reached by the staircase that is right in front of the bookshop.There is a new additional gallery overlooking the garden to accommodate rotating exhibits of the Frick's great collection of Meissen porcelain, don't miss it as it it is only accessible through the library.The shop at the Frick is one of the few remaining quality bookstores in the city, like the Frick House and Collection the collection it is small, but every inch filled with quality.

My favorite art collection. There is a very rich selection of wonderful museums and galleries in NYC, but this is definitely my favorite. It's an impecably decadent art collection that always makes me smile. Not too big not too small- it takes me about 2-3 hours everytime I go there. Free on Sundays between 11:00 and 13:00 and they have a 50% student discount everyday.
Mini Met. If your time is limited and you can't handle the Met, this is a nice alternative. Lots of beautiful paintings, furniture and exhibits. Easily done in 1 to 2 hours. Great date place.
Best small collection in NY. Often overlooked as a museum but these is a delightful place with a great collection and free audio guide. Takes a half day.
The Frick. Wonderful museum. So many beautiful works of art, it boggles the mind. Plan on spending at least half a day. You can't rush through the Frick.

THE FRICK ........ One of the best collections of artwork in a superb environment to show the work in a natural and peaceful way. There is not enough room here or time to list all the attractions there. My favorites are the Japanese influenced Whistlers, The Four Seasons, and those incredible Rhembrants with the sparkle of the jewels and the eyes of the artists subjects captured in oil paint. You can feel the soft texture of the fur on their sleeve. After 50 years, I still eat it up. I like Cezannes peaches too.
Trip back in time. If you enjoy art and the grandeur of seeing a magnificent l mansion. Take this tour. I have not stopped dreaming yet.

A largely undiscovered treasure.. This is a hidden gem if you like art and your tastes are eclectic. I couldn't believe what amazing old masters were lurking in there. The audio guide is excellent and it's quite quiet. Well worth a visit.

Don't miss it!. As an art teacher, this would have to be one of the best museum collections/buildings I have been to. The art collect was fabulous with so many well known works that I studied years ago. The design of the building also needs to be appreciated. The foresite of Frick in developing this 'family home' as a museum needs to be slowly appreciated. Get there early and take your time. It's well worth it. If your short of a dollar go on a Sunday as admission is by donation (USD$20 is the usual fee). For a quick look check out the free virtual tour at http://www.frick.org/visit/virtual_tour

Wonderful small new York gallery. One of New York's best museums. Housed in former home of Henry Frick an impressive collection of paintings of major European artists,numerous works of sculpture & porcelain. It also has 18th century French furniture, Limoges enamel & Oriental rugs. Included in our enjoyable 2-3 hours viewing were works by Frans Hals, Vermeer, Constable, Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Renoir & Turner. Not open on Mondays, On Sundays, pay what you wish from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. Definitely worth the normal entry fee $20, $15 for seniors. No photos of art allowed.
Well worth it for art lovers. One of the best museum in New York and one of the least heard of. If you appreciate art, don't miss the frick.

one of the great museums of the world. There is nothing like the Frick collection, still a quiet meditative place to look at art on weekday mornings. Leave the weekends to the crowds. Every artwork a masterpiece.
art at the frick. excellent art collection,just amazing all in this gorgeous mansion,if you have just a couple hours to spare this is it,worth checking out!

Go for the Mansion as well as Art. Very interesting collection and the house itself is worth seeing. I enjoyed this place very much. There is a great film talking about Frick, the house and the collection in the Music room. Great background for what you are seeing.

Love at first sight. From the very first time I went to the Frick, on my first trip to NY, I fell in love with it. Gorgeous building and some iconic paintings I had assumed were somewhere like the Louvre, rather than a private collection. When I was there this time, there was temporary exhibitions of sculptures and a visiting collection from Scotland.If you want an all-round taste of culture, rather than at least 4 hours in the Met or other superb, but massive, museums and galleries, you won't go wrong with the Frick.Go before the proposed restructure to get the atmosphere and charm of the original home of Henry Clay.

The insecurities at the court of Henry 8th.. Having seen Mark Rylance as Thomas Cromwell on BBC last winter, I went to see the latter's portrait by Holbein, & Thomas More as well. Just to see them there eyeing each other, made the visit worthwhile

Amazing. My wife and I absolutely loved the frick collection. This mansion itself is gorgeous and the artwork inside is something that should not be missed. We loved the polish rider by Rembrandt. We loved the flaming June exhibit. Crowds definitely wasn't an issue. Staff in the museum shop were very helpful and friendly

Step into Another World. Vermeer and Fragonard among this wonderful collection offirst- class art. The mansion is flawless. Sit in the interior "cloister". Concerts are sometimes given there. The Frick is an island of tranquility situated in a rather bus island. One must visit it.

Eclectic but brilliant. An amazing and brilliant collection of some of the world's best paintings in a beautiful setting. It may be referred to as eclectic, but to decorate one's house with only one style or period would be boring, and we are enjoying someone's house decorated with his art, and stunning the quality of the collection definitely is. Far more enjoyable than the Met, and less crowded than the Rijksmuseum.

Excellent exhibits. The Frick has moved to the west Village or there abouts. We went midmorning on Saturday and timed it right. when we cam out, the line was a block long. We enjoyed the exhibits and the glass of wine we had upstairs in the café.

Interesting collection of art in a Gilded Age mansion. The Frick Collection is housed in an amazing gilded mansion. My daughter and I went to see the Flaming June exhibit but were impressed with the variety of European paintings, porcelain, furniture, clocks, etc. The collection is free/donate what you wish on Sundays from 11 to 1 pm. The website has virtual tours and is definitely worth checking out before a visit in person.
Compact Charm. This is a world-class museum packed full of delightful surprises.The art collection is comprehensive and exciting, house in a gorgeous mansion on Fifth Avenue. It's a must-see!

Exceeded expectations!. This is an underrated gem in the city. The mansion itself is worth the visit, especially when you find out some of the history behind it and its owners. In addition, it has an excellent collection of art from many parts of the world. Very unexpected and definitely worth the visit. Also, from 11 AM to 1 PM on Sundays it’s pay as you wish, i.e. the entrance fee is entirely up to you – can’t go wrong.
An eclectic mix of art. Not only do you get to see some diverse art you get a sense of the 5th Avenue mansions now mostly all gone.

Sunday mornings for pay-what-you-wish entry. Go on a Sunday 11am-1pm for 'pay what you wish' entry. We paid $2 for two tickets with no guilt or pressure for more. This is a wonderful house with a great collection of art, mostly 17th and 18th century European paintings, and we went deliberately to see a Vermeer painting. Go early enough and get to the head of the queue at 10.30am and it isn't too crowded once you get in; wait a little longer and you might find your experience impaired a bit, since it is a house (admittedly a large one) and not a gallery or museum. It can all be seen in 45-60 minutes, so plenty of time to beat the crowds and head off to lunch or Central Park.

great place. awesome museum..its amazing to walk this halls and realized the wealth of people in this country ..to live amount beautiful pieces of art ..this used to be Frits house..love the "ladies" room apparently the room that the wife was allow to decorate..

Wonderful art collection. We thoroughly enjoyed the Frick Collection. Amazing to think this was the passion of one man. Being a smaller collection it was far less daunting than some of the big museums - and no queues.
Wonderful art pieces, not to be missed!. There are masterpieces in a beautiful ancient house, a real treasure that has to be respected and seen... But no photo admitted there !

Amazing Art, Amazing Mansion, Amazing man!. The extensive collection is around every nook and cranny. It is truly amazing how one person had such a diverse and huge selection of paintings. There is not an empty spot in the mansion unadorned. Please skip the free Sunday mornings, the huge crowds will ruin your experience.

Interesting history and collection. The Frick collection combines a great personal history with an exceptional art collection. It is not as busy as the major museums of NY so navigating the collection is a little easier. The mansion was a private home that was purpose built to be an eventual museum so the layout is thoughtful and well planned. There are some amazing pieces including Turners that we could have spent hours looking at. The short film that plays is one of the rooms is also worth watching. A great visit.
Deigo Velazquez!. I went here because of their selection of Diego Velazquez paintings and was not dissappointed.This is one of the most underrated medium sized museums in the city.

A n Unusual Museum - Understated Grandness with a Lovely Collection. This lovely building on the upper east side houses the collection of Mr Frick in his former home. It is low key, elegant and always a pleasure to visit.
Great collection. Fantastic museum in very beautiful building. Worth a visit if passing by NYC. If possible try and book entry beforehand
An absolute Treat. Loved this place, not far from the Met, we spent 2.5 enjoying his collection and the beautiful house. Well worth a visit.

wish they opened the bowling ally in the basement!. love the courtyard, lots of old famous paintings. its small enough for an afternoon. i like the paintings of old money aristocrats. glad that the girl with the pearl earing is gone and its a little mellower.
NY highlight. No trip to the city would be complete without a visit to the Frick. A gem of a collection in a fascinating setting. We revisited this July and it never fails to delight.

A fabulous collection of art in a unique setting.. Some truly fabulous paintings and other forms of decorative arts. I particularly loved the Rembrandt's Turner's and Vermeer's. The Leighton painting "Flaming June" is stunning to see in real life.We visited on a Sunday and it was very busy. I will return but ideally at a quieter time of day so I can spend more time looking.

See art in a different way. A house with a special collection of painters and decoration. Displayed in a relaxed ambiance, that gives visitors the possibility to experience art in there own way and style, with a special story and inspiration on top of it. Just gorgeous!
Frick. If you can squeeze in the time, The Frick is a great house and collection to visit. It right up there by several museums. I loved the collection.

Wonderful collection of art. The Frick is a most interesting museum. It is a small museum filled with pieces of work from some of the worlds most famous artists. My husband, who is from NY, thought I would like this museum and he was right. I found it fascinating--loved it!!

Hope you like Old Master portraits.... I think you'll either love or hate this place, depending on how you like your art. It's a small museum, so easy to cover in 90 minutes or so, and there are a few wonderful pieces, but for the most part we're talking a ton of portraiture that all began to blend together. I like it when art provokes, and the work here just felt one dimensional.

Great for art lovers.. This is a very unique place. If you appreciate old, classic art, this is the place for you. Easy to go through in under an hour or two. No photography allowed except for in the room with the fountains. Was really cool to see Rembrandt's paintings.
A must for the traveller who appreciates Art.. Excellent collection. An opportunity to have a glance of old fashioned philanthropy with a fantastic taste in the Fine Arts. Highly recommended.

An Amazing Collection. This was my second time to the Frick Collection and it still amazed me. The mansion is gorgeous! It's a great place to see beautiful art work in an intimate setting.An audio device is included with your admission ticket. The device is easy to use and very clear to listen to. Be sure to stop in for the movie to learn about the history of the actual building. Very interesting.

Excellent experience on a free Friday morning. Perfect place for a short magnificent Art experience: the mansion is amazing and you can enjoy several Turners, a Rembradt, a Renoir (my best choice), among others! different impressionists and 19th 20th century masterpieces. Go for the short videothey show in the small auditorium as you will understand much more. Also free audio guide!

Wonderful collection of art. The mistake we made was to turn up at 11.00 on a Sunday just as it was opening, which meant we queued for about 10 minutes. When we left just after midday there was no queue at all. I would recommend people take the time to watch the short film about Henry Clay Frick, his beginnings, how he obtained his wealth and what he chose to do with it, namely put together a fabulous collection of old and new masters. It's not a huge museum of art if you compare it to the Metropolitan opposite, but in some ways that makes it more enjoyable. It is one man's obsession and each of the rooms that you walk through reveal how good an eye he had.
Perfect afternoon. Beautiful art in a gorgeous landmark. Viewable in under an hour. Not too large to be intimidating and perfect for a relaxing afternoon.

One of the Great Small Museums of the World. Mr. Frick and his advisors knew what they were doing. This is a small museum but every painting is a masterpiece. There is a Titian, a couple of Rembrandts, a couple of precious Vermeers, a Velazquez, a couple of Turners, and so forth. A two-hour visit here suffices to see the creme de la creme of Western art. This is a very good place to take a young person just learning about painting for whom the big museums would be overwhelming. Or for the person without much time or energy who wants to see magnificent masterpieces in a civilized setting.

fantastic art collection in a genuine late 19th century-early 20th century Fifth Avenue mansion.. This is for art buffs; avoid the crowds and enjoy a quite couple of hours just soaking in the ambience and beauty of the collection; the mansion is amazing; this was one of the highlights of our New York City trip
