Beautiful palatial house and lovely paintings. It takes not more than2 hours to see the various paintings Mr. Frick collected in his lifetime.
They are different and he has an artistic view about it. The house in itself is vv beautiful.
Do take the audio tour.
If you love art, then definitely visit it

Breathtaking . The Frick Collection has an amazing collection. Not just the paintings on the wall but the entire building, the furniture, the rooms, the sculptures, and the porcelains are all so carefully selected to inspire. This is a must for any art lovers visiting New York. It is a place to return to every year just to sit and admire the collection.

Good but not Great. I think I must have had this built up in my mind; although I enjoyed the artwork and the home, it's not at the top of my list as far as collections. I wish I had gone back to the Metropolitan Museum of Art instead.I want to be fair about this, since I try to be positive in my reviews, but I've been to all the major museums in DC, Philadelphia, & San Francisco, as well as a few in San Diego, Los Angeles, and other cities, so I do have a basis for comparison. This one felt like a letdown.

Fabulous works of art!. Came here to see the Turner masterpieces and othe signature works. Got to see some visiting huge French tapestries in the special exhibition. I skipped the tour as it went slow.

Marvelous collection of paintings including some marvelous Vermeers and more. Although it cannot compete with the Metropolitan Museum of Art or the Washington National Gallery of art, the collection is fantastic , not in the last place because of the Vermeers and the other Dutch paintings in the Frick Collection. Furthermore Mr. Frick added some wonderful French and British paintings to his collection including even some impressionist. The museum location itself is already a sight. If you like beautiful paintings in a classic setting the Frick collection is a must see when in New York, even if it's less know then it's much more known colleague the Metropolitan. You won't be sorry you spent your time here.
Great collection. Intimate. Loved!. Great collection in a private home. Akin to the Philips in Washington DC but not as fabulous. Still a great museum!

Amazing collection in an amazing setting. Special and unique. The collection is amazing (many works by old masters) and is shown in a beautiful and unique setting. The location would be worth a tour even if there was little art to see.

A quiet relaxing visit.. The Frick Collection is actually the mansion and art collection of Henry Clay Frick. The building itself is worth the visit. When you step into the building you can feel the peace and quiet after being in the bustling streets of Manhattan. The art spans from the 4th century to about the middle of the 20th century. The main huge gallery was planned by Mr. Frick and I believe the paintings hung there were hung according to his plan.Compared to MOMA or The Metropolitan Mus. this is a small place but the artwork is superb, the surroundings are gorgeous. It makes for a lovely 1 or 2 hour visit.

Lovely place for an afternoon date. Go in early e ending to enjoy the golden light in the main rooms which face fifth avenue. Do use the easy headsets to fully appreciate the collection. The building is a lovely mansion with a central water garden

A Quiet Break From the City. One of my favorite museums because it's so quiet. Being in the mansion makes you feel like you're in another time. Then there's the art--not all great, but some of my favorite pieces. A late Rembrandt self-portrait that I have to visit at least once a year. Portraits of Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell on either side of a fireplace. A few Turners. To step into the Frick for just an hour is to take a break from the busy-ness of the city and get nourishment from another time.

The Frick, superb !!!. Small and exceptional. Make sure to visit. Make sure to spend time relaxing in the courtyard. There are incredible paintings but always stop and admire the furniture and decorative arts. This museum is my favorite and a real, real gem.

Great little museum!. Beautiful house with great paintings and furniture. The size is great for a short morning or afternoon visit if you do not have a lot of time. The 10 minute free talks are a great introduction. Wish the garden was open!
Worth it!. An excellent museum, worth the steep entry charge. Lovely and peaceful inside with good labelling and wonderful art and objects. Do go and visit, its worth it.
Great for a quick visit.. This is a great collection in a historic building. It doesn't take a long time to view, so it's a great choice if you're pressed for time.

Gem of a small museum. Not to be missed collection which was put together before there was a Federal Income Tax so many old masters (Rembrandt, El Greco, etc.) are found here. If possible, try to go to one of the concerts on Sunday afternoons. Check the Museum Website for information and instruction.
A must see in NYC!. This is such a wonderful art collection and gem of a museum! It is such a wonderful spot to spend a afternoon, very peaceful and relaxing!

A gem of a collection. This remarkable collection of paintings and sculpture is housed in the former principal home of its collector. Every time I visit the museum I am deeply moved by the consciousness behind the personal selection. The mansion itself is also beautiful. The Frick Collection is an absolute must for any art lover in New York City.

So many treasures!. Yes, so many treasures in a private collection, created with the aim of leaving it to future visitors.
Thanks to the money of Henry Clay Frick and thanks to his heirs.

A great secret, almost. Amazing. Came in from a brisc March morning, and was met by a surprisingly nice staff. I mention it in parti ular since several others have mentioned bad temper and lack of manners.The house itself was a great surprise. None of our friends had mentioned it, but we wanted to see the portraits of Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell (yes, have read the books by Mantell). Beautiful rooms, a good choice of paintings, so peaceful compared to Moma and the Met Museum. We were also told not to photograph, but in a polite manner, just matter of fact. Would probably go there again, in spite of it being small. Such a gem. Probably shouldn't write about it. The fewer who knows, the better :-)

One of my favorite small museums in NYC. One of my favorite places to go in NYC. Located in the old Frick mansion you truly feel as if you are transported to another time as you wander through enjoying the wonderful collection. Be sure to see the Reuben on display.

Best Kept Museum in NYC. Small gem of a museum that is a best kept secret in NYC, close to Central Park, in on 5th Ave. There are some major pieces of work and sculptures in here. What is most amazing is that this little oasis was all owned by the Frick Family and the collection is in their previous mansion that was converted to this museum.

If you do one thing in New York....... The Frick collection is the best $20 in New York. Beautifully presented in a turn of the century house this art collection is simply stunning and yet not so overwhelming to be off putting. The Holbein painting of Sir Thomas More is the highlight for me but every famous artist is represented, I approached one painting I thought was a Monet, silly me it was a Dagas, the Monet was opposite. If you have interest in Old Masters you must visit, if you think you ought to have an interest this is the best introduction possible. Simply world class.

Nice Collection of Art in Beautiful Building. Visited the Frick Collection during a recent trip to New York. Whilst it doesn't contain as much art as the Metropolitan or MoMa, it does house a very nice collection indeed, and I very much enjoyed the paintings by Turner, Vermeer and Whistler, as well as the current showpiece - Flaming June by Frederic Leighton.The building itself is a work of art and whilst the recommended admission fee of $20 is a little expensive if compared with the $25 for the larger galleries, it is pleasure to visit and enjoy.

A favourite of mine. Absolutely my favourite museum in NYC. It's close to the MET and has a most excellent collection of paintings and sculpture. There is an excellent movie explaining who Robert Frick was and why he donated his collection to the people of NYC. I love that he collected stuff that he himself loved. The portrait of Sir Thomas Moore is gorgeous. You are not allowed to take photographs unfortunately. The mansion is stunning and visitors get a real feel for how the rich lived back in the days of the Robber Barons. Do not miss this museum!!!

The Frick - a must-see for museum lovers!. Be sure to put The Frick on your must-see museum list. Housed in a beautifully restored building, the Frick collection is extensive and well laid out. My two favorites are the portraits of Thomas Cromwell and Thomas Moore flanking the sides of a massive stone fireplace in one of the charming rooms.

If you haven,t time to visit the Met, Don,t miss this.. Fabulous art work in a beautiful setting. Paintings by Vermeer, Turner, Ingres, andFlaming June by Leighton as well as others.Believe we saw 5 Vermeer,s. If only have 2 hours to spare this is the place to go.
The intro video give a very good background before strolling through the house.. This is a must museum visit. One and one half hours will be sufficient and will prevent "culture shock "

Lovely intimate collection. Really fantastic collection of Old Master paintings. I am not really into art but I throughly enjoyed this. It was easy for a non expert like me to connect to it, really loved the Turner paintings.

Frick is magical!. Combine an outstanding building with wonderful art and you will want to go back again and again! Leave lots of time to see this collection as you will want to soak in the atmosphere.

An Oasis in the City. Perhaps my Favorite Museum in NYC! The quality of the collection is incomparable! Such treasures, and so beautifully presented in the original home. The building is as much a part of the art as the work itself. It does not take long to view the collection. It provides a perfect stop, mid day, to refresh yourself, physically and mentally! Please note that I would NOT recommend this attraction for children.

Go on cheap day, ironically. The Frick Collection is a strange collection of what one might do if they had a lot of money. There is a lot of art including sculptures, however, I wasn't particularly impressed with any item in particular that was stunning or immaculate.
Beautiful collection. Size and scope give you the opportunity to feel at home with the artwork in this elegant museum. Don't miss the audio tour.

Exquisite art at a jewel in New York. The Frick Collection (not "museum") has some of the finest examples of western art available, but in a small, intimate, personal setting.The personal collection of Henry Frick, the "robber baron" is perfect for introducing someone to excellent art without having to traipse all over a large museum to find the pieces.I brought a group of high school students, and the docents were charming, lovely, and affirming.The art was fabulous! The court paintings of Holbein, the Impressionists, the Dutch Masters and many more types of art are displayed here. You think you're in someone's living room--which it was.Perfect views of Central Park enhance the setting.It is difficult to believe that one man owned this home and the art in it.Superb!
Excellent and quiet. Lovely relatively quiet house/museum. Interesting house and collection. Well worth a visit with lots of varied pieces.

Definitely worth a visit. This was our fourth visit to New York and previously we have not visited the Frick because there always seemed to be bigger places to go. A fascinating collection placed in the house where its owner intended it to be seen. Reveals a lot about this particular US robber baron and the treasures he acquired from Europe but im glad that its now available for the public to access (for a price). Dont miss the video background, it shows how much the staff at the Frick love and care for the collection. I especially looved the ceramics ans porcelain. Allow at least an hour.

what a jewel!. no photography in this amazing place which meant that tourists without a clue were not propping themselves against masterpieces and having ridiculous photographs. What a beautiful, peaceful place filled to the brim with amazing works of art, furniture and sculptures. A must visit.
Great place. The Frick Collection is housed in a wonderful house with amazing art. Take the time to watch a short video which gives a history about both the art and house very interesting.

My favorite part was the house. The Frick Collection is housed in the former mansion of Henry Clay Frick, which is a fascinating piece of architecture. The house is virtually unchanged since Frick lived in it, although some furnishings have been removed. What's also amazing about the home is it's location. Strange to see a house of this size on a piece of land this size in Manhattan, or anywhere in NYC, for that matter. When you enter the museum they hand you a headset to wear, but no one tells you how to use it or suggests a route to go. There are a lot of people working there, but no one was particularly friendly or helpful. After not being able to get my headset to work, I gave it back, and was not offered a new one, or offered any help when explaining mine didn't work. We didn't have a lot of time, though, anyway, and I feel the headset would've slowed me down, because it goes over almost every piece in this enormous collection. I spent my time studying the velvet line walls and architectural details. I did look at most of the paintings, and the collection is impressive, for sure. There is no access to the upstairs. I asked one of the guards about it, and she explained it has never been open the public. I asked if Frick's family ever stayed there, and she said no, although they have been known to drop in from time to time. She said that when Frick died, the home was turned into a museum, as were his wishes. Definitely stop by here if you have a morning or afternoon to spare. It's kind of a hidden gem in the city.
The very best small museum. Of all museums, does the Frick have the highest percentage of really fabulous pictures on permanent display? Yes, it does.

Frick Collection NYC. A very beautiful setting,. The artwork was extensive and the gallery was efficiently and effectively administered . The staff were friendly and very helpful and the audio provided was comprehensive and educative. Although the was a queue when I arrived it never felt crowded in the gallery, nor did we have to wait a long time to gain access. Well worh a visit.

Beautiful Museum. This was our first visit to The Frick and it won't be our last. Absolutely beautiful former private mansion. The free audio tour was so incredibly informative and interesting. The paintings, furnishings and architecture are just beautiful. $20 adult fee. I think there is a deal on Sunday's. We will be back to visit again.

Frick Collection. Very interesting art collection. I also loved the building itself. It's in a great location and very close the the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Guggenheim Museum, and the Neue Galerie.
Fantastic. Everything, especially the magnificent Turner's. Also Velasquez and Gainsborough - amazing, just like a private house with no crowds.

An Absolute Gem - a must visit. What a great attraction - its like visiting the home of a wildly wealthy relative - none of the sterile environment you can get at the normal gallery - tag it on to a visit to Museum Mile (Met, Guggenheim).

highly recommended to us. We were going to spend a half day at the Met and were advised by locals to visit the Frick. This museum had 3 original Rembrandts, an original Monet and was not crowded. This is a must see!

Intimate Art Experience . Flick is a wonderful intimate art experience. Good private collection displayed in beautiful mansion and gardens. Up close and personal with the art and without the crowds. Highly recommend

Visit it for the house. There are some interesting paintings in the collection, but what really impressed me is the whole experience. You'll get to see paintings that were actually owned by one single rich family, mostly in the setting they would have been back then. I think it gives you the feel of the opulence some families lived in at the time.

Fantastic ! Not to miss in NYC. I am not a very sophisticated art person but I do like art museums.
This place is amazing.
Must see for people who likes European 18-19 century art.
Hard for me to explain what's so unique about this place , maybe being a private art collection in private beautiful house...

World Class Private Art Collection... Henry Clay Frick was a multi millionaire who collected fine old master paintings and furniture among other extraordinary works of art. When he built his giant mansion on Fifth Avenue he intended that his 'home' would eventually become a museum. Victoria and I spent three solid hours with Mr. Frick's collection. Frans Hals (many) to one of Gilbert Stuart's wonderful portrayals of 'George Washington'. There were quite a few Gainsborough's and beautiful Whistler's too. Rembrandt, Renoir, Van Dyck and Van Eyck were all on display along with many other 'masters'. The house along with this stunning art is simply enchanting. Strongly recommend this museum only after first visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It's worth every moment of your time in the big apple.

Museum With A Spiritual Feel. I know nothing about art. However, each time I visit the Frick, I see something else I hadn't noticed on prior visits. There is no place in New York City that feeds my soul more. Many times, I've perched on a bench and just soaked up the surroundings. It's one of the best places in the world to sit, pray and see priceless works of art in a space that is architecturally unique and magnificent.

Wonderful art. An excellent museum with an extraordinary colection of European art. Just big enough without overwhelming, like the Metropolitan. Plan on at least a couple of hours to stroll and look. Just a gem of a collection, even if it was collected by a individual who had little social conscience.
Fantastic Collection. Wonderful art collection and display at this beautiful museum. Would highly recommend to art lovers who appreciate Turner, Kandinsky and Monet.

Privates collections are my favourite . I discovered the place 5 years ago. There is something moving about a private collection. It goes with the moment in life it has been collected and selected. Eclectic, moving... Me Frick also knew, when he build his house, that it would be turned into a museum after he died. From the Fragonard room, to books, clocks, furnitures, portraits, landscapes, drawings in the basement, patio with the fountain inside .... Forbidden to child under 10!!!! Make the visit even more enjoyable. Can t wait to take my 7 years old son there.

An antidote to crazy downtown Manhattan. Feeling a little jetlagged after a long flight, I couldn't face downtown Manhattan so decided to spend a hot afternoon at the Frick. It was the perfect antidote. I took a docent introductory talk, and then wandered through this beautiful mansion that was built to house the most amazing works of art - Vermeers, Bellini, Holbeins, and a special summer showing of Flaming June by Frederick Leighton, on loan (from of all places) the Puerto Rican National Museum. A gorgeous alive work. The central indoor conservatory garden is a peaceful haven, and perfect for regrouping with a little powernap on the benches listening to the fountain tinkling away. Portraits and landscapes were Fricks favourite works and there are many to feast your eyes on. No cafe but a lovely shop. You can spend hours in this beautiful place. One of NYs treasure houses.

Breathtaking. After hitting Times Square on a hot, humid, wet day this was a breath of fresh air. We have visited New York once before and done most of the architecture so decided to make this a more 'museum' experience. As we walked into the building the beautiful courtyard garden was our first stop and a breath of fresh air! The rest of the collection was breathtaking and the handheld information easy to use with just enough background on most pieces of art.
Small gallery but an excellent collection.. This is a small museum compared to others in NYC. Be sure to get the headphones to use while here. The added narrative was very informative.

Absolutely Worth a Visit. I lived in New York, have been here many times and had never made my way to the Frick. I am glad I did -- if you want to get a sampling of art from various periods of history, paintings and porcelain mostly, and you do not want to bump into 500 Chinese tourists taking pictures or children screaming, as you will at the Met and MOMA, this is a good place to be. There were a couple of early Turners (my favorite artist, very good movie), a couple not so late; lots of portraiture, Goya to Gainsborough et al; and the building itself is quite stunning, a muted testament to the wealth of the man and the lifestyle of the rich during the Gilded Age. I sense there are free tours, I was invited by the young guide if I wanted to join, I had already strolled the place but had an I engaged in a very interesting conversation for ten minutes, he knew his stuff and I assumed gave an excellent tour. One downside is there is no coffee shop, a helpful docent recommended Via Quadronno on 73rd off of Madison and it was - shock of shocks - reasonably priced (for that neighborhood in New York) and had excellent service and food. Bottom line -- the Frick is well worth the $20.

Don't miss the Frick. In you are travelling to New York and love Art and History do not miss this museum. Trip Advisor rates the Frick #9 of 1663 things to do in NYC. Can't argue being in the top 10, but truly one of my favorite places on the planet let a lone a museum. The Museum itself was the former residence of Henry Clay Frick. Like many of his rich contemporaries he built a mansion here in Manhattan. His home (the Museum) is exquisite. His private collection is unparalleled. Perhaps the greatest private collection in the world. I'm sure it is. Very interesting man indeed. He was not a nice person. He was basically a thug or "Capo" for Dale Carnegie (Carnegie Steel Company) and yet here we see a side of him very few people probably knew. I know he lost a daughter and perhaps it touched him and reflected in the Art he purchased. Not one Masterpiece in this collection depicts war. In this relatively small museum we find Vermeer, Rembrandt, Titian, de Goya, Bellini, El Greco, Velasquez, and the list goes ON. it's simply mind boggling, the Frogonard room is Spectacular. His 2 Holbein's facing each other is insane. The stairway, gardens and above all the intimacy of this very personal museum makes it my Favorite. Hope you stop at The Frick Collection. It's a must see for all. 2 things I would recommend. 1: purchase the head phones or download the ap! and 2: As a Dad, think twice before bringing your child, you'll understand when you go.
A respite full of beauty.... Vermeers, Turners, Rembrandts - all in an actual home (well, mansion) - a peaceful venue to see great art. We come here every NY visit - it calms me.
NYC art. stunning collection set in an amazing home, with very helpful custom audio guides available at no extra charge
A Special Small Museum. It's the Frick Collection and the pieces are very special. It's a lovely museum to stroll through and then have a walk in Central Park.

Not a must see, but a good see. Finally went to see the Frick. Small, but worth the visit. Interesting historically because Frick's collection is housed in his mansion, which was lived in until the 1930's. You are walking through his living room etc...Definitely grab the free audio guide upon entry as it describes the rooms you are standing in, the furniture, evolution of the house as well as the individual works of art.
Worth repeat visits. The Frick is a gem with a wonderful, varied collection in beautiful surroundings. Just strolling the galleries is a pleasure.

A Special Experience!. I have visited The Frick several times for special exhibits. It is one of the most beautiful museums I ever visited; one literally walks into a private home. You can walk around freely to view the amazing art displayed in this home setting. The paintings are stunning!On Sundays free admission from 11:00 am to 1:00 pm. A donation would be appreciated.

Favourite museum in town. Can you imagine that all this used to belong to one single man? When you are entering in this monumental house, you re not simply entering into a museum but into a private and incredible private art collection. Sometimes they have beautiful temporary exhibitions, I went to see the one about Vacheron Constantin and their watches, it was absolutely amazing in a perfect decorum.

Time well spent. Brilliantly collected masterpieces displayed in a beautiful mansion, and easily viewed in less than 2 hours with the aid of succinct audio guides, the Frick was a hit with not only the adults, but also the children in our party. However, it must be noted that children under 10 are not admitted. A very enjoyable contrast to the massive collection at the Met.

Leighton's "Flaming June" at the Frick on view only until September 6. British artist Frederic Leighton's now-iconic image "Flaming June" of a sleeping woman in a vivid orange gown is on loan to the Frick from the Museo de Arte de Ponce in Puerto Rico until September 6. This nineteenth-century masterpiece embodies the modern philosophy of “art for art’s sake,” the belief that the value of art lies in its aesthetic qualities rather than in its subject matter. The sensuously draped figure — freed from any narrative context — is integrated into a harmonious ensemble of rhythmic lines and radiant color.

A nice way to view art. Like the Villa Borghese in Italy, the Frick Family established a gallery in their mansion that makes for a pleasant alternative to cavernous, more theme park-like museums. I imagine this sort of collection viewed in this way was how it was done in fin de siecle Paris. A throwback, if you will.
A Jewel Box of a Museum. Beautiful old home and an amazing collection of european masters. Definitely worth a stop to come see how luxurious Gilded Aged 5th avenue was.

Unique display setting for art and furniture. This is such a unique experience. It is a family home that was designed and preserved as a museum. It's a lovely way to view the artwork as it is not sectioned off according to time period. Instead, you are walking through the rooms of a home with artwork assembled for tone or color or other reasons that they compliment each other. I went on a discounted Sunday morning. I highly recommend it!

Research library is separate. Never saw the collection, as the library enrtance is on the otrher side of the block and our request was lost. Waiting for ti we lost the afternoon when we wanted to see the collection.

Beautiful Home and Art. It was raining so we caught a cab and went to visit the Henry Clay Frick Collection museum. The mansion, built in 1913-14, which was their home for awhile, has become a splendid place to look and enjoy their art collection. He collected many of the old masters, eighteenth-century French furniture, porcelains, Limoges enamels, oriental rugs, sculptures, and some artists from NYC. It was also kind of neat to see two pieces of art that were done by of my wife's relative - George Romney. So this made it kind of special to visit.

Beautiful small museum. I can't believe I waited so long to visit the Frick. It has an amazing art collection and it was thoroughly worth the visit. So much of this city can be so crowded, but this museum was a lovely setting and not crowded at all!

A must do in New York. This incredible mansion houses a truly magnificent collection of art, furniture and other treasures collected by a man with a great passion for art. A must see in New York. This was my second visit in seven years, and I was still highly impressed.

Worth a trip. What an amazing place, and to think this was a family home and this was all of his personal art. Definitely worth a visit; much less crowded than some of the other art museums in the city and with amazing art to boot.
New Yorkers favourite Museum. An incredible serene museum housed in a beautiful mansion in the Upper East, close to the Guggenheim and MoMa so fit it in to your schedule

Very pleasant and easy to see all the paintings. Two things stuck out in my mind as I visited the Frick last week.First is you get an audio handset that you can use to listen to descriptions of the paintings. Most paintings have a three digit number on them, and you type that three digit number into your handset to listen to a 45 second description of the painting. This really made this visit great fo rme as I could find paintings I liked, and then listen to the description of it and find out details about the painting that were not readily apparent.The second thing I liked was the small size of the Frick. The small size was great since it was very manageable to see the entire collection in about two hours. You do not get the overwhelmed feeling like you do in large art galleries.The quality of the artists was great and included Vermeer, Manet, and Monet. It also had Gilbert Stuart's George Washington painting.The Frick is located just off the east side of Central Park on about 70th street. It was a great and peaceful visit in such a hectic city.If you are a member of your local art gallery, check to see if the Frick offers reciprocity. I am a member of the Cummer Art Galley in Jacksonville, FL so I got free admission to the Frick which was great.
Definitely worth a visit!. Loved this house, garden and art collection! So precious. Make sure to catch the film about Frick; the history of the house, his life and the collection.
Fabulous collection. Some of the best old master paintings anywhere. Worth the price of admission just to see Rembrandt's self-portrait.

Sunday sketch is Sunday best. On my must visit list for years, I finally ventured over on my recent return visit to NYC. I visited Sunday so was therefore able to pay as I wished. The collection of art, furniture and architecture was wonderful, considering this was a family's home. Sunday sketch inspired me to create my own vision, an opportunity to dabble like a true "artiste". A well spent couple of hours topped off by a modest purchase at the gift shop. Top notch museum in all accounts.

Best intimate yet world-class museum in NYC. And even more of a must now that the Whitney has left the neighborhood
For some relief after the MET, head south a few blocks to this little corner of paradise
Little Gem of a Musuem. One of my favorites in NYC. Very manageable and the architecture alone is stunning. No children allowed so be aware.
One of NY's little secrets. Great art in a serene setting. It has been one of my favorite places in NY since I first went in the mid-1980's. To think Ford Frick lived here!

Perfection in a museum. Just a wonderful place, with an amazing collection. You can really appreciate the work, as there are no large groups taking selfies, no giant text panels to obscure the walls, but instead just amazing art works, displayed in keeping with the rooms.

spectacular new setting!. If you liked the original Frick, you'll love this one. The collections seemed even better displayed than in the old building. This should be the one boutique museum stop you don't want to miss

Amazing. A walk through this home is worth the entrance fee alone. It is a maxing to think of the decadence that frock lived in. The rooms are huge and lush. The conservatory is bigger than our house. Then there is the art and furniture collection is wonderful.

Great mini-museum. This is a home that was built and furnished with the idea that it would one day be a museum. It was perfect for my mother, who recently had knee replacement surgery; she got to see a nice variety of art and objects without walking too much or dealing with the stairs at the Met.My only complaint is that the tour guide booklet isn't up to date; things get moved to other locations, so the room-by-room descriptions aren't always accurate. It got confusing. In all fairness, I didn't do the free audio tour, which might have cleared some of that up.Very friendly, helpful personnel. Nice little gift shop. Great stop near Central Park for people who are overwhelmed by the Metropolitan or short on time.

Not To Be Missed!!. The Frick is my absolute favorite art gallery in New York. It is not as big as the MET or the MOMA, but it's manageable size is part of its appeal. In particular, you can see the whole gallery in a few hours, and feel as you received the full experience. You don't walk away thinking you missed viewing half the art work. Also, the portraits are excellent and charming. Overall, The Frick has a homey, yet classy and cultured vibe to it. I definitely recommend.

Stunning Frick collection in wonderful setting.. My favorite museum in NYC, this little gem is worth visiting anytime. If you can only see one art museum in NYC, the formal Frick collection is the place to go with absolutely every painting being of the highest artistic quality including an absolutely top notch Ingres and three luminous paintings by Vermeer. As a cherry on top, a little exhibit of Sir Frederic Leighton's beautiful painting, "Flaming June" was on display flanked by two lovely portraits of young ladies by Whistler, a treat indeed! I would advise seeing the introductory film on the collection that was much enjoyed by my son as it explained the background of the mansion and collection and then also described the works of art and layout. It is short and concise but most helpful to the first time visitor. Enjoy the amazing works of art, decorative arts, the poetic atmosphere of the mansion and glimpses of the gardens and the central court. No photos are allowed except in the central court yard which seems appropriate for this quiet and art infused venue.

boutique quality collection,like French chateau. no photography allowed, unlike similar venues in France wonderful spread of paintings, sculptures, furnishings and porcelain and enamelled piecesbeautiful interiorsnear to Central park for picnic lunch afterwards

Small exhibition with great works. I assume this is one of New York's lesser-known museums, but it is absolutely worth a visit. The beautiful old mansion is a dignified setting for some wonderful pieces of art. Turner, Bruegel, Frans Hals, Rembrandt to name just a few. They are well presented in the stately rooms and the audio guide gives extensive yet never boring information about each room and the pieces of art displayed therein. We enjoyed our visit and highly recommend this hidden gem.

Awesome. Calm and worth fee - the paintings are beautiful but the house itself with the furniture and architecture is stunning - lovely walk up from mid town opposite Central Park and a do able museum for a couple of hours.

Walking Through Someone's Private Collection. This is hands down one of my top five museums to visit in NYC. The beautiful collection is housed in a gorgeous house on the Upper Eastside. If you've ever seen a period piece where they have scenes of people exploring some duke's private art collection — that's exactly what you will feel when exploring the rooms. The artwork is strategically placed all around the house and the whole experience is very intimate.I suggest going right when the museum opens and if possible on a weekday so that you almost have the whole place to yourself. It heightens the sense of seeing someone's private art collection that much more.

Don't miss this museum. In a city full of museums this is one that should not be missed. Located in the Frick mansion, the house itself is worth seeing. Most of the selections were made by Mr. Frick himself and that in itself is interesting. The home was created to showcase his possessions. Not just paintings but furniture and other decorative items. The size of this museum makes a visit managable. It is not overwhelming like going to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The auto tour is worth listening to.

Lovely collection. The Frick is a lovely art collection and worth seeing - if art is your thing.My honest opinion is that there are so many amazing things to see and do in NYC that this wouldn't have been high on my list if a friend hadn't offered me tickets. It's a lovely art collection, but... that's it.
Loved it. Currently showing Leighton's FLAMING JUNE. truly beautiful.The Frick home is magnificent and I highly recommend visiting the collect of art/furniture in a home setting.

Small and beauty. Compared to all the great museums in NYC, the Frick Collection is small, but it's very beautiful!!! You can visit the whole museum in a couple of hours, and I strongly recommend the audio guide, since the building itself is part of the experience, and the guide will explain it in detail.

A little piece of heaven.. One of the most enjoyable afternoons I have ever spent on this Earth was strolling through the Frick Collection. An oasis in the midst of mayhem, this is New York's must see. You senses will be caressed by the beauty of the art on display with every painting a beauty for the eye to behold and set your heart ready to burst. Don't leave NY without stopping here.
One of the best ever. Excellent collection, beautiful mansion , pictures as a part of interior make the visit absolutely stunning

An indispensable part of a New York visit.. The Frick is my favourite museum in the world, in part because it has a very high level of average quality. While the Met, great as it is, occasionally has stretches where nothing is terrific, that's not the case here. The Vermeers! Goya's The Forge! Rembrandts, especially the self-portrait! El Greco! Bellini!It's a special treat that the museum is on a domestic scale and feels like the intimate home it was to Mr. Frick. You are never rushed to finish nor overwhelmed.I've been there when there were orchids in the rooms, with their pedigree typed beside them.The atrium with its pool is such a relaxing setting.Don't miss Renoir's La Promenade, in the stairwell.The Frick is often open a little later than other museums on the stretch, and that's helpful too.They don't let you sit on most of the furniture, but you can relax in the atrium or in the theatre and watch a movie about Mr. Frick.I go every time I'm in New York - four times now in the last six months. Would never ever miss it.

Worth the trip for art lovers. You probably have to be a serious museum/art fiend to fully appreciate the Frick. I hadn't gone in decades so decided to make a return trip. I liked it and enjoyed the fact that it wasn't very crowded (unlike its neighbor about 10 blocks north, i.e., the Met). It is not particularly large and so can be leisurely gone through relatively quickly and you don't need to spend many hours there unless you want to.
The Frick. Intimate and historic! Excellent collection of Holbein paintings. It is an engaging museum - not overwhelming the way larger ones can be.

A magical house. It's almost worth the admission just to see the two Holbein portraits and the room that contains them. The whole house is filled with wonderful art and the fact that this was the collection of one self-made man makes it even more fascinating. The video about Frick is well worth watching. Currently (July '15), there is the added attraction of Leighton's "Flaming June", which is breathtaking. More intimate than the nearby "big name" galleries, this is a must-see for any art lover.

Good Art, GREAT Venue. Nice collection of work assembled in a beautiful setting. The garden room is not to be missed. Be warned, because of the large collection of antiquity, children 10 and under are not admitted.
What a house!. Impossible to believe that this was a private home/art collection! An often overlooked gem in a city of museums, the Frick is not to be missed!
Best small museum in NYC. The Frick is an intimate museum with a wonderful collection and a great space. Do plan to give yourself time and don't hurry while you walk through this collection.

Loved Every Bit of It.. My daughter is a designer and she has always commented that she wanted to see the Frick Collection when we visited NY city, so it was one of the first things on our list. I/we loved our time there and are so glad we visited. I have never been to a museum like this before now. It was smaller, intimate, and you could see his lovely collection of masterpieces up close. Make sure you pick up the free head set before you enter which is a real plus. There just happened to be a tour starting when we arrived so we gladly went along and the guide was very knowledgeable and pleasant to listen to, enjoyed it very much. Mr. Frick's collection is spectacular, a must see!

Great setting, Beautiful Gallery, Stunning Artwork. Larger galleries hold more art and artifacts, but the setting, the rooms, the furnishing, the magnificent artworks and the spaciousness and quiet graciousness of this art museum are tops. It is what I call "bite size" in that you can enjoy all it has to offer in 2-3 hours without being exhausted. Only drawback is that there is no cafeteria or restaurant in the gallery, so be sure to eat before visiting as there is not a lot available in this predominantly residential neighbourhood.

Great sketching for artists!. The Frick houses a modest but great collection of 18th and 19th century pantings along with some wonderful sculpture. But one of the best highlights of my visit was signing up for the free Wednesday night sketch groups after hours at the Frick. By signing up online ahead of time (Frick website) you have 2 hours to sketch from the works after the normal visiting hours. A folding stool, paper and pencils are provided, along with admission - all free. A great opportunity to spend some real time in front a masterpiece and learn from the masters. My hats off to the Frick fro providing that opportunity! Also, Sundays are pay as you wish and can be a great time to do some sketching though there may be quite a few visitors then.
fabulous small jewel. easy and very accessiblewonderful art and a beautiful museum that used to be the home of the Frick Family
WAS EXPECTING MORE. Was surprised to see a mix of old and new. Looks like many objects and furnishing have been removed.

Get Up Close and Personal. The Frick allows you to literally wander into rooms once occupied by the family members and gaze at an incredible collection of paintings. There are some masterpieces that must be seen up close to believe.

Calm, serene and beautiful!. Start your visit by watching the short but very well done film that gives the background information on the owner/family of the magnificent home that is now the Frick Museum. Enjoy the calm and beautiful portico and go through the various areas of the collection that only show beauty in not only paintings but sculpture as well. Really a magnificent show and Mr. Frick chose only art that is wonderful to behold, no horrific war scenes...

Art and Architecture. What a wonderful afternoon. The Frick is the perfectly sized Sunday afternoon venue. It combines fantastic architecture, furnishings, and interior design with an extraordinary collection of important and significant paintings by extraordinary and significant artists. All in a space that is easy to take in and appreciate in a day.

Incredible collection where you can get close to masterpieces. To my shame, I've walked past this beautiful old mansion on 5th Ave for years without venturing in; I knew it was a world famous collection, but always had better things to do: or so I thought - I'm kicking myself that I haven't visited more often. It wasn't until I realised it housed Holbein's portrait of St Thomas More that I visited and I'm so glad I did - and I've been back several times since. Incidentally, staring at More from the opposite side of the fireplace is Holbein's portrait of Thomas Cromwell (the man who brought More down).Most of the art is European and was collected by industrialist Henry Frick and displayed on the ground floor rooms of his NYC residence. Some of the rooms are relatively small, so it can be a little crowded - especially around some of the most famous works. Being a small museum has its advantages - it's very intimate and you can see the art at close quarters. It also has some disadvantages: there's not a huge range of visitor amenities, of course there are restrooms, a shop, and free bag and coat check. But there's nowhere for refreshments and a couple of the staff can be a little on the grumpy side. There is a free audio guide, which is well worth getting and the museum has a "pay what you want" admission policy on Sundays from 11am. If you get museum/art gallery fatigue quickly, this is a perfect place: as it's relatively small you could see the majority of the collection in under 2 hours. It's also a perfect place if you're like me (I feel that I want to see everything when I go to museums so leave places like the Met or British Museum, where it's impossible to see everything in a day, with an unresolved feeling) - you can easily see the collection in one visit, but never tire of it on subsequent trips.

One of the greatest museums in the world. My favorite museum in NYC, and one of the best in the world. A small, very carefully chosen collection (including 3 Vermmers!) is on display in the gorgeous former home of Henry Clay Frick. The buidling itself is almost as a big a star as the artworks.
fantastic museum. Great paintings, very nice atmosphere, fantastic house, quite, a different way to see art. While Metropolitan has a lot of people, here you can see art peacefully.

Great small museum. This is a good museum when you have an hour but not more. The building itself is an attraction and the historical rooms are amazing. Definitely worth a visit if you are a museum lover.

A window into how the other half lived. This was a recommendation from a friend, and one I would have skipped if I wasn't with others. I am so pleased I didn't. A lovely collection of art and sculptures, which I enjoyed, but being a more casual art observer, what really impressed me was the beautiful architecture of the old mansion, and how beautifully preserved it is. Worth a stop.
Beautiful. A historic piece of New York. The visit felt a little like a school trip but it's still worth the walk through.
My favorite museum. I never get tired of this place. The beautiful Frick mansion and its garden court are so relaxing. Some of the greatest pictures in the world are here. Well worth a visit!

Ah, the Gilded Age!. You can forgive robber barons whatever they did when you see what they built. The Frick is a splendid place to visit, whether it's for a new exhibit, or to wander around or to buy beautiful cards in the shop. Good for the soul.
A Must. This is by far the best art gallery in New York. It is a must and it puts the others to shame. We go every thine we are in the city

Simply Fab. What a great museum in an old robber baron's home. He had great taste and it shows. Leave yourself plenty of time as this place has the really famous pieces of art we are all familiar with. I recommend 3 to 4 hours.

Amazing collection and mansion. I have visited many art museums in Europe and the US and the Frick Collection is my favorite. The art is amazing and so is the furniture and interior design of every room.

Intimate, splendid art collection. Transport yourself back to the early 1900's and enjoy the splendor and glory of a bygone era. While the mansion is certainly grand, it is still a relatively intimate way to view significant works of art in this magnificent home. The depth of the Frick art collection is extraordinary when you consider it was a personal collection in the privacy of his home. Be sure to utilize the audio tour, which is very well done.

A must-see on any trip to New York. For quality of the collection I cannot recommend too highly. Think Wallace Collection in London and that's the sort of experience you can expect. Can be visited within one hour (but quite understandable if you loiter longer. Pure class!
History plus art NYC classic. This is my favorite museum in NYC, you get to see a little of Manhattan's gilded age in the House while admiring an amazing art collection. NYC MUST
Nice small museum. It was a beautiful building with classic gardens. Wish there weremore rooms open for more exhibitions. It was too fast to finish the tour,

Favorite Art Museum in New York City. Gorgeous art museum located in the beautiful Henry Clay Frick House - and the house / rooms are worth the trip alone! Sundays are "pay what you wish" days from 11:00am to 1:00pm, and I highly recommend going then (sometimes the line is a little scary, but it moved pretty fast both times I have been). I haven't been back yet to see Leighton’s "Flaming June", but I'll definitely go back before the end of the exhibit in September.
Classy museum and great building. Only a relatively short visit but really enjoyable even for someone not into the art scene. The building itself is a work of art and well worth a visit.
Frick Collection Review. The feeling is much like that of entering the home of someone who has a love of art of all kinds. The layout and presentation is art in and of itself. We love it.

Nice and worth the money. A great collection with the works of famous artitst such as Vermeer and Rembrandt. This is a quiet museum and that is a nice change compared to some other museums in the city.

Art - Up close and personal. Great small museum. Extensive collection of European art and artifacts. Wonderful portraits. Some very special Vermeers. All art is on a single floor. Good audio narration available.

A sense of elegance and legacy. The combination of the old Frick mansion and the collection (both the original plus the later acquisitions) conveys a sense of how the original collector viewed his world and the sort of legacy he sought to eatablish. A great collection of classic, Old Masters and 19th Century work is the centerpiece of the Frick and later acquisitions and exhibits maintaint that aesthetic perspective.Visitors should be aware, virtually no pieces outside of those on special exhibits or galeries have explanatory signage, depending instead on the free audio-guide available at the point of entry into the ticketed part of the museum; do remember to pick it up.

A treasure trove of Monet, Renoir, Manet and more. Beautiful museum filled with treasures....Monet, Manet, Renoir....incredible. It is also a smaller collection so you can see it all in about an hour. We also saw the Flaming June on loan through Sept 6th. Stunning.

The Frick: A Great Art Museum. The Frick is not to be missed by any art lover visiting NYC. It has a fantastic collection of painting, many of which are very well known, and an unusually pleasant atmosphere. I've visited many of the top art museums in the world, including many in France, Italy, London, Belgium, Amsterdam, Washington, Chicago, Cleveland, and New York, and have enjoyed all of them, but found the Frick to be special in regard to the fact that the whole museum is easily seen in a couple of hours or less and one leaves having a memorable experience. I spent 2 days in the Louvre and 1 1/2 days in the NY Met Museum and left feeling like I rushed in order to take in as much as possible, and felt like I needed another day or more. The Frick is a museum in which to relax and soak in the art.

Intimate collection . Private Frick collection is impressive. Beautiful structure right beside Central Park, so don't miss it if you are in that neighborhood. Be sure to get the audio guide to access information about the outstanding art work.

Excellent Experience. This is one of the best art museums I have ever visited. Primarily consisting of 18th-19th century European art, the way it is displayed forms a critical part of the experience. I enjoyed the portraits of Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell glaring at each other on either side of a fireplace, and George Romney's portrait of the Lade Hamilton was mesmerizing. Free admission for military, so make sure to ask.

A beautiful oasis. I recently reacquainted myself with this lovely museum. It's actually the home and collection of the Frick family and little has changed since they lived in it. I was fortunate to be able to see Fredrick Leighton's "Flaming June". this painting is on loan and is relentlessly sensual. It was worth going to the Frick just to see this piece.
Walking distance from Central Park.. What a wonderful, intimate museum. Please tell me it will not be ruined by the proposed addition! Arrive early or go late. Take time to sit inside. The best!

Selective Historical haven. Highly recommended, this place has it all. If you had limited time, and couldn't make it to The Met, this place should be your choice. Art pieces from all over, are wisely selected. A relaxing haven is your ice topping, as you sit and relax at the indoor garden with a view of Van Gogh masterpiece.
Easily an 8/10.

Magnificent Collection. Their collection is small but absolutely astonishing! It is a completely different experience from visiting a huge museum (like the Metropolitan or MoMA). One of the top 3 art museums in NYC for sure.

The Frick Collection surpassed my expectations. The Frick Collection is the stunning home of Henry Clay Frick the industrialist and his frankly stunning art collection. I've never seen such a cross section of old masters displayed in such a beautiful setting. Download the app for additional information on furniture, and paintings with audio that you can use for a self guided tour. A great way to spend a couple of hours in NYC!

great museum. It's in an old Fifth Ave mansion, it snowed when we were there and it was stunning to look out, While we were in NY (this was Oct. 2013...during Hurricane Sandy) they had a Van Gogh lecture that was great. Just a wonderful setting to see fine art, leisurely browse the scupture and paintings. Wonderful!

Leighton's "Flaming June" is a must see!. After several trips to NYC and many visits to the city's great museums, I finally made it to the Frick Collection. Why I waited so long, I have no idea! Stunning artwork in a classic NYC residence in a beautiful neighborhood! It's easy (too easy!) to imagine living in that elegant environment, with the art as the star attraction. The best reason to visit this summer--Leighton's gorgeous Victorian school "Flaming June," on loan from Puerto Rico until early September. I've tromped through a lot of museums in America and Europe, but have never paid much attention to Victorian art. This painting instantly became one of my favorites of any school, any period, ever. The composition is quite different, and the central color--a vibrant, breathtaking orange sorbet--makes the painting dessert for your brain! Make sure to stop in the museum's video room for a fascinating presentations on "Flaming June" and the history of the Frick house. Loved the whole experience!

Frick for Classic Art. Perfectly sized museum in stunning Gilded Age mansion. Three Vermeers! If you like Old Masters through to end if 19th C. art, this is the place. Stunning collection. The Degas ballerinas alone would be enough of a reason to visit.

Day trip to NYC. An absolutely marvelous display of priceless art work, This gem is stunning in the beauty of the Mansion with the furniture and display of treasures that are on display. The old masters are on display with Constables, Turners, Rembrandt's, Vermeer's amongst others. I would recommend a visit to this Collection to anyone who has an interest in art.

Very select. A wonderful collection of paintings, furniture, sculptures in a very grand home. The handheld audio guide was excellent. I'm surprised that the UK has any Turners, Constables, Gainboroughs left after the number we saw here. Be aware that there is a lower age limit which I feel was very appropriate as young children would hate it. Very peaceful place.
Beautiful!. This is where I saw my first "Monet" in person. It brought tears to my eyes. They have a great museum. I would have loved to be able to see the whole mansion.
beautiful. my favorite museum in NYC, not an easy choice! but I love both the collection, the manageable size and the architecture. it's just a lovely place.

A must do while in New York. Superb collection of arts from paintings to sculptures - very nice and helpful employees who seem to know about the collections quite a lot - go on Sunday morning at 1100 for nearly free entry.

What the Frick?!. The Frick is marvelous! It is not a free museum, but it is on 5th Ave. and is the only private residence that was built with the intention of becoming a museum. It is divine! I have gone twice and both times it was amazing! The Fricks were Pennsylvania Steel magnates and contemporaries of people like J.P. Morgan, Andrew Carnegie and more. The house is filled with beautiful objects and there is a great slide show on the Frick family that explains their wealth and how they collected their massive collection. It is a nice afternoon or morning as the tour which can be accompanied by a sound recording or not will not take up your whole day. There is still time for a walk up the street to another gallery or down the street to the stores of 5th Avenue!

New York art while walking. Walking in NY is always a lot of fun and when my wife suggested we stop here I was again glad I let her lead. We enjoyed all we saw and would recommend it to anyone that enjoys art and beautiful venues

Amazing collection of iconic classical art. An extensive collection which contains some iconic art, including Holbein's portrait of Thomas More, several Gainsboroughs and Turners and currently Leighton's 'Flaming June', as well as Sevres porcelain and some lovely French furniture. Entry is somewhat expensive and the security overly zealous in the rules, but a very pleasant visit nonetheless.

A Favorite. One of our all time favorite museums. The fact that is Mr. Frick's private collection displayed in his home is nothing short of fabulous. So many maters and so beautifully displayed. The building itself is gorgeous only enhances the Rt.

Amazing Art Collection in an Amazing Home!. Start with the movie giving you the history of the Collection and the former residence that houses it! There is a varied yet really lovely pieces of art to enjoy. But best of all is how the home was built specifically to house the pieces. One room renovated for the amazing Fragonard Panels. We were fortunate enough to enjoy a single painting on exhibit - Leighton's Flaming June considered the most beautiful painting in the world. Review the collection before you go, do a little homework and the collection will mean so much more! Enjoy!

Surprise Collection. This was a fascinating museum within walking distance of our hotel. The collection is almost hidden away and what a surprise it was. I only found it through Trip Advisor so Thank You.

Bring a friend who has never been… amazing. Though we are not from the City, we are members. Not because we visit often enough, perhaps, to pay for the membership. But because we want to visit every time we are in NY…. it's an amazing place that could not be replicated today. The masterworks that are in the Frick, one man's collection for a relatively brief time, are a remembrance of decades when a collector could buy Vermeers (in the plural) and Fragonards (in the plural) and Van Dyck and Bellini and Piero della Francesca and Titian and so so much more. We visit more than once a year because it is such a breathtaking place. Bring a friend!

So Much in Such a Little Space.. So, OK, here's the library. Bellini's St. Francis in on one wall, flanked by two nice Titians. Across the way, El Greco's St Jerome is above the fireplace, and Holbein's portraits of More and Cromwell face each other on the sides. Wow! Three Vermeers. A Rembrandt self-portrait next to The Polish Rider. Even the Fragonards are bearable because they have their own room, with all the accompaniments fitting in. And Lady Hamilton is hot (even if you wonder about Lord Nelson robbing the cradle). The Met could hold 30 Fricks. But then it would take a long time to see everything.

OMG. This was one man's art collection.. Building alone, complete with interior courtyard, worth a visit. The art collection is fairly eclectic, and very well displayed. I can never really get over the fact that this was someone's private collection.

A NY oasis.. Step through these doors into the beaux arts interior and you will be transported in time to a quieter time. One can almost hear the clopping of horses hooves outside. One can almost imagine these pleasant canvases were hung on the walls yesterday, fresh from the artist's studio: Klimt, Whistler, Degas, De la Tour, portraits of Cromwell and Sir Thomas More, leaning forward out of their canvases. Glass cases contain gilded and bejeweled watches. Furnishings look so comfortable one is tempted to plop down and put one's feet up on the priceless silk upholstery. The Girl with the Pearl Earring by Vermeer may no longer be hanging but her spirit lingers.

One Cannot Miss the Masterpieces in the Frick Collection. A superb collection in an exquisite environment. Many large museums can leave one exhausted, but the Frick Collection, just the right size and filled with masterpieces, leaves the visitor inspired. This is a must-do in NY, and this from a native New Yorker.

Classic collection. If you are going for a look back to 100 years ago, see the Frick Collection. Magnificent permanent collection (especially the Turners) for art historians. Exhibitions are very well presented.

Too little time..... .....to really do it justice! We went towards the end of the afternoon and simply ran out of time. We would have returned if we could because some the paintings are breathtaking and there is a great range of artists.

Definitely the jewel of Manhattan. Liked: an eclectic museum-home, not divided in schools.Disliked: nothing.It reflects the personal style of Mr. Frick, who listened to others but made his own decisions.
Frick Collection. Small, but beautiful and impressive. It is a very nice spot for na afternoon, especially if it is raining.

A New York 'must do'. The Frick collection is the only place I have been where you can get so close to the art work, that you can see the tiniest brush strokes. The setting is amazing - when walking through this private house, you almost expect the owner to say hello. The art work is amazing. We allowed 2 hours and left feeling that we had had rushed things a little. Three hours is a reasonable time to look around and then have another look to soak up the art work as well as the environment. This experience rated higher than most other New York experiences for us
NYC's classiest act!. What a trip!  Go back in time when really significant works of art were part of a home.  Beautiful paintings. Set in the most refined environment.

Great visit. This was my second visit to the Frick, and I enjoyed it even more than my first visit a couple of years ago. This time I took my teenage daughter who is a painter herself. She loved it! The Frick is beautiful and classy, but not too large or overwhelming. It is definitely worth a visit. We got there at opening on a Saturday morning, and almost had the place to ourselves. We roamed around for about 90 minutes, completely unhurried, enjoying everything we saw. It was a great visit. Just wish I lived closer so I could visit more often.
A wonderful gallery. Small but amazing pieces of art. Well worth the visit. We spent 1.5 hours wandering. Make sure to see the video shown - wonderful history of the Frick family!

Hard to not love the Frick. Hadn't been there in awhile and found it to be just as great as before. Small but interesting collection means that you can relax and enjoy it and the wonderful setting in a few hours. Leighton’s Flaming June painting on loan from the Museo de Ponce is not to be missed.

You can fall in love with NYC right here. Go for one reason - "Flaming June". The painting is moody with swirly orange. It is set on either side with a demure, elegant Whistler. You will see many old friends here - Rembrandt, Vermeer, Frnas Hal, and El Greco, but maybe you will see one of their works that you hadn't visited before.
Good art, great history.. Nice art collection, though a little froo-froo for me. But the building is one of the last remaining 5th Avenue mansion, which makes a real gem.

Mansion-turned-museum – My favorite NYC museum!. Having lived in NYC for over 6 years, I’ve been to pretty much every museum more than once. The Frick is by far my favorite! The museum was actually Henry Clay Frick’s mansion. He designed and built the mansion intending for it to be used as a museum later on. Although small, it houses beautiful and famous works by Gainsborough, Fragonard, Whistler, and Turner. The furniture, tapestries, fixtures and artifacts are also works of art and complement the paintings very well. The museum also has a peaceful courtyard with lush greens and fountains, a beautiful garden, as well as an event space where various small concerts are held every year for $35 a performance! Concert-goers are able to enter the museum free of charge an hour before the performance to explore the museum. It is highly recommended to attend one of these concerts. Seats are first come first serve so make sure to get there early! On Sundays from 11-1pm, its pay-as-you-wish. Definitely get the free audio guide. You must use the coat check or wear your coat; you are not allowed to carry it. Also, there is no museum café, as the museum is quite small.

Jewel of a Museum. Loved visiting the Frick, and were able to see the beautiful painting "Flaming June". Located East of Central Park, this Museum is small enough that you can visit without becoming overwhelmed.
Home and hearth with art galore. Wealthy family shared the art and love of all things beautiful with the public. This collection is inviting, gorgeous, multi-faceted, and breath-taking.

Not your typical museum. Really enjoyed seeing this collection of art, furniture, sculpture and the home of Henry Clay Frick. This is a museum that is easy on your feet and love the wide assortment of art to enjoy. Hand-held audio device makes it really enjoyable.

Amazing collection and setting - like a great painting in the perfect frame. One of the most beautiful museums in New York. In particular for those who love art, like to see unique pieces by the world's greatest artists, but do not want to spend the entire day at the museum. The collection is the perfect size to spend a few hours and then move on to another one of the many sights Manhattan has to offer - like the nearby Neue Galerie, Guggenheim, Metropolitan Museum of Art or "just" Central Park.

A highlight of our trip to NYC. This collection of fine art is housed in a wonderful old mansion on 5th Avenue, right near the Met. It is the most wonderful private collection and the mansion is filled with a staggeringly gorgeous array of paintings and sculptures.The collection is displayed in such a way that the visitor can view everything at very close quarters…..not at a distance as in some museums and galleries. It is highly recommended that you take the time, when in NYC, to visit this lovely collection.

Impressive. A local suggested I skip the huge museums this trip and see the Frick instead. It was great advice. The collection included Renoir, Rembrandt, Vermeer, and a host of other artists. The architecture, furniture, and other items held my interest even more than the paintings. It's wonderfully done.Located across the street from Central Park, it was an ideal size to visit without being overwhelmed and saving a little time for other activities.

Stunning. What I like most about the Frick is the small scale - you don't get the 'art overload' syndrome I experience at the bigger museums. The collection is beautiful, and the museum's history and personal feel make it unique.

Favorite NYC museum. Actually went in 2010 and just reviewing. This colection in Frck's actual home is excellent at every level. I adore the Met, but this is our Fav, as generally a smaller museum amazes without overwhelming.
Wonderful Gallery. The artwork is fabulous, the setting equally so. The old Frick Mansion is glorious. The gardens aren't generally open to the public but are lovely viewed from the street.

Absolute Treasure in Manhattan!. Such a brilliant gem in the heart of Manhattan! It is one of my all-time favourite institutions, which boasts an incredible collection of Old Masters works housed within just the most beautiful setting. I visit it every time I'm in NYC!

You Cannot Imagine the Collection!. Pristinely kept museum that houses some of the most incredible, rare, and well-conditioned pieces I have seen in some time. A great stop if you wander into the Upper West Side. Big enough to keep you busy for two hours or more if you choose not to rush things. On top of all that, the story about Mr. Frick, the industrialist, is very interesting.
Fantastic frick. This is a must see activity. It is easy to navigate and contains an amazing collection of famous artworks.

Serene & Lovely. I love Frick: The building is beautiful (love the reflecting pool in atrium), the collection superb and small enough to warrant lingering over every piece and not get "burnt" out by too much art. I wish they had a little cafe in the internal Atrium, then I could linger even longer.

nice small museum . I found the architecture more interesting than the art but that's just me. It is just one floor and can easily be covered in 1-2 hours. The staff are friendly. There is a free audio device which is a must and docent tours as well which are supposed to be very good but they only had 2 tours the day we were there. I would not say it's a gem but I'm not a huge art person either.
Small and impressive. Small but lovely museum on the upper east side. Something for everyone. For those days when you're not quite up for the Met!

Finest collection of Impressionist in NY. Just a beautiful museum across from Central Park. The old Frick mansion has been turned into a magnificent art gallery. Not to be missed museum if you are in NYC.

a museum with great art and atmosphere. The Frick Collection contains a great art collection, but it has also retained the atmosphere of a private mansion. The interior is beautiful, and is a great site for chamber music concerts.

Thank god for Mr Frick!!!!!!!!!!!!. I felt utterley honoured to attend the viewing in Mr Frick's home.Mr Frick has bought so much pleasure into my life by viewing his collection.The man had foresight to purchase such fabulous works of art and I felt a warm glow in my soul upon entering this beautiful residence.The world needs people like Mr Frick to open the hearts and minds of generations to come to appreciate the beauty in the world.May you RIP MR Frick and I thank you and your family for sharing your home with me.

Wonderful collection, but invest in some docents. The collection is simply wonderful and the home's architecture is impressive! You are provided with a free audio guide which provides you with helpful information. Unfortunately, the Frick Collection employees are unable to answer any questions or provide additional information on top of what is in the audio guide. I had a few questions during my tour and quickly realized that the employees were there to make sure I didn't touch the art and architecture, not actually help me know more about it.I would suggest that the Frick Collection invest in some docents to answer questions or begin a volunteer docent program. Those visiting the collection will greatly benefit from it. Tip: they have "pay what you wish" time from 11am to 1pm on Sunday if you are looking to save a few dollars!

Excellent smaller museum. This museum is smaller, of course than the Met , but it is filled with a wonderful variety of paintings, furniture and other works of art that make it truly a delight to visit.

Memorable visit!. Museum is relatively small but it has such charming and private feel that it takes permanent spot in one’s memory. I rate it high because of the various programs and lectures museum is offering through the year. If you are visiting NYC and into art and history, check the calendar of events and combine museum visit with an event.
What an impressive art collection!. I was truly mesmerised from the moment I stepped in. Frick Collection is absolutely one of the best private art collections I've ever seen. Must visit!
Off the beaten track. My husband didn't want to do this but absolutely loved it and went through the house twice. On a Sunday between 11am-1pm you can pay what you like (donation) - usually $20
Unexpected treat. My children (10 and 14) were thrilled to see the art at the Frick Collection. The collection was varied and interesting. To see the whole museum took about an hour and a half.

A Jewel. Sadly more and more people are discovering The Frick Collection, so each time I visit, it's just a little more crowded. But walking through the halls of this mansion and knowing that it's largely left the way it was when Henry Frick lived there -- it's my favorite way to view art, seeing how people lived with masterpieces. Fun to envision yourself in the Gilded Age, pulling up in your buggy and going to a lavish party in a gorgeous mansion with some of the best paintings!

A very enjoyable tour, but some research needed.... Who is/was Henry Clay Frick?? That was the question my wife and I kept asking ourselves as we toured this wonderful museum. Perhaps he's better known to native New Yorkers, but the average visitor may have to look it up on Wikipedia (like we did) as the answer isn't immediately apparent on the tour other than a brief hint to his background on the audio tour. That being said, my wife and I enjoyed the audio tour of the Frick collection immensely as various narrators filled us in on the detailed background of the rare pieces. We truly enjoyed this tour, though were it not for the unfortunate rudeness of the coat check personnel (which could have possibly bumped this ranking a little higher), we were well pleased with this experience and will encourage our friends to see it for themselves (perhaps after doing a little research on Frick first :))

Good Collection of Paintings and Furniture. It was nice collection of paintings and Furniture. I was more interested in Furniture. Central courtyard with fountain was very peaceful. They were distributing sketch papers and pencils for people to draw. It was quite and worth place to draw a sketch. I went there on Sunday when it is pay as you wish during early hours. Its a nice place to spend hour or two.

A very doable museum. This museum is in a mansion built in the late 1800's. All on one floor with a huge personal collection of art of Henry Clay Frick. Stop and watch the movie before you tour the museum, it's a good way to get the history of the place. There are not many places to sit while viewing the various rooms. Although it's easy to get back to the movie room if you need to sit for a few minutes.
A Must See Private Collection. This is a masterful collection in an absolutely gorgeous home, well worth spending a couple of hours exploring.

What a lovely collection. I went with a friend and we had a wonderful couple of hours in this house - we both liked the idea of only collecting art that makes you feel good and it was certainly a pleasurable experience, worth a visit and take your time.

A real treasure made even better by a private tour. Day 5 - straight after leaving our tour of MoMA we headed up to the Frick Museum for a private tour for just Liz and me, and what a treat it was.This collection of art works, furniture and porcelains is definitely one of NY's finest collections and set in such impeccable surroundings. Whilst Henry Frick may have been one of NY's most ruthless robber-barons, he had impeccable taste.Renoir's 'Mother and Children'; Vermeer's 'Girl at her Muse' and 'Officer and laughing girl'; Gainsborough's 'St James' Park'; Bellini's 'St Francis in the desert'; and Holbein's incredible portrait of 'Sir Thomas More'; Turner's 'Fishing boats entering Calais Harbour'; Constable's 'Salisbury Cathedral'; Degas' 'The Rehearsal'.The list goes on and on and our guide was very informative and gave us a great insight into the meaning behind a lot of the art work.A fantastic two hours that are now stored away in the memory bank.
Our favorite museum. A beautiful museum in a stunning home. A wonderful opportunity to see a "Gilded Age mansion". Beautifully arranged and just a joy to visit.

My home - The Frick Collection. What can I say? This was my second visit to the Frick and I love it even more now. A beautiful 5th Avenue mansion that is now a world class art gallery of distinction. Where to look first - the Vermeers, the El Grecos, the Rembrandts, the Italian masters of 14 and 15th centuries, of maybe the magnificent Renoir of the little twin girls and their nanny? No wait, what about the Fragonnards, the Bouchers, and so much more! A delicious treat - just go!

A great collection of masterpieces of European painting. I cannot say it better than Frick describes itselves; "The Frick Collection includes masterpieces of European painting, major works of sculpture (among them one of the finest groups of small bronzes in the world), superb eighteenth-century French furniture and porcelain, old master and nineteenth-century works on paper, Limoges enamels, and other works of remarkable quality."
Perfect sized museum . Watch the 12-minute history video in the oval room. Love the size of the museum. It's big enough to be comprehensive but not so big that it overwhelms the visitors.
Fabulous!. Wonderful collection of art in a home setting. The Frick Family lived in the home and turned it in to a museum

An Enduring Sanctuary. The Frick has stayed true to its original nature, as a private home with some amazing art that you get to see on intimate terms. I love the Turner paintings, more so now that I've seen the great film, "Mr. Turner." The Rembrandt Self Portrait and the Vermeers are also priceless.

Such great art, and also the source of a funny error in Fun Home. We hadn't ever been here (apparently my partner's mother was once thrown out of the museum for getting too close to a painting!), but we'd chatted with a couple at breakfast the previous morning about the Frick, and given that they like the Morgan Library (my favourite museum in NYC), we took their recommendation.One thing I hadn't realized before we went there was that the collection doesn't travel. So, yes, I've seen the portraits of More and Cromwell, and I've seen some of the Limoges enamels, and yes, I've seen the Turners, but it's pretty clear I've not seen them face-to-face, nor would I ever.The museum is not super-crowded, and it forbids visits by children (which is contrary to a section of "Fun Home"), which makes for a quite pleasant experience.
