The special exhibit about porcelain made me think that maybe the Jacobins were right in the French Revolution, given that many of them were made during a period when the French had a fairly large fraction of their population starving.

Beautiful.. One of the most beautiful collections that I have ever been to. Every aspect of the resident, both inside and out, is stunning. I went primarily to view the three Vermeers, but was left more in awe at the elegance of the residence! Note Sunday between 11am-1pm is 'pay as you wish'.

At Last!. On previous trips to NYC this Museum has been high on my list and I've never made it until this month. This is a lovely small museum. We took the docent tour which really covers in a little more detail the information on the audio recording. It was everything good I had heard and more with a lovely tranquil atrium to have a rest before continuing.

A Gem of a Museum. I visited this museum after a good friend recommended it to me. It was so worth the time to visit and the master pieces of art Mr. Frick accumulated are astounding and so worth seeing. He truly had a great eye and I enjoyed knowing he did not want any war pictures. The mansion is also worth seeing. It was a nice change from the other museums where there are great crowds and huge to traverse.

Magnificent historic Home & Art Collection. My wife and I were so impressed with the setting, structure and contents of this magnificent home turned museum. With admission you get to use a personal digital audio tour guide device. Punching in the numbers associated with the exhibits results in an audio overview of the item as well as a glimpse into the Frick's. The free 20 minute video of the house and family history provides great context for what you have come to see. Children might find this exhibit a bit dull but adults who have any appreciation for art will enjoy this museum. My wife and Imtook the subway up to 49th and 5th and walked up,along Central Park to The Frick. After were strolled thru the Park and eventually ended up over near Lincoln Center where we had lunch in a neighborhood restaurant. This made for a wonderful excursion.

Brilliant collection. This is a great place. Far away from the crowds and no lines. The museum is a mixture between a museum and a mansion, which adds a nice atmosphere to it. Excellent collection of art. Lot's of Turners and some Rembrands. The yard in the centre is just great.

small and perfectly formed museum with eclectric art displays. Frick museum housed in a " home" has stunning selection of art - paintings, furniture and sculpture. Unlike New York's huge crowded museums the Frick is of human scale. No children under 10 reduces the crowds and gives more time to appreciate the art. Go on a Sunday morning when it opens and you pay what you want to enter (5$ seemed average when I went). The history is well explained in 20 minute film show and then a couple of hours will be enough time to tour the house and its treasures.

Don't miss this one!. The Frick Collection is one of NYC's gems. Sadly (or maybe thankfully) it is often skipped by tourists. Going to this museum is like going to a rich uncles house. It is often times very quiet and not very crowded at all. The paintings are appointed in a spectacular display. The rooms are magnificent. And a stop here is well worth a visit. Spend roughly two hours here, you will not regret it!

A Cultural Gem Among Gems. The Frick Collection is housed in the Frick mansion, which is an incredible work of art in its own right. The top-notch architecture with exquisite materials and intricate detailing could never be as beautifully built today! And housed within this architectural masterpiece is an art collection that astounds in content and beauty. Works of the old masters chosen personally by Mr. Frick himself are beautifully displayed through-out the house. The collection is personal and impressive. What a treasure found in a city renowned for its art museums! Make this a part of your trip; you won't regret it. Oh, I don't think children are allowed as the art work is displayed out in the open, as it would be in any home.

Often overlooked gem. Wonderful collection in the Frick mansion. Incredible to think that someone actually lived with this collection on their walls. Especially liked the galleries that were still decorated as rooms with the art all around.
Well worth a visit!. The building alone is worth a visit but include the collection and you have a wonderful few hours of visual pleasure.

Most impressive museum. Great exibitions.. The art collection was incredible.Although smaller, this would be the best art collection I have seen outside of the large galleries. The artifacts, sculptures, furniture and china are amazing. This was a real surprise.
Take Time To Visit Frick. This is one of those museums that unless someone tells you about it, you may never discover it. Great collection in a convenient location. Slices of American all around.

Magnifiaient private home converted into a Museum. Similarité to Jacquemard and André in Paris, the Frick house is a must see whenever you go to NYC. This personnage, Mr Frick was a visionary in art collection and made sure his mansion would become a Museum after he passed. What a pleasure to explore his collection.

one of the best collections of old masters. we visited the Frick Collection early June this year ,what an amazing collection of art and all in the Home of Henry Frick .to walk into a room and to be able to see masterpieces by Vermeer,Turner , Rembrandt ,El Greco ,Goya , Constable and others is a sight to behold a very special place and a must to visit

Small museum in a home. Mr. Frick had this house built to house his collection. They clearly lived very formally, not a homey place. Nice collection but did not live up to the praise I have heard. A few good pieces. I would not make this a top priority considering the other museums near by.

Fantastic collection. Not far from the Met Museum this is a much smaller building but contains an amazing collection of classic European Masters paintings! Its also a lovely old building to walk around and is still decorated as it was back in 1930s. Another plus is that children are not allowed so there are none of the usual velvet ropes to keep you back from the art!

A classic collection that art lovers will appreciate.. We have visited the Frick many times, wife resident a few blocks away during an extended "tour of duty" at a major NYC hospital/medical college. Even though I probably have seen the same works several times, it seems that on each occasion when I visit I see something different in familiar works of art, the majority European classics. Moreover, the setting inside the museum itself is very peaceful and attractive, adding to the experience of appreciating the art works. Definitely worth a visit.

Excellent collection! This is a must see!. This is absolutely amazing house and private collection of art at the same time. If you don't have time or energy for visiting MET, but would like to see some of the best pieces of art on the earth - come here. The whole exhibit can be easily seen in one - two hours with the concentration of excellent art not seen in any other place. TIP: On Sundays, pay what you wish from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. Worth visiting during those hours as it isn't crowded and you can easily enjoy the collection.

Masterpieces of European art in the Beaux Arts mansion of Henry Clay Frick. A small gem of a museum in the house (now extended) of Henry Clay Frick, which houses his original personal art collection as well as later additions. In a relatively small area, there is outstanding European art displayed - think Vermeer, Turner, Rembrandt, whistler, El Greco, Goya, Fragonard - 18th century French furniture, Limoges porcelain, outstanding small sculptures and even an enclosed garden with fountains in what used to be where the coaches drew up. The house I itself is I teresting and is wonderfully maintained.It was not crowded on the day we went and was an absolute joy to spend time there. It is a very special and beautiful space
Always wonderful. It is just the right size and all on one floor. There are many masterpieces to view. It has a beautiful inner courtyard.
Worth a visit.. Saw three by Vermeer and two by El Greco. Many amazing originals in a lavish setting. If you visit between 11 and 1 on Sunday the entry fee is a voluntary donation.
Charming museum. Not too small, not too large, great collection and you feel like visiting someon's home. Highly recommended plus see the movie in their theater about making of this museum.
A great small museum with treasures. Very European.. I love going to the Frick. Every time I go I see something I haven't previously noticed. Go and be moved by great culture.
Very much like an English country house. A superb collection of art works, furnishings and ceramics displayed in opulent surroundings.A tranquil oasis away from the bustle of Fifth Avenue.

Frick - still great. Frick set about assembling the best of the best, and his collection still stands as one of the best in the world: Holbein, Titian, El Greco, Bellini, Constable, Corot, Goya, Velasquez, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Turner. Those were the best paintings on the market 100 years ago, and they still are. It's a priceless collection. Unique in the world, I believe.

The Frick Collection/Museum: A stunningly beautiful art collection. The collection was started by the late Henri Clay Frick (1849-1919) and his family since approx. 1914 in their newly build limestone mansion in Manhattan, which was converted into a museum between 1931 and 1935.What makes this private museum so special, is the fact that within the relative limited space of the original mansion and subsequent additions, one find s a stunningly beautiful collection of paintings of Rembrandt (incl. his self portrait), Frans Hals, Vermeer, El Greco, Van Dyck,, Gainsborough and Holbein, just to mention a few, besides old furnishings, sculptures, French porcelain and clocks.Anybody visiting New York should include in their itinerary a visit to this museum - 1 East 70th Street, New York
Fabulous old school New York and precious masterpieces. The title says it all. Do not miss.You can wander Central Park afterwards and revel in the beauty of old school upscale Newy York.

Diverse and interesting Art Collection. Incredible collection of European Masters in this beautiful mansion. You can walk throughout the whole collection in one hour and not be overwhelmed like in some of the other huge museums. Interesting 15 minute film as well.

Nice!. A private home with a lovely collection of art, the Frick Collection is a must see while you are in New York.
Located along the Fifth Avenue, it is central, easy to get to, small and extremely convenient to visit - which I did during my recent trip to New York City.
Recommended!

A hidden gem. I am an artist by trade and heart. I was visiting NY with a friend of mine, and was scouring things for us to do to help kill some daytime hours. I saw the Frick Collection museum, and thought, 'Why not?' Let me tell you, it was money well spent. My friend is not a frequent art museum attendant, so to stand back and watch her be 'sucked into' my world, was a true delight! This museum is actually an old mansion with a vast, interesting history. The architecture is spectacular within itself and the art is truly the icing on the cake. You can spend a little time there, or a lot, it is truly up to you.I enjoyed hearing about each piece as I listened to our little hand-held receivers. (The ones where you push in the number of the painting you are interested in.) My friend and I are so glad that we went. I encourage others to seek out this hidden gem that boasts a gorgeous in-door and outside garden area and beautiful sculptures as well.
Great art. The Frick has a beautiful collection of art displayed in an intimate and elegant setting. The interior courtyard is also lovely, as is the exterior Russell Page-designed garden.

A small Gem.. What a stunning museum. It is small but well worth a visit. The queues were long in the winter but this was due to "The Girl with the Pearl Earring" being on display. Its a home with a private collection, similar to Kenwood in London.
Frick - quite amazing. Wonderful museum - don't miss it ! Very small but so much to see - there is a half hour film at the end on the story of how Mr Frick and how it all came to be - amazing !

Art gems in historical mansion.. The mansion itself is a work of art and fun to walk through to see how the robber barons lived. The central courtyard with pool and skylight is a great place to relax in. The art works are primarily European and feature the most famous names such as Rembrandt, Vermeer, Gainsborough, Turner, etc. One of the most enjoyable art experiences in the city.

A gem of a Museum!. The usual museum circuit in New York is the Met, the MoMA and the Guggenheim. By the time your done visiting one of these, you can't feel your feet and yet you feel like you haven't even covered half the museum! The Frick Collection allows you to see the complete museum and save your feet a world of pain at the end of the day! The museum itself is housed in the house build by Henry Frick. The museum not only displays the art pieces itself but also has restored the furniture of Mr. Frick's time beautifully! Its hard to pick a favourite room but the sun lit museum in the house leading to the oval room and the Gardens inside the house are a treat! Truly candyland for art lovers
A NY Mansion on 5th. A fabulous mansion now filled with furnishings from the previous owners and some beautiful artwork. Home to many special exhibits, so there is always something new to see...

Stunning treasure; a small gem of a museum. I love everything about the Frick! Just to walk by the architecture makes me smile. Actually it's the former home of Mr. Frick, who built it to house his art collection! Who else does that? With a sun-drenched center courtyard conservatory and a handsome precious auditorium, the Frick is an oasis for the soul in the midst of NYC. If you like European "classical" paintings (a Rembrandt!, Fragonards, Boucher), drawings and exquisite examples of furniture, porcelain, enamels and other decorative arts, you must see the Frick. wonderful gift shop with books
A peaceful, non crowded experience. Terrific collection displayed in beautiful suroundings.The gardens are equally beautiful and worth a visit. Staff were discreet and knolwedgeable

For adults. The Frick is like a dessert after a good meal. The kids may find it boring, but adults will think they have stepped into a candy box: which item or room is the best? How can you pick when everything is perfection? Try to fit it in.

Beautiful art and building . If you're looking for quantity than the Frick Collection may not be for you, but if you're looking for the melding of beautiful art work and architecture, then it's the perfect place for a visit.I went in the late morning on a Saturday and worried that it'd be overly packed but it wasn't meaning that you could soak in the Vermeers, Goyas, and others without worrying that you'd be hurried out.Pictures aren't allowed except in the Garden Court so you don't have to worry about the usual museum issue of people trying to snap a picture of the artwork.

Tired of large museums?. The Frick is the best! Small enough so your feet are usable at the end of the day, and the collection large enough to feel like you've seen great art. If the Met is too overwhelming, go here!

"Quite Another World". As I walk around the Frick Museum I can't help to imagine what life in this Mansion was once like. The view of Central Park is amazing. This is a beautiful place to sit and relax in the refreshing environment. It is a place to enjoy the environment as much as the art.

A Treasure of the city. A gem of New York City that is down the street from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. This the mansion of Mr. Frick that has one of the best collections of art and sculpture in the area. What is nice about this museum is that it is manageable to see it all in less than a day. And if you fortunate enough you might be lucky to be present when there is a concert in the atrium area.

Always a Treat. Every visit to the Frick is a pleasure. It belongs to a ritual during NYC visits. Grecos & a few Rembrandts. Whistler should get more attention as should the small Cimabue Panel in the 'renaissance' gallery.

Fantastic Collection. This is an amazing collection of art. Every room you enter is jaw dropping. There was even a painting of my home city by John Constable. The house it self is an incredible building.

Great for limited time in NYC. When you've got limited time or looking for something different to do. The Frick has a good app to use, the collection is fab and definitely worth getting the free headset to listen as you go.

Best I've seen..... Loved the ease with which you can view each piece with the audio. Very impressed with how it is a personalised collection of one man (family), and being kept that way. Nothing I can think of to dislike

A must see. A house that is now a museum. It is like walking around someone's house admiring their art, which made it a unique experience. Visit the Music Room first to watch the film about Frick, interesting background information.

Always a thrill. The Frick is always a pleasure visiting. The video show is a great way to learn all about the history of the place and the art while resting your weary bones. The internal court garden is unforgettable. We have been twice and I look forward to our next visit.

Very Nice Museum. Not only do you get to view great art, but you get to tour one of the great old residences of NYC. There are not only paintings and sculptures, but the furniture in the Frick is also great art.

The Best Art Museum In NYC. Frick is the name of the man who collected these works of art, and it is in his house that they are shown. Every piece is a masterpiece, and this is the best art museum in New York City.

one of the best art museums in the city. The Frick Collection is amazing. In the mansion built by Henry Clay Frick I think in 1913. Filled with amazing art from around the world. It is quiet and easy to get around and see all of it in a day. At 70th and 5th Avenue at Central Park.
A real treat. The Frick mansion and location. The art collection. The friendly staff. Walking distance from the hotel, along 5th Ave.

Don't miss this museum in shadow of the Met. The home of Frick (business partner of Carnegie) is now a museum showplace with a beautiful display of some fine works of art. For those who really appreciate the beauty of fine art, along with an interest in seeing how the upper echelon live life, stop by and visit. Be sure to watch the 15 min movie of the background story, then take your time exploring the home and works of art. A bit sad for me, was the beautiful collection of old books, never to be held and read again. The library is a beautiful room, but how can it be justified that all those books must never again be enjoyed by looking within the pages. still, it's a great place to wander and soak in the finer things in life- plan to spend 2-3 hours.

Beautiful. The Frick is fairly small by museum standards but well worth the visit. It is in a landmarked mansion on Fifth Avenue which is a perfect building to view such great works of art. The building itself dates back to the 1930's making it a piece of art itself. It has a beautiful viewing garden with flowers, a lily pond, and more. There are pieces by artist such as Goya, Rembrandt, Velazquez, and El Greco that are wonderfully displayed in the various rooms. There is always a special exhibit on display...that are always a great addition. If you are someone who appreciates art, make a trip to the Frick.

A small and excellent museum - good story and art. The former mansion of a steel baron this museum has a fantastic collection of art and an interested back story. Definitely worth a visit.We walked through Central Park (about a mile from our hotel) and found it not at all crowed - in contrast to the other museums we visited in New York.

Jewel of a museum. Love this beautiful small museum. Very different from the other huge museums in New York, this one is visited by many just because of the gorgeous building that houses the collection. Best in nice weather so you can enjoy the beautiful grounds and courtyard.
Small and Sweet. As others have mentioned, very much like a home rather than a museum. Though of course quite a grand one. Easily doable in a couple of hours. Quite a few treasures from Old Masters.
The Frick Collection (Mansion) is worth a visit.. The taste of Mr. Frick is admirable. One of the greatest collections in the US. Spend some time there and relax in the Garden Court.

If you appreciate art, you MUST visit the Frick. Pure class and detail all around, this institution is a class act. It's small but there's a ton to see. I recommend staying around for a docent tour and really going through the audio guides as they're all well done and informative. The arrangement and orchestration of the collection throughout the mansion is very awe inspiring and it truly feels like you're going back in time.

European Architecture in New York. I visited this museum with my wife. Not only the arts in the museum but also the architecture itself had an European mood.I could see some famous pictures in the museum, and especially, I was satisfied that I could find three pictures painted by Vermeer.On the other hand, the entrance fee cost 20USD while the museum is not so large, and it is a bit expensive comparing to the huge Metropolitan museum which costs just 25USD at maximum. Also, I was sorry that it was prohibited to take pictures inside the museum, although I wanted to do that.

Favourite NY museum. This was absolutely my favourite visit in NY: just the right size and where the collection and the building itself are in complete harmony. Reminded me of my favourite Paris museum, the Jacquemart-André - if you love that you'll also love this.

Brilliant little museum. An amazing collection of art in a mansion near Central Park, with beautiful views of gardens and the sound of fountains. Highlights include paintings by Rembrandt, Holbein, and Vermeer, as well as exquisite furniture, vases, and silver.

Great Private collection. it was an interesting building and collection. The building was a private home at one time. Would have been a beautiful home. Great small collection but seen in a natural setting makes it special.
outstanding. It's small.. You can cover this in an hour or two. Well worth it. Some interesting pieces of art, and it is nice to sit and relax by the indoor fountain

Unusual Museums that are Terrific. We can all critique divergence of wealth, but Manhattan has a number of examples of the benefits. The Frisk is one. Really, this is just a rich guy's house on 5th Ave on NY's upper east side. But it is a treat, and I would hate to see you miss it. There are some works of art that are world class. There is also an ambiance that arises from understanding the time from which these originate. This is a place on a must visit for New York, and a place on a must visit at least a couple of times a year for those of us pri'sonesrs in Manhattan. It is a concern that the museum is succumbing to large museum itis and looking to capital projects and additions, but the curator has done a good job so far in balance, and the show is worth the trip.

A mid-size alternative to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Visit the Frick then pop over to 72nd Street and the wonderful Bethesda Fountain at the center of Central Park on 72nd Street. The Frick is extraordinary not only for its world class art collection, but it is also an extraordinary mansion--the building itself is worth the price of admission. If the Metropolitan Museum seems overwhelming to you but you'd like to take in some very fine Old Masters (and more), then try the Frick. You won't be disappointed.

Art in a mansion setting. The Frick collection is housed in the Frick's home, just down 70th from Central Park. The bones of the house are still visible, and many of the rooms feature either original or period furniture. The living room still features the original interior design from when Mr. Frick first had the house built. Art in this collection includes paintings, enamels, porcelains, some small statues, furniture, hangings, clocks, books, and other small domestic pieces. I enjoyed the Turner seascapes, and my companion was transfixed by a small bronze representation of Hercules fighting the Hydra, where each head resembled a different monster. Children under 10 are not permitted, so it is a fairly quiet experience. Photos are only allowed in the atrium near the fountain.

One of the best collections of art in the world. Frick assembled, and then curated and replaced these pieces, assuring he had only the best. On the wall of this compact home lie paintings you will recognize as "The" one. The Rembrandt self portrait. The Holbein Thomas Moore AND the Holbein Thomas Cromwell. The George Washington... Plus paintings of pure beauty. This is best-of, gathered delightfully around an inner water feature and in warm, but luxurious surroundings. Highly recommended!

One of NYC's Finest Museums. This is a museum you can see in a few hours but you will want to come back like I have. The highlights are the library and the gallery. I sit in the galley and just picture Mr. Frick coming in in the evening, taking a seat and admiring his collection. On the first visit you may want to rent the self-guided audio tour. These are quite good. Guests to the museum are afforded up close looks. They have a beautiful book/gift shop. Please turn off your cell phones while in this museum and all museums. Let your eyes and brain look not your cameras.
Do not miss this one!. Besides all the amazing artwork, the home itself is a must see. Be sure to watch the film before you wonder all the beautiful rooms!
Amazing place. No kids allowed which makes it really peaceful. The art work is amazing and some of it is very famous.

A small, bright gem. van Eyck, Bruegel the Elder, El Greco, Bellini, Holbein. Oh, and Rembrandt, Whistler, and Vermeer if that wasn't enough. Spend a few hours or a few days. This treasure chest should not be missed.
An interesting Sunday morning visit. The Frick Collection is an interesting and intimate, somewhat eclectic, museum. We enjoyed our Sunday morning visit, though it began to get crowded.

Interesting Collection. I especially enjoyed the portraiture. The incredible house alone is worth the price of admission. Bequeathing this collection to the public is likely the best (only good?) thing Frick did in his lifetime.
My second favorite museum.. generally very peaceful. it had a lovely courtyard with a large fountain where you can sit and contemplate what you have seen.
frick. wonderful place to view a vairety of paintings, very quiet and tranquil environment. There should be a place to have coffee and a little food
Atmospheric!. A great collection still housed in the private and opulent home of its donor circa 1930. A must see for art lovers visiting New York City.
Intimate museum experience. Small, residential style museum. Fantastic artworks, quiet and enjoyable experience. Not overwhelming large as so many NY museums can be.

AMAZING. It was only thanks to Trip Advisor that I found this amazing place. Searching for places to visit in NY with our Australian friends, I checked on Trip Advisor and found this rated as 9th under things to do in NY. As you walk from room to room you are WOWED from the ceiling to the floor. The art collection is just phenomenal and we just lost all track of time. The 5th Avenue mansion itself is a true work of art. There is a free audio tour that explains things about the artist and also how Charles Frick and his family lived. Our traveling friends have been all over the world and they were so impressed with the Frick. This is a definite MUST SEE if you are in NY. A big thank you to Trip Advisor for leading me to it.

A house of history. Not only do you get some great paintings, sculptures, and artefacts, the house is maintained in the style it was when the Frick family lived there. The decor and the garden makes this a delightful museum to visit. Take a free audio tour machine which enables you to find out more about selected paintings.

Very excellent museum. The Frick Collection is an excellent museum to visit. Both the art collection and the building are worth taking the time and trouble to visit. It is near the Metropolitan Museum. If the Metropolitan is too crowded, go to the Frick.
Love the Frick. Had wanted to visit for years, and finally made the time. Room after room of lovely paintings, but not overwhelming.
A gem. The Frick is essential for art lovers. It's small and you truly get a sense of it being a person's home and their personality coming through.

Great view into the past. The Frick Collection is both worth visiting for the Frick Manor and the art included. Artworks are mostly European from the 18th to late 19th century. Check the website to get an overview of what to expect. While this is a collection the background information to the paintings doesn't get close to museums like the MET

A Collection for the Ages. It is impossible to predict what you are going to see inside this stately mansion of yesteryear's steel baron multi-millionaire. The paintings, furniture and architecture leave you breathless.

Gorgeous!. This is a small museum with a phenomenal collection of classic artwork, particularly painting, amassed by industrialist Frick. Also of interest is the fact that the collection is housed in what was the family's amazing mansion. My only criticism is that no photography of any kind is allowed in the museum. Kind of a silly rule.

A gem!. Not only is the artwork stunning, but the estate itself is magnificent. Absolutely amazing to see so many works on display including El Greco, Rembrandt etc. Highly recommend watching the short film in the Music Room - provided excellent context to the overall collection and about Mr. Frick's life. The enclosed courtyard is very peaceful as well and is the only spot allowing photography. Overall, a lovely and worthwhile visit - easy to take in some fine art at a leisurely pace under around 90 minutes.

Fascinating glimpse of diverse quality art. I had an unexpected extra 2 hours to spend in Manhattan and used my time wisely at the Frick collection. I was not disappointed. Wonderful works on display.
One of my favorites. A small museum but with great art! One of my favorites in a city filled with amazing pieces of art. Well worth going to see.

Intimate collection.. Considering the hubbub of this busy city, this was a welcome find. Lovely looking building with some quite special works of art. Not too over whelming - Making this a quite intimate collection.

Impressive Small Collection. I was extremely impressed by this collection. There were some really fantastic and (art-historically) famous paintings in this museum. Definitely check this out, and grab one of those audio recordings to learn some more art history :)
Nice place to visit. Beautiful building and art work. A must see if you enjoy art. Great place to take pictures too. Enjoy

Fabulous Collection of Paintings. The Frick Collection is situated on Fifth Avenue opposite Central Park and is a wonderful collection of paintings, sculpture and furniture. Some of the pictures are so well known that they seem familiar, particularly the Holbeins and Gainsboroughs. I really liked the fact that photography is forbidden, so people are actually looking at the paintings, not just taking photos of them.
original works. so impressive the building itself and all the original works.You can each listen of headphones to whichever painting interested you. well worth a look at.

A great human scale gallery. While the Metropolitan is awesome and needs a week to do justice, the Frick is a lovely human scale building with a very high standard collection that only needs half a day to explore and enjoy. Definitely worth a visit

A must see. After being at the MET which is so huge and at times overwhelming, it was a relief to go to the Frick. It's more intimate and the house has a really nice feeling. You can slow down and enjoy the paintings, decor and your surroundings.

Do not give The Frick a flick!. On our last trip to NYC from Australia we'd visited some of the larger galleries so this holiday was about the smaller, more boutique and out there collections and this one is outstanding!The gallery is a once grand home which provides unique and changing spaces to view the fantastic collection and also provides a glimpse into bygone lifestyles. Its easy to relax and meander at you own pace with an audio tour through rooms that have been beautifully restored and maintained.The collection is wonderful and wide ranging too.I'd recommend it to anyone interested in private collections and the contribution of philanthropy to American culture - past, present and future

Lovely little museum with an eclectic collection. The Frick is a beautiful mansion filled with the lifetime collection of Henry Frick. The paintings are varied, and most by the great masters. The porcelain and furniture is lovely. The audio guide is free with admission, and it is well worth listening to. The courtyard garden is beautiful and a great place for quiet contemplation away from the NY throngs.

It is hard to believe that one person could own all of that wonderful art.. The museum is a treasure, built in what was a private home for a nineteenth century Robber Baron. Frick collected an impressive amount of old Masters, Chinese Porcelains and furniture. Frisk bought what he liked and displayed in his home to be appreciated. He left the house and art with the intention that it be open to the public so they could enjoy it. You walk through at your own pace and there is so much to see, it is hard to take it all in during one visit.

A Treasure. The Frick home compliments the collection and the collection compliments this beautiful home, best of both worlds! The beauty of this home is the perfect setting for these old Masters. Definitely a gem in the middle of NYC.

What the gem the Frick Collection is. lThe Frick Collection is a gem. It is an old mansion of Fifth Avenue and houses wonderful furniture and art work. The little gift store has lovely things at very reasonable prices

worth some time and cost. Sculpture Collection in a former American tycoon's family mansion. New York has more to see and do than you will have time for: theater, sight seeing, shopping, walking, people watching, museums, neighborhoods and much, much more! Make sure you get to see the skyline during the day and at night.
Quick museum fix. The Frick is great. You can be in and out in less than a couple of hours. Perfect especially if your company includes a non museum goer.

The house of a handful exquisite paintings. This museum deserves to be visited, if only for the Rembrandts and the Vermeers it houses. I have been told that one better not ask how Frick made his money, which seems somehow evident even today in the cold personnel and the unfriendly premises.
Beautiful. Very unique collection. Fascinating collection of art and beautifully displayed. Very doable in 2 hour period and would recommend getting free headset accompaniment to view museum.
What a house!. This is a great museum. Not overwhelming, has great masterpieces and the building itself is very impressive. A must!

Golden Age Splendor. The mansion, gardens, and vast art collection is a feast for your eyes. There are two Turner paintings in the West Gallery - that are worth the visit. Over 1,000 different art items from the Renaissance to nineteenth-century. A nice respite from the busy pace of NYC.

Fantastic visit. Accessible and manageable. A chance to see some really one and famous works of art close-up. Liked the app which was available for download. Not too crowded during our visit so it felt as if there was plenty of time to view the things we wanted to see. An amazing collection.
the Scottish museum exhibit. Lots of El Grecos, Vermeers and assorted other gems in a mansion, with a homey rather than a museum atmosphere, in a walkable area.
Amazing people of New York. This is a great museum! Collections by Frick - an entrepreneur in early New York City. Many beautiful pieces of art in a beautiful family home.
Some outstanding art. ...in a magnificent setting. Because of it's relatively small size and 'domestic' setting, the Frick Collection is very accessible.

Gilded Age on Display. The Frick has a great collection of art and antiques from the dawn of the Renaissance to the beginning of the 20th Century, displayed the way they had been when Frick was alive.
amazing collection. Beautiful building, fascinating history, some of the finest paintings in the city, maybe the world A must-see for any art enthusiast. Great gift shop too.

MUST SEE. We were going to go to the Moma but a friend suggested the Frick collection, we will go to the Moma next time, but the Frick was awesome. It was interactive and because of the narrative you were able to appreciate lesser known artist and it also point out how the painters or artists used paint stroke, and their materials usedWE WILL RETURN ONLY BECAUSE AFTER 2 HOURS THERE WAS STILL LOTS TO SEE.

A 'must' for art lovers.. This, my second visit, was just as wonderful as the first! Having recently been to 4 exhibitions in London and fought my way through the crowds, I really appreciated the opportunity to view such magnificent works of art in this lovely setting. I would happily come back again.

Excellent Small Museum. The Frick Collection is one of the best smaller museums I've ever been to. It is just large enough to enjoy the whole thing before one grows fatigued. Their trio of Vermeer masterpieces is a highlight of the collection, as are their Rembrandts. A great place to spend an hour or two some afternoon.

Wonderful World. If you appreciate art this is the place to go! Amazing history of the collection and the life of the creator of the collection. Not to be missed, beats most collections that I have seen.

Always a treat. Whenever you are fortunate to be in New York City, save some time to visit the Frick Museum. It is worth the trip and the collection of art is astounding. What is so impressive is that the Frick Mansion is so incredibly magnificent and the art has a real home within it.

Sublime !. After years of seeing this museum & it's art in pictures it did not disappoint on any level. I hope to return to take a tour specific to the building as it is an architectural & decor wonder in and of itself.

Absolutely amazing. If one likes art collections, this is the best there is. Do not miss the Frick Collection.. Extremely enjoyable museum to stroll through. Not sure how many times the average person will say, "Wow!" If you love art, please do not miss this museum. No chance that anyone will regret spending time in this place. Wow!
What a Treat!. I so enjoyed my visit to the Frick! It was a real treat to enjoy such a beautiful and expansive collection in such an elegant mansion setting.

Never would have expected the greatness of this gallery. What a surprise this was. The history of the Frick Family and the love they had for art has blessed many people in the past 75 years. Quiet and magnificent. Many thanks to Mr Frick.

So great!!. The Frick is one of my favorite art collections/ museums in the city. So unique and beautiful. The architecture is interesting - it was Frick's house- and the collection is stunning. Perfect for art lovers.

Impressive collection and quiet atmosphere. We enjoyed visiting the Frick Collection as the mansion was beautiful and the collection was impressive. It offered free audio guides and it was pleasant to view masterpieces without hoards of people around you and jostling for position. Very subdue environment.

One of the best!. It was wonderful to escape the frenetic atmosphere of the busier parts of New York and come here to this peaceful and elegant house with its fine artworks and beautifully appointed rooms. Mr Frick had excellent taste and a great deal of money to indulge it so there is the best of everything. The high point for me was the gallery with paintings from the masters shown as they ought to be shown to their best advantage. The paintings by Turner were quite stunning facing each other on opposite walls and there was a fascinating self-portrait by Rembrant. What helped immensely was the excellent audio-guide which was free. It was an experience I shan't forget.

The NYC Mansion of Carnegie's Right Hand Man. The Henry C. Frick Collection is an oft-overlooked gem of a museum facing Central Park, at Fifth and 70th Street. Built as the New York home of the Frick Family, who were based in smoky Pittsburgh, it's a stunning limestone mansion built between 1912 and 1914 as a showpiece of wealth and "good taste". The family lived there for a time, and apparently it was staffed with over 20 servants. However, it was always meant to be a public legacy of wealth and opulence. Inside is a sizable collection of Old Masters paintings, sculptures and the finest indoor decorative arts. The museum and grounds are a relaxing place to contemplate New York as it once was, right before the Great War, when Robber Barons ruled the US.

More Vermeers than the Rijks. This is a not-your-be-missed treasure. Not only the artwork but the home itself is on display. We just returned from Amsterdam and I was shocked to see more Vermeers at Frick than at Holland's National Rijks Museum. Allow more than the recommended 2.5 hours and use the free audio tour.

Stunning Quality. This is a highlight in New York. This small museum has a range of art selected by Mr Frick who made a fortune in coke and steel. He was a very discerning buyer and not only has a range of superb pictures, including Vermeers, Rembrandts, Turners, Gainsborough s, medieval pictures, porcelain and sculptures, and other Dutch masters BUT he has chosen the very but of examples of their period. He displays them beautifully, for example a portrait of Thomas Moore looks across a fire place at his nemesis Thomas Cromwell, with a picture by El Greco of the the man who translated the bible. Perfect hanging. Since his death the building and range of paintings has been further developed. It is a relaxing enjoyable gallery with excellent audio guides. A real highlight in New York

Is it overrated?. Some of the exhibits most certainly are very worthwhile to see, and the crowds visiting on a Sunday around noon were still quite impressive. I was disappointed, though, that the museum prevents youngsters under ten from being admitted, a somewhat snobbish attitude which could be dealt with differently by asking people with uncontrolled children to leave, for example, or to have a separate children's area available. There are many people with young children who cannot afford baby sitters under such circumstances...

First the Frick, then a macaroon?. I had not been to the Frick in years and was very happy I went. Iit was wonderful to see the works in the home Frick intended for them andit is a smaller museum experience than all the others. Get the free audio tour, and don't miss the Renoir near the (roped off) steps. House wheelchair available for no charge on a first-come basis. If you can, walk either to or from the Frick by going either in or along Central Park - it's a great walk and far faster than a taxi! Afterwards? Go to Ladurée (roughly 70th and Madison, on Madison, so right around the corner), get some upscale macaroons and head to Central Park for an elegant snack. A perfect NYC afternoon.

Highest quality from start to finish. We knew the Frick was going to be good but it exceeded expectations in spades. The Fragonard room, Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, both by Holbein, staring at each other just feet apart, Vermeer and Rembrandt et al all magnificent. Mr Frick selected nothing but the best for his home and the museum directors have enhanced his legacy. If there is a better small museum anywhere on the planet I would be very surprised.

WE NEVER TIRE OF THE FRICK. Coming from the Pittsburgh area, I've always been sorry that Henry Frick and his once close friend and business associate Andrew Carnegie had such a terrible falling out and Frick in his stubbornness refused Carnegie's offer of reconciliation. . .but upon visiting Frick's magnificent New York mansion with its superb collection of artwork and furniture I felt a little better about the man. It was an altogether splendid gift to New York and to posterity. The mansion/museum is seldom crowded (except on weekends), and you are able to wander about at your leisure with an exceedingly helpful audio-guide. If you are there at lunchtime, my wife and I highly recommend the dining room for a tasty bite to eat.
best of NY. apart from the queue...we loved this place, a reall highlight of new york. we arrived early as this meant we didnt need the timed entry. we loved all the art..

This is a must see. What a huge privilege to be seeing this art in the flesh . I was stunned by the quantity of amazing art works . Staff were friendly and hugely knowledgeable about their subject . I urge you to go

Forget the giants - visit the Frick.. World class art in a pristine and totally charming venue. Do yourself a favor, escape the tourists (usually) and spend an hour or so in possibly the best museum in New York.

A true gem on 5th ave and 70th st. Henry Frick started his substantial art collection as soon as he started amassing his fortunes. A substantial amount of his art collection is located in his former residence "Clayton" in Pittsburgh, which is today a part of the Frick Art & Historical Center. Another part was given by his daughter and heiress Helen to the Frick Fine Arts Building, which is on the campus of the University of Pittsburgh.The family did not permanently move from Pittsburgh to New York until 1905. Henry Frick initially leased the Vanderbilt house at 640 Fifth Avenue, to which he moved a substantial amount of his collection. He had his permanent residence constructed from 1912 to 1914 by Thomas Hastings of Carrère and Hastings. He stayed in the house until his death in 1919. He willed the house and all of its contents, including art, furniture, and decorative objects, as a public museum. His widow Adelaide Howard Childs Frick, however, retained the right of residence and continued living in the mansion with her daughter Helen. After Adelaide Frick passed away in 1931, the conversion of the house into a public museum started.John Russell Pope altered and enlarged the building in the early 1930s to adapt it to use as a public institution. It opened to the public on December 16, 1935.Further expansions of the museum took place in 1977 and in 2011.

Great Art. This is a terrrific museum like being in somebodys house
staff are very knowledgable great display of art on view every major painter displayed. Only slight downside is that they do not have any catering facilties

Second Time Around. Just over a year ago, I wrote that if you only have time for one gallery in New York City, then this should be it. My visit today confirmed my belief that this gorgeous home started in 1911 and the incredible collection that Mr.Frick assembled, is truly a wonderful display of art and sculpture. The entire experience, the house, the collection, the grounds all combine to make this a must see attraction.So, why a second review? First of all I began today with a docent tour. Her commentary was stilted and boring!! Skip the docent tour.......Your entrance ticket includes an audio guide. The tour has been changed and wan't as good as I remember it, but it is still a fascinating tour full of historical tidbits.So, go to the Frick House, give yourself two to three hours, do use the audio guide and dream of just what one man can accomplish.

Step back in time. Great art in great rooms. I love this place..the environment is welcoming, and you will feel transported back to the gilded age. Also none of the awful cafeteria smells that emanate from certain other nyc museums.
Don Quixote tapestries. I went on a Friday evening and the experience was amazing. It felt much more intimate, since the rooms are more softly lit at night. Use the audio tour if you can.

Excellent collection. I can't believe we had not visited here before - the collection is small but really worth seeing. The original artwork is interesting with wonderful stories. The story of the Frick family is a piece of american history you don't usually hear of.
A gem of a museum. Magnificent permanent collection. Manageable to see everything in one visit. The special exhibits are generally not at the same level. The buildling is also interesting.

Manageable museum for limited time. This museum isn't too large which may be attractive for those travelers who have limited time. It is located on Fifth Avenue and a stroll on the sidewalk afterward is fun. The art collection is approachable and within reach. I was disappointed that the gift shop didn't have large print copies available for some of the more popular paintings.

Unbelievable works of art and architecture!. This european designed home on Park Avenue was as spectacular as the displays. I was blown away by the Fraggonnard room, works from the Gobelin's in France, original Sevre from France, Rembrandts, Vermeer, Monet, El Goya etc.... I don't think I could pick my favorite. Make the time to go - it's very easy to see it quickly

Just incredible!. So glad that we visited this museum. The setting alone is incredible. You wander through the most beautiful rooms, the quality of the art in each room will astound you. Just amazing to think of so many paintings by incredible artists mainly collected by one man and displayed in what was his home. Highly recommend a visit.

Love The Frick Collection. Small museum in a great location across from Central Park. A lovely morning or afternoon can be spent admiring the former Frick mansion and European works of art. A glimpse into 5th Avenue of days gone by. Also just to enjoy the serenity inside. A nice grown up thing to do.

Beautiful Museum That Is Not Overwhelming. This probably is my favorite NYC museum. Housed in the former Frick mansion, the art and furnishings reflect the classical, largely up-beat taste of its one-time owner. What is wonderful is that you can spend a couple hours here, reflect on nearly everything, and not come away feeling brain-numb from the too, too much. There are some fine pieces in the permanent collection (Wolf Hall fans - this is the place to contemplate the Holbein portraits of Thomas More vs Thomas Cromwell!), and there are a couple rooms that are devoted to a visiting exhibit. There also is a lovely garden room that makes for a restful break.
Great museum, go there!!. Loved this. One of the highlights of our trip. Worth a visit, not as crowded as some but who knows why as it is great.

A discerning eye to reach various artists. Vermeer has been well-known as unprolific painter. But you can expect a few works, in addition, similar values from the others. I mean, this private owned collection was based on sparkling and discerning eye. In one hour, you look through whole arts in the world by the past owner.

A wonderful museum-easy to see it all in a few hours.. This museum has always been a favorite of mine with its impressive collection of (mostly) European art in the beautiful setting of the former Frick mansion on the upper east side. You can stroll the intimate galleries at a leisurely pace and still see it all within 3-4 hours.

Great European collection. This is a great European collection. It's smaller than some around town, but the way that the works are displayed make for an intimate display. The only issue I had was that one work that I was hoping to see wasn't on display. Not uncommon in museums, but still regrettable.
Do not miss this one!. Beautiful museum with amazing art work. What an exciting piece of history here. Frick Collection is a timeless treasure not to miss

A must see!. Love the Frick-- it's a quaint museum (in comparison to the other NYC giants). It has a lot of great history and is unique compared to other museums as it is a preserved home. It's great because they have Rembrandts but also lesser known artists, in addition to sculptures and rotating exhibits. I love the courtyard in the center.
Unmissable. This is one of the best art collections in New York. It is a private collection in the original house which adds to the unique nature of the collection.

Unique paintings in a palatial Fifth Ave. Mansion. It has some of the most beautiful Rembrandts in the world, exqusite Vermeers and at least one Piero della Francesca and a Giovanni Bellini that I always return to see. The cadre is beautiful. The robber barons knew how to live!

A quiet retreat!. Once inside the beautiful House/Museum, all the hustle and noise of NYC disappears and you are surrounded by low lights, the sounds of trickling fountains and a beautiful art collection!
Small and cozy. It's like visiting the home of a Fortune 500 host. Lovely exhibits, small and manageable. The permanent collection, surrounded by elegant furniture, is always a treat.

Robber Baron Art (and worth the visit). Henry Clay Frick was, depending upon your point of view, either a "titan of industry," or the "coal czar" that exploited workers, broke strikes by hiring mercenaries to bust some heads, and was the stereotypical "robber baron" . . . but he had great taste in Art.The Frick Collection is in his former home, which was planned from the beginning to become a museum after his death. But it IS a home, and it's remarkable to see such incredible works of art as they were originally placed during his lifetime, when it was a home. We're talking paintings, of course, but also gorgeous furniture, porcelains, sculpture and more. Very impressive, and well worth the visit!

A wonderful place - don't miss it. Unlike many galleries and museums in NY, the Frick is on a human scale. You can get round it all in a morning. And the staff are so helpful! - just don't take any photos except in the lovely garden court (you don't need to). It's the former home of Henry Clay Frick, a NY industrialist who collected superb art works by .... I give up. Just see the list at http://www.frick.org/collection/works_on_display . Wonderfully displayed, with the rooms much as they were when the Frick family lived there.The opposing portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell glaring at each other across a fireplace are stunning. Just go there!
Stupendous collection. What a great "little" museum. The setting is lovely and interesting in itself. The collection is magnificent. Not to be missed.
Annual visit. Love this small, eclectic museum with wonderful collection of pictures, furniture, etc. Enjoy the audio tour. Sometimes catch a lecture. There's always something new.

A pintsized firecracker of a museum. I have been to the Frick a few times over the years and it never ceases to delight. As many reviewers have stated, it is located across an entire block in a private mansion. Henry Clay Frick was an extraordinary man whose business acumen enabled him to assemble a collection of great distinction. There are a few paintings and objets d'art that are not to my taste (and not always of the greatest quality) but, pound for pound, this is one of the finest small museums in the world and highly recommended. It is on a par with the Uffizi in Florence which, though magnificent, is housed in a former palace and lacks some of the intimacy and personality of the Frick I was interested to note, amidst the drooling appreciation of so many visitors, that the Helman family in San Rafael were so underwhelmed by the Frick. I would be curious to hear which museums induced rapture in them. Perhaps they might like to wander round the Frick a second time with me in tow! I could fly over from London to perambulate across the collection with them and others besides. There is so much to savour and chew on at the Frick rather than consume whole. Moreover, there is a pleasure in sharing the pleasure of others even if It does not always accord with your own. As it happens, I composed an article a few years ago, entitled Day Trip, about an afternoon at the Frick that gives a more considered view of the overall experience. I wrote it when I was in NYC on business so do please let me know if you would like me to send a copy to get a better idea of where I am coming from and, indeed, where I may be going. All comments welcome, whether good, bad or indifferent!

Wonderful Collection. The Frick is fun to visit because of the quality of its collection and the fact that it is not so large that it overwhelms the visitor. There is a free audio tour which adds so much to the visit. It is well worth a visit.

A very personal gallery. Small enough to be enjoyed, big enough to be worth the visit and of wonderful quality this collection of Art is simply wonderful. Don't go if you only like modern art, if however you appreciate more traditional efforts its simply a must.

Easy and not overwhelming!. This fabulous gem of a musuem is located in a neighborhood across the street from Central Park. Easy to access and easily accomplished from beginning to end in about 3 hours. Great for seniors, as there is not much walking. Beautiful courtyard to take a break and take some photos. This is the only place where photography is allowed. Cute gift shop and compilmentary coat check. There are a few Masters spread throughout the museum - quite impressive!

Get Lost in One Man's Art Obsession. This is a rare collection that could never be re-created in that the cost and availability of similar works of art today would be near impossible - 3 Vermeers, 2 Holbeins, Rembrant's including one of his best high period merchant portraits and one of the best late period self portraits, Turners, Titians, Whistlers, etc, etc. It's a perfect art afternoon. Excellent audio guide is free with admission.
The best of European art. Haven't been there? Like art? Must see. There is no better small-medium collection of important paintings in the country.

Do not miss this gallery. In the early 1900's, Mr Frick put together one of the worlds finest art collections imaginable. All the paintings by several masters as well as sculptures, porcelain pieces, tapastries and furniture are housed in his beautiful mansion. Both serious and casual art lovers will enjoy browsing this small intimate gallery.

Self-guided tour. My wife and I were walking along the east side of Central Park on May 7th, heading to the Metropolitan Museum when we discovered the home of Henry Clay Frick and the Frick collection. We had limited time and were somewhat daunted by the thought of the Metropolitan Museum. The self-guided tour of the Frick collection was the perfect solution. He has a wonderful collection of paintings and sculptures by Old Mastersas well as period antique furniture pieces. We spent 2 hours taking in as much as we could before we had to leave. This was 2 hours well spent admiring the works of the various artists in his collection. The home that houses these masterpieces is amazing as well.I recommend this tour.
Small art collection. Unless you are a true art afficionado, skip this one. It's a small collection of art in a former mansion. Not too exciting

Wow!. We have done a few museums lately and this was the perfect match with the Guggenheim today...every room was full, but it was a home! Unimaginable the joy it must have been to live here. You can stare out if the window and imagine you were there...well if the security guards let you! I understand they have an important job..but they take it far too seriously. We went on a day when you could choose what you pay..standard $20 each..which is worth it..Rembrants, Constables Abound..marvellous...and you can sketch in the gardens on Sunday's..lovely

If you like art, you must visit the Frick at least once. My sister-in-law is an artist and always encouraged me to visit the Frick. I lived near NYC for 6 years, but, always had a baby or toddler to look after and the Frick does not allow such young visitors. Therefore, I was never able to get there. I moved away, but, recently was able to visit with my mom without any of my kids. My top priority was to get to the Frick. We went and it was well worth the wait. The house itself is beautiful. I especially loved the library which has special leather mats across all the rows and rows of books to keep the dust off- clever guy that Frick! The art was amazing- as others have said, not a huge collection (I had just been to the Louvre, so I was tough to impress), but, very well-selected and well-maintained. There was no photography allowed in the galleries, but, I was able to take some nice pictures of my mother in the center courtyard which is a very nicely manicured mini garden. Fantastic gift shop with all manner of books and gifts for art lovers. Overall, it was a very pleasant use of an afternoon in Manhattan.
Interesting. The property is beautiful. The art inside as well, includes paintings of El Greco, Renoir, Velazquez. I'll come back to visit the library, heard that is just as cool.

Wonderful as always. A visit to New York without a visit to the Frick is very nearly unthinkable. The collection is really excellent, and the gallery is small enough that you don't get exhausted, as you easily can in the Metropolitan Museum. The paintings, sculptures, and porcelain in the Frick are all of very high quality. The three Vermeers make it particularly worthwhile, but there are lots of other splendid works. This time I revisited Holbein's Thomas Cromwell more than once, hard to resist while "Wolf Hall" is on stage and on TV.
Amazing. The best of the best. Not a huge collection - but every piece is extraordinary - Audio tour (headset) is well done and worth the extra few dollars.
Amazing Museum. This is a must to visit when saying in NYC. Not seen such high end collection in many countries. Fee is 20 USD but this is really worth it.

Stunning. I visited the Frick Collection on a cool,cloudy day. I expected crowds but I was pleasantly surprised that it wasn't at all like the Metropolitan Museum. The collection is nothing short of stunning. Set in the Frick mansion, the collection is displayed thoughtfully and beautifully. Nothing short of a masterpiece. Rembrandt, Renoir, El Greco,Goya to name a few noted artists whose works are displayed. Impressive display of Limoges enamels. There is a $25 admission. Discounts for Seniors and students. They are currently featuring a Don Quixote installation of engravings and tapestries. Small children are not allowed!Highly Recommend.

Worth a visit whilst in New York. The Frick Collection is housed in a lovely old mansion and all the art work and furniture are well displayed. The interior garden is lovely and a nice place to spend a few minutes of reflection on all the treasures of the Frick Collection.
Lovely museum. This museum transports you to a different place. This man collected the best painting and has a Versailles like mansion in Manhattan!Beautiful, you have to go!

An amazing collection of old world masters. A great way to see some of the world's greatest paintings in a beautiful 1900 mansion. Collection is not overwhelming, so you can see everything in a couple of hours. Very professional and friendly security staff. Highly recommended for anyone interested in great art.

Well Worth a Visit. Interesting art collection in a lovely old townhouse with charming interior garden (with benches). Frick's collection includes many not-to-be missed masterpieces by the likes of Rembrandt, Turner, Whistler, Titian ,Ingres, Vermeer, etc. etc.. Paintings are scattered rather idiosyncratically, in a home-like fashion that adds to the charm, e.g. don't miss the little back room with the late Medieval/early Renaissance Italian works, stuck over near the furniture and frilly French chamber decorations. The Frick also sometimes has fantastic special exhibits. On the downside: admission is expensive, it's often overcrowded, and some staff members are not particularly friendly. Still - don't miss it.
Must See. The Frick Collection is not to be missed! You can spend a short time or a long time viewing the collection. There's something for everyone.

Classic museum/mansion. The Frick collection is a bit eclectic, and accurately represents the style of collections from the early 20th century. There are a variety of styles represented in sculpture and painting. There are also some tapestries. The house itself is a work of art, with many elegant fixtures and details. A very manageable size for perusing good art. The audioguides are free with admission.

Best classic museum in US?. Located in an old mansion along the 5th Ave, this beautiful museum shows master pieces in a traquil and peaceful environment. Walk around, take a break, look at the Movies offered.

Breathtakingly lovely museum for those who don't love museums. Stroll through the the Frick Mansion and you can almost imagine being a guest there. The audio guide is very well done. This is a perfect outing if you don't have a lot of time to devote to one of the larger museums.

Small and intimate, good art, home setting. I love this art museum. Lovely and quiet - unlike the bustle of the other larger museums. Only set back is there is not cafe - go to the Asian art museum near by for a nice lunch, or any of the coffee shops in the area.

Vermeer and the Camera Oscura. so you heard of how Vermeer used the Camera Oscura to facilitate translating our three-dimensional perspective into a two-dimensional painting (the Camera Oscura being a intermediate step before the development of microscopes, another instrument changing how we view the world). One of his paintings (other than the woman with the pearl earring) is here at the Frick - showing a red caped officer in the foreground facing a young woman.The Frick is full of such surprises. Also a member of the National Association of Museums, check whether you have reciprocal privileges!

Stunning building with eclectic art collection. A smallish, 12 room, museum based in what was once a family home - although extended when it became a museum. Opposite Central Park amongst the tall buildings it is a small oasis. One man's collection - added to after his death - randomly displayed in lovely rooms. Gives a flavour of what being very very rich must have been like!

Grandiose Mansion - Wealthy lifestyle - Thank you Mr. Frick..... Henry Clay Frick used his fortune to collect art and turn his lavish home into a beautiful museum. It does have the feel of a private home , filled with the furniture and tapestries..The Old Masters is the main reason to visit of course.The very peaceful and quiet ambience allows for the most enjoyment of all the treasures.It is interesting that they planned all along to turn their home into a museum after their death, for others to enjoy.Way to go Mr. Frick ! :)I visited once before, when we lived in Manhattan, and it was definitely worth it to return Don't hesitate ... take a partner on a date - yes it is romantic, or just take a moment to escape the hustle and bustle off the city. Look out of the window- you will be rewarded with a beautiful view of Central Park....

Ab Fab!. This an outstanding, manageable collection of premier pieces, just outstanding, set in a Gilded Age mansion across from the park. Grounds are lovely and the inside garden/pond is amazing. Furniture, decorative art, tapestries all work. And don't miss the short video on the founding of the Frick Collection!
Decent Art Collection. Lovely art collection in an old mansion. Everything is beautifully restored & the collection of art is impressive.

Quaint Museum. This one is not to be missed. Only need an hour or so to wander through this fabulous home, enjoying the maginificent artworks while being transported back to yesteryear.A great experience, and one to stir the senses.

DO NOT MISS. What a gem this museum is. The building is something in itself to see how the wealthy lived. The art is a lovely collecltion. You are given audio guides so you learn so much. I just wish the guards knew something about the museum to also share.
Great Art at the Frick. Wonderful fifth Avenue mansion filled with "old masters" work. Friendly and helpful staff. Takes about an hour

One of the most intimate art museums. This home, still in most of its original setting and its artwork are truly a lovely, must see experience for those who enjoy experiencing the history, the experience of the uber-wealthy, and the beauty of art from Europe's great masters. We spend 3 wonderful hours.

Hidden gem. The Frick is one of my favorite art museums anywhere in the world. A private and varied collection in a beautiful mansion house just east of Central Park. It has a very intimate feel but try to go early before it gets too busy and don't bother with the free entry days as the queues go around the block.

Building itself was fantastic but expected more..... Architecturally the museum is quite beautiful and we ( my husband and I ) got just about as much if not more from the building itself than from the entire contents of the museum...really expected more..

Amazing concentration of art. This museum probably has less than 10% of what is in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but it is still well worth visiting. There has obviously been a lot of thought put into the collection--something even a philistine like myself can recognize. I left with a feeling of satisfaction as though I'd just finished a great meal! It's definitely a jewel.
Fabulous stunning collection of old masters.. Such special space to house these amazing works of art...well worth a visit. Then stroll along the road to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Wonderful Experience. What a great way to spend a couple of hours. Make sure you watch the 10 minute video that is played in the music room. I usually skip these but this one was just about 10 minutes and very informative and interesting. Really nice exhibits and the building itself is pretty incredible too.

Classic Architecture and Interesting Collection. The Frick is very convenient if you are staying uptown and if you have been to the Met and MOMA and are looking for a different sort of museum experience, the Frick is great. The ambience is more like a tour of an old home with amazing European paintings from primarily the 19th century. Particularly noteworthy for those who enjoyed the film "Mr. Turner" are three of his works that were shown in the film.
Small but excellent collection.. Highly recommended. Great collection. Disappointed that we couldn't take photos. They have 4 Vermeers and many Rembrants. World class.
Amazing art. Great concentration of classic works of art. I you are in to the impressionists or modern art this is not your kind of place

Wonderful Collection. We arrived at the opening and found it a great time to experience the museum. The collection is outstanding and the free audio guide explains the story of Henry Clay Frick and his passion for art. Don't miss it!

If you don't have much time or patience. To visit a museum in 2 hours and leave satisfied is very rare, and you can do it in the Frick Collection. It has a beautiful collection and the mansion itself is pretty impressive. It doesn't overwhelm us to much though, as the Met and the Louvre. You can pass from room to room with ease and time to admire the paintings, sculptures and tapestry.

A must see in NYC. I have had the pleasure of living in New York City for many years and I count each day of them as a blessing. One of the most incredible hidden treasures of the city is the Frick. The collection is incredible and the home is stunning, a little bit of old NYC. Please take the timetoviit sit when your re in our incredible city.

We all should live like this!. A fantastic term of the century 19th to 20th) mansion chock full of great art. Mr. ( &/or) Mrs, Frick certainly had a good eye for art--or for people with a good eye-- the Turners alone are worth a trip or two, The house is great too. Don't delay because the planned renovation will probably disruptive to some extent no matter the good intentions. If you support your local art institution, flash your membership card it might help with the significant fees. There are some very interesting programs if you plan ahead.
Beautiful mansion, great collection. It is a must to visit this great mansion with its stunning interiors filled with magnificent pieces of art.

Almost everyone that goes through this incredible collection walks away in awe!. The collection in display in this residence is truly incredible. Beautifully organized, the rooms are all filled with breathtaking masterpieces. The personal electronic guides offered pull in both the historical and artistic points for each piece displayed, The most common exclamation was "WOW!".

If you don't have enough time for the Met.... This is a beautiful museum mansion, housing an array of masterpieces and offering rotating special exhibits. If you're looking for something manageable with a two hour (or more) window, the Frick is a must. And if you can, share what you know about this notorious Robber Baron. It will definitely pique the interests of younger visitors.

A must see if you're an art lover.. this art collection is stunning! There's everything from Goldsbrough to Turner and Holbein to name a few, all in their original positions when the owner Henry Frick was alive. Most of the paintings are numbered so I would advise that you pick up an audio set as you go in, that way you will learn about the paintings etc, there's also a small auditorium where you can find out the history of the collection and museum.

a little gem.... ...nestled along the Park. Definitely worth a visit. Mr Frick was a visionary (at least) as far as collecting art and sharing it with the puiblic goes. Beautiful building, lovely collection, great display.
Just the right amount of Culture. Fascinating building and collection. Rally nice free electronic tour guide. Nice change of pace from the Met.
Beautiful!. The museum itself is a work of art. The collection was breathtaking. We went on Sun so we could make a contribution instead of ticket price. Helped out a teensy bit on expenses

Beautiful Place to Visit. The Frick has a wonderful collection but do keep in mind that it is not particularly large and can be very pricey for a family. I love Dutch Masters so it was a must for me but if I were taking the whole family and had limited time it might be one I would skip.

A peaceful oasis in NYC. I loved everything about the Frick Collection. It is a great art collection in the former home of Henry Frick. They offer an audio guide free of charge. Entrance was $20. I recommend viewing the short video in the music room.

Exquisite!. We visited the Frick following a recommendation from a NY based friend and, of all the museums or galleries we visited during our nine day trip, this was our absolute favourite. The mansion itself is stunning and the artwork just incredible. Every time you thought you had seen the 'star' attraction there was another even more amazing piece awaiting your attention.

must-see museum. The collection of paintings on exhibit in the Frick Collection is exquisite - and the three paintings by Vermeer in the collection would be worth a visit on their own. On top of it, all these masterpieces are displayed in beautiful rooms and salons. Have been there on several occasions and never tire of visiting again.....

Great Art in a Great Home. The Frick is one of New York's hidden gems. If you go just to see the architecture you will be satisfied. It takes you back to another era. Now that they have redone the museum it flows even better. You must go to see the classics that are on exhibit.

Nothing less than Excellent!. Long time since the last visit to this exquisite place. What a nice place to stay and to visit!Located at 71 st with Central Park East (5th avenue), the neighborhood is quite beautiful.You pay 20 bucks to admission. Museum is not a big one, have a human size, you can visit it in about 2 hours.A lot of Masterpieces in the walls and the furniture is great! There you can see Holbein (Thomas More and Crommwell portraits), El Greco, Bellini's St. Francis in the Desert, the Fragonnard room, and many, many others. Fine sculptures, like Houdon's Diana... and the decoration is superbe.Not many people around there, so it is quite fine and relaxing to be there.One of the best places to visit in NYC, do not miss it!
For Art Lovers. An exceptional private collection of paintings by renowned artists. Beautiful rooms and display and a wonderful gift shop!

Wonderful collection art in an intimate environment. Frick collection is a great museum with a very intimate environment. I love the way artwork is displayed. It is a great way to spend an afternoon stroll in an amicable way.It is a hidden gem in the crowded NYC museums!

One Very Special Museum. This is one which is often overlooked. Located in a Grand Mansion on the East Side. Filled with magnificent masterpieces.The atmosphere and art blend together beautifully. A special place which is not on the list for everyone who goes to NYC! Don't miss it!

This is my favorite gallery in NYC. I have been coming to this place since 1975 when I was a student in NYC. This is a wonderful house appointed with very exquisite furnishings and paintings. You can spend one hour or three, but you will not be sorry that you came to visit this mansion.

Two museums in one!. The Frick is double the fun because not only is the Collection stupendous, but the house itself is worth the price of admission. In fact, some of the artwork actually is part of the house. There are some lovely paintings done right on the walls in some rooms. The rest of the collection speaks for itself, and I'm sure everyone will have several favorite artists and works of art. In addition to the "wall art", I loved the mouldings and the (sort of) hidden pipe organ, although the upstairs was closed. The courtyard is also very special and a great place to take a break. The Frick remains one of our favorite stops.

A beautiful old friend. This Collection makes you feel that you are wandering around someone's home and noticing the art of the walls - wait, that is exactly what you are doing. Brilliant docents, Vemeers and many other treasure.

Always a delight to visit. This collection in a "home" setting is marvelous and extensive.
The old masters are displayed so that you can 'get up close' and really enjoy the art work. The special exhibits are small but choice.
Wow. If you want to know how the other half lived, visit the Frick and you will see opulence beyond belief. And there are a few old pictures hanging on the wall, a Vermeer here, a Vermeer there.
Outstanding. Elegant and precious....an amazing assemblage of first rate paintings in a Beautiful space! Easy to drink in all the masterworks available

Foresight and Style. Henry Clay Frick was born in rural Pennsylvania, of humble beginnings and with almost no formal education.
