However, he had the perspicacity to be an early investor in coke (necessary for the huge amounts of steel the Industrial revolution will require). This made him millionaire by the age of thirty. His business association with Andrew Carnegie increased even further his wealth, but brought him also a lot of grief: he is credited with a prompt and efficient breakup of the Homestead steel strike, which did not make him the Darling of labor. This, as well as his relationship with Carnegie going sour, convinced him to leave Pittsburgh (where his former house, Clayton, is a wonderful museum today, see separate review) and move to New York City. He purchased the entire block between 70-71st and Fifth & Madison and vowed to make Carnegie’s mansion on 91st St “look like a miner’s shack”. Already a collector of fine art, he hired Hastings (of New York Public Library fame) to design a Beaux Arts building and got personally involved with every step of the design and architecture of his future home. When he died, he left his mansion, his collection and a $15 million endowment for the museum to acquire future art.  Whether you like or not Mr. Frick’s taste (portraits and landscapes), you will admire his mansion, its intricate woodwork details, the floors, the unobtrusiveness of books, the harmonious co-existence of paintings, decoration, architectural elements and sculptures. There is an introductory video in the Music room about the collection. Currently, there is also a short movie about the Coypel illustrations of Don Quixote and several of the tapestries created after those illustrations. Admission is $20, well worth it. Tuesday to Friday there is a docent talk at 1PM in the courtyard (the only place where photography is allowed).
Amazing. My favorite museum of the 5 i visited in NY. Quiet and intimate and boy did this chap and his wife have great taste!!!

Great variety in a small museum!. Part of the joy of visiting this former private home is imagining what it might have been like to live surrounded by such beautiful things. Also, if you're a fan of Wolf Hall, these folks have Holbein's portraits of More and Cromwell.

Stunning in every possible way. A fine selection of paintings and sculptures surrounded by a magnificent residence in the upper east side. It's an art collection based on the British and French styles that match perfectly with the architecture of the house. It's the perfect place to go if you want to avoid the tourists of the MET and MOMA but without giving up the classic and nice tastes of been located on the fifth avenue. Sadly the second floor is not open to the public but it doesn't make your visit less enjoyable. Take your time to visit this place because you'll want to hear the audio guide trough all the mansion for its important information and funny quotes! Totally worth it!!!!

The Best of the Best. This museum is home to stunning masterpieces by the the world's best known artists. It is truly the best of the best in a beautiful setting. The Rembrandt self-portrait at the Frick is magnificent and worth the price of admission all by itself. It is sitting in the same room as wonderful paintings by Ver Meer, Velasquez, Turner and many others. In many cases the Masterpieces are hung right next to each other so you barely have to move to see the next one. The Renaissance collection is wonderful, without travelling to Florence.Oh, and by the way you may want to look in on the Hans Holbein portrait of Sir Thomas More- I kept going back to view it several times on my visit. To say Mr. Frick had superb artistic taste is an understatement!

Perhaps my favorite museum in the world!. This is a must see. I've been four times in the past year. I went once with my 18 year old and once with my 22 year old. Even in this era of smartphones and video games, they LOVED it! So why is it perhaps my favorite, on a par with the Louvre? The art was selected by Frick because they were masterpieces - but also pleasing to the eye and in concert with the room. Well done Henry! Also, various styles, artists, and genres are mixed in each room. You can see it all in a couple hours, the temporary exhibits have all been great, and the audio tour is a must.You just get the most amazing, yet indescribable feeling when you visit.

Do Not Miss the Frick Collection!. If you don't get to see any other museums in New York, make sure you get to see this one. It is exquisite. Mr. Frick's taste was sophisticated and I am so thankful I got to see his collection which is generously shared with the public. Incredible artists are featured, like Turner, VanDyck, Titian, Vermeer, Gainsborough, El Greco and Degas among others. I loved the home and the various rooms filled with exotic art. We went on a Sunday and paid what we could which is wonderful for budget-minded travelers. I highly, highly recommend this museum. (No photography allowed other than in the Garden Court.)

A Gem. This is the biggest, grandest former residence left on Fifth Ave., right across from the park on 71 St. It's a $20 admission fee, except from 11 am (opening) to 1 pm on Sundays, when you get to give what you would like to give for your entry fee. Go first to the indoor garden, which is a calm respite from the noise and bustle of the city. It's classic design, beautiful plants and fountains are a wonder for the busy city. Then on to the galleries, where there are the best classic paintings around, all placed in a gorgeous home, with vases, urns and furniture complementing the spectacular paintings. The Frick also has a beautiful garden, and it also has whole rooms taken from European castles. They sometimes have concerts here in the evenings. If you have a deep interest in art, they also have a world-class art library next door, where you can do your scholarly work.

stunning - intimate and beautiful. The Frick was recommended to me by a colleague. Perhaps it's just a little out of the way on the Upper E. side if you like to hang out in midtown, but well worth the walk and also near the Guggenheim and the metropolitan museum of art. It's home turf for several long established and new galleries, so there are lots of reasons to wander and if you go, don't miss the Frick.It's an eclectic collection but it was the paintings that took my breath away along with the fact that it really does feel intimate, almost like visiting someone's home, albeit a very luxurious and exceptional one. And that's what it was in the first place. The whole collection is beautifully curated to maintain that intimate feel.If you do nothing else, find Renoir's La Promenade and the beautiful Vermeers. They alone are worth the entry fee.

Small but stunning. A true gem. The building itself is a work of art, enhancing the experience of viewing such significant works. A testament to the good that financial/industrial magnates can do when focusing on what is best and beautiful about human endeavors. Excellent.

Slow show. This was a new museum experience while in New York this time, and it was a lovely collection. You could walk and view at your own pace or with an audio explanation. You could see the art displayed closely-and the frock home displays it in a personal way. I was disappointed that no photography was allowed, but I understood, as it is a private collection. In a little over an hour we saw everything available, and children under ten, (under 16!?! would probably be quickly bored. It was a nice view-but the $20 each was a little pricey for an hour of looks.
Special place. A very special museum. Frick was Andrew Carnegie's partner and VERY rich. A window to how the very rich lived!
A gem!. The best thing about the Frick collection is that it is a manageable size, you can do all of it. We went on a Sunday and that is the pay what you want day, double bonus!

An quiet oasis of small art museum.. The Frick Collection is housed in the exquisite mansion of the late industrialist Henry Frick. The permanent exhibition is primarily old European masters and fine furniture. In addition temporary exhibitions are organized.This is the perfect relaxed getaway for art lovers on Upper East. This is not huge like the Metropolitan Museum of Art or MOMA, but more intimate. I do recommend to take the time to enjoy this tranquil museum.The audio guide is very good.

Really worth a visit. Finally made it to the Frick and can't understand why I had not visited earlier. The art, furnishings and architecture of the building are all amazing especially when you consider it used to be a family home before it became a museum. It was a very enjoyable couple of hours on a cold day.

An absolute gem. The Frick Collection is housed in a private mansion on the corner of 5th Avenue and 70th Street. Beautifully decorated period rooms with an exceptional collection of paintings by British, Dutch, Italian and other masters, as well as a collection of Limoges enamels. Not to be missed!

An Absolute Gem. A gem that delights with its quality and variety- a superior collection refreshingly displayed in a very navigable mansion-turned-museum! Paintings by the greats, in all rooms, free of genre compartmentalization, exquisite porcelains from Sevres and China, a library of impeccable books, dazzling furniture. The history of each item is as fascinating as the experience of viewing it.The breadth and dynamism of this lovely museum are worth every lingering moment.
Oasis in the concrete jungle.. Central Park never disappoints. I have seen it at all seasons and in mid April it's as breathtaking as ever. Clean, quiet and tranquil. Definitely worth a visit.

Great setting for great art. Vermeer. Of course the Frick has so much more to offer, but start here. The beautiful indoor fountain is a place to rest and reflect. The most intimate great art space in New York.
Amazing. Cultural oasis. Amazing collection. A great collection of Old Masters collected by one man to showcase his home.
Emma. Who would have thought that a failed assassination attempt would result in one of the top private art collections in the world?

A Quiet Getaway for Art Lovers. The Frick is a particular destination for art lovers. Located just off of Fifth Avenue in New York, it houses Whistler to Turner to Goya to Rembrandts. I used to go there after school just for quiet time and to immerse myself in the great collection of former industrialist, Henry Clay Frick. Its a gorgeous house and a world class collection that warrants a visit by any gallery/museum lover.

Excellent. There is a collection that has been decorated mansion of industrialist Henry flick When walk north from MoMA. Here is a mansion of perfect atmosphere to appreciate the graceful European painting of the 18th century. It is a museum drifting NY classic mood.
Not too big, but great works. This isn't a mega museum, but the art is excellent. The audio tour is very informative and free. They might not let children in, at least I didn't see any.
Worth a visit. Superb selection of paintings in wonderful setting. Reminded me a bit of the Wallace Collection in London.
Museum To See. Everyone goes to the Met and MOMA. Go to the Frick for a more intimate museum that has great quality art.

Fantastic Frick. I managed to deposit my husband & son at some nearby shops & take a walk to the Frick Collection. It's a lovely collection, and not such a big museum that it takes up hours of your day, if you are short of time. Lovely staff, happy to have a chat with you, obviously they really like where they work as very informative. Fascinating story - well worth a visit.
A must!!. A must!! The art is unbelievable. The furniture and decorations are beautiful just go!!!! don't take kids under 10 though
A little gem. So cool to see art in a mansion displayed as in a home, but what a home. To see a Renoir in an alcove by the stairs! The quality of the works is stunning, especially the vermeers
Excellent art gallery. Well worth a visit. It is far more manageable than the huge Met! The audio guide is good, explains the paintings well without rambling. It is a very impressive collection

Small (not the house) and Beautiful. Two things make the visit at the Frick collections recommended. First it has some fine arts and paintings, in amount that average person can really look and observe there details in one visit (not like the other magnificent hotels in New York, that you need several days in order to be able to see all what they have to offer). The second is the house itself. It is very interesting (at least for me it was) to see the house, the design etc.
Manageable collection. Considering the size, it should not take that long to zip through, yet every time I go, I saunter. The walls are especially impressive but I most love the center courtyard.

Best museum in New York. This is an amazing collection of art in a beautiful home of a steel tycoon. He just loved art and collected it. He built this beautiful home in order to house it and have it as a museum eventually. Absolutely doesn't disappoint. My favourite museum in the city.

small but fantastic collection. They have a free audio guide and you can wander the galleries at your own pace. They have 3 Vermeers as well as a Velasquez on display (along with many many other wonderful works)!

Private home with a BIG Surprise. Want to see great art in a small intimate setting? The Frick should be your first stop not your last. For a small fee, you will be provided an audio guide and a relaxed atmosphere to enjoy some of the most wonderful pieces of art that you have only seen in books. OR, you can take advantage of the free tours. It appears that Mr. Henry Clay Frick was a collector of the finest and built his home to display his masterpieces. No children under ten and groups are schedules.
Quaint Museum. Loved the Frick Museum. Beautiful pieces of art. The building has beautiful wood work inside. There is charm here and not to big, so it's not overwhelming. Great to do in a 1/2 day.
The Mansion of Art. Small, but great collection. Not to be missed. Great location off Park Avenue near the Met and Central Park.
Great collection. Loved seeing the Frick collection - good audio guide and helpful staff. Beautiful rooms and not too busy.

Unwelcoming and rude. I arrived here with my wife and three girls on April 9th at 4pm and had a really bad experience. This is our first visit to the USA and this was our first museum visit of the trip. It was only 40 degrees fahrenheit outside but the welcome inside was colder than that. We had been looking forward to it and I had been telling my girls about Holbein, Turner and Vermeer. We are from the UK and so Holbein and Turner are particularly interesting for us because of how these works are so deeply entwined with our history. At the door the sign said that children under 10 are not permitted. We had never seen a rule like this before in any gallery so we were a bit bemused. Two of the girls are 14 and 12, and the third is 10 in May this year - next month. Assuming that the rule is there to avoid screaming toddlers, and anyway considering 10 is her closest birthday by far, we didn't think it would be a problem. Wrong! The problem wasn't just that they applied the rule, it was the way they did it. Children who are a little bit small for their age tend to be self-conscious about it. For a male security guard to look her up and down and loudly proclaim his disdain for her size and accuse my wife and I of lying to him in front of other visitors, was a terrible introduction to the United States for us. Children should be encouraged to think of fine art as something that is remote, snobbish and inaccessible. An impressionable young child will not forget an experience like this, and an institution like the Frick has a responsibility not to damage the image of the art world in this way. We never saw the collection, and I suppose we won't now.

Outstanding. one of the best experiences I have had in a gallery. Liken it to the Wallace collection in London in that it is the collection housed in the home of the collector. Wow the Rubén's portrait of Sir Thomas Moore and Cromwell were thought provoking, Wolf Hall and all. Loved it and will revisit whenever in NYC.
Weekend in NYC. This was my second visit to The Frick . You will be amazed, the home and art! On Sundays you get in free, so go early!
Good collection go on Sundays!! free entrance. I like the architecture of this building, big and well presented art collection, I'm not an art expert so not going to comment about.Worth the visit!!

Uplifting. The Frick is a must-see for anyone interested in visiting an elegant mansion filled with gorgeous art. The setting is perfect; right across from Central Park in the upper east side. A beautiful New York City experience.

Amazing. In addition to the superb collection of masterpieces (paintings, sculptures, ceramics, tapestry, etc.), what makes the Frick Collection really amazing is the setting: a beautiful Italian style villa on Fifth Avenue with a great view of Central Park. It probably added to the romantic atmosphere that I visited while NY was covered in snow. The art is carefully placed and several rooms have maintained the original setting from when Mr Frick was alive. I highly recommend a visit.

Rude staff who think they are superiour to the tourists!. Coming from Britain, where stately homes are ten a penny, I felt that the staff thought they were superior to all the tourists, and our party was treated like children. One security guard/tour guide tried to smack the back of the hand of someone who was in our party. Apart from the rude staff, it was just a big house, but in the grand scheme of things, as its on 5th Avenue it just looks out of place. I wouldn't stop the taxi to visit there if I was you. I had just visited the Guggenheim and stopped here before we did the MOMA, both of those were much better and well worth it.

Great architecture and well laid out. I am not a fan of the "classics", but I enjoyed this old house turned into a museum. The architecture is really amazing as well as the volumes of sketch books from Rembrandt and other important artists. The wooden chests are amazing with their detailed carvings. This place is well laid out and was not crowded. Unlike the Wallace collection in London, it's elegant but subdued. Well done!!

Spectacular. Located adjacent to central park, this wonderful museum has the highest density of old masters in North America. Titian, Rembrandt, vermeer, Monet, Renoir... the good stuff! Set in this beautiful home one feels like we are visiting these great collectors. Make sure and take a docent tour and use the free audio guide. 2-4 hours.

The building itself rivals the art inside. A gem near the Met, not to be missed. An beautiful mansion transformed into an intimate museum with an outstanding collection of old masters. Avoid Sunday when admission is voluntary, crowded. Pay a few bucks during the week & enjoy. Put aside a few hours, you won't regret it.

A rare museum in a private home. This is a rare treat of beautiful high quality art set in intimate private home. The permanent collection is outstanding and the special exhibits are remarkable. One can make a reservation to enter the museum at a set time.

Unmissable Collection. One of the finest collections and a wonderful experience. No visit to New York is complete without a visit to the Frick collection with its superb works of art and the quiet and elegant setting for them.

some great paintings. Half a dozen rooms with some great paintings painted by famous artists ,however don't think you are going to see a time warp of a very wealthy mans private home you will be disappointed, all the furniture and things that make a home are all gone ,its just a painting gallery on a small scale with a entrance fee of $20.i supposed living in the UK I've been spoilt by the magnificent

Don't miss the Frick!. We were so glad this had been recommended to us by friends as we might have missed it otherwise. The house is stunning and the collection is amazing. It's a really lovely way to see art which feels much more personal than visiting a typical museum. We especially loved the Holbein paintings of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell. There is an excellent audio guide provided which provides interesting commentary on the rooms and paintings.

The Frick rocks!. Nose to nose with some of the greatest artists in the world. Compared to other NY museums this one is relatively intimate and easy to navigate. Up close and personal with these magnificent works of art. Best way to work the Frick....walk around each room, noting everything. Then go back through the room and linger at each item, whether it's art or decorative or furniture. Your appreciation of everything will expand exponentially.

Dont miss this wonderful art collection. The Frick Collection is based overlooking Central Park in a building which was designed to become a museum after the death of the owner. It was designed with taste and with an eye to commercialism which sit well together. A very varied art collection and the free tour was worth attending. Try a walk in Central Park afterwards, just to finish the day.
Frick collection visit. They were some really nice bronze sculptures on display. They were also 2 beautiful Turner paintings in one of rooms. These were the high light of the visit for me.

Adorable. Beautiful place. The building in itself is great, architecture and style. The art collection is impressive. Huge names in painting... Well organized and friendly. Except kid adverse below the age of 10. And not clear to me why...

Breathtaking and Beautiful. An awe inspiring collection of art, statuary, icons and tapestries displayed beautifully in a glorious building. Set aside several hours, take advantage of the audio guide, and prepare to be transported.

I loved this museum.. I had seen some documentaries lately that included Henry Clay Frick so seeing his former New York home and art collection was amazing. The collection is intimate and easy to see in a couple of hours. Audio hand helds are available.
Often Missed but Great Place. See how the rich used to live when they still allowed visitors. Many people miss this museum but it is worth the visit.

Some fabulous paintings.. Lovely collection with several very famous paintings on display. Maybe abit dark, but I suppose this is in keeping with the exhibits Convenient location, on Museum Mile, with several other museums quite close. MY FAVOURITE AMONG THOSE is the Neue Gellerie. on Fifth Avenue on 86th Street.

Mr. Frick. Very nice collection. Liked the way it is presented and the serenity. only one toilet access... I didn't like the entrance... Too small if there are too many people... One might feel squeezed.
Lovely. Wonderfully sized museum with beautiful art that is well placed and spaced so one can enjoy each piece.

Museum with it's own sense of history. The permanent collection at the Frick is outstanding. The Don Quijote tapestries currently on exhibit are worth the visit just for themselves. The movie explaining the life of Henry Clay Frick is an interesting aspect of our history apart from the art collection. It is not so popular I think but well worth a visit.

Tour this early 20th century home with its historic architecture and Gothic and Renaissance art. If you enjoy touring historic homes and seeing major works of art, this is a must see museum. Mr. Frick's collection of art contains numerous pieces that are included in art history and art appreciation text books. The emphasis of this collection is on portraits. An audio tour is included in the admission and the visitor is able to select which works of art he or she would like to learn about by selecting the number adjacent to the work of art.

Stunning!. A beautiful period building - reminiscent of The wallace Collection in London - full of fabulous art, furniture, porcelain etc. Very knowledgeable and approachable staff and often free talks on the various collections from real experts. Not to be missed.

A little gem.... I've been visiting the Frick for many years and always enjoy their collection. It is particularly a fond place as I spent many afternoons working on projects in their garden when a I attended college in the city (many, many moons ago) and now I visit with our kids for wonderful, artsy afternoon after Central Park.

My Favorite Musem in NYC. Smaller than more popular museums but going to the Frick is a different experience. My favorite visit to the Frick? 1980s? The Faberge Collection. Still, it is a lovely museum that should not be overlooked when touring the arts.
This should be top of your list. An amazing museum and an outstanding collection of artwork. If this is the only museum you visit in NYC it would certainly be worth it

Our only art museum visit and a good one. This is a great collection and a really lovely museum. The fact that the collection is one individuals is interesting in itself. audio guide ( free with entry fee) worth having. A classy and really interesting morning.

What a gem!. Came with friends from CT and loved the fact that on Sundays between 11am to 1pm, you "pay" what you want. We made a donation and were shown the coat room......no coats in the galleries. What impressed me, was this was once a private residence and the library was my favorite room in the house. Lots of extravagance in most of the decor, but the art was outstanding. This is truly a hidden gem in the big city!Be aware that you can only take photos in the garden courtyard.
So Pleasant. Beautiful collection. Beautiful! Don't miss it. It really is that simple so go ahead and get your tickets now! Enjoy!
Picturesque museum. An small and picturesque museum, but it has the highest level of rich parts, allocated on a mansion with a interesting story behind.

Very interesting visits. It is a great museum, not far from Central Park and the Metropolitan museum.I have been there a few time; although I do not fancy classical styles, I have never regretted going back there.

HENRY DIED IN 1919, WIFE ADELAIDE DIED IN 1931, IN 1935, AFTER CONVERSIONS, - OPEN TO THE PUBLIC.. Daughter Helen Frick has added to Henry's collection, so that now one third of the present collection Henry would never have seen. Helen may lend out her additions, but Dad's do not leave the premises.In 1977 the building was further expanded, and again in 2011. These days about 300,000 sight seers view the Frick masterpieces annually. The 6 galleries also contain sculptures, ceramics, and beautiful French furniture.So if you have never seen a genuine Fragonard, El Greco, Vermeere, Goya or a Franz Hals; pay your money at the door and experience why people pay millions of dollars for some paint on a canvas, - in an expensive guilt frame.Brian, from Perth W. Australia.

Wonderful house. the house is really delightful and the art work he collected is presented within the lower level rooms just as he wanted it. You can get really close to the art work and there are some lovely pieces including the portrait of Oliver Cromwell and Cardinal Woseley. Well worth the visit and the covered garden area at the centre of the house gives you somewhere calm to retreat to when you ge tired.

Pay what you like Sundays 11-1!!. What a great spot. Had always wanted to do this and recently got a chance to go with my architecture loving husband. Something for everyone at this museum. Truly lovely. Just don't try to take a selfie - no photos allowed :(

One of my favorite museums in the world. This is a truly amazing collection, in a gem of a building. The whole experience is wonderful, and although I love the Met—just up the street—this the the museum I'll visit when I'm low on energy and need a relaxing and peaceful setting. Just sitting in the lily pond atrium is worth the entrance fee. The only sad things is that 1) They are not very artist friendly: no drawing with charcoal or painting with oils, inadequate seating in front of the works; 2) Henry Clay Frick built the collection on the backs of his under-paid workers and the thought of this always makes me a little sad...and my grandmother's family was from Johnstown, PA, so the South Fork Fishing and Hunting Club—of which Frick was a member—and its culpability in the flood of 1889 probably looms larger for me than it will for most visitors.

Does not admit children!. It's a fab place to visit but be warned the Frick does not admit children under 10. This information is buried deep on the website so easily missed. I suggested I take the baby in a sling rather than pushchair - he could hardly cause any trouble - but we were refused entry.
The art work is amazing!. This is my favorite art museum. Its small but totally worth it! The Coypel’s Don Quixote collection was my favorite. Its also reasonably priced.

New York's show case of art and esthetics. This grandiose mansion is worth the visit even if only for house itself with its furnishings still kept as in the days when the Fricks were living there. The art collection inside will have something for everyone, mine were the Don Quixote tapestries so unusual but how very expressive. Entrance is free, cloakroom is free, audio guides are free but you are invited to make a contribution which you see fit.
An artistic gem. Stunning building, beautiful art, interesting audio guide, friendly staff. It also has a superb discount for students.
Gorgeous. A very beautiful , doable museum in a gorgeous mansion on museum mile on 5th Ave. Not overwhelming like the Met and contains realy impressive art.

Do Not Miss the Frick Collection. The building itself is a gem, spectacular paneling, ceiling moldings, with a beautiful classical glass-roofed atrium with a pool and fountain. The collections of paintings and sculptures are also spectacular and just enough to absorb in a visit, without being overwhelming.
Art History for the folks who always meant to take it in college. I felt like I got an introduction to all of classical Western art wandering through this amazing house. The audio guides are great.
Delightful. The Frick Collection is an intimate museum with some outstanding art works. I loved the Rembrandt self-portrait.

A Gem of a Museum. This museum is housed in the Frick mansion in Manhattan. The Frick family donated the building as a museum to display their extensive and exquisite collection of artwork.One can feel intimate with the paintings and sculpture there because of the beautiful setting.
Great collection. We went here to see Vermeer paintings and were not disappointed. This is a great small museum that you can see in a few hours easily.

Free admission on Sundays but crowded. This museum offers something a bit different than conventional ones and is worth a visit. Go early because it can get really crowded. Love the atrium area as a place to sit for a moment.

Small Gem Tucked Away in a Busy City. This is a small museum that was once the private home of Henry C. Frick. His home and art collection are fabulous and there is always some sort of traveling collection on view.

Beautiful collection in heart of NYC!. I would highly recommend this collection. $20 per adult includes audio guide. There are multiple rooms of beautiful classical pieces intermingled with sculptures, oriental vases and antique furniture. I guarantee you'll recognize some of the paintings. I would recommend taking your time to appreciate the interior decorating. The paintings are not in chronological order but are designed to complement the room. Not too big so you'll see everything. A lovely way to spend a couple of hours.

A Stunning Collection.. I loved the Frick Collection and it really is a collection. It is a manageable size and is housed in a beautiful building. If you want to see some stunning art but don't want to tackle a huge museum I woul recommend it.

Old master heaven. This house/museum is a must on your list. The house itself is beautiful and the art is amazing, turner, Holbein,Rembrant' the list goes on and on. It is also small enough that you don't get aching feet. The only thing it lacks is a cafe!

A Wonderful Collection. We went here on Sunday morning between 11 and 1 when the admission is whatever you wish to give. I was impressed by the variety of the collection which covered the renaissance, to the Dutch Masters, statuary, furniture, tapestries and a Gilbert Stuart Washington portrait. There is a nice enclosed garden in the center of the exhibit which is the only place photos are allowed. The wait for the Ladies room is a bit lengthy so plan accordingly.

Beautiful museum.. Historic home of Henry Clay Frick with his collection beautifully displayed.Not too large so one can see everything in a few hours. Wonderful talk by a docent - wish it had been longer. She was great.Will definitely go again.

Snooty Staff at Front Desk * Nickeled and Dimed Despite $20 admission. First the good - beautiful works of art. Beautiful building. Also, one of the guards was very nice and friendly.Now the bad - overpriced admission - $20 adults. They do not post any information about the works of art other than the artist name, perhaps the name of the subject. Why the lack of info? Hmmm, perhaps because they want to force you into paying for the audio tour - which by the way, is some archaic thing you have to hold up to your ear - no ear phones.We skipped the audio tour, refusing to be nicked and dimed. Front desk staffer was snooty as all get out - young woman who I think might be an intern. No welcome, no smile. Poor gal, maybe she was miserable at her job.The place could use a good airing out - the place was quite stuffy, stale air. I actually hated being there, could not stand to stay long enough to see everything there. It's a beautiful building, and I would have liked to enjoy it. Other friends of mine had raved and raved about it, so I finally said "Fine" and checked it out for myself.With all of the other art museums in NYC, I doubt I will be returning to this place again.

Suprised at how much I enjoyed this collection. Really not an art lover (my wife is) so I had to go. Much to my surprise it has been my most enjoyable visit to an art museum. Been to the Louvre, Prado, Met, National Gallery. But not being an "Art" person I am sure others who are might have a different opinion.

Amazing collection of art!. The Frick Collection is an unbelievable private collection turned into a museum, contained in the former home. WOW! The house could be a museum without the art work. Very well preserved. And the collection was amazing! Younger children aren't allowed, which to me is a huge plus. It was a really quiet, peaceful place that allowed a self guided visit which made for a very pleasant afternoon.
Beauty within. Lovely this little jewel. A haven of calm in the middle of cultural overload. Been before and always enjoy. Do the audio tour and sit by the pool and contemplate.
good value. Hand held devices were provided, no cost, so I could view numbered items of artwork and learn the background. Beautiful home turned museum. $20 good value.
Surprisingly good. An exceptional private collection. The house is almost as interesting as the art collection. Small, intimate, but will make you hate the truly rich :)

You much give a Frick to visit this amazing place.. New York City can be a place that caters to all kinds of tourists but the Frick collection caters primarily to the informed, tasteful, art-savvy visitor. The mansion itself (and its gardens) just off of Fifth Avenue are reason enough to visit. The artwork is breathtaking and it is small in size so if you only have an hour or two you would really take in a lot of what the Frick has to offer.
Frick Museum. Fabulous collection of art. Well worth a visit, we especially liked the way the paintings were displayed.
Well maintained. Beautiful building with a great art collection. The free audio tour was excellent. Located right across from Central Park.

Stunning Museum. This house, turned museum is a beautiful work of art.Definitely worth a visit. So personal and with a great history.Not too overcrowded like other museums and you can take your time to appreciate every aspect of it. Stunning design and artwork is beautiful.Its on the east side and is actually just lovely to walk around the area and you get a feel for how gorgeous New York can be.
Outstanding art collection! Beautiful gallery.. A good way to spend an hour or two in New York. I walked there from Central Park not knowing what to expect. It was worth it.

Fabulous Find!. The history of this HOME turned into museum is amazing. Mr Frick was obviously extravagant in taste and presentation. There is such an amazing collection of beautiful and varied art and styles here that is such a pleasure to take in. What a gem NOT to be missed! We all loved it.!!
Great small museum.. Has fabulous Rembrandts, Vermeers, Tuners. Small. Beautiful mansion. Doable in two hours. Can take bus to Museum Mile. Free on Sunday from eleven to one pm.

Probably best museum to visit in NYC. The Frick has many of the best pieces by the finest artist who ever lived. Its beautifully hung, very rarely crowded, and can be visited in 1-2 hours (a little longer if one watches the free film of the history of the Frick.) The pieces are so good they are accessible to visitors who have very little knowledge of art, There are wonderful pieces by El Greco, Rembrant and other great, great artist.

Fabulous Frick!. While the art is amazing, and clearly indicative of Mr. Frick's extravagant taste and budget, the building is equally impressive. Considering when it was constructed and the rationale behind the room design for art display purposes, it is national treasure that must be on all art lovers' bucket list.

A Real Gem.. Lots of people recommended we visit The Frick Collection and we weren't disappointed. A beautiful building with a beautiful collection of art. Wonderful garden room. Doesn't open til 1100 on sunday but then its pay what you think its worth. Fabulous concept.
Sheer excellence. In a city with so much competition ( Met, Moma,Guggenheim ) this small jewel should not be forgotten! It is just precious.

Beautiful museum, artwork and location. We loved the Frick Collection, just off Central Park on 70th Street. It is a great place to spend a rainy or cold day when you would rather be indoors than outside. The audio tour is extremely helpful as well. Hint: The museum usually charges $20 admission fee, but on Sunday from 11-1 you can pay "whatever you want." Literally. Now THAT's a great deal!
Excellently Curated Museum. The Frick is not nearly as large as its neighbor The Met but its targeted collection and special exhibits are none the less exquisite.

Very doable visit for an afternoon. NY Museums are tough if you don't live here. I feel bad for people who try to see the Met or the MoMa in on day or even a weekend. But the Frick is the right size for a museum visit that will not consume the whole day. Take time to sit in the courtyard and relax. The permanent collection along with smaller exhibits can be seen at leisure during a morning or afternoon. And make time for the little but excellent gift shop. You will love it.

Our urban gem. Looking for a mellow respite? Nothing like the peace and quiet, the calming effect of the Frick. Great art and surroundings take you out of the stressed environment of New York City. Like taking a deep restorative breath. Also the audio tour is superb for all visitors. (I am a museum professional and learned plenty.) I think that young kids, however, may not be welcome. It's not a place for the rambunctious.

My favorite museum in New York City. I love to see their great collection from Turner to Picasso... you can also see special collections such as Don Quishote goblens and paintings sketch books My best place to sit down near the pool and fountain in the garden and draw a chorachal

Go on a Sunday. The collection is a little small and is probably not worth the normal price of admission unless you're quite keen and knowledgeable about art and antiques but we went on a Sunday when it was pay what you want and it was well worth the dollar we paid.

Just the best!!. If you only visit one museum, let the Frick Collection be it! A gem in Manhattan! The history behind the collection only adds to the intrigue and enjoyment of the collection. Beautifully displayed paintings and furniture all make this museum worth a visit.
European Masterpieces. A great mansion with the works of the great masters. Was wonderful to see so many assembled in the one place.

Old Masters and a fabulous house. If you want a relaxed visit that includes close up access to paintings from Turner , Gainsborough, Van Dyck, Rembrandt and others in a house overlooking Central Park that looks like the owner just popped out in the 1930's and is expected back soon, this is the palce to go. Reminded me of visiting a national trust house in the UK. Definitely deserves its place in top 10 places to visit in New York. Been wanting to see this for ten years and did not disapoint. Normally costs $20 but on Sundays between 11 and 1300 pay want you want offer.
A jewel of a plac. If you go between 11 and 1 pm on a Sunday the admission fee is pay what you wish rather than 20 dollars each.
A Gem. An exquisite collection in a lovely setting. Not a single piece of junk and many old friends. Always rewarding. One of the best examples of a private collection in the world.

Disappointing. Far too much crammed into too small a space - there are other levels in this house that could have been utilised. Yes, many Old Masters but not a patch on any of the London Museums and galleries. Many people visiting it too, which made it seem even more crowded.

excellet collection. The art collection is phenomenal. The building was frick's home in the early 1900's. it is kept as it was then. Most of the art work is from non americans. There are only two american artists exhibites. The art is as it was when frick set it up. One room is 97 feet long and filled with art. Frick intended it to be a museum after he died. I am not a fan of Henry Clay Frick however, he along with Andrew Carnegie used Pinkertons to attack union organizers in Pittsburgh and 8 were killed.
Worth the visit. This is a small managable art museum in a former industrialist's mansion. Many beautiful paintings & sculpture on display.

Another Great Gem. The Frick is another great gem of NYC...less crowded than the Met or Guggenheim, and easier to get around in since it was originally the Henry Clay Frick house. However, if the exhibition is a popular one (like an Impressionist everyone recognizes), prepare to stand in a long line that can snake around the block. I've almost loved to take friends here who have been to NYC many times, but never visited the Frick. It's very quiet, peaceful, and beautiful (but can get very busy on the weekends, so go during the week). I am always fascinated by the views of 5th Ave and Central Park, and try to imagine what it would have been like to actually live there. It should be noted that Frick's private collection should not be overshadowed by the house itself, which is it's own museum of sorts. A lot of the furniture and rooms have been preserved just as they were when Frick himself lived there. So if you can suspend your disbelief for just a few hours, you can almost picture yourself on a private tour somewhere in time.

A New York must see. It's like stepping back in time to the Gilded Age of New York! Definitely worth a visit. Beautiful home and art and a chance to see what life was like in the early 20th century for a very privileged New York family

Amazing. The Frick offers an amazing collection of private art. The museum was a mansion that was planned to become a museum. It is elegant, grand, quiet and comfortable, a perfect museum outing. Videos in the music room explained the tapestries and a brief history of Mr. Frick. Audio guides were available. A visit to the Frick Collection is a perfect museum outing.

A unique art gallery. When the millionaire, Mr. Frick, built this elegant home on 5th Avenue, overlooking Central Park, he planned that it would become a public museum after his death and that of his wife. The home (grand, but feels like it was a comfortable place to live) contains perhaps the finest collection of art collected by a private person. The audio guide enhances your visit, as do the very knowledgeable guards.
Always a joy to visit.. i visit this collection every time I come to New York and there is always something new to see. The atmosphere is so peaceful and you can gaze into Central Park.

Incredible. This was a beautiful place to visit. I spent half a day here and could easily have spent more time if they had a cafe. The architecture of the house alone was incredible and add to that the beauty and variety of the art collection was just wonderful. I absolutely loved it.

Impressed. I was impressed with this collection! As it is shown in Frick's house you can not just see the artwork but also admire the furniture and architecture of the place. Pictures are not alowed inside of the house.

A house full of delights. Formerly the home of Henry Clay Frick who died in 1931, he has left a huge collection of the most wonderful painting from across the generations. El Greco, Botticelli, Rembrandt, Turner, Constable, Hans Holbein - we were exhausted by the time we'd finished - both physically and emotionally. We had to postpone a trip to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, we had nothing left! A terrific place, don't miss it if you are an art lover.

If you do only one 'cultural' thing - this should be it!. The fabulous Frick Collection is housed in the mansion Henry Frick built and lived in overlooking Central Park. So much more than a museum. Pick up the little device as you go in to tell you about the history of the rooms, paintings, objets d'art. It isn't overwhelming so you probably won't spend more than and hour and a half here. Why not follow a visit here with lunch at the Boat House, a short walk away. What could be more perfect!

Outstanding collection. This is in a beautiful building with lovely ground and convenient location. It contains an extraordinary collection of art, sculptures and tapestries. It is perfectly displayed and easy to navigate. The taped reviews are easily heard over modest sized hand held speakers. A truly amazing collection!

My Favorite Museum in NYC (and can it be done in one hour). The most fabulous smaller museum in NYC. Right on Fifth Ave at 70th, it has a STUPENDOUS Renaissance through Impressionist collection all housed as a robber baron's mansion built 1912-. Life as it was in the Gilded Age before the Fricks, Vanderbilts, Carnegies, et.al. were robbed of the ability to amass wealth without estate taxes. Everything is there, in situ: the furniture, rugs, wall tapestries, porcelains... all in a glorious house built around an open atrium complete with huge fountain and pool. SO COOL. Frick was a mega-steel magnate from Pittsburgh who battled it out with Carnegie (US Steel). Carnegie endowed the nation's libraries. Frick left the world this amazing mansion of a museum. Ever since the world has been able to see exactly what life was like for the Robber Barons at the turn of the century who really, really knew fine art. My Favorite Museum in NYC.

Private home, private collection. Although my favorite will always be the Met, this collection is doable in just an hour or two. You don't feel overwhelmed. Everything can be seen in one visit. It's nice to take a break in the solarium with the greenery and flowers.

Exquisite small museum. This is the most beautiful peaceful small museum in all of NYC. The building is a beautiful architectural gem and the artwork it holds is just beautiful, If you are in NYC you must visit this meseum. I believe that on Sunday mornings the admission fee is waived and "pay what you wish" is in place.

A museum within a residence. A collection of works of art which can be viewed at one visit and set in a building which you can imagine being lived in as a home. Not as overwhelming as some museums. Well worth visiting

Terrific!. We visited the Frick on a Saturday morning in time for the daily tour. It was a quick tour, the tour guide was knowledgeable and gave a good overview of the house and collection. The views are amazing, and the art is wonderful and impressive. This was a good choice for a Saturday morning, it was not crowded and we were able to see a good portion of the collection in just a few hours. Highly recommended!

Great place for Art Lovers. I enjoyed this place so much. I first came here in 2005-ish when I was in college. It's a beautiful building with some great works of art housed here. It's close to other museums in the area so you can hit those up too. It's not like the MMA where you could spend hours and hours here, maybe like 1 hour tops.

Best art collection ever. This is a fantastic collection presented in a personal residence (mansion) on Park Avenue. The smaller scale makes this a very easy to disgest museum visit and the quality of the collection is unbelievable. (Great)
an island in the busy world of NYC. outside it is not hell, but very loud - inside it is like a monastery and full of beautiful things to be seen again and again

Impressive Collection in great setting. I just love when a historic building is preserved in NYC. The art collection is an impressive mix as well with the few American artist paintings displayed beautifully. Worth a trip for any art and architecture lover.

Beautiful house & collection. I visited the Frick Collection during the Sunday 'pay as you wish' time. The house was previously the home of the Frick family and houses their personal collection of art. Even if you are not an art fan, I would still recommend going to see the house as it is very well preserved and in excellent condition. It is a rare opportunity to see inside a upper east side mansion! I really enjoyed my visit. You get an audio guide with your entrance fee so that you can get information about each room and specific pieces of art. There is a coat check on entering the house and if you choose to keep your coat you must wear it all the way round. This rule is strictly enforced and there are a lot of staff to make sure you wear it! I didn't check mine due to the huge queue, but then was really hot while looking round. As well as the art, I really appreciated the house. It is beautiful and so grand, there is so much detail in the decor of the house. The rooms are huge and when you looked out of the windows you felt like Central Park was the back garden, it's so close! There is no photography allowed except for in the garden court where the fountain is. Again, this was strictly enforced. I was disappointed that the gardens are not open to the public, although you can see then through the railings from the street. The music room was closed during my visit due to a scheduled concert that evening, which was disappointing. It is a round room so I'm sure it would have been nice to see it. The film they usually show was also not being shown today either. There is a small gift shop, with the majority of stock actually relevant to the museum (mostly art books and postcards of the exhibits) which is often not the case at some museums! The staff were also very helpful. It took a little over an hour to go round the museum, which is not long if you pay the full admission price on a regular day. However, I would still recommend the museum to fellow NYC visitors.

A beautiful museum with an impressive collection.. This is a small museum with an incredible collection. including some of the most well known painting on the world all housed in a mansion which includes original furniture decor. A must see if you enjoy art museums.

see great works of art. The Building itself is quite a looker, considering it was actually a home for some time - right next to central park on the uws.A must visit if you enjoy the work of Turner, Vermeer, Rembrandt, etc. - quite an impressive collection.On sundays between 11am and 1pm it's "pay what you want"-time which helps you safe a few bucks since the general admission is $25,-

Beautiful museum with excellent collection!. I visit Frick Collection every time I visit New York City. The museum is housed in a magnificent building with a beautiful garden. The collection of art is fantastic. A must visit for New York!
Charming museum. Beautiful Central Park mansion , no crowds and excellent collection. Very enjoyable visit. Can comfortably visit in 1-2 hours.
Beautiful villa. Wow, to be so rich at so young an age. Disliked the impersonal feel of the collection. Liked the layout of the collection.

Charming art museum. I visited The Frick Collection museum in NYC, across from Central Park, on the upper East Side, on 70th. It is a very well maintained mansion, beautifully furnished with Antiques and decorated by many works of art, from Paintings from various eras and styles, to a collection of mini Bronzes, to amazing old French China, an indoor pond, etc...A short and sweet visit that takes you back over a century.
A gem. The first time I visited the Frick, my wife and I discovered it by accident as we walked up Fifth Avenue.Now it is one of my favorites and I recommend it to anyone without hesitation.
Fantastic collection. Probably the best private art collection outside of Europe, all in a beautifully decorated house. Definitely worth a visit.

Fantastic private collection. It wasn't my first time at the Frick Collection but I wanted to show it to my son who was very impressed. It is a trip to the past specially when one considers that one man was responsible for collecting all these antique paintings and furniture.

Nice Smaller Art Museum. The building is an old home that is stunning by itself. The collection is a mix of European art. Artists represented in the Collection include Rembrandt Harmensz. van Rijn, Giovanni Bellini, El Greco, Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, Frans Hals, Johannes Vermeer and Turner. My favorites are Bellini's St. Francis in the Desert and Turner's Dieppe and Colonge's harbors. Great visit for an hour or so but $20 is a little steep.
Never been but .... I wish my home looked like this! I used to walk by on my way to school and dream it was my home. Great grounds but wish I actually visited.

What money and love of art bought. This site is a cognitive celebration of some of the best and most famous art in the world, all the while being a delightful architectural setting, much of which was built after the death of Mr. Frick himself. His daughter added wonderful pre- and Renaissance art that delights the viewer. Holbein the Younger, Titian, Rembrandt, Vermeer, among others, settled in the original places for which they were intended within the home's rooms set up for them is just so rewarding. "Exciting" at one level and "comfortable" at another. One of my favorite places, with or without a visiting exhibition.
Sublime art. I am a Vermeer lover and that alone drew me there. The elegant surroundings and other paintings increased my delight.

A charming museum. Housed in a former mansion (designed to one day be a museum) you get to see wonderful artwork, as well as fabulous home furnishings. Like walking into an earlier era. The short film is great background.

Beautiful museum that you can see in 3 hours. The Frick collection is an excellent choice if you are looking for a beautiful museum that you can see it all in approx. 3 hours. It has beautiful gardens and pools that you can relax at.

Great place to visit. This house is more or less as the Frick family lived in it in the early part of the last century. It has some marvellous furniture, porcelain and paintings - the latter by some grand masters. There is a free audio guide which was well worth having, and a lovely indoor garden room where you can sit when your feet ache. The only disadvantage is there is no coffee shop - otherwise this place would be absolutely ideal for the visitor - but this does not detract from the fabulous rooms of this house and its location overlooking central park.

A multi interest visit. Here we have a wonderful opportunity to explore the town house of a steel magnate of the early 20th century, and to see the indulgences that wealth could bring in that era. The social architecture within the building gives a glimpse of the opulence of the era for the privileged few, and also allow you to share Frick's eclectic taste in art. In my opinion this has to be the best gallery in New York.

Gem of a small museum. This gem of a museum has a very good collection of european and american art for its size. Beautiful place shows decor and ambiance of the turn of the 20th century. Go and visit, you'll be glad you did, close to the MET.

My FAVOURITE museum of all time. I first visited the Frick Museum in 1962, aged 17 years' old, when visiting friends of whom the Dad was the PR guy for the New York elections for Governor between Rockefeller and Morgenthau.I LOVED THE PLACE AND PRACTICALLY LIVED THERE FOR A WEEK.My very favourite painter Ingres is great evidence with several absolutely beautiful nudes for which he most renowned, and I would stand in front of one of an incredible muse with the whitest of skin at her toilette and wish fervently that one day I would have her curves, her delicacy of features and her luminous skin. I have all of them - aren't I the lucky one!!Do go to the Frick Collection - it is wonderful - if you like furniture too you will be spoilt...and sculpture, and bronzes and carpets and..... everything but the kitchen sink, but all so very covetable....

A gem amongst gems. Whatever else you do in NYC don't miss Frick Collection - for a $20 entrance fee you get to stand up front and very personal with some of the most extraordinary works by extraordinary artists. The setting is beautiful and the paintings displayed so well. We particularly liked the audio guide which had a number guide so that you tapped in whatever number of exhibit you wanted to know about and then move on. (i.e. you didn't have to follow a certain path or linger where you didn't want to). Turners, Constables, Vemeers etc etc etc. Astonishing.

Great small museum. Wonderful neighborhood, history, art collection. You must stop in here if you're in NYC to see how the wealthy elite lived. The history is very interesting and this bygone era is just not something you come across from everyday. Worth a visit. We happened upon a certain hour window on a Sunday where the admission is free or a suggested donation of half the normal rate. I think we paid $10 admission but I think we could have paid nothing.
If You Love Ver Meers......... The Frick Museum is located in a home instead of a commercial building. It has more Ver Meers that the Rijksmuseumin Amsterdam!!

A more intimate art experience. The Frick Collection offers a great art experience on a much smaller scale than many of the other popular art museums in NYC (Met, Guggenheim, MoMA). I went on a Sunday during the pay-what-you-wish time period, and had a great experience. I took advantage of the audio tour and made my way throughout the Frick house at my leisure. The audio tour is highly recommended - I enjoyed that there was commentary for both the art and the room decor of the house, and I felt that the narratives given in the audio tour enhanced my enjoyment of each art piece. The best part of the Frick Collection is being able to enjoy someone's personal art collection in their own period home. It is truly a unique experience to know that the entire museum and it's art collection was once someone's own little (or not so little in the case of this mansion!) space in the world.

Fabulous European art collection. This was a personal collection in a large house on museum row (south of the Met Museum of Art). For those interested in European art, it is much more accessible that the Met: A much smaller number of works of art and furniture, but each one is a high quality gem. There are audio-guides that are helpful. Also, the Frick has a virtual tour, which is great: Before going, check it out to get a feel of the place:http://www.frick.org/visit/virtual_tour (e.g. see the "living hall" room for an overall idea of the museum).

A nice collection . This was lovely on a cold day. A nice collection of old masters. Be sure to pick up a free audio guide. We also caught one of the free 15 minute docent tours, which I would also recommend.

Wonderful Artworks in a Beautiful Setting. A wonderful place with a very helpful staff. If you can time it right, you can also attend a lecture in their auditorium. It is great to learn about the artists and the works on display.
Beautiful Museum. This landmark is a special piece of UES history. The interior atrium is beautiful & timeless. Strolling down the hallways while viewing the collection is an enjoyable experience.

Fragonard, Fragonard, Fragonard.. This place is da bomb if you like rococo painting. Think Fragonard. The interior decor is also fascinating, but somehow less immediately capturing of the imagination. It's certainly worth a look if you're intrigued by how very rich and famous lived in a previous era.

Perfect. Come to see the house and a great collection of art in Henry Clay Frick's turn of the century home on Fifth Avenue. Frick turned coal to coke for the Pittsburg steel mills, formed a partnership with Andrew Carnegie that became US Steel. With unlimited funds he assembled a eclectic collection of paintings, porcelains, rugs and furniture. Look for the Turners and Constables notable for their size. Two things to remember, children under 10 are not allowed, nor are large backpacks or suitcases which their cloak room will not take. And secondly The Frick Art Reference Library on 71st Street was started by Helen Clay Frick and contains reference books and over a million photographs of art works. Henry was curious about the artist he was collecting and his daughter obliged. If you are a teacher or otherwise involved in art history, stop in and become a member... you'll be overwhelmed, and who knows, you can use it to deduct part of your trip.

A must for art lovers. This is a must for all art lovers who visit New York. Certainly, there is the Met, but this is a more immediate experience in a more intimate setting with a much higher concentration of pure masterpieces set in a fin-de-siecle glamour of an upper East Side mansion. Frick, an industrialist who amassed this extraordinary and tasteful collection at the beginning of the 20th century, stipulated in his will that no painting was ever to leave the house, and so you will never NOT find a painting in its place because it's on loan elsewhere. The museum does close early (by 5pm daily) I believe, so check the website for hours of operation. A free audio guide comes with the ticket, and it is extremely useful and informative. The exhibits are numbered with a matching number in the audio guide narrative, so you can move from painting to painting in the order of preference and input the number of the painting into the audio guide to hear about it, thus leaving the pace and exploration of exhibit space completely up to the viewer.Although overwhelming in its greatness, the Frick is quite manageable in its size, so at the end of the day, you can enjoy that rare feeling of actually seeing most of the museum. It is also right across from Central Park, so depending on time of year, you may enjoy letting it all sink in as you rest your feet sitting under some trees.

Another New York City Treasure. For those of you who have visited the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, the Frick will remind you of that but on a much grander scale. Mr. Frick's collection is nothing short of spectacular housed in a building that should qualify as a piece of art itself. The setting on 5th Avenue at 70th Street adds to the grandeur. We went on Sunday (during the pay what you want time period) which made it a bit more crowded as many students took advantage of that. It still did not diminish from the experience. Be sure to take one of the portable audio units which give a nice description of a number of the works as you walk through.

MUST SEE!. Worth spending a leisurely afternoon, browsing through this beautiful mansion and the phenomenal collection of artwork; including paintings, sculpture, porcelain, tapestry, furniture and more. What an eye for art Henry Clay Frick had. Prefer these types of collections housed in the homes of the collectors (like Isabella Stewart Gardner!), than the big, cold museums. A "must see" for art enthusiasts!
stunning. what an incredible residence to turn into a beautiful museum. The solarium is breathtaking. Great place to have an event too.

The museum as masterpiece. At the corner of 70th St and Fifth Avenue, across the street from Central Park and a little over half a mile south of the Metropolitan Museum is a gem of a building meant to serve as both private residence and then museum. As a piece of art unto itself the building, set back from the avenue, looks exactly like what it was and now is, a showpiece of architectural elegance for its time and still so classical in execution that no container could better honor the treasures held inside.I enjoy museums and as a New Yorker I revel in the opportunities available to me, but the Frick stands apart. For starters, it is managable in size so that if you want to stroll leisurely through all of it you can do so in less than an hour including a little time for absorption sitting in the pool room (as I call it, not sure of its formal name) but if you would like to spend time really looking at what Rembrandt, or El Greco, or Whistler, not to mention JW Turner, or Vermeer (you can see that his missus got her earring back) were capable of, the Frick is the place for you. While you're there, try to imagine what that massive embedded pipe organ would sound like in the middle of the morning, or any other time for that matter. The place has something for everyone, from wall sized tapestries, wall covering cupid-filled tableau in baby blues and pink with gold trim (not my personal favorite) the library where heaven only knows what Mr Frick paid to have his books bound and then stashed but it is masterfully done and then on to the sculpture gallery where the daylight gleams upon the marble busts and figures. It's a respite in the heart of a busy and bustling city and it is the perfect place to catch your breath. In the meantime, go to frick.org for a preview.

Great European Art In An Intimate Setting. Going to the Frick is like stepping back in time. The collection of European paintings, rugs, and porcelain is housed in the home of industrialist Henry Clay Frick. If you don't want to pay the $20 admission fee, go on Sunday and pay what you want between 11am and 1pm. The Metropolitan Museum of art can often feel overwhelming because of its size and vast collection. Head to the Frick if you want something more intimate.

Jewelbox of a Museum. Beautiful museum which was the private residence of industrialist Henry Cray Frick to house his Euroopean art collection. The Garden Court is absolutely spectacular and a fabulous spot to sit and chat!
Little Gem. Exhibits are small and carefully curated. Visitors mostly knowledgeable. Building is exquisite. Now and again, sketching is permitted on Friday evenings.

Frick Collection--New York City. The former home (built in 1911) of Henry Clay Frick, one of the world's richest men a hundred years ago, is filled to the gills with art works of the highest order. There is no anti-art or tat in the place. It is a collection that Frick amassed himself. Early in his collection period, he bought works of the French Impressionists. Few of those remain because a few years before he died (in 1919) he hired an "art expert" who sold most of the Impressionists' works and purchased great masters (such as Rembrant, Goya, Reynolds, Raeburn, Vermeer, Turner, Hals, Hobbema, Constable, ElGrego, Valasques, de la Tour). The paintings are hung rooms which are still furnished as they were when he lived there. Among the treasures are (unfinished) murals from Madame Dubarry's chateau which adorn the walls of his wife's bedroom and some of the finest Bouchers in the world on the walls of Mrs. Frick's tea room and in a recess (Boucher's four seasons).-----There are comfortable couches in the main gallery, and the museum is seldom crowded.Mr. Joseph London
Interesting collection. Went for a specific show and stuck around for the beautiful portraits, architecture, and furnishings. True art and craftsmanship everywhere you look.
Wonderful art collection. Great collection featuring JMW Turners paintings amongst other notable works, all in Frick's grand mansion.

Amazing, tasteful and top-notch. The only front lawn in NYC belonged to the scoundrel Henry Frick. His questionable legacy to NYC has been justifiably overshadowed by his incredible mansion, which he donated to the city, as well as his prized and truly outstanding art collection which is houses. The Met and MoMA are must sees, but if you miss the Frick, you're missing one of NYC's unsung gems.

FRICK. This is an opulent American dream, one of Henry Frick, millionaire, who sought to present us with treasures that are beyond compare. (There is a short film detailing its history) I love the Monet snow scene, St Francis in the Wilderness is one of my favorite paintings and the Titan portrait — amazing. There are also objects d'art for those who are not into paintings and an indoor garden. This was his home. There is nothing that can compare to stepping into one of the small but vast galleries, whose moss green carpet, cushions your feet, and quiets the air, making the Turners, Veronese' and other works live in the space that they deserve. This is a place of timeless, that place where all art inhabits, but that we humans often forget, as so seldom is art surrounded by its own jewel of a building. Go and enjoy!

Frickin Loved It. I found the Frick Gallery to be well maintained and an interesting medium sized museum for a nice tour. The history of the building and its owner makes for a unique view of historic living in NY for the wealthy, and the gardens / interiors are a nice respite for a chaotic city.Taking time to walk along 5th avenue and jumping over to a restaurant between 5th and Madison makes for a great 3 hour part of your day.

A wonderful gem. The Frick has an extraordinary personal collection of truly great art. Its display in what is basically a large home makes for a very comfortable visit. I highly recommend a visit to the Frick as part of an adult visit to New York.

Nothing Like IT!. The personal collection of Henry Clay Frick housed in his Gilded Age mansion is like nothing you have ever see. Be sure to get the headset with the recorded guide as it is like having a personal tour with the curator. For me one of the highlights was getting close to the Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington...amazing!
Amazing house/museum.. Wonderful house with many art pieces, some of which are very well known. Much more intimate than MOMA or Metropoliten with just the right size for a few hours visit.
A perfect art museum. We go every few years. This time I liked it even better than usual. Just the right size. Extraordinary collection. Lovely setting. Quiet even when crowded. Civilized.

Still my favourite art museum in New York City!. I have always loved the Frick Collection, not only for the really wonderful pictures, bronzes and pieces of art which comprise the intimate personal art collection of Henry Frick, but also for the ambiance of the museum in which they are housed - Henry Frick's own house - or rather, mansion - on Fifth Avenue. This is one of the numerous grand mansions which used to line Fifth Avenue - one which survived - the others destroyed to make way for the elegant apartment buildings and skyscrapers of later years. The Frick Collection is a must-see for any visitor to New York City - I would always choose to visit this intimate, personal collection of art over any other in New York! Please do not miss it!

An amazing exhibition - and just the right size. You won't be overwhelmed by the size of the Frick Collection, but you will be by the collection itself. Make sure you use the audio guide.There are some fabulous works of art here in a beautiful environment. The only issue is that there';s nowhere to eat at the Frick - so make sure you've stocked up first! - They also host concerts - so check out their web site.

A must see!. Out of this world collections! The architect is amazing. If on a budget go on a Sunday because it is "pay what you wish day"! Spent several hours there and it wasn't enough, will return on next trip.

Excellent, top notch. A spectacular collection of art in its original domestic (albeit palatial) setting. Far more enjoyable than the Met: if you have time for only one art gallery in New York, this is the one. The quality of the collection is superb, and the environment in which it is displayed is architecturally stunning.
Always a hit.. We always marvel at the collection. I cannot imagine living there. It's all concrete and marble but the ART is unbelievable.

Wholistic Art View....Wow!. This should by no means be your only museum stop in New York City, but missing it would be a shame. This rich-man's Fifth Avenue mansion, now about 100 years old, contains his collection of art while he was alive. His foundation made additions to the mansion and there have been donations by third parties. The result? Walk into any room and you will not just see great art, you will see a vast collection of antique furniture, topped by sculptures and vintage clocks. Not just empty rooms with paintings on the walls, but chandeliers, painted walls, some life-size sculptures and an interior garden with fountain. Worth the visit--- you only need about 90 minutes. No restaurant. Please go!

Not for fans of exciting artworks.. This was a short, expensive and uninteresting visit. Admittedly, this is not my kind of museum at all, since it features mainly portraits and decorative furniture, neither of which I find particularly interesting. For five small rooms though, the $20 fee seems excessive even if you do like these sort of ostentatious displays of wealth masquerading as museums.
A real gem. A visit to this small but wonderful museum is essential for anyone interested in viewing great works of art in a beautiful setting. My favorite museum in NYC.

Old money New York. This is Mr. Frick own palace converted in one of the finest New York museums. So not only you see the most refined collections, but the setting is such that you enjoy them as they were when Mr. Frick lived there.

impresive. The Frick Collection is by far the attraction that surprises. I believe that is it not rated as should, because I had 3 guides with me on the trip and they said it was nice to visit. Now, I must say that arriving there I began to understand that it is not just nice but really impressive. It is a window into another time and space, were people lived in extraordinary luxury, with taste and good old fashion European influence. I will spoil it for you if I get into details but trust me from my number of countries and cities visited; it is worth it although it sits in the shadow of the two great tourist attractions The Met and Central Park.

Excellent Value. Astonishing! Hard to believe the museum was once a private residence. The museum is nicely curated. We spent two hours there and could have spent more but we found ourselves in need of a drink and something to eat. Lesson learned; don't visit such exquisite sites so close to lunch. The visit was worth the cost of entry.

Amazing museum. This is an amazing art collection in an amazing mansion. We spend a few hours there. Where else can you get to within a few feet of a Rembrandt and see the brush marks on the canvas. Make sure you get the audio devices to give you an explanation of what you are looking at. Although if was quite busy on a Sunday afternoon the place is spacious and was easily able to handle the number of people there.I

A superb collection. What a gem! This fantastic art collection is housed in the house built by one of New York's last great robber barons. The house is ridiculously ostentatious but was built to house the collection and gives an insight into the mind of Frick, the collector. Works include Turner, El Greco, Holbeim, Degas, Rembrandt and Vermeer. There is a free audio tour which provides information about the paintings and the collector and gives a great sense of context.

Frick Collection: Great private art collection. The Frick Collection is a very good private art museum in NYC. The collection is comprised of European artworks amassed by Pittsburgh industrialist, Henry Clay Frick during the 19th and early 20th century. Today, you can view the full Frick Collection within the former Frick Residence building on 5th Ave. just across from Central Park. Here you can see important works by the European Old Masters as well as an impressive collection of sculptures, 18th century French furniture and porcelain amongst other impressive items. There is also a beautiful and peaceful garden court within the Frick residence and a music room where performance and lectures are held. The strengths of the Frick Collection are the European masterpieces which include fine works by Bellini, Lippi, El Greco, Velázquez, Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Van Dyke, Vermeer, Goya, Whistler, Boucher and Fragnard just to name a few. Part of your entry fee (US$20 per Adult, US$10 per student) includes an audio guide which is advisable to take. This helps explain most of the major art works on display. This can be very helpful if you are rusty on your art history. As well as the worldly collection of permanent works at the Frick Collection, there are temporary exhibitions that can be very much worth seeing as well. We had seen a Picasso exhibition back in 2011 that was enjoyable and we very much enjoyed the Masterpieces from the Scottish National Gallery exhibition which recently ended. In the end, if you are enjoy fine art, you will want to visit the Frick Collection. The entry fee is on the high end of the scale but this is probably one of the finest private collections of European art in the world so its worth seeing, even if you also intend to visit the much larger collection found at the nearby MET. If you are not as much of a fan of fine art but want to see European masterpieces during your trip to NYC, you might prefer to visit the MET instead. Here you can find a much larger and diverse collection and you have the ability to pay what you like to enter the museum. Tip: If you visit on Sundays (11-1pm) you can pay as you wish instead of the mandatory US$20 adult entrance fee. This makes the museum an excellent value for money experience if you can visit at this time. Note: Children under 10 are not permitted into the Frick Collection. Make sure you are aware of this before arriving with young children.

Museum Gem. The recent exhibition of treasures from the Scottish National Gallery was outstanding, but this museum is always a treat to visit. The Frick Collection is housed in a former mansion that in itself is a work of art to be appreciated. The works of art are quite extensive and beautiful to behold. A great place to spend a few hours.

Lots of antiquities have the history and meaning creating the minds of the new art fown the road. The antiquities have.. I like the meaning of the pieces creating the minds of the art in front of us.
