Lots of antiquities have the history and meaning creating the minds of the new art down the road. They have meaning and purpose.

Impressionist heaven. This is a small gallery when compared to the Met but for any Impressiinist purists, it is a must. Great opportunity for kids or adults to learn to appreciate art at its most simple and dramatic. It is cramped for everything that is on offer. Great location. NYC is not known as cosmopolitan-this is the best of France without going to Europe-for art, not food
A gem. A small museum with an excellent collection in the former Frick residence. It is not usually crowded and has a nice indoor patio where you can rest.
Absolutely stunning. What a gem! Amazing architecture, art and antiques. A wonderful surprise and so well run. An absolute must in NYC

Beautiful Museum Mansion, Top-Quality Art. The old mansion is beautifully kept and the ornate , elegant design lets one see how the gilded age barons lived. The garden interior is peaceful and restful and one can sit on benches to rest here. Frick collected great rarities and great examples of the best works available to him of the artists of his period of interest. Don't miss this great experience while in NYC.

How Can So Many Great Art Pieces Be in One Place?. If you wnat to see some of the choicest pieces of art in the Western Art world, come to the Frick. Nice location. Esay to move through. If you're lucky to get a guided tour, take it --- the stories behind the collection add so much more to appreciation. And if you are double lucky to be there when they have a special show on loan to them --- don't miss this museum. Most people don'e even know it exists --- too bad for them --- or too good for thaos ewho go and can avoid the over-crowds that other museums hve these days.
Very nice museum. This museum is fantastic.It has lots of amazing artwork.It's located in an old beautiful house that once belongs to Mr. Frick.

The House embraces you.. The best museum in NYC, this is a warm house with many and important pieces of art that embraces you. Suggest to start in the concert hall to understand the story of the museum and Mr. Frick.
I'll always go back - small and superb. It's like visiting an old friend - the courtyard, the rooms. You must see the Ingres, the Holbeins, I have to go on.

A Must Visit Museum in NYC. Not too much mentioned museum or reviewed but definitively a must see. America paintings, european, china and decor. You have them all in a very beautiful designed and built early 1900's mansion.

A museum you can see in two or so hours. The Frick is beautiful ,full of period furniture and great art and is pleasant to walk through and less crowded and overwhelming than the larger galleries and museums which of course are a must see in New York. However if you would like to have time in a day for the surrounding area of Central Park and Fifth Avenue and spend some time in a gallery,The Frick can be a nice option.
Museum Mile's Mansion. On Museum Mile south of the Met, The Frick is sometimes overlooked as a Museum to visit. A world class collection and easily visited because of its size.
One of the country's premier family collections. Everything about the Frick is interesting, from the house, to the collections, to the locations. Not to be missed.

a delightful pleasure. Thank god for Henry Frick, a rich man who amassed a fortune, spent some of it on building an elegant townhouse and filling it with masterpieces, which we can now enjoy much as he did. Intimate, small, delightful. Combine with a walk in Central Park.

Showcasing a horrid man's impeccable tastes in art. The Frick Collection has always been in my to-visit list, but the admission was just too steep for me. Fortunately, they have a pay what you want window on Sunday afternoons. The line for this gets very long so be there early.Seeing the collection makes you rethink what kind of a man Frick was. History says he was ruthless and cruel, even murderous, yet this collection seems to belie this description. Especially impressive is the Fragonard Room, and the fountain area.
Boutique Museum. This museum is small, but very select in hanging their shows. Wonderful pieces and knowledgeable staff.
Unmissable!. A beautiful, peaceful slice of NY how it was at the turn of the 20th Century. A superb collection and a magical place.

Just beautiful. This is a stunning place. It's full of exquisite furniture, paintings and sculpture but it still manages to give a feel for how it was when it was a private (if very very very wealthy) family home. I romantically imagined Mrs Frick in a gorgeous gown, sipping her tea whilst she looked out over Central Park...If you can, eavesdrop on one of the school trips that go round. The young woman guide we saw was brilliant at making the art accessible; there was also a rather more formal tour going on, but the kids were having much more fun. I particularly loved the Holbeins and other portaits, but there are Turners, Gainsboroughs, Whistlers...but there is something beautiful in every room, so set aside an hour or so to stroll round before heading out back into the bustle of 5th Avenue.
Outstanding !. I don't like museums but this was outstanding. A wonderful collection. The only thing that could be added would be more information about the Frick family---both past and present.

Excellent way to spend the afternoon. Although I was not impressed with the artwork, admitted it is not my "thing". However, the mansion itself is impressive. Some rooms are decorated although a work of art themselves. I did like the furniture and the tables and stands that were used to display the artwork. They details on them are absolutely amazing and not to be missed for the paintings themselves (i.e. lion paws of the table, the stand decorated with amphoras, which actually display amphoras. The sculptures are also impressive. My favorite were the petrified wood vases, GORGEOUS! Finally, worth the mention is the elaborately decorated oil lamp. Unfortunately pictures of the collection are prohibited, but that only means that you would have to ingrain the image of the piece of art into your mind, which science shows prolongs your memory of the experience over snapping a photo. TIP: At the end of all of my experiences, I like to ask myself (and those who I am with) about the most memorable piece...try it and you will see that it truly works.

Don't miss this hidden jewel!. It's right on the way as you are walking up to The Metropolitan Museum of Art......and yes, you should walk there on a summer morning as part of your visit to Central Park.
Beautiful mansion with great art. Comfortable visiting this elegant mansion on fifth Avenue. Beautiful artwork in a gilded age mansion. Highly recommend. Free admission on sunday from 11 to 1 p.m.

Frick Mansion. Amazing private mansion turned into a treasure of a museum. The collection of paintings, sculptures, furniture is breathtaking. Well worth the visit and plan at least two hours. There were short films presented that gave the background of the Frick fortune and highlighted the special collections on dispolay
Lovely Gallery. A must for all art lovers, a lovely house for one, and one mans art collection inside, beautiful. There are always special exhibitions here as far as I can tell.

"Two attractions for the price of one". I cannot say what was more impressive, the art or the mansion itself. From the outside the mansion seems so out of place with all of the high rises surrounding it; but when you enter the building the two story structure packs a big punch. I cannot imagine living in such grandeur; but obviously people did. The artwork is awe inspiring; a powerful collection of influential New Yorkers and other people of merit. The best two hours I have spent in a long time.

A flashback to 19th century!!!. Amazing stuff!!!!Definitely need to go here. Every time I´m in New York I pay them a visit. It´s a magical place to transport you the Frick´s era. Love their art collection and how they preserve it. During spring time they have such amazing flowers in their gardens, specially in early spring the tulips looks great!Pay What You Wsh every Sunday from 11am to 1pm. I recommend you to go early this day so you can enjoy it better because afterwards is too crowded.

Best Museum in all of NYC. This intimate and very personal collection of collected art and antiques rivals most museums for its sheer ease of visiting, the interesting layout and the beautiful historic home that it is housed in. The Met and the Moma overwhelm, where this place sucks you in and makes you feel as if you were an invited guest to a private home.
special museum in beautiful mansion. Love the Frick--for both what is there --and the house it is in. It gives one the feeling of stepping back in time. Going there on my next trip.

Gorgeous. This is an amazing museum. The collection staggered and it's displayed in rooms of what was the Frick home - original decor intact. I love that the museum isn't big enough to overwhelm or wear me out.

Imagine living here!. It is a grand structure that you can imagine living in if you were living at that time and very wealthy! Vey pleasant to stroll around the rooms. Manageable size for an outing in the city.

A Gem of a Museum. This beautiful museum tucked away on 71st street and 5th Avenue is the former home of industrialist Henry Clay Frick. Much of the home still has the original furnishings from when the Frick family lived there. At this museum, prepare to be overwhelmed. You will see fabulous Vermeer, Rembrant, Turner, Hobbema, Hals and many, many other famous artists. Additionally, there is fine French furniture from the 18th century as well as bronzes and porcelains. Since the home is a former old mansion, pay particular attention to the architectural detail in each room. Each room has exceptional and unique crown moulding as well as other details. Parquet floors and oriental rugs abound. In the center of the home, there is a magnificent atrium with plants and an enclosed dome roof. Spend as much time as you possibly can over here.

Wow, I am so glad I found this place. My mother in law mentioned about Frick collection to me and suggested us to go for a visit. I was skeptical about it as it is not something on a top 10 must visit NYC place so I was concerned it might disappoint me. I was WRONG, the building, the painting of old masters, the furniture, and the information just blow me away. I will go back when I am in NYC to take an audio tour of the place again.
Lovely small museum.. This is in the former home of Henry Clay Frick and has one of the finest private art collections in the world.

Old New York at its Best. Before looking at the art, take 12 minutes and watch the movie of Henry Clay Frick's life. You will get so much more out of your visit and touring the house. Sunday is pay-what-you-want day from 11-1. This is a great deal, but it also means that it is quite busy. Admission is $20 with discounts for children and students. They have a ton of activities in the winter months such as drawing programs with materials provided--how great is that?!

Wonderful "Home" with Magnificient Collection!. Try to make time for this wonderful Art Collection--it's located off 5th Avenue, on 70th Street. Wonderful mansion built by Henry Frick, one of America's greatest art collectors, and donated to the city at his death. Included in the massive collection are masterpieces of Rembrandt, Bellini, El Greco, Vermeer, and many others, in its 16 rooms, furnished with beautiful period furniture, much as it was when Frick resided there.

Audio Guide Very Helpful. The detail on the audio guide was just right. The voice of the reader easy to understand. Plenty of people, but not so crowded it could not be enjoyed. Took our time to carefully see everything.Shop had so many interesting books/items.

Best Painting Collection per square inch. The Frick Collection includes three Vermeers, Turner, Rembrandt, Goya, Whistler, etc. For a small museum it is unparalleled. Elegant town house with some rooms still furnished in Frick's style. An absolute must for a visitor to New York.
What a gem. The Frick is a beautiful small scale museum with wonderful contents well explained by the audio guides. Interesting but not so large as to be daunting. Perfect

Great Place to see art if you have a short time. I enjoyed the Frick collection. It is not a huge museum, and there is lots to see. It is not overwhelming, so you can spend and hour or more here and feel like you have really enjoyed the experience.

Take me to the Frick.. The home that Henry Clay Frick built ( converted to a museum ) is worth the visit alone.Frick began collecting the masters in 1901. His pet like was to reunite couples and even adversaries such as Moore and Cromwell. The other unusual fact is that no pictures housed in the Frick are permitted to travel. Hence my highlight were the four Turner paintings in the collection.They are extraordinary.

Favorite NYC Museum. The Frick Collection is truly a hidden gem of New York City. Sure, admission prices are steep for a small museum, but it is so worth it. Never crowded, never loud, the museum is perfect for an afternoon retreat on the Upper East Side. You truly get a feel for the culture and history of this city. The free 15 minute tours with admission are a must, as well as the 12 minute overview of the collection! Perhaps the best thing about this museum is that it was actually the Frick residence-- creating truly a unique setting!

A special presentation. the setting is equally impressive, it has such a warm welcoming feel, natural and flowing. The collection speaks for itself. if you have the time, you MUST. We will return when we can spend much more time. You could easily spend an entire afternoon here and never want to leave.

Maybe the best little gallery in the world. Small exquisite and varied enough that your senses are filled, but you don't get museum legs from the trudge. A room of Fragonards (8) bought 100 years ago from the estate of JPMorgan. 2 huge Turner seascapes, Piero della Francesco. The list goes on. A lovely place. But no under 12s and nowhere for even a coffee. Odd omissions. Also on the way out, I tried to photograph a poster in the Foyer for the visiting exhibition: Treasures of the Scottish National Gallery ( I'm a Scot) and was stopped by Security. Why?
Go for the mansion alone! The art is pretty good too!. Lovely afternoon stroll, you can see the entire gallery and a helpful short film in 2 hours. Free on Sundays from 11-1.

Impressive building. I really like the building (house) and the grounds. The collection was okay, but not really to my taste: there weren't any memorable sculptures, there were too many figurines and the like, and the paintings were too 19th century for my taste. It's still worth a visit (mainly for the architecture).

Loved it. What a wonderful collection. The museum is just the right size for an afternoon's visit. There are some amazing pieces here, many of which were part of Mr. Frick's personal collection. Even on a cold and rainy day, with a line of people around the block waiting to get in, it was not overcrowded and felt calm and relaxing.

Henry Frick not at all worth the visit.. The history of Mr. Frick is somewhat amusing considering what he left to the public in the form of a collection. Mr. Frick was the CEO of Carnigie Steel he earned his money by reducing wages of his hard working labor to less than poverty levels. Further he was responsible for a lake that when the clay dam broke (and it was always know that it would break) killed more at one time in the US than another time up until 9/11. Johnstown flood. Thank you Mr. Frick.

Would you like to see masterpieces but can't face the Metropolitan?. The Frick, named after it's founder and the original occupant of the mansion in which the collection is housed, is well worth a visit for anyone with an interest in art. The collection is not limited to a particular period or style but rather represents a certain "balance" on the part of the collector. The Whistlers have a common theme as do the Vermeers. Both Holbeins, the meticulous rendering of St. Thomas More and the more sinister rendering of his persecutor Cranmer are on opposite ends of the fireplace. It is a gentle entry into the world of art if one is traveling with people who might not want the all-day slog of, say, the Metropolitan Museum. The home element adds interest and a sense of comfort.
Art in its original surrounding. Fine art in not to large museum in Manhatten. One day a week you pay as you wish. The location used to be a private home.

Cosy but full of beauties. Before going, I suggest reading the story of Mr Frick. I went because I was looking for a "European-sized museum" (=small) and I did enjoy the collection. Please consider that the majority of masterpieces are from the XIX and XX centuries, so nothing modern in it.

World class collection. I'm so glad we made the decision to visit the Frick during our stay in NYC. This is by no means just a small private collection. The Frick contains works by Vermeer, Turner, El Greco, Whistler, and more all housed in a beautiful and architecturally fascinating mansion. Where the Met or MoMA can be intimidating and overwhelming, the Frick is the opposite. Despite it's somewhat small size compared to other NYC art museums, there are so many magical works of art that no visitor would be disappointed.

A Masterpiece collection not to be missed. We have been to NYC many times but never went to the Frick. We made it a point to go this time the first day. It does not disappoint. It is small and you can spend four hours and see most of it. The masterpieces are well described in the audio tour which is included in the price of admission. The building is beautiful and there is a good description of Mr. Frick and how he acquired his money and his paintings.

Hidden Gem of a museum. A friend recommended this wonderful museum / former residence on 5th Avenue. Don't miss it!! I love the Metropolitan Museum of Art for it's grand scale however this a wonderful, smaller, more serene art experience, less crowded and intimate. Located across the street from the Met and down a few blocks on Museum mile (5th Avenue). You can sit and enjoy in the art in a mansion like atmosphere - be sure to sit in the center garden area. It was fascinating to learn more about the legacy of wealthy steel tycoon, Mr. Frick in an educational movie shown in the theatre. It was simply wonderful to be surrounded by superb art, furniture and sculpture by world famous artists. A New York version of Downton Abbey perhaps, of course smaller with great views of Central Park. I would compare it to Boston's Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum with a bit more New York polish.

The architecture alone is worth seeing. Our visit to the Frick Collection was prompted by a recommendation from a fellow traveller - if it wasn't for this recommendation we might not have known to visit, but I am so pleased we did. The architecture alone is impressive, but the collection itself is phenomenal. There is a clear passion for art evident in this collection, and a theme that would appeal to most visitors. All of this in the heart of one of the busiest cities in the world - a true gem well worth the visit.

Top of the line! Very enjoyable experience.. Tripped over this place not meaning to go- but up we went and it was awesome. Lots of people but the elevator system was very efficient and we did not have to wait 10 minutes. At the top there is a nice shop but the best think is the view. 360 NYC and they have those magnifier cameras... You can look right downtown at the Empire State Building Observatory and see them on top looking at you! It was great - not pricey- and I say its a must do!

Historic Home Tour and Fine Arts Museum in One!. The Frick Collection has long been on my to-do list while in the City. This time, I made it a priority for hubby and I to go. It was worth the wait! The home itself it a work of art. Approaching its pristine upper eastside location on 5th and 70th along Central Park and entering the grand, pristine, residence that served as home to Henry Clay Frick evokes a sense of what it would have been like to be a person of wealth in the Gilded Age. Like other industrialists of his era, Frick amassed a vast personal fortune, and also had a civic and community sense about him, which may be why he willed his home, an architectural masterpiece by the highly popular and leading firm of the time, Carrere and Hastings, its furnishings and his massive personal art collection as a public museum. The art is displayed as Frick himself enjoyed it, not by period or by artist. Before opening as a museum the home underwent some alterations and enlargement to accommodate crowds, but the architectural integrity of the home was not sacrificed, the space was expanded and complimented the original home. The Garden Court, which is like a little sanctuary (indeed, the entire Frick Collection is) was not original to the home, but part of the 1930's expansion. . The collection abounds with masterpieces in each room and special exhibits. Practical info: Admission of $20 is well worth it! Sundays enter between 11am-1pm and you can pay what you will, but it is known to be a bit of a madhouse. There is a complimentary audio self tour so you can go at your own pace. Depending on how much detail you want you could allot 2-3 hours to thoroughly cover the tour. Only the downstairs is open to the public. FYI - Must check coats or keep them on the entire time. Enjoy this intimate museum!

Small but lavish museum. This musuem is a nice surprise to the average visitor of NYC. A wonderful collection of art and antiques , which was a private collection. A great way to spend time, especially on a rainy day. Be prepared to spend time waiting to gain entry, especially if it is cold or rainy due to a problem with checking coats. Not sure if this is a common problem, but happened to us. The cost of admission also includes an audio guide. A very nice bonus! A beautiful court yard to relax in and also a chance there may be some other type of entertainment while you visit. They have a small performance room, which can be for guest singers or lecturers. Really a great place for the reduced fee.

A mansion and its art. A wonderful way to tour a fifth avenue mansion (former home of industrialist Henry Frick) and see some outstanding old master paintings and decorative arts. The central "garden" is a peaceful area to ponder all of the things you have seen. A mini art museum tour combined with a look at a fifth avenue mansion. Not to be missed.

Lovely winter oasis. This collection with a current exhibit from Scotland is a breath of fresh air especially in the winter doldrums. That is not to say it is not great other times of the year, but the plantings, gorgeous building and irreplaceable art work is a combination that cannot be beat.

Excellent collection but avoid Sunday mornings. I am not sure whether it was the extra numbers linked to the reduced cost of entry or the very wet weather; however, we had a 30 minute wait to get into the museum on a Sunday morning. Standing in heavy rain for that long was not pleasant. The main reason for the delay was an understaffed cloakroom. Quite absurd. Rant over, the collection - brought to life by an excellent audio guide - is superb. It's the quality of the setting that, quite rightly, makes the Frick so popular. Highly recommended.

Unforgettable. As a former student of Fine Arts this gallery was one of my priorities for New York City. I was pleasantly surprised that the collection was well represented and compact. You could spend 2 hours there and see mostly everything.The highlights for me where the Boucher 'Four Seasons' paintings and the Drawing Room full of Fragonards. These for me would be a good enough reason to travel across the globe to experience again.Its well organised and wasn't crowded when we visited in early January. The courtyard was restful and the giftshop was very good.
great setting. Loved the courtyard and the mansion it's in really invite closer viewing. Watched a film of the history of the place.

Frick Collection is a Must-See. My husband and I visited the Frick Collection in December of 2014. I had bugged him for ages tor a visit and he told me that he had seen it 30 years ago and that it was not that great. What a difference it makes to make a re-vist. My husband and I were bowled over. The Frick Collection is not something to be just ticked off a list. It is EXTRAORDINARY. Be prepared to invest a minumum of 2 hours if not more. Their website is excellent, but still cannot fully prepare you for the delights that await. It just boggles the mind that even an extraoridinary businessman could acquire a Botticelli that is just as worthy of a place in the hallowed halls of the Uffizi Gellery in Florence. Magnificent Holbeins , Turners, Gainboroughs. It is unbelievable what a treasure trove this is. Do not delay. This is definitely worth seeing on your bucket list. We yearn for a return visit..

A tremendous afternoon with the Masters. The Frick is affordable ($20) and a great place if you only have a couple of hours open. Without rushing, you can experience everything in about 2 - 3 hours, or you can spend the entire day among the works of the masters; Rembrandt, El Greco, Houdon, Clodion, etc. The mansion is just as magnificent as the works that surround you. The intricate attention to detail in every room only serve to highlight the sculptures, paintings, and enamel works in every room.

Excellent. The quality of the Frick Collection was excellent, the building and location were incredible, the staff were very helpful (and there were a lot of them). This is an essential museum to visit when you go to NYC.

A home that's also a museum. Henry Frick, a Pittsburgher who made his millions in steel and coke, built this NYC mansion with the idea of it becoming a museum upon his death, and it was a brilliant idea. I make this a stop on every visit. The indoor garden court with fountain, not part of the original design, but an area enclosed from what used to be a carriage-way, is beautiful and relaxing. The free audio guide is excellent. The collection is arranged as Frick did it in his home; paintings, sculpture and furnishings are not grouped by artist or era. They also have occasional special exhibits. Scottish masters on my most recent visit and it was spellbinding. Definitely get the free audio guide. It adds a lot to the visit. This museum usually isn't too crowded, especially at opening time. It's an easy walk from the 6 train at 68th Street.

If you are an art lover, do this!. This is a truly awesome collection, and the audio tour provided with your admission ticket brings it all to life. So intimate and beautiful compared with any large gallery, and such a varied collection of great artists. We enjoyed it tremendously and will return.

Glorious Cultural Oasis. For once in NY small really is beautiful. Wonderful building and location by the park. And the art - just breathtaking! Highlights for me were the Holbeins (Portraits of Moore and Cromwell) and the Rembrandt self portrait. And then the Vermeers and the Bronzino....enough already! Make sure you visit if you are in town. Don't know why I hadn't been before and I will be back. Its a glorious cultural oasis in the middle of the city.

World-class art in an intimate setting. An exquisite collection of European paintings, sculpture, furniture, decor viewed in an intimate setting of the Frick mansion (as opposed the city-block long Met Museum). Henry Frick had the money,but the daughter, Helen, guided the collection as the art history expert and philanthropist. She also set up the art reference library, which conducts important research and conservation of all major European art (note: movie "Monument Men"). You walk into each room and see works by the masters. There is one long room where you can view Rembrandt, Goya, Joshua Reynolds, J.W. Turner, etc. all at once. A round alcove holds several Whistler portraits. As a fan of British history, I could see closely the Hans Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, two history changers. Other must-sees: the inner courtyard, the Bouchard season paintings in the hallway, and an amazing French clock with moving figurines.

Unique Way to See Art. To put it simply, the Frick Collection is so cool! The histories of the collector, the home and the collection are fascinating. Seeing such a personal collection of art in such a unique setting was a very special experience. We really felt as if we were guests in someone's home. Make sure to watch the short presentations in the Music Room for a full appreciation of the history.
wonderful museum. This is a gem of a museum, located in a beautiful old mansion in Central Park east. It is filled with a wonderful variety of artwork including furniture, paintings, and sculptures.
A Must See. This is one of the best collections that I have seen and wonderful to see it in what was originally the Frick House. Do not miss if you are in NYC.

Fabulous Art in a Fantastic Building. This museum not only has great art but the building that it is housed in is a magnificent piece of art history. Built for one of the richest man in the United states, it was given as a sumputous backdrop for his art collection. Complete with a pool the estate on Fifth Avenue is breathtaking in it brilliance and affords us a glimpse at what life was like for the highly monied class of early New York. No expense was was left out and it is a marvel. They hae a very good gift shop and I always enjoy the movies shown there as well as the docent's tour of the facility.

Unique Collection. You will be pleasantly surprised with some of the paintings in this museum. It's like listening to the b-side of an old record and finding out you like it better than the popular song. I think it may have something to do with the fact that it feels like you are looking at paintings in someone's house rather than a large exhibition space. If you haven't been, you should go.
Expensive but beautiful. Great audio, beautiful setting. Vintage restrooms... Reminded me of childhood and 30s fixtures. Marvelous interior garden.

Small museum, big heart!!. We visited the Frick on a cold miserable day in New York and it lifted our spirits with it's beautiful architecture, sensational Art collection and wonderful view over Central Park. An intimate museum definitely worth a visit!

Must see attraction. In a city where there is so much to see and do the Frick collection should be at the top of the list.An amazing art collection housed in a beautiful home.Hint...go on a Sunday between 11-1 where you can pay what you wish for entry.

Art History in Nutshell. Liked:What a collection! Something for everyone, plus you get to see the amazing mansion.Disliked: why are places in NYC in winter kept so HOT? I felt like I needed shorts and a t shirt under my outer clothes.
Don't miss it. Not only is the art fantastic, so is the house, wonderful architecture and overlooking Central park.
A gem. I loved this intimate, personal museum where you go from room to room and see just what it was that the owner wanted to achieve. Clever, intelligent but encompassable.

Size isn't everything. A wonderful museum housed in a magnificent mansion across the road from central Park. The teenagers had zero interest in a Museum but they were pleasantly surprised and in awe, at times, by Mr Frick's collection. As it is small with audio tour they could see works by the Masters, for example, in a classic, elegant NY home in a short time. A small easy to swallow dose of culture for he kids, that were reluctant to be cultured..."is there wifi there"...oh dear. A wonderful and charming experience for their parents. Sydney Fam

First class experience, superb. The staff are calm, the surroundings sublime and the exhibition exquisite. This is a fabulous museum which takes an enormous amount of care to explain what you are looking at (audio guides come as part of the $20 entry fee), and the entire experience left one feeling as though you had just done something worthwhile. Highly recommended. It takes about 2 hours to do it justice by the way.

great collection, but hard to navigate. I loved a lot of things about the Frick, the collection is spectacular and the setting is absolutely gorgeous. I love art museums in homes, so I was so excited to finally get over to the Frick. However, I think the overall visitor experience could use some work. The free audio tour is a great audio tour, however I found it hard to navigate my way through the collection, because some of the audio tour labels are small, clear and not in a uniform place, so it was hard to know where to find them and there seemed to be no organization as far as the numbering of stops went. I also think the map visitors are given is tiny and hard to read. My only other complaint is that at some point in my visit the garden court closed, but I was given no notice of this by staff, so I didn't get to even walk through, seems like that would be an easy enough thing to notify visitors about.Overall, I think the Frick is a brilliant collection and worth a visit. Even if just to see the More and Cromwell Holbeins, but it's the collection that makes it great, not the overall experience.

Delightful. My husband really wanted to see The Frick. I was less keen but glad I went. Lovely home with superb collection. Large but not overwhelming. I really enjoyed. When one has money and good taste the result is outstanding.

Iconic Art in Lovely Mansion. On Fifth Avenue just across from Central Park, this home turned museum houses beautiful art, furniture, and sculpture including some iconic paintings. Because Frick required the trust never to let any of the art that he purchased leave the mansion, none of it is ever on tour to other museums. However, tours come to the Frick. We saw Masterpieces from the Scottish National Gallery. An excellent audio tour is included in the admission price. Be sure to use it. I suggest arriving when it opens because, like all Manhattan museums, it is very crowded. Bathrooms in the basement. No cafe. Young children are not admitted.

Amazing and wonderful. A highlight of our visit to NYC. A wonderful collection, in a grand mansion. The Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell are here, in the "flesh"! And a walk across Central Park to access the Frick, is a bonus!!

One of Many Superb New York Museums. The Frick is a far more modest undertaking then say the Met but the building and collection are nonetheless dazzling. In many ways a more manageable undertaking but still impressive

beautiful collection. very beautiful museum,,with admission is included a headset where you can learn about different portraits around the museum. Interesting history and museum is a nice size and not as overwhelming as bigger ones but still $20, Would highly recommend.

A true gem in the heart of NYC. The Frick collection reminded me a lot of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. A private mansion turned into a museum. A private collection made it available to the public. Among Botticelli, and Titian, and Tintoretto and Duccio there are three amazing, extremely rare Piero della Francesca. It's a museum off the main stream touristic path and truly gives the visitor a chance to enjoy the art it treasures.

Another view of a wealthy collector of (fortunately) good taste. As often, my title is the story; a great collection, showing the view of a very rich person with taste, who, eventually, in effect, turned his hobby into an obsession and then shared it with the world in turning his home into an exhibition space (See Phillips in Washington, for the same)(Why didn't Mellon and Lehman do the same with their vast collections, now in the Metropolitan Museum? At least the name "Lehman" might have now smell a little sweeter! On the other hand it's good to have the plunder of those robber barons in public hands now

The home that became a museum. The Flick collection is a wonderful, quiet art oasis whose collections span many centuries and schools of European art. Walking through the rooms and salons of this once private home, provides a welcome break from the bustling outside city and the nearby more crowded MoMA and MoMART.
beautiful. this is a small museum, but nevertheless is rich of art and furnitures , it is the perfect museum if you don't have all day

One word - amazing. This is one of the finest private art collections I have ever seen All of the masters are there, even three Vermeers.. Wonderful, wonderful paintings, sculptures and furniture. This was Frick's home and to see these wonderful things in the setting of a home gives one much more empathy with the artist and the subject.Each individual item picked by Frick and his wife and to share in this is a joy. Cannot recommend it highly enough.
A Gem of A Museum. WOrth a visit. I'd like to live there. Add it to a tour of small NYC Museums and you will be rewarded with a great collection and a beautiful structure.

Not my cup of tea. My painting teacher sent me here. I went the day after my day at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Now the history of the place interests me, but the collection is the Old Masters and that is just not my cup of tea.

Amazing collection. My boyfriend and I thoroughly enjoyed our recent visit to the Frick Museum on the Upper East Side. I'm not an art expert, but the Frick has an amazing collection of European masterpieces of artists such as Vermeer and Rembrandt. Henry Clay Frick was an interesting guy. It's also within walking distance to/from the MoMA and Guggenheim, and it is right across the street from Central Park. We spent approximately 90 minutes here.

Serene experience. Thankfully no kids allowed.. Avoid the crowds of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and enter a residence that holds treasures from the renaissance to today. Most people appear to be there to look at the art, not just 'tick the box' of another tourist attraction.
Go to the Frick. The Frick is an interesting venue with fascinating history. It is definitely worth the stop to see these collections.

Rembrandt self portrait. It's not really my kind of collection - too much Fragonard for me!But it's a nice place to visit at least once. & there is a great late Rembrandt self portrait here. Worth going for this. & a wonderful GoyaBut it's $20 ($10 for students)
Best collection. I love this museum. The building itself is wonderful and everything inside is worth seeing. The history of collection is something to be appreciated.

intimate viewing of art treasures. We walked through Central Park to discover the marvellous Frick collection. Wonderful paintings and other art works, all viewed in an intimate setting and we were able to get close up and personal to the art which made it all the more enjoyable. Well worth a visit if you like art and are in NYC!

Interesting paintings and furnitures. Went there in Octobre 2013. This is a small collection (or a big private collection, depending how you see it) with quite a bit of interresting painting and furnitures. It is a expensive though and you're done with it quite quickly.

Don't miss it. When you are planning your NYC trip, and wonder if you should see the Frick Collection or not, do it! There were so many wonderful paintings and sculptures, so much incredible furniture. The carved panelling, the magnificent stone, the parquetry floors, the rugs, the window fastenings, the curtains, the velvet walls, the lights, the cornices. But I think the most amazing thing about the Frick Collection is to see so many priceless works of art in such an elegant intimate setting. Walking through a private home being able to stand a foot from masterpieces like Vermeer's Mistress and Maid. You must see the introductory film before you look at the collection as it answers so many questions before you begin. I loved the audio tour with commentary on Mr Fricks' negotiations of his purchases, his personal involvement in the placement of paintings, and the way he walked the West Gallery at night. I adored the whole experience. And the shop is a perfect place for gifts to take home.

DO not Miss!. It wasn't until I moved to New York that I discovered this gem.There is something about this place that elevates it beyond a normal museum. It is amazingly well maintained and it feels very timeless.Do not miss it if you are headed to 5th Ave to go to The Met!

Amazing Art in an Amazing Mansion. The Frick Collection is definitely in my Top 10 things to see in NYC. The "residence-like" venue was totally unexpected; the quality of the art was totally unexpected outside of a major museum. The Frick ranks up there with the National Art Gallery in Washington DC having some very fine European art and hosting some of finest traveling exhibits of famous paintings (like Vermeer's "Girl with the Pearl Earring" which we had previously seen on a separate trip to the Frick the past year in December, 2013).

Blast from the past. See how the 1% lived in the gilded age (livin' large so to speak.) This facility, originally home to Henry Clay Frick was converted to a museum but gives you some view to how he lived and some great works of art. A few notes: the exhibit does not travel so you can only see some of these pieces here. Visiting exhibits are also hosted and those we saw were interesting and well -presented too. No children under 10. Entrance fee $20 for adults, discounts for students (with ID) and seniors. Note to Pittsburgh folks: this is an interesting contrast to Frick's home in Pittsburgh (Clayton): much less "homey" and more museum. Right next to the park so in good weather, nice opportunity for stroll as well.

One of the best world Museums. Probably the best collection of classic art, collected and exhibited by one of the most impressive specialists in the beg 19th century. The location is also worth discovering.
A fantastic collection. The Frick is my favorite gallery when I visit NY. It has an exceptional collection of masterpieces. And it generally not overcrowded with camera flashing tourists.
Best museum in Manhattan!. Small museum in a Victorian mansion. Excellent collection of art in a comfortable setting. Unlike a more sterile museum, this one displayed the art in a home.
Fantastic. This is the most perfect gallery. The atmosphere is peaceful, the staff are kind and the pictures fantastic. The best of everything in one small package.

Interesting place, a fine artistic taste. A big colection, many good artistic works from diferent life times. If you go there be sure to take a walk on the little square where is the fountain. Important: You can´t take pictures inside the place, so keep this present to avoid troubles and the entrance for adult is $20.

Exquisite. Beautiful collection, superbly presented. Really easy to take in. Not overwhelming like the Met.. This museum is not as busy or as overwhelming as the Met. It's fabulous the way the collection is displayed the way the collector wanted it put together. It's not logical, but it makes sense and you can cover it all without exhausting yourself.

awesome!. the frick museum is truly a hidden gem of a place.
being in such a private setting the museum is more than worth the admission price.
we loved it!

The highlight of New York. My family loved it. Great art but not an overwhelming number of pieces. The audio tour was very educational, both for the house and rooms and the art. Two wonderful Vermeers are on display. The Renoir is kind of hidden by the stairs.

Super boring and underwhelming . I did not find this museum interesting at all. Especially having seen MOMA, MET, and natural history museum. The museum is basically all self portraits of different people. I don't enjoy that kind of art. It's also a little pricey for what you get. I liked that they had a free bag and coat check.

In an out within 2 hours. I like that there are other, smaller museums to tackle in NYC. This is a former residence and that makes the space much more interesting to me. I really loved the architecture and there's enough documentation on the Frick family and this building. We came to see a special exhibit and we purchased tickets beforehand. So glad we did. It was raining that day and there was a line outside. We were able to go right in. Also, we were 30 minutes early, and they didn't mind. Apparently, they just want you to have a ticket and won't hold you to the time slot that you signed up for. So nice that they're flexible.

Art Heaven. There is nothing to dislike about this Museum/Mansion but plenty to like. Great Art housed in a magnificent purpose-built mansion where each room takes you on its own journey....the Fragonard Room is so romantic, the Living Hall so masculine,the Enamel room with all the religious arts......feels more like you are a guest exploring the home of the host. Worth a trip just for Rembrandt's self portrait.......Do Not Miss!!
Fabulous Frick!. Private family art in their mansion...... impeccable! Loved the feeling of old money and art, in a perfect "tango" of the ambiance of Old NYC!

Great Museum, and Manageable. What I liked most about this place after the fabulous collection on display, is that it is on the smaller side as museums go so it is very manageable. Certainly you can spend many hours there, but you can also see all of it in an hour if you have limited time.A nice touch is the portable audio device is included with your admission.

Great small museum and audio tour. Took advantage of Sunday morning, pay what you wish day. Spent a delightful two hours in the 'best small museum in the world'. Not all of the art was to my taste, but combined with the house, it was well worth my time to visit. Highly recommended.

Great Audio Guide. We enjoyed the audio guide as we explored the beautiful collection at the Frick Museum. The Limoges enamels are stunning and rich in color. The museum itself is beautiful and we liked our brief tour.

Small but excellent collection.. We visited on a Sunday during the holiday season. Sunday between 11-1, you pay what you want for admission. If you want to take advantage of this option, arrive by 12. A line forms. We arrived close to noon and the line was almost a block and 1/2 long. It took the hour for us to get to the point of paying. This is a private home that was built with the plan of turning it into a museum upon Frick's death. It is not huge and the lobby entry, coat drop off and ticket purchase areas are tight. If you do not check your coat, you will have to wear it the whole time you are in the museum. They do not tell you the audio tour is free. Signage on painting and sculpture are limited and the audio tour would have been nice to have. For $2.00 they sell a written description where the audio tour is given out.  In the back of the museum to the right of the garden/fountain they show a film on Frick, the collection and any visiting exhibits. The film is a good overview and worth watching.  The collection on display at the time of our visit included paintings, sculpture, furniture, silver and terra cotta sculpture. An excellent exhibit from the Scottish Museum was on display. I would allow 1-2 hours.

A unique experience. We had 12 days in NYC in October and had been told by a friend that the Frick was a must see. My wife was especially keen to go, me less so. However we walked up to the house and I thought well I'm here now I should go in - and I'm so pleased I did. We were both very impressed by both the house itself and the collection and would encourage everyone to add this little treasure to the "must do" list of New York attractions.

Just the best sumeum in NYC. This beautiful house near Central Park was built by Henry Clay Frick to display his extensive collection of Fine Art. He only bought the very finest of objects throughout the world and it is so beautifully displayed.

How the 1% lived back in the day. This is a must-see: a stunning collection of art and furnishings in a magnificent mansion built for the industrialist Henry Clay Frick in the early 20th century. Only in New York...

best and most varied arts collection. the Frick is incredible just for the architecture and interior design of this historic building; the collection is varied and important and another enjoyable experience in itself.

Exquisite!. Frick House holds some of the most beautiful artwork I've seen. While I visited there were paintings on show from The museum of Scotkand! Such a beautiful stroll through the house!Well worth the walk up 5th Avenue! Highly recommend!

A wonderful morning spent wandering around this amazing collection. If you are interested in seeing some of the most amazing pieces of art curated by an individual make a trip to the Frick Collection. With your entry fee you are given a head set and can listen to a narration on certain pieces in this collection.I took my 16 year old son, and 22 year old daughter who are not into Art .However each one of us found something in this collection that we loved, from the Ecstasy of St Francis of Assisi , to the Sculpture of Hercules and the Hydra, to the El Greco's. Please if visiting New York make a trip to this amazing home and museum .

Really Big Collections for a Small Museum. One of Clayton Frick's many Mansions, I understand this is not the really fancy one there is a really nice one, I believe in Pittsburgh, but then again it might be on Riverside Drive. He had so many!! A nice respite from the City. I always loved the collections in this museum, especially the Vermeers and ElGrecos. The sculptures have their own section now that they have opened another part of the house in the front, or something in that vein. The other detail of the house I loved architectually is the atrium in the middle of the mansion. If you are a student or an Educator as about discounts for the admission. But know this is a private museum, so don't expect them to let you in free, however I have gotten as much as 50% which is much. I don't know if this discount still exists since it is never adverstised, but it never hurts to ask.

Step back in time. Visit the Frick if you feel like getting a glimpse of the 19th century. Such a special place, exhibits s are always changing but there are permanent visits which are always there. the physical building is so gorgeous.

Great Art Collection in an Incredible Setting. The Frick is really special because the art collection is housed in someone's home. There really is a lot to see if you consider the interior design and architecture aspects of the building itself, which lends great ambience and sets it apart from many other museums. The collection is also world-class. They have hosted some really amazing exhibits as well. I'd advise arriving on foot via public transportation. There is a subway stop nearby (4 or 6 line).

Oh My, What a Treat for the Eyes!. We visited the Frick Collection on Dec. 28th. Being between two holidays, the crowds were something else. Even so, we were glad to visit this incredible collection in what was built as the Frick's home. The architecture is amazing, the art collection is incredibly beautiful, and the furnishings add a wonderful dimension to the appeal of this special place. If you are in a wheelchair as I am, or disabled in some other way, be sure to go to the front of the line where there is a special needs entrance. One other person can accompany you. The elevator is small, and once upstairs you wait while the person with you buys your tickets. If you arrive between 11-1 pm on a Sunday, you pay any amount. Otherwise it is $20 per person -- and it is worth it! And oh, be sure to get the free audio guides. Most paintings have a number that you enter and then listen to an informative narrative. It is easy to do. Frick had a desire to "reunite" couples whose portraits had ended up in different places. These are something to see! He also liked paintings that seemed to radiate light. Wow! Many Dutch masterpieces were on display during our visit. I took several paintings home with me, on postcards, that is. The gift shop is small, but nice. And the courtyard with its flowers and fountains is a serene pace. I highly recommend the Frick Collection. I am so glad it was left for all to enjoy.
A visit to NYC isn't complete without visit to the Frick. A respite from the busy streets, a viewing of the great masters in a few rooms. The Vermeers alone are worthy of visit after visit.
Excellent private art collection. The collection is housed in a 19th century mansion extremely well maintained, so the atmosphere and context makes the art pieces more relevant and beautiful

Between 4 and a half and 5 stars.... Could not quite decide. It is a truly impressive collection, thanks to the exquisite taste of Mr Frick. The house itself is also quite splendid. So, why the hesitation concerning that 5th star?Well, firstly it is quite small which makes it difficult to appreciate everything in the collection, especially when it is busy as was the case during Sunday's 'pay what you wish' session. Some of the labeling of items in glass cases was so discrete, presumably so as not to detract from the items being displayed, that it was actually hard to read. It is almost impossible not to draw comparisons with the Metropolitan Museum which is just a few short blocks away and where one can see so much more for a 'pay what you wish' admission charge 7 days a week instead of the usual $20 charge to enter the Frick.All that said it is a very fine collection very well presented. Do take time to watch the video which is informative without being unduly long and take time to appreciate the courtyard space.

Nice house....museum. Not your average museum. It is more like visiting a nice house. Great paintings, nice furniture, sculptures, bronzes, etc. The indoor garden with the fountain is so relaxing. I really enjoyed my visit

A Delightful Gem. Several friends suggested we visit the Frick, so we did. Not an aficionado of Modern Art, I'm more interested in Impressionists and earlier works. What a delight to see Gainsboroughs, a Renoir, Monet, and Hans Holbein the Younger's Sir Thomas More....and all so accessible. We were concerned that we wouldn't. have time to see the whole collection because we arrived in the afternoon on Veterans' Day, when the hours were shortened, unbeknownst to us (this information was not on their website). But it only takes a few hours to see it all, which is another reason to go. I highly recommend this museum.

One of the best small art collections. The Vermeers, the Holbeins, the Boucher room, the very tall Renoir of a woman with two young daughters, the many other fine paintings...and the wood floors. This museum is just bite-sized, comfortably viewed in just a few hours.
Unforgettable. Perfect sanctuary with incredible collection of work. Do not miss it. One of the most significant Rembrandt self-portraits in existence.

Small and beautiful museum. New York has some world famous museums, with large and incredible collections. The Frick is not one of those. It is a mansion housing the collection of Mr. Frick, who bequeathed it to establish a public gallery; he left an endowment so additional works of art could be added. None of the collection is allowed to leave the building, so you haven’t seen any of the works of art anywhere else. Visitors can see many masterpieces by famous artists (El Greco, Titian, Whistler, Vermeer, etc.) as well as fine furniture and statuary, all pretty much as they would be seen in an active residence. It’s a small collection in a gem of a museum, just down Fifth Avenue from the Met.

Wonderful Collection . We had a rainy day in NYC and decided to visit the Frick where we had never been. It's wonderfully doable in as long a time as you wish to spend there. Henry Clay Frick collected various artists such as Ver Meer, Rembrandt, Whistler, Monet, Titian, Botticelli, Hals, Van Dyke, Holbein and Turner to name just a few and displayed them in his lovely home on the upper East Side along with sculptures and exquisite furnishings. He designated his home to be a museum in his will. The Trust added a lovely entry way with a fountain and pool and flowers flanked by stone benches by enclosing a carriage way that ran from 70th to 71st Street. It's a lovely place to sit and enjoy the splash of the fountain. There are often visiting collections to see. When we were there the Royal Museum of Scotland had loaned the Frick a wonderful Collection of Scottish artists. The Frick is a small, intimate and wonderful museum in which to spend a morning or afternoon.

What a special place!. Vermeer, Rembrandt, French inlaid tables, garden court, splendid woodwork, chandeliers, oriental carpets--this is how the Bill Gateses of a century ago would have lived, collecting art and furniture of the highest quality, rivaling royal collections in some cases. Sunday mornings there is a line, since payment is as one wishes. It's one of my favorite places in the city, large enough to offer one amazing seletion after another, yet small and intimate enough to spend time gazing at the wonders in one beautifully panelled room after another. The collection shows that it takes more than mere moolah to be a discriminating collector. Across Fifth Ave. is Central Park, so go for a stroll if there's time!

Lovely museum. I had never been to the Frick museum which I am sad to admit. I finally went this weekend and it was such a wonderful way to spend a Sunday afternoon. We went on Sunday at 11 which is when the museum is a pay what you wish rate for two hours. We did have to wait a bit outside but it was very much worth it. We each gave a dollar for the admittance. I particularly liked the people that worked there. As soon as you entered the man navigated us to the correct line and told everyone that if you had a coat you could check it or wear it. You were not allowed to carry it. I particularly liked this because at another museum we had not been told this when we entered and half way through our visit was very rudely told that we had to put our coats on. We also got the free audio tour and then spent almost two hours walking through the grounds. The home is lovely and the collection is varied and interesting. I also liked how when you put the number in the audio guide a picture would pop up showing you what was being spoken about. This is a lovely museum and I will be back!

I love this place. No visit to New York is complete without a visit to the Frick. As I said in an earlier review, it's one of the best smaller art museums in the world, located in a building that displays the art to excellent advantage. The permanent collection gives a wonderful overview of western art from the late Middle Ages to the nineteenth century, with treasures such as the Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Sir Thomas Cromwell, the three Vermeers, the marvelous Bronzino portrait of a young man, the Rembrandts, the Gainsboroughs, the Turners, and so on. Frick's taste in art was limited, perhaps, but what he collected was first-rate. This time there was a rewarding special show of ten works from the Scottish National Gallery. Time spent in the Frick is invariably well spent.

Great little museum and collection. If you prefer smaller museums (like me) this is an excellent choice. Located directly across from Central Park on 5th Avenue, this is an excellent option for seeing beautiful works of art but in a smaller more intimate setting.Highly recommend as the collection is beautiful!

Time capsule. The period of art and how it is displayed is not really my cup of tea. They do a good job of engaging children in art as evidenced by the many groups of eager students. Just didn't think the overall effect is relevant to today. The house is lovely, but looks a little unloved.

Remarkable Colletion. The building alone is worth the price of admission. The collection is priceless.The history of the building and it's occupants is a trip back in time to see the beauty that unlimited resources created.

Good house. Good little house off the park. Nothing too fancy just the usual billionaire's pad.Art wise it's perfect for a 2 hour escape into another world. Not too busy. Good staff. 20$ per ticket seems pricey but that's new york.

Wonderful collection in a beautiful setting. With kids 10 and 12 we really enjoyed this visit as so many times before. Wonderful selection of Vermeer, Turner, Whistler, Velasquez and El Greco....and so many more. The building in itself, in its splendour on the boarder of being a bit "American" in its overwhelming impression, is an experience of itself. The balanced distribution of paintings in the rooms provides a very convincing holistic totality- pictures for the soul.
Girl with pearl earring. Went to see special visiting "The Girl with a Pearl Eearing" and enjoyed the history and full collection of this museum.

Fascinating small scale museum and gallery. An interesting and eclectic collection, in a beautiful 19th century mansion. A few relaxing hours are enough to take it all in, so it's good for filling in gaps in a sightseeing schedule, as well as being lively in its own right.

A perfect museum experience!. The Frick is the most delightful and worthwhile museum to visit in New York. It has collections of the highest quality and and retains a human scale for their display, as it is still in the house of Henry Frick, the original collector. Though everything now in the museum was not purchased by Frick himself, later acquisitions (made with great discernment) and special exhibitions show respect for the founder's ideals. The crowds are always manageable, not overwhelming, and the lovely atrium offers a perfect quiet space to rest the feet. And the little bookstore always provides some unexpected temptations and perfect gifts.

Frick's European Art Collection. This is a fun destination to see how the robber barons lived back in the 1800's. This collection is still in Frick's mansion. Frick didn't like American artists, so it's all European. But! He did deign to buy some Gilbert Stuart-including a famous portrait of our own George Washington. Nice!

Great Small Museum. Took a break from shopping and visited the Frick Museum. I had always wanted to go to this museum. There is a brief movie that was very informative about the history of the museum and would recommend taking that in for a good overview. The museum is small but packed with excellent paintings. I would highly recommend the handheld audio guide which is included with the price of admission in order to gain more insight into each room and the paintings. Being an art novice I liked hearing the story behind each painting and made the visit much more enjoyable. The size of the collection is such that it is not overwhelming and seems very accessible. I would highly recommend this museum.

Hidden Gem. This collection is a hidden gem which gives you the chance to see a coherent art collection assembled by one man, so expressing his taste, but of exceptional quality throughout. The setting is of a manageable size for a single visit and is a lovely tranquil spot to spend half a day.

Mansion with Masterpieces. The Museum is just off Central Park so a nice stroll from hotels near Times Square. Not only does it house masterpieces from Rembrandt, Whistler and others, the mansion itself is interesting to walk through. Its a glimpse of what life was like in the 30's for the ultra wealthy.

If you can only visit one museum make it The Frick. This was a lovely museum and it doesn't take too long to see it all. It's a private collection and includes three Vermeers and when we went there was a special exhibition from the Scottish National Gallery on as well. There is a lovely courtyard and gardens outside and it's in a central location easy to access. Well worth seeing if you are an art lover as Mr. Frick's collection is outstanding!

A real gem!. Finally made it to this wonderful home and collection. I was absolutely delighted with the atmosphere, property, and of course the collection. I walked through each room slowly soaking in and appreciating everything I saw and then decided before leaving to walk through each room once again. Well worth your time. I found the paintings spectacular. Mr. Frick's left a wonderful collection that is well displayed that is well worth your time and money. I spent the remainder of the day reflecting on the various master pieces I was able to look at closely marveling over the skill and technique of each work of art.

Perfect way to enjoy a morning. We visited The Frick Collection for the first time this morning. Every aspect was a delight. The building is interesting with beautiful rooms which enhance the artworks rather than compete with them.The paintings are magnificent, so many glorious old Masters. Stunning silver and fabulous clocks, Most keeping perfect time. Wonderful to view everything close up, and with a very comfortable number of people.The staff were all friendly and very helpful and informative.The size of the exhibition is perfect, we enjoyed it all and there was no feeling of being "galleried-out" or exhausted.

Frick is a hidden gem!. Frick Museum is a hidden gem! It is a small building with many masterpieces to see. You will be very impressed in everyway. The building is beautiful not too big and yet small enough not to overwhelm you. The fountains, courtyard and the furnishing add to the very special athmospher here. Audio tour is available. Not to be missed!
wonderful. wonderful collection of art. just down the street from the Met, it is a true gem. Be sure to get the free audio headset.
A microcosm of western art. Amazingly eclectic collection of art masterpieces in a beautiful and accessible setting. Gainsborough, Reynolds and Rembrandt were worth every penny, plus Renoir, Degas.

Pre Christmas break. An amazing collection and definitely worth a visit even if just to see the home in which this collection is displayed. It contains at least one art work of most every famous artist, it was mind blowing moving from room to room to see what had been assembled! The Gray Line bus tour guide could not believe we had been, we were the first she had encountered! Do not miss this!

A very great pleasure. Having been to NYC many times, this was the first time at the Frick. The collection is mind boggling. This rivals any other painting collection in any city in the world. When it says you will see "Masters" it delivers in a magnificent way. This is a don't miss.

Superb building with world class contents. Miss this when in New York, and you will kick yourself.The building and its contents are not massive not like the Met, but that in itself is massive attraction, the contents and interior are beautiful and would out shine most large City's major galleries.Guggenheim first walk down 5th a few blocks then visit the Frick you will not have a better morning anywhere in the World. Fantastic.

Beautiful place. I felt like I was in a home, not in a museum. Great experience. The garden is unique. Wonderful Paintings from Bellini, Goya and El greco belong to the permanent collection. I would came back many times.

my favorite museum-great small collection, relaxing, approachable. The Frick is my favorite museum because it is relatively small, with a great collection of diverse Western art (and furniture and clocks) and a relaxing atrium with fountain and green growing things. Unlike a larger museum, where there is always something new to see and where you can be overwhelmed by the size, in the Frick you can see and remember the pieces you like -- and, if you're like me, you go back and revisit them, seeing them anew and, like old friends, experiencing their familiarity and their end fascination of seeing something new or different each time. Just as Frick exercised his taste in choosing the works, I exercise mine in visiting -- I avoid the Gainsboroughs, the Fragonards, and the Sargents, which others love, and look at El Greco's Saint Jerome, flanked by Holbein's Thomas More and (the dastardly) Thomas Cromwell; I go to Salisbury Cathedral and to the Turners, and to the Polish Rider and an Ingres portrait of a woman.Their recent visiting shows -- Girl with a Pearl Earring, the current dozen masterpieces from the Scottish National Gallery -- are fun: new exhibits, but small enough to be manageable.Go to the Metropolitan, of course; but for a relaxing two hours in the company of great works of Western art, visit the Frick.

Magnificent Art and Architecture. I enjoyed a magnificent European art collection in this fabulous house. Henry Clay Frick built this structure to serve as his family's home and to house his art during his lifetime and after his life ceased. The tour was very enjoyable.

Amazing collection in its original setting. . Wonderful collection with informative audio guide. Great to see the collection in the rooms that were designed to display them. Courteous and helpful staff and a well stocked and informative shop. Walk from the park to enjoy the house from the outside too.

Superb collection. I spent a couple of hours enjoying the artwork, sculptures, furniture and architecture in this museum. It is a superb collection and very well laid out. The audio guide allowed me to focus on the key pieces and provided interesting facts and comments. The staff was very knowledgeable and friendly. Highly reccommended.

WOW - Wealth or what?. This collection is well worth seeing - It's a mixture of works of art together which makes it even more interesting - You see different artistic masterpieces next to each other based on what the founder wanted.A MUST SEE - especially as it's next to the majesty of Central park!Steel to artistic masterpieces in a fabulous house turned into a museum - who wouldn't wish they were fortunate enough to bring all these masterpieces together in one place?
Amazing collection. If you like art and stately homes, this is a must. Free audio is essential to guide you through the rooms and the amazing collection of art
Wonderful gallery. Small wonderful gallery in an old mansion. It was as interesting seeing the old furniture as well as the wonderful pieces of art.
A True Jewel in NYC. A born and bred New Yorker and museum goer... this was my first visit and WOW!!! What a collection and what a lovely way to spend a few hours.

A Special Collection of One Man's Art Favorites. When you visit The Frick Collection, make sure to stop at the small theater near the rear of the building to watch the video about Henry Clay Frick–how he made his fortune, why he built his mansion on 5th Avenue between 70th and 71st around 1915 to house his collection, and how the building was expanded after his wife's death.For a world-class museum, it feels almost intimate. Most of the pieces are exhibited in the rooms and in the style selected by Mr. Frick when the building served as his personal residence. the collection features many portraits, with a number of Gainsboroughs, Whistlers, and a rare Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington.When we visited last week, the special exhibition displayed10 works selected from the National Gallery of Scotland, several of which were on loan for the first time. Also, in recognition of the 300th anniversary of ElGreco's death, the three El Greco works that are part of the permanent collection were displayed together for the first time.If you want to visit that won't overwhelm you with its sheer size, The Frick Collection is a fine choice. You can easily view the entire collection in slightly over 2 hours.

A Lovely Collection. What I really liked was the size of this museum because it is manageable to tour and still have time left in the day to do something else. It is housed in a mansion and is very interesting.

A PRIVATE MASTERPIECE!. The Frick flies under the radar of the likes of The Met, MOMA and Guggenheim, but impresses never the less! I found myself not only admiring the art but the furnishings, home and the grounds. Truly Beautiful!!!

You only need an afternoon!. This gem of a collection complied by Henry Frick is housed in a mansion he built on Fifth and 70th and even though the collection is quite terrific, your visit can be completed in an afternoon without being overwhelmed by a huge museum which can be exhausting. Mr Frick's eye for art comes through this wonderful gift to art lovers. The price of admission includes the audio guide and is well worth it!
Become a member. The Frick is an amazing collection, amassed by one mogul, housed in his beautiful home. Be sure to watch the intro film and take time to enjoy all the rooms and special exhibits.

Love the Frick!. What a fabulous place to visit! The amount of art in this building by such famous artists is astonishing. I could've spent all day here. The audio tour is complimentary and make sure to make time for it. Our timing was off so we missed the movie but it gives me another reason to come back one day.

A Jewel Box Museum. This is an intimate setting for a world class collection that includes of Turner, El Greco, and Vermeer, to name a few. The special exhibits are always interesting and appropriate to the setting. I have also enjoyed concerts and the Sunday sketching events that are offered. I enjoy The Frick Collection so much that I support it as a member.

Great concentration of Master Pieces.. The Frick Collection is a must see for all. The property and mansion itself are worth the visit. It has some of the greatest and most expensive art works in the world. What I liked the most was you could get quite close the art work and the whole tour took less than 1 hour.

"mum and Frick". A little gem nestled opposite Central Park on 70th st. Beautiful grounds. Historical background interesting from a home to a purposely built museum. No cameras inside. $20 admission. Self tours available. A must if you appreciate fine art and sculptures.

nice museum. Beautiful home from the 1920s, turned into a museum with a large collection of well known art. Nicely maintained, knowledgeable staff. They have a neat free audio tour (w/ paid admission) that you can pick and choose which art you want to hear about. Found the museum to be a pleasurable experience

This is one spectacular house!. Mr. Frick was an interesting person rising from no education to building a house in the first part of the century that cost $5 million on central park. It is an amazing home that seems like it was very liviable. On top of the home itself, Mr. Frick collected an amazing array of pictures, sculptures and furniture of the finest quality including world renowed art works such as Mattise and many others. This was a real surprise recommended by a friend and I would certainly go back on the next trip to NYC.

Great little museum. This is a great little museum directly on 5th Avenue. I feel it might be sometimes omitted in comparison to the Met or Guggenheim but its definitely worth it. It has paintings, sculptures and furniture in it.

Beautiful, Small Colelction. For such a small little museum there are some amazing paintings and furniture. Free for NYC college students. Because of the size, it does not take long to go through, budget two hours max for this trip.

Prepare to be blown away!. This is such a magnificent collection of paintings in a wonderful setting. Allow enough time to see El Greco, John Constable, Turner, Vermeer - the wonders of the art world under one roof!

A Museum not to be missed. Among people who know the crowded art museum scene in New York City, the Frick Collection is held in the highest esteem. Many consider it to be the best art collection in the City for several reasons: first, it is a small, intimate museum that can be completely enjoyed in about two hours; second, the permanent collection is the vision of one man, Henry Clay Frick, a Pittsburgh industrialist who moved to New York (which is what many men of wealth did once they made their fortunes elsewhere -- think Carnegie and Rockefeller for two); and finally, the collection is housed in the mansion Mr. Frick built on Fifth Avenue for his family, but also to display his art collection. In fact, many paintings are still hanging in the locations where Mr. Frick placed them. The point that this museum was also the home of a wealthy cannot be overlooked because it defines this whole collection, and says as much about the man as about the art. It is unique among NYC art museums in this regard and is well worth the time to visit it when you are in New York City. In my opinion, it is one museum not to be missed.
Amazing collection and not overbearing. We really enjoyed this iconic collection and its worth noticing the furntiture as well as the wonderful paintings and sculptures

Alwasy an amazing treat to visit this collection. Mr. Frick collected art he liked and built this mansion on Park Avenue to display it. And we are thrilled he did as we always enjoy coming to see the amazing collection when we are in New York. Easier to cope with than the MMOFA since the size is manageable. Unfortunately there is no concert there this weekend as they are an added joy. Do visit this collection when in New York, although I hate to tell everyone, as it will get more crowded... but you will love it

Wonderful museum. I really like this museum/gallery. The collection is small enough to see everything without being overwhelmed and there are some wonderful painting. The house itself is worth seeing too and the setting is so peaceful. Well worth the visit

I have been visiting for 50 years. My, when I wrote that line I felt like a real geezer, but it is true. 50 years and I still love the garden, the elegant rooms and the art oh the art that is eternal and ever inspiring. A real NYC gem that must not be missed, a small collection but a proud one. Visit as often as you can.

A Generous Industrialist. Go to this museum! It's small by comparison to others in the city. It's right on 5th. On display isn't just paintings. Tapestries, china, clocks, furniture as well as the structure itself. Step into the small theatre to find out about how this private home came to be an impressive collection for all to enjoy!

A must see art collection in NYC. This was my first visit to The Frick. It was frankly awesome. Unbelievable collection of artwork by well known artists. Other wonderful statues and objet d'art etc. I was spellbound for the entire vista (make sure you allow at least 1.5 hours). Delightful.

What a little gem!. Throughly enjoyed this. Some of the art is exceptional some average. Lovely setting such an interesting mansion. Wish we could have explored upstairs as the house is as lovely as the art.

Amazing collection. This is one of my favourite art collections in NYC. To see this amazing artwork displayed in a house rather than a gallery is something special. Each room is filled with treasures and the excellent free audio guide gives succinct background information to many of the pieces. The Frick Collection is top of my 'to do' list each time I'm in New York.

a private collection of worth. What could be better than actually going into someones private house and seeing their personalized collection of art hanging on the walls of their home. On a quiet day, with few visitors, one can embrace oneself in the intimacy of the experience.It is a precious experience.

Go and enjoy this gem. I had never been to the Frick until last year when the Girl with the Pearl Earring was shown there.
