The line was so long and it was so cold and late that I joined in order to get in and see the exhibit. It was a treat then but I didn't have time to see everything. I finally was able to get back there today to see the Gems from the Scottish Museum. Wow. Go if you love beautiful art. It is a small place in comparison to most NYC grand museums. In fact it calls itself a collection and not a museum. What ever you call it, it is wonderful. The paintings and other art objects as just superbly curated. I am a member but I didn't know that they have those self guided audio tours until i was walking around and saw people with them. this is a quiet place, and you have to know the ins and outs to get the most out of it. I will definitely be back again and am so glad I have finally discovered this wonderful place to experience very interesting art.

Art at the Frick. I've wanted to see the Frick on my many visits to NYC and finally got around to it this past Thanksgiving. The collection is pretty extensive. There is a lot of English portraits on display - Gainsborough, Reynolds, Romney, none of which I care for much. But there is so much more - Vermeer, Bellini, Goya, Hals, Holbein, Rembrandt. Frick impresses me as a robber baron - the Donald Trump of his day. But at least the guy had class as far as art was concerned. The museum is worth a visit. Where else can you see art such as this. Certainly not at Trump Tower!

Definitely worth a visit. The Frick is absolutely worth a visit. The collection is home to a number of amazing pieces of art. Furthermore, it is displayed in H.C. Frick's former home, which was designed specifically to become a museum/gallery after his death, parts of which are still furnished as when it was his home, making it a truly unique space in which to view the artwork.
Amazing. Really, this is a tour of someone's wonderfully decorated mansion which beautiful furnishings and artwork.

Up close and personal. I love that you can be inches from great masters' paintings. The tutorial hand-helds were easy to use and not too lengthy about each piece. There are so many small sculptures and busts too. The nicest twist to this as a museum is that you see the art as the owners used them: in the sitting or dining room and entertaining with these works as a backdrop. The detail of the home is beautiful also, with lovely ornate plaster moldings and period furniture (I think most is the Frick furniture) Really wonderful.

A Gem of a Museum. The Frick is a small museum with an extraordinary selection of Medieval, Renaissance and Impressionist works of art. It is always a visual delight to stroll through the galleries and the period rooms. For those on a budget, Sunday morning is usually "pay what you wish."

Fabulous Frick. This was one of the best displayed and impressive collections of art my wife and I have seen in NYC. Though small, the treasures inside and quality of the Frick house --- the organization of the paintings, the decorative arts, etc. were breathtaking. The central garden is a nice quiet place to take a break and reflect on the beauty of this collection. We can't wait to go back when the outside gardens are in bloom as well.

NY's Best Art museum. The Frick is a mansion built by a robber baron who, when not having his workers shot or arrested, carefully assembled a world class art collection. See the portrait of HC Frick himself, surrounded by a harem of beauties, and see Renaissance and Baroque masterpieces throughout. The Titians, Rembrandt self portrait, Bellini, are about the most stunning paintings anywhere.

Wonderful small museum. I knew I could not overwhelm my husband with paintings and Art Galleries so I had to be careful to choose something varied and interesting which could be viewed in one hour and a bit so I choose the Frick! He had enjoyed Somerset House Courtauld's collection in London. This definitely was a winner. There were snow flurries outside and it was lovely and cosy and very accessible. The audio guides were excellent and allowed great freedom to wander between all the original furniture and view the wonderful paintings still hanging where they were when it was a lived in home. I loved the fact that there was no collecting paintings into iras . I real must for New York
Visit with Jane. Small enough to enjoy, some excellent paintings and lovely covered garden. There is no cafe, good location opposite Central Park, nice carriage ride after visiting the Frick.
Lovely Museum. The collection is an interesting mix of Bronze and paintings. The building is also very interesting and has a wonderful layout. The gift shop has much to offer as well.

My favorite small NYC museum.. When I have a free hour in NYC the Frick is my favorite destination. The galleries are frequently uncrowned and the mood contemplative. The collection is extraordinary and the small special exhibitions always world class. Also conveniently located near MET, Guggenheim and other cultural attractions. Free admission if you are a member of a North American Reciprocal museum.
Small, but impressive. Excellent collection in a beautiful building, Can see everything in a few hours. Also, nice gift store
A little Treasure - one of the world's finest.. You will not find more world class Masterpieces per painting in any Museum in the world except the Musee d'Orsay.
Free on a Sunday. If you are in town at the weekend, definitely worth visiting. A little bit of Europe in central Manhattan. Lovely internal courtyard, and a great collection of works.

Great little museum. This is an understated gem and if you have a few hours to spend, you should spend it here. It is small enough to see all in the space of two hours, and always has great paintings and exhibits which are redone every two months or so.
More than a museum. The collection is housed in the family's mansion, so if you love architecture or just grand houses, you'll love wandering the rooms as much as seeing the extraordinary artwork.

Go on Sunday morning!. This is well worth seeing - go on a Sunday morning, between 11am-1pm you can pay what you want to get in. It's breathtakingly beautiful, interesting, and not so big that it's an exhausting experience. 2 hours is plenty of time. You could even do it in an hour if you're that way inclined.

Excellent art collection -- Free on Sunday. This was a private art collection, now viewable to the public. Entry is free (or "donate what you wish") on Sunday from 11-2. Better art than many museums we have seen around the world.
Peaceful and manageable. Easy to see in a few hours. Some nice pieces, but no real impressionism. The tastes are mostly earlier art.
Great Museum. It is unusual to be able to see and be very close to the art, An intimate museum that offers a very up close and personal experience that one can truly appreciate only at The Frick.

Oasis of elegance. This is a peaceful oasis close to Central Park. The Art is typical of a 19th/20th century collector, some beautiful Dutch paintings, including Rembrandt, which you can enjoy at leisure as it is not crowded. There are small stone benches to sit on in the central atrium where you can rest from the NY bustle. This is a real gem of a museum. Highly recommended.

Unbelievable treasure!!. I can't understand how we missed this treasure during countless visits to New York over 30 years. Amazing unique collection of paintings and small bronzes. Impossible to absorb the quality in one visit. Metropolitan eat your heart out!!!

This is truly a hidden gem. The house itself is fabulous, but the art is incredible. Hard to imagine that it is one man's collection. Lots of different styles, from medieval to late 19th century. And the central courtyard with it's beautiful pond and plants was so relaxing. Don't miss this if you like art and/or architecture. Allow at least 2 hours.

The best private museum in the world?. The setting is very grand on 5th avenue, the building is wonderful now and must have been amazing in the early 20th century.The collection is a 'must see' for NYC.The collection has an eclectic mix of artists but some truly wonderful pictures- Holbein's Thomas's- Moore and Cromwell, these made the day so fulfilled.Just go and spend time absorbing the history and atmosphere.
Interesting. Great collection of artwork from mainly European artists set in a building with a beautiful interior. Not too busy so you easily spend time pondering over the artwork.

Worth the Visit!. We visited the Frick collection on the advice of some friends, and were not disappointed. The collection is housed in the former Frick home, which was built to be a museum but which they did live in. The collection is so appealing -- even for someone who doesn't know much about art -- Mr. Frick personally collected pieces that he found pleasing to look at and be around. The audio guide is very helpful, and the informative video gives the background of the man, home and collection.

Awsome. The collection of masterpieces is fantastic, the home of Mr Frick is a beautiful example of the turn of the century mansions that are all but gone. This is more than a museum, it is a walk through time.

A different experience. The Frick collection is an ancient nice house with several antique paintings, sculptures and and furniture. Its peculiarity is that it is a private house presently dedicated to the public. Something you would not expect in a city like NY

Highlight of my Trip!. Having never heard of Mr Frick I came across him first here in Trip Advisor (researching interesting places in New York). I took the advice of another poster and visited on a Sunday (11am-2pm) when entry is by donation (common in London BUT a rare thing in the city that thrives on "making a buck!". I wasn't disappointed. Being an ardent UK National Trust and English Heritage member it appealed both from historical interest and curiosity as to the individual I consequently researched on Wikipedia (do this before visiting it CERTAINLY adds to your interest).Located overlooking the lower eastern side of Central Park on 5th Avenue it's not a hugely imposing building but one of utter charm. Immediately on entering one gets an atmosphere not really common in NY attractions, one of a cosy home filled with warmth and homeliness. I was spellbound from the beginning and blown away by the absolute quality of the collection. Matisse, Degar, Monet to Holbein, they are all to be viewed, with the most stunning Singer Sergeant canvas I have viewed (the highlight of the collection and rightly featured on the front of their promotional brochure).After enjoying Mr Fricks house I felt I had to go visit "Mr Carnegie's" house which is further up 5th Avenue (read the story and you'll understand). It was sadly closed but being reopened as a design museum. I nevertheless enjoyed peeking at it and what made Mr Frick comment (in a book I subsequently read) that he was going to "outdo" him!!!This is a story of real American success for one of a pair of Scottish immigrants who acheived truly vast entrepreneurial wealth and success, in Fricks case near death assassination from his strike breaking stance (his communist killer was later deported after serving 14 years in the State Penitentiary) and humbling affection for his family. Do visit his home even if briefly assuming you have the time when visiting this huge City of great contrasts (extreme wealth and poverty!). ENJOY.

For the art lovers. On 5th Avenue between 70th and 71st streets the impressive house of one of the richest men in the city is worth a visit. Take your time to walk around the rooms and admire the collection in a very quiet environment full of pure art.

my favorite. I always visit the Frick Museum when in New York.It is like living in another era......sophisticated, elegant, enchantingand filled with the most precious art anywhere I recommend a visit for all those who live in or visit New York

lugar imperdível. The art collection Frick Collection, belonging to the american Henry Clay Frick, and his house are part of the Frick Collection. The collection features some of the best-known paintings by major European artists, as well as numerous works of sculpture and porcelain. It also has 18th century French furniture, Limoges enamel, and Oriental rugs.[1] After Frick's death, his daughter, Helen Clay Frick, expanded the collection, with a third of its artworks acquired since 1919. paintings by the greatest European artists, sculptures, eighteenth-century French furniture and porcelains, Limoges enamels, .It definitely.worth the visit!!!!!

Best place in New York. I have been to most New York attractions over the years but I can honestly say nothing beats this one. The museum is not huge but it is a beautiful building and the art collection is outstanding - in my view the best in NYC.Also extraordinary is the peaceful indoor garden, it is so relaxing to sit there, I could have stayed for hours.Do not miss the excellent audio system which is provided free with the admission fee and explains the paintings in a great way.

Lovely place. Since you're so close to the exhibits they have a lot of little rules. Definitely check your coats and backpacks before you get your ticket. Also, if you do have a small backpack, you can carry it with you, but you can only carry it one shoulder and try to keep it from swinging around. The museum is small, but the works of art are wonderful. I like going when there are less people and I go to other rooms when one room is occupied by a tour group so I can hear the audio guide. Everything is on one floor, but with multiple rooms, you can spend a few hours there. Also, there are no real signs, but there are bathrooms in the little entrance ways between doors (ask one of the guards). There is a bigger bathroom with multiple stalls near the visitor's entrance area. Overall, I really enjoyed seeing all the work. The current temporary exhibit is works of art from the Scotland Museum. Definitely worth checking out. And if you need a break from all the luxury, the center courtyard with the fountains and quaint, little frogs are worth taking a rest on the benches.

A 'bite sized' cultural experience. . For those who find large museums and galleries overwhelming take a look at the frick. It is a small and very 'personal' collection of pictures and objet d'art. It is far more pleasant to walk around than some of the larger collections. However, two criticisms: some of the paintings are poorly lit and inexplicably the finest painting in the collection (Renoir's la promenade) is tucked away on a staircase that is inaccessible.
A Favorite. Best small museum in New York! Lovely Interior Garden near the met . Love the Art Murals!Nothing to dislike except Museums closed Mondays.

A view to the past. Wandering through the rooms in this place is a chance to glimpse the life during the "Gilded Age". It's hard to imagine any one person owning so much spectacular art. But so glad the Frick family decided to share with the masses.

Beautiful mansion. I've visited NYC several times but had never got around to visiting the Frick before, and having been there I can see that I had missed out! It's a beautiful mansion located by Central Park, and filled with a variety of art works and furniture which gives a tantalising glimpse of what it might have been like to have lived there at the time. I'm not massively into art and found this collection just right to hold my interest, I especially enjoyed seeing the paintings in the context of the rooms which had various styles of decoration and it felt more like a stately home than a gallery.I went on the "pay what you wish" day (11am-1pm every Sunday) but thought it was well worth the usual admission fee and would certainly pay another visit in the future.

Amazing place. Not a very large art collection, but a very selective one. There is some great stuff here, and everything is worth a look. It is set in Frick's mansion, which gives a feel for how the very rich and very cultured lived.

Beautiful collection. The Frick houses a collection of wonderful paintings and objects. It feels less like a museum than someone's home, which it once was. I visited to see a special exhibit from the Scottish National Gallery but was even more taken with the permanent exhibits. The enamels were astonishingly beautiful - such vivid colors. While I was on my way out, something strange happened. A very formal but peaceful place. I highly recommend it.
Exquisite. Another "don't miss" for those visiting NYC. Especially for art lovers, but the Frick mansion setting is jaw-dropping. New York as it used to be...

Wonderful collection of masters in a grand house. The wealthy Fricks filled their home with the most amazing paintings and sculptures from artists of the 15th to 19th centuries. This must have been the most amazing place to visit when they lived there. Even now it's a wonderful place for art lovers.

An excellent venue. It is always wonderful to see artwork that rests in an spot that was specifically designed for it. To get a "sneek peek" inside the home of a wealthy family who enjoyed artwork and had the means to display it in any manner that they chose was a highlight of our recent trip to NYC.

Beautiful Mansion and Terrific Art Collection. Located just southeast of the much larger Metropolitan Museum of Art the Frick offers a terrific insight into the world of the early US industrialist in an intimate setting.

Peaceful. Beautiful home on Central Park houses this collection. It's hard to believe someone actually had a Rembrandt hanging in their home. The home has been beautifully maintained and it is a relaxing museum to tour, which is a delight in NYC.

A gem of a museum. The Frick Collection is well worth viewing for its quality, diversity, setting and accessibility. Though the entrance fee is a bit steep ($20. regular/$15. seniors) it is possible to spend a fair amount of time wandering through this magnificent mansion that houses the Frick works of art. A short film shown on site gives wonderful background information on the origin and the people behind this public "gem". There is also a self guided audio tour that adds to the overall rich experience.

As wonderful as ever. This is a gem of a collection and if you haven't the energy to tackle the Met but love art it shouldn't be missed. We went on a Sunday when entry is freeish, paying what you want. The audio guide is free however and an excellent companion. Don't miss the video.
Always a favorite. Great art in a setting fit for a king. There is something for every art lover and usually not so crowded you can't enjoy your visit

Great collection. We love this place. It's wonderful to be in the atmosphere of the Frick's home as you look at the masterpieces. A small enough collection that you can see much of the whole place in a couple of hours. We had a short 15 minute docent tour that was great too. Loved the free audio guides too as nothing is written on the walls about the paintings.

Mr. Frick!. This museum is simply outstanding, an incomparable private collection from a man with incredible taste. The building resembles a villa, what a family house this place must have been! In addition to the gorgeous painting from Vermeer, Whistler, Gainsborough, and other masters, the furnishings are exquisite. Don't hesitate, see the Frick!

Beautiful collection in beautiful house. This is a small art gallery in what was once Mr Frick's private home on 5th Ave. It is well worth a visit but do go early so that you can view the paintings in a relatively uncrowded and quite time.

Remarkable setting and remarkable collection. The Frick feels like the family just left on vacation and you wandered in in their absence. Go on Sunday between 11 and 1 and pay want you want and be sure to download the Frick app for your phone as it is excellent and free.
Treasure along museum row. A hidden gem along museum row. If you get a chance visit the frick collection. If nothing else the beautiful courtyard provides respite from the craziness of NYC

More like visiting someone's house than a museum. The Frick has some one-of-a-kind paintings that you must see, but they are next to paintings that are only average. The whole museum is poorly arranged with little information on the artwork unless you use their audio headsets, which I detest. We have gone once, we have seen what we needed to see, and there is no reason to return.

A PERFECT step back in time, with GREAT art.. The Frick Collection is a New York MUST. The permanent collection is boggling: Rembrandt, Monet, Vermeer, El Greco, Whistler, Sargent, Turner, among so many other masters of canvas and statuary. And it's all beautifully displayed in the Frick family's grand Gilded Age mansion: a relatively small space... easy to traverse in a couple hours, AND the listening devices are user-friendly and so very informative. 1 East 70th, near the Met, and SO much more "accessible," charming, and easy to navigate in a short time.
Amazing !. Right in front of Central Park. Wonderful collection ! Worth to go ! Very tiny and interesting museum

The best small museum in nyc!. Whenever I enter the Frick, it takes a while for it to sink in that this was someone's home. It is a Magnificient building on 71 st Street and Fifth Avenue. The museum has a wonderful permanent collection with a gallery that was built by Frick when he was living there.The atmosphere in this small museum is remarkable as it is quiet and beautiful. As you are looking at the paintings and sculpture, you are soothed by the ambience of the building.There is a garden area outdoors as well. My concern is that they are enlarging this museum, and since I have been going to the Frick for 50 years, I hope thy do not change it to become too big.It is close to Central Park, and visiting the Frick Museum with a walk in the park can be a perfect day in NYC!

Intimate setting for an artful afternoon. Small collection in a beautiful setting -- perfect for destressing after a busy day sightseeing. Loved the house and gardens as well as the unique art collection. Nicely appointed gift shop and a convenient location.
A must do!!. An amazing experience to wander around the home filled with priceless art works and exquisite artefacts. Would thoroughly recommend.

Various portraits from the 1800-1900s. Enjoyed this collection on a Wednesday. Mostly portraits and some sculptures. Highlights were a Degas, a Manet, and Rembrandt's self portrait. Worthwhile to sit in the Atrium and relax.
NYC Gem. The Frick is one of my favorite museums. Check out Hans Holbein's "Sir Thomas More" which, in my view, is the greatest portrait in the world.

Not Worth The Trip. The Frick is located in a beautiful mansion on Fifth Ave. There is a nice collection of art and antiques on the first floor. The entry fee is $20 for adults. There is a small shop but no cafe or place to relax. Considering what NYC has to offer, I would skip this and go to one of the larger museums. Also it's overpriced, especially since there is only one floor to visit which should take less then an hour to do thoroughly.

Special treat on 5th Avenue. Great variety of artwork. The Frick Mansion itself is worth price of admission. Imagination takes over as you walk around this gorgeous mansion. Not crowded. Don't miss it!
Small and intimate. What a treat. Very intimate gallery, interesting history to the houseWhich is the Gallery, nice array of Art. Degas, Rembrandt, and more
Great Art Work. The art work is outstanding and the neighborhood is beautiful. Central park, 5th Avenue and Madison Avenue are all there.

My favourite New York museum. The Frick is always at the top of my NY to do list! It's very restful , a home rather than a museum and each piece of furniture and every painting has been chosen to complement each other and their surroundings. Hence Holbeins portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, sworn enemies look at each other across the fire place. There are 3 exquisite Vermeers, 3 unusually subtle Turners, many Gainsboroughs, Reynolds and 2 Constables. There is a lovely cool atrium to sit and contemplate but no cafe!

One of the best small art museums in the United States. Built one hundred years ago by Henry Clay Frick as his home but also home for his very serious and ongoing art collection, the Frick Collection is a stunningly beautiful piece of architecture in one of the best locations in New York City, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 70th Street. The artwork is largely comprised of European paintings from Cimabue to Sargent, all beautifully presented. In the main gallery there were at least three Turners! The admission charge is high but if you go on Sunday between 11 and 1 you can pay whatever you please, but as a consequence that is a very busy time. The audio guides were free for our Sunday visit.

Perfect little museum!. Outstanding, world class collection of art! It is worth going just to see their permanent collection. Take the time to use the audio tour. It makes it all even more impressive. The building itself makes it with the visit.

Elegance in NYC. Apparently Frick gave instructions to his architect that he wanted his new house to have "..a simple design, nothing extravagant..." - this building is anything but !The structure itself is wonderful, and very elegant. In the hallway/staircase, look out for the organ pipes and the built-in part-hidden keyboard located opposite.The varied artefacts are well presented and very accessible. Do use the audio phones - as the brief explanations given are very useful. Cost wise - On Sundays rather than charge their usual entrance fee, they simply request a discretionary contribution. Enjoy !

Frick collection. The collection of artworks is stunning and well worth a visit but I wish they could cheer up the attendants who seemed uninterested in their job and not particularly knowledgeable about the rooms they were attending. Otherwise, fantastic.

World class collection. Great art housed in a beautiful estate which is very ornate and a work of art itself. The paintings span the centuries starting with the pre renaissance religious type and including Titian, Constable, Van Dyck, Gainsborough, Goya, El Greco, Hals, Rembrandt and Renoir to name a few. In addition there is plenty of sculpture, furniture and other objects of art. Two hours was enough for what I wanted to see but I will go back if I get a chance.

A world class collection in a stunning environment. Definitely worth a visit, even in the most crowded schedule. The art works are stunning and the presentation - building, commentaries, make the collection highly accessible..

A must for any designer/art enthusiast, or for anyone who appreciates beautiful things... I had an afternoon to spare while visiting New York with friends, and decided to make the trip to the Frick Collection to see what the fuss was all about. As an interior designer, and a very appreciative art enthusiast, I relished in each and every room of this gorgeously opulent house museum. Not only is the artwork of a very fine calibre, but so are the furniture and ceramics pieces that adorn every room with such presence and beauty. Allow approximately 1.5-2 hours to walk through every room and appreciate every piece of art hanging of every wall.
Small and elegent museum. Beautifull paintings and a small elegant museum which is nice for a change. Good for those who don't want to spent a whole day indoors.

Not Worth $20. I read many reviews before visiting the Frick Collection and 99% were positive, but unfortunately I cannot say the same. At $20 entry fee, I expected more than 5 or 6 small rooms of artwork. I was not allowed to walk around with my backpack on both shoulders, I wasn't allowed to carry my coat - I was forced to wear it indoors as I didn't want to pay or wait to use the cloak room, and I wasn't allowed to take a sip of water out of my drink bottle. The artwork was nice but definitely not worth it. Won't be going back and won't be recommending it.

Step back in time. I felt like a guest stepping into a beautiful home from a bygone era. It was peaceful and tranquil and quite genteel. It's a really nice place to visit with some beautiful pieces in a lovely setting with very friendly staff.

Beautiful house, loads of great art. This is a great place to visit for a couple of hours. There is a diverse range of art which is exhibited well. The house is beautiful and there is a short film about the history of the family. There are also complimentary audio guides which explain rooms and individual bits of art that you select to listen to.

the perfect art museum. Location is perfect. The venu is a spectacular 5th avenue mansion. The artwork is arguably better than in the nearby Met - in a far more intimate and relaxed atmosphere. Just enough to merrit a visit, but not enough to end up on overload. I live here and visit regularly - it's that good..
Beautiful art museum.. Loved the art. Would've liked to see more of the building as I'm more interested in that than paintings. Well worth a visit though.

Closing the Spanish collection. A small but significant collection including 3 Vermeer paintings . However part of this already small museum was closed to the public in anticipation of a new exhibit ( 400th anniversary of El Greco? ) . Very disappointing ! None of the Spanish masters on display except for one Velasquez . No Goya!

Fabulous. I had never heard of the place, but it was recommended by a friend. Amazing what one man collected. Beautiful house, full of fantastic art and furniture. Highlight for me was the two Holbeins (More and Cromwell)

Astonishing collection of art. If you only have time to visit one art collection in New York, make it this one. The Frick houses the most incredible & beautiful works of art, objects d'art, furniture & interiors, in the world. The mansion in which it is all housed, is elegant in proportion but not overwhelming so one can easily navigate the entire collection without going glassy-eyed.The audio guide is well-worth doing; it is flexible so you can select the works that interest you the most if short of time.In the main gallery alone, there are breath-taking works by Veronese, Turner, Rembrandt, Vermeer & Corot, to name a few. There is also a terrific representation of French rococo work, which is beautifully incorporated into the interior. The Frick is a must-see for anyone interested in the visual arts.

Stunning old masters. On our previous trips to Manhattan we hadn't made time to visit the Frick collection and we were so happy we did this time. Not only is the collection amazing, the audio descriptions greatly enhance the viewing pleasure. The architecture alone is worth a visit. A reminder of the Golden era of the turn of the last century almost as amazing as the Biltmore House in North Carolina.

A gem. No surprises. One of the great smaller collections anywhere in the world. Still will take two good hours. The audioguide is part of the admission price so definitely take it and use it. Not overly detailed but enough information to keep your interest. Rembrandt, Vermeer, Ingres and more. A do not miss when in NYC if you are into painting and sculpture plus a gorgeous building.

Astounding beauty everywhere you turn.. 3 Vermeer's, that's almost 10% of the world's total. The architecture of this place is breathtaking. It is said that Mr. Frick's staff would find him sitting up in the middle of the night, where he would be studying one of his paintings for hours. The collection is amazing. The home it resides in was built as a residence, and to showcase the collection. You can't go wrong. Sundays from 10 - 1 are pay as you will, this is good for any budget.

quiet and not crowded. The atmosphere is very conducive to enjoying art. The variety of art puts the Frick into a MET category of available art and is a must for all tourists from any country. It is in a great location for visiting and enjoying.

amazing from one collector. the Frick is always a "must go" when in New York. Wonderful art in a magnificent purose-built house. worthwhile taking the audio tour which has excellent commentary about the pictures and the house's history

Interesting house and collection. My friend and I spent a few nice hours exploring this collection. The house itself is beautiful as are the furnishings. The art includes Renoir, Degas and Rembrandt as well as a host of 18th and 19th century paintings. While I prefer more modern art, certainly this private collection is inspiring and interesting. The included personal audio tour is helpful and informative.

It doesn't get much better than this. Gorgeous beyond belief. Sunday morning from 11:00 (opening) until about 1:00 there is not a set entrance fee, but rather donations at the discretion of the visitors are gladly accepted. This is wonderful for those with children or people on a budget. Frankly, the regular ticket price is a bargain, so we were glad to pay their standard charge.

Great small museum. This beautiful house on the Upper East Side, combines great design and architecture with excellent pieces of art. If you don't have time for a long visit to a major museum, you can have a great couple of hours visiting this museum.

A splash of culture. Loved stopping in for a quick dose of culture on one of the most beautiful 'houses' in Manhattan and learning about the history of the mansion, the collection and the trip from Pittsburgh to Manhattan that gave us the museum!
Still Love this place. If you are looking for a place to see great art in a relaxed and impressive location, The Frick is the place.

Interesting. Have passed this building numerous times and had time waiting for the NY Marathon and decided to visit. Not our type of art work. The building is amazing and it is incredible the collection that Frick collected.
If you are into the classics, don't miss this museum.

Frick collection, one of a kind. Living in New York, I love to spend sunday mornings at the Frick collection. It is actually free at that time. The Frick collection is unique in the sense that all types of art and beatiful ornaments and furniture are in the same rooms. This very special place, right across from Central Park, will always be my favorite museum in New York..

Free on Sunday morning!. I love the Frick because it is small and intimate. This smaller museum is perfect on a Sunday morning or if you just want to spend a couple of hours in the morning or the afternoon during the week.

An Art Gem in New York. What a wonderful Art Collection Mr. Frick amassed in his lifetime. It was a joy to see beautiful Rembrandts, Turners, Monet's plus so much more amid impressive bronze sculptures and a room devoted to huge Fragonard works. The room with the pool and lovely plants and flowers is like an oasis in a concrete city. It is a place to return to often.

Fantastic Turner's. This is such a beautiful small gallery to wander around in for a couple of hours and then you can find a spot to sit in the courtyard and think about what you've seen. The Turner paintings were magnificent and the house itself is worth a visit. It doesn't have the crowds of the larger galleries but having said that there was a queue forming about 20 minutes or so before opening. If you love fine art and architecture, it's so worth the visit.

Unusual. This is a much more manageable art museum than the Met.. We visited the museum in a couple of hours, and felt like we had the time and space to really enjoy the collection. I liked the fact that that the art was not sorted by style, so you see a Rembrandt next to a JW Turner, next to a Renoir. Keeps your mind fresh.

Life style before income taxes!. Nice to see how the super rich lived in the gilded age of NY. My favorite painting there, and there are many masterpieces, is the Romney portrait of Emma, Lady Hamilton. Fascinating young woman, the Liz Taylor or her day, only higher on the scandal lists. Read about her before you go. You'll enjoy the portrait even more.
Something that you feel. This is a place some people miss , you should not miss it. It is a period piece of America and you can not see this anywhere else.
beautiful collection, but kids are not admitted. The building and the collection are certainly worth a visit. Both very impressive. Too bad that kids are not admitted.

Well worth the stop. I had read in the past year a book on Frick and had never visited his collection or mansion. We took easy walk through central park and enjoyed our tour quite a lot. I loved the audio where you could type in number and listen about a given room or work of art. Most memorable and well worth doing.

Not Just The Collection, But The Building And The Family. This really is a top attraction. Not only superb exhibits, beautifully presented, but also the history of the house and it's building growth, plus the story of the family that built the collection. Entry to The Frick includes a good, free, individual audio guide, but also highly recommended as a start to your tour is the 20 minute introduction video shown on continuous loop in The Music Room. Short videos are also shown on special displays and this encouraged us to look at, and enjoy, objects that we may have overlooked. A quality collection reflected in it's high position on the attraction recommendation list.

Cute little european place. Every European in NY loves to go there because it looks like an european museum. The place is lovely, the collection is not that amazing but for the atmosphere you have to go !

A must see. The museum is open from 10 to 6 Tuesday through Saturday and from 11-5 on Sunday. The museum is pay as you wish on Sunday from 11 to 1:00. Otherwise, it is $20 for an adult, senior citizens $15 and students $10. Children under 10 are not admitted. There is a free audioguide. We opted to visit during the free hours on Sunday and it wasn't crowded. The mansion cost $13 million to build in 1913 and was built for the purpose of turning it into a museum for the public one day. There are 179 paintings, beautiful furniture, rugs, silver, and sculptures to admire. There is one room that is entirely French. The collection is very impressive with paintings from: Monet, Manet, Degas, Whistler, Stuart Gilbert, Rembrandt, Titan, Velaquez, Gainsborough, Goya,Vermeer, Turner, and Van Dyck. Viewing this collection is like visiting an extremely wealthy person's home and admiring his artwork that he acquired. I would highly recommend.

A truly manageable museum experience. Our annual 'fall in NYC' trip--we lived there over twenty years, and I return to NY frequently on business during the year. 2014 was the year for The Louvre in Paris and the Metropolitan, as always, in NY. But this was the first time (in my fading memory) for me at the Frick and the experience was perfect. First, unlike the Louvre or Met, this does not overwhelm: it is the private collection of one specific gilded age millionaire: Henry Clay Frick. The 'included' audio tour was, for my, the best of its kind as it allowed one to select specific art works for description--and the narrative (sounded like Philippe de Montebello) was studied and spot on. Most importantly, the narrative threaded the artworks and made them 'one of a whole'--why they were acquired by Frick--what he saw in each work--and how the whole fit into his life. If you, or members of your family, are otherwise reluctant art museum devotees, I would highly recommend the Frick in order to enhance your life.

A Masterpiece Collection. This would have to be one of the best attractions in New York if you are a culture or art lover or even a part time admirer. This was once the Frick family home many decades ago and the owner was a massive art lover & later in life collection other rare pieces like furnisher, sculptures and fine porcelain. The house was purposely built to display the family art and when Mr. Frick died the home turned into a museum for all to admire the collection. The house itself is worth seeing, but the collection is magnificent. This is one of these places not on the main tourism lists and you don’t get in with New York Passes or anything else. But I would fully recommend a visit while you are in upper Manhattan. you cant take photos inside only in the courtyard.

Can I please live here?. Stunning artwork in a home that is equally impressive as the works that line the walls. I thought it was truly beautiful and only wish I had more time to spend here. If you appreciate antiques then you will really enjoy the Frick.

A gem!!. Wonderful to be able to visit this private collection of so many famous and outstanding works of art .... Henry Clay Frick certainly knew which artworks were worth acquiring!! For me, the Hans Holbein portrait of Sir Thomas More was alone worth the visit.
Don't miss it. A slice of what New York used to be like back in the Gilded Age. Just a fantastic, personal, and one-of-a-kind museum. Don't miss it.

Interesting museum. Stunning museum opposite Central Park. The collection of paintings, furniture and other antique pieces are amazing however the house is stunning. Really worth taking the time to see this gem.
Fascinating. what a gem of a museum.....totally individual ...an absolute must to include in any tour of the wonderful museums in New York

Beautiful museum with great collection. Even though you need to pay on days other than Sunday but it is worth the $$.
I would definitely give this quaint museum a visit. Their collections are amazing and the house is beautiful. You can easily spend an hour or 2 browsing the art work.

Very good. The sheer diversity of the paintings on offer blew my mind. Central park provides the perfect backdrop for the collection. Must-sees are the Holbeins, the Degas and the Rembrandts and Vermeers

Hidden gem of an art museum. My wife and I love art museums and have visited a number of museums in a number of cities - including the MOMA and the Met in NYC. My wife had seen a review of the Frick Collection and was interested in visiting it. Before leaving for New York, we ran into a gentleman at a wedding reception who - when he hear we were heading to NY - started raving about the Frick and urging us not to miss it.The Frick Collection is actually housed in what had been the home of Henry Clay Frick which Frick had planned to become a museum after the passing of he and his wife.So -- part of the attraction is the setting in the old Frick estate and part of the attraction is the art. Frick and his wife amassed a wonderful collection of art and it's presented very well in the Frick Collection. Your admission price includes a free self-guided audio tour device which is nicer than most of these devices. The device allows you to key in the number of a specific piece of art and to learn about that particular piece. You don't know to tour the collection in any specific order when using the device.For art enthusiasts of any kind - the Frick Collection should be on your list.
What a great museum. This museum was wonderful. Wonderful works of art hung as Frick wanted them hung in a interesting setting
jo. A fantastic collection of priceless art in a great original buiding , a must see in new York , a real treasure .

A museum with a view. This elegant once private home is full of beautiful objects and gives a nicely sized sample of how a ( very ) wealthy American family once lived. With beautiful Central Park as its 'front yard' this is a fascinating collection, one that is neither overwhelming or exhausting in size.

Lovely Museum. After many, many visits to Manhattan, I finally visited this delightful museum. So glad we did; it is truly a gem. The museum itself is worth a visit because it's hard to believe it Henry Frick actually lived in such a magnificent building. I highly recommend it.

What a gem!. This is a fantastic, if somewhat limited, collection of art and sculpture in an magnificent setting. It is well worth about two hours with the audioguide devices. There is really nothing to dislike and it is one of the more positive and rewarding "museum" experiences we have had. Be sure to listen to the descriptions of the rooms as well as the individual art pieces. Truly a joy!
mandy. the best art pictures we have seen so far in a lovely building , a priceless collection , saw orl with a pearl earing paintig .

The most intimate museum experience in NYC. If you value art as a vehicle to express your feelings and your personality you can't hardly do better than visit the Frick Collection. And amazing array of first rate paintings and sculptures. Makes sure you don't miss!!

Most impressive collection! A gem!. Not only are some of the best master artists represented here, but their works here are the exceptional ones. The Collection is vast and impressive -- three Vermeers! The mansion was beautiful, a masterpiece too. Headphone guides were helpful. Not sure of the age requirements, but respectful children (mine are 10 and 8) will be welcomed. Got to know the masters and masterpieces in detail, and better experience for us than the Met. Truly worthwhile.

Eh.... Well, the house is kinda neat and the collection is small but interesting. If art is to be displayed pictures should be allowed, but they don't allow it. Frick was also a dick (read up on that), so I guess they are just carrying on the tradition...
Lovely Museum - Definitely worth a visit. Not only is this museum in a beatuful NYC mansion that is worth a visit in itself but the art work and history is wonderful
Wonderful couple of hours. Forget the crowds of other museums and come to this beautiful home and enjoy the great collection. Watch the short movie with interesting history

New York's Finest Museum. The Frick was an absolute delight , the range of paintings and artists was superb.The setting in an industrial baron's New York home is a glimpse into the recent past and how they set up their home.make sure you get the audio guide (it's free) to hear the history behind some of the fabulous artworks

Masterful Private Collection. Beautifully laid out and preserved. Wide variety of arts and collectibles. Staff were wonderfully helpful and attentive.It is wonderful the of the generosity of the Frick Family to donate not only the art works but also the corne-rblock location that was customised for the collection

Wonderful Collection. I went feeling tired and was so uplifted. Wonderful pictures, house and decor. Well worth a visit. No queuing which was an advantage and a good 30 minute walk down 5th Avenue from my hotel. Friendly helpful staff.

One of the best. This museum is one of the best NYC has to offer. There are several things that separate it from other collections. First, the museum's setting in the Frick mansion, is beautiful. It truly transports you to the gilded age. Secondly, the collection is very accessible. Upon admission, you are given a device that explains each piece to you through a small speaker. It allows you to choose the pieces you are drawn to, and learn more about each piece. The collection has quite a bit of variety, including works from all over the world, different periods, and different mediums. There is a wonderful collection of bronze statues, as well as paintings, and sculptures. The entire museum can be done in a matter of 2 hours. An absolute must see for any art lover, and can please even the staunchest museum hater.

Unique, intimate and beautiful. The Frick Collection has been on our list. This trip we saved it for a rainy day outing. It was perfect for that. It got us into a neighborhood where we had not been. The setting is beautiful. On view, is the family's collection. It is very personal. The audio headsets are free and very informative. One can spend as much time as you need. It's an interesting glimpse into someone's personal collection. We were very struck by the eclectic nature of the people visiting. This is a very special place.

An homage to European manor houses. This is a wonderful viewing experience. Not only some exquisite artworks and beautiful bronzes, but also a step back into the very best of European 1880s interiors. There is no New York style here.This is also a very personal experience. You walk through the Frick family home, the dining room, the drawing room etc and look at their art works as they lived with them. While the home is stately you can imagine how it would be to live in it, having coffee in the library looking at the Turners and Constables. Then a port in front of the fire with the Holbein paintings of Thomas Moore and Cromwell on either side. I loved the window dressings, so opulent and reminiscent of Josephine's personal quarters at Fountainbleu.This is a treasure, not only for the collection but also for an insight into a family's life.

A must-do!. Smaller museum which was once a 'real' house/home (some lifestyle!). Amazing collection by an obviously brilliant collector. Could use a few more stools/benches for the older crowd to pause.

The absolute best of NYC's museums. This gem is just the right size to explore in one visit. You will enjoy not only the fabulous art, but get to experience how the robber barons lived in absolute splendor.

No need to read any more reviews about it - just go!!. It's brilliant and $20 - it's a bargain!(TripAdvisor requires at least 100 characters… so, I'm just filling in… PLEASE just go if you love Gainsborough, Turner, Constable et al!)
Frick Collection. They are about to renovate the building, but you will still be able to see the old mansion on 5th ave. Terrific collections. Small and doable museum.

Frick offers opulent view into NYCs Gilded Age. The Frick Collection offers a look at the opulent past of America and New York in particular during the height of the industrial revolution when barons the country's business. Obviously the works of art are fabulous to view, but what makes this collection unique is the manner in which they are displayed---in the home of the collector who came from very humble roots. Perhaps the only downside was the price $20 per adult, which Is a little steep when compared with other more extensive art offerings around the city. However, if you want the chance to really review a collection in depth, this may be the best choice for you. Furniture and other artifacts are part of the collection, and audio tours are included in the price of entry, as well as an introductory film and short videos on the current collections.
Wonderful gem. This museum is never on the lists of Must Dos, but it should. Fantastic building combined with great art is unique.

World Class Art Museum with charm. This is an amazing collection in a tiny little house. Much like the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in a much nicer and cleaner city. Its amazing to find such charm and wonderful works of art in manhattan. It almost makes you forget about how bad manhattan smells. Its a life changing experience to see the work of Johaness Vermeer in person. The entrance fee was what you'd expect for NYC but maybe they'll have a coupon day or something. I recommend this museum to everyone even non art lovers.

My favourite museum. I visit many museums around the world, none matches the Frick. It offers marvellous tranquility in the bedlam of the city and being able to linger in front of Thomas More, Lady Peel, Mrs Hamilton or fabulous Gainsboroughs is a treat indeed. Don't miss it!

Charming. A small collection of artworks set in a beautiful 'house'. My Mum worked here in the 1960s, so I was keen to see the corridors and rooms she would have walked through - a delightful find! The Sunday 'pay what you want' offer is popular and a large queue formed at 11. My advice would be arrive after 11.30.

My favorite. It was such a pleasure to stroll through this beautiful home. It was quiet and dignified and the staff was unobtrusive. It was a thrill to walk into the next room to come up close to such stunning art. Be sure to see the Whistler collection. This lovely museum is well worth the price of admission.

A wonderful house and collection. A great private collection in a house purpose built to display it. Good concept. A wonderful collection of paintings, furniture and other collectables. I enjoyed selecting each room in the audio guide and hearing how these rooms were designed and then selected the details for the artworks I liked. Fantastic atrium courtyard in the middle.

I AGREE WITH THE MAJORITY-ONE OF THE BEST. The Frick seems to be rated at or near the #1 attraction in New York City. I cannot disagree.
The building itself is almost worth the price of admission. After tolerating the crowds at so many other NYC attractions, do yourself a favor and languish at The Frick.
lovely veneers. the frick has several wonderful veneers. Just stunning. also several amazing sargent portraits and rubens.
A Gem. Not everyone knows about this gem of a museum, but it is worth a visit. It is not a large museum so it will not take you very long, but it is a true gem in the heart of Manhattan.

Great Museaum and Less Busy!!. This is a great little gem in Manhattan for someone who would like to see world-class art but without the crowds. I loved the Vermeers at this museum and the collection overall is vast and fascinating. This place was near our hotel (The Carlyle) and it was really nice to be able to enjoy the art without being rushed. This is a New York Must-See.

See the Frick.. A wonderful private art collection in a lovely old mansion. The price, I felt, was a bit steep at $20 pp. this is a collection that is not overwhelming but varied with works by Rembrandt, VerMeer, Turner, Monet to name a few. Easily done in1-2 hours. Central Park is right there. So a great time to stroll the park as well

A step back in time. After hearing about 'The Frick' for years, I was pleased to visit on a recent trip to NYC. Beautiful, restored mansion abutting Central Park filled with art and home furnishings/decor of the family. Impressive audio guide was a real plus. Expansive collection. If you're a lover of classical art and homes of some of our nation's wealthiest, you'll love this venue. My only regret: no photos (even w/o flash).
Surprising. I was really surprised by this collection, so small and so rich! Wonderful architecture and amazing work of arts

Gem in Manhattan. Wow, this was such a nice surprise, to find a mansion turned museum mid-Manhattan. I have never seen so many Dutch Masters paintings. There was a glorious finding in every nook and cranny. Make sure you give yourself a couple of hours to enjoy the mansion and it's collection.

Don't miss The Frik. Lived the beautiful old Madison left to the city. The late Mr Frik left his beautiful home complete with beautiful and so mant art work. Many of the masters and the enclosed garden lovely. Admission was $20 each but worth it if you like art

One of the best galleries visited- a great private collection. Set in the stunning family home of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick this museum houses his personal art and artefact collections. Well hung and presented the visitor feels like entering a private space. The mix of famous artists is a great pleasure to visit and enjoy. The entry charge also includes an audio guide which is a must.

A walk through your Art History book. Stunning! Masterpiece after masterpiece all set in the opulent residence of the Frick family. These paintings are the original pieces you've enjoyed seeing in your textbooks. This museum is a "must see" and truly amazing. Go there...do it now!
Everything under one roof and a beautiful building as well!. Love it love it love it. One of everything. A joyous collection. Restful interior garden. Wonderful history of the frick family.

An art lover's museum. the Frick collection is pretty small and one can only visit the rooms on the ground floor of the house, but for art lovers there are some real gems here, from a lovely Renoir hidden away at the bottom of the stairs to the fantastic Goyas in the gallery. It is $20 to get in, which is pricey given what you can see in the Met for that, but if you've seen NY's other museums the Frick should be up there on your list - 1 or 2 hours is plenty and you can get a sense of how billionaires lived pre WW I. I wish they'd open up some of the upstairs. It would really enhance the sense of the house as a museum.
Beautiful art and architecture. The house itself is worth the visit! Be sure to see the Renoir under the stairs. Husband got lost- bring phones!

Great venue, staff could be more welcoming. We specifically sought out the Frick on this visit to NYC and spent a full day there mid-week. Viewing a great collection in someone's home is always a treat and while busy, it has a much more peaceful vibe than the Met or MOMA. We found a few members of the staff quite welcoming and forthcoming with info but others who weren't. It'd be nice to be treated like you're welcome and given a few guidelines like here's the brochure that gives the lay-out of the house, there is a film in the music room, the restrooms are downstairs, etc.

Underwhelmed. First of all if I hadn't been to the The Wallace Collection in London recently I wouldn't have been so underwhelmed. The latter is a similar set up being a large mansion, former home of Sir Richard Wallace who collected art and porcelain. I still remember those glorious miniature boxes even now. Also it's free! So although I enjoyed the Frick for being a small and accessible collection with some great art including Vermeer and Turner it doesn't bear comparison. In my opinion.

A gem of a museum. Close to Central Park in the museum area, the Frick was a pleasant surprise and a welcome respite in uptown Manhattan. An historic home turned museum, the Frick is an elegant manageable collection of beautifully appointed rooms with an exquisite art collection. The museum has the feeling of being transported back in time, elegant period furniture in the rooms, huge vases of lilies in vases and a collection of art any museum would be proud to procure. The atrium begged one to stay and relax an oasis in the center of this once grand home to the Frick family. I
A morning at the Frick. Fantastic collection of art in a beautiful 5th Avenue mansion. Good value, not crowded, excellent narratives of the art on hand-held tape recorders.

Splendid Museum. Fine art should be delivered to the public in small doses so that it can be digested and enjoyed in the best possible way. It is so with the Frick Collection, a jewel box of a museum with a splendid combination of very important works of art by very famous artists along with sculpture, fine furnishings, enamels, and porcelains. The museum is small enough to be viewed in an hour or so - and then you can go back to re-visit your favorite objects and artworks.This beautiful museum was once the home of Henry Clay Frick which was constructed between 1913-14. Mr. Frick had an eye for fine things and each object in the collection is of the best quality. There are representations from Europe's finest artists - splendid Turners, Holbeins, Goyas, Rembrandts, El Greco's, and not one, but two Vermeers. The collection is awesome. And the quality is so overwhelming, that it's easy to miss things. I had to ask a guard where the Duccio was located and went back to spend time with it. I was in heaven.No photographs in the museum except for the garden court. Bring glasses so that you can read the labels. Labels aren't the easiest to read. Free audio tour with admission.

Small, but lovely museum. The museum is located in what used to be Henry Fricks home on 5th Avenue. The collection is small, but outstanding, and includes several old masters, such as Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Goya.Due to the size of the museum, it has an intimate atmosphere, and part of it is the beautyful furniture.We went on a Sunday, where you pay what you wish between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m., but the quality of the collections makes a visit worthwhile anytime.

A jewel of an Art Museum. Probably my favourite art museum ever. I love looking at the art in a beautiful heritage home. And the scale of the space is perfect. You can thoroughly enjoy this gem without getting exhausted!

An Outstanding Art Collection. This outstanding collection of mainly portraits is housed in a wonderful house at 1 East 70th Street NYC.The collection includes works by Rembrandt,Bellini,Reymond,Reynolds,Constable,Howgarth and Gainsborough as well as magnificent furniture and sculpture.It is well set out and easy to navigate with inexpensive entry.A very pleasant way to spend a coupleof hours even if you only go to see the house.

Frick: A Museum to Discover. Mr. Frick, a steel magnet, built a beautiful estate on Central Park East. The museum houses Renoir, Degas, Rembrandt, and others. Beautiful indoor garden with water features and huge ferns. Marble masterpieces. Worth the cost.

Not to be Missed! Spend Several Hours Here!. This is a lovely, warm, elegant museum. If you are in New York City you should go here (and the Morgan as well). Allow at least two hours, to really enjoy what is offered you should linger over the many beautiful pieces.It is small but everywhere you turn there is an exquisite painting or enamel or sculpture, a vase or a clock. We were there for about an hour and a half which is, in my opinion, the minimum time. A few notes. First, they have an audio tour available right after you pay and enter. I didn't use it but many people did. Second, there is a brief movie shown on the half-hour which is a good introduction. I would also read up on Henry Frick and the Collection before you go (especially his acquisitions from Morgan). Also, go to the website and see the virtual tour beforehand. Third, do not touch the tables with the bronzes. There are no ropes and I put my hand on the table to lean in for a closer look and a guard very politely asked me to move back. Finally, my mother uses a walker and was able to get around without a problem.
Small unique art museum. It is a little bit of a long walk but the art collection is worth your time. When walking back to take time to Enjoy Central Park

This is the way to live. If you enjoy museum and glimpses into the past, you have to go the the Frick. First off, it is one of the last remaining mansions on 5th. It is grand. The Vermeers and the story of how they were acquired is interesting. The sun room with the statues in beautiful. This is the good life!!

A special museum. This museum is housed in the former Fifth Avenue home of industrialist Henry Frick. It's small enough to get around and understand, and the movie about the house helped put it into perspective. It was easy enough to navigate with a nice amount of special paintings from Rembrandt, Goya and other artists. It's not overwhelming like some museums. Recommend it highly if you've already done some of the other more prominent musuems.
Fantastic Hidden Gem. One of the best museums I have seen in NYC. In addition to art they have a lot of clocks that are in working order.

Awesome private collection. You can watch Vermeer here, very naturally. I went on Sundays, pay-what-you-wish from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. It's not so big, so if you go to early this day, you may wait in front of entrance.

Great museum in NYC. This is a small museum with a fantastic collection. It was once the home of Mr Frick who was a great collector. It has paintings, furniture and sculptures. It is well with a visit and the audio players are awesome.

My favorite museum. This museum is so cool for even the novice art and history enthusiast! It has plenty to see, is set up for easy viewing in the mansion and keeps you interested throughout! This is a definite for anyone visiting NYC as a great way to see fantastic art without spending 2 days to get through it!

Fantastic. Make sure. That you see it!
A museum at central park, inside and outside nice
Not to big. You can walk to the gugenheim, but this museum we liked more
Well worth a visit!. This is a great art gallery. A beautiful building that houses a great collection. The Vermeer paintings are worth the visit by themselves.
Stunning. This museum is the old Frick Mansion and is absolutely amazing, what spaces and what an art collection. For lovers of architecture and absolutely stunning art you need to go here.

Classic. Small enough to savor and enjoy.. This small museum used to be someone's home, which is enough to make most jaws drop. The garden adjacent is also open to the public, with statues and so on. The house--mansion, really--and the patio are beautiful, with art that competes with any museum. It is intimate and though there's no hurry and you can easily spend several hours there, you can also see it in an hour or two if you have a window of time and want to do a bit of museum'ing without getting your feet tired or your brain swimming with too much items. I wish more of the house was open to exhibits (only the ground floor is), but it is still a pretty impressive place. Right smack in the middle of Manhattan, on 5th Avenue, right across the street from Central Park, close to many good restaurants (on Madison but even more on Lexington a couple more blocks down). Been there several times over the years. Always great.
Inside a glorious old world villa-. A most beautiful mansion housing a wonderful collection of earlyItalian drawings.Really worth a visit-!!

A must to visit. Absolutely fabulous collection - not like a Museum but walking through a house, very old furniture. Beautiful displays of china and pictures, lovely garden in the middle. Definetly worth a visit.

Simply the best!. If I could have dreamed up a lovely setting for the very finest art in the world, it would not have come near what the Frick has to offer. The quality of the surroundings and the joy of the magnificent art on display make this surely the finest art collection open to the public in the USA. Vermeer, Rembrandt, Holbein, Turner, Reynolds, the list is endless and there are some wonderful surprises on the way. This is a must for any art lover.
WONDERFUL EXPERIENCE. Kate, our personal guide, was fantastic. She made Mr. Frick and his "bungalow" come to life. This collection is truly a gem.

Small but powerful!. I had read that the Frick was possibly "redesigning" the building and gardens so wanted to be sure we were able to see the original building again before any changes were made. It offers a wonderful collection of English, Italian, Flemish and Dutch masters in a home setting. A sense of the history of an American collector.

If you're an art lover, this is a must see!. This was our second visit to the Frick and we are so glad we returned. The intimate nature of this museum make it such a joy to visit. If you love Vermeer, like I do you'll be thrilled to find three of them here. One piece of advice: Sunday morning was much busier than we anticipated because it turns out that on Sundays between 11AM & 1PM you can choose to pay less than the regular admission price. Lots of folks seem to take advantage of this.

My Favorite Little Museum. The Frick is a step back in time and a great overview of European Masters, nicely presented in this elegant mansion. Each time I visit, I discover something new. This visit, I walked down the newly enclosed Portico Gallery and discovered the Clodion sculpture, The Dance of Time, Three Nymphs Supporting a Clock. What a treasure.

Intimate and astounding. It is a mansion just across from Central Park on the East side and presents a remarkable art collection in a manageable size. It is small enough kids won't complain, but the collection is so remarkable that adults will appreciate the beauty of it. Go. It is worth it - and then you can get lunch nearby.

A beautiful home.. What a gift the Frick family has given NYC. I must say, however, that I found the ambience to be very 'stuffy' and off-putting. The paintings and other art and furniture were a pleasure to see.

small museum, great collection. I've visited the Frick Collection four times to date, and each time it remains a gem. What's nice about it - other than the great paintings and occasional roving exhibitions - is that it is small enough not to exhaust you. The entrance fee is, however, on the higher end for this scale of a museum...

Good collection by FRICK, Nice to visit. wonderful collections by Frick .... excellent paintings.. proved the importance of cultural values .. under 10 years not allowed inside .. entry free on Sundays.. taking photos only allowed in one hall.. ok can watch .. near by metropolitan museum is there .. so covering all these at a time.. will make you feel bored..
A must. Without a doubt the most amazing Museum I've ever been too. It was incredible, and takes about 1.15hr to go around the whole building.

The Freeky Frick Collection. In this private museum you could experience what life was likeover 100 years ago and delve into the mind of a great visionary for building his home and his art collection. It had a grandiose and serene quality about it.

Went looking for the Gold Finch.... Amazing interior and art lovers will enjoy the tour. I didn't find out until the end of our visit that the Goldfinch had only been there on loan at one point...so was a little disappointed as this was not obvious when I looked on the website
Absolutely fabulous gallery. Beautiful private mansion with stunning range of European master pieces. Good audio guide and shop. Not so crowded as some of the other galleries - peaceful atmosphere.

Must-see, mind-blowing collection. I'll keep this short and sweet: go see it, you won't regret it! This collection is just staggering.
If you're on a budget: on Sundays it's pay what you like as an entry fee so everyone can get in on student rates (or less if you're really pinching pennies).

Old Masters on Fifth Avenue. The Frick Collection is housed in the former mansion of Henry Clay Frick whose European master paintings by Vermeer and others fill about 6 galleries along with fine furniture and carpets.. Some paintings are still displayed as Frick himself arranged. The Frick is on Fifth Avenue below the Metropolitan Museum of Art between 70th and 71st streets. It's on "museum mile" so from the lovely Frick you can walk up to the Met, the splendid Neue Galerie and to the Guggenheim among others.
Deserving of its reputation. A private home updated to museum status. What a collection! A private collector did all this. Van Gogh, Rembrandt, Degas! A must!
A Magnificent Mansion. A great Fine arts Mansion. The paintings collection is truly exquisite, as are the porcelain and metallic statues/figurines. The gardens are also worth a visit.
Great Museum. A beautiful home on the edge of Central Park houses this wonderful collection. It is a great way to spend an afternoon.
Wonderful art collection. A fabulous collection of art in a beautiful setting. We spent a whole morning looking. Hand held audio descriptions were perfect for viewing at your own pace.

A highlight of our NYC experience. We were astounded by the number of famous European masters represented in this collection. Children under ten are not permitted to visit the Frick collection, nor is photography permitted except in the internal courtyard. Moving between the various stunning rooms, it becomes obvious why such rules should be enforced. This is not like any other museum or art gallery. Not only are there many, many large scale paintings on display but also vases, urns, statues and furniture are on open display. We visited around noon mid week and found that it was not at all crowded Audio sets are included in the admission price, but there are also free guided tours. It is a very quiet place to visit, probably because visitors are in respectful awe of what the Frick collection entails. A walk through Central Park opposite after our visit really rounded off our day.
Stunning art works. I have never seen such a collection of amazing art works by famous artists. As one who is not a great follower of painters and artists this just blew me away.

Beautiful collection. A beautiful place with an impressive art collection. Small, you can see it in one morning or afternoon. You can have a glimpse of what was the way of living of the rich people in the early twenties.

Unparalleled Quality. The Frick is a "Collection" not a museum because the holdings are Frick's personal choice. He always chose the best. You can appreciate this by viewing the Frick and then going uptown to the Metropolitan Museum of Art where you can see many of the same artists' lesser works.
A must do for art lovers. The Frick Collection is exceptional. QuIte AA few J M W Turner paintings. Eclectic in some senses but just a wonderful collection - a must do for art lovers

Not so nice guy--great art.. The history of Frick and what he did to afford such a collection is very violent & abusive. But, as far as the art & his home, it is well worth the visit. The collection is very comprehensive and well displayed. It's not often you get to see such a variety of artists displayed in such a setting.

Great, small museum!. If you enjoy art, make sure you check their exhibits. Sometimes the temporary ones are worth revisiting this magnificent museum. I particularly like their cloister. It's a great place to sit and meditate about what you've seen.

Civilized New York. Every weary traveler touring NYC should take some time at the Frick, one of the most elegant and civilized spots in the rushed city. The elegant rooms that once housed the Frick family are gracious and welcoming. The art is excellent and much more manageable than the big museums. And the center courtyard is a wonderful place to sit and relax.

Perfect & manageable.. This is a small but beautifully created collection of paintings but also furniture and style in an old house created by millionaire Frick in the early part of the 20th century. Walking through the rooms you get all the atmosphere of the period, the dining room is sensational and the west gallery. The audios (free) are invaluable and informative. It is well worth a two hour ramble into another world in the heart of NYC. Compared to the Met (and you can't really...), the Frick is easy to get around and absorb. The Met is a three month odyssey, but the Frick is comfortably enjoyed over half a day.

Magnificent. Hard to say more about this wonderful collection. It is truly stunning what has been amassed and put on view for the public. We went on Sunday morning which is by donation between 11-1. People in front of us donated a dollar each. My group paid half price of regular admission and felt it still a great bargain. The line was long but moved quickly to get in the doors.

Fabulous Building and Collection. Great artwork and individual information handsets were brilliant and enabled you to gain information about the artwork and rooms. Not too big so you could spend time and enjoy each piece. Family history film very interesting as it gave background to the building and collection. Loved it.

Great opportunity to visit. Nice art museum in a beautiful setting. Many of the paintings are breathtaking and the home is equally stunning. The hand held devices for interpreting and history of the art pieces were informative and concise. *Hint: for a limited time on Sunday AM, you can pay whatever you like to enter the museum.

Beautiful setting. The Frick Collection has been on our must see list for a while. It is situated on 5th Avenue facing Central Park. The home was said to be built to be a museum one day, which it now is. The museum not only houses many famous artists paintings, but the furnishings inside are themselves part of the art. Each rooms details from the woodwork, wallpaper and furniture are exquisite. Only allowed to take pictures in the inside atrium/garden. Well worth the visit .

Loved the Fragonard Room. Frick's museum is a masculine and muted backdrop to an amazing collection of art. It was very crowded, which is New York, lots of people on cell phones getting information on the art. It is an extensive collection of art. I saw Vermeer, Corot, Han's Holbein's famous portrait of Sir Thomas Moore, Whistler, Gainsborough, El Greco, and the lovely Fragonard Room, with wall to wall landscapes of teenagers in love in swings and atmosphereic gardens with statues, ribbons and cherubs. I had to take a second peek before I left to remember it, one of my favorite childhood artists.

Wonderful Experience. The Frick Museum is a great place to visit and dream about the most beautiful and opulent aspects of life. Firstly, situated on Fifth Avenue right on the Park, the mansion must be one of the finest properties on Manhattan. The collection is expansive, extensive and divine. The internal courtyard is perfect to sit, relax and soak in the wonderful atmosphere. And if you are in the City on a Sunday, you can experience all of this for as little as 1 dollar. In a city of a thousand must sees, this surely must rank as one of the most impressive.

Change of Pace. Visiting the Frick Collection enables you to avoid the crowds at the Met. Mind you, you can get crowds here too, nonetheless, give it a try. While there is not much represented by Iimpressionists paintings, I especially enjoyed Manet's Bullfight. The portraitures are remarkable. Enjoy the central garden where you can take a few pictures.

Favourite Museum in NYC. The Frick Collection is stunning. We went to this small museum on the recommendation of someone who had been before us. It turned out to be one if my favourite places in NYC. If you go on Sunday between 11am-1pm then entry is pay as you wish, rather than $20 pp. Be warned though, it's packed with 100's of people so try and get in early. The building is beautiful and the art is brilliant. It's a great place which we highly recommend. We spent the rest of the afternoon in Central Park. And it was a great way to spend the afternoon.

Remarkable collection. Having spent time in many European cities this is a great accessible art collection.We turned up at just before 10 and joined a queue of 20 people. Once in, its 20 dollars, we went the other way round to have a few rooms to our selves.Fabulous collection, its unfair to pick any out but, two Holbeins of Moore and of Cramner, over a fire place, two Turner seascapes opposite each other, a room of Whistler...Its well worth a visit, its great

Very nice collection.. This museum isn't that big so you can get through it in a couple of hours. Many artists are represented in the collection. The audio tour not only gives more information about certain pieces but gives you background about Frick and the house so I think it is worthwhile. It's well worth a visit.
Awesome!. We went to the Frick house and I didn't know what to expect and it turned out being awesome. Free admission on Sundays between 11-1. Loved the art & the building itself was beautiful
Great collection. We didn't have a lot of time and given it had been years since visiting the Frick it was a terrific choice

Fascinating story, building and collection. A little pricey for it's size, the Frick Collection is a beautifully curated example of how to do galleries well. The building itself is fascinating and beautifully fitted out. Wherever your eye falls you'll find something to investigate.

A peak into history. I really enjoyed this Collection. The furniture was exquisite and the artwork and sculptures beautiful. I particularly liked the Men in Armor showing as well as the sculptures from Clodoin and Houdon. I also enjoyed standing inside the home and having a view of Central Park. I can only imagine how beautiful that view will be on a wintery day. I can't wait to go back then.
