Surprising museum. This is my favorite museum I have visited in New York, hands down. I even like it better than the Met! The quality of the art here is outstanding and the variety is unexpectedly vast. I love the intimate atmosphere, you are actually visiting the original Frick mansion with the original furnishings and objects d'art. Highlights include the beautiful indoor atrium with a garden and fountain, the video of the history of the Frick Collection in the auditorium, and Fragnonard's "Progress of Love" drawing room. Also don't miss the Van Eyck oil in the first room and the Ingres portrait in one of the main drawing rooms. I spent a few hours in this museum and didn't want to leave! Look for the collection of clocks and timepieces in the house, they are truly one of a kind and very interesting to learn about. The Frick gift shop is a really great place for the art and history nerd in your life; you can find a book about almost anything art related. I love that the Frick is lesser known, which equates to less crowds. I also love that children under 10 are not admitted. Call me mean but I like to view my art in peace.
unique and gorgeous. A beautiful building with fittings that are extremely appropriate. the art collection is stunning and unique. Velasquez, Vermeer, etc. Can't be found anywhere else.
Frick Museum. Probably the best private art collection I have ever seen. Three Vermeer's, Rembrandt's an so much more.

Amazing house and art collection. Quite a variety in the furniture, art, pottery, and other pieces. See the movie first (if you arrive near the movie start time) to get the background on Mr. Frick and the house, and then take the audio tour. It is free with the price of admission. The two guards we spoke with were knowledgeable of the museum and one almost insisted we take the audio tour. We had previously breezed by the audio tour station thinking it was an additional expense. Most of the rooms have an assigned number. When you enter a room just type in the number and get an audio overview of the room. The works of art are also assigned a number, either individually or by collection. Type in the numbers you are interested in and hear a well written, informative and interesting description. We didn’t have enough time, but if we did, I would have typed in every single room and art number into the audio tour device. It was that good.
Mega Masters. Fantastic collection of world reknowed paintings by all the great artists in a sumptuous, once private, mansion. Very good audio guide too. The shop was disappointing and no tea rooms.
As usual, magnificent. I can only thank Mr. Frick, his descendants and the Foundation that runs the museum. I can't get enough of this wonderful oasis in the middle of NYC.

What a Collection. This is a delightful museum with a wonderful mix of well known paintings that blend beautifully within this Manhattan mansion. The furniture and silver is spectacular and the joy of this collection is that is all at ground floor level

A small gem. A monument to one man's taste, this lovely old mansion houses an amazing and beautiful collection of paintings, sculpture, ceramics, furnishings and more. Exquisite Meissen vases are juxtaposed with portraits by Gainsborough and Reynolds, or land- and seascapes by Turner and Constable, all in the setting of a private home, albeit that of a very wealthy man. Do yourself a favour, go and see for yourself.
Don't miss this!. Grand, beautiful house, great art and a really good audio tour. As you go by room, enter a number and you get a description of the room or the artwork. Allow about 2 hours.

A great collection of acknowledged masters in one of NY's best mansions.. Read the history of Mr Frick and his some before you visit. I haven't seen every private collection but this surely has to rank among the best collection of any private citizen in the world. The house is astonishing, built to display the art in a series of connected salon-style rooms. I need to go back for a longer visit to better appreciate some of the magnificent pieces in this collection.
You'll just want to move in!!. A wonderful trip - you can spend ages here, but even if you've just got an hour, it's worth a visit.
Stunning collection of art. The museum is amazing, showcasing the incredible wealth accumulated by industrial titans of that era, and one of the best collections of art to be seen.

Outstanding. Light rain changed our plans and we headed here for a couple of hours and what a good decision that was. Not crowded, so many helpful attendants/security people and so many artworks I'd seen before in print or elsewhere or just knew about. Recommend to anyone
Lovely displays of art. An enjoyable way to spend the afternoon strolling through the museum housing personal collections of artifacts and old paintings. The staff was cheerful and accomodating.
Well worth a visit. Lovely place to visit. Great for those that don't like large galleries as this takes less than an hour to get round but some greats things to see and not crowded.
Wonderful Exhibit. We had a wonderful time viewing the beautiful collection at the Frick museum. I would highly recommend it to people visiting New York.

Great little museum with some great art. We didn't have lots of time to do one of the big galleries but wanted to include something, The Frick is house on the edge of Central Park. It has some great art collected by Frick who owned the house. It is nice to view the art in the house he built to show off his collection! A nice bit of peace and tranquility in the middle of all the hustle and bustle of New York, There is a audio guide that you can dip in and out of,

House makes the Museum. I am more of a modernist, so the collection was Nice, but the true masterpiece is the House (Mansion). One family/the heart of Manhattan/images of the furniture that must've filled each room/the heating bill? Wish we could see the upstairs.

Perfection for an art gallery. This museum is centrally located next to Central Park along Museum mile. It was already on our list of sites to see but it surpassed our expectations. The building and collection is not so large that you get tired as you do in the major museums. It is kept in excellent order and in a home setting. The paintings are of the finest quality and the building almost like a Stately Home which in reality it is.The staff were both helpful and friendly and we had enjoyable chats with more than one. This helped to make our visit a very pleasant one. You can only take photos in the garden court with its statues, plants and water pools - exquisite. The shop is well stocked and has two guide books, one simply of the paintings, the other a different shape which shows more of the building etc. Mindful of the weight in my suitcase with the growing number of guide books from our trip to New York, I could not resist this one and will have much pleasure in savouring the visit. The collection is all on one floor with a short film in one of the rooms so you get a chance to sit down, there is seating in other rooms as well. The rest room is downstairs and there is a water fountain if you are thirsty just outside it. There is also a cloakroom to deposit your bags and coats which is free. There is no café and therefore you will have to eat and drink elsewhere
A small and excellent collection. This is one of the greatest collections an art lover can wish for. Every work is a whole experience. The house itself is also beautiful.

Amazing collection of art!. Great find - enabled us to escape the heat of Central Park and enjoy great paintings etc. Enjoyed the hand held commentary which enabled you to log into the background history of paintings and artefacts on display. Particularly liked Constable painting of Salisbury Cathedral as close to home in UK.
Worth a visit. This collection is worth seeing. The home is magnificent and the audio tour is brilliant. It is a peaecful space to be in.

Wonderful collection of Art in beautiful setting. Was my first visit to the Frick Collection. Stately mansion whose architecture is as much a draw as the art inside. A more intimate setting than a grand museum with much to see. Interesting to imagine what life was like for those who resided in this grand setting.

Intimate museum with impressive European collection. This is a lovely, small museum that was the former home of the art collector. It is just beautiful. Every time we entered a new room, we were surprised about the number of European artists that were represented. Seeing the 3 Vermeers alone is worth the trip. We spent a few hours here, and I could have spent an entire day; but if you don't have time for the Met this is a great alternative. We arrived mid-afternoon and there was no line at all. We have an affiliate membership through the Detroit Institute of Arts and upon showing our cards, we received free entry. See my previous review on the Art Institute to learn more about the affiliate membership.

A must see. We went early and waited for the Frick to open as we were flying home later that day. Our time in NYC had passed quickly but, having read about how worthwhile the visit would be, we were determined to see it and we were not disappointed. The Frick Collection is one of the finest gatherings of European paintings in the United States. The items are rarely, if ever, on loan outside of the Frick site. The buildings they are housed within is worth the visit too. We would definitely recommend this as a must see when visiting New York.
A beautiful setting.. Located in what was a private house this places the art in an original setting that is very atmospheric.

The Frick. we went for the dutch exibition which was wonderful, however smaller then expected, only 30 pieces in the show.the museum itself is small and can feel cramped if crowded but the space itself is magnificient, worht the visit, but gete tickets in advance otherwise you may be waiting on line for 30 minutes
So impressive!. The Frick Museum is a "must-see" for anyone with an interest in art. The collection is expansive and impressive, and the staff is so friendly and helpful.

Small and beautifully formed!. An excellent way to spend an hour in a beautiful house amongst so many beautiful objects - furniture, porcelain, sculpture but most notably a great collection of old master paintings.

Gem of a museum with three Vermeers. There are only a handful of Vermeers in U.S. museums and the Frick has three of them. Even if their collection weren't world class this would be worth the visit just for the lovely interior space. Without question this is one of the great small museums of the world. A trip to NYC isn't complete without a visit.

A Little Gem. I visited the Frick years ago on a private tour and still remember being awed by its collections. In the Upper East Side, it is MUST-DO if you are spending the day at the Met or visiting the Guggenheim. The Frick is special: it's small, it's less well-known, it's simply enchanting. MOST HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

Breathtaking art. A visit to the Frick Collection should not be missed. The house itself is amazing with its period furnishings true to the lifestyle of the Frick family. The art collection is breathtaking. Admission is $20 however on Sundays, your contribution is at your choice and voluntary.Located in the museum mile stretch in NYC means you can easily visit two museums in one day, if you are pressed for time.
Wow. Another stellar art museum in New York City. Staff was nice and I found the collection inspiring. Highly recommend.

Absolutely fantastic museum. The Frick collection has to be one of the most beautiful collections that I have ever visited, not just for the collection but also the building in which it is housed. The sheer enormity of this collection defies belief and then to have it donated to the public is very humbling.

Favorite museum. This is one of my favorite museums. Not for children. The beautiful home of mr. Frick. They give you free headphones that tells you all about much of the artwork , house and furniture. They have a docent lecture at one and three .It's a small and easily maneuvered museum.

A museum that makes you feel like you own it. The Frick collection is one of those musea of which one says ' this won't be my last visit' when leaving it (I have the same with e.g. The Courtauld Gallery in London). This is an absolute gem with pearls by a.o. Rembrandt, Whistler, El Greco and magnificent bronzes. Top class!

A real surprise packet. This may be an under-rated attraction, but its small size means you can see the whole of the museum. And besides the magnificent art collection it contains wonderful collectables, objects d'art, and furniture and furnishings. Don't miss it !

The most wonderful small museum of New York.. Yes the palatial residence of the wealthy New Yorker creates, with its patio, an unbeatable atmosphere. But wandering around and discovering the superb paintings or the special exhibitions is always a renewed pleasure.

Unique Museum. To be able to see the actual mansion and then the priceless art collection in situ, it's really quite amazing! A pleasant surprise is to be able to see the original decorating- all the original furniture and draperies and whatnot. The main living room is left exactly as it was. You can't go upstairs which is a big disappointment, in his house Clayton in Pittsburgh the entire house is open for the tour (totally worth it if you're ever there). There is quite a mix of objects, from clocks to sculpture to furniture and of course paintings. Was busy but not over-run the way some major exhibits or popular works can get in a major museum, plenty of time to look at whatever you wanted. I highly recommend!

A New York Must-Do. This is a fantastic glimpse into life in NYC in the early 1900's together with a wonderful display of art. The building is itself a glimpse into how the rich and famous lived in that time and the art, almost all of which is as it was displayed 100 years ago, is thoughtfully presented. For someone who is not too interested in art galleries it was still a memorable visit made all the better by the helpful staff and the general sense of spaciousness that prevails.Absolutely worth a visit.

Amazing collection. The house itself is a work of art. You can see the entire collection within a few hours and there are many masterpieces here. Don't miss the Rembrandt. There are some marvelous bronzes too.

Great Art, Great Setting. Wonderful art displayed in historic 5th Avenue mansion. The collection can be seen in one visit. Many of the artworks are truly masterpieces. Particular favorites are the Rembrandt portraits, the Holbeins, the Turners, the Monet ... I could go on and on. Don't miss it.
Best art gallery ever. The art is so well displayed that your vision is never 'crowded' by other works of artI think is probably the best art gallery I have ever been toShould not be missed

A glimpse of another world, another time. From our first minutes in this amazing mansion museum we were awe-struck Each and every room housed a breath-taking collection of priceless treasures beautifully presented Silk painted walls, glorious French furniture, exquisite sculpture and countless art treasures sometimes familiar made this a feast for the senses and the soul. We felt privileged to visit and now have a store of lovely memories
Beautiful. Lovely building and a wonderful collection of paintings. The audio guide is included in the price and photography isn't allowed so nobody taking selfies in front if the Holbeins!
nice collection. the frick collection is really nice and if you're passing by it's worth to enter and visit it. it's a 1 hour visit and it's pretty pleasant.

Impeccable taste! No-one taking photos - phew.. Frick clearly had impeccable taste, as this exquisite collection demonstrates. A tiny gallery, compared to the Met or MoMA, but a delightful space, with friendly staff and, because no-one is taking photos, an air of gentility and respect for the art which is glaringly lacking in the more iPhone-friendly museums.The audio guide was reasonable - but lacking in content, veering off into subjective and superfluous praise at times, rather than providing detailed historical context.A great find; the images of Cromwell and More glaring at one another across the fireplace, are not to be missed.
Gorgeous small museum with amazing art collection. Loved the set-up of the rooms as tho the owners just walked out... the garden room is lovely and the extensive art collection wonderful.

This is how the really rich used to live.. The Frick collection of old masters has to be one of the best in America. Combine that with much of it being presented in his mansion and you have a combination that cannot be beat. Highly recommended.

Frcik Collection: Wonderful small museum. The Frick is an Upper East Side neighborhood art collection housed in the former mansion of the most successful and notorious Robber Baron of the late 19th century, Andrew Frick. Not a nice guy! Visitors have to use their imaginations to visualize that once Fifth Avenue was lined with elegant mansions for the rich from 55th to 86th street. Of course, the Andrew Carnegie's mansion is another one still left; it is now the Copper Hewitt Design Museum. Visitors can get the feeling of being one of the richest people in the world as they tour this collection. It is small, but worth seeing. There are several priceless works in the permanent collection, including a Vermeer, some Bouchers, and a few Goyas. Highly recommended not only for art lovers, but for seeing how the .001 % lived!
Classic art. Great space, good history but art a little too medieval and European for my taste in art. See how the rich lived around WW I

a fave. Wonderful smll museum tht features a "greatest hits" collection-representation of many big names in Art History. The building itself is stunning as well, making it an all-around lovely way to spend the afternoon.

Best gallery in NYC but far more than just a gallery. Its a great art gallery, but its also a luxury mansion. Best of all its on a human scale where you can soak up the history and lifestyle of one of NYC's former megarich industrialists. Don't miss it and don't be put off if you are not big on art, its still a must visit.

Elegant and Zen. I often find the big museums frustrating because I just can't give the attention to each painting that I want and I can never cover the whole thing.The Frick is the perfect size and has a small (relatively) collection of exceptional pieces- and a wonderful atmosphere. You can put the chaos of your daily life and the noise of the city behind you and really lose yourself in the beauty of each piece of wonderful art- not to mention the spectacular features of the Frick family home.A must see if you are in NY

Cool choice on a hot Summer day. This is a good museum if you have a couple of hours. The docent lectures are 10-15 minutes and vary during the day, so you have time to tour a beautiful Robber Baron-era mansion filled with Old Master art.
Audio guide a must. The free audio guide expanded our appreciation of the history and background to the art pieces. Give yourself at least 2 hours if you want to go through each room thoroughly.

A special museum. When I realized that Henry Frick was who everybody knows, I felt upset that I had visited his mansion and had spent my money on his foundation. Even so, it's a great museum. We've visited it on sunday, which is its free day, therefore there were too many visitors. However, we had a special walk around there and could enjoy it enough.Waiting outside might be as long as the walk around inside but it worth visiting the mansion.Everything was absolutely swanky: its wonderful paintings and sculptures.

Great art masters displayed in splendor!. Many great artists works displayed in the Frick mansion. Monet, Renoir, Rembrandt, Vermeer, ElGreco, and other masters. A lovely, splendorous setting to view the art. Go on Sunday from 11-1 for free admission. It is a lovely place. I recommend a visit.

Spoilt by over zealous security officers. My husband and I were really looking forward to visiting the Frick Collection, because of the architecture of the building as well as the artwork. However the visit was ruined by security officers shouting at visitors to stay on the carpet. However as the paintings had only small plaques on the actual paintings, you had to get up close to read the information. Not everyone wants an audio guide when wandering around. So if the information was larger, then perhaps people would not have to get close to the paintings. I was stood next to a chair, not even touching it and a female security officer shouted at me to move away from the chair. It completely ruined my visit. I think the security officers need to be more customer focused and help visitors enjoy the experience rather than trying to catch them doing things wrong.

Excellent security checks. They do the checks very quickly by scanning which is good . Their are plenty of staff around to keep everything running like clock work. We went in on Monday morning and didn't have to wait to long.

WILL NEVER COME BACK. I decided to visit the Frick Collection. I almost had a wonderful time and I stress the word "almost" because of an incident that occurred to me while I was there. It was at the end of my visit and while I was in the area next to the outside garden, I took a photo. One of the black female security guards confronted me and said no photos were allowed. I tried to explain that I thought it was part of the garden and that's why I took the photo. In the end, I said I was sorry, put away my camera and walked away. In the very next room, another black male security guard in a very loud voice, confronted me and said that when I was told to not take photos and I said "NO". THIS WAS A TOTAL LIE. Not only was it a lie but he said it so loud that those around me turned around and noticed me. I was really humiliated and extremely embarrassed. Meanwhile, the original female security guard wasn't there when he confronted me. She had already left the room. The security guards ruined my whole time here. I WILL NEVER COME BACK.

Interesting collection. Not a huge selection but interesting art - especially loved the Rembrants. The center courtyard was lovely. Enjoyed the sculptures by Houdon and Clodion (along with the brief video of the collection). Also enjoyed the Fragonard collection.

Nice little museum. It's in Frick's home which itself is worthy of an afternoon, and the works are displayed throughout. They have a high quality collection. Some drawbacks: Even after a lengthy renovation a few years back. a lot of the house is still closed to the public. There is an absolutely beautiful garden and lawn which are sealed off as well. The people in the store don't answer the phone, and they don't keep the website updated as to what's available and what's sold out. Have been there when there was a docent giving a tour to some students and she seemed kind of dopey. You also have to go clicking all over their website to see their ticket prices and hours (Oy!). Keep in mind that Sundays between 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. are "pay what you will."

A Lovely Place. Came here on the recommendation of a friend, and I'm so delighted. This was a lovely home on 5th Avenue in days gone by with a wonderful collection of art. It was well displayed and explained in the audio tour. I'd suggest taking some time to relax in the courtyard after taking in all the art--it's quite lovely.

If you are a museum lover than.... don't miss the Frick, a former Madison Avenue home now a do not miss art Museum for those who just can't get enough. My favorite place here, though, is the indoor garden. Rain, snow or hot weather I always find peace here!
Just Beautiful!. An amazing collection of beautiful objects! If you love art, architecture and luxury, go! To have amassed this collection by one family is astounding!

Best Small Art Museum. Probably the best small museum in the world and I am including London, Paris, Rome, Florence and Madrid. It is a pleasure to walk around Mr. Frick's house and enjoy his spectacular collection just he must have. His library/office is every mans dream. This is a place that one can return to again and again and it is small enough not to induce museum fatigue but with enough treasures that there is always something to spend more time with.
My favorite museum. I loved everything about the Frick; it gave me a glimpse into what life was like back then and and for a moment in time, you can pretend that you are walking back in time.

Gorgeous Mansion. We went to the Frick primarily to see the Goldfinch, but were taken aback not only by the exhibits, but by the beauty of this museum. The clock exhibit was as awesome as the views out the large windows.
Stunning. Reflect that this was a private home; this is the home owners private collection, and revel in the sublime art works.....amazing

Dont Miss the Frick Museum!. One of the great places to visit in New York along with The Cloisters is the Frick Museum ,eastside of Central Park north. This beautifully presented house of the Frick family is a jewel not to be missed. It exudes bygone times and displays magnificentfurniture and furnishings along with breath taking works of art collected by the owners over many decades.
Beautiful and Unique. I can't believe one person owned such an amazing collection. The house itself is worth a visit being one of the only original central park mansions still around. Loved it.

Amazingly beautiful. I have been visiting NYC regularly for over 20 years and and for some reason have missed this. The Frick is one of the most beautiful, cohesive collections I have ever seen and the setting, a 5th Avenue mansion on the upper East side, has to be seen to be believed. It is truly wonderful and should not be missed.

Relaxing day at a small world class museum. Loved this museum. Enjoyed 3 hours of strolling through the rooms, with out having to experience the crowds of other larger museums. Quiet, peaceful and beautiful.

A boutique gallery. My entire experience of my visit to Frick Collection will always remain ingrained in my memory.The art collection is classic and in the most superb condition. The building alone is an exhibit of Neoclassical architecturewith fine antiques and furnishings. Take the time to sit and absorb the tranquility of the conservatory.I support The National Trust Of Australia and regularly visit our buildings so naturally I appreciate the thought and level excellencethis landmark offers. It is worth the visit.
fine mainly european art. Nice collection, worth a visit. One of the best museums of New York City. And not as busy and crowded as most of the others.
Children are not welcome. We were disappointed upon arrival to find out that children are not allowed. It would have been better to have it more clearly displayed on the website ticket section.

superb collection. we were recommended to visit the Frick by a friend of the family. By coincidence we went on a Sunday and found it was free entry between 11am and 1pm. It houses the personal art collection of mr Frick a multi-millionaire from the 1920s. There are some wonderful paintings (from 13th to 19th century) and an excellent audio-guide. This large house is perhaps not what I would have built if I had all those millions but is a good environment to display the paintings, furniture and sculptures.
Girl with the Pearl Earring. While there was a long line, the work was so lovely! The space is pretty neat as well, several dutch pieces!

Impressive Collection. The Frick Collection is an impressive collection of paintings, done by a number of well-known masters, including Gainsborough, Hals, Goya, and Turner. The portraits are especially impressive.
Well worth the ticket.
top 10 museum. one of top ten nyc museums, a must see. great to visit after a stroll through central park, west side to east side.

Unique collection. We really enjoyed this museum. The unique aspect of this museum is that it is someones private collection available to the puplic. Mr. Frick's idiosyncrasies come out in his book collection.

Best Museum in New York City. Unique museum in New York City. Housed in a 5th Avenue mansion on the upper East Side, its collection of old Masters is incredible. While the art is impressive, the mansion site is exquisite and fascinating in its own right. The one museum to visit in the City!
Frick Colleaction. It is OK for an exhibit of art, but too off-the-wall for me. I found would display not OK. If you're way out there and like modern, than go.
Excellent. Free or pay as you wish on Sunday mornings and not crowded. Small but very interesting and nice location
Fantastic collection. We thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Full of exquisite paintings, sculpture. The variety of the collection was impressive.

Great small museum. Great exhibit, small museum that felt intimate and didn't overwhelm. I liked its proximity to central park, Park avenue (and shopping nearby) and its relatively inexpensive fee to visit.
Time Machine. Visit a home that speaks to you from a bygone era of gentile beauty and graciousness...such art as you will rarely have an opportunity to behold up close...

Unique museum. I always enjoy museums created by their founders, such as the Frick and the Isabella Gardner Museum in Boston. One can appreciate the unique tastes of the founders, and the art and sculpture in these museums are well cared for.

Wonderful Exhibit. A must visit for those that enjoy sculpting and other pieces of fine art (paintings, pottery etc.) from the masters of the past. Not only are the exhibits wonderful, but the "museum" itself (a Mansion) is an exhibit in it's own right. We loved everything from the architecture of the museum to the exhibits and the knowledge and attentiveness of the staff. I would visit again for sure.
Go on Sunday. Sunday is name your price day, but please do not take advantage of it by paying $1. This is an excellent collection, and deserves 1-2 hours if you like the Masters.

Highly Recommend this GEM!. Art collection not to be missed. Impressive and significant. Pay what you wish from 11a -1p on Sunday mornings. A NYC bargain! Stunning home and contents that are significant artistically and historically. Be sure to get the audio tour. Highly recommend. Allow 2 hrs.
Wonderful. Brilliant, the furniture and the painting are worth while going to see we did a few museums and thought this one was one of the best.

Best collection in New York. The Frick is the one museum you must go to in New York. It is a more expensive entry free but is worth it. There is so much to see at the Frick. And some amazing artwork such as the Constables and the Vermeer's.

Amazing Collection. What you can do when you have a lot of money. No evidence of Frick's taste, just the best example of what money could buy when he was actively buying and have the best dealers working for you. Amazing collection and the house is interesting on its on. One of NY's must-see destinations.
Fab Frick!. A fabulous collection of old master paintings set in a exceptionally beautiful 5th Avenue Town House overlooking Central Park. A totally different experience to the likes of MOMA.

Amazing!. It was amazing to see the original collection in the original home setting. It's like Isabella Gardner Museum in Boston, but the original owner did a greater setting for the collection. Everything is great about this museum: works of art, furniture, architecture. Would like to visit it again!

I would live in this place.... A clean,well maintened,easy access house art gallery that not only gives you an idea of how the rich lived in th early 1900's in NYC but also a rare chance to view a collectors life in paintings and sculptures.Being Henry Clay Fricks mansion,this museum puts all his treasures up front in your face.No cords or glass casings to stop you from admiring these magnificient works of art.From the different rooms of the mansion to the garden,all is quiet and peaceful as the guests wander the mansion with audio guides that help you understand the art and culture behind these priceless works of art.After your tour of the mansion,just sit in the garden and relax from the hussle and bussle of city life.A must visit in this great city.
wow. A must to see, awesome. The villa is gorgeous, the private collection is wonderful and the view on central park is unique.

Awesome, good diverse collection, something for everyone. Loved the diverse collection, wished they had more benches to allow contemplation of the work I am an art teacher, and find it helpful to be able to relax and view art at a slow pace, not like going through a grocery store line love the collection, I will go back
Gem. Beautiful building and collection. The museum is in an exquisite residence with a gorgeous courtyard. The collection is amazing.
Wish it was my home. Hard to believe it was someone's home. Had a good time visiting. The furniture and the art was outstanding.

Wonderful Unique Museum/Art Gallery. First class collection of top painters work set in a unique way. Really nice to see art in a 'normal' environment on the walls of a house (OK mansion) rather than normal sterile gallery.

Outstanding art collection in a stunning building. The Frick Collection contains some of the very best works by European artists in the period from the middle ages up to the last century. Henry Clay Frick had the taste and discernment accompanied by the money to buy the best.Many of the paintings and sculptures in the collection are recognisable because they are in textbooks on their subjects. The quality is unique and uniform in its standard.The free audio guides are an indispensable aid as you wander through the Clay mansion and view his collection of major art works. The setting in his mansion just completes the experience. Best gallery in New York.No refreshments on site but just two blocks away at the corner with Lexington Avenue is a selection of excellent outlets.Get there for 10 am when it opens for a tranquil time to view the collection.

Curated Gem. With all the massive museums sprinkled through out NYC, the Frick is a smaller, quieter, more accessible art experience. Their collection is iconic and every time I visit this incredible museum my breath is taken away. One of my favorite paintings, Picasso's Garçon à la pipe hung on the walls here for a long time, until it circulated back to other museums around the world. A perfect place to spend an afternoon in NYC for any art lover.

For Art Lovers only. There are so many museums to choose from in NY. I chose the Frick Collection because I wanted to see how the family lived, including the kitchen, bedrooms, and office. It was disappointing to find that where he parked his car was replaced by a fountain, that there was only main floor access, with no access to bedrooms or basement kitchen where his personal chef worked. Really it was an art collection being stored in a house. If I could chose again, I would go to the Intrepid museum instead.
Big surprise. was really surprised about the quality of this museum and how well presented everything was - well worth a visit

What's not to like?. No matter how many times I visit this terrific gallery, I am pleased. Vermeer, Goya, Corot, Roccoco, Romanticism, Rembrandt, and more, all in a lovely setting that you can leisurely wander in a couple of hours. I come back again and again. POTENTIAL DISAPPOINTMENT ALERT: Families with small children note that your little ones will not be admitted if they are under ten years of age.

To see the Vermeers. such a find. we are trying to see all the Vermeers in the world and were so lucky that the 3 here were in the Frick and not on tour as so often happensfree on sundays ,first thing
Excellent Gallery. Such a peaceful place to view some wonderful art. Easier to cope with than the Met. It easy to get on the subway. Loved seeing the Vermeer paintings.

vac.. I was 3days and two nights as I was watching the game between Puerto Rico / usa and the deal was good hotel staff, what I liked was not the company for transportation from the airport to the hotel but the rest helped me to encanto.me solve the problem. thanks, would recommend 100%.
Perfect place to visit. One of my favourite 'museum' of New York. The real impression that there are still living in their home.
Nice it you like paintings. It was lovely, i do not appreciate art a whole lot, so maybe not the best person to ask. The Video was good though.

Amazing find!. What a great collection of art and sculptures! Tip - go on Sunday from 11:00 - 1:00. At that time it is "Pay what you wish". Normal admission is $20 but we paid $5 each because we didn't plan to stay long.

One of my FAVORITE places. I love coming here ... never get tired of it ... a fabulous collection in a very cool house/museum. After you are finished enjoying your morning at the Frick, walk a couple blocks east to the Asia Society Museum on Park Avenue and have an awesome lunch in the garden cafe there.

Impressive art collection, indifferent staff. Loved seeing so many great works from such a wide variety of artists and genres. Wish the upstairs had been available to see how the family actually lived, but was captivated by the amazing and wide range of art on display. I especially loved the Constable's 'Salisbury Cathedral' and Bronzino's 'Lodovico Capponi.'This had been on my bucket list of NYC attractions for the past five visits, so we made the Frick the top priority this go-round. However, it did dampen my ardor a bit to find that most, if not all, of the staff were very stand-offish, barely smiling or responding to greetings or questions. One exception was a gentleman in the library area who answered questions politely and gave us a genuine smile. We travel to NYC often, and find most people are extremely friendly and helpful. Not so at the Frick, unfortunately. The young man who helped me with my large purchase in the gift shop was especially frosty. I believe we would have stayed longer but just really were turned off by the rudeness of the staff. Overall, great assortment of varied artists, time periods and styles in a gorgeous setting that is impeccably presented. Just prepare to be treated with disdain and indifference by the large percentage of the employees there.
Frick Collection. The Frick Collection is a wonderful house museum with a phenomenal collection. Spent a very enjoyable afternoon exploring.
Don't miss it. great small museum packed with great art and furniture.Self-paced with audiocould have stayed all day

30 years later and still a favorite. When I was a kid my mother always loved this museum. She dragged us to it a number of times and always recommended it as a must visit. 30 years later I dragged my family over to see it and everyone loved it. The collection is amazing and it is so well put together. It really is a one of a kind collection.

Not to be missed.. Some friends had said you could miss this museum, l would say you should Not miss it. Set in a two storey building on 5th Ave, all the masterpieces are set in the house as if it was.If you enjoy European masterpieces then it is for you, if not give it a miss.Very good complimentary audio guide and intro video.

Interesting architecture but rather dry collection. I have visited here many times and find the collection instructive but rather dry. They do have a Rembrandt and a few other great masterpieces that should not be missed. The history of the building and the architecture is interesting. It was built by one of the notorious robber barons of the late nineteenth century.
The Frick - A must see!. Fantastic home turned into museum. Excellent diverse collection. Your admission includes audio guide.
Incredible. Worth every cent of my $20, an absolutely amazing place with the finest artwork I'd ever seen, a treasure of NYC.

Very special. Just seen that this is Nº1 on the list! On the one hand I find that surprising, as it was wonderfully calm, quiet and relaxed in mid August, no crowds, no queues, and only an handful of people to wander round with. On the other hand, I don't find that surprising at all, as it's absolutely fantastic! What a building, what art, what furniture, what a lovely museum! Would recommend the audio tour, if only for info on all the rooms themselves in the museum, the history of those is fascinating in itself. Highly recommended, and a free cloakroom, which is worth knowing too.
Wonderful. Very intimate museum, I especially appreciated the portrait of George Washington & the religious art.

Favorite museum in NYC. When I lived in NYC I used to come here at least once a month. It has a small collection, but very fine and with good breadth, so you aren't overwhelmed and can linger over each piece. The house is a piece of art itself. Don't miss this.
great collection. unique place with great collection...all in a beautiful home that was built to convert into a museum

Beautiful home and art collection!. We were able to use our Denver Art Museum membership for entrance into the Frick New York. We were invited to take an audio tour of the collection which exists all on the first floor of this large building. The paintings and sculpture and furniture are a collected history of a period of time. Numbers next to some items reveals more about it via the audio recorder.We started in Pittsburg at the Frick there and were so happy to see the rest of the story here. Very interesting and worth a visit but the items on exhibit change out since only the first floor living area is used as display space. Museum was smaller than I expected and we were done before we knew it. No photographs allowed.

this museum should never change. i never miss a visit to the Frick when in NYC. It feels cozy and luxurious, and the collection is varied, although all pre-modern. Nothing compares to sitting in the courtyard, or being so close to a Vermeer, El Greco, and amazing statues. This museum can be experienced in only an hour and a half, so it is a luxurious morsel of experience tucked into each NY trip.

The perfect 2 hour museum. From Hans Memling to Rembrandt and Vermeer to Turner and Degas, this is a greatest hits collection housed in one of the most spectacular mansions in Manhattan. The perfect two hours of art history.

Great way to spend an afternoon.... One of the best art collections I have ever seen in a unique setting - like visiting the house of the rich friend we all wish we had but of course don't.Collection includes Rembrandt, Goya, Turnball, El Greco, Constable. Mostly portraits and landscapes but many are recognizable from art books and high school art classes. Make sure you pick up the free audioguide that is included in the price of admission. The staff don't tell you it's free and there are no signs that indicate that either so make sure you ask when you pay. Staff there not the friendliest or most helpful. Very rules based as well - no photographs at all and no getting within 1 foot of any of the pictures and sculptures. Personally, i can understand why - the artwork is priceless and needs to be protected. Most of it is displayed in the open and within reach.Lots to impress even for those with only a very minimal knowledge of art.

A jewel in the crown of NYC. This wonderful museum never disappoints; I visit often to see my favorite paintings in a lovely setting. Go alone or with a companion; don't take the kids. Allow time to savor all the great works of art and allow yourself to be transported far from the hustle and bustle of the Big Apple.

A must see in NYC. Wonderful art collection in a 5th Ave mansion. A unique, wonderful museum to visit. See how the less than 1% lived -- wonderful collection of furnishings, paintings (including 3 by Vermeer) and some sculpture.

A Perfect gem of a museum. This is one of the world's great art collections, housed in an astonishing mansion which covers an entire block on 5th Avenue. Renoir, Rembrandt, Boucher, Fragonard, Turner - Henry Clay Frick collected them all, and arrayed them through the impressive public rooms of his amazing house. Easily the best small museum in NYC.

go back in time. The collection was put together with sole idea of collecting beautiful things. I go to the Frick to see the collection and the building and to take a break from the hurly burly of the city. I also buy art cards. What's not to like about that?
A small gem!. It is a small museum with an excellent private collection. You can do it in about an hour and a half and withing walking distance of Madison Avenue and Central Park.

Love This Museum. The Frick is my favorite NYC museum. It allows a peaceful, contemplative experience of art. In terms of its collection, it can't compete with MOMA or the Met, but it offers an experience that they can't match.

Nice museum in a fantastic house. Well situated.. It´s very close by and well worth a visit. Not so many tourists finds their way there. The surrounding is also very nice and very "New York" with a lot of good restaurants.

Exquisite. Huge Mansion on the upper east side where Frick lived in the early 1900s. Its ornately decorated and worth the trip if you are looking for something to do. You get to see how the wealthy lived back in the day. My wife and I enjoyed this trip very much. A must do in NYC.

Highly recommended!!. The building itself is as beautiful as the collection of paintings and sculptures. We spent about 1 hour there, but could have stayed much longer. I loved every minute of it! Don't forget to get the free self-guided audio tour, it's a must!
A beautiful location. It is a beautiful building and a beautiful location, with some nice pieces. In my opinion it is too expensive ($ 20) for its contents.

Superb couple of hours. A very good collection which is perfect for art lovers and for those who like exploring grand houses. Some amazing paintings and sculptures / items. A very enjoyable couple of hours. One for couples I'd say, it is likely to bore the pants off kids!

great art, rude employees. I loved The Frick Collection's artwork. The variety was wonderful, as was the audio tour. But every single employee I encountered was rude. I spent 9 days in NYC, yet only encountered rude people here. We are paying your salaries--treat us as you would like to be treated, or don't work with the public. Just a thought.....

gorgeous building, striking art, grouchy guard. My favorite room holds four paintings by Whistler. The collection also contains three of the 35 extant Vermeers. A golden Diana balances in a high- ceilinged glassed-in round room looking pensively out at a traffic light on 5th Avenue. I could not get close enough to see her expression because of a surly security guard who clearly hadn't been trained in the correct balance between keeping art safe and allowing for a peaceful, contemplation in an aesthetically stimulating atmosphere that people pay $18 to enter. I realize that this is New York, but I am the most harmless looking person you could ever meet.

Frick mansion something to see. This 1914 mansion is truly worth a visit. it holds Henry Clay Frick's art collection and furniture. simply beautiful. no photos of the collection were allowed however. Go on Sunday's when admittance between 11:00 and 1:00 is by donation.
Very nice. If you go at the right time you pay by donation. By our choice how much you pay. Very elegant museum.

Wondrous Art Collection. This is the most amazing private collection of art you are likely to see, including one of the best Vermeers anywhere ("Officer and Laughing Girl"). The man, Frick, may have been awful, but he certainly knew a thing or two about great paintings and there are enough of them here to satisfy most tastes, and beautifully presented as he left them. In addition, no cameras are allowed - which is a real bonus for old crusties like me who are beginning to wonder why some people visit art galleries - to study the art on view or to take pictures of themselves or friends standing next to the art works. A good catalogue is available, and some excellent postcards in the shop. A short distance from the Met, and a lot less tiring to get around.
Fantastic. Money well spent - simply amazing home/museum and art collection - first time I have seen a Rembrandt.
Beautiful setting for beautiful art. The house alone is worth a look, as the art is only enhanced by the superb surroundings. I would love to see the upper floors.
Another must do. If you appreciate art you would love this private collection. I have been to many of the worlds finest galleries and this one is in my top 5.

Fascinating small museum. Delightful small collection in stunning building which is as much an attraction as the art work.
An interesting collection of mainly European and British works but some American and Asian pieces too.
Well worth an hour or two to visit.

A PLEASANT SURPRISE. Decided to visit this place because of its high rating in tripadvisor and we are glad we did. This is a much smaller museum than the MET but our children (ages 12 and 17) enjoyed this visit more. I guess one of the reasons is that each guestis given a phone-like device where you just type the number indicated in each art piece and you will hear a brief background and description allowing us to appreciate it more. It also interesting to note that the place used to be Mr. Frick's house. It gives you an idea on how it is to live in a very luxurious lifestyle. It was also our first time to see Rembrandt and Goya paintings so it was quite a thrill visiting this place... I just wished they allowed us to take photos of some of the artworks...
small but worth the visit. I thought it was a little pricey at 20 each but that did include a free audio tour. Beautiful home with a great collection including many of the grand masters.

Wow! A glimpse into the very elite of yesteryear!. Aside from the impressive art collection, the estate and house are art on their own. A glimpse into the life of one of the most successful industrialists in the history of our country and all the luxury that such a life entails. I got lost simply studying the various books that Frick had in his library. From an age where all your knowledge was collected through books (and not the internet!). Very interesting
Pleasant surprise. We went based on the reviews on Tripadvisor. It was not as crowded as the Met with lots of amazing art pieces. Definitely good value for money.

Very Cool. My wife and I visited the Frick. This place is pretty cool, It's more amazing when you consider this was his house. Worth the trip. Not really for small kids. Has some really amazing art work. and they give you a phone like device, you just put in the display number and it tells you all about what you're looking at. I have no pictures to post, photography not permitted.

Sorry we missed it before.... This was our third visit to NYC and our first visit to the Frick. If we ever go back to NYC we will go back to the Frick. The Met has a larger, much more varied collection, displayed the way we are accustomed to seeing things displayed in a museum. The Frick Collection is comprised of almost exclusively European art displayed in much the same way it was when it was the Frick family home. We were amazed at the breadth and quality of the collection. It is much quieter and less crowded than the Met. Upon arriving you are given a handset (included in price of admission) that allows you to go through and choose which pieces of art you want to learn more about and which you just want to stroll by. Definitely worth doing.
Do not miss. This was my favourite spot on the visit to New York. Not a large collection but so many wonderful pieces and such a pretty place.

Beautiful but cramped. Wonderful museum. It is unique as the galleries are held within a very opulent house, not the enormous two story rooms of the MET, Guggenheim, and MOMA. The architecture and furniture surrounding you as you take in the paintings and sculpture on display are just as impressive and beautiful. I took advantage of the audio guides last time I visited and found them very illuminating---usually I find audio guides very dry and get bored listening to them, but I enjoyed the Frick's program thoroughly. There is a conservatory room at the center of the house that is a great place to sit and relax after walking the museum. They also have some great visiting exhibits, but beware of crowds. The line for the Dutch Masters exhibit (with Girl with a Pearl Earring) was around the block. The galleries were cramped and hot because of this. Seek out the Frick on an off day or off hour for the best viewing experience.

Full of beauty and history across in a Mansion across the street from Central Park. A beautiful, historic mansion containing the lovely art collection of the Industry Titan Henry Frick. 20 dollar admission except for Sundays. Worth every penny to see the great European Masters AND tour a home similar to the fantastic mansions of Newport. Sit and see the movie about Mr. Frick, his life, the construction of the mansion, and the art collection first. Get the audio phone and plug in the numbers next to the art or sculpture for its description. There are wooden stands behind the doors of most rooms and the stairwell that also has a number that describes the history of the room and how the Frick family used it. My favorite was Mrs. Frick's Boudoir and the sage green dining room overlooking Lexington Avenue and Central Park. Easily accesible using the Number 6 subway, get off at 68th Street-Hunter College stop. Immaculate bathroom on lower level. No restaurant but affordable cafe at pond at Central Park across the street if it is nice outside.

My Favorite NYC Museum. Henry Frick's breathtaking collection of art housed in his mansion. It's a total fantasyland inside. I love all the Vermeer paintings. It's a joy wandering from room to room and looking at the art. It's in my favorite neighborhood in the city also, which helps.

My favorite museum. This is my favorite museum in the world. World class collection of art and decoration in beautiful residential setting. And the interior courtyard is a great place to rest and escape the heat of a NYC summer or forget the cold and snow of a NYC winter!
Fabulous museum, just the right size. Great collection, comfortable size, like being in your own home (if you lived like a magnate). Not to be missed
excellent small museum. The Frick is not to be missed if you enjoy art museums. It is a gem on 5th ave. The last of what was a private collection in it's original residential setting
To of the list for NYC Museums. I highly recommend a visit to the Frick Museum to view the collection as well as the home if you enjoy museums. The venue is small but WOW!
Great collection in a unique setting. Loved the Frick collection. It's small enough to do in a morning, but is a great collection, not to mention the house itself.
A must in town.... If you have the time, please dedicate a couple of hours because it's worth it.Small collection but very well chosen.I love the place.

Not to be missed in NYC!. This is the second time I've visited the Frick. I first came with my husband then had to return this time with my teenage girls. They rated this also their top museum and one of the NYC highlights. To walk around the Frick Collection is a luxury: imagine meandering at your own pace, taking in Mr Frick's collection of Gainsboroughs, Rembrandts, Ingres, Whistler, Boucher, Monet, Renoir etc in the comfort of his beautifully decorated home. The audio guides are included in the ticket price and enjoy them. You will surely be enchanted by some lesser-known treasures during your visit. It's absolutely stunning!For more on NYC, visit http://goo.gl/fb/Lhvgmz

Must See. Best Museum in town. The Frick's Collection is small compared to the Museums next door (Metropolitan and Guggenheim), but incredibly and exceptionally interesting. This charming collection makes it a necessary stop on every trip I take to New York City.
Should be visited more. The architecture is the first thing you see, and it already transports you to a bygone era. And then there's the first-rate art, which should be on anyone's radar.
Great Collection. I love museums placed in a house setting. The pieces are not nearly as famous as the ones in the Met but the layout is beautiful!
First rate private collection. The quality of art was incredible. We spent about 2 hours and were extremely satisfied with the experience.

This is quite Amazing!!. Visiting Henry Frick's home and seeing his art collection is something everyone needs to do while in NYC. Although it's one of the highest rates things to do in nyc I still feel like it is a hidden gem, however I think it's something worth promoting. Henry Frick had an eclectic collection of art works and sculptures all over his mansion and being able to visit it and tour the grounds is such a treat. Be aware, pictures aren't allowed as you make your way through the collection..they're only allowed in the courtyard-type area where the fountain is. Also, there are free audio guides for visitors so it helps you truly understand all the wonderful pieces of art you're witnessing. It really was like stepping into history!!! Highly recommend this

Something truly special.. The Frick really is something quite different to your typical museum or art gallery. Set in the beautiful Frick family home on the upper east side, the collection is displayed throughout this beautiful period property.Art from all over the world is displayed throughout the collection, including period pieces that make up the fabric of the building itself.The property is well worth a visit for some of the best pieces of art you will see on public display, but also to get a feel for a traditional upper east side home and the beautiful architecture of many of these buildings.I would really recommend a visit.

Truly Special and Different. Our daughter, who lives in NYC, took us to the Frick on our last visit to the city. It is one of her favorites. We agree. The paintings and sculptures are amazing. What a collection! But, what makes it special is that the collection was a family collection and the Frick was a home (a very grand and beautiful one) from another era. There aren't too many left in Manhattan! Our visit piqued our interest in the city during that time period and the family.The size is perfect: plenty to see but not overwhelming. Children are not admitted. They are pretty serious about preservation and we were a bit amused by all of the rules. But, that's okay. It is a beautiful, special place.
A little gem!. Henry Frick's mansion and eclectic art colletion are a welcome oasis on the upper east side. I hope that recently announced expansion plans don't destroy what I love about it.
Great, great collection. High-end collection that's not so big that it's overwhelming. Loved it. Vermeer, Rembrandt, Gainsborough, Whistler and more. Great collection.
Definitely unexpected !. I couldn't expect such a huge exhibition of European masterpieces, from paintings to sculpture. Definitely worth to go !

A truly enjoyable experience!. We hAve been a multi- city tour and visited several museums! This was a terrific experience! True treasures displayed thoughtfully. Not overwhelming as compared to large museums. The audiotape is a must- gives you specific info on most pieces.... a must!!

Wonderful collection in a consumable size. The Frick has always been my favorite art museum in New York City, particularly because you get a wide sampling of the very best in art, and at a size -- the museum is small -- that allows you to savor each piece at your leisure. Compare that to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is, of course, exception, but overwhelming in the amount of things to see, so you end up rushing or feeling like you didn't really see everything you wanted to see. My pick -- the Frick -- every time!

Favourite museum in the WORLD. The Frick's small, yet incredibly charming collection makes it a necessary stop on every trip I take to New York City. Gainboroughs, Vermeers, and the incredible Fragonard room are must-see attractions in the city. TIP: If you are a student and you go on a day with an incredibly long line, just become a member. Student membership is 25$, the same price as an adult single-day admission. Also, It'll be a reason to return!

Most amazing collection. In a city with so many museums, the Frick is like the Jewel in the Crown - El Greco, Renoir, Gainsborough, and Vermeer, oh my! It is small and has an intimate feel, not the "lost" and impersonal feeling of the Met. Lots of places to sit and contemplate the genius of the artwork. Do yourself a favor and go.

A masterpiece of masterpieces. This was my second visit to this wonderful collection that will never bore you. I love the regular owned masterpieces and I am always pleasantly rewarded with amazing social displays. On each visit I am still blown away when I walk into the drawing room housing the Holbein paintings of my Tudor favourites. The beauty of the mansion and gardens us an added bonus. We tried the Sunday pay what you want session from 11 00 am to 1.00 pm and not surprisingly it was a bit busier than previous visits.

A hidden Gem. My wife and I looked at Trip Advisor and saw there was another museum next to Central Park. We read up on it and decided to go on a Sunday. The line was pretty long to get in and I asked someone in the line why this would be. They said that on Sundays it's "pay what you want" day. Normally there is a fee to get in on a daily basis (I think $20 per person) but you could pay a dollar if you wanted to. The "house" was turned into a museum and the quality of works there was amazing. And you could almost touch the art but of course, there were security guards there to make sure you didn't. This was a beautiful place and worth the 2 hours we walked through the museum.

Some notable artworks, atmosphere unpleasant. We visited the Frick as a family, and found the atmosphere unpleasant. While the art and artefacts on view are in some cases exceptional, on the day that we visited, the Frick seemed to be the exclusive habitat of elderly well-heeled pushy patrons, who seemed to labour under the delusion that they owned the place. Been there, done that, won't bother going back.
The Goldfinch and more!. Fabulous art, very manageable in short amount of time, beautiful building.....and getting there isn't all bad either.

A beautiful museum. I love the collection and the setting. It was a perfect romantic date night! The museum is not intimidatingly large so it is easy to appreciate and enjoy the artwork as you stroll through the beautiful mansion.

Coal and Coke Baron's Hoard. A good selection well displayed although somewhat eclectic. Frick was one of the C19 industrial barons but spent his ill-gotten gains on a fabulous art collection available for public viewing after his death. The museum's film does not omit his role in the very bitter Homestead dispute when workers were locked out and murdered by the Pinkerton mercenaries for daring to organize a union
great collections. a smaller museum with a magnitude to offer. easy and convenient to get to. their current exhibit of men in armor was extremely interisting

amazing. a wonderful collection made by a wealthy art lover.
This was our second trip and we jst loved the variety. More Rembrandt's than the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam. (not really now it is fully open!!) However the self portrait of Rembrandt in the Frick is my favourite Rembrandt.
Why Not Indeed!. We were walking around the city and happened upon the Frick Collection and said "Why Not". A nice collection and friendly host.
A real treasure. If you only have time for one museum this is the one. It has art, furniture, a beautiful building and and interesting story and we really enjoyed it.

Beautiful house, wonderful collection. When w-you take the subway in New York, look around and see how much steel there is below ground. It seems that the entire city is held up by steel. Then visit the Frick collection to see what steel money can buy you. It's phenomenal. The house itself would be worth visiting without the art work, but the works of art on view are just beautiful. This really is worth the two to three hours it takes to visit (all on one level, so easy for all ages).
Great Idea. small, easy to visit museum in spectacular building,business travelers could drop in at lunch time, art enthusiasts will love the collection
Don't miss out on this. Frick had a brilliant eye for only the best! Art is a very personal matter, I loved everything in this collection.

Pleasant place!. I liked very much! There are a lot of important artists but it does not make us tired and bored. There is a film in the entrance telling its history which helped us a lot to understand the Museum. Great place!

You MUST Go. Full stop.. This is quite simply one of the most jaw-droppingly wonderful museums in the world, in a gorgeous mansion house with paintings that, when you first see them, will practically make you weep with happiness. 'Nuff said. You must make time for it and go!
Beautiful museum. Gorgeous house, with some lovely pieces, particularly the silver. Go when it's "pay what you can afford", much better value.
GO THERE AND LOOK AROUND. How beautiful this old home and what wonderful art ! the gardens are lovely and the rotating collections are compelling. More than anything image this as a family home

Nice collection, but annoying guards and no wrtitten descriptions.. Really the mansion housing this collection if very interesting and beautiful, and there are many magnificent works of art, but the art work is displayed without descriptions, and the guards were intrusive and arbitrary. You do receive a free audio guide to use, but the descriptions are rather long and not to the point. I would rather have an explanatory card displayed near the piece itself describing the date, artist, subject, and one important feature to note, than have to dial in and wait for the audio file to start, then listen to someone ramble on about it for minutes. Also, I had to check a small plastic bag I had (fine, reasonable enough) and then saw people walking around with a purse and a backpack without anyone telling them to check it. A different guard came up and touched the strap of her purse on her shoulder telling her she could not wear her purse on her back over both her shoulders because it was then a back pack and had to be checked, while at that very same moment only a few feet away another woman had a similar setup and was wearing her purse as a backpack and he said nothing to her. We started counting, and by the time we left we had seen 9 women wearing their purses on their backs, and one with an actual backpack and a purse in the collection, drawing no correction from the guards. At $20 a person this was rather a rude way to be treated. So the collection and hall is worth seeing, but the descriptions and guards are substandard.

You must like painting. We were expecting more history about the guy but no this is a art gallery and I am not that good on that field. One thing I noticed, there's differrent kind of painting by many painters and you can really tell the difference in style. Furthermore, the audio provides you with a lot of information about many of their painting. A place to go but again this is an art museum not history.

An absolute gem. This is a delightful museum. Was recommended to go there by an art historian friend and it did not disappoint. A manageable size too, so easily 'done' before a visit to Central Park and a walk along to the Metropolitan Museum of Modern Art.
great visit. for the price you pay you receive an audio tour, what a wonderful place to explore, would recommend it to tourist and New Yorker alike
Nice place. This is a great placeLovely paintingsSmall is beautifulNice locationI highly recommend this museumWe recommend your visiting
Awesome and Different. Absolutely LOVE the Frick. Great art arranged in an unexpected manner. Must see if you're into culture, even just a little bit. :)

Jewel of a museum. Absolutely gorgeous. Saw the Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals exhibit. Just loved it.Bought tickets ahead of time on telecharge. You are assigned a time. We stayed about an hour and a half and then picked up our bags at the hotel and made for the airport, Would love to go back.

Art +. It felt like such a privilege to visit the Frick and see the hand-picked collection of art and furniture, lovingly gathered by Henry Clay Frick. It gave a glimpse into not only his taste in art, but also his life. We loved the audio tour that gave us information about each piece - how he came to add it to his collection, techniques used by the artist, and some history about the age it was painted in. Wonderful to wander through this beautiful mansion at your own pace and drink in all it had to offer.
Wondrous. Excellent collection, great history. Even though he was a robber baron, he had good taste as did his daughter.
too many guards. So many guards in a home(mansion) so you seem to be in a large museum. Loses the personal feel. Only allowed to see downstairs so very little for your money.

Excellent Museum. We went here on a Sunday between 11 and 1 when you can pay what you want. It is usually 20 dollars per person. They have a audio tape phone you can use for no additional charge which was very good. Good variety of paintings from several different periods. Easy to get to. One one corner of Central Park. Very well done museum which is actually in the Frick home.

Loved this place!. Luckily I loved it as I had to queue in minus 5 degrees Celsius for an hour!! Absolutely beautiful building with the most spectacular permanent collection. The special collections are usually brilliant - in my case I got to see Vermeer's "Girl with the Pearl Earring' . Brilliant!!

Amazing Museum...Created By a HORRIBLE MAN!. A must see in NYC, the Frick Museum is amazing, one of the best art collections in the world. Frick was a robber baron who created and destroyed people and property...but he was an amazing collector of beautiful things! Left his home and belongings that is now the Frick Collection. Sadly, he died from syphilis...just rewards for not a very nice guy in his life!
Not To Be Missed. Housed in a house built in 1913-14, everything thing is a delight to the eye. There are paintings, antiques, and furnishings just to mention a few treats.

Not to be missed. Fabulous collection of paintings, sculpture, furniture in a home, easy to view, visit on Sunday between 11 and 1 when entry fee is by donation only. Children under ten are not permitted, even babies in strollers. Only con - most attendants were not very helpful or welcoming.

Magnificent Collection and Setting. We had just come from a disappointing visit to the Whitney and were transported into a world of times gone by in the beautiful former Frick Mansion with its amazing collection of art ranging from Titian to Monet.

Great. Great and interesting museum. This is a small museum compared to the MET or the MOMA in NYC, but I prefered it because there were not many people, the map of the museum is clear, the audio guides comments are very interesting as well. Possibility to leave your bag at the entrance, which is very apreciable.
Definitely a Hidden Gem. I love this spot, so many paintings in this home - you really get a feel for luxury old-world Manhattan. Absolutely adore this collection.

Most Perfect Small Museum in the World. The Frick is a never-miss for me. The home of financier Frick, who had an incredible collector's eye, the Frick has an amazing breadth of work for such a small museum. I mean, when you have enough Turners, Constables, El Grecos, HOlbeins, Sargents that you can hand two of your three Vermeers in the hallway, you know you have a gem. It is beautifully designed to take advantage of the space, with a beautiful atrium for contemplation and the staff is lovely. My only concern is a considered expansion, that I think will ruin the old home feel of the place. But don't let that stop you. Don't let anything stop you from enjoying the Frick
Amazing. Beautiful home atmosphere - gorgeous collection. The art there is mostly landscapes and portraits of beautiful women.

Magnificent collection. The Frick collection was the cultural highlight of our visit to NYC. Every room, every corridor, every alcove contained something that just took one's breath away. Everything was just so beautifully presented in perfect light as well. The highlight of the visit was viewing the portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell and the manner in which these paintings had been displayed on either side of a decorative fireplace(?) - almost as if they could have turned their heads and gazed at each other (they both lost their heads).

Private Collection heaven. I adored the Frick Collection. Housed on fifth ave in his former home, the private collection of Henry Frick is the perfect escape from the larger galleries and museums. Try to time your visit with one of the free talks provided - I thoroughly enjoyed this, the museum staff are very knowledgeable. The audio guide is also excellent. This is also an great spot to unwind after a long morning walking, I found the central conservatory space to be very peaceful and relaxing.

Terrific Museum. This is the must-visit museum only after you have conquered the Met, MOMA, and the American Museum of Natural History. Compared to the other big 3 museums this one is much smaller, having been the former residence of Mr. Frick. It is definitely much less overwhelming (can be comfortably visited in about an hour and a half), and is relatively off the usual tourist path. The only other museum I have been to that I would compare it to would be the Sorolla Museum in Madrid, although the Frick has much more variety. I would also suggest a visit before the (controversial) expansion occurs as it currently has a truly unique feel to it which may or may not be affected by the expansion.

An Afternoon Well-Spent. I almost overlooked The Frick. We had so many other things to do that fitting it in a trip to The Frick seemed impossible. But boy am I glad we did. Between the elegant mansion that houses this amazing collection and the phenomenal Gainsboroughs, Turners, Rembrants, Vermeers, and even a Manet, a Monet, and a Degas themselves, this experience is not to be missed---even if you have limited time like me. As USA TODAY's First Road Warrior of the Year, I work a lot. But whenever I go somewhere for business, time permitting, I like to see at least some of the sights. This manageable collection of amazing art will provide you with an enriching afternoon. And be sure to save some time to spend in the spectacular Garden Court. It is a welcome place of rest and calm in the heart of the museum. A perfect way to spend an afternoon!
Unbeliveable Collection!. The entry fee ($20) discouraged the crowds, so the viewing could be enjoyed at a relaxed pace. Stunning art work, including several paintings that I never dreamed of seeing.
Very, very interesting. Wonderful collection!! Part of the New York History!! Near other galleries. Something you should know. Few block from the Metropolitan

Relaxing, manageable musuem visit. I really liked that the Frick didn't feel overwhelming as some other museums do. We listened to a short intro (optional) from a woman who gave us some history on Henry Frick. We borrowed audio equipment so we could get info on the paintings we wanted to. I liked this, because if we weren't interested, we could skip to the next painting and really go at our own pace. There was also a documentary going on in one of the rooms which we watched some of. I loved the courtyard. So beautiful!

The Museum of Class. The Frick Museum has a world class collection of master paintings and excels amongst New York city's multitude of museums and galleries. Should be #1 on any art lover's choice of places to visit.

very interesting until.... Nice collection in a house that was actually lived in by owners until death and then made into this museum. Delightful collection until you read up on how Frick made his money busting unions and getting people killed.

Superb. My son recommended that I visit the Frick Collection as he had been on a previous trip to New York, it was truly amazing, beautiful things to see especially the paintings, I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone interested in beautiful things.

interesting collection of art. it was interesting to see this collection which had been amassed circa 1900 but an American industrialist. he seemed to be wanting to capture the essence of the previous centuries European noble life. The mansion was interesting but I'm not much into furniture and that sort of thing. I did really enjoy some of the art - not the older, dark renaissance sort of stuff. But there were a few Impressionists (Monet and Manet come to mind), some Turners and Gainsboroughs, and some El Grecos. Those turned my crank!
Small but exquisite collection. A little gem of a collection that will surprise and delight visitors, especially the tranquil water display in the center.

great exhibit and not overwhelming. great premise, beautiful house transformed into a museum, with great collection, and pleasant visit where all can be seen within a relative short time, without the overwhelming feeling of the big museums
Often Overlooked by the Tourist. Most visitors will go for the Met, but if you want to see what living on Fifth Avenue in the glory days was like, plan a visit here, in relative calm and quiet.
The perfect art collection. I love The Frick. The perfect size and some exquisite paintings. A handful of masterpieces from several artists. Rembrandt's Nicolaes Ruts is my favorite.
This may be my favorite art museum of all time. Not only is the collection impressive, the home itself is an amazing work of art. Such detail. Architecture is stunning!
Wonderful museum. Wonderful things to see not really my thing but thought I would try it to see it, heard it was wonderful. And happy I did visit
Hidden gem in NYC.. If you have ever wanted to wander around an old NYC mansion, visit The Frick collection. Totally unexpected and enjoyable.

Beautiful Building. We went to see the Girl with a Pearl Earring and then explored the entire building. Magnificent art work all around the building and I particularly liked the inner peaceful courtyard

An Amazing collection in the great setting of a major townhouse. The Frick is a quiet oasis of high culture in the city. It's collection is extremely selective in the quality of the holdings, they have 10% of Vermeer's entire work for example, but also a great Velazquez, Ingres, Bronzino, Bellini, two Holbeins, two Titians and three great Grecos, an entire room is decorated with panels by Fragonard, another by Boucher which had been commissioned by Mme de Pompadour, a great selection of British painting in the dining room.Recently there is a new gallery that has been added just for small exhibition of porcelain, sculpture and precious objects, it faces the front garden and has excellent natural light.The exhibitions that are organized for the downstairs gallery are superb and truly hold an incredible track record on quality and selection, without a doubt it is one of the best museums in the city.
