An oasis of beauty and calm in a busy city. The Frick has a very impressive collection. A smaller museum, it is not as overwhelming nor does it require the time commitment of the larger galleries like the MOMA or Metropolitan. The building itself is a masterpiece.

jbfrommi. It was right in the middle of the theatre district on Broadway. Our hotel recommend it because we wanted cheesecake. The food looked amazing but we were just getting desert. The #seller, according to the waitress was the plain, we took her advice and it was delicious! The place was packed but we were seated fairly quickly. The service and fast and friendly.
Good time and nice art. Quality museum. Full of art amd it even has an inside fountain, very good experience. You can watch a movie inside a small cinema
Wonderful collection of art. Be sure to check online for upcoming events. The furniture and art are wonderful-check out fountain room the garden too, its an oasis of quiet and green in the city.

Nice museum. The Frick has a number of notable items, such as a couple of Vermeer's I'd not seen before, and an amazing Rembrandt that almost brought me to tears. I liked that the collection was on the small side, so as not to be terribly overwhelming to novice museums goers such as myself :) Frick also had a number of statues and antique furniture that were a nice addition to the art on the walls. I love that the museum used to be a residence too - very charming!

Wonderful museum. The Frick Collection is a lovely museum that used to be the mansion of Henry Clay Frick. There is an atrium with a fountain that you can sit and relax in. They had an exhibit of a painting that has never been out of Europe. "The Turkish Slave". Most of the paintings and sculpture are from Frick's collection. It is an easy afternoon of walking around, enjoying the art and can be seen in a couple of hours. Very nice

Aesthetics everywhere!. Located in the old Frick mansion on 5th Avenue on the East Side, opposite the Central Park. It belonged to a Jewish merchant whose intention had always been that his house be turned into a museum but who never told his architect so while the building of the mansion took place. World renown. Stunning. Eclectic collection in collector’s original home! It includes several exquisite artworks, famous paintngs, sculptures, furniture and decorative arts in a luxurious atmosphere. While you are visiting this incredible museum you forget you are in New York and feel as if in Europe. A must visit if you appreciate fine art.PWYW: Pay what you wish system: Sundays between 11am and 1pm plus a free audioguide. No photos allowed, with the exception of the roofed garden. 2nd floor: closed to the public.Great place for art lovers. Good option for weekends when larger museums are crowded. And more intimate! Not to be missed! You won’t be disappointed! Enjoy!

nice and quite. with the future expansion i can't promise this...but as of now its a great collection, and the museum as a whole is quite and not overwhelming. the entrance fee is steep, but it is a great date place. personally I'm more into contemporary works of art, but this museum is still pleasing and calming to go to

"Frick-ing Marvelous!". Beyond breathtaking. A true must-see in NYC. The Art collection is a wonder in itself, but the fact that its situated in what was once a private residence only adds to the mystique, not to mention being plonk in the middle of Upper East Side!

What an amazing gem.. My daughter and I went to see the Dutch masters paintings that were on a special exhibit and, while they were wonderful, the whole museum is wonderful and might even be better without something g like the special exhibit which brought huge crowds. I had never been there before but will definitely return.

A great visit. One of the greatest museums in New York City. Unlike all of the other's along Museum Avenue this is a former home of Henry Frick, that offers a beautiful visit to the home most of it original of his collection with a lower level that offers visiting art. Its a must see if your on the upper east side. Must be 13 or older to be admitted inside.

Frick museum . A fantastic collection of art and in beautiful house. Relatively small in comparison to the likes of Guggenheim but just as enjoyable and not crowded. More classical pieces and a privilege to see works by Monet, Turner, Degas, ver Meer, Constable and more. As well and enamel and brass pieces.
gem of a gallery. stellar art in a period home. small enough to navigate in a couple of hours but large enough to engage. my favourite in nyc.

Fascinating glimpse of turn-of-the-century luxury. I really enjoyed this eclectic collection, housed in the home of the original collector, Henry Clay Frick. There were many lovely works of art, but equally enjoyable was the insight into the life of a "captain of industry" in the early 20th century. The recorded commentaries on the artwork and furnishings were full of interesting anecdotes about the artwork and the man responsible for collecting most of the pieces. It took several hours to do justice to the collection, but fortunately there's a lovely conservatory courtyard where you can rest your feet. Important note for travelers hoping to get their kids some culture: children under 10 aren't permitted at all!
A real mansion and a lovely peaceful museum. This is a real mansion the paintings hang on the walls. Beautiful furnishings and a lovely garden. Off the main tourist track.

Superb gem of a museum, stunning setting.. A lot of visitors to New York, when thinking about its museums, call The Metropolitan and Natural History Museum to mind. However, the Frick Collection is a superb museum housed in a former private home. Go. You will be enchanted.

frick's art collection. This is a first rate museum set in a turn of the century home on 5th avenue in NY. Frick's private collection in this setting is very entertaining and satisfying. I would go back.

Best museum in New York. Amazing special programs.. Incredible collection of famous paintngs, sculptures, furniture and decorative arts, displayed in the opulent mansion home of the late Frick. There are many mansions to visit around the country from the Gilded Age...in Newport Rhode Island, etc, but none that also qualify as a museum with works of art on par with the great museums of the world. Similarly, there are many museums to visit, but none with the ambiance created by this opulent residence which was clearly once a home and not an institution. Stroll by works by Rembrandt, Tiziano, Corot, in an intimate setting, not overwhelming in size. Excellent programs offered - Summer Nights (free) are exceptional with talks, ballet performances, free sketch, etc. So nice to see so many young people taking advantage of these offerings. The Frick is doing a great job of making art accessible to the younger generation. Perfect location by Central Park at 70th street with a main entrance to the Park at 72nd street for those who want to combine a few hours of arts and culture with a row boat ride or fun with radio controlled sailboat or bike ride in the park afterwards.Pay what you wish between 11am and 1pm on Sundays and get a free audioguide in the front hall.
A classic museum, not to be missed.. A classic museum, not to be missed. More intimate than other museums, good on weekends when the larger museums are crowded.
need more time!. First time visit to the frick and was awed by the home as well as the collection. I can't believe I had not visited before. This is definitely a MUST SEE place to go in NYC.

favorite museum in the city. This museum is a two for one, its an amazing house and houses an amazing collection of European art! If you are a Fragonard fan you will not be disappointed! Each room is more amazing then the next

Hidden Gem!. If you visit New York and have time to spare, this is a must visit. The house itself is beautiful with lots of history behind it. The artwork is well organized and easy to follow. If you visit on Sunday from 11:00 to 13:00, you pay what you wish. A bargain if you ask me. There is no food vending on site, so eat before or after the visit. Not really a place for small children, so this would be better suited for 10 and over. Enjoy....
Great place to visit. It's a fantastic place to see some great art including Constable, Gainsborough and Titian. Only take 90 minutes and during 11-1 on Sunday you pay what you want.

Surpassed expectations. First time my family went to the Frick, great place for art lovers with older kids who are interested. Amazing collection of great paintings in a super pleasant setting, and the museum is not overwhelmingly big so kids were not intimidated at all. Wonderful and pleasant afternoon there.
Antique furnitures. I loved his antique furnitures in real residence with paintings and sculptures. I wish we could take pictures instead of only atrium.

What a nice fountain. It's such a treasure! What I liked most it was the building itself and how all different kind of art go together. I spend so much time on the room where the fountain is. So relaxing. You can get audio guide for free. It's "pay as you wish" on Sundays.

You won't be disappointed. These collection is one of the best I have seen. The selection of paintings was impressive. The design of the mansion was beautiful. The sense of aesthetic is present in every corner.Walking through the museum is incredibly pleasant. I visited with my wife and teens. Everybody had a great experience.
Nice collection in a great building. Interesting art in an old New York mansion. Do not miss the movie about Mr. Frick and his life. The staff has good stories.

Beautiful collection. I have visited the place once before and wanted to see it again. It is a lovely museum on the upper east side with a beautiful collection of especially European art from the great masters such as Gainsborough and Turner. Well worth a visit

A gem of an art gallery. Worth going to this small private museum on the other side of the road from the Metropolitan Museum. It has so many masterpieces that it is incredible to think that this was a PRIVATE home!

quality not quantity. Very impressed by this eclectic collection. You can see many lovely pieces and not feel that you are rushing because it is a beautiful building, not too huge, with light and windows.
Step back in time to discover how 5th Ave was like. Step back in time to discover how 5th Ave was like and the museum provides an insight into the life of Henry Frick.

Like being invited into a wealthy friend's house. I really liked the tasteful set-up of this collection, it was like wandering through someone's house. Bonus: Girl with a Pearl Earring was on exhibit! The gift shop is lovely too, the postcard prints are very good quality.

Don't miss this museum !. It's worth. These collection is one of the best I have seen. It a beautiful little museum. The selection paintings is very good and very various . The rooms are very pleasing. Don't miss the museum !
An artistic Wonderland . A very impressive and interesting art collection set in a house with a variety of tastes for all that is beautiful. Highly recommended.
Just amazing. Everything. Loved it, the collection was breathtaking. The house gorgeous. Some peace and quiet in a mad mad city 😀

A Gift. This museum is such a gift for New York City and all of us who are lucky enough to visit. We went on a Sunday to take advantage of the 11-1 pay-as-you-wish. It was fairly crowded but handled well with twenty people allowed in every 8 minutes or so. The home itself is a glimpse back into a life of extreme privilege and we are treated to an art collection of unbelievable beauty. The variety and exquisiteness are stunning. I wish I could remember everything I saw! It was stunningly beautiful. I find it a bit sad that they're proposing a six-story addition to this exquisite museum. I fear the character of it will be lost. I would rather that the second floor just be opened up. It's an amazing experience to have been here.

Not to big to get bored in. If you know London, it's like the Wallace Collection (Manchester Square, London) if you are coming to London and you like Frick then you will like Wallace.We had lunch at the "Congac" a few streets away which was nice.

An intimate museum that gives a glimpse into the home of one of America's most privileged families.. The Frick is the darling of many New Yorkers, with its intimate spaces, smaller crowds, and manageable collection. There are some surprising paintings one would not expect here. I won't spoil the fun. The inner enclosed courtyard with its water feature is very soothing. I just wish there were a small cafe.

Vermeers are worth the price of admission. Extraordinary collection includes luminous Vermeers and iconic Holbeins in an elaborate mansion. Small enough to do in a couple of hours and not feel overwhelmed. Sundays from 11-1 it's pay what you can.
even for non-art lovers. I am not an art person, but the mansion was fasinating to see. Like the places you see in Europe. The doors, ceilings, etc wer just unbelievable. Georgeous home,

Beautiful. This is one of my favorite places in New York City. Beautiful home and interesting collection. I love that Frick himself planned it out. There is a short film explaining the history of the museum, and you can see many paintings are still displayed the way they were when Frick lived there. So cool! Tip: Sundays from 11-1 admission is "pay what you will." There may be a line but they admit 20 people every 10 minutes so it moves along.

A Splendid House and Collection. A ‘must’ every time we go to New York, the Frick never ceases to astonish and amaze on every visit to this house-museum.From its strategic location right in front of Central Park to its architecture, furnishings and glorious art, one is transported to the gilded age of those (almost too monstrously) rich magnates and their families who surrounded themselves with opulence and with magnificent European art.For one it was again an occasion to contemplate Rembrandt’s disputed portrait of a mounted horseman and wonder if it was truly the master who painted it.And after gazing at the Fragonards, at Bronzino’s splendid portrait of the imperious-looking Lodovico Capponi as well as at the breath-taking still life with plums executed by Chardin, it was a wonderful moment of serendipity to discover Hans Holbein the Younger’s celebrated portrait of Thomas Cromwell, the - reputedly very Machiavellian - Secretary of Henry VIII! It gave additional life to the two books that British author (and twice Booker Prize winner) Hilary Mantel had written on his life and times, i.e. Wolf Hall and Bring Up the Bodies
a must see. a must see for art lovers, but the building it self is worth seeing. I would go back even though i have been a few times already.

Superb. I went with a cousin and two friends as we had heard that the Frick planned an expansion into it's lilly pond and wanted to see the original building and grounds in their original state.Everything is amazing. The collection of art and objects are absolutely superb and fascinating. Get and LISTEN to the audio tour highlights of the objects and paintings. And make sure that you see the short film that plays every 15 minutes or so. You'll understand what a special place this is. My favorite object - the Lapis Lazuli table star design inlaid top set in the beautiful claw foot metal table with caryatid supports.GO - see this mansion filled with art and objects that are treasures. It's just the right amount of a varied collection of styles and objects for an afternoon. You'll remember this far longer than the regular museum show.

Great Collection That's Not Too Big. Spend almost 2 hours there although it's not really that big. Lots of famous painters; Rembrandt, Vermeer, Whistler, Monet. On Sundays it is pay what you want and they had free sketching in the atrium (they supplied paper and pencils). Highly recommended!

Packed with masterpieces. The intimate Frick Collection presents a great contrast with the gigantic, somewhat overwhelming Metropolitan just up the street. The visitor to the Frick walks through the rooms of a stately, Gilded Age mansion, finding masterpieces of art at every turn. It is easy to see everything in about two hours, but of course, you may want to linger much longer amid these beautiful treasures.

Glad we took the time to explore the Frick. Visited the Frick with our teen girls. I recommend doing the docent tour to get a quick overview, especially if visiting with teens. Teens aren't going to read through everything so having someone to introduce the Frick was well worth the 20 minutes. Beautiful home, interesting history.

Very beautiful, but expensive. We've been intending to visit the Frick Collection for quite a long time, but always found the price a bit disencouraging... This time, we went to the venue in a "pay what you want" day.. and found the experience very pleasant.. some areas of the museum were closed, but we enjoyed it very much.
GReat and easy to do. One of the best Museums in NY charming and great art ....Easy to do and sundays till 13.00 free! If you are in a hurry this is the one miuseum to see

If you love civilization, you'll love the Frick!. An easily doable, small collection that offers a window to the cultural achievements at the foundation of western civilization. If you love civilization, you'll love the Frick!

Amazing. Well worth going just first rate collection
Interesting building
Saw a good Hogarth and many other rare pictures

Wonderful. In the middle of the hustle of the city is this wonderful respite. The collection includes 3 works by Vermeer as well as other fine paintings and sculpture; this is a must see for anyone that appreciates art. The history of the house and location just added to the experience- don't bring big bags or you will have to check them.

Frickin hell. This gallery is a real surprise in the heart of NYC. A privately owned mansion with amazing spaces that have interesting art.A visit here is worth the effort if you are into galleries. The art is well spread out so you have time and space to take it all in. An audio guide is included in the entry price (a surprise as most charge extra) and gives good commentary in nit just the art but also the architecture of the house.

Works of Art ...but... We visited the Frick Collection.  The Pros: The works of art are impressive as are those of similar quality in other museum type places. The building was well maintained and the art was presented in a way that you could get closer to it than in some other places. There were staff present in each room to ensure that no one let their fingers do the walking across the artwork. The indoor garden/fountain room is a nice place to sit. Overall a nice place.The caveats: $20 adult / $10 student. This place is not big. $10 flat rate would be better. No photos allowed except in the garden room. The gift shop is eclectic but not practical. A big disappointment is that you cannot walk on the paths in the outside landscaped fenced in area. What's the point of having it if you are not able to enjoy it. The recorded tour is free but rambles in places and there are a number of pieces of art that do not have the corresponding #'s listed to enter into the device to hear the presentation.
Best Collection.. I liked the Art Collection and the house itself with its beautiful Patio. Easy to visit when we don't have to much time.

Lesser known treasure. The Frick is much less well known than other art museums in NYC, but is well worth the visit. Certainly the main attraction is the house itself. Beautiful rooms, lovely garden. But also some world-class art including Van dykes, Monet, Manet, and others.

A New York gem hidden in plain sight. I love this museum - despite living in NY for a year some time ago and visiting the last 2 years, this was a new experience and I have been recommending it to friends far and wide. It is everything that is wonderful about Americans and this city, a monument to the eclectic tastes of one man and a wonderful art collection overlooking the park on the East side, just a short walk from The Plaza and the shops of 5th Ave. I loved the Fragonard room, the Renoirs, the remodelled carriageway. Just wonderful.

Beautiful, Stately Mansion. Interesting history of Henry Fricke, the wealthy (and arrogant) industrialist who lived in this mansion with his family. This beautiful property provides a glimpse into the lifestyles of the wealthy aristocrats of that era. Beautiful architecture and beautifully appointed rooms. There are even paintings done by famous artists like Rembrandt hanging on the walls of this mansion. Worth the $20

Fantastic.. An amazing look into how the 0.01% lived in the time of the robber barons.A stunning 5th ave mansion converted into a museum to display the work collected over the life time of Henry Frick.An amazing small museum that is a must see for any art lover.Great to see art hung as the owner of it originally displayed it.

wonderful museum. The Frick is an incredible museum due to the fact that is was once a private home.
The artwork is impressive and the building itself can stand alone as a museum

A wonderful experience. Visiting the Frick Museum is the best manner to spend 2-3 hours in New York and enjoy a beautiful cultural experience. We were lucky, as besides the usual permanent collection of the Museum, there was a temporary exhibition of fantastic bronces of different periods, this itself made our visit worthwhile. We could also follow a film in the basement, explaining how the bronce sculptures are made, a well filmed explanation, which we found very instructivel. The gallery is divided into sections, more by themes than by chronological order. My favourites are the three Vermeers, a rare quantity for any museum, there are many pictures of British painters, a very attractive Corot and of course the portrait of the founder of this museum, Mr. Frick, whose original private house is the seat of this museum. The entrance fee of $ 20 ($ 15 for seniors) is a well spent amount for a cultural delight.

Excellent Visit - please don't change it. Our Hotel was very close to the Frink and we nipped in for a quick look round, which is what the Frick is good for, it is compact and can be easily seen in 90 minutes unlike it near neighbour The Met, There was talk when we were in New York that there were plans tio increase the collection and make the who organisation bigger - that would rob the charm from The Frink and spoil the experience. Go visit The Frink while it is still the good old original - well worth the trip

A wonderful private art collection. The Frick Collection, located on 5th avenue and 70th street, is a wonderful place for art aficiandos and some NYC history of the guilded age. The building is a wonderful place for architecture buffs but the private art collection is renowned for having some permanent paintings of note and temporary exhibits. The collection takes about 1-1.5 hours to see everything and contains works by Titian, Rembrandt, Holbein, as well as the famous Gilbert Stuart Portrait of George Washington. This is a very popular tourist destination so expect long lines and crowed, but not impossibly so, corridors and hallways. The collection appears to be expanding and changing over time so it's a good idea to visit every few years to see what's new. This is a wonderful place to visit and spend a few hours looking at some fantastic pieces of art in an intimate setting. It used to be free to enter (many years ago), then went to a "recommended donation" of $10.00; however, most recently required a $20.00 admission fee so the only negative I came across on my November 2013 visit. The gift shop is wonderful. Can be viewed as part of a stroll down 5th avenue toward Central Park and great shopping.
Fantastic, quieter museum. The Frick museum is quieter than the more famous Met and Guggenheim. The courtyard is absolutely fantastic.

Spend Your Sunday at the Frick Collection. A beautiful Gilded Age Mansion built to display the art collection of industrialist Henry Clay Frick. Walking through the home allows a glimpse into history and view great masters such as Bellini, Rembrandt and Goya. Use the audiotape to learn about the rooms, such as the Fragonard Room and the Living Hall, the furniture and art collection.Make sure to watch the movie that details the history of Henry Frick and his collection.We visited on a pay what you wish Sunday from 11-1 and stayed to sketch in the garden.

Wonderful collection shown in its intended space. An excellent collection of classic art and furnishings by well known artists. We really enjoyed the collection as well as the Frick house. Highly recommend for a delightful morning or afternoon of beautiful art.

A must see. A very good museum with wonderful examples of several masters like rembrandt, vermeer and fragonard.extraordinary display of wealth arranged with good taste.if u've been to the met and the guggenheim and can't decide between neue gallerie and this, go for the frick collection!

Fabulous, wonderful, beautiful museum. The Frick is a perfect gem: the Gilded Age mansion of a cultivated collector with great taste. It's on a small enough scale that it is not overwhelming (unlike, say, the Met) but the quality is absolutely first-rate. The courtyard is utterly delightful.

A very well set art gallery. It's a beautiful small art gallery, very intimate. the garden is beautiful, the history of the house itself is very fascinating. And the audio guide is easy to follow and is a very nice touch.A must for art lover who visit NYC

Beautiful, varied collection with great audio recordings. Came here on a Wednesday evening around 4 PM and paid my $10 student admission. I opted for the audiobook since I had a couple of hours before closing and always enjoy hearing about each individual piece. It was GREAT idea because the audiophone allows you to type in the number of the work and provides a brief narrative about the artist, subject, technique, etc. I learned so much about the art and gained a better understanding of the varied and cohesive collection (art on the walls and architecture). I also saw a large group of people sketching so I signed up online to go two weeks from now (it's free!).
Wonderful!. We loved the house, the art, and the proximity to Central Park. Would definitely recommend. Wished we could have seen more of the mansion.

wonderful edited collection in an UES mansion. This was a lovely collection in a beautiful old UES mansion. The gardens weren't open to the public but there was more than enough to see in the house itself. The Fragonard room is lovely as was the Parmigianino which was visiting. Sunday from 11-1 is pay what you want. I spent about 90 min although 60 min is probably adequate.

one of my two favorite art galleries in the world. Hint: Come on Sunday at 11am. It's "pay as you wish" between 11 and 1 every Sunday. Along with Mauritshuis in The Hague, the Frick ranks as my favorite art gallery. Why? Because every piece is a treasure, and the collection is small enough so that one is not overwhelmed, unlike the great art museums, including New York's Metropolitan. I hesitate to single out any of the great works, but I always swoon when I see Holbein's Thomas More and Oliver Cromwell, and Bellini's St. Francis. But there is something for everyone's taste, and this is an excellent introductory gallery for younger folk. Set in beautiful mansion, it's easy to enjoy both the artwork and the ambiance.

Awesome little museum. We really enjoyed this small museum. The audio guide was really a nice touch. The mansion is quite a lovely place and a wonderful way of displaying fantastic art! The admission is steep but, if your a member of a museum that is part of the NARM (North American Reciprocal Museum Association ) then it's free admission. Until July 20th, they have a great photo of Francesco Mazzola's, "Schiava Turca". This painting has never been seen outside of Italy, until now.The private collection has Renior, Monet, Vermeer, Goya and many other European artist. Great clocks and bronze sculptures. Please don't miss the great Organ in the middle of the staircase.

Stunning. The collection at the Frick is stunning and the changing exhibits are generally quite unique. The building itself is a major star of the collection and makes a visit worthwhile. Because its size is manageable, you usually can see everything in a relatively short time frame.
Wow. This is an amazing collection for one person to have assembled. Audio tour was very good as well. I highly recommend this.

A great small place. The Frick Collection is a small museum, whem compared to the other museuns in NYC. But it's a wonderful visit. The location is beautiful, the house is truly interesting and the collection worth the visit.
Two for one. Art and architecture in one lovely visit. The audio tour was very informative and entertaining, and the crowds were manageable.

Go early. I'd advise going early as it's not a big place and is very popular. There are a wide variety of paintings on show (Titian, Turner, Renoir, Degas, Gainsborough, Manet, Whistler) from and the house itself is just as impressive.

Great way to display art. Visited the collection on a recent trip to NYC. Of all the art museums we visited, it was my favorite. I'm a huge fan of old mansions, so the house itself was really cool to see. Seeing the art displayed on the walls really added to the experience. I loved the audio tour (included in the admission price, which is rare. Most usually charge you extra). It gave a lot of interesting information not just on the composition of the art pieces but also how they were acquired, the history behind the items and also information on each room you were in and how it came to be or what it was used for. Another bonus, which I didn't realize until later, was how the art was never separated into periods. I can get bored looking at the same kind of art over and over again. I appreciated that the art at the Frick was all mixed together. It also gives you a good chance to compare the styles of various periods. I think this helps you to perceive a lot of the main features of each style by comparing it to other pieces.

A Gem. This a must see museum for art lovers visiting NYC. The admission is steep at $20 but well worth it. There are pay what you want hours on Sundays between 11.00am-1.00pm but you may not get in. The collection itself is housed in a mansion house located on the east side of Central Park. You wander from room to room and marvel at the quality of the art on display in a unique setting.If you only visit 3 museums on your trip I would recommend The Metropolitan/Cloisters, The Guggenheim ( ONLY if the current show is good. If not then MOMA) and The Frick.

Small museum, cool house. My wife and I enjoyed visiting this museum. The house alone is interesting to see and the collection is small but approachable and beautiful. I don't think the Frick would have been as enjoyable to visit with our kids (under 13).

Lesser known but fabulous. The Frick Collection is a gem of a museum. Not only for the collection, but for the museum itself formerly his private residence. It provides a glimpse of life in the gilded age. Henry Frick was an industrialist who made his fortune in the PA coal industry. It is also a great bargain if you have a NARM (North American Reciprocal Museum) card, you get free admission. Perhaps even better was you didn't have to wait in line with the card.

Absolutely stunning. Finally visited the Frick Collection this past weekend and was not displeased. The mansion itself is stunning with works of art not seen before in any other museum due to private collections. The French furniture pieces are exquisite as well as the amazing architecture. Be sure to watch the video on Frick and how he got started - very interesting.

Relaxing stroll though amazing art collection. My husband and I enjoyed a lazy rainy afternoon at the former residence of Henry Clay Frick.The collection of art is impressive. Take time to watch the movie about Frick's life.

Thank you Henry Frick. The Frick Collection in it's entirely was given by Henry Clay Frick in his will so that everyone could enjoy the art. The house itself is a joy to see. Sundays you pay what you want and the accoustaguide is free. You'll need at the very least 1 hour.
Awesome. The Frick museum and all of its art work is spectacular. Loved seeing the history of a gilded age family. It is on the museum mile so hit the Metropolitan museum of Art next
Magical. If you've ever watched a period film and wished you could have walked those halls, this is your chance. Beautiful home, beautiful collection.

excellent hidden gem near the park. As a banker and rich man Mr Frick could have done much worse than building himself a nice villa with view on Central park, buy lots of art, some good and real, including many Italian bronzes (a must see in the collection) and paintings from all ages, other just "in the school of". He then had a family good enough to leave all to a foundation which continues the tradition of collecting and uses the premises as a museum. A must see in NYC. Only four because as members we expected better range of activities but most of it is very expensive.

One of New York's "best kept secret" treasures. Three Vermer paintings, along with works of Rembrandt, Goya, El Greco, Reynolds, Stuart's portrait of Washington. A tremendous feast of fine art, in a lovely setting.

Beautiful house, beautiful art. The house and the art are equally breathtaking. The art collection is extensive and well organized. Throughout the visit the architectural beauty of the house including its interior design made one stare in wonder.

Well worth seeking out. This place didn't immediately spring to mind as a must-see part of New York. In fact we hadn't even heard of it prior to researching our trip. But we are very glad that we went. The artwork contained is exquisite and often remarkable. My absolute highlight, and a delightful surprise, was stumbling across the ORIGINAL paintings of Thomas Cromwell and Thomas More that are so famous. Having travelled all the way from England, it was a delight on our first day to meet these two masterpieces from English history. The free audio guides are excellent and really help to make the collection come to life. What's more, unlike the larger museums, the whole collection can be enjoyed in a leisurely 3 hours. Definitely worth a visit.

Frick Art Museum. Good old Henry Clay Frick left his house and his art collection to the people of New York and it was good of him. The museum which is on 5th Avenue is his house and that is\worth going to just for itself. The art work is eclectic and represents Frick's tastes. The painting and sculptures are varied and frankly are not to be missed. It s certainly a stop one should make when visiting New York

Frick Museum - Short and Sweet. The Frick Collection is a very intimate collection of wonderful works of art that can be admired and appreciated in two hours without feeling as if you've compromised.Beautifully displayed in the former residence of Henry Clay Frick and family, you can view works of art you thought were only accessible in Europe. You can closer to items than in many museums thought docents will caution you at times. The battles with other millionaires of his era make it more entertaining as you view the incredible Limoges enamels and superb 18th century furnishings that often came when JP Morgan's sons sold off many of his pieces. Check out the masterpiece from the "Master of the Large Foreheads" in the enamel collection that made us smile! You'll also see remarkable paintings by Turner, Valesquez, Rembrandt and more. It's nice that there are seats in several areas so that you can rest and enjoy them from a distance.Don't neglect the surroundings of the artworks - the audio tour is excellent and allows you to jump around from one item of interest to another without listening to the tape chronologically.And the audio tour is included in the entrance price for an adults of $20. Sundays offer a great special of paying what you wish between 11 AM and 1 PM which would be great for a family.The garden court is a peaceful oasis and intriguing as it was once a drive through and carport!We did not watch the history film in the music room but others said it provided a great perspective.So many museums are vast and overwhelming, but the Frick Collection is a fine jewel!
Beautiful Museum. Loved touring the collection in this east side residence setting. Holbeins and Vermeers were my favorites.

Frick Museum - A Treasure. Of course as one would expect, the art work at the Frick is just breathtaking, but besides that the house itself is a museum unto itself. It is certainly worth a visit just to see the Frick Mansion. I have returned many times.
Best museum in NYC? Maybe.. Great art collection of Henry Clay Frick, displayed in his home, approximately as it was in his time. Don't miss the Vermeers tucked away in a hallway.
Amazingly diverse collection. This amazing museum is my favorite in NewYork for its architecture, diverse collection amongst a relatively small collection. Excellent place to spend a rainy day.

A must see!. On Sundays from 11 - 1, you can pay what you wish to get in. This is a great deal! The collection was wonderful and the museum is nicely laid out. You can see it all in about 1.5 hours. This was Frick's home for 5 years and after his death stayed in the family. Beautiful art work.

Great little museum.. Great collection with many of the old masters. But in addition, this beautiful mansion itself would be worth seeing without art. With every admission, you get a set of headphones at no extra charge, which discusses both the art and the building. The Frick has relations with many other museums across the country, so if you are a member at one of those, you may not have to pay any admission at all

Nice and peaceful but. . .. Gorgeous art, lots of portraits in a serene setting. A nice break from busy Manhattan. Unfortunately children under 10 are not allowed, which seems a bit mean. I went there alone on a business trip but when my family joined me we couldn't go together so my husband declined to go at all. Every other art museum I've visited (in many different countries) allows children--they are people. Also too bad the original owner of the museum made his fortune breaking strikes. This all detracts from the experience.
not bad.. if you have free time and you fond of classic arts, it worth visiting.it can't be compared with famous european meseums, but not bad for USA

Art appreciators Gem!. If you go to NYC and have an hour or two - you must put the Frick Collection on your itinerary. It is similar to the Flagler experience in West Palm Beach and the two men knew each other and competed for works of art for their collections. The home it is housed in is magnificent and like being able to see what early NYC homes would have been like. It is great for children as it is smaller and not so overwhelming (it doesn't take a whole day!) and you see so many of the different masters in one place.

Museum Mansion. The Frick is a destination for me a few times each year. It is in the prior Frick residence which was donated to house this exquisite museum. Their permanent collection alone is worth going. The exhibits are always interesting, and well mounted. There is a short introduction film which gives the viewer the history behind the house,family,and how and why the museum now exists.

A Hidden Gem. This is one of my favorite museums ever as it is small and many of the exquisite pieces are from significant artists like Goya, Manet, El Greco and Rembrandt. The Frick Gallery was the private home and collection of a coking coal magnate from Pittsburgh whose grandfather mortgaged the farm to fund his venture. It is quiet and elegant in the middle of a city of flurry and provides a cool retreat in summer. The collection houses the Blue Boy and a famous portrait of George Washington and the boudoir of the King of France's mistress. What will be on display at the time of your visit I do not know as they do rotate artwork but each one is a fine example of the artist's work. You will be very near Fifth Avenue along Central Park.
Amazed!. It´s amazing, you can´t believe someone actually lived here. It´s pure luxury. Im not a big fan of paintings, but really loved this place.
Perfect museum. Interesting collection (love those Impressionists). Setting was wonderful. Tried hard to forget that Frick was not a nice employer.
Amazing Museum. If you've never been to the Frich, this is a wonderful, small museum with an outstanding collection that is housed in a fabulous old home. Truly not to be missed.

A wonderful afternoon. The Frick collection has an excellent array of pieces in one spot. If you are looking for 1 museum to visit that will give you more than 1 point of view as well as a feel for what life was like for the wealthy in early NYC, this is the place for you.

One if the must-do things in New York. Enjoyed this as much as any of the bigger galleries and rate it one of our favourite experiences in New York.The Frick Collection is in the former residence of Henry Clay Frick and beautifully displayed.It's quite lovely roaming through a house and seeing the art displayed as it had been planned in the pastThe home itself, opposite Central Park, is also lovely and the audio tour excellent.It was free the Sunday we went so that could be worth checking on.
great museum. beautiful and small - can cover it in a day :-)beautiful and small - can cover it in a day :-)beautiful and small - can cover it in a day :-)

Lovely Building, old style art. The building was lovely, the art was high quality but very conservative. The staff was a bit cranky, and I was disappointed in it. I prefer modern art, but again, the building was so pretty.
Private Collection?. Hard to believe! beautiful setting, great masterpieces, most pleasant atmosphere. hrd to believe it was a private mension (jealousy!) and admirable taste in art and designs.

Mesmerizing in Manhattan!. Wow what a find. We were trying to make up our minds whether to see the Frick Collection or Guggenheim...totally different I know. So glad we went here. Walked up from our hotel on 56th through Central Park into this wonderful neighborhood. The art, the mansion, courtyard & the garden were all so relaxing...a step back in time. All for senior admission of $15 and the audio tour was free (rooms & most of the important art were numbered to correspond to narration...brilliant). Outstanding art, furniture, architecture, bronzes, busts you name it. Very enjoyable. FYI no children under 10 yoa. Don't miss it!

What a gem. This just blew me away! The building is beautiful and the art collection is absoutely fabulous - and so many of the great artists all in one place. So many times I heard myself saying " wow, that is a painting by ...." ! One of my New York highlights & highly recommended.
Perfect. Everything in the place, including the halls and the exterior building, worth a look! Feast for the eyes.

Impressive. A quiet museum well worth the visit. This place may be easily missed on the Museum Mile, but do pay a visit. Wonderful statues and work of art from all the masters. The building itself is astonishing.

What a Collection!. I am ashamed to say that I had never heard of the Frick Museum. This is an absolute MUST for any visitor. Some of the paintings are so well known that I had just assumed that they were in The Metropolitan or, more likely, in the National Gallery in a London. Visiting the Frick is now at the very top of my list of venues in New York. Not To Be Missed!!

Astounding! . This was my third time in NYC and my boyfriend and I decided to go. The mansion was like a step back in time and particularly so as my boyfriend enjoys art and I love history. We ended up spending over 5 hours wandering the exhibits without realising the time. The audio tour was very well done and as a bonus, a particular security personnel had some very interesting stories about the exhibit and art as well. Having been to almost all the major museums in NY, I can certainly say this one was very unique and offered up an astounding collection of art to enjoy! (Even more astounding when you think a single gentleman collected the lot!)

What a nice surprise!. Wonderful artwork in a lovely setting. The size of the Frick makes for a very enjoyable visit. In addition to the beautiful artwork, and lovely furnishings, I really enjoyed the vast collection of books in the library.

Always love it. I have to say it is much more about the Architecture of the place than its collection - but still it is totally worth a visit. What an amazing house...! The garden is my favorite part... Totally worth a visit!

beautiful and small but of the highest quality. This is housed in what would have been a very large Victorian/georgian house and it is quiet small but the art works on display are of the highest quality old masters. I visited on a day that had been snowing but the warmth and quality of art did the trick.
nice and cozy. you have to visit it just to enjoy the ambiance of the building, i'm not sure if the collection will impress so much, but while walking to the metropolitan, have a stop to see it

Quiet stroll through centuries of art masters..... Must be crowded on free (pay what you wish) Sundays. Noticed a lot of folks with headsets doing an audio-guided tour of highlights. I just ambled and stopped by what caught my eye. Of course, Girl w/a Pearl Earing did catch my eye.

Beautiful collection and location. Went on the Sunday for the pay what you wish between 11 and 1. There was a line, but we were there on time. The place struck me like a gem - how could this be hidden so well in this bustling city? It was like an oasis. The setup is great and I took an audio tour to explore by myself. It was busy, but that didn't bother me. It is an intricate museum to explore, even when the art might not be of your taste.

Fantastic of course. This venue is amazing. Frankly I was equally impressed with the building than the art. It deserves its high ranking as one of the best things to do in New York. Don't get me wrong - the Master's works are superb, and always good to see them in person, and change your perception of what you thought they were like (larger / smaller, etc.).But - indeed the structure as a home is simply amazing for this side of the Atlantic. It really is too bad they don't allow pictures other than in the atrium area. We used the New York City Pass for this place and it was well worth it. I would return to study some of the art in more detail.

Extensive Private Collections. This formerly private collector housed in his mansion, turned museum, is well worth the visit. Mr. Frick has extensive art collections from the Masters and beautifully preserved period furniture and other art objects. The house has been preserved and maintained meticulously. What I liked about it was the variety of paintings and art objects within a small venue rather than a large full scale museum which seemed more personable and manageable. From time to time they have objects on loan for a period of time, the latest was beautifully preserved bronze sculpture items from Italy. I enjoyed it immensely.

a fully loaded jewel. A marvelous collection housed in a remarkable structure. Part of the magic is the size that is so manageable - while being "loaded" with masterpieces. The garden room (photography permitted only in this room) is an oasis with bench seating for momentary relaxation.
Mini MET. It was amazing to see some great art in such a wonderfully casual setting. The story behind Frick family fortune and experiences added to the charm of the place.

A pleasant place.. I visited the Frick Museum after I heard so much about it years ago - before the latest notoriety witht Vermeer's the Girl with Pearl Earring. A small painting but a delight to see. I enjoyed the experience of walking through the museum with my girlfriend from Manhattan who took me there. There are so many great works and rooms on a single floor. The courtyard is wonderful. A gear place to take a break. This is the last and only museum I got to see in NYC and I am so glad I got to go because my GF dumped me the next day. My next one will be the Met, I hope.

A Less Crowded Tourist Attraction. I love the experience of visiting this museum, it is less crowded and you get time to look at the art in a more relaxed atmosphere. There is a free audio guide which was a great deal. Loved the Cimabue painting!
Not Overwhelming. This is a smaller gallery that you can cover in 2 hours easily. A nice quiet interlude and an escape from New York's business.

A Must See Treasure Trove. Though the bulk of the wealth of this odious man was built on the backs and deaths of desperately mistreated laborers and their families - this art collection is a delight to behold. Shocking to think the money he spent on his pieces of art while denying employees the very basic of human necessities and dignity. A sobering reminder of the robber baron error and the cruel treatment of workers before union and finally government protection. Pay what you wish Sundays - be sure to check their website for exact time. I would give five stars but the management is extremely rude. However the people that oversee the display rooms are very gracious.

A Different World. The best museum in NYC .. such variety and quality items on display .. you will be ammazed in just about every room .. if you go Sunday they have an unusual entry charge of where you determine what to pay .. but its a long queue so the entrance fee is worth the first 2 rooms alone .. so avoid the queue and go and see this wonderful world.

Impressive Even If You Don't Care About Art. We went on Sunday at noon to get the Pay What You Wish admission. Once inside, you find a lot of very impressive art - paintings, statues, ceramics. The complementary audio guide you can get is invaluable for helping you appreciate what you are seeing.

Very nice Museum, cool on a hot day.. The house and story of the man are very interesting. I do recommend the audio guide. The art is diverse and everyone in my group found something that they liked. If you want to read about where all Mr Frick's money came from "Meet You In Hell" is the story of his business dealings with Andrew Carnegie.

Second time here-will be back. The story is well known, rich guy builds a big house facing Central Park a long time ago, now is a museum. The facility is well maintained and interesting, there are secret passages in almost every room.The permanent art collection is significant but the special exhibits make return trips fun.It is worth going to see both the art and the building.
Amazing small museum. That it was once a private home and was like visiting someones house filled with beautiful paintings and objets'art.

One of the gems of NYC. My goodness. NYC has so many gems in the field of art! And benefactors who gave their collections to the public. Henry Clay Frick was one such person. His collection of paintings and sculpture, housed in his mansion, is wonderful to see. Just the house itself is a drawcard. We really enjoyed the time we spent there.

A great collection of art.. The Frick has a great selection of art on display. Even if you only have a casual interest in art, you will recognize the names of a substantial number of the artists works on display. Both times we visited this museum there were only a moderate number of other visitors, so we could easily stand in front of and appreciate the art.

A New York favorite. This beautiful collection is housed in the former mansion of Mr. Frick. It's a perfect size for a morning or afternoon visit. You can see the whole thing at once, unlike the larger museums. Plan your visit because there is no food or drink on the premises or immediately surrounding.

bronzes-special show. Always a perfect jewel box. The special exhibits are in basement rooms; but the scholarship is first rate. The entire venue is small enough to survive. The art is some of the finest in the city.
Excellent and manageable museum. Mr. Frick had a great eye for great art--just enough to wet your appetite without hurting your feet! The house is lovely and impressive.

lovely museum. this is always one of our favorites. Mr. Frick amassed a spectacular collection and the fact that the it is housed in what was his private home, adds to its WOW factor. It's also interesting to see how the 'robber barons' of the 19th century spent their money . The art is top quality and more intimate than in the larger museums
Always a nice tour. The house is amazing and full of art pieces and it is very nice to imagine that people would live like that just in front of the Central Park !

Just the right size and an eclectic interesting mix. Beautiful house with a really interesting mix of artists and sculptors displayed within. Just the right size, so don't get that 'supersaturated" feeling. Not sure that I like moving from Goya to Constable to van Gogh to Turner and then Whistler at such speed when they are in such close proximity to each other, but then who am I to comment? I am a boring scientist. Overall a great feel to the place and some of the collection is absolutely breathtaking

Great collection. I visited the Frick to see Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring as it is one of my favourite paintings. I was fortunate to be in NYC while Vermeer's exhibition was on and found the Frick to be charming and a joy to visit and rest my weary feet!

Excellent, even for non-art aficionados. Visited the Frick on a Sunday morning pay-what-you can slot, and was very impressed. I'm not normally an art museum person, but do appreciate classic pieces when exposed, and I greatly enjoyed a couple of hours in the Frick.The audioguides were very good, the size of the collection is not overwhelming so you can take your time and enjoy the whole collection, and the quality of the paintings and sculptures are excellent. Very nice, intimate place to really get to appreciate what classic art are always about.
Probably the best small art museum in the world. Wonderful,beautiful,magical the art is sublime and the interior conservatory so beautiful you do not want to leave

The Frick is a unique treasure in Manhattan. Like the Morgan Library, the Frick Collection is based on the personal collection of one collector and housed in what was his house -- a mansion, really, in midtown Manhattan. The collection has some really wonderful works, such as the Hans Holbein portrait of Sir Thomas More, and the Fragonard room is a unique treasure in NYC; but as wonderful as the art is, the setting is even more interesting. The Frick mansion is an ideal setting for viewing art; it feels much more like the private home it once was than a typical museum, and the interior garden courtyard is the most wonderful part of the building. The fact that the collection is only a fraction of the size of the Metropolitan Museum's means that you can see the entire Frick collection in about an hour without rushing through. And they often mount really interesting special exhibitions as well. The Frick is a must-see for art lovers~!

Excellent art collection. One of my favorite museums in NYC, the Frick collection is housed in Mr. Frick's mansion. The paintings and sculptures are phenomenal and it is more intimate than the massive Metropolitan (though that's a don't-miss, too.)

Not to be missed; to be enjoyed often. Before becoming a New Yorker, the Frick was always part of a visit, and living here I try to stop by several times a year, even if just for a quick look at my favorite Titian or Vermeer. This is a collection of paintings and furnishings that is uniformly excellent, housed in a beautiful mansion. The audio guide is the best I have ever encountered - virtually every item - paintings, sculpture, furniture - is numbered, so you simply key in the numbers of items of interest to you,k and the commentary is excellent. At least an hour is needed, but you can really spend as much time as you like, there is so much to absorb and the atmosphere is so appealing.

Why haven't I come here sooner?. This has to be one of the best museums/ collections in NYC. Only a short walk up 5 th Ave I was instantly impressed with the building itself (Frick's mansion) and then blown over by the artworks and sculptures. I will definitely be back and can't believe that I have not visited sooner

Outstanding Art & Home. The home of the collection is worth the visit by itself for anyone interested in period architecture. The art was well displayed with adequate space to accomodate the visitors,

A Little Gem. Although MoMa, the Guggenheim, and the MET might house more notable art, this gem across from Central Park should not be missed. The sprawling mansion is a work of art in and of itself, and gorgeous outdoor garden and garden court add to the glory of the Gilded Age. If you have time to plan your trip, buy tickets to one of their memorable concerts. The museum is large, but you can get through the main collection and the exhibition in the basement in about two hours. The intimate setting and amazing art are well worth the price.
Best Museum. everything New York is: extravagant, elegant, historical, and knowledgable. A museum for true art lovers and historians
Magnificent. Like walking into a time capsule. Amazing art and sculpture, furnishings, tapestries. How wonderful to have lived like this.
First the housing and then the collection. It is an amazingly rich collection for a private one. The location and the venue itself are most impressive. Warmly recommended to lovers of arts.
Great!!. Loved it, please go you won't regret it. Very interesting exposition. The building and location are amazing.

Jewel in NYC. Small but fabulous
You must visit this museum. A look into the life of the wealthy NYC millionaires and great art to boot.

Another fantastic NYC art museum. Having already visited the other famous art museums (the Met, Moma, and the Guggenheim) we decided to visit the Frick Collection this visit. We were both amazed about both the quantity and quality of the art presented in this mansion, the former home of Mr. Frick, who was a multi-millionaire industrialist of the 19th century.

Nice Collection. The Frick Collection is a pleasant place to spend an afternoon. It is much like a museum, with some beautiful pieces. It's big attraction is that it is of very managable size and can be done in a leisurely few hours.

Amazing collection. So many styles of everything ceramics, furniture, paintings and sculpture. A bit disappointed that can't take photo's especially as purchasable guidebooks only cover one aspect of this stunning space
Beautiful. This museum is a gem on the Upper East Side. A stunning converted mansion to be appreciated for its architecture and works of art. Just go!
Wonderful art. Perfect size for a quick 1 hour art fix! Loved it. The audio guide was extremely helpful. Such masterpieces and the house was beautiful too.

popular mid sized museum. If you want "pay as will/free" admission, go on Sun 11-1.On the other hand for less crowded galleries, avoid the above time period!Museum guard said 1 of the least crowded time is to go ~1.5hr before daily closing time.Make sure to stop at the auditorium for video on gen intro, and current special exhibits.Front Desk has free audio tour handsets which provide good info for pieces in its perm collection.
must visit. I just love this small cozy museum. It`s free on Sundays. Not much people so you can watch paintings instead of Chinese napes.
Fabulous art in a stunning setting. Interesting gardens, creative architectural elements, lovely art and decorative pieces. Very expensive

Great art collection and building. Love the art collection and building. We went on Sunday when admissions charges were on donation only basis. It was busy but still manageable. We arrived first thing at 11AM and there was no line. When we exited, there appeared to be much longer wait to enter. I did get the sense the staff was a little frustrated on the 'free day' crowd. Overall, definitely worth checking out.

Beautiful little museum in NYC.. This is a great little museum, set in the home of the the industrialist Henry Clay Frick. This beautiful home was purpose - built as Frick, who was interested in collecting great art, intended to leave his collection of sculptures, artwork and furniture to the public after his death. For this reason, the museum is small compared to others in the city and easily do-able in a couple of hours. Being in someone's previous home also adds to the charm and personality of the place. Just opposite Central Park, this museum is well worth a visit!!

Are we in Europe or NYC. Enjoyed a little bit of Europe here in NYC at the Frick. We waited in line outside on a cold blustery day. It turned out or be pay as you want day and can recommend that for those on a budget. However be prepared to wait. L o o o n g time.

Interesting !!!. Security a bit severe going in and an odd mixture of art on view including some of the art classed as "degenerate" by Hitler. However if you like Klimt you have to go to see the fabulous portrait of Adele Bloch Bauer. Didn't like that they also had some of the Nazi propoganda posters on view to blance the "degenerate" art of Klees etc but thought provoking
Beautiful Museum. Terrific museum with an amazing collection. I suggest the audio guide, lots of fun tidbits about the collection and history of the Frick Mansion.
Nice Collection. A small museum, so just right for an afternoon of lunch and looking. Nice artwork you will recognize and enjoy!

THE PERFECT MUSEUM FOR A MORNING OR AFTERNOON ART FEAST!. The combination of a beautiful location across the street from Central Park, a magnificent mansion with a fascinating story, and a fabulous collection of masterpieces (from ancient to contemporary) has made this our favorite small art museum. We try to spend a morning or afternoon at the Frick whenever we are in NYC. In addition to their amazing (for such a small museum) permanent collection, there are always worthwhile temporary exhibitions as well.
Great Museum Alternative to Teeming Masses. Much more manageable than the big guns. Wonderful collection in gorgeous setting. Very accessible and not overwhelming.

Wonderful Museum, with less crowds. Mr. Carnegie's partner, leaves NY a wonderful gem of a museum and a look at the guilded age of 5th Ave, that is long torn down. Get there early and plan to eat lunch at one of the many options nearby, within a short walk.

Small but lovely collection in a stately home. If you wish to have a glimpse into the home of a self-made man who was a contemporary of the likes of the Rockerfellers, and the beautiful art that he collected, then there is no other museum in the world quite like this one. It's not humongous and can be completed in quite a short time.
beautiful. well worth a visit - gives a true sense of the wealth at the turn of the 20th century and tie it in with a visit to the Met. to view more of the art that was collected during that period.
The frick. One of the city's most beautiful homes/museums. Beautifully displayed works of art with a warm and we,coming ambience.
Frick Collection New York. Difficult to beat the quality of the collection of pre-20th C European art in such a small museum. The staff can be a bit brusque. But the Frick is a must on every trip.

Fine museum to see and walk through. The Frick is a favorite here...easy to get to (on 5th at 70th St),
One is never overwhelmed with 'so much to see', but rather can take time to enjoy each of the varied works of art Well worth the time and the cost. Plan on taking about 2-3 hours.
Best kept secret museum in New York. This is by far my favorite museum in whole wide world, it has an intimate setting and some of the most amazing paintings.

The best quality art imaginable in a gorgeous setting.. This collection could never be created today. Such art is now available only to be seen in the best of museums. The Frick now is offering, in addition, excellent quality loan exhibitions. I love to visit when I need a pick me up from the ordinary quality of things one encounters in everyday life.
The best museum in New York. The opportunity to see the architecture of this beautiful Park Avenue home was incredible. A must see in NYC.
Great museum. Small, manageable, not crowded. Gorgeous art that you can see up close. It is my favorite museum in NYC.

Wonderful Collection. An excellent collection, and a manageable size to see beautiful classic art. I was recommended this by a friend and was not disappointed. Some museums are overwhelming by so much to see but not this one. A little garden atrium to sit in and a shop but no cafe. A little gem.

Great experience. This mansion is lovely and the furniture added to the comfortable feeling. The art work is outstanding and the recording that is provided with the tour was very helpful. This mansion/museum should be on everyone's must-see list. It was so relaxing to be able to enjoy the paintings without the crowds.

Yawn...Attend on a Sunday to get money's worth. So the Frick Museum is...boring. The layout and design of the house is lovely. The paintings are lovely, yes, this is true, but when I consider the actual price compared to say, the Met museum, I don't think this museum is worth paying full price. Go to this museum on Sunday between 11 and 1 when you can pay what you like. People ahead of us in line were paying $1 for tickets. We bought 2 for $5. This seems to be more reasonable for what you actually are viewing. I'd start with the movie which is actually towards the END of the tour. This movie will help you better understand the pieces you are viewing. Then, I'd get the audio tour which may also help understand what you are seeing and why the paintings are so important. Overall, after having gone to the Met on numerous occasions, I think the Frick was a bit of a disappointment. You can pretty much see similar items (more and better quality) at the Met and they have a pay what you wish option all the time!
Frick. As a family member Fred a Fricke I can say that I am very pleased with what they have done over the years..great place to see great Art pieces....

Frick Collection-Not to be missed. Fantastic museum. Walking around the mansion and taking in the wonderful collection is quite an experience. Watch the movie as it is enlightening about the Frick family. Imagine going to the kitchen to get a glass a milk at night time and walking into the one of the magnificent rooms to gaze at the paintings. Very enjoyable.

Beautiful Mansion on Park Avenue. Gorgeous setting to display classical paintings. You can really get a sense of how the wealthy lived. Great location too, right by Central Park. They often host events during the summer and offer free admission, free drawing supplies, and classical concerts.

A wonderful museum and mansion. This is a great place to see art since it feels as if you are visiting a mansion -- which you are -- and sharing in the collector's private art. In the many places you can see art in NYC, few have the intimacy and style of the Frick. DO NOT MISS IT

NYC Luxury. Not the best spa I've ever been too (and I've been to quite a lot) but you can't help to be swept away from the luxury of this place. Everything is just so pristine. I had a facial and it was so good. The staff are professional and friendly. My only regret is that I went alone as it wold have been nice to share the experience,
Lovely place, lovely winter garden. Tree fine paintings of Vermeer and many other exellent art peaces from Europe in big and lovely home of millionar Frick. Good book shop. Sit in winter garden!
Very good. Great building, amazing collection and paintings. Very posh neighbourhood. Gives a glimpse of the way billionnaire lived a century ago. Worth going++
Lovely mansion. First time here. Stayed in NYC for the wk end and visited on Sun morn when it is pay as you wish. Excellent,though small art collection. Truly enjoyed it.

Art & History. Interesting collection of art and antiques. The mansion itself is part of the experience. Take a few minutes and visit the music room for a short video about Mr. Frick and the collection.

Fabulous museum, not to be missed. Beautiful old home, reminiscent of the golden years in NYC, facing Central Park. We went to see the Vermeer collection, and waited perhaps a half hour to get in. I must say that it was during the Thanksgiving holidays. the entire museum is exquisite, and there are headphones available, if you wish to use them.

Did I visit the wrong Frick??. Based upon reviews I gladly gave the suggested Museum price even though it was Sunday's pay as you wish day.....I was VERY disappointed...Don't get me wrong but some of the works were outstanding but this institution in no way compares to the collections at the Metropolitan, The Smithsonian, The MFA or to Detroit's Collection...... Walk a few blocks and you will be floored by the Collection at the Metropolitan....... the breathtaking and awe inspiring Metropolitan.......BTW I am not from NY.....I was floored by the rudeness of the staff as well..... We were taking pictures in the Central Garden (which is the only place you are allowed to take Pictures) and was rudely told that flash was not allowed in a brightly lit room where the ceiling is open to the sky....I asked to use the bathroom and was instructed it was in the basement..... when I got into the basement someone said it was not there.... I later found the basement bathroom.....All in all.....- No photos allowed- Small but quality collection- Small footprint- Upstairs closed to access- Very rude staff- Not very knowledgeable- Only 10 year olds and above allowed- If you have experienced other world class institutions then this might not be worth your time

Nice place for 18th & 19th century pieces of art. We loved everything from the house itself to every piece of art.Some rooms, as the West Gallery even if it is big, is a bit dark but it seemed to be assumed by the owner and creator himself...

If you see only one Art Museum. At the Frick you basically get 2 attractions for the price of one - you see some amazing art (nothing modern here, go to MOMA for that) and you get to walk around in a mansion that actual people used to live in. It's small but so lovely, and it doesn't take 4 hours to get through. For those in your group who don't want to linger over the art there is a lovely inner courtyard where they can sit and relax. The audio guides are a must - included in the price of admission.

A museum the way museums should be. I visited this museum nearly 30 years ago. It is the one of the few museum I profoundly remember in detail. It is that good. The museum is small but mighty, uncrowded, has free audio tours, and is very easy accessible as a result. More importantly the art in this house is of great significance and is displayed in the house the way it was when Frick owned the house. It is also set within architecture of great significance and grandeur. My favourite is Mrs Frick's sitting room which consists of a 18th Century whole room uplifted from a french chateaux complete with painted panels, parquet floors, and sevre vases. I also liked the fact that he reunited pairs of pictures so that you got a sense of the story of the artist. It is very eclectic so whatever your passion there is likely to be something astoundingly good.

Breathtaking!. Our visit took us through beautiful main-floor rooms & halls where Henry Clay Frick's private collection of paintings, sculptures and furnishings were displayed. So many highlights - Vermeer, Rembrandt, Gainsborough, Turner, Constable, Monet, Manet, Titian, Goya, El Greco. It took my breath away! We also saw a special exhibit of renaissance & baroque bronzes from the Hill Collection - exquisite examples from Italy, France, Germany & the Netherlands. Lovely and well-worth taking the time to see.The Frick Collection is now one of my all-time favourite small museums ... along with the Marmottan in Paris and the Bargello in Florence.

Wonderful collection!. An incredible private collection of paintings, sculptures, Limoges enamels, oriental rugs and french furniture displayed in a delightful mansion. A glimpse into the lifestyle for the rich in times gone by.

No Young Children Allowed. Our group of 4 ladies loved this museum. Unlike the Museum of Natural History, there were no hordes of young school children to have to wade through. Due to the many small sculptures & figurines in the museum, no young children are allowed. So this makes it nice & quiet & you can really appreciate all the fine art. The museum is somewhat off the beaten path of the other famous museums in NYC, so it's not crowded at all & has a very tranquil & quiet atmosphere.

Devastatingly Heart Stopping. Every room I entered had many many many pieces which I've studied all my life. Profound collection in elegant, serene and approachable setting. There was a very short docent led tour and a film available to see. I loved every second. One of my favorite places of all time.

Love This Museum. The main reason I like this museum is because it is in the Frick Mansion, so you get to see the art, as well as the first floor rooms of the mansion. Also, it isn't too big to comfortable see in an hour or so. Unfortunately the day we visited the courtyard was closed due to some private function to be held there that day, and the music room was also closed. And for some reason I didn't understand, the film about the Frick Collection was not being shown. Therefore, I was upset that I paid full admission price, but was not allow to see the full extent of the museum. I think I should have been told prior to buying my ticket that I would not see three important features of the museum. It felt like I was tricked. Otherwise, I would probably have given this museum five stars.

Great Museum!. Considering it was once the grand residence of industrialist Henry Frick you get history and art in the same museum. I am not a big fan of art but really enjoyed this museum. More for the grand architecture than the art.

Historic Frick Mansion holds a small, but important collection of artwork.. Do take in one of the mini tours - you will learn much about the history of the original owner, Frick and the building.
Don't miss some of the important French impressionist paintings in the stairwell! Go early as the line can be 40" wait at times.
beautiful museum. wonderful setting for a beautiful collection-the center courtyard was so serene and peaceful. Worth the wait in line to get in.

Art Lovers, Don't Miss!. My Mom and I were overwhelmed by this beautiful gem! The house is lovely, the collection wonderful. There are artworks at the Frick that you will not be able to see anywhere else, as a stipulation in the will that created the collection is that the pieces may not be loaned out or sold off. Vermeers, Rembrandts, El Grecos and a beautiful setting make this a special treat for any art lover. No children under 10 allowed, not a place for the littles. The Frick lacks that industrial, high ceiling, echoing feel you get in some museums. It is a treat to wander through the former home of an art lover. We arrived at 11 on Sunday, which is pay what you will pricing day. We toured the entire museum at a leisurely pace, listening to about 75% of the audio descriptions available on the free audio guide. We feel we saw everything, we could have spent a little more time, but we had an appointment elsewhere so we left at 3. There is no photography of the collection allowed, which is a bummer, but there is a book that lists all the details of the works that was only $2 to purchase. We also picked up a full color book with the collection highlights for a reasonable price under $18 No food on site, eat before you go or when you leave. (We hit the hot dog cart one block down on the way out)The staff was nice. Many, many security guards. Keep in mind that they are trying to preserve the house, you might be gently reminded to stay on a carpet or not to touch a wall. there are sofas against the wall in the West gallery to rest weary tootsies, as well as seating in the Garden Court, the only place you are allowed to take photographs on the property. There were short films in the Music Room that told about the collection, as well as the special exhibit. Well worth the 12 minutes to get some of the history of the house and collection. And you can rest your weary tootsies while you sit and watch.We saw the Bronzes from the Hill Collection on exhibit when we were there, Renaissance and Baroque Bronzes From the Hill Collection at The Frick Collection, NYC, January 28, 2014 to June 15, 2014. Lovely, and an interesting quick video on a monitor that showed how bronzes are made using the lost-wax technique. There's also an exhibit at the Portico Gallery, a well-lit small gallery that was charming: Enlightenment and Beauty: Sculptures by Houdon and Clodion April 1, 2014 to April 5, 2015, an opportunity to see several sculptures from private collections in an atmosphere conducive to leisurely study. I absolutely fell in love with Hodon's "Vestal" - a sculpture I would never have seen otherwise, I feel fortunate to have visited the museum when we did.

Special treatment for special exhibition. We went over the the Frick to see The Goldfinch painting by Vermeer and were enchanted by the whole exhibit of Vermeer and colleagues. Notable was the polite and special treatment we received as my husband is somewhat handicapped (stenosis) and needed a wheelchair. Every courtesy was extended as we made our way through the crowds and wandered from room to room in this glorious house turned museum that is one of the great jewels in New York's art crown!

Probably our best visit in NY. We just loved the Frick collection. I'm not one for art collections but did like the setting here in a great house on Fifth. We enjoyed the great paintings by some of the US great painters and at the time of our visit there were certainly plenty of Constables to admire.

Different type of museum. Less crowded then the big museums, but you will not be disappointed. Seeing in situ art work in a lovely home surrounded by gardens. Next time we want to make sure we get the audio it definitely would have added to the experience.

Stunning collection of some well-known pieces. This is a gorgeous museum definitely worth a visit if you're in New York. They have a wonderful collection of some well-known pieces. It's hard to believe the museum used to be someone's house. It's so grand and opulent.

Amazing house and art collection!. I highly recommend a visit! The building and it's history is interesting and the art will blow you away! Of the thirty something known paintings by Johannes Vermeer, three are in this collection!

Spectacular building. A must do in NYC. The building and garden court are breathtaking.The collection is less interesting to me, except in the historical context of what a fabulously wealthy collector can do at a particular point in time, but really, whether or not you like the art is a matter of taste. If you are a Gainsborough fan you will love it!The audio tour is very well done.
