What an amazing house and collection!. So many familiar pictures in this beautiful house right opposite Central Park. Free audio guides keep you informed rather than lots of information boards as the Frick aims to be more like a home than a museum or gallery. Look out for the 'Pay what you like' slot which can save you lots of dollars. The only criticism is that there are very few places to sit down.

One of the best museums ever. I loved the fact that this collection is not huge and overwhelming. My favorite piece was the Renoir but there were so many others I loved as well. In some rooms, they are set up exactly how it was when the Frick's lived there. Highly recommend the free audio tour.

Absolut a top attraction.. It’s very nice to walk in a house with beautiful art.
When visiting New York this is a museum that you shouldn’t miss.
Really liked the audio tour!
pictures. no complaints enjoyed .not many seats ,though nice garden area and building spent over two hours could have stayed longer

Absolute Gem, Sure to be enjoyed by anyone who appreciates beauty, not just "Art lovers". The Frick is absolutely delightful. An exquisite collection of masterful old world paintings and other fine arts presented in the 5th Avenue mansion of the collector. A rare opportunity to tour a beautiful (but not ostentatious) mansion and enjoy the architecture in harmony with the art. The condition of the works and their presentation is pristine and yet approachable. The collection is also "right sized.". You can really see it in an hour or two. It is bountiful and diverse without becoming overwhelming. The personal audio devices offered are very worthwhile. A number for each room lets you hear the history and design of the room. Most works also have a number, so you can punch up more detail on all that interests you.

Exceptional. I'm not a big museum lover but this was fantastic. Interesting movie gives a historical perspective. Happy regarding in and out privileges for the day as we had a tour in the afternoon. Hand-held audio device is offered and provides insight. Was disappointed device were collected 1/2 an hour before the museum closed so you may want to plan your visit with that in mind. This is a don't miss.

A Gem. I have been to New York and it's world class museums often. For some reason, I had never visited The Frick. I finally made it over Mother's Day weekend. It is so special. Some of the best examples of the masters - Bellini, Holbein, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Manet - in the same rooms and positions that Henry Frick left them... surrounded by the equally world class furniture and decorative treasures he selected. Be sure to allow 2-3 hours and pick up the FREE audio guide in the entry.

Stunning Collection and Mansion. Toured at leisure. Lovely experience. Amazing collection of paintings, art objects, furniture, and decorative items. Each well described. Rotating special exhibits as well at no extra charge. Well organized with friendly attendants. Collection is not overwhelming as in some museums. Nice for a half day visit. Right on CPE. Highly recommend.
Hidden gem. Just fantastic if you enjoy art. Well worth a visit. Be sure to allow adequate time to visit all the rooms (galleries).
European Arthouse. Small digestible gallery of fabulous art in one of the finest houses by the park. Free Sunday morning

More than just Art. The Frick Collection is housed in the former home of Henry Clay Frick, who had the home built and furnished, and who collected the wonderful art throughout the building. The upper floor is not open to the public but the entire main floor is furnished as though the family were still in residence. As a result, a trip to the Frick is more than just the art on the walls, it is also a look at the antiques, the statuary, the wall coverings, fireplaces, bookcases, and a genuine peek into the home and grounds of the Frick family. The audio guide (free with paid admission) is really helpful when trying to learn about the various works and the rooms themselves. As previously stated, there are 3 Vermeers in the collection as well as originals by other well known artists. You could spend an entire day going through this vast home.

Vermeers!. Girl with a Pearl Earring has come and gone, but the Frick owns three Vermeers in its permanent collection. Those alone are worth a visit. It's also a stunningly beautiful building. I was admitted free with reciprocal admission from my home museum.

My favorite NYC museum. Not that many people visit the Frick (compared with the Met or MOMA). But it should be on your list of places to go. The house is beautiful--great period architecture and a garden room that is pure bliss. The art collection is very nice--even paintings in alcoves are worth your attention. And since there are not as many people there, you really can enjoy the rooms and retrace your steps to visit a favorite work again It's small enough not to be overwhelming but large enough to wish you could have been part of the Frick family...and be thankful that it is some place you can visit.
A must see. This is one of the best and it is so relaxing. Very European feel and wonderful, not often seen art.

The essence of elegance. There are few more satisfying centers of culture than the Frick in NYC. A glimpse into how the 1% lived in a bygone era (Henry Clay Frick built his home just after the turn of the 20th C to prove to his capitalism cohort Andrew Carnegie that it was possible to build a bigger, better mansion than Frick's, a few blocks north and now the Smithsonian's Cooper Hewitt Design Museum) and a clear view of how respectfully art can be treated in such a setting. The collection is stunning, the quiet is soothing, the light is neither dazzling nor diminishing, and the staff is helpful and warm. There is no better museum in NYC, and if you go on Friday evening, entrance is free. (NB: students are free, and this is NOT an ideal site for small children, as there is nothing to touch or savor sensually.)
A Great Collection. Wow. Really worth the visit. A small place that you could linger in.Some old masterpieces all beautifully displayed.Feels like someone's magnificent house- which of cause it was.
Wow!. I love the way that this collection is curated. There are things that moved me deeply and there was the time and space to figure out why. Hooray for bold choices!
I love this little museum!. It is quiet, relaxing, calming and has stunning works! It is an art museum that will not exhaust you or overwhelm you. It is lovely in every way! A NYC must see!

Amazing Museum not well known. We caught the Girl with a pearl earring exhibit, but were blown away by the regular collection pieces they had and the story behind this museum. Its on upper east side, very nice location next to park. Found out my cousin and wife love it so much they are members
Nice small museum. Great visit for architecture lovers. The museum features a nice collection, while the visitor walks through the wonderful house.

Best of the Best. My husband and I went to see the magnificent bronzes collection but wound up strolling through the entire museum, enjoying not only the incredible masterpieces in virtually every room but also the mansion itself, with its marvelous and elegant decor as well as the peaceful indoor fountain and garden room. Graphics were a little hard to read unless you are young and have 20/20 vision, information about the Frick family was a little sparse and the staff was aggressively and downright rude about what guests do with their coats, but otherwise the museum is truly a flawless gem. Great little gift shop with items to commemorate your visit as well.

Very nice Museum. It is a very nice museum but its not too big. If you are in that area or hanging out in Central Park and want to check it out it is definitely worth it but to travel there just for that museum might be a bit disappointing. Overall, a nice experience.

A must see. This mansion used to be the home of the very wealthy Henry Clay Frick; so you get to see both the beautiful house and it's incredible art collection and amazing antique furniture. I always say this is the quickest trip to Europe you can make ( it really feels like you're in London or Paris); but the great thing is that you're in the middle of the Upper East Side - and very conveniently across Central Park where you can go take a walk afterwards. The art collection is a marvel and can very honestly compete and even beat some pieces at the nearby Met Museum. The great thing is that it has a smaller scale, so you can see everything in 1 or 2 hours.They also organize very cool exhibitions, and sometimes have concerts.Absolutely worth a visit!

A Real Gem!. This museum is housed in the old Frick mansion on Fifth Avenue in NYC. It's collection is stunning - many best examples of history's greatest artists.If you appreciate fine art in an elegant enviroment, this is a must visit.

Everywhere you look, a masterpiece. You can see the Frick, unlike the Met, in two or three hours. If you think you might possibly have an interest in European painting from the Renaissance to the 19th C, do not miss the home of Henry Clay Frick. There is no dross here. The free audio tour (punch in a number to hear about the works that interest you) calls Bellini's St. Francis in Ecstasy the most important Renaissance painting in America. It is certainly the most beautiful. It hangs between two superb Titian portraits, across the room from an El Greco and two mind-blowing Holbein portraits. There are only 3 dozen Vermeers in the world, but 3 very lovely ones are here, as well as works by Rembrandt (the fascinating Polish Rider), Hals, Van Eyck, and rarer, Van Dyck. The Veroneses are among his finest, painted for Emperor Rudolf II. Even if Rococo is not your thing, the four seasons by Boucher are charming, and the decorative cycle by Fragonard is his masterpiece. A tiny trompe-l'oeil by Liotard, an artist few people know, is a thing of rare beauty. The Georgian portraits are fantastic, including Gainsborough's image of prominent courtesan Dally the Tall and Hogarth's painting of a heavily bejeweled woman who preferred to annul her marriage & declare her offspring bastards rather than allow her wastrel husband to blow through her inheritance. There is a small but lovely exhibition of the sculpture of Houdon & Clodion right now as well as one on Renaissance and Baroque bronzes downstairs. And when you've seen everything, you can relax in the garden court and pretend to be a robber baron with exquisite taste.

Wealth. The mansion alone is worth the visit, just to see how the uber-rich live. The art collection is astounding and I had no idea until I got there how broad the collection is. They should do a better job telling visitors who Frick was; they skipped that which is unfortunate. Staff was very picky about bags and jackets but I guess that's reasonable given the priceless art pieces around. 10-and-over strictly enforced, not a place for kids.

Visit the Frick Collection. We are members of the Frick Collection and enjoy visiting the Collection when we visit NYC. The three paintings by Vermeer are our favorites. The other works of art and the special exhibits are always wonderful to see. Resting in the courtyard is so refreshing. The staff is always courteous and helpful. This is a nice way to begin a visit to NYC.

Outstanding art collection in a charming venue!. We visited on a rainy Saturday morning and thought it was wonderful! The Rembrandts and Vermeers alone are worth the trip to the upper east side. The staff are very helpful, as is the audio guide that comes with the very reasonable price of admission ($15 for seniors). The art works are very nicely displayed, and there are ample provisions for sitting to contemplate the wonderful art. The gift shop is very interesting and worth a visit in itself.

Perfect little museum. A perfect museum if you do not want to be overwhemed by too much art. Great classical masterpieces About 1 hour it takes to see the entire place... a bit longer if you take the audio tour.

Fantastic exhibition. A beautiful collection of fine furniture and paintings in a domestic setting on the East side of Central Park. Well worth a visit...be sure to watch the short film about Mr Frick!

Jaw-dropping surprise. I had no idea that this house in NYC was so impressive and its art collection so surprising. Highly recommended. Excellent audio guide, incredible house, indoor garden courtyard, galleries, furniture, art by El Greco, Rembrandt, Holbein, Vermeer, Degas, Renoir - to name a few.

The best of the best!. Don't have time for a whole day at the Met but want to see some masterpieces of art? The Frick is for you. Housed in one of the few, perhaps only 5th avenue mansions left, the setting and the art are well worth the entry fee. Allow 1 1/2 to 2 hours and just enjoy.

A beautiful collection. The Frick is a great place to spend a few hours if you like art and architecture. A beautiful home containing an impressive collection including great bronzes. When I visited there was a special exhibit of additional bronzes from The Hill Collection that alone made it worth the visit. On a pretty day the courtyard is a great place to relax for a few minutes. One word of warning don't visit here if you are looking for volume, quality reigns here.
Very Interesting. Good art, in a nice restored townhouse. Contained paintings by famous artists and beautifully restored building.
Must see!. Fabulous collection, great museum and fab guided tour with a volunteer, would recommend a visit. Located on the edge of central park, and reasonably priced entry, included in city pass.

Gotta love it!. Beautiful home containing a faulous art collection. What's not to like? $20 admission fee. You can walk through casually and see everytning in about 2 hours if you have limited time in NYCDefinitely worth the short ride to 71st street.The staff was pleasant and helpful, too. Absoutely recommend it.
Super. An excellent collection of paintings and object d'art.Lovely mansion.An eccentric collection well rounded out by the robber baron's daughter.Do not miss.

Impressive Collection. I took the audio tour for the first time and it was fascinating to hear the history of the different pieces in the collection. I always love to sit in the center veranda, it is very relaxing and peaceful. I did get chastised for leaning on a wall which I guess makes sense since they are trying to preserve the house but still, they could have been nicer about it.

Neat to see. We really enjoyed seeing the Frick collection. Everything is displayed beautifully and you can look up close and personal. Beautiful home and landscaping, conveniently located in such a pretty part of town, right by Central Park.

Frick Museum - afternoon delight. Visiting the Frick is a wonderful way of spending at least 2 hours whether it be in the morning or afternoon. The audio tour is one of the best I have experienced. Please go and enjoy -- absolutely delightful

Amazing collection. Beautiful building and great location. We went on Sunday during the "pay what you want" time but paid the standard fare anyway. Our only mistake was not to leave enough time and to take advantage of the free audio guides. When we get back to NYC the Frick will get a return visit.
Really good and free on Sunday!. Really good museum, an amazing collection of bronzes in the basement, it's pay as you wish on Sunday! Definitely worth a visit while you're in NYC!
Must Visit!!!. I was in art bliss!!! Make time to visit the Frick, and take time to take it in....don't hurry through this splendid place.

My favourite New York attraction!. Smaller and more inviting than your typical museum. The art is beautiful of course, the mansion is wonderful and the staff were very friendly. I will certainly return next time I am in New York.

Beautiful Museum. Was recommended by friends and is well worth a visit. The fact that it was a private home makes the visit feel more personal. Frick certainly outdid Carnegie in terms of style and opulence! Great to see so many Old Masters and be able to touch the statues and ceramics (very carefully).

Simply Stunning. Beautiful presentation of many masters, sculptures, porcelains, furniture, Limoges, and so much more in comfortable home-style gallery settings. The Garden Court is a lovely place for contemplation. The Frick is a great respite away from the hustle and noise of the city.

Great architecture and collection but a bit overhyped. The place is really beautiful and the exposition is quite amazing. But I think the Museum is overhyped since it isn't that big and there are other great museums in NY. The bronze sculptures are specially interesting. It is worth to visit on Sundays, when you can pay what you want.

STUNNING - Old Masters with uninterrupted viewing!. A beautiful house facing the Park on E 70th - amazingly quiet, with a collection of truly magnificent paintings, marble busts and bronzes.
Much more dramatic than I had expected, in a homely setting......
Marvelous. Absolutely a beautiful house. The art is amazing and the architecture beautiful. This is how the 1 percent lives.
A Majestic Display Of Art. My favourite place in New York , sublime , beautiful ,contains an excellent collection of English art. Cannot recommend highly enough.
Wonderful Art Collection. Really worth the entrance fee (and they have also a "Pay as you please-oppurtunity" sundays 11am-1pm. Rembrandts portrait of him self was uforgettable.

An impressive building just for itself, not counting the artwork. It was definitely worth seeing....the building itself is worth seeing and we were fortunate to be there during the Vermeer exhibition. Very interesting.

Audio Tour is Essential. I liked the audio tour - mostly to find out the history of the individual rooms. The attendants may not appear helpful or personable, however they really care about the place and know a lot more than you think. Allow time to see the AV story about the Frick Collection.
Beautiful. Impressive collection in a beautiful property. Worth the price of admission. Beautiful garden. Reminiscent of Isabella Gardner Museum in Boston. Lovely.
free on sunday. It´s an old house with some really good works of art, Every sunday in the mourning the entrance is free (11am to 1pm)

Fantastic!. Amazing collection in such an original setting. How one man could have such taste and eye for art!
We visited early on a Sunday and there was a line to enter as it was "pay as you wish" day. How generous that such a high quality museum can afford to offer this.
Great and focused collection. Of NYC's galleries, this is the easiest to visit for an hour or so. Many great paintings / artists all within an interesting old home.

Well worth visiting. This is another great New York gallery/museum. Mr Frick had very, very good taste, both in his art and his home. The West Gallery may well be worth the admission fee alone if you're an art lover. The Collection is well displayed and there's plenty of space to move at your own speed. The audio guides are excellent and are included in the admission fee.
Beautiful art museum. This museum is filled with exceptional art. Plus, the building itself is breathtaking. It is one of the best private art collections we have seen.
Our favorite museum experience. The mansion itself is the most beautiful setting to experience the wonderful art. I find this place to be serene and relaxing in a way that large museum's can't match.

Letting Art do the Talking. Whenever I go to the Frick I don't try to view every masterpiece but plan to sit or stand in front of one or two for as long as possible and absorb its meaning. After sitting facing a J.M.W. Turner painting for more than 45 mnts it suddenly reveals some of its secret beauty. It is a small museum where each artwork can give you this great experience.
A gem of a museum of great art. Rembrandt, Bellini, Vermeer, Holbein, El Greco, etc. Quiet, lovely setting, never crowded. You can stand or sit in front the paintings for uninterrupted contemplation.

Frick Collection. I have been there several times, but I visit the Library almost every week. I love the Garden, this place used to be a mansion turned into Museum and the Library has been added by his daughter after Mr Frick died to keep his collection of books. The paintings are not really my taste except few but still worth visiting, it is a exceptional place in the middle of a city that so much has changed. I love the Library for researches and it is so heart warming to see how they really care for these old documents and books, despite the Public library. Spend a little relaxing time at the Garden.
Beautiful. An incredible place to visit no matter what the current show is, but usually there is something of amazing interest and value.

One of the great museums of the world. A magnificent but finite collection of great masters in one of the last mansions left on Central Park. All on one level and easy to see it all in 2 hours. Quite expensive but free from 11 on Sundays if you don't mind a short queue. Don't miss the Vermeers!

Sunday at the Frick--pay what you wish. My favorite museum in NYC and I try to visit any time I am in the city. On Sundays it is pay what you wish (regular admisson is $20 for adults and $15 for seniors and students). The museum opens at 11 AM on Sunday and when I arrived a little before 11, the line went around the block. It moved fairly quickly and it took 15 minutes to get inside the building. Same great setting in Frick's mansion and wonderful art work but with the crowds of people it was somewhat of a chore to enjoy the museum. You can also get in for free if you are a member of one of the North American Reciprocal Museums (NARM)--the Frick participates so it might be wiser, if you have that membership, to visit some other day. Easy public transportation--bus and subway stops nearby and the beautiful Central Park right across the street.

Beautiful. The art collection, the furniture, architecture, ambience… Everything is beautiful and classy. The audio guide is a must, in order to understand the history of the house and the family, what makes the visit even more enjoyable. It was the museum with the least amount of tourists that I’ve visited, so I had a nice peaceful time. The Garden Court is lovely, it’s really nice just to sit there for a while.

My favorite NYC art museum. I am not taking anything away from the Met or MOMA but there is something about terrific art displayed in an old mansion on a human scale that makes for a superior experience. It is also less crowded than the big places so you do not have to fight to see a work. The collection itself is outstanding - not many places where one can see three Vermeers in a row!

Dutch Masters exhibition and beautiful permanent collection. Nothing in New York is more interesting than roaming the Frick Collection in a carefully preserved example of the high life of turn of the century United States. Sure the collection might be a little heavy on English Portraiture, but viewing all the art in the way in which it was left in the sumptuous mansion across from Central Park is simply cool. I attended again during the "Dutch Masters" exhibition and saw several Vermeers and the famous Girl with the Pearl Earring. Perhaps even more astounding was the presence of the "Goldfinch" a tiny famous oil in the too real to be real style of that time.Get the audio tour, its worth it, and you'll hear little tidbits about how Frick made his selections and in some cases also why he placed them just so in his home. I like to end my visits in the garden atrium which is a later alternation to the property, but works fabulously for the gallery.

An extraordinary collection of paintings in one of the great Guilded Age mansions on 5th Avenue.. Here's a place to come back to every couple of years at least. The collection is outstanding--an assemblage of masterpieces brought together by an American magnate with a genius for impeccable taste. Everything here is worth seeing here--and there's a lambency about the light that seems to capture New York as it was a hundred years ago. Treat yourself to an afternoon here. You won't forget the experience. It is as if Henry James and Edith Wharton were just around the corner, sharing beau mots in the next room, ready to greet you.
manageable in short time. great collection in a stunning old robber-baron mansion on 5th avecan easily be seen in a few hoursworth it

amazing location and gallery. on Saturday, 1000-1300 it is pay as you will. We got there at 1310 :( but still worth it. Lovely surroundings and they had sketch group in the atrium. Beautiful experience.

The Best Small Museum in NY. The Frick has a great collection and a wonderful feel.
It is small enough to be do-able in 2-3 hours.
It is a must see when in NYC.

"Perfect museum". This is one of the small gems of New York City. Incredible masterpieces in a petite mansion. No extra cost for the excellent audiotape guide. If you don't have much time, this is a lovely stop. Then, go to Bemelman's Bar at the nearby Carlyle for a perfect day.
Frick Collection a must see. Highly recommended. A beautiful atmosphere, and a memorable b or collection... including Rembrandt, Goya, Renoir, Degas,Manet, Ellen Greco and Vermeer.
Always a pleasure. What can you say? Best small collection of wonderfully chosen beautiful art. We visit on every trip to NYC>

Nice look at how the rich folks lived. Wonderful collection of art housed in an industrialist's home. Since he decreed that his collection would never be shared, this is the only place one can see works that would otherwise be hanging in famous museums.

Little known gem. Many people miss this gem while heading to the bigger museums, but that is a mistake. One should find time to visit this extraordinary place which was once a private home. Wow, what a home. The art is beyond compare, every work a masterpiece and all visible in a quiet intimate atmosphere that is unlike the bustle of New York. An oasis of calm.

More than just an art gallery. The collection isn't as large as some of the other well-known New York galleries and museums, but the experience of viewing the Frick's collection is second to none. For one thing, it's not as crowded and rushed as other place. The collection is stored in the former house of Henry Clay Frick, an industrialist from the turn of the last century. For those familiar with National Trust houses in the UK, it has a similar feel to some of those. Parts of the house were added on after Frick's death, but they don't seem out of place at all with the original sections. There's a free audio guide, and at least half of the paintings have an audio description, so it's well worth picking up. There's also a short movie that explains Frick's background and the house - I'd suggest viewing this before starting in on the collection, though the movie room is near the back of the house. If the $20 admission puts you off there is a pay-what-you-want time period Sundays from opening at 11am to 1pm. When I visited over Easter it wasn't busy at all during this period.

Nice, small museum. This used to be the house of a very rich man. Some of the rooms have been kept as they were when he lived there, including the pictures that he chose. I especially like Giovanni Bellini's St. Francis and the 4 pictures by Piero della Francesca.

Lovely small museum. This is a lovely, small museum, and doable in 2-3 hours without exhausting yourself. The audio tours are included in the admission, and really add to the experience, as they explain the history of the art and how it fits into the collection. The house is beautiful, and gives you a window on the Gilded Age and its opulence (the house, and now museum, occupies an entire block). There is quite a mixture of art - paintings, scupture, bronzes, enamels, furniture, porcelain, and I'm sure I missed something. It is also worth watching the video and learning about Mr. Frick, and how the house was converted into a museum. As for the art, the Fragonard Panels are astonishing, and I loved the Gainsborough portraits.Afterwards, cross the street into Central Park and see the Bethesda Fountain, which is almost a straight shot across from the Museum.
Actually blown away by some of the German masters. Not sure what it was but the setting was perfect for the German masters, maybe something about Frick's stodgy taste in decor.
A delight. Probably one of my favorite art museums I've ever been to. The collection is diverse and displayed within a beautiful home. I would definitely recommend visiting this treasure.

A must. This is a very special small museum, a must for anyone visiting NYC who hasn't been there. Also check the special exhibits, I was bummed to have missed The Girl with the Pearl Earring when it was there visiting.

Unique & Beautiful. This is not to be missed! You get so much for you money - the art and furniture is the highlight but the property itself is also a work of art.
We had the best time here. It was peaceful and so beautiful there. A very unique experience. Don't miss it!

A Hidden Gem. The museum is actually housed within a turn of the century mansion right in NYC. The self guided audio tour is well done and the pieces on display are as amazing as the home itself. Don't miss this one!

Best small gallery in NY. The collection is small but impeccable; Mr. Frick had amazing taste. There are so many instantly recognizable pieces in this collection, especially English and Dutch masters. It's small enough that one can see the whole collection in a single view, which makes it quite accessible to older children. They don't allow anyone under 10 in.

Fricking Brilliant!. The Frick Collection is housed In a beautiful building with a wonderful central courtyard. We went on a Sunday where entry is technically free although they do request a donation instead of the usual $20 charge. There is a wonderful variety of art with an excellent audio guide provided for free. The beauty of this museum is that it is not too big and in a wonderful, airy and beautiful setting close to Central Park. definitely worth a visit.
great!. the quality of artworkw displayed is stunning but the light is so scarce that it is difficult to read the presentation notes!
Sublime. I never leave NYC without a visit to the Frick this once private art collection ranks among the worlds finest not to mention their are three Vermeers hanging in this house on Fifth Avenue.
Outstanding but not Overwhelming. Great collection in beautiful surroundings. Far more manageable in size than many other places with this quality of work.

For art lovers, no children allowed!!!!!. In the center of Manhattan, on the east side lies this small jem with paintings of Degas, Ranuar and other masters.
It is a private home converted into a museum. Also includes a a clock collection.
A must see. Fantastic art and furniture collection in a beautiful former mansion of H Frick. Beautiful collection. Convenient location.

Excellent art collection - go there.. Lots of excellent European art from the last 600 years. Paintings by many of the well known greats (sadly no Rubens). Also sculpture and furniture etc. Tours available. Beautifully presented.

Girl with a Pearl. Johannes Vermeer is my all time favorite painter and when I found out that a special exhibit had the Girl with the Pearl painting at the Frick Collection I decided to go. I was not disappointed. It's considered the "Dutch Mona Lisa". The Frick is a beautiful museum that can be viewed in a few hours. Many, many famous and significant paintings to enjoy. I highly recommend the experience.
Beautiful building and collection. This was a nice, not overly large collection. The building is beautiful and it was very quiet inside - a nice escape from the other tourist destinations.

Gem!. Amasing museum, a real gem! One masterpiece on another. Under the Mr Frick's will nothing can ever leave the museum so you won't see the collection anywhere else. Exclusions are only made to the works acquired after Frick's death in 1919. Also beware that children under 10 y o are not allowed. Free audio guide is a nice touch. However, there's no such thing as a suggested price to pay as e.g. in Metropolitan museum of art and the full price at the moment is $20. On Sundays though you can pay as much as you wish from 11am to 1pm.
Wish we had more time.. Wow, just wow. What a place, right in the heart of the city east side. Exceptional collection. I can come back here time and time again.
An excellent way to spend a few hours. A lovely setting in New York City. Impressive art works surrounded in elegant rooms. Impress your date and bring them here!
Spectacular mansion, wonderful light, outstanding collection of art.. Take a stroll through the newest addition -beautifully glass enclosed terrace. Leave time to sit and meditate in the pool area.

Nice museum. We had an afternoon free and it was raining outside so we were looking for an inside activity. This museum was near the 68th St subway stop. The museum housed the collection of Henry Clay Frick in his NYC mansion. The collection includes European masters, major works of sculptures, French furniture and porcelain. It was a reasonable $20 admission and comes w/ a free headset which is a must so you have a little background of the various pieces you are looking at. You can easily see everything in 2 hours but you might want to stay a little longer so you can admire and enjoy these wonderful works of art.
Old Masters. Beautiful old building, peaceful way to enjoy wonderful art and furniture. Compact museum so good if you want a short dose of culture

Best museum in New York. Imagine you are visiting the mansion of your very, very rich relative with exquisite taste. The Frick Collection at Fifth Avenue and 70th Street has Rembrandts, Vermeers, Goyas, Whistlers, Gainsboroughs, Holbeins, and extraordinary furniture and sculptures...but it's a small jewel box of a museum. When you leave your feet won't hurt and you will feel you've had a great cultural experience.

If I had gone with slightly lower expectations it might have been excellent. Not much of a learning experience. Exquisite pieces of art, but appeared to have been kept in some random fashion. May be, I shouldn't use tripadvisor to set my expectations. Of course, I can't believe that I am even allowed to comment on art when all my expertise is limited to visits to a few museums.

Girl Pearl Earing. As this museum is the most beautiful small museum in NY it is fitting that they exhibited Girl... a few months back. That's when I was last there, but I never got around to writing a review until now. For those of us who find huge museums like the Met daunting, or don't want to spend that much time in one, I think you will love the Frick. I think it is a NY "don't miss."

Wonderful Collection!. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Frick Collection. A varied yet tasteful assemblage of beautiful works by prominent artists and displayed wonderfully throughout this turn of the century mansion adjacent to Central Park.
A Hidden Gem. The Frick is one of the reasons I live in New York City. I am fortunate to be close by, no more than a few blocks away. It gives me great and continuing pleasure.
Never expected this wonder. The fact that this was somebody's home and everything in it was purchased by the family made it more special. Truly a must see. I was so impressed.

Terrific litte museum with Old Masters, Impressionist gems. Many people overlook the Frick, which has a terrific art collection and is in a very pleasant 19th century mansion at 69th and 5th Avenue ( next to Central Park, near the Plaza). No kids under 10 admitted-- there's a lot they could break!First-rate works by Giovanni Bellini, Titian, El Greco, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Turner, Constable, Goya, Manet, Monet, etc etc etc ; need I say more?N.B. Every Sunday, they have a "pay what you want" policy from 11:00am to 1:00pm. Bathrooms in the basement, but there is one for special needs upstairs; just ask.

Sublime.. My favorite Vermeer is here. This museum is a gem in a city with an extremely large number of fantastic collections. And in passing, the Fifth Avenue mansion in which it is housed is a destination in and of itself for those who admire nineteenth century Renaissance revival architecture.

A wonderful neighborhood museum. A wonderful collection in one of the great houses from the golden days of old New York. Recently went to see the Goldfinch after the novel, and was delighted to see a vibrant and well tended collection. The El Greco still shines and of course the Fragonard panels are delightful. I also love the Vermeer (if it is not out on loan) as well as of course the garden. Wonderful gallery space with great light an fun to walk around and think how the rooms were originally used.
Excllent museum. We love the Frick! Great exhibits and easy to get to from Manhattan via the subway. Beautiful exhibits.

Very intimate small museum. Love to visit the Frick collection, is a small museum compared to others, but have a little of everything. From Russeau, Van Gogh, Monet, Vermeer, Velasquez, Rembrandt, Turner, Limoges, etc and the whole house is a delightful visit.

Some exceptional pieces. Really glad I visited this museum and immediately saw why it was ranked so high.
Really great displays and explanations. At the time I went there was a temporary display on bronze statues which was truly impressive and well explained.
Definitely visit it if you have the chance.
Sleeper museum. The Frick is a jewel, a little museum with great masterpieces one next to the other. This is where a New Yorker goes to refresh the spirit.
Intimate Viewing of Great Art. It's conveniently located on the Upper East Side, and has gorgeous rooms with walls filled with great paintings.

Beautiful building but.... While it's nice to have the Frick Collection in proximity to NYC's other major art museums, it also suffers a bit in comparison due to its smaller size and specific focus. If your time and/or funds are limited, I would recommend the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Guggenheim Museum first - and probably the Museum of Modern Art as well, depending on your interests.Visit the Frick on a Sunday between 11am and 1pm and it's pay what you wish, as opposed to $20 adult/$15 senior. Children under 10 not admitted.

Lovely. I wandered around the Frick one morning while my husband was attending a meeting. I've never been but plan on returning the next time I'm in town. It was quiet, no crowds and the artwork was amazing. I loved every minute of it. I took the free audio guide and I believe that made a huge difference in my enjoyment as well.

Little gem. Very glad I went, even after total art saturation at the Met, MOMA and Guggenheim, as this is so different in its setting, with amazing works by Turner, Hans Holbein, various Impressionists, Gainsborough, Constable, Whistler etc. The setting in the Frick house is beautiful and it is excellent value at $20 dollars, plus free on Sundays 11-1pm approx

Loved it!. Went for Veermeer - The Girl with the Pearl Earing - in November and loved it.Perfect for a 2 hour well spent.Will return.Well located, accross Central Park. Very nice 30 minute walk to Madison Square Garden.

Walking through the Gilded Age. There is much not to like about Frick personally - his involvement with the Homestead strike and the Pinkerton's being one but this is an astonishing legacy.Walk through the ground floor rooms of the Frick and you feel the aura of the Gilded Age, of unbound wealth and the hunt for art. The paintings are excellent from Fragonard's to Bronzino's and all in an immaculate setting. Maybe because everything seems as though Frick has only recently left, maybe because you can simply walk through the rooms, maybe because the paintings aren't arranged as in museum by school but have their own sense of place.This is one of the delights of NY and repays frequent visits
Priviledge. What a wonderful collection of art. The blue Turner will always "stay" with me. The court yard was wonderful for a rest between studying or just looking at all the art.

Lovely place to wander about on a weekend afternoon. The collection is varied, colorful, and compact. It was helpful to buy tics online and avoid the weekend lines. My focus was on the Dutch painting exhibit which was well done. Was pleasantly surprised by the remainder of the exhibits.

The Hill collection is a must, if you like figurative bronzes. The small scale sculptures are the most beautiful I've ever seen. This is a rare opportunity to see some of those privet bronzes and to study them.

Wonderful collection, beautiful museum. The Frick Collection is fabulous, housed in a grand old mansion which is interesting in itself. I love seeing the works of art displayed in this home environment; it gives one a glimpse of what it must have been like to experience the best of everything in the Gilded Age. We went to see the Vermeer exhibit, which was wonderful, and beautifully exhibited in these elegant galleries. Not a large museum, the Frick Collection doesn't need to be - it is almost entirely made up of masterpieces by the very greatest artists. I try to go whenever I'm in NYC.
fantastic. A great Art Gallery stacked full of great masters, all set in a House resembling an English mansion.
Very enjoyable. A beautiful house/museum to explore. Peaceful courtyard inside to relax and appreciate your time there.

This is the place to be if you like fine art. If the Met is too large for you, MoMA is not your taste, Guggenheim is too small, then Frick Collection might be just for you. Not a large museum by any means (it was actually a former residence of Henry Clay Frick), but lots of fine paintings from masters such as John Mcneill Whistler, Titian, William Turner, Rembrandt etc.
Don't miss it. Great collection, great villa, great story. Loved the Fragonard Room and the china collections. Visit their site to see

Add to your list of world class museums!. The Frick collection is wonderful! It is unusual in that it was the residence of the Frick family, so it is more inviting than a traditional museum. The personal collection he amassed is extremely impressive. I particulary enjoyed perusing his insane leather bound book collection...I could've stayed for hours just reading all the titles! The furniture is beautiful, as is the architecture of the building. The self guided tour is easy to use. If you go on Sunday, it is pay what you can. They were surprised we opted to pay full admission price. You can do the whole museum in about 2.5 hours. All I can say is don't miss the Frick Collection!
My favourite museum in NYC. First, the Met: huge, comprehensive, diversified, impressive.Then rush to visit the Frick Collection. You will not regret it!
Great Art Surprise. Great art collection, great furniture collection. Beautful building. Great history. Must see for anyone visiting New York,

Something Odd about the Frick. I've been to many similar museums in my life and there is something very odd about the Frick. There is no charm, no patina of history. For example one can not even compare it to the Wallace Collection in London. And for $20, and the Guantanamo Bay style, guards, one can easily miss the Frick!

Amazing and Tranquil. I wanted to move in as soon as I stepped through the door. Such a lovely house and a really inspiring collection. The environment is soothing and elegant, the staff very friendly. I look forward to returning again next time I'm in NYC.

An Intimate Museum Experience. Our friends from Westchester asked us to visit the Frick with them when they had Girl with a Pearl Earring on loan. The famous Vermeer was part of a larger exhibition of other Dutch masterpieces. We went on a Saturday afternoon so there was a bit of a wait. But we were prepared for the blustery weather so we didn't mind. The Frick was once a private residence, so even though it was an opulent home, you could still imagine people,living there. Along with the borrowed Dutch masters they also have a first-rate permanent collection. Visiting the Frick is a more intimate experience than the Met, so it's not so,overwhelming. Will definitely be checking for upcoming exhibits for a return visit.

Top of the line art. Not your modern museum and quite refreshing for that reason. Classical but not stuffy. Unique religious art and intriguing portraits as well as large collection of bronze pieces. Sprinkled with enameled vases and antique furnishings. Can be toured in an hour, but you won't want to rush. $20 a person. Check website for discounted times.
Unique way to see art. Since the Frick is in an old house you see the art in an unique perspective. Plus you can see a gorgeous house

Interesting museum.. Small and cosy, so different from many other New York museums. The collection is interesting and rich and the interiors are really worth seeing. A great and useful thing: Sunday morning (11am-01pm) the entrance is "pay as you wish".

A Gem. This is an exquite museum. If you've never been, go! If you haven't been in a while, go! The art is incredible, the furniture is beautiful and the building is exquisite. Treat yourself to a visit.
I loved it. liked how unusual and disprate the pieces are. A real gem. Loved the limoges vases and the turner paintings.

Nice little gem. I love visiting Frick Collection, and I try to do it whenever I am in NYC. Although small(er) than a regular museum, the building itself and many of the pieces are amazing. The staff can be a little annoying and over zealous (I was reprimanded by the security guard from across the large room because I literally stepped half an inch out of the carpet) but it is definitely a great visit and there are any nice staff members.

Stunning. One of New York's special treasures. It's collection and the
building where it's housed are breath-taking and not overwhelming
in scale. A "don't miss" visit.

Amazing. Being Dutch and loving art, I was really amazed by the incredible wealth of the Frick collection. Vermeer, Frans Hals and two great Rembrandts in one room in a fantastic private collection, great atmosphere, excellent audio-guide, and on Sunday, you pay what you want. Highly recommended!

Great Museum. Love the personal, eclectic feel of this place - just enough to see and experience without being overwhelmed by the size and scale. New exhibition of bronzes is fantastic and also really enjoyed the presentation film about the museum and its founder.

A beatiful big house full of treasures and superb city gardens. Liked the variety of the artifactsfrom paintings to sculpture and furniture. I liked the temporary exhibitions.
Should be more modern art.

A "must see" collection. Imagine a home on Fifth Avenue that is one city block in length! Imagine a living room with Constables, Gainsboroughs, El Greco, Holbein. Imagine having Rembrandts, Goyas, Vermeers dotted around the house. Imagine everything of the highest quality in a unique atmosphere. That's the Frick - don't miss it if you are in New York.
Fantastic. Best museum art collection in the world! Lovely oasis of calm in the city. Walkable from Times Square on the way to the Guggenheim!

One of the best art museums in the world. I am a philistine. Slept through humanities and art in college. That being said, this is an intimate non hurried collection of european masters in a gilded era mansion. I saw iconic originals that have been part of our culture (like Holbein's Thomas More). The gallery is presented in the Frick home to almost transport you in the context of the industrial giants and their fortunes providing unique assemblage of great , fine art. My favorite were the three Vermeer paintings (only 35 in the world). Audio tour which is included with admission is very helpful. Spent about two hours there and Central Park is across fifth avenue for outdoor activities in this part of the city.

A special place. Read about this in my Lonely Planet Guide and decided to make a detour and visit. Well worth it. Stunningly beautiful house adapted for its new life as a gallery. Fascinating collection of paintings and sculpture. Great variety of works and some real treasures. The atmosphere of the place was tranquil and inviting, especially the lovely central courtyard.
a wonderful museum day. spent nearly the whole day in this wonderful museum . Many, many "old masters" well displayed.The audio guide makes the experience richly rewarding.

Smaller museum but worth it!. At the Frick one gets art, interior design, and architecture all wrapped up in one easy to navigate museum. This museum is not so large as to be overwhelming but there is still plenty to see. Go on Sunday between noon and 2:00pm and you can pay what you will for entrance.

Unique Gallery. The art work is equal to the setting of fantastic furnishings and architectural details. It is a magnificent house as well as art gallery in a lovely residential area just off Central Park.
Interesting. Small collection. Beautiful building. Not too much to take in on a short visit. Comparable in size to the Dulwich Picture Gallery.

Definitely visit this museum. We have visited the Frick in the past and enjoyed the experience again. There is a wonderful informational video on the history of the house and the art collection. To see the art collected by Mr. Frick in this beautiful setting of his home is exceptional.

The beauty of the art is matched by the beauty of the building. We went to the Frick to see The Girl With the Earring by Vermeir which was on a temporary exhibition. The painting was amazing as expected, but what was unexpected was the beauty of the Frick house itself. The molding, the staircase, the furniture were all beautiful and worth the trip alone. A friend is coming in from Canada and I plan to take her there regardless of what the exhibition is just to see the museum itself.

Great Museum. I had never heard of this Museum until I saw it on Trip Advisor as one of the top things to do in NYC. We went there Sunday morning, between 11:00 and 1:00 PM you pay what you want to gain entry. The audio tour, which was free, was great. Plan to spend a few hours here. It is a really nice Museum.

A hidden gem. Spotting this in my research preparing for NYC, my love and I were not disappointed. Beautifully appointed town home, laid out with some of the most impressive and stunning works of art by masters of times past. Very glad that we found this amazing host to the arts.
Best Museum in NY. Love this museum. I love "house" museums in general. Very grand home, lots of great rooms with beautiful art. Loved the center courtyard.
Make the time to visit. One of the best personal collections in the USA. Take the time to visit Mr Fricks home and admire is wonderful collection of art and sculptures.

Beautiful Art in a Beautiful Mansion. On Sundays from 11am - 1pm it is pay what you wish. Normal admission $20. This is a gorgeous collection of art in a beautiful home on the upper east side. Plan to spend an hour or two. They offer free head sets if you would like additional information on the art work. Nice size art museum not overwhelming.

A New York treasure. This is a beautiful museum - a private home (ie, mansion) that has art work of the level of the Metropolitan or the Louvre. Not only is it a treasure trove of Western art, but one of those rare museums where you can look at art quietly, usually away from crowds and big groups. A wonderful place for contemplation, relaxation, and a true aesthetic experience. I find the staff to be a bit snooty here but that is a small price to pay to have the opportunity to see such masterpieces in this kind of environment. While MoMA and other big museums increasingly go for spectacle and shows that will draw in crowds and money, this place stands apart in valuing the artistic experienced, above all.

A delightful visit. This is the home of the Frick family circa early 1900s. Apparently Mr Frick made his money from the steel industry, and his beautiful home reflects that. The number of original pieces of art displayed throughout the house is astounding and well worth a visit. Admission is $20 per adult.

"Prick" Collection. I found the gallery to be too snobby and pompous. There are nevertheless very important works in the collection such as a remarkable self-portrait of Rembrandt and the two portraits of Sir Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell by Hans Holbein. The general admission is pricey ($20, luckily I am a student) and the museum visit can hardly last more than two hours. The free audio guides are, however a nice treat, but on occasion the audio commentary would make value judgments of the paintings rather than providing us with background information for us to judge the work ourselves. Also the museum felt more like a nostalgic tribute to aristocracies than a cultural pedagogic experience.

Loved the Frick. The museum is small enough to navigate in an hour or 2. Very enjoyable for families with seniors or teens with short attention spans. The collection is amazing. I had never heard of the Frick....but seeing that it got much better reviews than the Guggenheim thought I would give it a try. The 6 members of my family that went ages 14- 74 all loved it. The only thing that dissappointed me was that you are not allowed to photograph the art--which was truly awesome. Glad that his collection is open to the public..and at the time we were there Sundays were free (or an acceptable donation) no fixed price. I believe other days it was $20. Not crowded at all and a wonderful experience across from Central park East. Will be back!

Regrets for missing for many years for the more popular museums.. Amazing collection, well thought out, and a beautiful home turned museum. I have missed this museum as a New Yorker for years, often taking the visitors that came frequently to MoMA, the Met, Guggenheim, etc. I actually enjoyed this museum quite a lot and think that everyone visiting should stop by. Feel free to chat up some of the workers there as they are quite knowledgeable and can give you insight that you don't find on your audio tour.
Amazing. People u must go there! It is small and easy to visit.. In a maximum three hours u can see it all... The building is interesting e beautiful too. Go there! 20 dollars and free audio guide

Spectacular. The experience is quite unlike most museums as you are passing through someone's home. I spent as much time admiring the home as the art, which are both spectacular. This museum can be enjoyed in an hour or most of a day. Worth the visit by all means.

Great art and great special functions. I went there with my husband for their benefit events and browsed their art, they have a great collection that are located throughout the house. I got to take time and enjoy them without being too crowded. Very nice set up and tasteful arrangement, it is one of the best museum in the city, small and easy to get to.

Art museum on streroids. I wasn't expecting the caliper of art that we were able to see at this place. We stumbled in around 1 PM and caught a quick tour from the lobby that mostly talked about Frick and his library. I highly recommend this because it does not take a long time and loaded with good information. You will recognize a lot of the pieces of work even if you don't know much about art.

Beautiful collection in a beautiful former home. We first visited the Frick Collection two years ago and loved it so much we returned this year on our trip to NYC. We enjoyed the bronze exhibit, but the truth is we returned mainly to once again see the three Vermeer's. There are only a few (estimated at maybe 35) authenticated Vermeer paintings in the world, and three are at the Frick. We saw one in Vienna and one in London recently but you have to travel to see them. The Frick former home is a lovely setting for a smallish but wonderful art collection. It is so much easier to enjoy a couple of hours here than at the Met for us. This time we also concentrated more on the other furnishings and objects rather than just on the European masters.There is a wonderful virtual tool on the the Frick website. Take a quick look to decide if this is for you.Also, for those who are worried about the admission price to this private museum, the do offer times with free admission. We went early on a Friday morning, and it was not busy. Watch also for guided tour times and lectures. We hope to attend one next visit.

Beautiful collection. It's rare to find a collection of beautiful things that isn't draped in the American flag (figuratively), but this place is exactly that. This building and collection is all about the art and it's heritage, which as a visitor to the US made me breathe a sigh of relief and allowed me to appreciate the art's origins more. Frick clearly loved European design and art and had excellent taste. Even the rooms themselves are beautiful without the art within them, but the art and statues are incredibly good. TIP: There are pretty much no signs or explanations of anything so you must get the audio guide which explains mostly everything in the collection and whose explanations are engaging and interesting.

Wonderful art collection in a historic setting, with special collections periodically.. We visited the Frick during a time when the Hill collection of Renaissance and baroque bronze sculptures was on display downstairs. Spending time in that section alone was well worth the visit. Learning about 19th century industrialist Henry Clay Frick, his partnership with Andrew Carnegie, and his love of art, was fascinating. There's a short film on his life and his construction of a home which he apparently intended to become a museum upon his death, without ever expressing that intention to anyone.There are so many works of art and period furniture that one could not begin to list them in a brief review. From Jan van Eyck's Virgin and Child, with Saints and Donor to Rembrandt's self portrait, you can spend hours admiring the works of the Old World masters. We are told that on the weekends you should be there early because of the crowds that gather before opening time. We arrived 15 minutes before opening on a Tuesday morning and there were already 20 or so visitors awaiting entry. This is a grand place to spend up to a full day immersed in beautiful art and architecture.

We always wanted to go to the Frick. It was amazing what Mr. Frick collected during his life. The Vermeers, Rembrants and Whistlers. This is a definite must-see destination for the serious "Culture Vulture."

Beautiful art in a beautiful mansion. The Frick is an old school art museum in a very good way. Housed in the former home of 19th Century industrialist Henry Clay Frick, the collection focuses largely on European old masters. The interior, a work of art in and of itself, has been featured in many movies shot in New York Cityl

Brilliant - don't miss this!. This is the museum that most sticks in my memory from a recent trip to New York. It is a relatively small art collection, but that means you have time to concentrate on individual pieces (unlike the Met, say, where you're constantly hurrying through rooms). Every painting is worth seeing. The most perfect room for me was the 'Living Hall', which has six exquisitely beautiful works - two Titian portraits, Holbein's 'Thomas More' and 'Thomas Cromwell', El Greco's 'St Jerome' and Bellini's 'St Francis in the Desert'.You can easily spend two hours here without losing interest. The audioguide, included in the admission charge, is very informative and certainly worth getting. The only drawback is the lack of a cafe; there are restaurants close by, although they all seemed quite expensive.

One of the Best Museum Galleries in the City. Not only is this a great gallery with an amazing collection of priceless art, the gallery is housed in the former 5th Avenue residence of Henry Frick, one of the most influential figures in American history, when the country was in its modern industrial revolution. Read up on Frick and his relationship with Andrew Carnegie before you visit and you'll enjoy not only a premier gallery, but you'll appreciate the man who created it. You see everything within a couple of hours, so you'll still have time to do other things. If you enjoy classical art as well as New York history, then this is a must see.

worth visiting if you have still time left.. As I had seen almost everything famous in New York 25 years ago on my first visit, this timeI visited my then second choices including the Frick Collection. The exterior and the interior are romantic and I liked elegant and beautiful court very much but the ticket is too expensive compared with Metropolitan (US$20 vs USD25) if we think of the numbers of pictures exhibited.
Disappointing.. Not a high priority must see in New York. There are much better attractions in this city. A very ordinary gallery,
One of the Best Museums in the City. This museum has a great selection of European and American paintings. It is a must visit for anybody interested in artwork.

Worth the trip to NY!. My no. 1 stop when in NY. Why traipse round other galleries when you have La Creme de la Creme in one small(?) location.And I,m a Philistine!! This is the only place that brings fine art to my soul in one easy fix! Must visit for all Philistines with a glimmer of conversion!!
great museum. Sunday, pay what you want from 11:00-1:00. Such a beautiful collection, so easy to get to, and a beautiful mansion to walk through.
Impressive collection.. The Frick collection is impressive. It feels like a private residence experience in contrast to stuffy museums in the City.

Words cannot do justice. Oftentimes, I am disappointed with museums' collections. The Frick was overwhelming. I didn't mind paying the price of admission (you can pay what you want on Sundays) because the collection was mind blowing. To think that a person had the foresight to gather all of those works of art under one roof with the express purpose of showing them to the public after his death? I enjoyed the Frick more than the Metropolitan (much more intimate).
Wonderful Private Collection. A must see in New York with the Fragonard room an excellent Bronzino and much more. Helpful staff, nice Woman on the till told us the story of the Fragonards.
Beautiful 'hood, intimate feel. Interesting exhibits, beautiful location (both in terms of the physical building and the neighborhood) and rooms, very well preserved.

Small grandeur. I love small museums & private collections so I was positive about this place even before visiting. The building itself is a fascinating remnant of the grand era of tycoons who were building their homes as European grand villas so the whole atmosphere is of old world charm and opulence. The artworks themselves are a melange of styles with only a handful of true masterpieces (the Vermeers and the Fragonard room were the ones that stole my heart). What makes this collection really worth visiting is the way Frick himself combined these artworks and used them as a haven from his frenzied life. A nice short film presents the story of the place and the man, but look up his story for yourself to discover a controversial visionary.

Give this two hours.... A week after our visit to the Frick, I still pursue web images of the living room, and the fine west wing paintings. A great setting for great art--certainly one of the finest private collections in the world. I thank this site for recommending this site so highly.

Amazing home and art. Loved the entire place and wish we could have seen more,like some of the upstairs. The ticket price is a bit steep but there is a free audio guide. Frick was an intriguing man and his collection was incredible. The house is decorated to perfection. Worth the trip. Plan two hours or so.
My favorite museum. THE Frick has the most amazing collection, priceless art, amazingly accessible, easily all absorbed without being oveorwhelmong or exhausting

Wonderful Museum in a Gorgeous Home!. Loved the home and the beautiful artwork. My husband and I had toured Italy the year before. Many of the bronze sculptures depicted marble statues that we had seen in Florence. Some of the Artwork was from France. There are a few Rembrants too! The library was my favorite. The book collection must be priceless. The combination of the beautiful time period furniture coupled with the art was really cool.

A stellar private art collection. Located opposite Central Park, this former private house holds a magnificent collection of art and antiques. To get up close to paintings by Goya, El Greco, Rembrandt, Constable, Turner, Vermeer, Valazquez, to name but a few, all for a 20 dollar entrance fee, is a not to be missed experience. This was my second visit and I'll go again.

Wonderful way to spend the afternoon. My husband and I discovered the Frick collection on a recent weekend trip to NYC. We were looking for a quiet, relaxing way to spend our afternoon, and this was just the ticket. There was no line (we went in the afternoon) and the art is spectacular. The museum has so much character, it feels like you're looking at art in the home of a friend. This place is a must see for anyone who appreciates fine art in an intimate setting.

Unique experience in NYC. A time machine on the Fifth Avenue, a real must do. Moreover you can find inside several masterpieces of different authors and different periods that you van only see and admire in the Frick Collection.
Beautiful. Lovely building and furniture, has a cloak room. Interesting lay out where you can see the art on the walls but also some period furniture etc. Audio tour included in the admission price
Fabulous collection of art. Don't miss out on visiting this beautiful former home of Henry Frick. This is a must see for those visiting NYC.
Must See. Can't believe I've been to New York so many times and have never before seen this. To see original Rembrandts, El Grecos, etc. right up close - wow.

Beautiful art work. Because you can stand very close to the paintings and furniture, the guards are extremely afraid that you might touch something. We bent over to look at a loose thread in a carpet and a guard ran over to make sure we hadn't touched it!

Masterpieces. The collection is small but that makes it easy to not be overwhelmed. The quality is stellar. Masterpieces everywhere. There are exhibits in the basement that are easy to overlook. A must-see in NY if you enjoy painting and sculpture. The two magnificent Holbeins are worth the admission price alone.
The perfect place to spend an afternoon. Just find the hidden gems like the Bouchers and stand and stare until the sublimeness of this place refreshes your soul

Best if you go for free. The Frick Collection is actually bigger than what I'd expected. I had got a museum pass (from my local library) and so I didn't need to pay the $20 fee. But apparently on Sunday, between 11 am to 1 pm, it's "pay what you wish" and I guess it's more crowded than usual ---- I somehow went in this slot.There are a lot exquisite sculpture and paintings which I believe are mostly western. To me, it's not really that different other galleries/museum with western arts. I felt good when I paid nothing to visit but the fee of $20 (almost like the admission of the Met across the street, $25) is just too much if I have to pay.
Amazing quality of a smallish collection.. Very small crowds; a true art experience w/out the blinding white walls and copy-cat rectangular rooms.

Ruined my visit. I have to say the woman who was selling the tickets at the front really ruined my visit. it is indeed a beautiful place but i couldn't help but feel strange there. I am a student at Lyme Academy College of Fine Arts and had my student ID but she wouldn't accept it because she felt i was too old to be a student. Just cause i wasn't a kid does not mean i not enrolled as a student. What ever. Then i noticed all of the administrative staff were white but all the guards on the floor were black. The place was very up tight and I couldn't help but think racist. The guards sometimes were the only ones that would give you any insight to the collection.

Best museum in NYC. If you like Vermeer, this is one of the few places in NYC that you will be able to see his work. Add to that Gainsborough paintings, Whistler and Rembrant, as well as Frick's unique bronze art work and the actual museum itself, this is probably the best museum in NYC.

Our Favorite Museum in NYC. This museum in an absolute gem. The architecture of the mansion is incredible and provides an amazing setting for a spectacular collection of artwork. There is a wonderful free audio guide that describes the rooms and the important art pieces in an interesting and often entertaining way. The museum is small enough that you can get an overview of all the galleries in one visit without becoming exhausted or overwhelmed. We highly recommend it!

Go Sunday Morning. Sunday morning is pay what you'd like. Since I only had an hour, and that is all I cared to spend in the museum it was a great deal. Interesting artwork and place to visit. Some nice paintings. Worth a stop.
Delightful. Unbelievable how many big names they have on display. Truly an unforgettable experience. Costs a fair bit but is definitely worth dipping into your pocket for

Hidden Gem. A lovely museum. Went with a friend who is a member, as we were able to bypass line to see "The Goldfinch", which was part of a Dutch masters exhibit. The permanent collection is beautiful. Thanks Mr. Frick for being a robber baron and collecting all that nice swag to display in such a grand home!
Spectacular!. Great art in a unique and wonderful setting. I can't wait to return. I liked the audio tour, and I focused most on the entries for the rooms.

My Favorite Gallery in the Whole World. The Frick is the best. It has a wonderful ambiance and you just feel better after a visit. I try to go every time I go to New York. The paintings are pleasing and the gallery feels like you have been invited to walk through Mr Frick's home rather than a gallery. Everything is beautiful and calming with pleasant and personal paintings all around you. No disturbing or challenging art, just honest to goodness beauty. I love it.
Extraordinary Collection. an eclectic collection of extraordinary art compiled by one individual. All our European friends tell us it is the best private collection in the world. I agree
Intimate and a pleasure. This is a small museum in one of the great old mansions of the past. The collection is superb but refined. Don't expect to find Jackson Pollock here.

Great works of art. The Frick has an amazing collection of work from some of the great artists known to the art world. The rooms are arranged very well so walking through the Frick flows very nicely. Not a large collection but a good sized collection of great pieces.

Not as good as I was expecting. I was really excited to visit the Frick Collection after reading a brochure about it being a real mansion from the Gilded Age filled with priceless artistic treasures but I felt a bit let down from my experience there. Don't get me wrong: it is indeed a beautiful building and some of the art on display is amazing beyond words. I just felt a bit underwhelmed by the sparsely filled galleries and that the art on display was not always particularly impressive. I also don't understand why the Met allows picture taking when it has so much more on offer yet the Frick does not. I am glad I visited this museum, but I feel my visit to the Met was a much better investment of time and money.
Magnificent collection. housed in the mansion of Henry Clay Frick, this is a do not miss experience for lovers of art. Blissful.
Ok but not the best part of the trip. My wife and I were looking forward to the collection but it was not that great. Would recommend some of the other museums first.

Absolutely Stunning Once Again. On this my second visit to the Frick I brought my wife (my youngest son joined me the first time). Since my wife and I are Art Gallery of Ontario members we got in free and skipped the line. There was a line as there was a special Vermeer exhibit. We saw that exhibit and the "regular" collection. This is an absolutely stunning mansion filled to the rafters with priceless masterpieces. This is a must visit while in NYC especially for AGO members.

If your NYC time is limited, best museum to see maximum masterpieces. It's great to go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. You can easily spend a couple of days wandering through its immense collection. The Frick is much smaller, but every piece is a masterpiece. You will recognize most of the artists by name. They come from all periods and many different countries. Since it is a museum in a home, the decorative arts are also excellent and well displayed. Take the 4/5/6 train to the 68th street stop; go 2 blocks north and 2 blocks west over to 5th avenue. This museum is designed for those that have only enough time to fit in 2 or 3 hours.

Interesting insight into the life of Henry Frick. We visited the frick collection on a cold day in February based largely on the reviews on tripadvisor. The house was beautiful to stroll about for an hour or two and the video presentation provided interesting insight into the life of the 19th century wealthy American. The collection itself is largely portraiture and renaissance art which is great if you like that kind of thing. I enjoyed looking at the small collection of clocks and admiring the furniture placed around the museum all of which were beautifully presented and immaculately preserved. I give this an average rating as although the house is lovely to wander around, I thought that for the relatively short amount of time I spent there it would be quite an expensive trip at full price ($20). However, as a student the entry of $10 was far more reasonable, but at full price I would have been disappointed. Compared to other attractions in nyc (such as the Met) you definitely get more for your money elsewhere. From the reviews I did expect a little more.In summary, the house and collection are lovely if you have the money to spare, but I would choose to brave the enormity of the Met for a day (or more) instead.

An Amazing Collection. The Frick collection was our favourite Museum / collection that we saw in New York. The beautiful historic home that it is housed in gives you an insight into life for the wealthy in New York at the turn of the century.All the greats are here, Turner, Van Dyke, Van Gogh, Monet, Bellini, Boucher and so many more. It's unbelievable to think that this was a private collection. It's not crowded like the bigger galleries, the setting being much more intimate. There are some very beautiful bronzes and furniture on display too as well as an interesting display of old clocks.A must do on your visit to New York.

One of the highlites of our trip. We visited MOMA, Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Frick. Didn't much care for MOMA, but had to see the impressionists. Metropolitan is a must do. The Frick is a really, really, really should do museum. Small, cozy, friendly environment, great collection.

Very interesting building, history and art works. An intersting building with a range of art works beautifully displayed. We were asmazed at all the treasures in the collection!The indoor garden area was unusual and the audio guides helpful.
Worth a visit. Good collection, girl with the pearl earing was there at out visit . Great indoor garden, big queues however. Go early to avoid the crowds

My favorite museum in NYC. Wonderful collection which is in the previous home of Henry Frick. Went the Metropolitan Museum of Art the next day and realized what a gem the Frick is. if you only have 2 hour, THIS is the museum to pick!

A Gem Hidden on 5th Avenue. A gem in NYC, nestled away on 5th Avenue not far from the Met.If you don't have time to go round the Met (which is as big as it is brilliant!) then the Frick is a very good alternative. Based on one floor and in only in a few rooms, there very few places in the world that hold as many masters in such a small area. Pictures are housed in a classic space (albeit the benefactors ex-home) they range from Whistler to Gainsborough to Rembrandt to Turner within a just a few steps. For those who like art, it is a true spectacle. For those not so keen, it is a great way to see the classics in a small space without surrendering too much of your time. For those with kids (over 10 I think it is) it is a great introduction for them without the inevitable boredom slipping in. At $20 it's a bargain.
A gem. make time for this - I always do. It houses the very best examples - including three Vermeers! The audio guide is worth using; comes FOC.
Alot of famous Art for a private collection. Very interesting to visit. Frick bill a great mansion in Manhattan and it was neat to see as well as his art collection which was quite extensive.
Less-traveled house museum. Wonderful collection of art, and made me feel like Edith Wharton gliding through the rooms. Sunday 11-1 is pay as you will.

The Goldfinch, Dutch Masters and more. This exhibit is over now, but it was a special treat. The Frick is my favorite museum/collection/venue. It houses a vast collection of significant art and sculpture on the first floor of the Frick mansion. The mansion is well-preserved and the fountain garden is a peaceful place to sit and digest the wonderful art and rooms. I've been coming here for many years and I will always steer my out-of-town friends to the Frick for a morning or afternoon shot of art.

Well worth the time. This was our third trip to New York and we'd never been to the Frick (to be honest, we didn't even know it was here!) So this time around, having seen how popular is was, we decided to give it a try.There's plenty of "wow" to be had in the Frick. The highlights for us were certainly the exquisite enamels together on one room and Holbein's Cromwell and More facing each other across a fireplace.The audio guide is well written and interesting with no Disney-esque cheese.

Great way to spend an afternoon. From all the gigantic Gainsboroughs to just the splendor of the home, the Frick Collection is well worth the $20 entry. I was blown away by how the collection is laid out and also how friendly the docets were.They also had on loan, a fantastic collection of bronzes from the renaissance era, including a great video on how they were created back then.

Great Art Work in Beautiful Setting. The mansion is incredible. Art is beautifully housed in inviting rooms. We visited with three 18 year olds who loved the museum. You can visit for 1-3 hours and see everything. The indoor garden court is so peaceful that you can easily sit there for hours.

An oasis of calm and culture. This accessible gallery is easy to visit - very close to The Met and not too far from the Guggenheim. A lot of the art work is familiar and the audio guide means that y can make your own way around the gallery, at your own pace and concentrating on those pieces that you find most interesting. It was not too crowded and just provided a welcome respite from the madness that is NYC.

Can you believe this was someone's house. The Frick is one of my favorites. Don't miss the blue marble table. Just ask and a guard will point you to it. The Vermeers are of course amazing. And just remember, this was one persons house.
