A very special museum, not to be missed!. Great collection of paintings in an amazing house of history!I would highly recommend reading the book to get a better sense of what this house isAll about. I loved seeing the Whistlers and Vermeers.

Great Museum!!. I have to say I really enjoyed the Frick Collection. The collection is amazing but the fact that it was home really blows me away. I enjoyed the fact that they have a pay with you wish on Sunday mornings. It was a great experience.
Beautiful. If you want see great art in a beautiful place (home) and you don't want to be overwhelmed by the size of the place (e.g. the MET) this the place to go.
Unique in the world. The art is superior and you feel as in a private home of a wealty art patron...near the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Guggenheim as well.

Surrounded by Beauty. We visited the Frick when it opened on Sunday morning. The fairly long line was taken care of quite quickly. I'd recommend checking your coat so that you can relax and enjoy the stroll through the full range of paintings and assorted objects d'art.Manet, Monet, Gainsborough, Degas, Whistler - to name just a few - you get a glimpse into how the very elite lived, in a time that has passed, but at The Frick, has been beautifully preserved.To get the most out of the tour, audio sets are suggested.
Pay what you like on Sunday, 11-1. loved the self-guided tour...you can listen to commentary on the paintings that interest you and skip the others.

Don't miss it while in NYC!. With a pay what you will incentive in Sundays between 11am and 1pm there's really no reason not to visit this beautiful gallery. I had a lovely time strolling around and enjoying the wonderful art on display, particularly the Fragonard room which was such a treat.

Meet Henry Frick. Very informative, organized, uncrowded with plenty of space to stand state and wander leisurely. Viewing Fricks collection in his home, war and religious pieces heavily, coupled with the pre-viewing videos, imparts a feeling of knowing Henry Frick personally. A well done attraction.

Incredible estate... I have gone to NY many times and this was my first time at thee Frick....I will go back. I loved it. Loved the mansion itself and the head set really was full of interesting tidbits. Too much to absorb in one visit....this museum warrants multiple visits!
Great space...small collection. Really beautiful space, but the art is not that exciting. Still worth going if only to pretend that you are Mrs. Frick and this is your house.
Entertaining oppulence.... Lavish pad is itself worth the visit. The collections are icing to the cake. Diversity of objects de art is engrossing.

A NYC must see!. A gem of a house with a magnificent garden, filled with wonderful furniture and exquisite artwork! What a lovely surprise. The intimate setting makes the visit highly enjoyable and worthwhile. I highly recommend a visit.
Ab Fab. It's the former owners' place in the City. It contains art masterworks. It's a view of how the .1% of 100 years ago lived. Do it.
Visit to the Guilded Age. The Frick is small by when compared to some other museums. However, the collection is outstanding and the building alone is worth the visit.
Beautiful gallery with great classic paintings. Paradise on Fifth Avenue. Enjoy the wonderful paintings then take a walk in Central Park across the street to absorb what you just experienced.

Another gem. We went to see the Girl with the Pearl Earring, and it was indeed crowded. My Canadian friend who was visiting joined the Frick via her cellphone to ensure that we could get in to see this show. The museum is small and has lovely courtyards and corners to sit down and admire the paintings. The rooms are beautifully kept, and the docents helpful. It is nice to get the experience of a private mansion and see how art was incorporated into the home by those wealthy people back in those days.

Visited for Masterpieces of Dutch Painting. We visited to see the Masterpieces of Dutch Painting from the Mauritshuis, but stuck around to explore the permanent collection. Thank goodness we reserved our tickets to the exhibit online, because it was a cold day and the line up outside was hours long. There was also a line up inside, but at least it wrapped around a peaceful inner oasis completed with a pond.The Mauritshuis paintings were a treat, especially the presentation of Girl with a Pearl Earring. The museum's own collection of Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals paintings is equally outstanding, along with its wonderful Turner landscapes. One room that was particularly interesting was the collection of early French time pieces. While the staff working the Mauritshuis exhibit were harried and rude, almost to be expected considering the crowds (thought rudeness is never excusable), the ones working with the clocks and watches were friendly and clearly quite proud of the cool items on display. Many of the rooms in the museum were fun to explore in an effort to imagine what they were like when the Frick family lived there, especially the highly decorated nursery.
Often overlooked art museum. Great art work. Often heard about art but rarely seen. It has one of the original Gilbert Washington portraits.

Great art, great setting.. We have been going to the Frick for a very very long time. This former home of Henry Frick it offers the chance not only to see some great art but a peek at life on Fifth Avenue at the turn of the 19th century. Highlights include the Vermeers, the Turners and the Rembrandts, but surprises abound Holbein's portraits of Thomas Cromwell and Sir Thomas More are hardly the least. The recently closed special exhibit of Vermeer - Girl with the Pearl Earring and some of the greatest Dutch art are an example of the treats one can find in this manageably sized museum.It is a don't miss in New York.

A gem of a museum. The Frick is a gem. Small, personal and with a fabulous cross section of art (mostly western). The audio that comes free with admission is particularly well done and includes a history of the Frick family and how the various rooms were used when the family lived there.

The Frick Collection - opulence and style. I had never been to the Frick before. There are two Holbeins (Thomas Cromwell and Sir Thomas Moore) that should draw anyone who has been reading Hilary Mantel's recent novels. They are either side of the mantelpiece, separated cleverly by El Greco's St Jerome. The rest is worth seeing - the art ranges from the excellent - Bastiani, Filippi, Memling, three (or two) Rembrandts and much more, but also schlock cheesecake by Boucher and Fragonard. The building itself is superb and the room full of Whistler portraits is almost worht the trip to NY in itself.

Wonderful Museum. I saw 'The Girl With the Pearl Earring' a few weeks ago which was wonderful. The Museum normally is one of the less crowded ones but it was busy for that exhibit. Its always a treat to go there even when there isn't a special exhibit. I love the Atrium - so quiet and relaxing.

Gorgeous, intimate art collection. The Frick houses a world class art collection within an intimate, comfortable mansion. It is usually not too crowded, giving you time to enjoy the art work.The mansion itself is a work of art too. Enjoy a couple hours here while in New York.
rare artifacts. I have been to NYC many times but finally made it to the Frick...a must see. Worth the entrance fee.

Always worth your time. This beautiful gem has become a favorite haunt of mine in the City. The collection has so many notable and fine elements in painting, porcelain and sculpture. One of the very special treats is having a docent on hand in each room who has special knowledge of the pieces and who is just dying for you to ask him/her about them. It is like having your very own guide who is there just to educate you on all you ever wanted to know and then some about Sevres porcelain potpourris or seascapes by Turner.I highly recommend a visit even if you have only a short while to spend. Have a seat in the main gallery and visit the Rembrandt , the Vermeers and so many other masterful works.

A surprising gem. I lived in New York for years before I visited the Frick - and regret not going sooner! The collection is beautiful but equally as impressive is the space itself. It feels like someone's home with an amazing courtyard in the center. It's a lovely place to walk around and look and also to sit and take it all in. Sunday is pay-what-you-wish morning!
Wonderful. A quiet and enthralling place to spend an afternoon amongst a fantastic collection of art and architecture
beautiful museum. We went there during the Mauritshaus exhibit. That was out of this world. But the rest of the museum was so beautiful. I love the way the art was displayed

An Exellent Collection in a Beautiful Setting. I had not been back to the Frick in over 30 years, so it was like seeing it for the first time. The collection represents a history of European painting housed in an elegant mansion. The best part is that you can easily see the entire collection in an hour and a half. We went during the Sunday morning "pay as you wish" entrance fees, so it was a bit crowded but not so much that it interfered with our enjoyment of the art works (and there was no wait to enter). The regular admission price is $20, which some may consider a bit steep, but when you consider the quality and range of the art works, it is worth it. All of the masters are here: Rembrandt, Vermeer, Hals, Titian, Gainsborough, El Greco, Goya, Boucher, Watteau, Turner, Constable and many others. For those (like me) who were disappointed to miss the recent show with Vermeer's "Girl with a Pearl Earring," you can be comforted by the fact that the Frick has three Vermeers on permanent display, including "Officer and Laughing Girl" (which far exceeds "Girl with a Pearl Earring" in my humble opinion). Mr. Frick didn't collect many Impressionists, so if you are looking for those, you will be disappointed, but the few Corots and the one Renoir and one Monet are very fine indeed. When we visited last weekend (January 26th), the room with the Whistlers was closed for an installation, but that did not detract from our enjoyment of the museum.The complimentary audio guide is highly recommended. Nearly each painting has a commentary on the audio guide, so you can stop and listen to excellent (but not interminable) commentary as often as you wish.In addition to the paintings, there are also bronze sculptures and decorative arts, such as furniture and porcelain vases and, at the moment, a special exhibit of clocks, on display.This was a very pleasant way to spend an hour and a half on a Sunday morning. You will probably have it all to yourself on a weekday. Highly recommended.

Nice collection!. I went on a Sunday morning during "pay what you wish" hours. I was disappointed that the "Girl with the Pearl Earring" was no longer there - mix-up on my part with the dates I guess. Anyway, I as impressed with the house and the architecture, and there were many amazing pieces of art on display. I was disappointed that some areas of the house were temporarily closed for setting up a new exhibit, so I felt that I was not getting the full experience. So I'm glad I went during "pay what you wish" hours. Works by many of the greats are on display. The staff seemed a little overly surly to me, not friendly at all - they came across to me more like prison wardens & guards, though it must be trying to spend you day telling people "no photos". I don't really get the "no photo" rules, particularly given that just about everybody these days has a camera on their cell phone, and despite the rule, many photos were taken. But I digress - the museum was nice, and the house & architecture are as impressive as the art work. An hour and a half was plenty of time for my visit.

Dutch Masters & Frick Collection. Holiday culture seekers lined up outside the doors and snaked around the corner and down Fifth Avenue. We had made reservations in advance and swanned in to enjoy Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring, The Goldfinch, Rembrandts, etc., in a tight, small exhibition. We then wandered through the permanent collections in this beautiful mansion. It was a true treat!
Wonderful gem of a museum. We saw the Dutch masters exhibit and then continued through the other galleries. The collection is remarkable, with a masterwork (or several) at every turn.
Immerse Yourself in Grand Art. Well worth two to three hours. Be sure to get the complimentary audio tour player. Old masters galore with small bronzes and a few specialty collections.

Beautiful House and Museum. This museum presents many different art forms including paintings, furniture, silverware, bronzes and more. It is a gorgeous home of one of the Robber Barons who built the US. The museum offers free audio tours with the admission price which I found very helpful and informative. Will visit again.

This is an insight to the life of the 85 folks that control half of the worlds wealth.. Beautiful collection of fine art preserved in the beautiful mansion. Much of the house was blocked off under re- construction the January day we were there.Memorable quote of Mr. Frick steel coal and oil baron "if it is so hard for a rich man to enter the gates of heaven, how much harder it must be for a poor man". However god must have loved the poor he made so many of them, author unknown.Very stimulating, very educational and well worth theinvestment. One could return again and again.The art is amazingly incredible.
Museum in a mansion. This wonderful museum is housed in a mansion of a former steel tycoon, which makes the viewing of the impressive collection of artwork even more enjoyable.

Spectacular. As a native New Yorker I'm so sorry I never visited this spectacular collection and mansion sooner. The recent Rembrandt, Vermeer and Hals exhibit, and visiting family's desire to see it, finally brought me here this month. I've wanted to see "The Girl with the Pearl Earring" but never knew when I was going to make it back to Holland. One word of advice at any museum with a very desirable exhibit: pre-order timed tickets (if possible) OR get on line early!! The Frick is my new favorite museum....well, maybe after The Met's Cloister!!! The former home of art collect Henry Frick is a gem in itself: the outside garden; the inside courtyard with fountain; the stairwell with built-in organ; the exquisite furniture and decorative artwork....though, I'm sure, plenty come just to see the oil pantings and sculpture!It's a must see!!

What a gem. We are art lovers and have visited many of the US and European major collections. My wife visited NYC earlier with friends to see Vermeer's Girl with Pearl Earring and recommended that I accompany her in a return visit. We had to wait in a queue 1.5 h in the rain to get in, but it was well worth it, both for the Hague traveling exhibit, but also for Frick's main collection. I was very impressed by the choices he and his advisors made in selecting the works for his home, particularly the 17th-19th century works. Awesome. The audio tour was excellent and is available in one of the books available. Having lumbar problems, my only complaint is that there is not enough seating provided the leg weary for rest or sustained contemplation of the fantastic art on the walls.

I live Frick!. This museum is perfect for those who want to experience art, design, history and architecture in one beautiful space reasonably quickly and very atmospherically. In other words, for those who want to see a lot of New York without being caught up in museums all day this is the perfect attraction! My children who were 14 and 15 enjoyed the variation of culture offered here. The audio is fantastic and recommended for an enlightening story about the industrialist Henry Frick and his amazing purchases. The museum, a former home, transports you back in time and was picture perfect with snow falling and lovely views over Central Park.

Europe in New York City. Despite the long lines to get in especially during the holiday season it was well worth the wait. This is like walking into a palace in Europe, stepping back in time to an amazing personal collection. It is in the Frick Mansion, and not only do you get to see famous and amazing art, but also the furniture and architecture of the mansion which is completely european influenced. Its amazing to think these mansions used to be someones residence right on 5th opposite central park.

A New York City Treasure. Our group visited the Frick Collection to see the exhibit of Dutch Masters, including The Girl with the Pearl Earring. The exhibit was excellent but it is worth the trip to see the magnificent museum itself and its permanent collection. Don't miss the film about the history of the house.

Cold Wait, But Worth It. We had to stand in line, outside in sub freezing weather to get tickets. Next time we'd do this online ahead of time. The centerpiece of the collection was the The Girl With The Pearl Earring. There were a lot of people there, but it was not crowded.

A jewel in the NYC museum crown.. Wonderful art, architecture and furniture. Always a joy to visit the Frick. Was just there for the Vermeer exhibit and even though it was so busy, it was still a joy to have time with the paintings and the surroundings. I always recommend it to out-of-town visitors.

Fine Vermeer Exhibit of "The Girl with the Pearl Earing.. Managed to see the Vermeer "Girl with a Pearl Earing" along with some Rembrandts and other notable paintings in this Museum. This painting is simply amazing. Very enjoyable museum and took time to see the permanent collection as well

Dutch Masters was awesome!!. This was my second visit to the Frick Collection, and I planned my recent trip to NYC to catch the Dutch Masters exhibit before it closed. I had just finished the book "The Goldfinch" and reread "Girl with a Pearl Earring" before I went, so seeing those two paintings was a real treat. It was VERY crowded, but the staff at the museum did a great job of moving us into the exhibit area very well. I enjoyed being able to go back and forth between the various rooms to revisit some of my favorite pieces based on how the crowds were moving. This is a beautiful museum and worth a visit at any time you are in New York.
Expensive and a tad disappointing. I was hoping to see more of the beautiful home, but many spaces were blocked to the public eye. Still a good experience.

Vermeer, Vermeer. I have rarely been to the Frick, and I must admit that as I have grown to establish a personal appreciation for art history, the Gilded Age is not one of my favorites. But to separate the mansion from the collection, and to see a few of the great works, feel their place in the western world is very satisfying to me.The occasion of the Dutch Masters exhibit and the Girl with a Pearl drew great attention to the three Vermeers resident at The Frick. I wish they would hang together for a very long time. And of course, the timing of the new novel and the presence of "The Goldfinch" is a spectacular alignment!But the Masters are gone and now we have The Frick permanent collection to enjoy until another exhibit entices us.
I hear that it is great. But the line went all around the block!! at least a hour wait and it was cold so we missed it but we understand that if you go about 5:15 pm there is usually no line

Always a delight. I'm always pleased with the intimacy of the Frick Collection. Even with the "Girl with the Pearl Earring" and "The Goldfinch" being surrounded by novel readers, it was easy to see everything and the museum looks terrific. We visited the other Vermeers and the Bellini "Ecstasy of St. Francis" and just enjoyed the pleasure of leisurely art looking.

the Frick....forgotten gem. In NYC with MOMA, the Met, Guggenheim...it's easy to forget about the Frick.Went there for the Dutch Masters exhibit. Girl with a Pearl Earring, the Goldfinch, couple of Rembrandt's....nothing special :)Great little exhibit. But also reminded me of how nice this museum is. Manageable in a couple of hours. Typically not crowded, but for this exhibit it was.Worth checking out.

Vermeers to die for !. This is the place to go for Vermeer. The Holbiens were fun to see if you've been reading Hilary Mantel's Cromwell historical novels. It was very busy, but organized. I would like to return on a quieter day.

Don't miss this Museum. I'm embarrassed to say that this is my first time to the Frick and I grew up in NYC. We didn't see the Vermeer special exhibit, but we did tour the regular collection and the time piece exhibit. There is NOT a nicer or more intimate museum in NYC and I can't believe it's not on everyone's list. This is Mr. Frick's home and one room is more incredible than the next. From incredible Vermeers to Rembrandt's, you can feel like you are living with these pieces in your living room. I will make sure to visit every time I'm in NYC as it's almost hard to take in all the great paintings in one sitting. The time exhibit was fantastic as well especially the Breguet pieces....
Vermeers!. Yes, more than one. Gorgeous museum. The perfect size place, without feeling overwhelmed. All the wonderful art is worth the trip.

Vermeer. Girl with Pearl Earring and Goldfinch on loan were a sight to behold. If you become a member for a small fee you don't have to wait in line around the block on busy days. Suggest checking coat, gets hot inside.

An absolute must. Make sure you book well before you are due to go or you will be standing outside in a long line. This is a wonderful museum and I would go again tomorrow. I realise that the exhibition that included The girl with the pearl ear-ring and The Goldfinch was near to closing so this may have influenced the line.

Vermeer and the Frick. Don't fret if you miss the big Vermeer exhibition. The Frick owns three lovely Vermeers. This has always been one of my favorite museums. It is the right size, not overwhelming, and whoever advised Henry Clay Frick about his purchases was great.

A Glimpse into an Opulant Life. The Frick Museum set in an old mansion facing the Park is situated in a beautiful location. Indoors, everything is lovely. The indoor fountain, the paintings, the set up are beautiful. It takes around 2 hours to get through it at a leisurely pace and you can just relax and soak up the ambience. So if you appreciate art, beautiful interiors and architecture, its a great way to spend a few hours. You can imagine yourself in a past luxurious lifestyle.But its definitely not a place for kids!

Girl with Pearl Earring Tour GREAT!. First time at the FRICK and joined to see THE GIRL WITH PEARL EARRING TOUR. It was great but the FRICK was even better. Glad the tour got me to learn more about this beautiful place.

My favorite museum in NYC. I have been to the Frick numerous times over the last 50 years. It is a beautiful building and it is a small enough museum to be fully enjoyed in 2-3 hours. It is not nearly as ponderous as the Met, but given its size has some wonderful collections. My personal favorite work is The Polish Rider.

not to miss. I would have loved to live in that house. With my girlfriend we played at imagining how we would arrange the house, and actually there is not much to change. Mr. Frick and his wife and daughter did a pretty good job. Perfect location, facing the park. On a smaller scale than the big museums. A very pleasant, but not tiring afternoon.

Really Beautiful. We are given a glimpse into the opulent history of the very wealthy. This mansion is beautifully preserved and it's furnishings are works of art as well. There is a media presentation that gives the story of how this museum came to be. With so many very famous paintings exhibited in a relatively small place expect it to be extremely crowded. It is helpful that the staff are friendly and helpful.

Fabulous Gem - Not to be missed. If you going to New York and looking to go beyond the obvious collections at the Met and MOMA - then the Frick is a must include. This is an astounding collection including Vermeer, Gainsborough; Turner; Holbein – the list is endless. But what is the most wonderful find is the pleasant atmosphere of the Frick Mansion that houses the collection. Every room is designed around the art, sculpture and artefacts contained within it. The residence and the collection you will love them both!

Totally Blown Away. This was my first visit to the Frick. My wife had visited once about 40 years ago. We wanted to see the Dutch Masters of the Mauritshuis, including the Girl With The Pearl Earring, before the exhibit was closed. We had seen the Girl With The Pearl Earring twice before when it was on tour in the USA. The problem was that we could only visit on a weekend (and there were only 2 weekends remaining) and all of the timed tickets were sold out. We discovered that timed tickets were not necessary if you had a membership. We decided to bite the bullet and purchase an annual membership....essentially 3 times the cost of an individual ticket on a per person basis. The museum last Saturday opened at 10am. We arrived, after driving over 100 miles, at 9:50am. The line for the timed tickets was about two blocks long. The line for those with a membership....less than 1/2 block long. By 10:10am, we were actually inside. We spent the next 90 minutes in the two galleries of the paintings from the Mauritshuis. We spent close to twenty minutes just admiring the Girl With The Pearl Earring, and noticed a few details that we had forgotten. I liked EVERY PAINTING in these two galleries! When our viewing of the Mauritshuis paintings concluded, we decided to see the rest of the museum. We did not leave until 3:30pm (non-stop). We were pleasingly tired by then, and felt that we had accomplished something great. The remaining pieces in the Frick blew us away. Titian, El Greco, Goya, Holbein, Vermeer, Rembrandt, Turner, Renoir, Bellini, Cimabue, Martini, and Hals to name a few. What a world-class gem this is!!!! We expect to return when the crowds are back to normal. We expect to talk about this journey for years to come.

Girl with the Pearl Earring. This museum is probably a little less known than the big guns in New York but who else has three permanent Vermeers of the 34 known to exist? The "Girl" is visiting from The Hague and this of course made the place very crowded as it is one of the most beautiful paintings in the world. I imagine a visit after she leaves will be much more calm.

Lovely gilded age house holds some real gems. It's a beautiful house evocative of New York's gilded age. Beautiful proportions, luxurious decorations and amazing paintings. The Titian of a young man is gorgeous, and the Holbeins of Thomas Cromwell and Thomas More are mesmerizing. The interior courtyard with pool and fountain is one of the most peaceful rooms in the city. Unless you're there during the Vermeer show, in which case all bets are off -- it's a zoo. Though seeing the Girl with the Pearl Earring is worth it. But go back when the exhibit is over to experience the real Frick.

What a Gem. The museum, which is the former Frick mansion, has an incredible permanent collection. Mostly old master, but Mr. Frick and more recently his daughter had excellent eyes for art. Many of the pieces were hung as he had originally hung them, so you get a real sense of what he was trying to do. We were also there to see the special Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals exhibit - absolutely incredible!

Get to the Frick by 8.45 to be first in line for the Mauritshuis exhibition. We finally saw the Mauritshuis exhibition today after an aborted attempt on Saturday due to the cold and the length of the line. So, the question on many peoples lips on Saturday was what time do you need to turn up to queue if you want to get in at the 10am opening time? Today we arrived at 8.50am and were 6th in line. We walked into the exhibition at about 10.10am.Once inside you are ushered to get tickets ($20 adults, $10 students) and then shown the way directly to the Mauritshuis exhibition which is shown in two beautifully laid out rooms. The star exhibits are Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring and The Goldfinch (courtesy of Donna Tartt's recently released novel of the same name). The Vermeer is in its own room and is absolutely stunning. The Dutch Mona Lisa. This is a very small exhibition so once you've seen that then you must continue on to the rest of the amazing collection in the Frick. Turners, Gainsboroughs, Constables, Hans Holbien, three more Vermeers, Renoir, Monet - the list goes on - all in a beautiful turn of the century mansion.You cannot miss this on your visit to NYC.

The Frick Forever. The Frick is a model museum, with a star exhibit of Vermeers and other Dutch masters topping up a priceless permanent exhibit in a jewel of a mansion. I especially love the Fragonard room showing the "stages of love". A museum to come back to every year.

Mauritshuis and the Frick. The Mauritshuis museum is located in a lovely 17th century mansion in The Hague and contains some of the treasures of Dutch art. The spare collection of Hals, Rembrandt and Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring on exhibition at the Frick Collection by itself is compelling but perhaps a bit underwhelming after waiting in line for over an hour outside in the freezing cold. The real genius of the exhibit is the kinship between the Mauritshuis collection and the Frick permanent collection. The Mauritshuis works offer the perfect complement which allows the permanent collection of Dutch art, including TWO incredible Vermeers, to shine.The Frick itself is one of New York's greatest art museums, but that is not the only reason why it is unique. The mansion itself is one of the only ones left of its kind: those constructed by Gilded Age millionaires who sought to emulate the European aristocrats of the ancien regime. The result is a collection of art on par with that of a European great home, curated and displayed as the Fricks would have done while living in their extravagant home with its imported boiserie and grandfather clocks. And it is home to one of the most incredible portraits: Holbein's Sir Thomas More.If you are visiting the Met: why not pay a visit to the Frick? It's just down the street!

Best museum experience in NYC. The Frick Collection is the perfect collection to see in New York City for the most inexperienced to the most knowledgeable visitor with two hours to spare in a busy schedule. Try to take the time to view the informative film in the music room before viewing the extraordinary collection as you will appreciate the collector, Henry Clay Frick, and what makes this collection so special, even more. Over the years, I have taken many friends to the Frick on their first visit to the city. All, without exception, have told me that it was, by far, their favorite museum experience. There is something very special about the fact that this was the Frick home. In addition to the extraordinary collections, the peaceful atmosphere and decor offers insight to another time. On Sundays, you can pay what you wish from 11 AM - 1 PM. On my most recent visit, I purchased my ticket online and am glad that I did so I didn't have to waste time waiting in line when I got there... I find that when I go to the Frick during my all too few, very short, self-imposed breaks on my annual business trips to NYC, the rest of my time in the city is much less stressful. If you haven't been, go; if you have and went when it crowded, go earlier in the day. It is that special and definitely worth it.

Treasures from the Mauritshuis. Girl with a Pearl Earring and The Goldfinch among other great pictures on loan from the Netherlands. Very crowded on a Friday morning, supposed to be timed entrance, but it seemed they let in quite a few more so had to look at the pictures through crowds. Always a great place to visit, wonderful art, but the lighting is not good.

A Hidden Gem - Do Not Miss!. I am rewriting this review because I accidentally gave it 1 star instead of 5 on my initial review. The Frick Collection is recognized as a premier museum and is well known for it's extensive collection of Old Master paintings and many examples of European sculpture and decorative arts. It was assembled by Pittsburgh industrialist Henry Frick and is housed in his family's former residence on 5th Ave. It is a tranquil setting for visitors to experience masterpieces such as Bellini, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Goya and Whistler, quite a departure from large, crowded museums. The grounds and gardens are beautiful as well, and it was great to see fantastic art in this Golden Age Mansion from a former time!

Incredible art in great venue. Anyone who enjoys art should visit the Frick at least once. Located in Frick's residence, this small gallery has no 2nd tier pieces. Be sure to use the free audio guide which explain all the different pieces of art and the rooms they are housed in.You can view everything at a leisurely pace in just over 2 hours.

Magnificent !. You will probably never get so close to so much spectacular art. Fantastic museum, worth every cent. Make sure that if you take a coat you check it in-they will not allow you to carry them which sounds fine when you first go in but when you have realised how much there is to see and you are getting toasted then it is a pain in the ***! To imagine living in a house like this is to truly appreciate immense wealth and what it can offer. Unimaginable riches, words fail me. Even if you are not a huge Art Buff (and I'm not) it will knock your socks off! A must see of NYC

Amazing collection!. i went to see the special collection of Dutch masters but stayed to enjoy the truly remarkable private collection…just breathtaking. really liked the small nature of the museum--not too big and not too crowded.

Buy your tickets online. The Frick Collection is a must see for anyone who loves art or antiques.I recently visited the Frick Collection and made the mistake of not pre-purchasing my tickets online before visiting and as such waited 95 minutes to enter. I was willing to wait this long as I had heard how enjoyable the gallery was to visit.I thought that the queue could have been better managed. Those who pre-purchased their tickets online could bypass the queue and enter as those left. A better system would have been to make those people still wait but only for 1/2 the time that those in the regular queue had waited.The collection did not disappointed. Unfortunately my time in the queue evaporated some of the time I had hoped to use in viewing the collection. The traveling collection did have blurbs and descriptions with the paintings but the permanent collection did not which resulted in me buying a book from their store to learn more about the paintings.If you do plan to visit, don't be silly like me and buy your ticket online and print it out before you go.

Well worth the wait. Mr Frick was a very philanthropic gent. Moving from the mid west after a very successful career, he bought this land and constructed the Frick. The old boys intention was to collect Artwork HE liked, and display it in a manner HE liked in his home.He'd then spend time in each gallery of the house just admiring the pieces. He'd mad provision for the whole operation to be used as a gallery on his death ( with a proviso for his wife of course, and here it is today.Reasonably priced, a beautiful setting a captivation history.Allow 3 - 4 hours at least.

Really Special Permanent Collection. We went for the special exhibit of Vermeer and others from the Hague. It was crowded but worth it. We saw the Girl with the Pearl Earring and the Goldfinch and other Dutch works of art. However, the building itself is incredible, as is the history of the building. There is a brief film on the history. The permanent exhibit is wonderful (and includes three other Vermeers). Really nice place to visit. The staff are very accommodating.

Vermeer Special Exhibit + Permanent Collection. So happy that we were able to get to the Special Exhibit. And the Permanent collection is very interesting as well. The building is beautiful, staff helpful.

Must see for art lovers. The definitive 15th thru early 20th century European art collection in New york. Displayed beautifully in a late 19th century mansion on Fifth Avenue. Masters such as Rembrandt, Renoir, Bellini,Gainsborough,Hals ,Lawrence, Fragonard and too many others to list here. Uncrowded, unhurried private appreciation is major benefit of this fabulous treasure. Probably my favorite museum in the world. Do not miss.

Superb collection. While private art collections cannot rival the size and range of the finest national or municipal museums, when presented in their residential settings they can have a unique charm and intimacy. The superb collection assembled by Henry Frick, and which has been enlarged substantially after his death, is no exception. Housed in a beautiful New York City mansion, it includes numerous fine works of sculpture and French furniture as well as masterpieces of European painting. Special exhibitions frequently add to the splendour of the display of permanent works.
A Perfect Afternoon. If one were to select the perfect museum, this would be it. A superb collection in extraordinary surroundings. Go on a Winter Sunday and enjoy the garden court and the music.

Amazing venue and art collection. This was just down the road form where we were staying. The building is magnificent (previously a residence) and the rich artwork collection among the best we have seen. Not crowded.

See how a turn of the century millionaire lived. This magnificent home to Henry Clay Frick is a wonderful glimpse into how he lived and the fabulous art collection he amassed. It is amazing to stroll through rooms filled with treasured objects that make you feel you are a guest not a museum visitor. Due to this it is not suitable for children to visit. It also has special exhibitions that are always special.
DO NOT MISS. Beyond words!! Great art, Great architecture.Anyone who can- see Vermeer before the special exhibition ends (this weekend)!In any case the museum may be the best I've ever experienced.

My favored museum in NY. My most favored museum in NY. I have been here many times and love coming back. Collector had an excellent taste. The museum is small and can be viewed in a couple of hours. It’s not overwhelming and very romantic.

A>M>A>Z>I>N>G. Do not miss this Collection as it was amazing.We starting queuing one afternoon but it was so cold we gave up but went back when the queue was not so bad. My husband actually became a member and bought our tickets so we could get in quicker and it was definitely worth doing this.Make sure you put all your items in the clock room as it is free and the museum is hot and you are not allowed to even carry a scarf, you have to keep it on. Another tip is to use the toilet before you go as there are only 3 ladies toilets which is ridiculous with people queuing for over half an hour, something the Frick need to look at.Ensure you get the commentary headset as they are the best ones I have every used. Each picture, room, bronze, clock is labelled and you can go round and put the number in and listen at your own pace and for the items you want to hear about. This also means there is not great queues at the same picture.The Girl with the Pearl Earring was amazing as was the clock room. It was definitely the best thing we did in NY.

Exquisite Fine Arts Collection of Robber Baron Frick. Talk about the vanity of the wealthy. How about the zillion dollars worth of classical art collected by Henry Clay Frick? The same Mr. Frick who unleashed the Pinkertons on striking steal workers in Pittsburg before the turn of the century. Social commentary aside, this collection and the current show of Rembrandt, Vermeer and Hals is a must see for lovers of fine art and Dutch Masters in particular. Viewing THE GIRL WITH THE PEARL EARRING gave me the same sense of awe as the Mona Lisa in Paris or David in Florence.

Fabulous venue. This is gorgeous mansion in the east 70's near lots of other museums. The recent exhibit of "The Girl with the Pearl Earring" was a knockout. Certainly worth a visit for any art or architecture lover.

Extraordinary venue complements extraordinary art. The building itself is a work of art that almost overshadows the art collection. Architectural details, household artifacts recreate the feel of opulence from 100 years ago. The gardens and setting are unique. The period art collection is extensive, definitely get the audio tour free with admission.

Got Married Here. My wife and I love this museum so much that we got married here including wedding dinner/dance. We were just here in December 2013 to see the Vermeer exhibit, which attracted thousands --so the museum was a bit crowded. Past exhibitions have all been world-class. Try to come back on another day when it is quieter -- this "intimate" museum would make you feel like the place is your own personal museum, or if your imagination soars high enough, your mansion and your art collection. Bring your date, spouse, parents, your kids. After the museum, this most exclusive part of the Upper East Side offers a number of restaurants, small cafes (American, Italian, French) nearby for lunch, dinner, or coffee/tea. Ask "Siri" on your iPhone for suggestions.
Must see. Beautiful peek at the past wealth and grandeur of NYC old guard. Furniture, art and home design should not be missed.

Three Vermeers in residence, one visiting. This has been my favorite museum for many years - it's small enough in size to allow the visitor to take in the collection in a day, it's generally (except for the current traveling exhibit from the Mauritshuis) off-the-beaten tourist path, the environment is quite, comfortable and welcoming. The collection is stunningly beautiful, and restful. You feel at peace when you leave here.The Mauritshuis exhibit is presented simply, elegantly, and even at the height of tourist season in NYC, crowd control ensured that visitors could have a close-up, tranquil visit with the artwork on loan. Reserve tickets in advance (otherwise you'll wait on line in the coooold), or buy a museum membership and walk right in. The membership cost is not much more than the cost of tickets for the exhibit and you'll be supporting a lovely institution.The Frick is NOT for families with young kids - they do not admit kids under 10. Even then, you want to savor the experience and linger with the art. Neither my nor your kids are that precious :-)
Small beautiful museum. A beautiful small museum on the upper east side . We did end up standing in line to get in but it was Christmas week so there were many tourists .
A Must See. I have been here twice and it has impressed me even more on the second visit. Incredibly selection of art given the fact this was a private home.

Excellent pictures. The staff are a bit frazzled.. Loved the pictures in the permanent exhibition. We've seen them before but it's a wonderful group. Of the 15 paintings in the Special Exhibition, the Hals drinking/smoking picture was my favorite, as was the tonie. Still love The Lacemaker by Vermeer more than The Girl with Pearl Earring! But it was worth the short wait for members. The staff, many of whom were hired for this special exhibition, were rude on a heavily attended Sunday. (The admission was free from 11-1 Sunday so there was a very very long line for those who aren't members.) Not sure if it would be worth the 2 hour wait in line for me. But seeing the Frick at any time is definitely a beautiful experience.

A Great Art Collection In Fine Mansion. The Frick is often overlooked by visitors to New York focused on other larger, better know museums. However the Frick Mansion on 70th & 5th Ave houses a great and varied collection of manageable side wonderfully presented in a fine mansion.

Saw two of my favorite paintings. Saw Goldfinch and The Girl with the Pearl EArring. If you don't have tickets, go first thing in the morning. Very little wait. We tried the afternoon and the wait was terrible.

"Appalling Experience at the Frick". While the exhibit was phenomenal, the Frick Staff clearly showed no concern or respect for their patrons. Guests had to wait outside in bitter cold conditions with dangerous wind chill factors upwards of 2 hours to gain entrance to the museum. Time estimates given were grossly inaccurate (told 30 -45 minutes on the phone). Provisions should have been made for indoor waiting or outside heat lamps should have been provided. A displayed sign invited cold, frustrated guests to buy a Museum Membership for immediate entry. Many who could afford to buy the membership on the spot chose to do so and end their misery. Timed tickets (used at other large Art Museums around the country) would have helped with capacity issues and guests could have enjoyed other offerings as they awaited their time to view the main exhibit or arrived at the appointed time. This was unconscionable behavior on the part of the Frick and highlights the inability of this venue to handle an exhibition of this magnitude.
Girl with the Pearl Earring. Book tickets and go straight to the front of the long Queue. we enjoyed the art / objects on display.

Slice of NYC history. If you've ever wondered what it might have been like to be a titan of industry at the end of the 1800s, this is the place to find out. Henry Clay Frick was a giant in the coke and steel industries. The Frick Collection is housed in his former home, with all of his gorgeous furniture and personal art on display. You can walk airily through the rooms (which, incidentally, border on Central Park), pretending that you own all you survey, to get an idea of how good life really was for this ruthless businessman.What I loved about the Frick Collection was that it was completely do-able in an afternoon. The home is large and the collection extensive, but it's nothing like visiting the Metropolitan Museum of Art and feeling as though you'd need to spend a week there to even scratch the surface. After walking through all of the gorgeous rooms (except for the Oval Room, which was closed in anticipation of an installation of Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring - we just missed it!!), we sat daintily on a bench in the garden court, the fountains playing and the light filtering in from above.Audio tours are also available.

well worth a visit. we were lucky enough to catch the Dutch exhibition, and really enjoyed our visit.The only problem was its popularity, we had to make 2 trips there before succeeding in getting in! Definitely recommend pre-booking if possible.

A bad experience trying to get in to the Frick. I stood in the rain for 3 hours in the hope that I could get in to this famous Collection and see the Dutch Masters. I never got in. I am so disappointed that for those 3 hours no one from the Collection communicated as to why the long line wasn't moving and whether I would get in. On 2 occasions a Frick employee walked around with an umbrellla trying to sell membership to ensure instant entry. Eventually I left when another person ahead of me found out the problem was congestion in the cloak room where they were unable to handle the quantity of wet coats and umbrellas. This was a very disappointing experience for me. I felt as though the staff had no concern or consideration for the hundreds of people standing in the freezing cold and pouring rain. Everyone was exasperated that a museum could treat its potential patrons with so little regard by not communicating the wait time and what the problem was. Not good enough especially as they were closed Mondays and so I was unable to see at all as I then left NYC.

Entry to Frick a Nightmare!. This is a wonderful museum with a fabulous collection, which is currently exhibiting Dutch Masterpieces. However, getting into the museum for the Dutch show (and I assume other special exhibits) is horrendous!! I specifically flew to NYC to see the Dutch show, stood in line in the freezing cold for an hour without moving, then gave up. Tried again the next morning (once again in the freezing cold), waiting for over 2 hours, and when I finally reached the front of the line entry just stopped. Waited another 40 minutes without moving while I watched museum attendants busying themselves selling memberships to the people in line as a way to get in right away. Definitely a sleezy, money grubbing tactic by the museum to take a advantage of a bad situation. I finally had to leave to catch a flight back home - a complete waste of time and money.

Frick Collection. The Frick Collection is one of my favorite museums in New York. Located on the corner of Fifth Avenue and E. 70th Street, the collection is housed in an old mansion. The permanent collection has masterpieces by Bellini, David, van Dyke, Gainsborough, El Greco, Manet, Renoir, Rubens, Titian and many others. It also has an extensive sculpture and porcelain collection.Currently, they have a special exhibit. The Masterpieces of the Dutch Mauritshuis. On display are works by Rembrandt, Vermeer, and other Dutch Masters.
Beautiful building, beautiful works of art. THe building itself is a surprise - especially given it is located right on Fifth Avenue.That art collection is a must see.

Favorite museum, plus a fabulous show. I've always loved the Frick, and the Maurietshuis show was the icing on the cake. So wonderful to see Girl With a Pearl Earring and The Goldfinch up close. A perfect part of a perfect day.
A must visit.. The mansion, it's history and the art collection are fabulous. The staff are knowledgeable and are eager to answer questions. I would visit again.

An Unforgettable Experience. Just across from Central Park, you can imagine the life of the Frick family back in the day when money was no object, and the world was their oyster. What I love about this collection is how personal the rooms are and they just happen to be filled with old masterpieces by the likes of Renoir, Rembrant, Vermeer, Turner, Constable and the many others that "spoke" to the collector. Many of the works seem sentimental, maybe souvenirs from time spent abroad. Take note of the exceptional upholstered chairs and sofas in the rooms. Some of the embroidery on these pieces rival the wall hung art. If you visit first thing Sunday 11:00 - 1:00, admission is pay what you want. Be prepared to line up.

Traveled to NYC just to see Vermeer. Beautiful art! Pre-purchase tickets as the lines go around the block if you don't buy ahead. Very crowded, but well worth the wait to see the wonderful Vermeers and all of the other art at this museum.

An oasis In the city. Can there be a better art experience in New York? Such a quiet place with a quiet respectable crowd there for the art. The short film on life of Henry Frick is worth 10 mins of your time for background to the home and collection. The Dutch masters exhibition filled with gems (but disappointing in its installation-not enough room for the works)

The Girl with the Pearl Earring. My partner has talked about The Frick being his favorite NYC museum for years and we just never had made a visit together. We got in on our recent visit and got to see Vemeer's Girl with the Pearl Earring, what a treat. This is a collection of classic European art mainly and well worth the visit. And to think this was someone's house once....ahhh, what a dream.

Comfortable. The Frick is comfortable museum to see a collection of a certain timeframe in a mansion that was purpose built to be converted to a museum after the owners death. A little crowded for a special exhibit.
Beautiful collection.. Great collection of XVIII and XIX C. european painting. The Vermeer´s are worth the visit. Very crowded.

Vermeer Exhibition. We decided to visit NYC mostly to see the Vermeer Exhibition at the Frick. The exhibition and beautiful museum did not disappoint. Loved the exhibit, some amazing pieces, of the The Girl With The Pearl Earring was stunning. The museum is well kept and timeless. Could spend hours just enjoying the mansion itself.
Frick Collection - Dutch masters. Lovely to see originals of Vermeer, Constable, Rembrandt etc. And in the setting of the house still as it was at the turn of the century.

A Forgotten Gem. How would you like to view art in an elegant mansion (palace) like in Europe? This museum provides a nice relaxing experience. I recently had an opportunity to see the Dutch painters' exhibit which was superb. Don't tell anyone, because the best kept secret in NY might be lost!

Excellent as always. Among the reasons for visiting New York the Frick Collection ranks high. To get in this time I found it expedient to join as a non-resident member, there being a long lineup this morning to see the selection of paintings from the Mauritshuis that has been on tour while their home gallery is being renovated and expanded. It was pleasing to see paintings from one of my top choices among galleries displayed in another of my favorite galleries. But the main point of going to the Frick is to see its own splendid collection. It is not to be missed.

Beautiful experience. We decided to go to the Frick after seeing all the Girl with the Pearl Earring posters. We loved the exhibit but actually found the rest of the museum equally appealing. It is a lovely mansion. The audio guide was very good. We didn't like the long line but it was our own fault. Had we bought tickets on line we would have gotten right in. Also it was good that they controlled the amount of people. It wasn't jammed pack like so many other institutions in New York at Christmas. I spent quite a bit of time here in college so glad for the opportunity to return many years later.

well perserved. It is a great place to see what it might have been like to be that kind of rich, then. The presentation of the place is open and comfortable. It is clean and neat. The art is of the finest in any museum.

Great Small Museum. Do you ever find that large museums are overwhelming? This place has some really great things to see if you like representational pictures. Some of the stuff struck me as aristocratic kitsch, but when you have Bellini's "St. Francis in the Desert" and several Vermeers, and a few Rembrandts in your collection, so what. We were also able to take advantage of their concert series which was reasonably priced and see the special exhibit from the Mauritshuis.

Goldfinch. After reading Donna Tartt's third novel, had to get to the Frick to see Fabritius' masterpiece tromp l'oeil. Did not disappoint. The tethered bird looks at you from his shelf, captive and plaintive. Lines to see this Dutch exhibition were around the block, but we thought it worth becoming members to get right in and support such a wonderful art collection. Vermeer's Girl with the Pearl Earring was there, too. But, Goldfinch was the reason to go.

Jewel of a Museum. We have rarely visited a museum with a greater number of treasures in a fairly small building. It is possible to see everything in just 2 or 3 hours and the paintings are truly masterpieces!

Wonderful!. Apart from the wonderful building this collection held two stunning paintings for me. The first was a surprise. I was not expecting to see Holbein's portrait of Thomas More, nor to be so taken aback by its beauty - a true masterpiece. The second was Vermeer's Girl with a pearl earring, which I found truly amazing in real life.
Girl with the Pearl Earring. Breathtaking! We came on a Friday during the holiday week so we waited quite a while to get in. Best bet is to buy a timed ticket ahead of time. Staff very attentive.

Wonderful way to spend an afternoon. Although this museum is along museum mile on 5th Avenue, it's less visited than some of the others. I enjoy museums that don't overwhelm the visitor and this fits that bill. The well laid out floor plan, diversity of objects displayed and wonderful special exhibits are just enough to satisfy. Avoid the Sunday free crowd which tends to be a cattle call.

A great collection, a wonderful house, a popular visit for our five teenagers. Travelling with five kids (teenagers) may be challenging: we have a hard time spending more than one hour within museums. But this visit to the Frick Collection was nevertheless among our highlights in New York: the collection is manageable, yet of impressive quality; and the house is an attraction in itself. Thus, I strongly recommend this visit!
Fantastic collection. It's a splendid collection and lovely surroundings. Love the layout of the place, as someone's house, the surroundings makes the collection feel even grander.

Jam packed and not too big to see in a day. Worth visiting just to wander through and see how the Fricks lived. The permanent collection is great, and the special exhibitions are usually quite good too.

Marvelous Museum. We saw the paintings on loan from the Mauritshuis (the Hague) and were thrilled to see the Vermeers, as well as so many others. The building itself is lovely, and we look forward to going there again and taking in more of the works displayed.

A small but perfectly formed museum. A must see.. A go-to museum in NYC. Extraordinary collection of mainly Renaissance art collected by an (in)famous 19th Century Robber Baron. A very clever exhibit (at the Frick) some years ago showed that Frick himself (actually his agents) had paid top dollar at the time for each of the pieces acquired. One always has a sense that he wrote the checks rather than chose the art. A better indeed almost perfect collection of Western art than the Wallace Collection in London but less authentic because of the nature of its creation.

Beautiful!. This may look like a small museum but be prepared to spend quite a number of hours here. The collection is extensive and we were fortunate enough to see the "Girl with a Pearl Earring" by Vermeer here. Book early and be prepared for queues.

Another Vermeer notch in my belt.. We went to see a travelling show of paintings by Hals, van Rijn, and Vermeer. These are paintings that are travelling the world during the renovation of the Mauritshaus museum in the Hague. We went specifically to see The Girl With the Pearl Earring by Vermeer. There are only 36 Vermeer's in the world (actually 35 until they recover the one stolen from the Gardiner in Boston). The Frick has three, the Met' Museum (4), the National Gallery (4), and one is on loan at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.. NO ONE PAINTS LIGHT AND SHADOWS LIKE VERMEER. This show won't be here long so now is the time. If you get a chance to visit the Louvre, don't waste your time at the Mona Lisa. Go see the Astronomer and the Lace Maker!

Should have discounted!. The is an amazing collection of works of famous artists! Sadly, we waited for 45 minutes in the freezing (25 degree) cold to get in, and the courtyard and music rooms were closed for an evening party. So we had to contend with the hustle and bustle of workers setting up and hauling equipment all around us. Seeing Vemeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring was a pleasure compared to the nightmarish scene at the Louvre, viewing the Mona Lisa. Pearl Girl was encased in a much clearer glass case, and the crowds were more controlled!
Mauritshuis collection. Go - see this exhibit. The most important paintings on loan here in NY. See the influence of Rembrandt on Fabritius who was Vermeer's teacher.

Great Art Museum. fantastic building and art collection. Saw cuurent Vermeer show and it was quite good. suggest youbgetbtickets ahead ad the line for ticketscwasbpretty long, tickets arec available on the web.

Art and artifacts in a domestic setting. The Frick has been open to the public since 1935. It was formally a home, but has been extensively expanded. It contains a major art collection in a very pleasant setting.

An absolute must when in town!. We booked this museum to see the Vermeer and Flemish masterpieces exhibition which is a small but special exhibition and it gave us the chance to view the exquisite permanent collection and the museum in its entire beauty. The space is well lit, beautifully arranged and the visitor gains a clear concept of the collected pieces of art. The explanatory documentary about the museum's history is brief but well researched and packed with data. The museum's size is also fairly contained so I would recommend to visit it to anyone even with a limited time.

The Frick, a Small Museum with a tremendous Collection in NYC. The Frick Collection, amassed by Henry Clay Frick and housed in his former mansion on Fifth Avenue in NYC, is one of my favorite small museums, filled with masterpieces of European painting, sculpture and decorative arts. As an art historian who specializes in European art, I can attest to the remarkable quality of the works Frick collected. Their are many highlights and strengths: 17th Century Dutch painting, including three Vermeers, numerous Rembrandts, and other Dutch masters; wonderful 18th and 19th century British and French works, and many other delights. On a recent visit to see the special exhibit of Dutch paintings from the Mauritshuis, we were delighted to view a special exhibition of 16th- 18th century clocks. When visiting NYC, Art lovers should not miss this gem if a small museum.
Don't miss. Some excellent pieces by the Dutch masters, as well as (unexpectedly) works by Velasquez and Goya. A fascinating insight into the lifestyle of the extremely rich.

Mauritshuis Collection. Currently, there is a special exhibit of paintings on loan from the Mauritshuis collection in the Hague. Included in the exhibit is Vermeer's painting of the girl with the pearl earring. This is a very popular exhibit which will be on until January 19. It is possible to book timed admissions through Telecharge, but with the snow storms, we were not sure we would actually make it to New York. We took a chance and vsited on a Thursday morning and only had to wait 10 minutes to get in without a reservation.It is an incredible exhibit. Plus the regular Frick collection of paintings, furniture and other art works is outstanding. It costs $20 at the door. If you book through Telecharge, there are additional fees. I highly recommend trying to see this special exhibit before it leaves.
Fabulous collection. Rivals most of the great homes in Europe.. The traveling exhibit of Dutch paintings should not be missed. The permanant collection of paintings and potery is also exquisit.

A gem. It is a gem of museum: so close to the famous Metropolitan Museum, it withstands comparison by being different. Frick collection is not overwhelming in size and can be explored without rushing from one room to another,and it is of supreme quality, I enjoyed visiting it several times, anticipating meeting familiar paintings as old acquaintances.

Very busy but well presented with great special exhibitions. The Frick Collection isn't technically on museum mile, but it definitely holds its own with the other more well known sites further north on fifth avenue. We were fortunate to arrive at a lull in entries, as our wait on line in the below-freezing cold was only about 2 minutes. The Flemish Old Masters exhibition from the Mauritshuis only needed two rooms, but the audio guide to supplement them was very comprehensive.The rest of the collection is eye-opening; so many iconic pieces that you would not have expected to be all in the one place. The Stuart portrait of George Washington, the Holbeins of both Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell and dozens of other spectacular classics. A great time definitely well worth the money for European art lovers in New York.

Beautiful NY museum--great collection.. Definitely visit if you have time and like classic art--great collection of Vermeer and Rembrandt complimented recent Girl w Pearl Earring show. Watch out for lines and reserve ahead or join for no lines.
Once is never enough with this museum. Try to go off peak hours, if there are any! The collection is at the top of any scale! The setting alone is worth visiting.

No trip to NY complete without a visit. Not a large museum but a place where everyone can find something of great quality and beauty to see. To think that one couple collected all these wonderful paintings, furniture, sculpture, china etc and then built a house just to hold it is rather wonderful.Do not go if you only love very modern art but go if you love everything else.

Frick Collection, an oasis of beauty. This is a great museum, not too many tourists go there, it is a great location on Fifth avenue at 70 Street, in a beautiful old mansion. The permanent collection is great, small but excellent, not overwhelming, and the visiting collections are wonderful.

Dutch Masters...Oh Yeah!. If you've got 2 hours to kill and you enjoy Dutch Masters join the crowds at the Frick. Marvel at "Girl With a Pearl Earring", possibly a greater portrait of a mysterious young woman than "Mona Lisa." The Vermeer masterpiece is currently on loan. There are also 3 more Vermeers in the permanent collection, which also features 19th century English works and a George Washington by Gilbert Sturart.
Girl with a Pearl Earring. Magnificient! Definitely worth the time and money spent in travel to see it. Buy timed tickets online before you go to avoid long lines.

Pearl Earring. Separate area for the Vermeer paintings, monitored to allow everyone in to see and stay as long as you'd like, once you leave this area you can not return unless you line up again. Well organized but the rest of the museum is very over crowded at this time of year. If you go Sunday morning for the " pay what you wish" the lines are very long, over 3 blocks, and takes about 45 minutes to an hour to enter.
This is must see. This collection is the best in New York City. Go and enjoy. You can get up close to some of the best art in the world.

Enchanting. A exquisite small museum, set in the lovely house in which Frick lived. A very impressive collection. I have a weakness for the Hans Memling portrait there, a window into another age. You'll have your own favorites, no doubt, as you imagine living in these rooms. The museum's size is appealing too, particularly if your time or energy is limited.
My favourite museum in NYC. We were lucky enough to not only visit the permanent collection, but got tickets to the Vermeer exhibition and it was breathtaking.

Went for the Mauritshaus Special Exhibition - Superb!. We went to the Frick at the last minute to view the Mauritshaus special exhibition of works by Rembrandt, Vermeer & Hals. Was superb. The museum itself is a lovely urban mansion with beautiful rooms & woodwork. The special exhibition had some well known pieces such as Vermeer's Girl with Pearl Earring, and a Rembrandt self portrait. If we had to do it over again, we'd reserve tickets on line. We did this at the last minute and had to wait outside in the cold for 35 minutes to get inside.

One of my favorite museums. The Vermeer Show is spectacular. And, the regular collection is something to be savor end. Mr Frick knew what he was doing. The house is also just marvelous, I can't believe people actually lived in homes like that in NYC. Go!

Beatiful home and great art collection if you only have a few hours.. My wife and I visited because we had a few hours to spend and thought that the Frick Collection would be appropriate for the time slot. After reaching the line for the museum we learned that an exhibit from the Mauritshuis museum in the Netherlands was on display including the Girl with the Pearl Earring by Vermeer so that was a pleasant surprise. I would highly recommend a visit if you are in the area.
Small museum. I like the Frick because it is small and doable in an hour or so and frequently has excellent touring art.

Lousy museum but a great collection of art. Frick, the person, is one of those embarrassing sorts that most families avoid inviting for the holidays. He made his fortune in a dipicable manner, Had no real taste other than what he could purchase from others and built a sad monuments to himself that he could never enjoy in the brief years it was compete before his death. The museum is as fascistic and humorless as was he. The guards are ignorant and rude, the collection confused, the docents well-meaning but poorly informed.The exhibition of Vermeer and Rembrandt is a disaster. No one can figure out where to go and what there is to see and where they can see it in the museum. There are favelas better organized. The Frick has great works of art that are nearly impossible to see owing to horrible lighting, which means everything in a museum. Most of these works are best seen in reproductions or on loan to other museums.
jewel box. The permanent collection is breath-taking. Sitting quietly in the courtyard, an experience by itself. lately, the crowds are apt to ruin an otherwise wonderful day
The Vermeers took my breath away!. Enjoyed the special exhibition immensely, but would definitely return for the permanent exhibition and the magnificent building alone.

Don't visit NY Without Visiting the Frick. A spectacular selection of European paintings with a number of famous canvasses often seen in art textbooks. The house, built by steel magnate Henry Clay Frick, is worth seeing in its own right. Easily seen in a half day, but of course one could spend far longer with pleasure.
Vermeer Exhibit. Great museum, lots to see. We have been here several times to see the three Vermeer paintings that they own. We saw Girl With a Pearl Earring which is on loan right now.

Overrated. We specifically visited because of a exhibition. Descriptions of the permanent collection were on very small placards, in a pale shade, forcing the observer to lean in close or strain to see what was written. Is this to prompt visitors to rent to earphones? Not cool, Frick, not cool.

If you love art you must visit. I always visit the Metropolitan Museum of Art and MoMA when in NY, but had missed out on the Frick. It is nothing like the big museums, being the private house (albeit huge) of Henry Clay Frick, with his collection of European art.He was well advised (as well as very rich!) the quality is outstanding. There are three Vermeers for example, out of only 35 extant in the whole world and not counting the one visiting at present - well worth a visit to see those alone. They are not alone, of course, there are other Dutch masters, a magnificent Bronzino, a couple of notable Constables and some lovely Gainsborough portraits, and much more.We booked for the Dutch visiting exhibition and found that that meant we did not have to queue, and that entry to the permanent collection was included.Brilliant!

A quick visit on the Sunday "cheap time". We lined up for 30 mins to get in and paid $5 each because we had a deadline. The girl with the pearl was in a special exhibit and it was very crowded. The movie was mainly about Frick's life and said very little about his interest in art although you have to wonder why anyone would build a museum to live in as his home. The collection was varied and there was a special exhibit of clocks in another room. The staff/security were pleasant even when I accidentally ventured off the carpet. I don't recommend going on Sunday from 11-1 as it was too crowded and difficult to actually view the art. I would visit on a different day and get the headphones if I came again.
small cozy museum. great museum to visit in nyc if you've been to some of the bigger museums in the city already. Get to see both a early 20th century mansion as well as some fine art.
Simply perfect. One of the great NY houses. One of the finest art collection anywhere. This is a lovely place to take visitors; it will not overpower.

Enjoy This Magnificant House & Collection. Be sure to get the audio guide which is included with admission price. The guide is well done, making design and art come alive for the listener. We spent twice as long here as we had planned. Our goal was to see the Dutch special exhibition, but we enjoyed the entire home and art collection so much that we felt rewarded for the long walk to get to the Frick.

Don't leave NYC without visiting The Frick. I will visit The Frick on every visit from now on. It is the most beautiful place to view a stunning collection of art and sculpture. I had booked my ticket for the Dutch Masters so was happy not to queue on a rainy day. It was a privilege to see Vermeers and others.

I love The Frick - and I recommend it to you!. The Frick is located in a gracious building that was formerly the home of Henry Frick, so to go there is to see how the art complemented his home and was an integral part of it. Every room is a delight but my favorites are the Hans Holbein paintings of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell who glare at each other from either side of the fireplace in the Living Hall. Viewing the collection is manageable in about 2 hours and you leave feeling elated (and not exhausted as can happen at other larger museums).

Small, but beautiful collection. This is a great small collection. Be sure to watch the 20 minute video on Frick and the history of the museum. It's very informative and gives you some background when looking at the collection. I also loved the interior garden. I spent about an hour inside the museum.

take your time to explore. Loved the set out of the rooms - felt like wandering in someone's house - although the staff are a bit on edge to say the least. We were not told what time the exhibition closed or we may have chosen to go another day - we were all practically ushered out (and not politely) when it got to 5pm. I had not expected to see Girl With the Pearl Earring (which my daughter had written about for her art thesis) but it was a lovely surprise. We went on recommendation of Frick being a bit "different". The internal "garden" area was lovely and we took time to take in the film explaining all about Frick and the building of the house....I guess that cost us a little time in looking around so we had less time to spend looking at all the original art. It is quite amazing to be able walk from room to room with all those famous artists pieces just hanging there, alongside lovely furniture, lamps, wall hangings etc. A lovely place - going late in the day was our own mistake....maybe it was less crowded that way. I would recommend it and I would imagine that restless teenagers or children would probably especially enjoy it. Less stuffy than an art gallery where all the art is practically in rows of similar - here it is all mixed up and you get some great surprises as you go round! Loved it!

Superb collection well grouped and displayed.. Certainly for the English visitor this is well worth seeing for its great collection of English artists and English historical portraits, for example the Holbein More and Cromwell portraits very lifelike and well known as illustrations in many books. Many society portraits as well with interesting characters such as Emma Hamilton Etc. Also many landscapes from various periods, fine furniture and china not grouped as in most museums but spread over this rich man's mansion which keeps the interest from flagging. The New York equivalent of the Wallace Collection but without a cafe, however there is an OK place just along70th St at Lexington.

Wow, an amazing private establishment. The Frick is a testament to what wealth can accomplish when turned to the collection and exhibition of great art. This famous and delightful museum is a delicious haven and should be on everyone's list of places to visit.

Lovely museum. I really loved this museum, it had a different feel to other museums. I guess its due to feeling quite personal. We were fortunate to see the Dutch collection that was a special exhibition. I love the indoor fountain area which is calm area with beautiful art.
My favourite New York Museum. The collection is stunning, as is the house Mr Frick built to display it. Tip, get there early. So much better without the crowds.

An unexpected gem. My son suggested we should go, and we were pleased we did. After a short queue (buy the tickets on line and you don't need to wait), we got into this converted home. The exibitition of Dutch masters including the "Girl with the pearl earring" was worth seeing, as well as the rest of the exibitions.

Man I hate this museum. My older sister loves this museum. After my first visit, where I was unimpressed, I was willing to be convinced. My issue with the museum is that they've "collected the whole set". Think of an artist and you can bet that they're represented in the Frick Collection. Thing is, none of the pieces are worth writing home about. So, off we go... only to find a line. Turns out the Girl with a pearl earring is on display. Well, cool! Oh, and when you hand in your ticket for the exhibit, this means you can't go back in for a second viewing on your way out. Okay... And as we're admiring the other works in this special exhibit we're witness to a security guard telling a woman she's wearing her purse/backpack in such a way as to make them worried. She points to another guard who told her a completely different story about how she's to wear it and that she was only doing what she was told. Ultimately they wanted her to wear it on her back with her coat over it. Moving on, I left my party to use the 3 stall ladies' room. It was a skillion degrees with a massive line. I took off my coat. Upon returning to the museum I was told to either check or put my coat back on. I couldn't walk around with it over my arm.In waiting for my party to return from the ladies' room, I had the misfortune to hear the woman at the member's desk explain to the woman who wanted to become a member that while yes, she would get in for free, her membership didn't include any guest passes and her friend would have to pay.Seriously???I couldn't get out of there fast enough. I'll never be going back. At $20 a person, there are plenty of other museums I'd rather visit.

Wonderful museum. Stunning collection with superb audio guide. My advice would be to spend an hour walking round then spend two hours going round a second time with the audio guide. It's a great museum and the film of its history is also well worth watching.

Always good. The Frick is worth checking out - for special exhibits as well as the permanent collection. It's small, so you don't have to spend the whole day there - but the art is first class.We went for the special exhibit on Dutch Masters - which was outstanding. And the Frick's permanent collection also has a number of them.

a hidden jewl. This is a small museum in the former home of the Frick family It is located on Museum mile. The collection is excellent with well know artists from various periods. It is not a museum for small children.

A museum experience as none other.. The Frick home converted to a museum after the founder's death is a must see. Beautiful architecture and interior design provide an incredible art experience. The collection is a mind blower.
Always a joy. The permanent collection includes two stunning Vermeers among its countless gems. An oasis in the city.

My favorite NYC art museum. The Frick Collection is known for its distinguished Old Master paintings and outstanding examples of European sculpture and decorative arts. Beautifully arranged and presented, there is a treasure of various artwork and the beauty of the building and garden. For me, it is a lovely escape with stunning works. Note: on Sundays, pay what you wish from 11am to 1pm.
