Just as good the second visit. A very nice sampling of some of the best works by the masters displayed in a beautiful setting of the Frick mansion. The only thing that is annoying is that The guards seem overly zealous in enforcing rules that are not posted anywhere in the building. I mean, what is wrong with having a sip of water from a bottle next to an indoor pond?

Do what you can to visit this Museum.. This is a GREAT Museum for Dutch, Spanish and Italian paintings housed in the former Frick Residence. It can get a bit crowded and you will be bumping into people but its well worth it. Definitely use the audio guide.
stunning. this would have to be one of the greatest collection of art , housed in a magnificent building , easy to get too , a must see when in New York

Where the Building is an Art Piece. Although we used to visit the city regularly, we’d never been here, but were drawn this time by Vermeer’s Girl with the Pearl Earring, which will be there until January 19, 2014. (If you saw the movie a few years ago, the maiden really does look like Scarlett Johansen!) We arrived just after they opened on a freezing day (temperatures in the 20s with severe wind) and the line stretched around the corner so we suffered in line for 25 minutes. We hadn’t realized that Sundays from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. are “pay what you like” days, which attracted more people. What an outstanding collection they have, with three more Vermeers, Rembrandt, Gainesborough, a stunning pair of Turners, and many more great artists. The building itself is a work of art, too. Don’t miss the clock collection. TIPS: The explanatory signs are hard to read printed on paper that matches the wall color and if you get too close to read them, the guards will chide you so one of their free audio guides can be helpful. Check your coat because a guard will scold you if you remove it while walking around the museum.

Art as it should be.... After visiting several museums in NYC, this is the top of my list. Why?? The staff never rushed you through any exhibits, spoke in a soft voice, easy to drop off coat/bags, head phone sets readily available, a small movie theatre to sit in comfort to view the beginnings of the Frick, and somewhat overview, clean bathrooms, well staffed gift shop. I will return next time to the city.
Lovely building, nicely displayed paintings. Disliked being told off for taking a photo in the centre section. I was not even in the same room as any exhibits

GREAT TO EXPERIENCE HOW THE RICH LIVED. This is a great museum to see how the rich lived at the turn of the century in NYC. The collection of furniture is not the best ( see the metropolitan Museum) but it is lovely and interesting.

Fantastic collection - beautiful building. Spent a Saturday morning (at 11AM it's "pay what you like) at the Frick. We visited because of the touring exhibit of Dutch painters and were very pleasantly surprised by the overall experience of the collection. Some amazing pieces, well described in the free audio tour. Frick was quite a collector with some clear themes and interests he brought to his collecting. As others note, it's a manageable size so you can reasonably spend a half day here. Highly recommended even without the touring exhibit.

Lovely setting, perfect size. There's a special exhibition of Dutch masters on at the moment, as well as the regular art works. I love this museum as its size allows for a more personal relationship with its collection. It's all very manageable whilst remaining impressive. The art is an eclectic mix so that a stunning Turner hangs amongst much darker, Dutch works. Try to book. We went early which was fine, but by the time we left, there were long queues - and it was wet and cold.

Quiet but full of wonderful art.. "Oasis" is indeed the right word for this museum. The home that houses it is beautiful and serene, and you will find this a very welcome respite from the chaos in the streets of NYC. While small in comparison to the giant museums around Central Park such as the Met, it still houses a very sizable collection of wonderful art, well worth the admission. This is a site often overlooked by tourists, but I think that the Frick home is such a fabulous piece of New York history, that the house itself should be seen. Highly recommended.

Excellent Museum. I really enjoyed this collection. You can tell that the collection has been carefully put together, built with quality pieces. This Is a really nice quiet museum, where you can enjoy viewing some beautiful and amazing historical pieces.
lovely, quiet museum. Much smaller than most of the city's museums. A quiet oasis of great beauty to be enjoyed immensely.

Wonderful art and history too. I had not been to the Frick in a while, so I not only enjoyed the paintings, but I loved this history of the Fricks and the fun of being in a historic mansion right on Fifth Avenue.

Great Art collection in NY. The Frick Collection is located on the Upper East Side at the 5th Avenue in NY. The collection is housed in Henry Fricks's former residential mansion consisting of fine furniture and six exclusive galleries. Some of the many masterpieces of European painting in Frick's collection include the "Mistress and Maid" by Johannes Vermeer, "St Jerome" and the "purification of the temple" by El Greco. Amongst the unique sculptures of the collection are the favorite "Head of the angel" by Bernini, "Mars" by Tiziano, "zephyrus and Flora" by Claude Michel Clodion and one Pietà by Michelangelo. Frick's collection is a great Art Collection & a Must while in New York. I would go back as many times as possible!

Back to Frick to see the Dutch Masters. I came back to Frick Collection for the special exhibition from the Mauritshaus in Den Haag. I highly recommend the museum and the exhibit. I arrived about 30 minutes before the opening on a rainy Sunday. The line was not very long. It is pay as you wish on Sundays from 11am-1pm. The exhibit includes masterpieces by Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals. The Girl with the Pearl Earring is the star of the exhibit, the Dutch Mona Lisa, although the other Vermeer paintings in the Frick are equally great. Photography is not allowed. Also, children are not allowed.

Dutch Masters at the Frick. Well worth the visit to see not only the permanent collection but the works on loan from the Maritshaus, including Girl with Pearl Earring and other Vermeers. A cold wait in the line outside and very crowded galleries on a Sunday afternoon, but not to be missed.
Very interesting museum. Another must see in NYC. Get a glimpse of the impresive life this family led while enjoying exquisite works of art. Their audio tour is great company too!
Lovely. Beuatiful house with an outstanding collection of paintings of a manageable size ( we only had a couple of hours and were able to look at everything). Highly recommended.

What a girl. The Girl with the Pearl Earring has an enigmatic smile that defies categorization....and she is the star of their recent exhibition from the Mauritshaus in The Hague....this is in addition to the the Frick collection's normal outstanding collection of old Masterpieces.

A Stunning Jewel in NYC. On a recommendation from an acquaintance we headed to the Frick collection on our way to the Met. Wow, what a great building museum and exhibition is hidden in this jewel in New York, and should be included in every visitors itinerary. We were lucky enough to arrive early before the larger crowds, and we're fortunate to be able to see the Dutch Masters exhibition with works by Rembrandt and Vermeer. His Girl with the Pearl Earring is a masterpiece and to see it in such a great venue added to its overall charm. The museum itself contains numerous pieces be many different and varied artists and sculptors, that space here doesn't allow more detail. Needless to say, visit the Frick when you are in NYC. A true art lovers paradise. An absolute gem.

A superb private collection. I always like private collections because they are more focussed and personal. This is one of the best. A superb collection of pictures, furniture, clocks, etc. housed in Mr Frick's vast purpose built house on 5th Avenue facing Central Park. Particularly strong on English painters, with some wonderful Gainsboroughs, Reynolds, Constables, Turners and even a couple of Romneys. The European painters are of similar quality. Wonderful stuff. Really needs more than one visit because the quality is so high, but it is certainly one of Manhattan's highlights and is absolutely unmissable.

Our favorite art museum. The Frick is a museum like no other - the masterspiece after masterpiece are just inches apart, smiling at you in the most sumptious setting of a mansion from the gilded age. The spirit of Mr. Frick permeates every tufted tassle, every gorgeous bronze miniature. The courtyard (formerly the driveway!) at the center is so serene and beautifully proportioned, you can feel its quiet beauty slow your pulse. The current Vermeer exhibit is a must see.

An Exquisite & Manageable Museum. I'd never been to The Frick Museum, and we took the opportunity to visit because of the Dutch Masters exhibit highlighted by Vermeer's The Girl with the Pearl Earring. (I like it better than the Mona Lisa). The Frick is an old & stately early 20th Century mansion that was turned into a museum in 1935. The rooms are full of Frick's collection of paintings, sculpture, furniture, etc.--all in a homey setting of the super-rich from a by-gone era. I would love to know about how the rooms were used in Frick's day. The museum is not so vast as most, and one could easily see everything in an hour or two. Still, it would have been nice to have more places to sit down, especially in the galleries. My husband, who complains of "museum legs," wanted to rest a bit, and there were few places available. We'll be back.

Amazing culture in the heart of NYC. A group of friends and I waited in line and were lucky enough to see the Vermeer Collection at the Frick on a rainy Saturday. The architecture of the mansion is itself a work of art and I truly encourage visitors to sit and watch the relatively short video the museum plays on rotation that dives into the building and additions made throughout the years. It's a unique experience because the collection is so eclectic and impressive that you know you are in a museum, but there is still a feeling of being in someone's home that makes the entire trip through the various rooms more intimate and real. I highly recommend for anyone visiting NYC! Students get a discounted rate as well!

The Jewel of NYC. If you love museum art but become overwhelmed with the larger museums the Frick may be just right for you. The building itself is magnificent, once a private home! The collection of art is exquisite. The size of the museum is such that you can see it all in a couple of hours. Audio guides to each piece of art are provided for the price of entry. Make sure to get your tickets on line before you go. They are sold by time frame on the date of your choice. We were thrilled to avoid the line that went around the block. We walked right in.

Girl with the Pearl is exquisite. And to top it off --- there were three more Vermeers in the galleries.The gallery is top notch and walking through the house made the paintings come alive.The house architecture is early 1900 and adds to the entire experience.If you love galleries, this is a must see

If you are going to go to ONE museum in NYC, go here. I enjoy museums like I enjoy desert - now and then and in moderation. I am not a fan of all day marathons where all works of art end up blurring together into a tired, sweaty, crowded experience. Not for me. Frick Collection on the other hand is a delight. It contains stunning works of art that span various forms from paintings to clocks. The mansion itself is a work of art as well. But the best thing about it - you are in and out in an hour or two and you actually end up with pleasant distinct recollection of what you saw. Great for people who have never been to a museum and even children. After you are done, stroll across the street for a nice walk in the Central Park. This will make for a delightful afternoon.

A journey back to the Victorian Era. It's an old beautiful mansion of what the REALLY rich had at the turn of the 20th century. Each room has it own sense and there are docents there to bring the era and the family alive. Friday nights and Sunday mornings are Free. And, then you can take a stroll in Central Park.

My Favorite Museum in NYC. I live in New York. When I need a place for relaxation (especially in winter time), I go to the Frick Collection. As usual, I admire the great taste and careful selection of the works of art. It's a place where I feel good and spend valuable time.

Paintings from Mauritshuis on display. The Girl with a Pearl Earring and a dozen of other paintings are on view until Jan 19. No separate fee required, it's included in the regular fee. The line rounded the corner though, took about 30 minutes. Also the 3 Vermeers from Frick's permanent collection have been moved to the main hall where the light is much better than that at the bottom of the staircase.

House museum of art par excellence. If you have time after visiting the Metropolitan, a trip to the Frick, to see the personal painting collection and gilded age mansion of a robber baron will not disappoint. Several Vermeers, Rembrandts and other iconic European paintings are highlights.

Wonderful collection, and some house.. Great collection of art in a very interesting and historic setting. Kind of surprising they don't allow non flash photography. Wonderful website if you want a virtual tour.

My favorite museum in the city!. Sure, Metropolitan Museum is something to behold. But its mere size is overwhelming. Frick, on the other hand, is small enough to give one a better sense of intimacy and closeness to the works of art. The crowds are also not as much as the other more popular museums.Frick is a must for anyone who wants to visit a museum in the city.
Girl with a pearl earring. Been to The Frick several times and love the building and the collection of paintings. Seeing the Girl with the Pearl Earring by Vermeer was a special attraction

How the other 1% lived. The Frick collection is a wonderful museum housed in a 19th century grand 5th Avenue mansion. The collection is set in what was once a grand family home of one of America's elite. The collection of old masters is world class and includes Dutch, French , Spanish and Italian art. It is an intimate non-institutional space which lends itself to the pictures and sculptures on display. This is where they would have been when America's rich brought European art back to impress and to concrete their social credentials. The art here is only half the story. It is a must see collection in NYC. Tip bring water as there is no cafe.

Don't leave NYC. Without a visit. It's like stepping into a movie set in elegant times gone by. Beautiful informal and stunning collections of one man with exceptional taste. It's almost as if you have been to a wealthy mans home as a guest.

Amazing Permanent Collection Plus Girl with a Pearl Earring. The Frick Collection is one of the gems of New York City art museums, with a permanent collection that ranges from Duccio to the Impressionists with particularly rich holdings from the 18th century. Like the Morgan Library, the Frick conveys a real sense of its founder's passion for art. The experience of viewing the collection conveys something of the intimacy one would have experienced seeing the collection when it was a private home. The Fragonard and Boucher rooms are wonderful examples of the Rococo, and the portraits by Reynolds, Gainsborough and their contemporaries are top notch. At the moment, there is a small but choice special exhibit of work from the Mauritshuis in the Netherlands - the centerpiece is "Girl with a Pear Earring" (c. 1665). It is worth braving the crowds to see this lovely painting with its spontaneous expression and wonderful handling of light. The 14 other works in the special show are by Hals, Rembrandt, Steen and their contemporaries from the Golden Age of Dutch art (which was the 17th century, just when the Dutch were flourishing in New Amsterdam). The Frick has three other Vermeers and additional works by Hals and Rembrandt in the permanent collection's West Gallery.This museum should be a "must visit" on every art lover's New York itinerary.

Wonderful collection. This museum was recommended by a friend and we were so glad we visited. For a relatively small site, it houses an impressive art collection (Rembrandt, Vermeer, El Greco, Velasquez, just to name a few). And since it is small, it is easy to see the entire collection. The building (a mansion) itself is worth seeing. We were there on a Sunday morning and surprised to see a line that went completely around the block. When we finally got inside we discovered that on Sundays between 11:00 and 1:00 entry was free - a nice surprise.

Dutch masters abound!. While the museum in The Netherlands is closed for renovations, they have lent their works to other countries. What a pleasure to view in a couple of rooms at the Frick mansion. The house itself and its permanent collection is lovely and then to have this terrific Special exhibit is just great. Be sure to watch the short movie of Mr. Frick's history. Interesting.

Great but crowded. We planned our Sunday for Central Park and the Frick Collection. The park was very crowded (a major fundraising run was going on) so we crossed over to the Frick around 11 a.m., not aware that until 1 p.m. on Sundays it is "pay what you like" - so it was crowded too! Still, we managed to work our way through all the rooms and enjoy the wide variety of works on display. Definitely will return at a quieter time so we can absorb all the details of the art and the building itself.

A Must See!. I am not usually a fan of art museums. But at the Frick, you not only get an important and stunning collection, but you also get one of the only existing mega mansions from the Gilded Age in the original condition with original furniture in a rare city block width building directly overlooking wonderful Central Park. Magic! I had lived in the New York City area for 25 years and had never been to the Frick. One of the most outstanding things to see in NY. Go. Go. Go.

Just love this museum. We went to see the Girl with the Pearl earring...a bucket list item if you are one that enjoys art. It's lovely and will not disappoint. I love this museum as it's not too large, the collection is nice and the garden/atrium is a lovely venue to just sit and take in your surroundings or have a nice quiet conversation with someone you love. My daughter and I love meeting here just to catch up!
Went for the Art, Loved the House. It is like a peak into another way of life. Make sure you use the audio tour and listen to the narration on the individual rooms.

Run, don't walk!. Run, don't walk to the current exhibit of Rembrandt, Hals and Vermeer at the Frick. This is such a beautiful mansion and this exhibit (including Vermeer's "Girl with the Pearl Earring" is absolutely stunning. Make sure to get the audio tour. We spend about 4 hours there and could easily have spent another one. I just wish they had more benches for resting. There are very few. Hint: order your tickets in advance for a timed entry. You can stay as long as you want, but you will avoid a very long line that must involve at least a 30 minute wait in the cold.

Worth the line outside. The wait at a recent lunchtime for about 15 minutes was because of the special if small exhibition of paintings from a Hague gallery at the present time, but it was worth it. This was the second visit in two years, and the collection is certainly worth revisiting.
Quick Trip to the Museum. We loved our tour of the Frick. The Swedsh Art exhibit was on when we were there. All of the rooms and the art were wonderful!

What a museum!. One of my favourite museums in NYC. Stunning building and amazing collection of paintings, sculptures and furniture.There was a special exhibition of Dutch masters when we visited so we saw 'The girl with the pearl earring' which was magic!Free audio tour definitely worth taking!

An amazing collection of paintings in a mansion setting. What a gem. I loved the variety of the paintings and it gave me the opportunity to see what one of those famous Fifth Avenue Mansions looked like. The Fragonard Room really appealed to me and I absolutely loved the Courtyard.

A wonderful museum with a fantastic collection. Henry Clay Frick had a wonderful eye for beautiful paintings and his collection has a little of everything from the medieval to the impressionists. He was particularly attracted to the Dutch Masters, so has several Rembrandts, Vermeers and Hals. The collection is displayed as he had them in his house, so you are able to enjoy them as he did (with a lot more people joining you), but that makes your visit less overwhelming than when you visit s Museum as large as the Met. WE ere also lucky to visit the special show of Dutch works from the Maritshuis in the Hague which included the enchanting "Girl with the Pearl Earring". One suggestion would be to check for lectures and programs available while you are visiting. We missed a showing of the movie "The Girl with the Pearl Earring" with a lecture by a curator the night before our visit which we would have enjoyed tremendously. This museum is definitely on the list for a revisit in the future.

Exquisite. Touring collection (Dutch painters) was nice but quite small; standing exhibits and the home are magnificent and alone are worth the visit. If going Sunday for free admission, start lining up 30-45 minutes before opening to get in quickly.
Even better than expected. I had been told that the Frick Collection was well worth a visit. It turned out to be even better than I expected. Such a great collection of art.

A wonderful house. Unlike Hearst's 'Castle', which seems like mere kitsch plundering, Frick was a real knowledgeable collector of fine art, and it's shown off to perfection as it was in his day. Holbeins either side of the fireplace... We spent half a day here, and wished it cuold have been longer.

If you're into Dutch masters at all, this one is a must. I had a few free hours during my last business trip to NYC and based on friend's recommendation this seemed to me like the best way to spend them. And it was well worth it. Some of the paintings there are really exceptional, some by Rembrandt and especially Vermeer. Definitely recommend!

The loveliest Museum in NYC. This museum, the former home of Frick, provides the most beautiful backdrop for an incredible private collection of world class art....three Vermeer's for example. When we visited there was also a another traveling exhibit of art from the a Museum in Holland with yet another Vermeer... so 4 under one roof. Don't miss this gem!

Special Exhibit from the Maurithaus. We were recently in The Hague and saw most of the wonderful collection of the Maurithaus Musuem, relocated due to renovation of the building. Learned that several major paintings are on loan to the Frick, including several Rembrandts and Vermeer's "Girl with the Pearl Earring". We booked a timed admission on a Friday afternoon, after arriving in NYC, but it was still packed. Try to go early AM. The Frick Collection itself, shown in the original rooms of the Frick Mansion is magnificent and well worth the visit.

Fabulous Frick. An excellent experience--The Old Masters show was very well done--easy to see and free acousta-guide added to the show. Touring the first floor of the mansion and viewing the film helped to bring the era of the period alive. It really is an excellent show and well worth the time.

How the 1% Used to Live. The Frick Collection is an incredible collection of art largely purchased by Henry Clay Frick (1849–1919). The collection is housed in the Fricks' 5th Avenue home, which itself is worth the visit. So much more manageable than the Met or MOMA, the Frick is a must if you love art.

Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Hals: Great Art Badly Managed. The lines around the block waiting for admission make it clear that the Dutch Masters on display at the Frick are a big deal indeed. While the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis in The Hague is closed for renovations, 15 paintings, including some by Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals, are on global tour, stopping until January 19, 2014 at the Frick.The Dutch Masters are splendid, of course. Did you anything expect less? What's awful is how badly the exhibit is managed. (It was open almost a month when we visited.) Tickets are timed, but the exhibit, which is housed in the smallish WWI-era mansion built by Henry Clay Frick, was crammed to the draperies.The number of visitors may have been legal, but permitting so many at once is a crime.The star of the show is Vermeer's "Girl with a Pearl Earring," which is showcased in the Frick's Oval Room. The other Mauritshuis paintings are on exhibit in the East Gallery, adjacent to the Oval Room on the right. Three of the Frick's own Vermeers are housed, with the permanent collection, in the West Gallery, off to the left of the Oval Room. Sounds dandy, but you can't get to the West Gallery from the East and vice versa without a block-long trek through crowded mansion hallways displaying other parts of the Collection.What made this exhibit even more difficult were the absurd curatorial placards. Made with relatively dark backgrounds, to match the wall-color, they had lettering in the same color family, just a bit darker. Tweaking the absurdity, the placards were printed in a small typeface, legible only at close range. Reading aides required.You would think the Frick, which has been open for nearly a century, would have learned by now to serve the public first and itself afterward. But until they get it, try to visit at off-off-peak times -- we went on a Sunday morning -- bring comfortable walking shoes, and take the audio tour, or bring field glasses.

Magnificent Mansion-Museum. One of the most elegant and enticing establishments in the world is currently hosting a small show of famous Dutch masterworks by Rembrandt, Hals and Vermeer. But the "Girl with the Pearl Earring" is not the only thing to admire here. El Greco's "St Jerome", Velasquez's "Philip", and a series of Turners have found a thrilling home, sumptuously decorated and maintained in top condition. A must for museum goers.

Truly amazing and well worth a short queue on a Sunday morning.. This was our first visit to New York and we wanted to visit one Museum and this must have been our luckiest day. The collection is a feast of treasures not only art but sculpture ceramics and much more in a warm "home" setting before it became a museum. The brief video described the origin of the collection was well worth viewing and it is free entry on a Sunday morning (you are asked to make a small contribution of your own choosing). Brilliant. A must visit!

Unbelievable collection. This is a must see of you enjoy artwork. I was fascinated by the Frick house due to my love of history and Henry Clay Frick's association with Andrew Carnegie. Although not on the same scale as the Borghese Gallery in Rome, it is still very impressive. The visiting gallery was the Dutch Masters so that made the visit that much more enjoyable. It only takes a couple of hours to peruse the collection and view the incredible home. Although Frick is considered the worst CEO in the history of America, he obviously knew his art. A can't miss!

The Frick. The primary reason we went to the Frick was a curiosity about the mansion. It was interesting to listen to how the family lived in it when it was first built. And it was beautiful. We did not know the Vermeer exhibit was on but it was a nice surprise. I would have liked to have been able to tour the entire mansion if it had been possible.Note that no little children are allowed in. There was a family in line ahead of us with an infant (<6 months) and they wouldn't let the child in. The grandmother was going to sit with the child while the parents toured. The guards were going to make her sit out in the cold with the infant until someone higher up intervened.

dutch masters wonderful: permanent not so great. The Frick is not really a destination location. The permanent exhibitions are a hodge-poge and the museum itself is dark. Having said that, the view to the garden is lovely, the location is too and the Dutch Masters is delightful Hopefully, they will get more special exhibits.

A great collection inside an astonishing building. The Frick is a small museum (compared to most museums in NYC) but the building itself is probably the gem of the collection. See how the rich lived in the golden age of wealth.
Take a private tour ($50 includes $20 admission) and you will come away awestruck at what you have seen and heard.

Small Space, Amazing Gallery. The Frick Collection is like the Musee D'Orsay in that its small enough to take in without feeling your head spin from an art coma. The works in this gallery are wide ranging in terms of styles and period and is just the most extraordinary family collection I think that must exist. A definite must see!

Beautiful collection. Delightful building and setting for some of the worlds best art
And not so much to overwhelm like larger galleries.

Dutch Masters ROCK!!!. The whole reason for my most recent trip to New York City was to go to the Special Exhibit of the Dutch Masters to see The Girl With the Pearl Earring. I got there extra early, which was a good thing because I was only third in line to get untamed ticket when they opened their doors. The whole exhibit was spectacular and then of course I viewed their regular collection which was just as wonderful as before. Go before the exhibit is over, it is worth it.Note: The Girl With the Pearl Earring is smaller than you expected it to be.

Life of the ultra wealthy. The Fricke Collection is an unbelievable art museum, plus a lot more. Housed in the Fricke mansion, you get a look into life of the ultra rich during a period in life which in itself was fascinating. The art is wonderful, but the mansion is breathtaking.

First visit - would absolutely return. Despite frequent visits to New York I had never been to the Frick, and now can't believe I missed it all these years. A real oasis in the city - wonderful to soak up the art and then take a break in the garden. Even with a special show, it didn't feel crowded. Will absolutely go back.

A New York City Gem!. I hesitate to write this review because I wish I could keep this museum to myself! Since the word is out, this is a stop no one should miss if visiting New York City! The collection is superb, and so is the setting! It is also not an all day bone tiring experience like the Metropolitan Museum. So go if you must, I never miss it when I am in New York.

Went to see the Vermeer exhibition!. Well, the Girl with the Pearl Earring was worth going to see. But, there weren't many other Vermeers that are not in the permanent collection - which is superb - so that was a disappointment. Also the security staff have a thing about anyone carrying a coat, which was quite strange. They didn't suggest that you had to use the cloakroom, but if you hadn't they insisted that it had to be thrown around the shoulders. Either clearer signposting or a more relaxed attitude. ( some really were quite aggressive).
Vermeers!. Masterpieces in a lovely house. I especially like the quietness of the indoor reflecting pool. Don't miss it.
Fabulous art and collectibles collection in a lovely setting. Have never seen such an impressive collection in a private home setting (actually, it's more like a mansion…)

Magnificent. Time at the Frick is a reward for all of your senses. I spent a long afternoon there recently specifically to see the Vermeer exhibit currently on offer. But beyond the Vermeers, I remembered that the entire Frick is a place of warmth and culture. The building itself is a marvel of the upper East side of the city, you can imagine life in the city when industry titans were creating mansions that befit their egos and income...but that were also examples of fine design and artistry. The collection of the Frick is fine tuned and beautifully presented. Take the time and immerse yourself in a bit of history.

best private collection in NYC. this museum is my favorite after MET, the collection is awesome, the building itself and the guideline very informative, you should plan your visit with googd timing, because there are always lines! and the museum is qiute big so better plan no less than 2 hours only for visit
What a Gem. I love the Frick. It is a great way to spend 2 hours in NYC. Go to their website to see what is available. My favorite part of the museum is in the old Frick home. Just go.

Wonderful Collection. I have been to the Frick several times and each time it has been a wonderful experience. It is not really for kids (everything is hands off). The Frick is mainly for those who appreciate art or students that are studying art. The building itself is beautiful and definetly worth visiting.
Superb.. Excellent. Time just seemed to ebb away. Fascinating. Would recommend, though New York should learn a thing or two from London, where art galleries are free.

Intimate Museum but World-Class Pieces. My favorite museum in New York. It is a great smaller museum which makes it much more intimate. As most people know it was a private residence so all the pieces take on a much more casual air. The bronzes are superb; the women's parlor is a flourish of color. Best painting - Rembrandt's (maybe) "Polish Rider". Don't miss this museum.

The best museum in town. We didn't know Frick Collection until a friend of mine told me about it. It is our favorite museum since we visited it. With a marvelous collection, you feel the taste of Frick's and not the cold taste of a regular museum. And it's a small museum, not a MoMa-style-one...It has one of the most beautiful collection I have ever seen. We trully recommend it.
The Girl with the Pearl Earing. Well mounted show of famous Duch artists is a beautiful turn of the century famous mansion. A great experience.

Very Unique!. This collection had a very good set up, which was in an old home. The architecture was beautiful! The rooms in this gallery were amazing! The art was beautiful and the collection is mind blowing, because of how much there is. It is different, but it is a great place to go!

An Oasis of Calm & Serenity in a Sea of Turbulence. There is a reason The Frick is rated 5 stars and few other NYC attractions are. It is a lovely & rare example of a preserved private residence of a bygone era.
my favorite. I love the period and I especially love portraits. And it is particularly nice to see what started as a personal collection in the house of the collector.

Beautiful building and well presented art. This is a unique exhibit space and the art is great. We visited during the Vermeers et. al. exhibition which was outstanding. Well run facility and a very good experience.

Fricking Wonderful. First off, the building in which the Frick Museum resides is a masterpiece. The elegance of the rooms, and quality of finish, reminds me of some of the Louvre or an English manor museum. Look at the arched ceilings and doorways, the mouldings, the panelling, the furniture, the curtains, the chandeliers----Frick had great amounts of money AND great taste, which is always a nice combo.Our local museum, of which we are members, has a reciprocity arrangement with the Frick, so admission was free. The artwork on exhibit (including paintings, sculpture, clocks, silver, etc.) is first rate. They featured a Vermeer, Hals, Rembrandt exhibit---Dutch painters---which was stunning. The general "collection" features a lot of portraits (Gainsborough, etal) and landscapes. Its on Museum row on the UES so very convenient---we stopped in before an early dinner and it was perfect.

Hilariously Snooty Staff -Superb Collection. The ladies on the entry desks are worth a viewing in own right - but better yet is the wonderful Frick Collection. Wander through the rooms of this former home and marvel at the art they contain. Note that unusually for one of the NY galleries there isn't a café or refreshment facility here. Our enquiry for such was met with a stony glare from the security guard we asked and a curt "NO" - which is not a problem really as there are other places within a short walk.
Gem of UES. This is my most favorite museum in the City.This building was originally owned by tycoon MR.FRICK.You can enjoy the essential collection of European art.
Proper art. A stunning collection of famous pictures as hung by the owner in a more random order than most gallery's which helps to keep the interest from flagging. We even bought the catalogue.

A Gem for Classics in Western Painting and Decorative Arts. I began visiting the Frick Collection as a teenager and have never stopped. The other day I went to see Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Hals - Dutch Masterpieces from The Mauritshuis for a morning that raised my spirits. The 15 paintings in this loan exhibition included the famed Girl with a Pearl Earring by Vermeer, more stunning face-to-face than in any reproduction I've seen. In a separate gallery were two formal full-length portraits by Hals which surprised me, being more familiar with his earthier work; there were a number of small-scale landscape and genre paintings by other 17th C Dutch masters, each a pleasure to view, and a wall of little-known Rembrandts. A fantastic treat. In the decorative arts gallery were antique French sculptural clocks from the permanent collection, each amazing and beautiful. The other galleries have unchanging displays of furniture, decorative arts, and great paintings from Medieval through Goya, Ingres, Corot, and Degas. The Vermeers are priceless. There is a small auditorium for occasional concerts, a small gift shop, an interior fountain garden, a landscaped lawn facing Fifth Avenue which can be viewed from the interior or the sidewalk, and an inner courtyard garden facing East 70th Street which can be viewed from the inside or the sidewalk. Downstairs are several rooms for temporary exhibitions, usually of classical drawings.

way to spend a Sunday afternoon. it was almost disappointing going to the Metrapolitan Mus of art after seeing the great works at the Frick..Sunday afternoon open for a few hours, get there early, not as many people as the Met

Don't miss the Frick. Made our first visit to this gem of a museum to view the Girl with Pearl Earring and other visiting works of the Dutch Masters. Timed tickets are sold and while the exhibit was busy, we didn't feel that it was overly congested for viewing. The Frick itself is a gorgeous building harking back to the Gilded Age of Robber Barons. And it has an unbeatable location on the Upper East Side near Central Park. We took the # 6 subway uptown from Grand Central and stopped for lunch on 74th St. at Cucina Vivolo. Simple, fresh salads and paninis at very reasonable prices had all five of us happy. One issue with the exhibit: we and others of a certain age had to stand almost on top of the descriptive signage because both the colors (artsy, but poor contrast) and font are not senior-friendly. Hope that the presumably young curator(s) takes note.After visiting the museum, we enjoyed a leisurely walk south to our midtown Bolt Bus. Right down Fifth Avenue to Bryant Park where the Winter Village shops are set up and we enjoyed a snack and excellent people watching.

Lovely home and collection. The Frick is a leisurely half-day visit to a lovely old mansion with an interesting collection of art. The Vermeers were my favourite, but there were many other impressive pieces.
Go see Girl with the Pearl Earring. This collection is really amazing, but try to go when Vermeers masterpiece Girl with the Pearlk Earring is there. One of the greatest pieces of artwork ever made

Current Exhibition- Masterpieces of Dutch Painting from the Mauritshuis. We stood in front of Vermeer's Girl with a Pearl Earring and pretended it was ours. The Frick just makes you feel like you are walking into someone's home and enjoying their amazing collection.
It is friendly, easy, lovely and on this crisp fall day - very. very busy. A must visit - even for us jaded New Yorkers.

Stuffy, Prepare for a Wait. Arrived about two on a very nice Saturday afternoon, and waited outside for about 30 minutes to get in. You can beat this and go straight in if you join for $75. The coat check is a huge racket, as you have to wear or stash your coat and bag.The residence itself is amazing, let alone the art. It brought to mind the Biltmore. We wanted to see more upstairs--maybe this could be done in the future. The art is pretty bland, very old-timey and traditional. We came during the Dutch Masters show, and saw the Girl with Pearl Earring--very nice.They offer a military discount, but only for active duty--this should include everyone who has served, such as retirees.

Try to get there while Girl w Pearl Earring is also visiting. She's here till Jan 19, 2014, while her European digs are undergoing remodel. Frick Museum is a member of the North American Reciprocal Museum Membership group, so if you are, too, bring your card and go to the front of the line, and enter w/o charge. VWe lingered looking at her yesterday, and decided that, to us, she is more beguiling than the Mona Lisa. Don't miss the rest of the show...it's a wow morning or afternoon.

A Museum and Mansion. The Frick has an eclectic collection of art work from well known artists which is housed in a beautiful mansion . We attended a special Dutch exhibit where the famous "Girl with a Pearl earring" was displayed (among several other works). Just wonderful!
Amazing Art!. This is one of my favourite museums: small and accessible. Lovely collection of art and beautiful gardens.

Girl With a Pearl Earring. We only had 6 hours in Manhattan & decided to check out the Frick. So glad we did. Currently on view is the Vermeer masterpiece Girl With a Pearl Earring. This was stunning, but so is the rest of the collection. Free audio tour. Highly recommend.

Art in an opulant setting. The Frick is a mixture of fabulous art in what used to be a family home. The home itself is magnificant Nd Mr, Frick filled it with art from Rembrandt to Monet meaning for it to be open to the public after he died. It's a wonderful place to wander around. There was a very good exhibit of Vermeer and other Dutch artists while we were there and I got to see The Girl With The Pearl Earring in person- such a thrill.

Simply incredible. Took a 15 minutes walk from The London NYC through Central Park to the Frick. Waited in line for about 30 minutes. First visit. Special exhibit of Vermeer and Rembrandt from Holland was a treat. But the rest of Frick was a mind-blower. The setting itself is amazing when you start to focus on small things like the hardware on the casement windows, door jams, and architectural features. The short film on the history of the Frick is worth the time. We found ourselves not just admiring the collection itself but contemplating the placement of the art works from the psychological perspective of Frick. The juxtapositions surely are grist for the mental mill. Plan on at least two hours but three would be a good start. We are going back on our next visit. Frick staff did not permit photos. There is a way around the line by buying a membership.
Spectacular art and clocks. Fabulous art collection and a nice size - enough for a good range but not so much that it blows your mind! Great clocks too

Always a Joy. While Frick's bio may not have been very savory, his taste in art definitely was. The museum is housed in what was Frick's New York mansion - conveniently located on the city's Museum Mile - yeah Met. The super rich definitely did/do live differently from thee and me. One plus is how Frick integrated his collection into his daily living - check out the fireplace wall in the main drawing room.We went for the special Mauritshuis exhibit and thoroughly enjoyed it - how did the masters get the lace trim and collars so detailed? In hindsight we should have rented the exhibit's audio tour.We hope that sometime in the future the museum might open up the private rooms upstairs.

Fantastic collection and house. Hard to believe such a wonderful art collection has been assembled and displayed by one family. Truly incredible collection of masterpieces in a house worthy of a visit all on its own. Much less overwhelming for a quick visit than the Met. Get the audio tour.

Frick Collection Excellent. Arrived early to see The Girl With The Pearl Earring. No line at 10:30am. One can see entire collection in 2 hours, all on one floor. A very enjoyable former home. Coffee shops and cafes outside nearby.
Girl with a Pearl Earring. Always a great afternoon! Hard to believe that with such a famouse piece arriving, the Frick will not change the price of admission!

Moore v Cromwell. There are numerous aspects to why this collection is one of hte finest in NYC. It isia relatively intimate experience beacuse it was originally a home albiet on the grand scale for an wealthy indutrialist. The diversity of art - sculpture, wall handings/panels, furniture and the actual pictures is fasinating as it reflects the taste of essentially one indivudual. However for anybody interested in English history or that of the refomation in England the defining monment is on entry to Frisk's studey where either side of the fire place stand the Holbein's of Moore & Cromwell. The impage esp. of Moore is the one that everybody can recall and it is so striking that it is almost breathtaking.

Still worth a good two hours. Quite apart from the special Mauritshuis exhibit with the Vermeer Girl, the regular collection is a treasurehouse. We love the Rembrandts, we love the Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell; we visit the Frick each time we visit New York.

New exhibit. My wife and I went to the Frick collection for their new Mathiushaus exhibit. This is one of our favorite museums in New York.Great art in a beautiful setting and not usually crowded. A wonderful place to see great art and able to contemplate.

Marvelous. Definitely a different feel from the Met; I can't say it's better, but it's certainly not worse. The collection here is just stunning, any art enthusiast who finds herself in this manor is going to have a field day looking at all the rarities! The only thing I didn't like, though, is that photography of any kind isn't allowed.

great expectations not fulfilled. Had great expectations towards Frick Collection, but I was disappointed. The day I went was a bit cold and we had to wait outside for about half an hour. Some people skip the line either because they were members or could become members on the spot! I'm not a local, so becoming a member was out of question. I waited. Others went on straight because they had bought the ticket previously. However, I had the impression that more people could skip the line simply by joining in the gathering of people walking to the entrance door. When I was inside, a couple appeared behid me, but they weren't in the line outside! Once you're inside, the process for buying is a bit slow. The line doesn't move on fast (too few staff selling?) Inside, there was a temporary ehibition, but it was confusing. They don't make it clear like showing arrows for visitors to follow a circuit. Another drawback is labeling. Some labels are so small (and on the frame) that you have to get really close to read. I saw some visitors almost touching the paintings! The good points are: The fact that it's a house ( a mansion, in fact), it features a splendid collection, the decoration, the furniture, the building, everything is beatiful! It´s a pity that the top floor is closed. The most impressive work of art to me was The Promenade, by Renoir. Still, it was a bit expensive. Larger museums in the world and in New York, display many more items for about the same price.

Best show in New York. A much smaller collection of pictures and furniture than the Met but much higher quality, and without the hordes of tourists taking photos of everything. In fact you cannot take photos here. But their version of Constable's Salisbury Cathedral or El Greco's St Jerome are far finer than the Met's. If you go to only one gallery in New York, make it the Frick

super colection. flick has had a very good advisor for his art collection - his private villa is a wonderful frame for its exhibition!
a must see for museum & architecture lovers

Cool small museum and it is free on Sundays. This mansion is loaded with lovely paintings, sculptures and furniture. Everything is beautiful. The collection also includes multiple Vermeers. Best of all, it is free on Sunday.

Golden era mansion filled with beauty. Not only did the Frick display some of my favorite Italian Renaissance and French paintings, it also had decorative art such as furniture and clocks which made the experience feel more like you were walking through a home rather than a museum. We were privileged to see Dutch masters who were on special display. Wonderful experience.
Nice find.. Interesting audio tour--husband enjoyed all the history of the building itself. Nice collection housed in a well-appointed mansion--not an overwhelming museum feel.

I'm not an art gallery guy, but.... I thoroughly enjoyed the collection and the Frick house... a fairly lengthy line outside to get tickets but it moved quickly - in about 10 minutes we were inside. I'm no art collector or enthusiast but I loved this collection, particularly the Rembrandts.

Art Overdose!!. I never had the pleasure of visiting the Frick until this past weekend. We went to see their new Dutch Masters exhibit including "The Girl with the Pearl Earring" - Vermeer, Rembrandt, and Hals. The musuem also has several of their own in addition to the exhibit! Room after room of masterpieces in this elegant building. Be advised, you need timed tickets for admission. I found the exhibit pretty crowded, but we were there on a Saturday afternoon. Coat check available, be prepared to go up & down a flight of stairs to the basement to the ladies room.

Not everyone's taste. We went here on the spur-of-the-moment but have to admit very little of the art excited us. There are a few very fine old masters but there are also some very average examples of good artists' work, too (as though Frick thought the name was more important than the art).

Impressive collection. I thought I knew the most important museums in New York, but had never been to the Frick Collection! This time I went and I was amazed by the unbelievable richness of this private collaction! There are works by Cimabue, Brueghel, Hals, Tiziano, Gainsborough, Turner, Rembrandt, Renoir and many more famous and illustrious painters. Now I want to know more about Frick. The collection is a must for anybody!

Sunday...pay what you want day!. Lovely fall day in NYC, which made the long line tolerable. Also, being across the street from Central Park, helped as well. Sunday from 11-1 is pay what you want day and thus, long lines around the corner and down the block. Beautiful, small venue....not overwhelming. Some places to sit among the collection were nice. The ear telephone like devices that you out in a number corresponding with the piece, were very informative and I highly recommend getting one. Went across the street to Central Park after and ate my lunch on a park bench people watching.

Splendid Setting for a Superb Collection. This modest size but superb collection can be enjoyed in the wonderful setting of the Frick mansion. There is no better way to enjoy selected top paintings of Dutch, English and German artists.

Smaller but superb. The building itself is beautiful and the original portion still feels like a "home." It houses a small, but superb, collection of art. If you have limited time to spend while in New York, the Frick should be high on your list of priorities.

'Unique view of how a privileged few used to live.'. Possibly my favourite place in the city to visit when I want to enjoy the tranquillity, beauty and style of a bygone age. This impressive mansion needs to be savoured and time taken to truly appreciate the wealth of detail in the architecture and design. Imagine, you have all of this to enjoy, even before discovering the rich collection of paintings. Throughout the year the permanent display is impressive, however, at the moment you have the unique opportunity of viewing the superb collection from the Netherlands when the most well known of the Vermeers can be enjoyed.One of the joys of the Frick is that it provides a welcome respite from the frantic energy of the city. Here, unlike the Met, visitors take their time allowing you, and others to enjoy the richness without the overwhelming, noisy crowds.
Absolutely superb Gallery and Museum. Beautiful art collection, superbly displayed. A quiet and peaceful escape from the noise and bustle of New York. Well worth a visit.

I Could Live There. Located on fifth avenue just a tad south of the Met this museum home also has extensive gardens. The building is an architectural treat...lots of light; unusual shaped rooms and a rare small collection of unique visual arts in all traditional medium. Never too crowded. One can easily digest the art in this special place. Robber barons did leave some positive legacies too.
Another must see in the Big A. Well' a museum that holds 3 Vermeers does not need my recommendation. A beautiful collection, worth visiting.

Great experience. We visited the Frick Collection in September after a friend recommended it to us. Set in a luxurious building the paintings of Dutch, Spanish and English artists was definitely worth it

Girl With Pearl Earring!!. We saw the Dutch masters exhibit on loan from Holland, including the breathtaking Girl With Pearl Earring. This museum has a wonderful collection and is a beautiful, gem-like home to boot. Love the Frick!
A must see if in the city.. Beautiful house, fabulous paintings clocks and artifacts with a wonderful indoor water feature courtyard .

15 paintings from Mauritshuis visit The Frick in Fall, 2013. The Frick is always a wonderful art experience, with a medium-sized collection of "only" masterpieces. For a few months, they are featuring a visiting exposition from the Netherlands, while the Mauritshuis museum is being renovated. The big draw is Vermeer's "Girl With A Pearl Earring", but all of the visiting works are landmarks of the history of art. It runs until January 19, 2014.During this show, the Frick is selling advance, timed tickets on Telecharge (wearing charity lipstick ... ), with the usual extra fee. There's no fee at the Museum desk ($20 adults), but they also don't guarantee that you'll be admitted immediately without a timed ticket. When I entered on 10/22/13, there was no line on the street, but when I left at Noon, they had started a line (with ropes) going towards Fifth Avenue. The entrance is on East 70th Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues. They expect this show to sell heavily, so I recommend reserving and buying in advance, although I hate paying Telecharge/Shubert Ticketing for the privilege.Members and reciprocal members go to the "Membership" desk that's to your left as soon as you pass the checkroom desk. People who printed out their Telecharge tickets in advance go directly to the ticket-takers, who are at the head of a hallway just to the right of the "Membership" desk. People buying a new ticket get in the same roped line they always have, on the windowed, long-dimension side of the big lobby.To control crowds, ropes have been put up, especially around the Garden Court. You /cannot/ go from the West Gallery into the Oval Gallery, which is where the visiting exhibition starts, with the Vermeer. The other 14 paintings are in the East Gallery, where the Goyas usually are. ("The Forge" is temporarily in the West Gallery, along with all three of the Frick's Vermeers. This is a jarring change for Frick regulars!)So if you want to start with the Mauritshuis show, skip the stairs down to the Pierre-Jean David d'Angers show in the downstairs gallery (one of these is closed, no doubt as a lounge for the extra guards!) and take the third right (shop, small gallery, Garden Court) into the end of the Garden Court. Bear left to the entrance ropes. (There were NO SIGNS on the first day of the show.)This is a good exhibition. (Note that no museum, INCLUDING the Frick, allows photography of borrowed works. No photos.) But for someone who might eventually get to the Mauritshuis in The Hague, it's a little thin compared to the 100 works they showed across town (The Hague, that is) in the Gemeentmuseum. So you'll miss Vermeer's "View of Delft", Paulus Potter's "The Bull", and Rembrandt's "The anatomy lesson of Dr Nicolaes Tulp". (The latter is of special interest to those who like Thomas Eakins' medical portraits in Philadelphia.)By the way, the Syracuse University Palitz Gallery (11 East 61st) is showing a group of Netherlands etchings, including many Rembrandts that makes a good companion to the Frick show. The Palitz show runs until November 14, 2013 .There is a very funny 1981 parody of Potter's "The Bull" in Gallery 915 of the Metropolitan Museum of Art right now. Anyone going to this Frick show will want to see the Met's Vermeers too.
Perfect. Always my first stop in NYC, a perfect gem of a museum. Unique, calm, exquisitely beautiful. There's always a profound sense of gratitude from the visitors to Mr Frick for this great gift.

Look for free admission day. Have visited Frick Collection 3 times over the years. Love to imagine life in this mansion, with all of the art, culture, and sumptuous furnishings. If you have time to wait for a free admissions day and can make the hours that it is open, it is well worth your time. We went on a Sunday in the early afternoon. Check their website for day and time, in case it changes.
big old house, with a modest art collection. Expensive for what you get. I would recommend the Metropolitan Museum of Art instead. The Frick is microscopic by comparison.

Definitely worth it!. If you like art in a home setting, this is it! A great display of masterpieces in a beautiful home. It's not big enough for the "museum fatigue" to set in, yet the senses are satisfied. A definite must for anyone who appreciates art...

Perfect and not to be missed. This perfect collection is wonderful, one of the very best things we did in New York. A comprehensive and beautifully exhibited collection. The rooms themselves are a delight. Seeing the original Thomas More moved me greatly. Do not miss this if you Are an art lover.

Some of the world's best works of art. The Frick mansion is magnificent -- but the art treasures it holds are wonderful. It is interesting to see how the Frick family lived and entertained. It is a perfect spot to spend a few hours. Wander the rooms and examine the magnificent collection of art pieces. If there is a special exhibit, get there when the Frick first opens at 10 a.m.

Wonderful! Wonderful!. This art museum is a complete must if you visit NYC. Such a marvellous collection of art over a very wide range. Wonderful examples of rococo - Fragonard, Boucher and in the next room two quite startling Holbeins with a superb El Greco in between. The two large Gainsboroughs in the third room are quite breathtaking - really magnificent! A beautifully sombre Manet, in another lovely room with two Watteau and a lovely Degas and all this before you even get to the main long gallery with its selection including two wonderful Turners and a truly marvellous Rembrandt self portrait. The paintings are wonderful enough but the house is also full of other lovely artefacts, vases, silverware, figurines etc. This is a great 'house' museum to potter round and really take your time as its only small and you don't have to rush. Perfectly located for a nice stroll in Central Park afterwards to contemplate all the wonderful masterpieces you have seen.

The fabulous Frick. The most perfect collection of the best old master paintings in a quiet, uncrowded mansion. A relaxing experience unlike the daunting multiple collections of the Metropolitan Museum a few blocks north.
A fine and well selected collection of works of art. The scale is interesting but not overwhelming. Obviously a collection put together with taste and time.
GREAT museum.... The paintings are wonderful and it's a tremendously pleasant experience to just walk thru. it's not usually terribly crowded and it's a convenient location on museum mile.

What a gem. For anyone who hasn't visited this diverse, one-of-a-kind collection with works from the world's finest artists, it's a must on your next trip to the city. I can't say enough about it. Beautiful building, spectacular artwork, and less crowded than some of the other museums.
A rare gem for all.. A long stroll through Central Park and then Chamber music and rooms filled with period furnishings and art. Not to be missed. A lovely afternoon for adults.

Grand House & Art Collection. To me this was more about the spectacular house than the priceless art works. You can imagine Mr Frick and his family living here in the early 1900's. There are 12 rooms filled with masterpieces of Vermeer, Goya and Renoir to mention a few! There is an audio tour included in the entry price
Fantastic architecture and art in one package. A great small collection full of masterpieces - in a gorgeous architectural environment. A must see for art lovers!

Unbelievable art collection in a gorgeous setting. Absolutely gorgeous and authentic setting - beautiful furniture and objects as well as a world class art collection. Some of the most famous and beautiful artworks in the world. Holbeins's Thomas More & Carlyle portraits, Bellinis, Rembrandt's self portrait and the best collection of Gainsborough portraits displayed together I have ever seen. Impossible to recommend this enough. Moreover it is not rammed with visitors like MOMA and Guggenheim. Room to move around and pause, some seats and a great audio tour is included in the price of admission.
A gem beside Central Park. Wonderful quiet and understated building in itself and a great art collection. Go on a Sunday and pay what you wish.
A must see!. I loved that this collection was in a house and displayed in rooms in the way they were intended and not in a vast museum.
tops. This a must visit , you cant go to new york and miss it , highlight was seeing girl with the pearl ear ring , many famous works here in a beautiful building

Superb treasure. The Frick exceeded our high expectations from previous posts here. Such a beautiful home that has been turned into a wonderful intimate gallery. One that is crammed full of paintings and object d'art of premium quality. Each room provides a unique feel and is a space you can imagine spending long and happy hours in. The gardens are also superb. Because of its compact size, this is a perfect place to experience a New York gem.
Great collection. A smaller space, a smaller selection, but every piece was top quality. Excellent pieces in several styles and a great setting in a historic NY house.
Beautiful. The artwork and setting were awesome. My granddaughter and I toured the Frick and felt as if we were visiting a wealthy relative. We could imagine living in that beautiful house.
Frick Collection: small but worth it. Beautifull house and setting and I was amazed by the quantity of priceless oeuvres d'art in this gorgeous upper east side residence. A jewel of a find.

Great art, small crowd, lovely house.. Wanted to go to the MET, but the crowds toooooo big for me. So went to the Frick, and loved every moment. The staff are fantastic as well....very helpful, friendly.

Fabulous collection in historic mansion. The Frick Museum is a New York City treasure. Where else can one enter an historic mansion and view such an incredible collection of paintings? Three of the 27 Vermeers in existence are at the Frick. Several of the rooms have incredible paintings done on the walls and the grand staircase and the décor in the various rooms are beautiful to behold.
Interesting museum. The Frick museum has an interesting, but small art collection. I found the mansion itself to be of more interest.

Manhattan Frick museum. Walking on Fifth Avenue you can visit the beautiful home of Mr. Fink which was his private residence and is now a museum. The Frick Museum has a rich collection of paintings by old famous artists which are displayed in the many rooms of the house where the furniture remained unchanged and looks as if the owner is still living in . For this reason the visitor can admire not only the many valuable paintings but also the many various beautiful objects that belong to each room.Sometimes during the visit you may forget you are a tourist and get the feeling of being a guest .

Undenialbley The Most Precious works of ART. The most elegant collection of art to behold. all decorating his magnificent home.Mr Frick had a eye for collecting unbelievable pieces. Massive murals with elegant furniture left as he used this mansion on 5th for his private residence in the early 1900's. We visited 3x this summer of 2013 and want to go again.It will imprint in your mind a lasting memory of the old masters each artist has there own flair from Whistler to Renior to El Greco. You will have a favorite piece,one of mine being the girl with the ball of string& cat, also the large scenic portraits where spectacular..The bronzes where very interesting and murals spectacular.His private collection surpasses other crowed museums, as the big Met.etc.I guarantee you will return. Very easy to navigate.You are given a hand held in your choice of language, a recording of each piece corresponding with the art work.A lovely relaxing day in NYC.  .

A must see in NY. This is such a beautiful old place. It is very small - as it was a private home, but is worthy of being a museum as the building and architecture, and grounds are not only magnificent, but bespeak another period in NY's history, so it is like going back in time, as well as visiting an absolutely beautiful home. On top of all of this charm, it is filled with magnificent pieces of artwork. The loveliest part, is the quiet, so one can feel as if they are living there, and contemplate the beauty in peace and complete tranquility.

See how the other 1% lived... Really.. The Frick collection is not just about the art. The house itself is an amazing collection of Gilded Age American life. The detailing and eclecticism in the home and furnishings is remarkable. Soak in the fine art as you move through the spaces. (Any work of JMW Turner is always a treat.) The Frick is a great opportunity to understand the history of Fifth Avenue as the home to many of the great 19th Century houses and families...
Wonderful smaller museum. The Frick is a great museum, fabulous collection and easy to get through. It is a definite stop on my trips to NY.

Gorgeous. This is one of my favorite museums. The building was originally a private home and has an incredible collection. I saw the Vermere collection at The Met a few years ago and the two paintings at The Frick were better than the fourteen that came over for the other show. I've been three times now and will continue to return.

A must see for art lovers. I had no idea what to expect. I had heard of the Frick, but it was much more than I expected. The collection is amazing and since it is on display in someone's home, it is even more impressive. Plan to spend 2-3 hours easily, but it will be totally enjoyable!

Perfect if you are alone or with a group. The Frick Collection is an oasis of order and beauty in the midst of busy 5th Avenue. How often do you go into a museum and are able to see EVERYTHING in just one leisurely visit? I spent three hours there and didn't even realize it. The Museum gives you a free audio guide with your admission and it is a great asset to the museum goer. I also took a 15 minute tour and watched the film. I had been to the Frick many times over the years but this time by choice, it was the only museum I visited on this trip. Good choice. I went away delighted and not overwhelmed.

A lovely oasis of calm. I visited the Frick Collection with my friend when we visited New York recently, we chose to go there instead of the Met because of the time we had available, and the quality of the art work on display. We were not disappointed, the calibre of paintings in particular was exceptional and it was easily manageable in an hour or two. In the centre of the house is a lovely conservatory with a pool where you can sit and gather your thoughts; the shop also has a good choice of interesting books and stationery.

Frick. What a gem, we only found out about the Frick during a bus tour. A little peace and quiet in the hurly burly of NYC. Some amazing original paintings by Goya, Rembrant, El Greco, Constable and Turner. Wow! The house itself is beautiful too
French Excellence. If you are a fan of French antiques, grandeur and sublime beauty, then this is worth the visit. A small intimate museum, not too many people with enough room to enjoy the sites.

Great little art gallery. If you have limited time in New York go here in preference to the larger galleries. Mr Frick sounds like a pretty unpleasant character, but he lived in a lovely house on Central Park, and collected one or two works by pretty much every painter you've ever heard of. The world of art in microcosm.
Great experience. Spent a couple of hours looking at some great art. Audio tour very good. Small shop and no refreshments available.

What a hidden treat!. This outstanding art collection is housed in the former home of Henry Frick (1849 - 1919) and his wife on Fifth Avenue. Tranquil environment and beautiful grounds makes it the perfect place to view the wonderful art of Bellini, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Goya and Whistler. Also wonderful sculptures and artifacts. Much more intimate and slower paced than the larger museums. Enjoyed every minute!

Living the dream on Fifth Avenue. We are both not art lovers and normally wouldn't rush to a museum like this. However friends had recommended and we where not disappointed.It is a beautiful museum and gives you an glimpse of how the other half live!There is amazing pieces of art everywhere and the audio tools really help us get the most out of the experience.

You do not need to be a great art lover to see this. I went there with my husband who is not very interested in art but even he loved this. Great combination of art and history. I think this is a must to see if you visit New York.

It like living on Fifth Avenue for a few hours. I've lived near Manhattan all my life and never went to this museum. Last February my husband surprised me for our 40th wedding anniversary and booked a wonderful hotel to stay at for a long weekend. We've toured so many places in Europe,the US and cruised the Caribbean but we were never tourists in NY. It was so wonderful to have this opportunity to see through the eyes of a tourist how wonderful this city so close to me really is. And going to the Frick mansion and seeing the wonderful art works is really a great treat. Besides the wonderful collection of art, the mansion itself is a wonderful insight into another era of how the wealthy lived and the opulence of the time. It's right across from Central Park on 5th avenue. So treat yourself and go fantasize about living there, the lavish life style and picture yourself living among all the wonderful art
Greatest small gallery ever. The quality of the Frick Collection is beyond compare. More great art per step than anywhere if ever visited.

Frick Collection is fabulous!. The Frick Collection is fascinating and astonishing. Learn about the life of Henry Frick in the detailed audio tour. The house is amazing as is the art collection. See the room where TS Elliot read poetry and be amazed by the history. I'm looking forward to our visit to NYC in January again and The Frick will be on top of my list.

A Great Small Museum. This museum is not just about the art - as great as it is, it is about being able to observe the art by meandering through the rooms of an authentic gilded age mansion filled with beautiful furniture. The collection includes works by artists ranging from Rembrandt, and Vermeer to Bellini, Gainsborough, Goya, Fragonard and Whistler. It also has a reflecting pool where you can sit, relax and try to absorb what you have seen. There is a fee, but admission is free on Sundays during certain hours.Children under 10 are not admitted to the collection.
A fantastic collection. I loved this gallery. The range and quality of the art and furniture is fabulous. It's not so big, so you can enjoy it all.
Frick. The Frick Museum is a wonderful example of one man's philanthropy. An astonishing collection of art in the home of this great man.

Best Private Collection in the City. I was very impressed with this extensive collection, housed within the original walls of a gorgeous estate. There is no better way to see these pieces of art and furniture, than the spaces they were originally commissioned for. Whether you are an art lover or just looking for a way to kill an hour or two, I highly recommend visiting the Frick and taking the Audio Tour.
Fabulous Frick. We always enjoy a visit to the Frick. It is a museum full of top notch art without the viewer feeling overloaded and much as it was in Mr Frick's day.

Art Treasure Trove New York City. This is a jewel in the crown of NY Museums and Art Galleries. Amazing collection of European Art. Beautifully presented and well laid out Museum. One of the highlights of our trip to NY.

Best museum we have ever seen. This has got to be the best collection of artwork, clocks, furniture, etc that I have ever seen. I was overcome by the home, the calm, quiet and sheer brilliance of this collection. By far the best attraction we visited in New York.
Frick in Autumn. Small and accessible, fantastic building and art collection. Good value and well located close to Central Park

Fabulous collection. This museum has beautiful European art exceptionally displayed and a pleasure to view in a very special setting. The collection is small and not too overwhelming so an experience too enjoy at leisure.
Arts and beautiful house. As well as arts displayed, it is worthy seeing the house itself. I liked a small garden In the middle of the house.

Fabulous Collection!. This is one of the loveliest museums in NYC. Housed in the grand home of a rather unseemly character in his day, Mr. Frick amassed and now shares some of the finest art in the world.
The furnishings along with the art create such a delightful museum experience. Free on Sundays from 11-5

One of my favorfite museums.... ever!. Bellinis' St. Francis in the Desert, Chinese porcelain, the inner courtyard, library, and furnishings make this visit to The Frick one of my favorite museums ever. Private collections turned museums feel like getting a secret glimpse into a different world. We went during the free hours on Sunday (11am-1pm), waited maybe 5 minutes, gave a donation, and spent the next couple of hours joyously before heading to the Met, which felt too organized and sterile after leaving the warmth of the Frick. Go, go, go!!!

Very enjoyable. We wanted to visit at least one museum while in NYC and decided on The Frick because we had such a hectic schedule, we thought this museum would work out better since it is smaller and a short walk from our hotel. So glad we did. This is a beautiful collection of art and furnishings housed in a grand old home. Allow a few hours to savor the experience. Definitely worth a visit for anyone interested in art or history.

Amazing building, amazing art. The world's a better place thanks to people like Henry Clay Frick. The museum was his home, and the collection is (mostly) his awesome personal collection. Renoir, El Greco, Titian, Gainsborough, Turner, and many many more, in a building that is itself a work of art, and pretty much as it was when it was the Frick family home. Would be wonderful to see the rest of the building, not just the ground floor. Smallish collection but very manageable - not an exhausting visit. Spend a bit of time just sitting in the courtyard near the fountain - very relaxing.

A very very special house. I adore the Frick...the paintings are one man's passion for art that he wanted to enjoy so its mainly portraits and landscapes and still lifes. The Joining together of lost pairs like the Holbein T.Cromwell and T.Moore are so wonderful to behold all in their original setting unaffected by the later additions after Fricks death. Unmissable.

Small but powerful. By far one of the best & most eclectic museums. The house itself is a marvel to behold, particularly the main atrium water fountain. The artwork on display are some of the great masterpieces of the world. The clock display is a marvel to behold,especially because some of the 16th & 17th century pieces still work.

Allow plenty of time. This is an amazing collection which although small relative to the Met still takes a while to enjoy properly. Security will require all backpacks and large bags to be checked in. There is a small gift shop with items relating to the collect. The only negative is there is no food or drinks available on location so fill up before you go. If you want to view a number of masterpieces in a small area this is the place to do it.

Great collection!. If you want to see what it's like to live during the Gilded Age plus see a wonderful collection of art from the Masters, this is the place to go! It's a great size museum and a wonderful setting. If you go between 11am and 1pm on Sundays, admission is "give what you like." MUST SEE!
A Bonanza of Masterpieces. We were overwhelmed by the number of masterpieces and sculptures on display. This private museum is a must see. A beautiful building on the upper east side.
Enjoyable. Not as good as the Met but an impressive building nevertheless. An interesting collection of art and sculpture.

Excellent Collection and Setting. The Frick Collection came highly recommended to us and we really enjoyed its lovely setting (the Frick Mansion) and the unique collection. It has a relatively small number of paintings, sculptures and antique clocks which allows you to savour the works within about 1.5 hours without museum fatigue. You then can go for a walk in Central Park to round out the experience. I really enjoyed the portrait artists such as Winslow Homer, Gainsborough and Hogarth. It is definitely worth a visit.
Outstanding. Wow what a treat! Tis could be my favorite New York museum. Outstanding collection, and gorgeous property.

Worth visiting for the house and art. The house itself is worth a visit. Make sure you pick up the free audio guide, which has appropriate, concise descriptions and is easy to use. It's certainly an amazing collection- with lots of examples from many parts of the world. The clocks are a bit different and are supported by interesting background information.
