Not cheap, but worth the money to enjoy on a non- crowded day. We had a short conversation with a knowledgeable docent/ guide and would have taken a tour if we'd had time.

Loved, loved, loved. I'm a bit of an art history nerd, but I think this collection is accessible to everyone. The home, which was Frick's, displays the collection he built up over the years. The building is stunning and there is plenty to see, but it isn't overwhelming and can be seen in an afternoon. I think the Met can be too much if you have a limited amount of time and don't want to be rushed trying to fit in seeing every piece. There's also a beautiful courtyard area. When I went in December, this was the perfect oasis to sit and relax.

Very nice.. Lovely collection and a very nice gift shop. We enjoyed it very much and will return again. Not a kid friendly place though. We did not have kids with us but others did and it looked nerve wracking.

Well worth a visit. Smallish do-able museum visit within 2-3 hours with very good audio presentation . The Audio is a must as it provides the backdrop / reasons behind the various acquisitions . Lovely snippets of info / lovely, serene and peaceful house.

Great Setting. Lovely art in a perfect setting. It is fun to walk around, enjoying the art in what used to be someone's home. The Frick Collection never seems to be as crowded as other museums and a smaller collection for those who get overwhelmed at the MET or MOMA.

An amazing collection of one man's passion. The museum was the private residence of Henry Clay Frick, the infamous coke and steel baron It's first floor rooms are filled with a stunning collection of masterpieces of art. The two Vermeers are worth the price of admission alone. The size of the museum makes for a pleasant afternoon as one strolls among some of the most famous pieces of Western Art.

Architecture, bronze sculptures and clocks. The Frick Museum provides a nice varied collection of paintings from artists including Rembrandt, El Greco, Goya, Renoir, Boucher, etc. There are also many beautiful bronze sculptures and a room full of clocks. What we enjoyed most though was the architecture and furnishings of the house. Allow yourself a couple of hours for your visit. The Frick is across the street from Central Park on the East side. If you drive, there are parking structures a few blocks away on 73rd between Lexington and Third. You'll have a nice walk through pretty neighborhoods full of upscale shops, businesses and flats. We had a picnic in the Park before our museum visit and were able to store our bags in the cloakroom which was very convenient. A great way to spend part of an afternoon in NYC.

Great Museum. Both the building (Frick's house, built in 1914 or so) and the painting collection are terrific. Unlike some private collections, this one has first-rate paintings by first-rate artists (Vermeer, Rembrandt, Constable, etc.) This shouldn't be missed. It's very close to the Met.

See beautiful art, paintings, sculpture in luxe old NYC mansion. Imagine a gorgeous old mansion housing a wealthy millionaire's fabulous range of paintings, sculpture, clocks and other furnishings just off Fifth Avenue and this is the Frick Collection. The mansion and its treasure within once belonged to Henry Frick, a wealthy industrialist with excellent taste and deep pockets for collecting fine art to display in his spacious mansion. Now yours to enjoy! Small enough to see within 1-2 hours if you're pressed for time, but rich enough in depth and scope if you have the time to linger at length in each of the beautifully appointed rooms. There's nothing quite like entering a beautiful old room and not knowing whether to first look at the carved wood paneling, admire the floor coverings, study the paintings, check out the Chinese vases, notice the statues and clocks, or look at the lovely antique furniture! We went on a Sunday between 11-1 when you can pay what you think is fair. Just off Fifth Ave in the museum mile near Central Park, it is well signposted with helpful staff. You will need to check large bags etc in the cloakroom, and there's wheelchairs available if you need mobility assistance. All rooms are on the ground floor and the restrooms are accessed below stairs. If you are "museumed out" suggest you still make time for the Frick Collection, or if you have limited time, still squeeze in the Frick Collection - you won't regret it.

If you only have time for one museum - go here!. The Frick has an amazing collection of art & furnishings all displayed in the most amazing old NYC mansion built by Frick himself with the idea that it would one day be a museum. Pay as you wish on Sundays from 11am - 1pm.

A Must See. Small, easily walkable, great location, wonderful collection. Pictures you have seen in books, artists you learned about in school, rooms and other spaces that are art in themselves, audio guide included in admission (and worth using). Go see it.

Sunday, Pay as you wish, 11am-1pm. Our group paid $40 at the Pay As You Wish Sunday, 11am-1pm. Fabulous home complete with beautiful art, furniture, sculptures, gardens, watch and clock collection. Small enough that you are not exhausted from trying to see everything. Really a nice visit for us.
Beautiful setting. Absolutely lovely works of art displayed in an elegant house. This collection demonstrated the wealth of New Yorkers.

Wonderful. What a find! This magnificent former family mansion was a total joy to explore. The art is incredible, better than many traditional museums. Would have loved to explore the upstairs rooms, but access not permitted.

Gorgeous and unique. you feel as if you're in someone's home (which you are) and the art you see is magnificent. This is a high point if you're interested in art and an opportunity to see one of the great mansions of NYC.

Great little museum. This place is really good - we went early on a Sunday ( pay a donation to enter if you wish ) and it was a fabulous 2 hours looking at great art, in a beautiful house. The free tape with headsets was informative and helpful, without being too verbose.
Very nice smaller museum. Designed in a private house, this exhibition elicits a large sample of various centuries, worth both the house and the museum

stunning private collection and house. experience a unique visit in a unique "house".
I have been there several times and for a few hours, you are in a peaceful environment.
The collection is stunning and they have masterpieces. I really appreciated the watched section as well.

Staggering private collection. A beautiful mansion housing one man's private collection. Imagine having works by just about all the famous painters you can think off having on your very own walls! We took advantage of the Sunday 11 to 1 pay what you want, and had to queue for about 20 minutes, so if time is tight go another time and pay full price. It will be worth it,I only wish the upstairs was open too, No children under 10 by the way.

Great 2 hours spent. The artwork here is absolutely spectacular, great Masters. In one room alone there were 3 Rembrandts, 2 Turners and 1 Constable!! And lots more! The house itself is magnificent and as you walk around, you have a sense of what it would be like to live in such a luxurious mansion. It is $20 per adult but if you go on Sunday between 11:00 - 1:00 pm you only pay what you want! Make sure you get the electronic tour guide as it is free and gives a good account of what you are looking at.

Great museum--in someone's house. To really get understand why it was called The Gilded Age, see this museum, which is in Mr. Frick's house! (As my husband said, "that Renoir was the perfect choice for the empty wall by the staircase."). Because the paintings were essentially the centerpiece of the mansion's decor, they are not all arranged by genre, artist, period, etc. So don't give up after you've seen the two Vermeers in the hallway (opposite the Renoir)...there's another one in another room (3 Vermeers! Holy cow!). (The exception is the watch and clock hallway.) The Frick is walking distance from the Met, but it is not as heavily trafficked, and is therefore much quieter (great!). A comprehensive and surprising collection--if possible, study up on what's there before you go so you don't inadvertently miss anything (due to the way the paintings are arranged). I didn't have children along, but I believe the Frick is not open to small children (and rightly so).
Amazing collection in someone's house!. The eclectic range of art on show. Beautiful house well beyond its time. A haven in the museum mile.
go to the Frisk. Loved that the collection was in a house. There were paintings I'd only seen in books and it wasn't super crowded.

World Class Museum Housed in New York History. The Frick Collection houses a magnificent collection of European paintings, sculptures, eighteenth century French furniture and an excellent collection of porcelain. Housed in the home of Henry Clay Frick on East 70th the setting enhances the collection enormously as you can get a rare glimpse of how these pieces were intended to be displayed and used - not in museums but in the homes of collectors as integral parts of their residences and lives. Recently the portico was enclosed to create the new portico gallery. I most highly recommend spending a day at the Frick Collection - it is illumining, educational and most rewarding.

This one you have to see. An unbelievable collection of great paintings in a museum just the right size for an afternoon's visit. The best Rembrandt I have ever seen, one of the finest El Grecos, Holbeins , Ingrers, Whistlera, three Vermeers, etc. It's incredible that anyone with that much money had that much taste! If you love great art,go for it. You won't be diosappointed.

A hidden Gem. Museum is on corner or Fifth St and E 72 St. We comfortably walked from subway station on 68 St (6 line) to the entrance which is in E72 St. in about 10 minutes.Recommend purchasing the acoustic guide with the entrance ticket; as usual it makes the the whole experience far better.This is an eclectic personal collection of amazing furniture & art , housed in a magnificent building (modified original house). Recommend watching the movie in the music room before you tour the museum.

Wow what a building. We caught the subway from Grand Central to 79th Street (or a number close) it had snowed the night before and Central Park was closed but peeking over the fence it looked beautiful. We were going to the Frick not for the Art but for the building, just in awe that this was someone's house and we weren't disappointed. The art was pretty exciting also especially the room with the two Turners on opposite walls lighting up the room.Back to the view of Central Park, wow what a view Mr Frick had from his front rooms and we didn't even get to the second storey. The music room is a dream and showing a very informative video of the collection a good thing to do first.Handsets for each piece of art kept the kids amused as they entered random numbers and then tried to find the artwork from the description.

Don't miss this treasure. I was very impressed with this gem. A great collection of impressive art in a beautiful part of history in the city. A very beautiful collection of pieces worth the visit. Each room brings a new find, many pieces I have never seen before. Beautiful rooms left untouched through history. Add to your list of "Don't Miss' places in New York.

An interesting place and collection. I only just heard about this place and was fascinated that such a rare treasure still exists. The artwork is amazing and the indoor pool and fountain is beautiful. It would have been nice to be able to explore the garden area as well as that looked lovely but it seems that was off limits to the general public.

Lovely collection in an impressive building. The Frick museum houses some very impressive artworks; in particular I very much liked the portrait of Mr Frick. Equally impressive as the art however is the beautiful building, a converted apartment/terrace, in which it is housed. Worth a visit just for the building! Recommended.

A wonderful private collection. A coal magnate built this Romanesque palace to house his private art and sculpture collection.It a jaw dropping lay beautiful in every way.It is worth taking time to take in the small theatre where relevant films are shown.

What a gem. This is a gem of a museum, with such beautiful paintings, in a quiet region of old Manhattan mansions. Its a wonderful feeling to just walk about the place, and take in the feel of it, especially when its mostly empty.

My Favorite of all New York Art Museums. I always go to the Frick when in New York. My Aunt & Uncle used to live 2 blocks away and took me there for the first time in 1978 when I was in 7th garde, and I have been enthralled with it ever since. Originally built as a private home, it was never used by the family. It is a very interessting story behind the Ruthless Industrial Magnet who was Mr.Frick.I suggest learning the history of the buildng before going. You don't need a full day there, but I would suggest 3-5 hours, depending on how much you like to study the artwork.
Wonderful house of paintings!. We went round this museum- it was wonderful to see so many paintings displayed alongside each other. Well worth a visit!

Now see the real thing. The Frick is full of paintings and sculptures that you have seen in books. Going to the Frick gives you the opportunity to see the real thing up close and personal. The collection is housed in Frick's mansion, and that alone is worth visiting. Admission includes a very good audio tour. This is a self guided tour so you can determine how much time you want to spend here. The Holbein portraits of Thomas Moore and Cromwell alone, are worth the admission price.

Nice surprise. I have been to NYC a number of times but only read about the Frick Collection via Tripadvisor recently. Very glad we visited it as it is one of the most impressive monuments of the American gilded age. Definitely worth a visit for anyone interested in art or history. Our only regret was the music room was under renovation so we missed the movie that would have been a good introduction of the place.

I enjoyed it. A wonderful building.... I can't imagine someone having lived there though! But wow, what a collection of art! The entranceway with the little pool was so beautiful, it's a shame you can't take photos! The movie that plays is also very interesting and I would recommend watching it to learn about Frick and his history in NYC.

World Class Collection Beautifully Displayed. A beautiful collection of masterpieces from 13th & 14th sacred art, English Portraiture, Turner & Constable landscapes, a couple of Rembrandt's, one amazing Holbein, two VerMeer jewels and much more. Many of these masterpieces and grand in scale and they are appropriately and beautifully displayed in galleries with grand proportions and much natural lighting. Tips: the Ladies Room is down stairs. There is a handicapped toilet on the main level, but it is hidden back in the galleries - so be sure to ask directions if stairs are an issue for you.
A museum in a Manor !. I liked everything about this Museum. I visit it everytime I am in NYC. Do not miss it ! It is like entering a Manor of the last century.

Stunning collection. Mr Frick had great taste in art. This mansion turned to museum is full of extraordinary paintings from Rembrant, Vermeer, Turner, Renoir, etc. Take the audio guides (they're free): it really helps appreciating the paintings. There is also a great collection of clocks and pocket watches and a beautiful courtyard. Some of the rooms still have the original furniture and give you an idea of how the extremely rich lived in the 19th. It's obvious that Mr Frick loved to be surrounded by beauty.Not recommended for children, OK for teens if they are into art or history.

Unbelievable Art Collection in Former Private Home. Visited The Frick Collection today.Hard to believe all of these beautiful paintings were one man's passion. Placement in his private home lends an intimacy hard to beat. Vermeers and Rembrandts line the walls. This museum is a Must See!

Full of good stuff. Been to new York many times but never the Frick. we were impressed that it was so full of stunning art work. Normally you get a couple of classics. these are all classics and in a stunning building. Well located just off central park

Beautiful but expensive. They would have more people visiting this beautiful collection if prices were slightly more reasonable It was pretty empty this weekday afternoon in August. Anyway....We enjoyed it and it's Wonderful collection. The audioguide is OK and does help to understand the house better. A 'must' in NYC but maybe not for everyone's budget.

An island of beauty and quiet. I have visited the Frick Collecting more than once but I keep going back. This little museum is so well taken care of and the staff is so kind that is a real pleasure to go visit again. You can spend an hour admiring beautiful painting and furniture without the chaos you find in other NY museums, the most of the tourists haven’t discovered it yet, so you can stroll through the rooms in total quiet. It is really a little jewl, not to be missed.

Beautiful little museum. A treasure of a museum. You can see it all in about an hour to hour and half. Be sure to look at the rooms themselves as we'll as the art. The only downside was we could not go into the gardens

Old Masters in a Grand Home. The Frick Collection was the most unique museum we experienced on our trip to New York City. It was as if we had been invited to tea in a 1914 mansion of a industrial baron. The house was built to showcase his collection of Old Masters and exquisite antique furnishings remain to add to the experience. We all enjoyed our time and recommend it .

Don't Miss it!!. Smaller museum - especially when compared with nearby MET. But that's what makes it easier to see, easier to tour, and easier to appreciate. Great collection of old world paintings paired with an exquisite furniture and setting.

Wonderful exhibition!. Very complete exhibition with wonderful pieces! The house is quite lovely itself. Enjoyed very much this museum and think it is an ideal presentation of great art and not too much to be overwhelmed. Highly recommended!

House plus fabulous collection are a winner. This venerable institution had been on my "someday" list for many years. I am happy to say that I enjoyed it immensely when I finally went & I wish I had made time sooner. The setting for exhibiting the art shows it to its best advantage. Fans of Whistler's portraits of fashionable women will be rewarded with a small room featuring several ravishing examples. Don't skip the film about Mr. Frick & about the building of the house & the later conversion to museum. This is a slice of New York history that adds to your enjoyment of the city. The gift shop has an interesting array of books & some other unusual items.

Second visit and still blown away.. I first visited the Frick Collection years ago as part of a school trip. Years later, I am still in awe at the amazing collection of original artwork this beautiful building houses. Have a seat on one of the stone benches in the private garden for a nice end to the tour. The architecture of the house is enough to capture anyone's attention.

Unusual private collection. The building was just beautiful, full of old world charm. This is a private home and collection given to the City of New York. It also has a visiting exhibition from time to time. We loved the ambience. We are glad we did not miss it. Near Central Park on the museum mile.
The Audio Guide made our visit. An outstanding collection in a beautiful old NY mansion off Central Park. Make sure you get the audio guide - it added so much to the paintings.
Wonderful museum. Amazing mansion, fabulous paintings, intriguing bronzes and fascinating furniture..would recommend to future travelers to NYC.
THE FRICK HOUSE!!!. What a beautiful home! The art was amazing, too. We visited for Christmas. I would highly recommend stopping here.

Worth it. Was hesitant about going there, after all the ticket for entry is not cheap. But definitely worth it.I don't want to spoil for you but this place has a lot of interesting history and the collection is fascinating. The fountain inside is mesmerizing. The collection is pretty too and colorful (from the paintings to the stunning sculptures). The rooms have a nice classic decor.The staff are courteous and there wasn't a long queue.

Great art, building, service and experience!. I cannot recommend the Frick Collection enough. The art on display is exceptional, but that in itself is only half the story: the collection is housed in what used to be the house where some of it belonged (the house itself being an impressive exhibit in its own right) and it is very refreshing to see all of this very interesting art without the usual gallery/museum categorisations and silos (Renaissance next to impressionist, next to a Far Eastern vase). Add an extremely comprehensive audio guide, very helpful staff and a very civilised crowd compared to the chaos of Guggenheim, Met, MoMA and this adds up to a great experience. Very highly recommended.
Poor. Nice and boring pantings but the real downer is very unchildfriendly. They wont let anyone under ten in. I would recomend it for people who like classic pantings and old oeople

Well worth a visit.. If you have a spare day in NYC this is a lovely collection to see, unfortunately as this is privately owned collection photography is not permitted. Many unique items - especially time (clocks) pieces. Entry fee may be a bit pricey compared to other galleries in the city.
Small but Precious. Not populist but brilliant. Small collection but priceless works of art worth looking at with leisure and without being rushed. Incredible.

Great collection of art. Frick Collection is definitely one of the best one collected by individual.Located just few minutes from Central Park is really worth visiting.Would recommend to go there early in the morning when it's not too busy and you can find a free parking space.The museum has a really good display of Italian renaissance religious paintings as well as great examples of French Impressionism.You can get an earphone and listen to a tape with tour guide recording in many different languages so it is quite handy and allows you to move around the museum quite freely.Was on top of my sightseeing list in NYC and think it was a great choice

Lovely collection in a serene atmosphere. I love seeing the Vermeers at this museum. This was the home of Henry Clay Frick so the collection is displayed as if in a private home, with furnishings and books on view also. When I was there they had a beautiful exhibit of watches and clocks. There is a wonderful indoor courtyard with pool, where you can just relax. It never seems crowded, maybe because the admission price is a bit steep at $20. Worth a visit.

Wonderful Collection. This is a fantastic collection of artwork from industrial tycoon Henry Clay Frick housed in a historic setting. The renaissance and 19th century paintings are a treasure and wonderful examples of the artistic developments of each artistic era. The atmosphere can be a bit stuffy and there aren't many opportunities for children or large groups. Opportunities for engagement and discussion with museum education staff are stellar and highly recommended!
Small yet beautiful. An oasis of calm amid the chaos of the busy NYC art scene. Fabulous building holding a treasure chest of priceless artworks.
Beautiful museum. Just a great way to spend the day! The house is amazing and the artwork was fantastic. Highly recommend for anyone that enjoys antiques and paintings. Go and enjoy!!!
Good on a Sunday morning. Great to see the inside of a 5th Avenue house, and went on a Sunday morning when its free. Good opportunity to walk through central park and go visit.

A must see for Art Lovers. Step back in history in a grand old New York Home that was dedicated from the beginning to become a museum. You can start to envy one man's passion for collecting art of Old Masters.

Where else can you see Stuart Gilbert and Whistler hangig out together?. This is the best art gallery I have ever seen! The paintings seem to be in no particular order but each is spectacular in its own rigth. taken together, with the beauty of the building itself, it is awe inspiring. There is way too much art here to really take it all in in a mere hour or two. Save at least three or four, or risk missing a lot.

Small but good. I loved this museum - it is a collection of art and antiques in a previously lived in NY Residence. I am not normally a person to spend hours wandering thru museums but I did enjoy this collection.
A gem!. We visit yearly this gem of a museum. We love every room. This is a mini Met, cozy, rich, enchanting. If the (fab) Met is overwhelming this is a second d best.
Fabulous Frick. Beautiful paintings in a beautiful settings - Holbeins, Titians, Constables, Monet, Turners, El Greco. Not to be missed
A real collection of chef d'ouevre. Great collection, not very exhausting, every visitor is provided with audio guide, it is a must see sight.

LOVE THE FRICK!. The Frick is a wonderful place to visit a less overwhelming collection of art than the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The house alone is worth seeing. Make sure you use the audio device as you walk through the museum. It is definitely worth going to.

Wonderful museum. I've been to the Frick a dozen times and it never ceases giving me pleasure. It's the perfect size for a museum if you don't want to feel overwhelmed and the collection is simply beautiful And in a perfect setting. I think it might be a great way to introduce a youngster to art museums.

Another free jewel of NYC. This collection and its setting are splendid. Go on Sunday AM when it's free entry from 11:00 to 1:00. If you plan to be there when it opens, be ready to wait in line. Usually it moves quickly and after the initial rush, it quiets down a little inside. Definitely read up ahead on their website. They have lots of rules, like no small children and no photos. But when you are moving about among the absolute treasures on view here, you will understand why they try so hard at the Frick to preserve the feeling of an elegant private home. And don't pass up the free audio guide. It adds so much.The collection of paintings is outstanding: Bronzini, Van Dyke, Sargent, Holbein, etc. Take you time, sit when you can, and enjoy.

Amazing collection. The collection and home were equally stunning. Worth the $20 entrance fee. It took us about 1 1/2 hours to see everything. Be sure to use the free device to listen to a description about all the artwork and the home.

Best museum in new york. Truly great collection of mostly European art. It is small and maintains a consistently high level of quality through out. Pesonalvfavourite was an orginal painting placed along side an copy , truely showing the differrance between art and mere mechanical reproduction. Well worth going to.

Mansion of art collector that only lived there 5years before his death. very nice to be able to see main floor of someone house in NY , great collection of paintings, including Rembrand , Cezanne , collection of asian china , go on Sunday between 11- 1pm where you pay what you wish , worth seeing 10min movie explaining his idea of making a museum of his house , one thing , no pictures so its hard to remember what you just seen after seeing 19 different room, halls, galleries in this mansion, no children allowed under 10

Gem in the City. This is one of the finest private collections in the world. I was so surprised to see how many master pieces there were. The more one visits art museums, the more one understands that not all great artists' works are 'master pieces'. In this case, Frick Collection has shown us what a truly great collection it has. In addition to that, the museum itself is also a piece of art. Highly recommended to all art lovers!

Remarkable masterpieces of painting and clockmaking. Use a reciprocal membership if you have one.. The Frick does not admit anyone under the age of 10 which is inconvenient for people traveling with kids, but a nice respite for those of us without.Admission is expensive. If you're a member of a museum check and see if they have a NARM reciprocal membership arrangement. We used that for free admission, although the volunteer staffing the desk seemed to have an issue with the fact that our membership cards had the NARM logo printed on them permanently rather than just having a little sticker stuck on.The included audio guide is excellent. Use it often as it adds context to entire rooms in the house in addition to the objects on display. While some of the paintings are merely pretty there are some masterpieces on display, including three Vermeers and two El Grecos and some Holbeins. A small exhibit on clocks is also fascinating.A lovely small museum.

FAVORITE Museum in NYC. The Frick Collection is definitely worth visiting. I don't recall what I said first, "..Wow" or "Can this be my house?" Either way, this museum is absolutely gorgeous. No photography? How can I resist with all this Victorian furniture around me!? The attendants were everywhere, I couldn't even sneak one in. The admission for adults is $18 and I would highly suggest taking the portable voice guide as it describes all the paintings which are number coordinated. Mr. Frick was definitely a baller. Titian? Van Dyck? Rembrandt? I was blown away by his collection and these masterpieces. Also beautiful were all the 16th century furniture pieces and overall décor. So European and fabulous. The music room and the 'garden' in the middle were both highlights. note: if you have to use the bathroom, please go ahead. They have beautiful individual vanities if you need to touch up.

Free to roam!. If you have the chance go see this wonderful collection. Unbelievably you can look at rare and beautiful objects close up without any obvious restriction and if you love paintings well this is the place. All displayed as a lived in palatial home. Excellent audio tour.
Great. Beautiful small museum with great images and very impressive building.Highly recommended if you love art and atmosphere of the 19th century.

Go with the Met. It's only a 12mins walk from the Metropolitan Museum, so you might want to visit both on the same day. I'm not a fan of paintings, so I didn't find The Frick Collection exceptional (mostly paintings, and more paintings). On Sunday mornings, between 11 a.m. and 1 p.m, it's pay as you wish, so you might want to drop by if you are in the vicinity.

Pricey admission, but great. You're paying euro-museum prices here, but you're seeing a big bang attraction that puts most small museums in Europe to shame. Great if you're doing Central Park and want a little plush cultural class in the mix. The guards do indeed hover, but not offensively so. People have been complaining about the Frick's snobbery forever, but they're right to protect it's legacy. I sort of like that they don't care one whit whether you come in or not.But a couple of hours to see it? Only if you take a nap there (don't even think about it). 40 minutes at the absolute outside will do it for anyone who's not a beaux arts scholar.

Old money buys nice stuff. Very impressive home and collection! Well worth spending the afternoon enjoying the building and the furniture. Maybe our grand kids will get the same experience touring Bill Gates house in Seattle someday?

Go see Frick Collection. Family visited Frick after a hectic run through the Met. What a relief! Walking distance from the MMA and delightful. More time to pause, reflect and admire. Great story behind the man who built the mansion and collection for anyone who loves the great American story.

Worth a second visit. I first visited the Frick museum 4 years ago, so it was time to revisit this highlight of New York City. The house itself captures the elegance of New York living on 5th Ave, especially the internal colonnades, the oval room, the staircase. The art collection is superb - key pieces from such a broad range of artists, including the wonderful display of Whistler works in the oval room. As well, the collection of clocks and their accompanying descriptions is so interesting. Well worth every cent to get into this museum.

I usually resist art galleries and museums when on holiday, but.... The Frick Collection lives up to all the great reviews. It is unlike any gallery or museum I have ever visited, in both presentation and content. The building itself is a star attraction, and the main exhibits are presented in their original locations: the Dining room and Library are staggering creations. We spent nearly three hours at the Frick, including 20 minutes for the video presentation which you should try to see before going round (we didn't, and wished we had 'cos it gives a good insight to the man). The exhibition of clocks and watches was a particular favourite of mine.
Great. This museum is a brownstone donated with art to the city, google and read the history. Really nice small collection, live music one night a week.
Beautiful, truly rare and special collection.. This is a top 3 quality museum in New York, and not very crowded. If you need to be selective, go here. You won't be dissappointed.

Must visit!. This museum was love at first sight! Every time i go to NYC, i can't leave without visiting the Frick Collection. It is a mansion filled with an amazing private collection of art masterpieces and precious objects. It is small and doable in a couple of hours. You're in for a visual treat if you go!

Warning- no kids allowed.. We made the trek to the Frick Collection based on reviews here on trip advisor only to be told at the door that children under ten are not admitted. Although I had referenced the Frick Collection's webs site several times I saw no notice of this policy. It is buried three pages into the web site under Admission. We also heard the guard telling patron's they could not lean against the walls. Obviously this is a hands off environment and probably not one I would want to visit even with teenagers. This is an unusual policy that should be front and center on the museum's home page. Very disappointed in the fact that children are not allowed and even more disappointed their lack of up front communication about this policy.

Awesome Gilded Age Mansion. The Frick Collection is located on Fifth Avenue between East 70th and East 71st Streets. It is across the street from Central Park and about 10 blocks south of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Frick is one of the great small art museums in America, with a quality collection of old master paintings and fine furniture housed in the former mansion of steel magnet Henry Clay Frick. Most of the collection was assembled by Mr. Frick before he died in 1919. The house is one of the few remaining Gilded Age mansions left on Fifth Avenue.Frick died in 1919 and in his will left the house and all of the furnishings and art to the public in a gallery (his old mansion) called The Frick Collection. In his will, his wife was allowed to live in the house the rest of her life. Following the death of his wife in 1931, the Frick Collection was opened to the public as a museum in 1935.I went to this museum on a Saturday afternoon in May with my wife and oldest daughter and really enjoyed it. Admission is generally $10 but on Sundays from 11 AM – 1 PM you pay what you want. The museum was generally not very crowded. While the art is great I really enjoyed looking at the awesome gilded age mansion. I liked looking at Frick’s mansion more than the priceless art. In addition, there was a great temporary Impressionist exhibit in the basement with works from Degas to Toulouse-Lautrec. I really liked Monet’s Caricature of a Man with a Snuff Box. One of several caricatures he made to earn a living at the beginning of his career. I also liked the interesting clocks and watches on display.In summary, I really enjoyed the mansion and the Frick Collection and recommend it. My only complaint was that the security guards were a little over the top. They were very strict about checking your coat or wearing it (you could not carry it). At one point a guard came up to my daughter and told her she was too close to a painting and needed to back off (I think she was pointing to it and her finger was over some imaginary line).

another must in New York. Beautiful collection, tastefully displayed in this smaller museum in NY. But absolutely worth the entrance fee and the time. However maybe less interesting for the general public and more a place for the lovers of fine art. Unique opportunity to experience the wealth and taste of the NY elite of the beginning of the 20th century.

Beautiful art and venue but overpriced and dreadful staff. If the adjective, "effete" required an exemplary picture in the dictionary, the Frick Collection would fit the bill: $20 admission for what is a relatively small collection; no one under 10 years of age allowed under any circumstances; no cameras, no umbrellas, no bags, no nothing. Henry Frick was not known for kindness, and the legacy lives on in the currently-hired staff of Art Nazis. For the 90 minutes it took me to go through, I heard patrons corrected/yelled at/what-have-you in a manner that was embarrassing and unprofessional on every level...including a young woman who merely wanted to sit down on the marble steps of the garden/fountain area and enjoy..nope..not allowed...move along, move along. Only one of the employees kindly welcomed the patrons to his area with a smile and gave directions cheerfully. The collection is impressive, but I'd rather spend another $5 and walk north to the Met, where you get the bang for the buck on every artistic and human. Once at the Frick was enough.
A Gem. Beautiful and relatively unknown art collection just a few blocks from the MET. For art lovers only. A glimpse into the choices of a collector with good taste.

A gem of a museum: small but valuable.. The Frick mansion is an awesome but intimate venue for this astounding collection. Every piece is wonderful. There are Vermeers and Rembrandts and Turners and Sargeants, etc. all in a gorgeous former home with a lovely garden and interior courtyard.
Superb collection in Frick's beautiful home. This is well worth a visit whether you are a lover of art or architecture or just want to see inside a stately 5th Avenue home.
excellent and beautiful. we loved this collection. it was amazing to be in a room filled with beautiful art and overwhelming to be in a room with Rembrandt self portrait!

a place you must visit. After the visit in Metropolitan the vist in Frick Collection creates sensation to admire small but very pretty collection ,with a perfect garden and waters and rare view paintings as Greco and others.

3 Vermeers, 2 Holbeins, a treasure not to miss.. What a beautiful home and so many treasures of Museum quality, the Fragonard room, the Bronzino, the Whistlers, it's overwhelming. Such beauty! The home itself offers beautiful and majectic perspectives.

Overpriced trip to the guilded age. The tickets were overpriced and the staff was pushy and unhelpful. The collection is impressive, but the surroundings are gaudy—a sickening monument to conspicuous consumption.

Great collector, great collection, great home. Much as the Jacquemart-Andre rather than the Louvre is many Parisians' Paris museum, the Frick is the New Yorker's New York museum. Beautifully displayed in the home of the coke magnate Henry Clay Frick (sometime partner and then most bitter enemy of Andrew Carnegie), the collection includes any number of stunning gems, among them a tragic late Rembrandt self portrait, Bellini's St. Francis receiving the stigmata, a brace of Vermeers, and -- speaking of mortal enemies -- Holbein's Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell looking balefully at each other from opposite ends of one wall. The house itself, artfully reconfigured as a museum while retaining fully the character of a home, is a huge part of the attraction. An accessible, economical and utterly fascinating experience, not to be missed.

Not my scene.... Went with some friends who are fans of the Frick. I found it pretty meh. It is basically the house of a 19th century industrialist who bought a bunch of art to prove he was more than just a 19th century industrialist.The Clocks and Watches exhibition was actually quite interesting, but that is a temporary exhibit. I am sorry Mr. Frick, but no matter how many boring 15th century Italian painting you bought, I will still remember you as a guy who hired the Pinkertons to break strikes by your workers.To summarize, bad guy, okay art.

Incredible, stunning collection. I liked the self tour option. You can choose to listen to the audio on a particular item or not. Each room tells a story. I was very impressed with the painting collection. Many famous painters! It was well worth the admission fee. I would see it again.
Terrific Museum. Nice layout, "do-able" in a dy or less too a real gem outside the usual tourist MOMA et al nice Courtard, old home exquisite layout of art work he owned

If I could turn back time.... From what I understand, Mr. Frick was a though man, but the house and art that he left behind and which compose today one of the most beautiful museums I have ever visited, is an indication of the sensitive man inside the rough exterior. To think that The Frick used to be a home is astonishing. We have been honored to attend two business receptions at The Frick and we were elated to walk its corridors covered in art and rich architecture from floor to ceiling and everywhere in between. I just wish they would allow entrance to some of the rooms upstairs. We highly recommend an afternoon at The Frick with your better half. Unless they are into art, which is not the case with our kids, I would leave the children home until they are at least 16.

Amazing collection. One of the best museums in NYC - a unique experience with a great story behind the collection. This is definitely worth an afternoon visit. Be sure to get the audio tour to hear the back story behind each room's arrangement.

A Gem and Definate Must!. This is a five star attraction with a major collection of European art from the 13th century on. The museum was not crowded (less than 100 visitors) when we were there in the late morning on a Wednesday in July. The collection consists almost entirely of world famous pieces. The Frick mansion is itself worth the visit. It is a wonderful example of New York's Gilded Era! Unique to the Frick compared to many museums, you are inches from each of these masterpieces.!

One Of My Favorites!. I can truly say that the Frick Collection has been one of my all time favorite museum for over 25 years! Why? Because, I love impressionists art, the collection is just enough to enjoy for a few hours and not overwhelming and you can see everything there. Te home is beautiful. Not to be missed in NYC.

Amazing collection, beautiful building. The frick collection offers a unique museum experience, it's small enough to cover in one visit without feeling overwhelmed or dizzy from lack of sunlight but it also has a great variety of masterpieces, furniture, figurines and paintings from all time periods and many famous masters. While the works are not curated periodically its a great space to visit.

decompress. Tired out by the city? Visit the Frick Museum to "unstress" Museum is set in the former Frick Mansion on Fifth Avenue but a world away.Quiet, peaceful and relaxing.Not overly crowded but filled with wonderful art.Very similar to another great museum,the Phillips Museum in DC

Small and Elegant Respite when the Crowds Drive you Crazy..... The Frick has it all: for voyeurs who want to see how one of New York's wealthiest patrons lived, you get to roam around the insanely beautiful (first floor) mansion of Henry Clay Frick himself. For art lovers - well, it doesn't get any better than this - everything from Vermeer and Rembrandt to Corot and Chardin....but the very very BEST of each, there's not a single dud in this collections. If it's quiet contemplation and respite you're after, the garden court is an oasis just steps off of 5th avenue. The Frick is another perfect gem of a museum (like the Tenement Museum in the Bowery or the nearby Neue Gallerie) that often gets jettisoned in favor of the "big" museums like the Met, MoMa, Whitney and Guggenheim....but don't miss this, it's one of the city's most special places, and lacking the crowds elsewhere...
Artists and Art. On certain Friday evenings, one can sketch old masters. Need to make reservations. Yhe area on Fifth Avenue around the museum is residential, quiet and lovely. Free admission.

One of the nicest mornings I have ever spent. Beautiful and peaceful.. I heard about the Frick collection from a friend, and was so glad for the recommendation. This is a wonderful collection of art in the most lovely setting. Every room is full of beautiful things, and all tastefully displayed with the rooms decorated with the particular paintings to be hung there in mind, which makes for a harmonious interior. There was an audio guide with information on almost every single painting which was very informative but still extremely accessible and friendly. So many beautiful things - and if you can manage to pass by the clock collection just as they are striking, that's a real treat. The courtyard garden is an oasis of peace just off 5th Avenue - if I lived or regularly visited New York I would definitely become a member just to have the privilege of dropping into this fabulous place as often as I could.

How the Other Half Lived. This is a living museum--one man's art collection in the home where he lived. Plus it has rotating exhibitions, some of them really spectacular. A tranquil place to spend several hours.
Jewel of a Museum. This is a splendid museum on Fifth Avenue. The home of a real robber baron who lived in great splendor

Intimate museum. This small museum gives a Big Bang for the Buck.....the Frick Mansion is a museum in itself, and the exhibitions of both in house and borrowed works are always of the highest quality.

Amazing museum.. Amazing museum. The museum is Frick's home which he built to showcase his art. Beautiful furniture,objets,and art. Very doable in 2 hours. One of my favorite museums in NYC and one too many people miss.

Smaller is better. A fantastic art gallery in a grand house. A big advantage is that it is not too big, so you can see everything before exhaustion sets in (which is not possible at the Met, for example).

Well worth a visit. The Frick Collection is a great destination for art lovers. I only wish it was bigger! As it is, it's a modest size museum and you probably see most of it in an hour (which is a plus if you are on a tight schedule).

the best little museum there is. For a great museum experience in New York, the Frick Museum is not to be missed. Set beautifully in the Frick Mansion, it shows the best of the personal collection of Mr. Frick. He clearly loved his collection and apparently often spent his evening just looking at his own art. Noticeably none of the pictures show any violence. I do not think the museum lets in children under 12

Best example of grand private houses in New York. This splendid house is the best sample of what grands living was in New York up to the late 1920's. Do take your visit or visits slowly and savour the miriad of wonderful things in this elegant house.

Calm and soothing; beautiful art, shown in an uncrowded environment. A huge relief from masses of tourists; open free to the public Sunday 11-1. Otherwise, definitely worth the price. And the interior gardens are maganificent.

So THIS is how the rich folk live.. This beautiful NY city mansion houses the Frick Collection displayed room by room, making one feel as though they've dropped in for a tea. It is absolutely gorgeous, and the courtyard is so cooling and relaxing. I've been there 2-3 times, at least once with teens, who were really fascinated. They don't let kids under 10 in, though, so wait until they're old enough.This is a great place to take in some great art without foot fatigue or being overwhelmed.
Calm escape from the heat. My adult sons and I toured the Frick and loved the art, beautiful courtyard and cool escape from the blazing heat last weekend. This is a hidden gem in the city.

A Hidden Gem Among NYC Museums. While many have never visited or heard of this museum, it is one of New York;s loveliest and most beautiful. Reminds us of the Musee Marmottan in Paris. The gallery is set in the mansion of Henry Clay Frick, an early industrialist, and houses an amazing assortment of art from various historical periods in its permanent collection, including French, Italian, Spanish, English, American and Dutch works that easily rival the Metropolitan Museum's collection, although not as vast. There are some very well known works of art here. A beautiful mansion on the inside, with an interior design that Includes an indoor courtyard and fountain area, a bit like the National Gallery of Art in Washington D.C.. There is a presentation about Mr. Frick which is informative. They have good special exhibits and concerts here at various times. Well worth the visit. Young children not allowed though. Visit on a day when admission is free.
Great art treasure. A stone throw from the grand MET and a beautiful treasure of art to explore .Its a beautiful mansion with enough to see without going away art deprived.

If you go to one gallery in NYC...... ... this is it! Beautiful in every way. Breathtaking collection in astounding venue. Make sure you absorb the history via the short movie to understand the history and extent of this collection.
Museums. My favorite New York museum. I love the permenant collection and it is so intimate and lovely, just a pleasure to sit in the atrium and relax.

Lovely legacy from the Frick Family. Super . Wonderful, intimate experience as you take in the contents of a wonderful personal collection in situ in one man's home ( admittedly an elegant mansion!). Top tip- visit the clock room/collection on the hour to hear the wonderful clocks chime- very special.

Always love the Frick. We visit the Frick each time we visit the city. The quality of the art collected by a private citizen is hard to comprehendare. The setting in the home still feels like a home. Hard to imagine coming home to this setting on a daily basis. What a treat left behind to share with mere mortals.

Beautiful little museum. I highly recommend a visit to this place. As everyone has said its a lovely mansion and collection. my favourite were the clocks. There are not too many pieces but i liked the fact that it was not overwhelming. Nice and peaceful. Coming from Central park there is an accessible entrance just before you reach the main entrance. it is clearly marked and you simply use an intercom to be buzzed in. Staff were very pleasant and helpful. I also noticed an accessible washroom/toilet though didn't use it.

Beautiful building and great art. I definitely recommend visiting this for the unique setting and great art. It was very interesting to be able to experience a mansion and art collection at the same time. Audio tours are included in the price of admission and are very informative. The place is not very big, so don't expect to see thousands of pieces of art.

Incredible art in a great setting. One of my favorite museums, after the Borghese. There are many lovely portraits by some of the great artists in this genre, including Rembrandt, Van Dyck, Holbein, and John Singer Sargent, to name a few. The rooms are pleasant to wander through, and did not seem overly crowded, even on a Saturday in July. The audioguide is very good, too, since you are able to hear commentary on most of the paintings displayed, without having to follow a particular sequence (you can pick and choose those pictures that interest you). The short film on Frick and his collection is also worthwhile. The Frick does have reciprocal memberships with other museums, so if you are a museum member elsewhere, check to see if this applies.

An enduring pleasure. An outstanding collection in a private home setting- it's been a favorite spot my whole life. The quality of the art is unparalleled, and the size is easy for those who can't quite spend an entire day in museums. A gem.
Megabucks Frick. Amazing collection of fabulous art in an impressive house. I didn't expect to see so many famous artists' works here and prefer this venue to MoMA.

Great collection of all sorts of art. This is not the kind of art everyone may appreciate because it focuses on specific styles and periods of time. The mansion is in itself a piece of art including each room's architectural details.Checkout the Frick website first. Also, read up on the history of Henry Clay Frick before going. Knowing some of the details of this man's business career will add to the experience of this collection and the mansion as well. After paying the $15-20 admission ( pay what you can, Sunday 11A-1P) pick up the Acoustiguide Audio Tour for a well designed description of the rooms and art pieces. there is also a short movie that completes your tour.

Stunningly worth it!. A breathtaking setting to see a fabulous personal collection of art. The Old Masters are worth the trip, but the furniture & mansion accentuate the art so beautifully! Much better than a trip to the bigger museums.

The Frick Museum. So many Masters under the one roof, unbelievable. The collection was endless with so much to see it was well worth the time. Not only paintings but furniture also and sculptures also. The building alone was worth seeing.

Shockingly a must see!. We were convinced to go see this over some of the larger and more known museums, due to our time constraints, and wow did we make the right decision. This mansion is absolutely stunning, so just to go see this place is worth it, but to see one of the best private art collections around on top of that is well worth the price tag. So wished the upstairs was open to look at, I was so curious to venture up there. Would definitely go again and recommend to anyone.

Not to be missed. If you are in New York, and have not visited the Frick Collection, then do so now! It is an eclectic mix of fine art, that is all the more interesting because it is a personal collection, in a building of great interest in its own right. Well served by public transport, the collection is of a manageable scale and is all the better for it.

Magical little place with beautiful art. the Frick is one of my favorite galleries in NYC - unlike the big museums this collection is small yet at a very high quality and you can see it rather quickly. It is a nice way to combine some art in your trip if you don't like big museums or if you have little time to spare. It is like a breeze of art! (they also have a nice student rate)

Decent collection but I've seen better. Not the best I have ever seen, but there were some pieces that were worth it. The security staff are super vigilant, but a bit intrusive IMO. I got yelled at for answering my phone very quietly (i immediately stepped out to the indoor garden and whispered hello so I could tell my friend "not now, I am in a museum"). I don't think anyone heard me do this, but I am sure everyone heard me getting yelled at for it. I understand their need to safe guard the museum goers experience, but this was a bit much.Save your money and go to the FREE collection in at the Yale Art Museum instead. Beautiful facilities, and a better collection, IMO.

Worth the visit!. Loved this beautiful mansion of outstanding paintings, sculpture and furnishings! I was fascinated that one individual would acquire such an unbelievable collection and then share it with the world!
Not to be missed. Rather than the Gugelheim which was crowded, we went to see this amazing collection. Really worth it.

Stunningly beautiful...a must see. Probably one of my favorite stops this past weekend. The collection of art is well complimented by the building...a almost enchanting experience. You get an appreciation for the art, the man and his tastes, as well as the effort to preserve and showcase it. I have to see the other museums in NYC before deciding that this is the best, but the Frick sets a very high standard indeed. I was stunned to be a few feet away from art that I had seen numerous times on television. The audio tour was free and its commentary added to the enjoyment of the art. The collection of pieces is very accessible to normal folk like me and an education of sorts on how the artists did their work, why they did it and an insight into their methods. A terrific overall experience. The 300 year old clocks that were still running was difficult to fathom. The admission is very reasonable, you can see everything in about 2 hours. Not crowded on a Friday afternoon and the staff was helpful and pleasant. Don't miss this.

Nice, but go on Sunday Morning. There was a line around the block to get in on a Sunday morning, but the have a 'pay what you like' policy from 11-1 on Sundays. The collection was eclectic, and interesting to review. Only takes about about 1.5 hours to see all of it, along with a short film on the founder and how he built the collection.

Definitely worth a visit. One of the greatest attractions of Frick Museum is not just its rich collection of some magnificent paintings, sculptures and objets d'art but the mansion itself, the rare remaining vestige of the way the corporate robber barons used to live in the days past. The royal atrium, spacey halls, charming galleries and vestibules all add up to conjure up the images of the bygone days of the Gilded Age (of which, incidentally, Henry Clay Frick was arguably the worst, the most ruthless and cruelest representative).The collection itself features two amazing paintings by Hans Holbein, some interesting works by Francisco de Goya, terrific St-Jerome by El Greco, fantastic auto-portrait by Rembrandt, and enchanting The Bullfight by early Édouard Manet, to name a few.Having said that, the entire collection does leave a hefty impression of a mismatch, for Mr. Frick (unlike Dr. Albert C. Barnes, for example) never had any clear goals or defining objectives as what exactly was the main interest and driving force of his efforts. Photography is not allowed.
Shocked at the beauty. Was pleasantly surprised at the collection. Loved the free audio. The crowd was very small. there was no waiting. It is a well kept secret.
Magnificent. I have been here many times with different ladies and it never fails to please me ( unlike the ladies of the past ) .This is the best place to come to in NYC for history and beauty.

Absolute must do.. What a hidden gem this is! This was our favourite museum to visit. The home setting is a magnificent back drop for the wonderful art work in this collection. If you go on Sunday before 1pm you can pay what you want, which is a great bonus when travelling and watching the pennies! This was a great place to visit.
Fantastic collection. Don't miss The Frick. Gainsboroughs abound!Atmosphere in the old home of the Fricks takes you back 150 years. Quiet and very pleasant visually.

Marvellous Museum. This is a wonderful place to visit. The house is beautiful and gives you a glimpse of what New York must have been in the early 20th century. It is a museum and a tribute to those who built it and donated to the nation. An excellent documentary tells you the history. It has many treasures, paintings, furniture etc. We spent four hours and we did not see everything. It is a must see in New York.
Great Museum. Even if you are only a fan of Modern Art you should go for the building and it's architecture. It's wonderful.

Wonderful Landmark Museum!. We spent several hours here and the art collection was very impressive. The setting is amazing especially since it was a private home. There is a small theatre which shows a short film about the architecture and site. The audioguide is very helpful as many pieces of art are described at length. It is worth the price of admission.

Family friendly. I used my upgraded DeYoung membership and got in free. Kids free anyway. Small Gem in a beautiful house. No crowds when we were there. Quiet, peaceful. Staff great. Elegant. A real reprieve for our family from the craziness of the crowds and noise just outside at Central Park and Met. Artwork lovely to look at. Because it was a home, it lacks that cold feeling of most museums. Instead it is cozy and elegant. Excellent for my 10 and 12 year old. See AWESOME web site with virtual tour for a preview.

A Gem of a Museum. I loved this museum & just wish I had known about it earlier (I have been to NYC several times). It's probably one of NYC'S most underrated museum/art gallery. I loved the collections--many of my favorite artists and works that I had never seen before: Gaugin's woodcuts and zincographs were amazing; Claude Monet's caricature of a man with a snuff box was delightful; and of course, the Degas and Manet etchings never cease to amaze and delight. The best part: the gallery is housed in a former residence (within walking distance from Central Park), so you feel as if you are in a private home enjoying some of Europe's best known paintings by some of the greatest artists and sculptures.

Gem of a museum. We heard about the Frick Collection from an art student we met on the airport tram, of all things. So glad we went. It's similar in some ways to the Borghese Gallery in Rome - once an elegant residence for a collector and lover of art. Much of the art is displayed as Mr. Frick originally placed it. Highly recommend this museum to art lovers.
Magnificent. Outstanding art collection all presented in a beautiful mansion. The audio guide (no charge) gives good commentary on the art and home. An oasis of beauty!

Small but Impressive. For a small ($17) fee, you can get a glimpse of the life of the American aristocracy. The interior of this home is very impressive, as are the collections of art on display. We went on a Sunday and there were students participating in an open sketching session in the courtyard, with all supplies provided by Museum staff. The portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell (advisors to King Henry VIII) facing each other across the fireplace are amazing. I liked it more than the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Marvelous place, the building and the gallery. If you haven´t time enough during your stay in N.Y. to see all the large museums, choose this one . It is really good and interesting and you will see not only some masterpieces from Rembarndt, Vermemer , Manet and many more , but also a very interesting private villa from the beginning of 20´th century . You can see and deduct how this first really rich industrial WASP generation thought about. You will receive during your vist a very good audio guide.
Don't miss this gem. Great variety of sculptures, porcelein and paintings. Free hand held audio tour allows you to move through works at your own pace.

Too too mainstream for me. Just what you would expect from a museum row art museum. There are no surprises here and nothing that "stretched" or uplifted me. A beautiful building but much like the living room of the rich great aunt I never had.

Glorious setting & collection. I love the experience of stepping back in time at the Frick. Everything is so 19th century and old New York! However, the staff are stuffy and unfriendly, which mutes the experience a bit.

Frick Collection well worth a visit. Really enjoyed our visit to this 5th Avenue mansion and museum. Mansion is incredible and filled with European and Asian antiques. Spend as little as a half an hour to visit but recommend an hour or more to really appreciate it all.

Beautiful Museum. Great overall visit. Beautiful building with a variety of paintings, sculpture and furniture. Can make your way through in an hour or two and well worth it. By chance, we went on a Sunday morning where it was "pay what you want" before 1 PM. Highly recommend.

An oasis in busy New York City. The Frick Collection is housed in a classic historic mansion built 100 years ago which houses a sensationally concise yet comprehensive collection of artworks, furniture and ceramics. The house and its beautiful atrium have a serene atmosphere and we viewed works by Whistler, Vermeer and Rembrandt, to mention a few masters. My favourites were two iconic portraits by Hans Holbein of Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell. We wondered if the entry fee was going to be worth it, as we are not normally art gallery goers, but we loved our experience.
Interesting house & museum. We really enjoyed looking at this collection, the house is beautiful and the collection very interesting.

Great smaller museum that you might miss. Loved the intimacy in this museum. You can walk right up to the porcelains and bronzes that would be covered with plexiglass in other museums. Explanations of the paintings on the audio-guides (included in the price of your admission) are worth listening to. The building, Frick's home, is worth the visit alone.

Sunday in the Park with Frick !. Loved the Frick museum ! My wife walked through the park to get to the Frick which is on 70th Street and 5th Avenue. Sundays are the best time to go (voluntary donations appreciated) otherwise it is $18 per person. Why go? The museum has one of the finest and most complete private collections of 18th century portrait paintings I have ever seen. What makes this rock is that the collection can be viewed in the original Frick home built in the 19th century which has always housed the collection. Very cool if you are a history buff like me! I have never seen as many Gainsborough portraits in one place in the Western Hemisphere. If you like art or history. Go !

One snag prevented me from giving it 5 stars. The Frick has long been on my bucket list. First, the good. I rank it with the Wallace Collection in London and Nissim de Camondo's museum in Paris: small, exquisite, intimate and high quality content. I won't repeat others comments already here at TA but wholeheartedly endorse that it's a must see and proved to be the highlight of my recent visit to NYC, ostensibly to attend a performance at Birdland. I also visited MOMA which proved underwhelming but then I'm not a huge modernist. Their audio guides were less than helpful, offering little information. Not so at the Frick. The audio guides there (included in ticket price) were both insightful and interesting. Now to the bad. My husband and I had checked out of our hotel (this was a one night only trip) and had planned to visit the Frick en route to the airport for the return leg of our trip. We'd stayed only one night and both had rolling, smaller than regulation size, carry ons. Upon arrival, The Frick's Security refused to admit us saying they were unable to check our two bags. We were stunned. I've been to small museums across Europe and never encountered this. I've been to museums where security is so tight even a woman's handbag must be checked and left in lockers. Never anything like this. My husband gallantly offered to remain outside on the sunny steps with our bags, always happily entertained by his iPhone, while I entered the museum. He knew I'd been so looking forward to this visit. When I finished and joined him on the steps, apparently another couple arrived while I was gone who encountered the same problem with their carry ons only she put up a real battle and they were eventually allowed in. Okay, perhaps another case of the squeaky wheel gets oiled but a world class museum like the Frick, they must encounter this regularly if there were two instances within an hour of one another. Surely something could be done to address this? For this reason only, I dropped a star. Otherwise, if you're even the teensiest bit appreciative of Old World elegance, this is the place for you. A fairly recent addition to the collection of extraordinary clocks was utterly breathtaking and beautifully displayed. There's also a small but very good gift shop where there's lovely stationary, unusual luggage tags, and other small sundries.  Frick I love ya (and your charming docent just inside the front door) but please look into this!
All types of art in one place. This was my second visit to the Frick and possibly not my last. The collection covers all types of art, housed in such a wonderful house. We liked it all.
My favourite New York Musuem. The best part about the Frick is that it is actually a house. Wandering though it's luxurious rooms is the most superlative way to spend an afternoon.

Traveling The World Through Art. I've visited the Frick numerous times and not once am I bored or disappointed. I find it to be one of the most intense collections of Art in the world. After living abroad for ten years, I can always count on the Frick to bring back golden memories of all the many Galleries, Art Salons, and Museums I visited during my travels. I'm also in love with the setting, and to think that only one family lived in this divine Mansion is beyond me. But, then again, I could easily kick off my shoes and set up residency in such a place!

Amazing. An amazing collection, so accesssible. The audio guide so enjoyable and informative. We loved the way different artists and peroids were hung next to each other, admire what the curatoral staff is doing and its activley living up to its mission. A pure pleasure.

A must do. I am so thankful that the concierge told me about this place. It was one of my favorite things if not favorite things I got to see in New York. The Frick collection is right across the street from Central Park and close to the Met and Guggenheim. What I loved about this collection is that it is in a "house" really a mansion on 5th Avenue so not only do you get to see some amazing art but you get to see it a really unique setting. Even if you know nothing about art it is worth going just to see the house. It isn't too big but has some really amazing pieces (I loved the Turners on display) so if you are short on time I would go here over the met. Yes, the met has more but it is so big. Everyone told us you could spend a week at the met and I am used to all the museums in DC and wondered how big could this really be. I think you could spend a month at the met. The Frick is gem in the city.
Our favorite museum in New York City. Viewing the old masters in the Frick family home on Fifth and 70th is always a pleasure. The home is only surpasses by his collections.

Beautiful art in a beautiful setting. Genrally, my favorite museums in the world not only contain great art but the art is displayed in a great building. I wish more of the mansions that no longer serve as homes to the wealthy could be turned into art museums. And on a hot day in New York City, how wonderful to enter the museum to enjoy the art and the quiet atmosphere just off of Fifth Avenue. Highly recommende

Love this museum!!. I love the collection here. Great chance to get up close to some wonderful art. I also love just being there. You can look out a widow,onto 5th ave. and just imagine what it was to live there once. You can picture the horse carriages traveling right past. Love love this place!!! thank you Mr. Frick!!!!!

Truly Extraordinary!. This museum never ceases to amaze me. Architecturally stunning inside and out, the beautiful old world master paintings, furniture (some owned by Marie Antoinette), books, pottery, clocks, rugs…the list goes on. We went on a Sunday which is pay what you want before 1:00 pm (we paid the full price) and leisurely spent the next few hours enjoying ourselves. It wasn’t crowed so we had plenty of opportunity to view everything. They provide free hand held devices (in many different languages) that give you very interesting facts about so many of the items and rooms – this proved invaluable and made the experience perfect. Centrally located near Central Park, you can take a stroll afterwards and close out a relaxing day.

Worth a visit!. This museum is definitely worth spending a few hours in. It houses some amazing pieces of art and is a must-see for art lovers. You can tell by seeing the collection that Frick loved his art. The museum gift shop is worth a visit for those looking to buy souvenirs.If you're in New York and like art, this is worth a stop.

A gem of a museum. If you want to a good overview of European art in about 2 hours, the Frick is the place. It's housed in what was once the Frick mansion. A bit pricey ($18), but looking at the home itself. Saw the special exhibit on time pieces. A bit small for what I was expecting, but excellent pieces.
a jewel of a museum. If you like to be transported in time see this Belle Epoque mansion with wonderful paintings, sculptures and rooms. It's never crowded and easy to navigate.
Wow. Many people miss this little jewel . Just as interesting as the Met with more intimacy and warmth . Many old masters paintings including Gainsborough , Reynolds and Rembrandt . Do not miss it .

Beautiful home and art!. We spent morning meandering through the rooms of this beautiful home learning about the works of art with the aid of a concise audio guide. Watch the movie about Frick first then tour at your leisure...enjoying the gardens and vistas as well as the rooms and amazing art collection. I especially enjoyed the Vermeer collection,and the clock collection.

Fantastic collection, great feel to the place. Don't compare to the MET, this is a unique small museum with great atmosphere. A treat for art lovers. It'll took us about 2 hours for the whole collection.
Great!. How lovely to go into a museum in New York and feel after 2-3hrs that you have seen it all! A beautiful museum, well laid out and a lovely way to spend an afternoon!

Exceptional Experience. If you want an art gallery experience in New York City that does not wear you out and provides a delightful combination of fine art and an impressive mansion, this is your place. You feel very privileged to walk through the quiet, magnificent home and experience it like those who lived there. We especially liked the atmosphere and paintings in the study. Would also definitely recommend the 25 minute film about Henry Clay Frick and how the collection was planned and brought together.
Well worth a visit. Excellent collection of quality art, some National collections are not as good. Building worth a visit on its own, thought it could do with somewhere to sit and have a coffee.

Well worth the visit!. This was an amazing house with some awesome art. I love the fact that you can get so close to the art to look at it. I really enjoyed the shop also! Be prepared to spend heaps if you like art. Some great books in the shop.

More Than A Museum. Mr. Frick's art collection is amazing in both diversity and quality. This museum is a more manageable size and layout than other art museums in New York, so it is perfect for those who have time constraints. The staff are friendly and knowledgeable; the location is an oasis of serenity.

Frick and Frack. An excellent collection in an interesting venue. We liked the fact that it was the Frick house and loved what he collected. A wonderful collection across many different types of art. Definitely worth a visit.
Excellent collection, manageable size. Not overwhelming in size like The Met, not difficult to maneuver like The Guggenheim... The Frick is a delight.
Go see it for the Mansion alone--. Nice art--fantastic Home of industrialist of the past--see how the super rich lived at the turn of the century.

Another must visit. Located opposite Central Park this wonderful mansion is located within walking distance of two other 'greats'...the Met and Guggenheim. The Frick collection is relatively modest in size but contains enough of interest to keep one captivated for at least two hours or more. It contains a wonderful collection of art through the ages, and truly is well worth the time for a visit.

Fabulous art in a fabulous setting. The Frick Museum is housed in Mr. Frick's home and was built with the intention of someday turning it into a museum. When that happened, an alleyway was enclosed and a gorgeous courtyard is the center of the home. What a respite from Fifth Avenue. The art collection is superb, with Holbeins, Titan, Rembrandts, Vermeers (two of them) and Sargents to name a few. Small, easy to view in an hour and see what money can really buy!

perfect for novice gallery/museum goers. The Frick is perfect for people who are overwhelmed (or bored) by large museums or galleries! It is a beautiful large mansion, hence giving you an idea how the rich once lived in New York, with a limited but superb collection of works.The tour guides are superb - really know their stuff and make you feel very special.Highly recommended.

Short and sweet visit. Worth admission price. Lots of great and good art, plus beautiful setting with rooms full of antiques. Doesn't feel like museum. Just big enough to take up morning. We got there right at 10am and finished at 1145am and headed for lunch without being tired.

A wonderland of Beautiful Art .. From the hub-bub of 5th Avenue one can enter a Peaceful and Beautiful House with a collection of the finest Art works and Ceramics to takes one's breath away. Gainsborough's beautiful portraits of Society Ladies, Vermeer, Constable, Holbein,( to name just a few) are hung in private rooms which were once the living areas of the Frick Family. One can just gaze and admire without having to peer over a shoulder as one does at special exhibitions in the Larger Art Galleries.. I was bowled over. It was the highlight of my first visit to New York.

An amazing art collection. The Frick Collection was suggested to us by two Australian visitors two years ago, they said if you can visit one museum in NY it should be The Frick. We were not disappointed. On a day of rain we sought peace and inspiration. A wonderful rich and memorable collection, set in magnificent surroundings. The room with the Whistlers is jaw dropping and gives one goosebumps. See the video on how the collection came together, it does set the scene. You MUST visit this collection otherwise your time your in NY is incomplete.

A private collection worth viewing more than once!. What an amazing private collection of art! Take advantage of the free audioguide that the museum provides. It gives a very good narrative/description of each labelled work of art. The religious paintings are particularly interesting. The mansion itself is breath-taking! The garden and the courtyard are beautiful. It is definitely a place worth visiting.

Not to be missed by anyone who loves art.. A wonderful museum - the breadth and depth of this collection is astounding. Right after you get the free audio tour (don't pass it up as it's very helpful) you are hit with not one but two Vermeers! These paintings gave me goosebumps when I saw them - both on the way in AND on the way out. There's even a third one in the West Gallery! Take the two hours or so to tour this museum - its quality is amazing. Titian, Goya, El Greco, Rembrandt, Whistler, Turner, Gainsborough - the list just goes on. You will neither regret it nor forget it!
