I loved the house itself. Listen to all the stories about the paintings, they brought it alive for all of us.. I think I expected more paintings, but it was a great afternoon for us. I would go again. It wasn't crowded and the building itself is worth seeing. The receptionist giving out headphones was trying very hard to wreck our day. I hope hers got better.
A high end boutique museum. This is a wonderful museum with truly amazing art pieces. The audio guide is informative. The Frick is a jewel!

Best most manageable museum in NYC. The man's home turned into a museum that continued to grow its collection after his passing. Interesting architecture, furniture and art collection. There are a few pieces in here you see all the time in print and to just happen about them in someone's private collection is amazing. We did it w three kids (10, 12 and 14) and it was very manageable and enjoyed by all. Worth the price of admission. Maybe an hour and a half to really see it all. Very easy and about the only thing we did in NYC where we weren't moved by a sea of people. A must see!

NYC History/Art Upclose. It is an easy way to see a part of NYC history and 'live' with the some of the masterpieces as its habitants once did. Charming. Excellent audio guide. Sunday AM from 11 to 1 is 'pay what you wish' time...go early as there is always a line. Be sure to watch the film about the Frick in the drawing room.

Spectacular Beyond Description. Regardless of one’s knowledge of art and architectural history, The Frick Collection should not be missed on a visit to -- or when living in -- New York City. The extraordinary collection of important art, furniture and artistic objects are displayed in the massive home of Henry Clay Frick, one of America’s great industrialists of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The building is as interesting and exciting as its contents. Frick’s knowledge and appreciation of great art and architecture, with the wealth to acquire them, is our good fortune, and The Frick Collection must be seen on a two or three hour visit to Mr. Frick’s mind boggling mansion in New York City.

Hidden Treasure. Go visit this wonderful house museum on Fifth Avenue, it's like walking into another world, the world of the robber barons and all their spoils and art. The place is so serene, it's almost like meditation, the collection amazing, Mr Frick did have very good taste in art.

The Quiet Museum. When all the well known museums are over crowded The Frick usually remains less traveled. Seeing the art and furnishing in the original mansion setting is an added bonus. There are a fascinating array of pieces and you can just wander through or avail yourself of the information available to learn the details of each piece. Slow down and enjoy the experience.

What a house..... The Frick Collection has to be seen to be believed, the art itself is amazing and the experience is heightened even more when you appreciate that this is one man's art collection exhibited in his house just as it was when Mr Frick lived there himsels
very worthwhile. I really enjoyed this stunning collection. It was small enough to absorb and not overwhelming like the larger museums. It was a beautiful experience.

Podge747. This villa is an NYC must see - perfectly exhibited paintings and sculptures in an iconic setting- a Manhatten jewel suitable for all ages. Annoying for the Pittsburgher that Frick raped and pillaged the 'burgh and left it all to NY City!

Well worth a visit. Excellent collection of masterpieces in a historical mansion, you can see many famous artists/paintings in a short amount of time. You can comfortably see the collection in 2 hours.Well priced at USD18 adult.

Peaceful and beautiful. Visiting the Frick is like visiting someones stately home and, well, I guess it is because it is in the townhouse of the Fricks who amassed a fantastic collection of art across the centuries. In every room there is work by for example Rembrandt, Turner, Gainsborough, Constable and Singer Sergeant, all in a beautiful setting. Tip: go early - we were there for opening time and the lack of visitors made walking the galleries a tranquil experience. At the centre is a peaceful patio with shrubs and froggie water spouts. Just lovely.
must. The house of Mr. Frick turned to be one of the most impressive museums that I ever visited must must.

Stunnin collection with a common thread thoughout. This museum, which houses the Henry Clay Frick art collection inside his 5th Avenue mansion, is absolutely beautiful. Some of the works were added by his daughter, who clearly shared his vision. The aesthetic is hard to sum up in a few words, but serene and exquisitely tasteful come to mind first. Not only are there many beautiful paintings and sculpture by well-known artists, but many of the furnishings and decorative elements were also chosen with the same vision in mind. The Rembrandts and Vermeers were especially exciting to see. The Oval Gallery, which houses life-size portraits by Whistler (the only American artist Frick allowed), was my personal favorite. And the spacious inner courtyard perfectly ties all the galleries together. This museum is what the Isabella Stuart Gardner Museum in Boston could be, if Gardner had not insisted nothing be changed after her death. The entire house can be seen and enjoyed within a few hours--a beautiful way to spend an afternoon or morning.

Opulence!. Brilliant collection, amazing space. A great place to see some of the Dutch masters that didn’t really seem to be represented in NYC. At least two Vermeer’s were on display, which was great as they weren’t up in the MET. A bit pricy, but the collection is just jaw dropping.Interesting that children under 10 can’t enter, but a dog can if you write ahead.A definite must for NYC.
blooming trees and delicate art. It is great to visit this small museum, with a special collection. Loved the impressionis exibition in the cellar.

A hidden gem. The Frick Collection is displayed in the house the Frick's built and lived in in NYC. Interesting art museum to visit. Unique in that this was the home of the Frick family and the art is arranged mostly as they enjoyed it years ago.
Pleasantly Surprised. We visited the Frick as an add on to our trip but quite enjoyed it. An impressive art collection in a beautiful building with period furniture. Worth a few hours to visit.
great if you are in a hurry. a beatiful house with one or two of every really important artist before the raphaelites. A great way of not having to deal with the Met.

Great art and environment. Wonderful place. Go when the kids are not with you since they are not allowed in. Great place to see specific pieces and shows but also just to take in the old house. Staff is not warm but helpful.

Classy Collection. The three Vermeers alone are worth the visit, but the Frick offers a transport back to a distant age when tycoons collected great art and then donated not just the art -- but the mansion that holds it -- to the public. While I don't always agree with Frick's taste in art (you can have the Fragonard room), the total experience is memorable. Don't miss the short film about Frick and his collection.
Great Collection off the Golden Mile. Right off Fifth Avenue the building and collections are worth a visit. Manageable in between brunch and a visit to the park.
Amazing. Amazing collections of artwork in an amzing building. Definitely worth going. You can spend ages here.

Uncrowded, intimate, with excellent art. One of the best museums in NYC.
The permanent and special collections are always extraordinary, including rare works by Rembrandt and Van Gogh...
A great way to spend a couple of hours and see things like sketches which never make it to larger museums.
Definitely should see. Well organised with recorded information on many paintings. A beautiful "house". Some of the paintings are incredible works of some very famous Masters.

Always a blockbuster. This is a great place to expose first timers to art. It's not huge, and every painting is a blockbuster. The building is incredible, often there are concerts happening. I highly recommend you add it to your bucket list. I have visited it many times and always see something new.

Gorgeous building and gardens.. I've been coming the Frick since I was a teenager. It's like an old friend that I visit from time to time. The collection is always excellent and the building itself and the interior gardens are worth the visit. I love this museum.

Really worthwhile. A wonderful combination of incredible works of art from Degas, Monet, Renoir to Rembrandt, Lippi, Turner... .the list is endless. And all housed in an original upscale New York Home from the last century. Fascinating. Well laid out, wonderfully air conditioned, plenty of seating throughout for aching backs after standing for long periods and friendly staff. Highly recommended. We had just three days in NY and as such couldn't get around to the museums/galleries, so this was a terrific condensed version of the two. Just go. And Central Park is a block away. We did the two in the morning and still had the afternoon to head back downtown for some shopping. Wonderfully non touristy for tourists who don't want to battle the crowds!

One of the most beautiful art galleries in the world. This was once the private residence of the industrialist Henry Clay Frick who amassed a stunning art collection. Three Vermeers for goodness sake! If you don't feel you have the time or energy to undertake one of the large museums, then this might be the perfect choice. Two or three hours should do you and you will feel culturally sated..

Worth it, if you have time to spare. This visit is worth it, if you have time to spare. The whole museum is on display. From the paintings on the wall to the carpet on the floor. It was a house before and all old items are on display, so you feel a bit at home when browsing through all the art displayed. There are lesser known painting from famous painters, which in my opinion is wonderful.

A must see. You have to visit this wonderful living art exhibition in the home of Henry Frick. A wonderful insight into old world living on 5th Avenue and some superb pieces of art and architecture. Do the introductory tour - 15 min and then get the audio guide and do your thing!

Exquisite art in a beautiful setting. An elegant, quiet place with one masterwork following another. This is the former home of a robber baron who knew how to get the best possible advice about collecting art and objects of the highest quality. You might check its website to see when it's free, but even if you have to pay, you will be rewarded with some of the most beautiful works of art imaginable----Bellini's St. Francis in Ecstasy, a Rembrandt self-portrait, Holbein's portrait of St. Thomas More, a room with charming panels by Fragonard, elegant aristocratic portraits by Gainsborough and Reynolds, powerful work by Goya, sea and landscapes by Dutch masters, Corot, and others.
Wonderful. Beautiful collection of art. In a gorgeous building. It is usually not too crowded. Well worth a visit!!
The best of an era. Understand an era before US decline when wealth was created and USA produced great things. the house is a masterpiece,as well as the art and decorative furniture.

A grand alternative to the busy Met. We absolutely loved the Frick! We travel a lot and always seek out art museums. This will be added to the list of our favorites. It is located in a lovely building and has a fabulous collection. We didn't really understand the scope until we were standing in front of them. It is absolutely amazing that a collection this size (as compared to some huge museums) has such gems. It is our understanding that none of them are ever loaned out, so this is your only chance to see some absolutely stellar pieces. And it is much less crowded that the Met which can be overwhelming. We were there about 2 hours or so including a rest break in the lovely atrium. Just a wonderful museum! (The audio was excellent.)
The wife loved it. Although I can take it or leave it, I quite enjoyed this museum. My wife fell in love with it. Visited on a early Monday afternoon. Not crowded at all.

Astounding collection. The abliity to be a collector of great works of art requires the finances to accomplish it. However, the vision to plan your residence as a future museum requires greatness. A gift to future generations.

A rare find indeed. This beautiful Mansion is exquisite and beautifuly maintained. It was a step back in time that allowed us to be absorbed in the beauty of times past and the incredible art collection

Wonderful Art Gallery & Museum. We visited the Frick Collection in late May 2013. It is in a magnificant old Frick family home and the home itself is worth a visit, even before seeing the collection. I would rate it as one of the best collections anywhere and very well displayed. A must do on any trip to NYC.

Amazing collection. This is a museum that is not to be missed. It is a glimpse into a private home with an outstanding collection of fine art. There are so many works, not just paintings but sculpture, furniture, porcelains, etc. It is an opportunity to go right up to the works and really view them. While there is a lot to see, you can do it all in a few hours.

Grand private collection. This is a collection that includes great masterpieces collected privately and subject matter that an extremely wealthy gentleman wanted in his mansion. Beautiful scenes, beautiful portraits, in a wonderful 100 year old 5th Ave Mansion.

Simply the Best. This is one of my all time favourite places to visit in New York. I never cease to become immersed in the history of the man who built the house and whose personal art collection you will see within the most beautiful rooms. It is just an amazing place. Do not miss it!
Amazing story. Brilliant history and story. Worthwhile going and visiting, go early to avoid the queues as they are quite strict on the number of people they let in at one time.

Wonderful Stop to Relax and See great Art and A Great building. When visiting 5TH Ave Museum Row the Frick at 70th Street is always a good place to stop and relax. If you have time check the concert schedules which provide an afternoon of Music along with the art.While you are there also pay attention to the architecture of the building which is also fascinating.In addition to the great permanent collection they now have a few special exhibits that are also worth a visit.
Revisited. Have been here many times. Never tire of it. The collection is quite incredible, full of European Masters, and sometimes a special show. The building itself is worth seeing.

A Gem of a Museum!. This was our first time to visit the Frick, but we will return. The collection is amazing! You can get up close and personal. You can see the entire museum in one trip, and that is without hurrying. Be sure to get the free audio tour.

Magnificent collectiojn. A must if you visit New York, to see the mixture of treasures collected according to the taste of one individual is very interesting, there is no rhyme nor reason to some of his choices, other than they are all real treasures

Very interesting collection. Stroll through Central Park and seek out this collection. A really eclectic mix of art including sculpture. The internal garden is tranquil and beautifully designed. Well worth a visit. Allow a couple of hours for a steady stroll around the collection.

Outstanding!. The intimacy of this relatively little museum is wonderful, as is the range of interesting objects to see: magnificent art work, collectibles, furniture & the architecture of the building itself.The audiophones included in the price of admission were great.

Frick for Free. Once a week the Frick is open to the public for free. You are invited to make a donation. I took four of my college aged children and we waited in line for about forty minutes in a light rain. If it had not been raining the line might have been longer. It was totally worth the wait. WE used the free headphones for a self guided tour and enjoyed seeing the beautifully maintained mansion with its fabulous art collection (mostly permanent and original).
worth every penny. compare to the big museums it seems very small. an opportunity to look inside a mansion of an art collector . a great collection and a great house

Genuinely awesome. I return to the Frick house whenever I can. It is an harmonious whole of architecture and art. The most wonderful paintings and sculpture in mostly their original settings as their owner intended. Indescribable, almost voyeuristic pleasure, at being able to enter the houses of the super rich from a marvelous era and enjoy the perfect harmony and impressive art.

Surprising glimpse of immense wealth. We are avid museum enthusiasts and spent the morning at the Guggenheim and then the Frick - the latter easily winning the morning showdown. The Frick painting collection was very impressive and I particularly enjoyed all the Gainsborough works. The mansion itself is a work of art from the woodwork to the stone work. Take your time and this is a two hour stop. Excellent experience.
had fun. great collection. a little bit republican crowd but friendly! I would happily take any of my friends when they are visiting.
Wonderful. Deservedly one of the highest rated attractions in NYC - its a fabulous place to visit. The collection is unsurpassed and the setting is very special. 100% recommended.

Little gem. This is a great collection which is housed in a lovely house right across the road from Central Park. It doesn't take too long to see it, which is great if you've not got a whole day for a museum. Really enjoyed it and would recommend a visit.

Rude woman at ticket counter. Despite my admiration for the Frick's important art collection, I wish to register my profound disappointment with the woman at the ticket counter. During a recent visit, I had hoped to revisit the collection for an hour or so, but when I showed a membership card from an out-of-state museum that was supposed to have reciprocal admission benefits, I was told, rather rudely, that it lacked the appropriate sticker and could not be used. I am a New Yorker by birth, an art historian by profession, and I found this woman's behavior to be condescending and unacceptable. We went to the Whitney instead that day, where everyone including the wait staff in the museum restaurant was a delight.

A Gem of a Collection. The Frick collection is an absolutely stunning art collectino/museum. $18 is a steal for admission, with the included audio tour a cherry on top. The art and design of the property reminds me just a LITTLE bit of a mini-Versailles.
MINI VERSAILLES. AN EXTRAORDINARY COLLECTION . Mr. Frick had great taste and acquired most remarquable works of art .The mansion is beautiful . Avery nice museum to visit.

Sundays were pay as you like.... big line up but it moved fast as the Frick is a big beautiful home!What an art collection! We saw Rembrandts too! Looking out the windows makes you think of how it was a 100 years ago. Great location, I saw Lauren Hutton!

A wonderful find. This is a wonderful museum with an excellent collection. It was,originally a family home and that atmosphere continues. There are not the barriers and full on security of the larger places. There is an internal courtyard which is great to sit and contemplate. Well worth being top of your list for museums

Beautiful day in the Museum. This is just a wonderful day to spend at the Museum. It is a true NYC experience. I was absolutely surprised over this place as I did not know what to expect! Happy to say it exceeded any expectations!

The best small(ish) fine art collection. Visited again after a gap of 12 years & enjoyed it even more. This collection is phenomenal but relatively compact & easy to visit with (or indeed without) the audio tour. Frick's home is chock full of wonderful stuff, world famous paintings, sculptures, bronzes, clocks & furniture & the house is not bad either, a modest mansion beside Central Park. Paintings by Vermeer, Titian, Holbein, Gainsborough, Sargent to name but a few favourites. It's $18 adult, opens at 10am & has very good lavatories.
Private Collection of wonderful art. Smallish museum , but it could take a few hours to admire all the wonderful piences here. Definetly a visit to New York will be incomplete if you miss the Frick.
Extensive Art Collection. Interesting, extensive collection of art in a beautiful home. Many well known artists included in the collection. Beautiful grounds around the home.
Outstanding. Not to be missed.outstanding art collection . Very worthwhile more intimate then the institute .upper east side close to the park

A wonderful place, high art in a splendid but inviting home.. An amazing collection of mostly European masterpieces amassed by the industrial tycoon Henry Clay Frick on view in his mansion built in the early twentieth century on the upper East Side of NYC. Anyone would be astounded by this embarrassment of riches: Vermeer (three!!), Rembrandt (his self-portrait can hold you spellbound), van Dyck, Bellini, Turner, Gainsborough (check out Mall in Saint James's Park with the snippy women raising haughty eyebrows at who has just shown up for a stroll), Holbein (Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell staring each other down in the living room on either side of an El Greco), Titian, Fragonard, Boucher, Houdon and Verrocchio sculptures, Goya, Corot, a Stuart George Washington, and hundreds more. Along with furniture, carpets, bronzes, etc. that have their stories too. Special exhibits, as in both an Impressionist drawing exhibit and Piero della Francesca in America at present (May 2013). No cafe, a small store. Not a good place for children.
Small but loaded. Great selection of some of the best paintings in the world. Beautiful facility as well. Two hours is a great investment here.

Wonderful!. What I loved most about this beautiful collection of art is that it is housed in a real house (mansion is a better word, I suppose) where the artwork is displayed in rooms where people actually lived. Each room is thoughtfully laid out to enhance the art, with furniture and surroundings to complement, and give the visitor more of an experience, rather than just a viewing of a painting. The Fragonard room depicts a love story, for instance, and you can immerse yourself in that setting. My favourite was Renoir's "Mother Strolling with her Children."

A fantastic gallery. Whatever you do, don't miss the Frick. I've been here twice, it is simply unforgettable. Stately old mansion, stunning collection, great value. I'd come back every time just to see one work - the Holbein portrait of Sir Thomas More - let alone the other magnificent treasures here. It also has a terrific gift shop. Quite simply, the Frick is a rare gem.

Excellent -. This collection is sufficiently diverse to make you want to visit again and again, Treasures are there for the finding, calm relaxed approach and a lock of fuss characterize each succeeding visit.

Excellent collection and Manageable visit in 2 hours. Unlike many other museums the Frick Collection is not enormous and you can see the lovely building and great art exhibition within 2 hours, and at a cost of $18 per person. It is quality over quantity - The museum is a lovely combination of grand home and great artistic taste. Pick up a free audio guide to ensure you get the details and of course ask someone in each room if you want to know more.

Wonderful Small Gem. The priceless works of art here are just amazing. The setting is so wonderful and it is smaller so you can take more time to appreciate and enjoy the art "in situ" and not feel rushed. I liked the included headset where you can dial in the number of the artwork and learn more about it. Very well done and worth the visit here.
Amazing. Extensive art collection, many masterpieces, just wonderful. 11 am - 1 pm Sundays pay what you wish.

Great collection of art work. I'm not an art lover, but this house-converted-museum by a man hated by Pittsburg steel workers (one of Carnegie's colleagues) was facinating. The history of the man and how his collection came to be is so intriguing. They don't allow cameras, but my favorite piece is in the main room of Hans Holbein's "Sir Thomas More". Go see the detail in this painting and you'll see what I mean! The Sunday 11-1 PM "Pay What You Wish" is a great deal, which we took advantage of as well. Would love to go back some day.

An Art lover? Do not miss it!!!. This wonderful private mansion includes some of the best-known paintings by the greatest European artists, major works of sculpture, eighteenth-century French furniture and porcelains.And the building itself is an artistic attraction. If you love works of art, do not miss this gem!
Gorgeous. Beautiful home with impressive artwork. An easy way to spend a Rainy hour! A little spendy entrance fee, but it supports the museum.
Tranquility amidst the chaos of NYC. A haven of tranquility,well worth a look on the way to Central Park-a complete aesthetic experience-the house the interiors,the art

A Treasure Trove. The Frick Collection is housed in old style glamour on 5th Avenue - one of the biggest privately owned mansions that has become a very special museum. You go back in time when you enter Charles Frick study with the two Holbeins on either side of the massive fireplace. Every room has something special in it - the glass central courtyard with the fountain brings a peace and quiet to the house that makes you appreciate it all the more. entry is 18dollars but note on Sunday between 11 - 1am you can pay what you wish - so if you are a budget thats the day and time for you!! My advice pick up the 2 dollar booklet which will help you identify the special pieces in each of the rooms. For me - one of the highlights of NYC - am just amazed how many New Yorkers have never seen inside the building.

It's such a shame.... That the collection is beautifully presented, the collection is well displayed; the works are international and have some absolute gems (Millet; Vermeer, Gaugin) but the staff were unhelpful, in one case rude and insensitive.My wife's medical conditio means she suffers extreme cold and hot skin sensitivity and has to remove or add clothes accordingly. Feeling faint through heat she removed her coat to carry over her arm and was immediately harangued by staff about taking her coat off and despite having it explained to them of her condition were not sympathetic or offered assistance.I was reprimanded for peering at a Turner painting from the distance of two feet and the coat check in staff were abrupt and discourteous..As a Visitor I'd expect better staff behaviour to make the collection a delight to remember rather than have it overshadowed by this negative memory.
art. the art collection was very impressive and not too busy on the day we visited Old family house was interesting
Best small museum in the world. It doesn't get better than a stately NY manor filled with masterpieces. Don't miss this gem and imagine a life before income tax.

A gem. I was totally bowled over by both the collection and the setting. This was the last museum I visited in NY and rather than making me feel "museumed out" it added a whole new, refreshing dimension to the appreciation of art.

Fantastic museum - if you're in NYC, you must visit. The Frick Collection is housed in a building built by Mr Frick as his home and a home for his vast collection of art. There are paintings, sculpture, furniture - you name it. And the building itself it beautiful with a spectacular inner garden courtyard. What a delight it must have been to live there and what a delight it is for us to be able to visit today. Take note - the museum is closed on Mondays.

The Frick has no rivals and must be visited. I am a frequent visitor to New York, having been born and raised there, but lived away from it for over 50 years. Nowhere is there anything like the Frick Collection, and no visit to New York is complete without an afternoon at this world gem of galleries. One very wealthy man was able to pick out for his private collection the best example of every artist's work that appealed to him for display in his own home. It's all still there. Dream on, those who visit, and contemplate what can never again be possible - and thank Mr Frick for enabling you to share this unique experience!
Gorgeous home turned into a museum. collection was excellent. Don't miss going into the theater for the short film about Frick - it's very interesting

A roomful of Piero della Francesca. A special exhibit, ending soon. I highly recommend a visit to see it, the impressionist prints from the Clark Institute, and to wander the Frick mansion to take in the art, furnishings and courtyard.

Wealth and good taste. Beautifully preserved mansion and collection on the Upper East Side. It's easy to see everything in a couple of hours which means that you don't feel overwhelmed by too much at much. The buidling and gardens add to the atmosphere. Well worth the trip.

Interesting Collection of A Robber Baron. Quite an eclectic collection of art in Mr. Frick's converted mansion.A little bit of everything...paintings, furniture, clocks, and sculptures from several centuries. Worth a look while touring the Upper East Side and Central Pard
New York Gem. The Frick is a boutique museum. The collection is always interesting and the building and grounds make the experience.

Beautiful. Imagine some rich guy gave his home and his art collection to be enjoyed by the public! There were three temporary exhibits when we were there, included in the price, all very interesting. It's very manageable, good audio guide. Bellini's St. Francis was my high point, although many more were close favorites. A don't miss museum

The best museum in New York. A truly amazing collection housed in a beautiful mansion. The quality of the paintings is amazing and it's a small enough collection that a couple of hours allows a leisurely visit with each piece of art. The Fragonard stuff is not to my taste but the rest is truly superb.

Beautiful mansion, interesting art. I am not too into art, but my husband wanted to visit here so I said ok. He enjoyed the art while I enjoyed the old mansion. Def worth a look, but not before MOMA and Met as far as art goes.

Worth a visit!!. An eclectic, fascinating collection in a gorgeous mansion. Houses the only Rembrandt I've ever seen that is not a seated portrait. Also the Holbein portraits of Sirs Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell are worth the visit alone. You'll find paintings by El Greco, Constable, Reynolds, Whistler, Manet, Van Dyck and many more here as this is a very eclectic collection reflecting one man's taste.

Wonderful exquisite house , furniture ,and painting collection. Two families visited, just lovely. Would be worth using the electronic guide for extra information about the contents. Will go again, loved the setting and accessibility of the paintings and furniture. If there was time for only one museum visit in NY, maybe this is the one as less crowded than MOMA and smaller than the MET.

The Crown Jewel. NYC can be overwhelming museum-wise. Same as Paris, London or Rome. And you are always tired of walking and sight-seeing. That's why the Frick is the best deal in NYC. You are visiting a 'house', not a museum. The tour will take under two hours, more if you are a connoisseur or want an in-depth look. Whereas in the Met, a two-hour visit will leave you unsatisfied because it is soooo big.The mansion was custom-built for Mr. Frick, the right-hand man of Mr. Carnegie, one of the great robber barons--who built his own mansion some twenty blocks North. Frick amassed a fantastic collection of European and Asian art, that is utterly well displayed in a palatial frame. Among the jewels: St Jerome by El Greco, St. Francis in the Desert by Bellini, Thomas More by Holbein, The Polish Rider by Rembrandt, a room-full of Fragonards, two Vermeer...exquisite bronzes, porcelain, sculpture, rugs, furniture, and French boiserie complete the mise en scene.Be ready for long entrance lines, especially Sunday mornings.

A peaceful treasure. Small, intimate and absolutely wonderful, one could spend a whole day here. Don't miss the garden court; the sounds of the fountain, the quiet in the midst of a busy part of Manhattan are entrancing. There were no crowds the day I went, but many art students copying and commenting on the art works.
Stunning. Great smaller Gallery. Not too busy. A bit tricky to find but worth the visit. See how the other half lived

Fabulous Venue!. We were fortunate to be able to visit the Frick during two special exhibits. There is an impressionist exhibit on loan and a clock and watch exhibit during this time. They are both worth seeing. The museum is splendid. It is warm and inviting. And to think that this used to be someone's house!

Little Oasis in a hectic city. this is a small gallery that is like a little oasis in the city. this collection was a private home and the paintings are not organized in the usual "gallery" fashion; they seemed more informal, and organized according to the owner's personal taste. To me this created a very relaxing experience.

Small museum with an amazing collection. I particularly love the Rembrandts, the Titians and the one Bronzino. I also just love the small scale. I always find I can focus right in on the artworks I want to see without being too overwhelmed by the space. The bookstore is also quite nice.

Simply one of the best attractions in New York or anywhere.. Unlike many other galleries and museums in New York, The Frick is an oasis of peace and tranquility with an amazing collection of art that will keep you coming back time and time again. It's the perfect size to stop you getting 'museum-ed out' and the history of the collection makes this a selection of old world masters you won't see anywhere else.

Quite an amazing personal collection. My wife was very keen to go to see the Frick collection, so I tagged along.I am not normally a big art fan, but this collection really stunned me. Not only were all of the works of art, furniture, etc significant pieces, you could actually get up very close to them. To think that one family could have owned such pieces, and then 'gift' it to us, is extraordinary.There are even chairs for us old blokes to rest on while the other half reads, and analyses, the details of each exibit !Well worth a visit.

A Surprise. I'd always heard the Frick was the most interesting museum in NYC, but seeing is believing. I was very surprised to see so many paintings I recognized, but had no idea were in the Frick. The house itself is worth the price of admissionTwo caveats:1) The staff are less than friendly. They are clearly there to protect the building and the art, not to make nice with the visitors. What's with the rule about not being able to carry your coat? You have to either wear it or check it.2) I was there on a glorious warm day and it was extremely hot inside, expecially when wearing the coat they wouldn't let me carry (see above).

Beautiful!. The Frick Collection is the best art collection I have seen so far in the US. I've been there many times and never tire of it. The "building" (which is the size of a museum) used to be the home of Henry Clay Frick, who became a millionaire in the coke/steel industry, back in the day. The building and architecture are stunning and the collection is gorgeous. The art was selected by Henry Clay Frick himself, who enjoyed beauty and serenity. There is a large Rococo selection, in addition to works by Vermeer, Van Dyck, Renoir, Gainsborough, Rembrandt and many others. My favorites include "Lady Hamilton as Nature" by George Romney, "Harmony in Pink and Gray: Lady Meux" by James McNeill Whistler and the Fragonard and Boucher Rooms. For art lovers, I highly recommend this!

Interesting. Enjoyed the artwork. Especially enjoyed the atrium. It would be an outstanding experience if a portion of the 'house' was restored and available for viewing as a residence at the time of Frick.
Love it!. All I can say is for me this is sheer bliss! One of the most interesting places to spend an afternoon.

A Jewel. I visited the Frick Collection on my last morning after spending two weeks in New York and have to say it was one of the highlights of my trip. The mansion is just as beautiful as the stunning art it houses. I liked that it was peaceful allowing you to truly appreciate each piece. I recommend using the free audio guide as it has information on Frick and the various rooms in addition to the artwork.
Amazing House. The architecture is extraordinary. It is beautifully designed and has some beautiful artworks. On Sunday you pay what you want to enter.
NOT TO BE MISSED. This is equivalent to a house tour of a fine mansion loaded with fine art and antiques. Quite the little gem, it has the feeling of viewing a house, not a museum.

I'm not a museum guy but.... This was a great collection and balance of Art and Architecture. I am a native New Yorker and it always amazes me to think of what some of these buildings must have been like back in the day. It was astonishing to realize that this used to be someone's own private mansion residence on 5th Ave. The whole place is gorgeous and you will want to move in there yourself! It's right by Central Park so it makes a nice day to check this place out and then take a stroll in the park. Again, I am the kind of guy who gets tired after seeing 10 paintings but this was different because the art was spread out and not overwhelming while the actual house itself is so impressive that you didn't mind wandering through the details. Admission was a little pricey but hey, it's New York.
Great collection. Wheelchairs available for free which was great for husband with mobility problems. Beautiful objects and paintings all on one level.

Frick Collection. My husband and I spent a very interesting couple of hours at the Frick Collection. It is a stunning building filled with the most unique, beatiful collection of art and furniture. The story behind the collection is terrific. We also thought it was good value for money.

A beautiful museum that feels like a home. The Frick is a delight.
An exquisite collection in a beautiful gracious home. Unlike the crazy crowds at the larger museums this is quieter and much more approachable ...beautiful works of art . A charmer
A must. Not widely known but fantastic - go! I'm not an art of mueseum guy but my wife dragged me a long. I think I enjoyed it more than her.
Amazing Museum. Incredible small museum, with great art in every room. Rembrandt, Hans Holbein, Titian, Monet. Also furniture and decorative art. Beautiful courtyard.
Wonderful Gem. One of the most beautiful exhibition spaces anywhere. Small but superb collection and special exhibits.
Wonderful collection. Wonderful collection of paintings inter-displayed. Particularly liked having a free audio tour so you could choose what you wanted to know more about.

Fabulous find!. This is a museum that must be seen. It is small enough to be enjoyed but has fabulous paintings and other collections. If you go on Sunday between 11:00 and 1:00, you will get a discounted entry fee.

beautiful museum. This museum used to be the home of Henry Clay Frick and his wife and daughter in the early 1900's. He always intended it to be a museum so that the public could see his art collection. The collection is wonderful to see but also walking around an old NY mansion from the early 20th century is amazing. It's a very unique museum. I highly recommend going.
Small but very interesting collection. Very interesting collection. Querying can take an hour. Some items are really unique. Expect it will take one or two hours.

Lovely building and art. This was my first time at the Frick Collection, but it will definitely not be the last. The museum building itself, which for the most part was the Frick's home, is very interesting. But at the time we visited there were also two great special exhibits -- one on Impressionist drawings and one on a Renaissance altarpiece. A delight!

Surprisingly Wonderful. This is one of the best kept secrets in New York. It is the mansion of the Frick family and it may be the most luxurious mansion in New York. The art work is almost at the level of the Met and probably exceeds the art in any other city in America. This must be on your list for a long visit to New York. Also, make sure you see the 20 minute film they show.
museum mile. Superb collection of paintings & furniture- not roped off no small children allowed Many English painters e.g.Constable,Gainsborough plus highlight for me the Fragonard room

Girl Interrupted. I visited Frick Collection because I wanted to see Vermeer's Girl Interrupted At Her Music. I have seen the film with Jolie and Ryder, and if you're really interested in it, then you have seen the deleted scenes and the influence of this painting on the main character. So I went in, saw this magnificent painting, that made me think about a girl's mysteries of heart, walked back and forth in front of it. I explored the rest of the collection as it was also worth checking out, it was a shame though, that you weren't allowed to take photos, but, well - it's not the first place to apply these restrictions.
Beautiful small collection of art in an amazing house. Really good range of art set in a beautiful home of one of the rich business barons of American history.
Love it. Fantastic collection in perfect setting. I love the indoor garden. Great place to check in New York.

Plum 22 Super paintings to enjoy. I came upon this gallery by chance as MOMA was closed. I was very excited to see, close up Van Gogh, Vermeer, Gainsborough and Turner paintings. Very well laid out and plenty of room to see each painting. I did not enjoy some of the more modern pieces so we started on the 6th floor and worked our way down to the 4th as I found those floors the most interesting.

Architecture and Art. Collection of the old and new masters is worthy but the mansion was just as interesting as well as the furniture and accessories. The crowds were not so overwhelming on a Sunday morning and the staff were accommodating.

A TASTEFUL MAN'S COLLECTION. What a wonderful, well-planned mansion! And an incredible collection with Rembrandts, Vermeers, Impressionists as Degas, Toulouse-Lautrec, Gauguin, Camille Pissarro...a delightful visit for art-lovers.

Great works but not so overwhelming. This museum had many famous paintings and artists as well as sculpture and beautiful furniture. It's size was such that we could see most everything without feeling like we had to spend days there (contrasted with the Metropolitan Museum). The free audio guide was excellent.It was also interesting to visit the mansion of Mr. Frick. We had heard of him through the H2 series "The Men Who Built America," which made that component and the film about him a little more interesting.

Blown Away!. So many beautiful treasures to see at the Frick! It should NOT be missed. Be prepared to be blown away by the collection of old masters, furniture, porcelain, bronzes, clocks, etc. We've toured European palaces that can't compare. Go, go! Pay what you want Sunday from 11-1, but be prepared for a long line. It goes quickly and is so worth it at a reduced or full admission price. This is a highlight of our NYC visit.

The Frick. I went to school in NYC. Although I went to most of the great museums in the city, I never made it to the Frick. While on a trip to the city to visit my daughter, I made it a point to do so. What a wonderful experience! In addition to offering great art, the museum extended needed relief from the hubbub of the city and the bad weather it was experiencing that day. Many of the other great museums, crowded at all times, do not offer a haven for the weary. I highly recommend this and regret that I didn't visit earlier.
One of the best. A most serene setting on the upper east side in a glorious mansion from the gilded age of America. World class ...no doubt

My favorite NYC museum.. My favorite NYC museum. It's not the largest museum in NYC, but it's my favotite. Maybe because it's the Carrere and Hastings designed 913 Fifth Avenue mansion of Henry Clay Frick, the original robber baron, for whom the phrase was coined. Maybe because it has more Vermeers than any place outside of Holland. Maybe I just love this museum because it never fails to refresh me.

Magical experiene. A great collection of art put together by Henry Frick and on display in his own house. Just the right size to enjoy and see a range of art from medieval to late 19th century. Magical

Great Museum. I loved seeing paintings and drawings that previously I've only seen in books. The works are presented in a comfortable way and it's not so overwhelming that you can't see the whole collection in a relatively short period of time. So many museums are overwhelming that I find myself exhausted despite only seeing < 25% of the entire show. The Frick is one that you can easily and leisurely see in an afternoon

Beauty and tranquility. The art, the ceramics, the furniture, the decor and the architecture of the house itself, everything is beautiful, even breathtaking, in this lovely museum which feels manageable if you want just a nice quiet museum experience without feeling overwhelmed as you might at the Met. They offer free sketching on Sundays in the courtyard and supply the materials, so if you have an artist in your group or family this could be a highlight, but we were happy just to soak in the beauty of the house and the artwork.

It is Worth the Visit Just to See the Home-But the Art is Amazing. The Frick used to be the former home of Mr. Frick, who spent a long time building it, for the comparatively short time that he got to enjoy it. But back then, nobody cared, since they had many other homes in which to reside while the new one was being built.He designed this home on Central Park both as a residence and as a gallery for his substantial art collection. The Frick's own collection is sufficient, but because of the magnificence of the setting, it is a frequent home to special exhibitions of art from around the world.And unlike some of the larger New York museums, like the Met and MOMA, you never feel crowded at the Frick, and there are so many beautiful areas to sit down and appreciate the architecture, as well as the art.

A step back in time..... The museum is a nice mix of great masters set in Mr. Frick's home built at the end of his life. He only lived there 5 years before his death. It takes about 3 hours to see it using the audio guide. I highly recommend it.

Amazing and peaceful museum. This museum has a fantastic collection, and its ambiance is great. The gallery is set in a mansion along 5th Ave. The art is arranged tastefully, and the mood of the museum is calm and relaxed. It's a great sanctuary from hectic NYC sights, and it's world-class.
Lovely Museum. It was a great museum and small which I liked. Very peaceful place to look at art.Easy to walk to and you feel like your in someone's home.

The house is just as interesting as the art. Great private collection of artworks on show, personally I found myself more swept away by the actual property as it was beautifully maintained and offered a glimpse into the past, with original furniture and features.
A true Gem. An intimate yet luxurious setting for viewing art. No mobs or strollers here. Great collection of Vermeers.

Beautiful and lived up to expectations. A beautiful gallery/house/museum, more compact, peaceful and manageable than the frenzy of MOMA for example and with some stunning and famous art. The audio guide, included in the price, is excellent.

Vast art treasures in a grand 5th Av Mansion. What I liked most about the Frick is its compact size and a feeling of being a a very wealthy relative's mansion. The galleries are set up in the various rooms of the former and imposing Frick mansion so here there's no sterile museum-like ambiance. On the contrary, there's even an inner courtyard with fountains. Tip: When leaving go to Laduree bakery on Madison Av , 2 minute walk from the Museum for the best (though expensive) macaroons in NYC.

Nice manageable museum. This was a cool place to visit, right off central park at 70th & 5th ave. Beautiful architecture and art collections. We toured the entire collection in about an hour. We are not art aficionados by any means, so some may want to take more time to appreciate! It was quick exposure to some world-class art and a step back into time. Clean bathrooms on the lower level!
Different museum. This is one of the must-see museums in NYC. It's inside a mansion, so it's really different and interesting!
A Treat. This small museum should be on everyone's list of places to visit in NYC. Unlike the MOMA or the Metropolitan Museum, the Frick is manageable. Make sure you see the Vermeer's!

beautiful. The mansion is beautiful. The architecture is stunning and look for the garden with a fountain and seating inside. The art on display is fantastic traditional old school. The Turner's are marvelous. It is a tad overpriced $18.00 non senior . while you are on museum row this is a nice stop. Look for the organ on the alcove in the stairs going up.

I adore this place. Imagine being so wealthy you can buy a complete block of New York and build your own home with an army of tradesman within a couple of years.Then imagine being so wealthy you can buy beautiful paintings by Renoirs, Fragonards, Vermeers, sculptures and and other top-name artworks rom history for your home to display throughout. Then imagine being so altruistic and generous-spirited that you donate your home and its breath-taking treasures to New York City for the public to enjoy.This is the second time I've visited and won't be the last.

More than a museum!. This gallery is definetely worth a visit. It doesn't feel like an art gallery. The whole building, the furtinture, everything adds up and makes this one of the most interesting museums in New York. There's paintings of most of the old masters. I am giving 4 instead of 5 stars because they don't allow photograpy, even without flash.

Great museum. Even if you are not a big art fan (I'm not) the Frick collection is still worth a visit, its not that expensive, we went on a Sunday and between 11am and 1pm you can just make a donation, or pay what you want. Just being inside a New York Mansion is an experience in itself, and if you like art and antique furniture then you will love it.

great mansion and artwork. beautiful mansion on central park with priceless paintings.was a bit crowded since free Sun 11am to 1pm. unfortunately, no photography. free coat and bag check. should have first seen the 15 min intro movie for its nice overview.
Beautiful collection.. Beautiful art in a lovely setting. The paintings, clocks and statues are lovely. The Frick home is also magnificent. It was busy, but you never felt rushed.

special!. GREAT museum... the paintings are wonderful and it's a tremendously pleasant experience to just walk thru. it's not usually terribly crowded and it's a convenient location on museum mile. only downside is children under 12 are not admitted.

Good place to enjoy NY. Near Central Park is the perfect place to end your evening. It is a small but beautiful palace with lots of art pieces and a good audio guide to follow all the details. No children allowed and people always advising you to take care of the furniture, the pictures, etc. It a comfortable place and very interesting with art from different historical moments. Absolutely recommended!
A jewel of a museum. A delightful collection of art in the former Frick residence, which is anything but "modest". Beautiful artwork and furnishings displayed in an elegant setting.

Absolutely the most beautiful museum I've seen.. A local New Yorker said to check this out. So glad I did. If you enjoy Manet, Renoir and the like, this is the place for you. I went on Sunday when it is pyc. I went for opening time and waited 20 mins to get in, so make sure you go early as the line was very long. The pieces are beautiful and the building itself inside is a work of art.Be warned, no pictures!

THE BEST SMALL NYC MUSEUM. I have been to THE FRICK more times than I can count. And it never disappoints, never fails, and always amazes. First, the location is stupendous, but that's not why you'll visit THE FRICK. You'll visit because the art is world-class and because, when you learn the story behind why THE FRICK even exists, you'll have an different appreciation for its beauty. Mr Henry Clay Frick built this "home" to house his art collection. He was a genius...a very wealthy genius, at that. So now when you walk around, imagine that you could have LIVED here. I love it so much. Be sure to see my favorite painting, the RENIOR that sits near the organ -- Mother and Children. Dreamy....ALL of it! Oh, and on Sunday mornings...IT'S FREE!!!!!

A true treat - old masters displayed as they should be!. This is a magical place - such an amazing collection of old masters, especially Italian. Wonderful setting too - very interesting history. Definitely worth a trip! Some of the paintings are in "Last Quarter" which we coincientally saw the same day we went to visit the Frick!

Fantastic!. Wonderful art in a beautiful setting...three Vermeers! I've always loved The Wallace Collection in London; now I know I can go to New York for the same (if not better) experience. Just lovely!

A Hidden Gem - Well worth it. The rooms are set up so wonderfully, and the center glass garden and fountain is so peaceful, you don't feel like you're in NYC! It really makes you able to imagine what the early years in the city were like.
A most amazing gallery. The most beautiful exhibition I have ever visited, especially as it was in someone's (original) home.........definitely worth a visit.

Real quality with an excellent video introduction. A well maintained art and furniture museum from the turn of the 19th century of one man in the house and collection he and subsequently his trustees created.
Small enough to see everything in 2 hours. Get there early

Quiet, unspoiled, lovely. Such a lovely setting to sit and contemplate an El Greco or other great artist. This is a small museum - but it's usually uncrowded and sitting and staring into the depth of a painting or at the work of a sculpter is so peaceful and enjoyable. The Frick Collection is one of my very favorite places in Manhattan.

Nice place to spend a couple of hours. A nice collection of impressionist era art and artifacts. Nothing modern, thank God. No written commentary, so pick up an audio guide on the way in if you want a brief explanation of the works.

Intimate and Awesome. The Frick is a little gem just off Fifth Ave. at 70 St. East. Housed in a beautiful old mansion, it includes some amazing art: 3 Vermeers, a couple of Rembrandts, loads of medieval religious art, and, my favorites, some beautful Turners. You walk from room to room and get to see the art up close. The collection can be viewed in an hour or two, so you don't feel so overwhelmed as you do at the Met, yet you still feel that you've had a walk with beauty.

Impressive private collection. . Wow! Mr Frick must have been seriously rich. Great if you want a small museum and great house. Audio guides were very helpful especially if you choose the audio for the whole room as you first enter each area. We're not ones to hang around long in a museum but took a good hour here as there was plenty of interesting stuff.
Best Kept Secret. I loved this museum. Went with my class. Amazing collection of art. It's unbelievable to think that this beautiful place was actually someone's home.
Well worth a visit. Eclectic mix of works of art in a superb setting.The house alone is worth a visit to see how a rich New Yorker lived.
Charming. A great stop to get away from the crowds of the other museums. The art is nice but the building is a great work all in its own. I really wanted to see the upstairs, but not allowed.

Only happy and beautiful art found here. This was a private house, belonging to Mr. Frick, and the house itself, the gardens, and the decor are worth seeing, but his art collection is amazing. He only collected works that made him happy, and I think that seeing them will make you happy too. Enjoy! Not a huge gallery, but big in content.

Amazing art in a unique setting.. Sunday's before 1 pm the entrance is almost free. It is the one day a week that you can pay what you can. I visited the museum in the morning before my flight, so it was enough for a couple of hours. You will find yourself in front of a Renoir, Vermeer, Turner, Velazquez...too many to mention and be awed by these great masters. Take the audio. Beautiful mansion, great collection.
Wonderful collection of art. The art collection is amazing, and I love that you can actually see a movie while in the museum that gives you the history of the art and the collector.

What an amazing collection!. We have visited all of the major museums in NYC, but this was our first experience at the Frick. We were familiar with the Frick Museum in Pittsburgh, where Frick had collected while still living in Pittsburgh. But when he moved to NY, he really became a world class collector. This collection was his taste and his money, and he used both well to create a very good collection in a gorgeous Fifth Avenue mansion. Not only is the art on the walls excellent, but his tables, desks, clock and decorative arts are all well chosen and well displayed Very nice.

Lovely. Fantastic balance! The art collection is varied but at the same time unique and sophisticated. Building and rooms well maintained and charming. Small garden inside is a wonderful oasis in the middle of NYC.

Wonderful museum overlooking Central Park. A fantastic find located in a lovely house overlooking Central Park which contains several original works of Turner, Constable, Manet, Monet and Renoir as well as a beautiful collection of furniture and enamels. If you go on a Sunday morning between 11-1 there is no charge of admission apart from a donation. Recommend using the hand held audio machine.

A piece of culture and history in the middle of New York. This is a fantastic venue to view some of the world’s most famous artists in an intimate and largely uncrowded place. To see close up the works of Renoir, Constable, Turner, Degas, Vermeer and others plus wonderful ceramics and sculptures was a real treat. A high light was to see juxtaposed the Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell. One can spend a few hours (guided by a recorded hand piece) roaming and taking in these masters and not be totally overwhelmed as one often is in a larger museum or gallery where there is too much choice. The commentary is wonderful and the rooms/galleries and layout spacious and friendly. You can sit and take in the works of art. A beautiful elegant old building now holding a wonderful collection of master’s works, well worth a visit. Staff are helpful, the home is spacious and the courtyard a great place to rest and reflect.
Often missed, but should not.. A very intresting story, a real tast of what it was like during the times of the Fricks, Rockellers, etc..

Enjoyable favorite art museum. Delightful visit. Art is amazing and well worth seeing. Visit feels warm and intimate and not overwhelming as in some of the larger museums. Nice small gift shop and very helpful staff. I will return.
Brilliant. Again, another wonderful collection and a must-see for anyone interested in art. The building that the collection is housed in is worth a visit alone
Don't skip the Frick. A jewel of Manhattan. Don't miss it by sticking only to the Met and MOMA. The building itself on 5th Ave is well worth the visit!

The Frick Museum is now my favorite museum!. An outstanding collection of artwork but viewed in the beautiful Frick mansion. So much more intimate than the Metropolitian Museum of Art. I loved that the audio tour provided information on nearly every painting in the mansion. If someone has only a limited time in New York I would recommmended the Frick over the larger museum.

My Favourite New York Place. Every time I go to NY I visit the Frick.I love art galleries but generally find the size, the number of paintings and the temptation to spend hours traipsing around always detracts from the experience in the end.The Frick is small and has some truly wonderful pieces of art in it. I always go to see the Bronzino of the young man in brilliant green and the two astonishing Holbeins. They are just my favourites and there is plenty more to see. They have added a new area with clocks and a few odds and ends this year which didn't particularly excite but I took two friends for the first time who really enjoyed the experience too.I love the story about Frick padding down the stairs in the middle of the night every now and again when he couldn't sleep and just sitting and gazing at one of his acquisitions. I think this appeals because rather than being a national collection collected and curated by professionals it was actually a loved collection collected by a man with lots of cash. It seems more personal somehow and seems to reflect a love of the art and objects.I would advise anyone who loves to pop in spend an hour looking at some beautiful art, some of it extremely familiar by very famous artists, to try the Frick. It's just a lovely little gallery in a Central park palazzo of the last century.

small, intimate, eclectic. the small size means that you can "do" the Frick in a couple of hours, should you wish, without feeling overwhelmed. But don't underestimate the collection! Very famous works lead to "so THIS is where this work is!" Vermeers, Turners, Rembrandt, Velasquez, two lovely Chinese porcelein ladies - amazing.
Fabulous Collection of Art. This was one of the highlights on my recent visit.The Frick mansion is incredible and the art collection is out of this world. One not to miss!
My favourite museum. Absolutely loved this museum!Not only was the artwork amazing, but also the house. Hard to believe only 4 people lived in this house!!!

Classic. Wonderful building, excellent exhibition space, great collection. Fragonards to die for. European paintings, furniture, porcelain, all in quiet accessible surroundings. Sunday concerts. A peaceable interlude.

Not to be missed. This is a wonderful museum, given that the house was specifically designed to show the art collection of Mr Frick. Make sure you put this place on your list, you certainly will not be disappointed. The museum is small, so try to arrive at less busier times.

Another intimate powerhouse. Some of the paradigms of western art are right here, tucked away in a quiet place, just waiting to be enjoyed. No fanfare, no splash, really, just really solid esthetics put together by personal taste and lots an lots of money. There's even a sense of humor with a portrait of Thomas Moore on one side of a fireplace and Cromwell of the other side. They were political enemies I believe. I also believe that the art in that room is in the position chosen by the founder. See, a sense of humor.
Beautiful Museum. My daughter loved it second only to the Metropolitan Museum. She loved that period rooms and the period art

A must-see attraction in NYC. A wonderful collection of art and objects. There's no pattern to the style of works of art collected by Frick. I've never seen so many 'masterpieces' in so small an area before.
The guy certainly had more than enough money to spend in his time.
Entry charge between 11am and 2pm Sundays is what you want to pay.

Peaceful New York . This museum is wonderful, the collection in unusual, lots of portraits in a wonderful furnished house, you really feel at ease, it was quiet, no one was talking loudly like in other museum in N.Y. and the people working there are really prepared!
A must for someone who likes art and beautiful houses. Not for everyone.

Haven. With two hours between engagements on the Upper East Side, what better place to soak up great art & reflect than the elegant Frick Collection. A haven from the noise & fast pace of the great city - especially during Easter Week - the stunning religious art in the opulent rooms surrounding the splendid center courtyard with its tinkling fountain, banked with white lilies & vibrant pink azaleas, took on added meaning & any opportunity to gaze unhurriedly at my favorite painting, Georges de la Tour's "Education of the Virgin," is always appreciated. Always, the tone is muted as well-mannered viewers wandered the darkened halls, lined with treasures, and marveled - in many languages - at the richness of the collection.Although the gift shop offers quality cards, serious reading material & unusual souvenirs, nevertheless I always wish the Frick had a tea room, where visitors could prolong their retreat for a while longer with a cup of chamomile tea and a pastry.

Great museum, unfortunately it's been discovered. We've been going to the Frick for eons. Maybe a decade ago it was still relatively crowd free, and then the experience was amazing. Now, as they say, tourism ultimately destroys that which it strives to promote. While it would be way too dramatic to say the Frick has been ruined, you're now going to have to, um, share space with a lot more folks than you would have a number of years ago. The museum itself is still a treasure, both for the artwork as well as the house it's collected in. Even now, even with more people pressure, the little fountain in the middle is a calming place -- testimony to the foresight of Frick himself as well as the efforts of the museum management to preserve some of the old ambiance.

One of my favourite art galleries in the world. An interesting art collection set out in a New York mansion , as though it were still a home. It's a great complement to the Guugenheim and the Met, and just a step from Central Park if you want a complete break from cultural experience.

World's Most Fascinating Museum. An amazing collection of art wonderfully arranged and giving a real impression of what Frick valued and enjoyed. Compact, stunning; worth visiting every time you one to this great city

Serene and fascinating. Visiting the Frick is a completely different experience than the nearby Met. It's quite compact, and in a few hours you can see a very high-quality collection that focuses on European painting of the sixteenth through 19th centuries. There are a few sculptures, clocks, etc, but primarily the visit is to commune with Vermeer, Holbein, Turner, Renoir and other great painters, and they are represented by some of their best works.There's a good short introductory film on Henry Frick and how he built his home with the intention of converting it to a museum, and the free audio guides are very informative about the individual works of art. Unlike the Met or MOMA, there's no cafe and only a very small bookstore, so the emphasis is totally on the art.

SURPRISE SURPRISE. In my difficult search for some old masters in modern-loving NY I came across Frick. Oddly, I never had heard of it before. One always learns I guess. And what a place. The building alone, with the indoor courtyard is worth a visit. I spend a few hours just being awed and absolutely loved it.

Masterpieces in an intimate setting. The small size of the Frick allows you to savor each masterpiece without feeling you must move on to the next in order to "finish." The collection is small and select.

well organised "pay as you wish" Sunday. To think there are people who actually lived and live in such mansions. Fabulous collection, but as I am into more modern art, I was most impressed with the impressionist exhibition - Toulouse- Lautrec, Degas, Manet, Monet etc borrowed from Clark. Well worth seeing. The courtyard is beautiful

Disappointed - so small. I have visited most of the top museums in the world, but I must say that we were disappointed with this one. Okay, so there are enough Gainsborough's and Turner's to throw a stick at - he obviously liked English painters - but frankly we were disappointed at how small the museum was. The staff were like little hitlers: I had trouble seeing one of the name plates on a painting and was abruptly told to move back. I wasn't even allowed to take a photo of the fountain - which isn't a painting! My wife was told to put her palm cross in the cloakroom for some reason! We should have gone during the 'pay what you want' time and put in five bucks perhaps. I cannot understand why it rates so highly.

Such a jewel!. The collection of art is a wonderful representation of great artists. It is small and very accessible. I brought my 12 year old who is not a huge art fan and he enjoyed the the audio tour and the fact that we would not be walking for miles within the museum itself -- everything is at your fingertips.

Beautiful art, beautiful home. This is a wonderful museum in the beautiful home of Mr Frick. I highly recommend it for art lovers. Many people told me not to miss this museum and , having seen it, I agree. The mansion and grounds are also spectatular.

so , so. It should be at the bottom of your museum list... Lots of better options ( moma , guggenheim , met , natural history )... If you've already seen them all , ok , go there , a very nice house to walk in and see beautiful things...

Wonderful art work in a home like setting. I loved my visit to the Frick collection, going mainly to see the Vermeers there. The setting for the pictures is lovely, rooms set out with furniture (all part of the collection) making it look like a very opulent but welcoming home. Admission charge of ~$15 so expensive to we Brits, but worth it.

Definetily must visit. Very good collection of musterpieses. Represented in a house where Frick lived his last years. Fine interiors make perfect foreground for pictures, wich are disposed not in historical order, but followed Frick's taste. Collection is small for scale of museum, and it remains very human and refined aftertaste.

Small but neat. It was fun to walk through this collection. We visited between 11 and 1 on a Sunday to take advantage of "pay what you want" admission. It was a bit crowded and by the time we left there was a line outside the building. But, we still had a nice time exploring the rooms and seeing the many different paintings and furniture on display. The Hans Holbeins of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell were my favorite. They're worth the visit alone, I think.

Worn, out-of-touch, Robber Baron vanity museum. I teach Art History for a living and spend most of my vacation time in museums throughout the USA and Europe. I visited the Frick Collection once 25 years ago and saw a decent Ingres exhibit. I went back to see the Piero della Francesca exhibit last week. I knew the exhibit would be small since most of Piero's works are located in Italy and cannot travel, but I didn't expect an exhibit that taught me less than a brief look the Wikipedia would. All right, one bad exhibit. So I toured the rest of the collection.Yes, the Frick does hold some great paintings (haphazardly collected by a Robber Baron with more money than taste), but the way they are displayed is terrible. The dark walls and carpets are worn and dirty and the lighting is circa the 1950s at best. The museum makes no effort to put the works in context--they are not even labeled or dated. The audio tour is a joke--grimy handheld gadgets that teach little. The "free" hourly movie basically talks about Frick, the capitalist--not the art.Another problem--no photos for its permanent collection. Are they kidding--I've been allowed to photograph most of the permanent collections in museums all over New York City, the USA, and Europe.The admission is expensive--$18 for adults. The Metropolitan Museum just up Fifth Avenue is $25 for the what I consider the best museum in the world. (By the way, the $25 is recommended, not required--you may pay less if you wish, but at $25 it is money well spent.) Skip the Frick and go directly to the Met, which is currently showing an Impressionist and Fashion exhibit that is fascinating--I didn't know more could be said about the Impressionist, but I can now do a whole new lecture on what I learned there last Sunday.

The greatest little Museum. A magnificent home, turned to a Museum by a man who collected art to please the senses and will marble you with the story, the locations and the surroundings. A visit to a noble home more than a line up at a museum, an experience highly recommended.

Romantic visions of art and education. The Frick is clearly a diamond in the coal of NYC Museums as its opulent rooms are filled with matching period art and furniture, so one gets the entire vision, not just a blank room with pretty pictures.

Simply my favorite. Whenever people go to NYC, I tell them to go to the Frick Museum; and of all the art museums in New York City, this is the only one I took my little girls to when we visited because I knew that if the paintings bored them, the Chinese vases and the furniture wouldn't. This is, as the Michelin Guide, once wrote, the "pearl" of New York City art museums, and I was delighted to share it with my partner on our visit to New York. Great Rembrandts, fabulous Vermeers, an exquisite Van Eyck, exemplary Van Dycks and Turners and...Bellini &...What a delight!

A great setting to relax and enjoy art. Unlike any US museum I had ever seen. Set in a beautiful old mansion on 5th ave, the Frick offers a relaxing environment to appreciate the Frick collect of paintings, bronzes, clocks and assorted items. Take a few minutes to sit in the central atrium around a water feature. Also a nice touch is they staggered the entry of visitors to keep the number of people reasonable inside and it worked. Also be advised coats and large bags/backpacks had to be checked (no charge though.) It helped keep things comfortable. Also they offer also at no charge a digital assistant for information on collection. A great relaxing few hours.

An opportunity to enter a gilded age mansion. There are such amazing works of art in here - Rembrandt, Piero della Francesca, Holbein - and the list goes on. Its a jewel crown collection, not so big as to overwhelm like the Met but genuinely well-chosen and lovely.

What a building!. Hola all,We had the opportunity to visit the Frick Collection on a rainy morning. It was one of the highlights of our trip to NYC.It was a rainy day. Upon arriving we were directed to a complimentary coat/umbrella/bag check. Admission was $18. The audio tour is complimentary, I highly recommended grabbing it on your way in. Among the amazing works of art you will see (the Thomas More...OMG) you will also have the opportunity to listen to how each room in the house was used. The house has just as much rich history of the works of art themselves.We spent about 2 hours at The Frick and would highly recommend it anybody looking to learn about the history of a NYC family who loved their art

Total Gem. I love all museums. This one I love as it is off Museum Way and steps from Laduree for macarons. But the courtyard is lovely and the art is AMAZING! If you are into the classics and not contemporary/modern art this is the place.
A beautiful museum in a unique setting but $$$. It's pricy and there's no discounts for Seniors; the exhibits we saw were wonderful, especially the drawings.

I can go again and again. This is one of my favorite places for going to see art work. It is an individuals collection, displayed in the house it was purchased to be displayed in. It is a fabulous atmosphere. It you go on Sundays then admission is what you want to pay until 1pm, a real deal for New York. Make sure you take the time to see the video when you first arrive (about 15 minutes, free), and you will understand the Frick better.
A wonderful experience. The art work was incredible and my grandson, age 16, fell in love with the museum. We spent many hours enjoying our trip through the museum.

Short and sweet. I have been to NYC many times, and have always wanted to see the Frick. Finally got there. The Gainesboroughs I loved, along with the rest of the collection. Each piece stands out. no clutter. The frescoes are fantastic. This is one of those houses built to scale to hold the paintings, and has a European sensibility to it. When I exited I had forgotten I was in Manhattan.
museum is a work of art itself. it is wonderful to see works of art in the home of the benefactor who aquired them.Informative short film giving background of Frick

Fantastic Mansion Part of the Exhibit. This home of the robber baron H.C. Frick has been turned into a museum housing his extensive work of art. Everything from Impressionists to byzantine art is on display along with individual works by El Greco, Whistler and Rembrandt. As much as anything, however, it's interesting to reflect on the fact that one family actually lived in this place, thanks to the backbreaking work of coal miners in Pennsylvania. One disappointing aspect was that there was little biographical info on Frick himself, who had a fanous feud with his one-time boss and partner Andrew Carnegie, who lived just up the street.
good museum but rather cramped when busy. A good option for a rainy day and more personal than the big museums and galleries. Less reliance on the audio guide would be good.

Worth a look. To be honest i had heard so much about the Frick Collection and was excited to see it.Besides the opluence of the house which was amazing i found the art very boring and you where only able to see only one level of the house it would have been great to go upstairs and have a look.

Amazing collection. This former private house of a multimillionaire shows in context an extraordinary collection of pitorial art, furniture etc. Its on a human scale so not exhausting, but utterly stunning that one man should have been able to amass such a collection of major art works. Strongly recommended to anyone who admires beutiful objects.

One of the two best small art museums in the world. It would be worse than a crime, it would be folly to visit New York without visiting the Frick, even if you've been there many times before. Only the Mauritshuis in The Hague ranks with the Frick as a superb small museum in which you don't get overwhelmed by the size of the building or the wonderful collection. It would take far too long to list all of the Frick's treasures, but here are some works that I always revisit: Bellini's St. Francis, Thomas Cromwell and Thomas More, both by Holbein, the aged Rembrandt's self-portrait, the Vermeers (generally better than those in the Metropolitan Museum), the Bronzino, the Turners, Romney's Lady Hamilton, Goya's The Forge ... I could go on, but readers probably already know that this is a magnificent collection. And if you visit it before 1 p.m. on Sunday, you can pay what you want.

Glad that you decided to share!. This art museum is just a right size for Sunday morning when they have pay as you wish. (11-1) So calming to go through all the artwork Frick acquired. Some from JP Morgan. One of the most beautiful setting to see the master artwork!!!

The Frick is Fabulous. The Frick Collection and its setting are equally impressive.
