The beautiful building provides a fitting backdrop for an amazing assemblage of paintings, porcelain, and furnishings.The interior courtyard has to be one of the most romantic spots in the City - particularly in the midst of winter.

Great small collection. The Frick is perfect if you don't want to deal with a mega-museum and huge crowds. The collection is limited, but there is plenty of great art, and the setting is beautiful. The interior courtyard is a fabulous space. You can spend a very peaceful hour and a half in the Frick and be very satisfied.

Beautiful Home. The art collection was interesting but really I came here because I love to see old private homes. The rooms were furnished as I assume the Fricks had furnished them and I loved wandering and wondering how they used the house. "so, guests would come in here...have dinner in here, then cigars and coffee here, ..." Obviously too much Downtown Abbey in my life :)

European paintings in a New York mansion. A neat alternative to the Met if you like European paintings (and a few Asian ceramics). They are all displayed on the walls of this Gilded Age mansion. I especially love how Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell glare at each other on either side of the grand old fireplace in the "living hall."

Small Space but Great Collection. Great collections of paintings, sculpture, furniture and porcelain.. Nice works bu Velazquez, Rembrandt, Whistler and Goya. Great locale just down from the MET on 70th Street.

Lovely reprieve from the craziness of New York City!. Amazing collection of artwork, furniture & sculpture. Lovely grand building which has been emaculatey cared forArt is amazing with some of the most famous painters who have ever lived. Even for those who aren't "into art" you will recognise many pieces of art. it is a nice timeout walking around the building as it is very serene & relaxingBe sure to check out the 15minute movie which details a brief history about Frick & the collection.Definitely worth it as it is not as crowded as other venues. You wil have plenty of time to admire all the work & even sit & just enjoy the ambiance. The shop is quite small but has lots to look at & prints are reasonably priced.

Outstanding. It is very near the Art museum, in 5th Ave by central Park.Its an American Mansion where Mr. Frick lived and collected marvellous art pieces. Paintings, sculptures, and all kind of high quality art. and very well displayed.

Enjoyed the visit. I enjoyed visiting the Frick collection - mainly because I love portraiture and partly because of the house it was in. Its a good way to spend an hour or two and doesn't feel over-whelming. If you can think of a 'famous' painter - he or she is likely to be here. Almost shocking that one man could afford to amass this amount of art.We walked to the Collection from our hotel on 31st and then cut across to Bloomingdales and came back to the hotel via many shops and Times Square after a rest whilst watching a film at a local Cinema. It was a good if tiring day!

Get a taste of how NYC society lived in 'the good old days'. This is my favourite 'old' museum in NYC. I have visited MANY times and never tire of it. I love:The classic paintingsThe mansionCheck out the concert schedule for special performances

Two Experiences in One. When Henry Frick moved to New York, he never mentioned to his architect that he was going to display much of his art in the home, most likely for fear that it would feel more like a museum than a home. What's amazing about the Frick collection is that the pieces are all of such high quality from Italian, Spanish and French artists, yet they are combined with equally great sculptures, furniture, rugs, silver and an amazing time collection mostly in the same manner as when Henry Frick lived there. Your experience is two-fold in that you can appreciate all these great artists, yet also experience how Mr. Frick lived in that era. Such a better way to experience the art than in a museum. There is a short (about 10-15 minutes) film on Mr. Frick and the collection that usually plays each day. I would highly recommend watching it (it's free) to give you an even better feel for the space. I would also recommend you check your coat upon entering (otherwise you have to wear it at all times) and pick up a audio set to hear about the most interesting pieces. Both are included in the price of admission.

The Frick Collection - time to marvel. The Frick collection is displayed in a private house, it is in fact, a magnificent mansion in the very heart of Manhattan. The mansion has a distinct European flavor, its precious furniture, chadeliers, porcelains, and clocks originate from France, Italy and England - everything is totally enchanting and elegant. But it is this cumilation of paintings that can easily blind you. From El Greco, Rembrandt, Impressionist, Titian to Gainsborough. I, for some reason, was so stunned by the latter artist, that had trouble tearing myself off from marvelling at those refined portrets. The collection is not that huge, everything exhibited is a masterpiece of an unbelievable magnitude, and it gives you enough time to take everything in. Come and enjoy, you will never forget the experince!

Beautiful Collection. The collection is amazing. To get a chance to see so many great pieces of art in a setting in which a private collector gathered and displayed them in his home is something I would highly recommend.

Oldest Mansion in Manhattan. You get a real feel for the elegant lifestyle in the early 1900s when you wander through the Frick Mansion. It displays famous paintings from Renoir to Whistler. But I loved the furniture, upholstered chairs and the handcarved chests were incredible craftsmanship. You realize that lifestyle is long gone but not forgotten here. Definitely worth a visit.
Art in a home setting. The Frick is unique in that the art is displayed in a home setting. The home itself, mansion actually, is worth a visit in itself.

Hostility to artists. While the Frick is a magical place, I was very disappointed in the staff's hostility to artists. After taking in the inspiring collEction, I sat down in the fountain courtyard on the stone steps, out of the way of traffic to sketch. Shortly after I was interrupted and told I could only sit on one of the benches. This policy is far too restrictive, and flies in the face of the very artistic mission that a good museum should embrace. My experience was spoiled, and I left angry and determined not to return.
Art when want intimate experience. I didn't have a lot of time, but enjoyed walking around with the free audio set; plus the special exhibit of Piero de la Franesca was great.

Close up cultural experience. This is a lovely way to see some of the best art works in the world. As they are displayed in the setting of a house you can see them really up close and even get an idea of the thickness of paint etc. In addition the relatively small scale of the house in comparison to a museum means that you don't get sensory overload. An ideal way to spend a rainy afternoon in New York.

Excellent little art museum. What an absolutely perfect intimate and thoughtful art display! The best part is the atmosphere, even though there are many very remarkable paintings. Visiting makes you feel immersed in beauty , style and serenity.

Go to the Frick!. Really enjoyed my tour of the Frick Collection. I was very pleasantly surprised at the wide range of well known artists and works. It is also not overwhelming in size and can be seen in full in 2-3 hours. Be sure not to miss the Renoir toward the end of the collection. There is something for every art lover at the Frick.

Best Art Gallery in NYC. There are so many good things to say about the Frick Collection: - The building is beautiful both internally and externally.  - It's a peaceful haven. Not busy, no school parties, in fact no kids at all (being a mom I can appreciate the novelty of this from time to time!) - The internal central court is one of my favourite places in the city. - This was Frick's home in his last years, and whilst it's too beautiful and grand to feel homely exactly, it's a million miles away from the usual sterile environments art is displayed in- It's a manageable size - you can appreciate everything in there without becoming snow-blind to the wonderful things hanging there- It's a real crowd pleaser of a collection. Frick collected based on his own personal taste - and there's heavy hitter after heavy hitter. Gainsborough, Reynolds, Renior, Whistler, Boucher, Turner, Rembrandt...Wonderful, wonderful.

always worth going. We had not been to the Frick for a few years but it is great. the movie on the house is well worth it[first time]. They give you audio and thereisso much on it you need many trips to catch it all.The special show was also good the Frick knows what they are doing

Perfect for Art Lovers. Everytime I visit NYC, the Frick Museum is one of my first stops. The collection of paintings is absolutely first class, and the furniture and other art pieces could keep you fascinated for hours! The self-guided tour is very well done, and unlike many museums, you can view the paintings and other pieces very closely (of course, security is high, but quite friendly, allowing you close views of each piece). As a senior, paying only $15, it is hard to beat the cost of this experience.
One of my favorite places in the city.. Bygone days. Gracious. Quiet. Only complaint is the long lines to check and pick up your coats. Definitely worth a visit.

a must see. Like all nyc museums, entrance fee is too high but this place is well worth it once through the doors! The history of the house and how the collection evolved over the years is so engrossing.

Wonderful Gem in NYC. This is one of the best museums in NYC! Housed in a beautiful Park Avenue home, this is the private collection of Mr. Frick who donated his art upon his death, so it could be appreciated by the public. The building itself gives guests a view into the lavish home of New York's wealthy, and the collection is beautiful. Because it's a smaller museum in a beautiful setting and not as frequented by tourists, you can enjoy the collection and not feel too overwhelmed as you can in a larger museum.

A beautiful small collection. The beautiful building by itself is worth the visit, but Mr Frick filled it with the things he liked, and he had both good taste and a lot of money. What you will find is a collection that's small enough to see in an hour or so, but of such high quality that it's like the best of a large gallery distilled down to the essentials. For example, the Frick has more Vermeers than the Louvre! A great bite-sized art gallery.

Great, old are for "traditional" tastes. The paintings, furniture and other pieces of art in this collection are undeliably beautiful. That said, I personally wouldn't rate this as a "don't miss" New York attraction. It really depends on your taste in art. If you like old masters, this is the place for you. If not, you will probably find this museum a bit under-stimulating. We had thought about taking a family trip here during Christmas week, and now I am glad we did not. My kids would have lost interest quickly, which would have dampened the whole experience for my wife and myself. The building housing the collection is, of course, beautiful, too. One small complaint: it would be nice if there were places to sit and relax in more of the rooms. On a rainy Saturday afternoon it was difficult to find a place to rest the bones after a long walk uptown. There is a fairly short, but interesting documentary movie about the Frick family and origin of the collection playing more or less continuously in one of the rooms. Lastly: $18 for admission to a fairly small museum is a bit pricey. But, hey, it's New York -- and you pay for quality here.

Pay what you wish on Sundays 11am to 1pm. Get in line early, it's well worth the time. A blend of architecture and historical displays and no small kids milling around as children under 10 are no admitted.
Beautiful art. Paintings by the old Masters in the rooms of a mansion where the owner hung them after he acquired them.

Nice Digs. A young millionaire, coke manufacturer/ steel magnate/robber baron, Frick collected/amassed sculpture porcelains, rugs,silver, furniture, prints, paintings, etc. All are housed in Frick's 1913 mansion at 70th & 5th. Do not hesitate to pay a visit. It will take a few hours to appreciate this collection, a splendid exhibition of a gilded age family's extraordinary story, wealth and aesthetic. Take the audio tour of the museum.Then complete your immersion by reading 'Meet You In Hell' the story of the 'friendship' between Andrew Carnegie and Frick, by Les Standiford. A great wekend diversion.
outstanding collection. this is a memory in itself. do not miss a quality collection.Great for the whole family as long as they are old enough to appreciate really nice things.
Interesting. Small place but with very good collection. Very nice atmosphere. Not sure if your little one will be interested in it. For sure not for small children.
NYC's Best Kept Secret. This Upper East Side treasure is a remarkable converted mansion housing an exquisite collection of European and American art. Quiet and uncrowded, don't miss it!

Astonishingly beautiful paintings. I don't know how he did it, but Henry Clay Frick put together one of the most exquisite collections of paintings in the world. It's not just that the paintings are excellent works of art in themselves. Just look at the condition of the individual artworks. "St Francis in the Desert", by Bellini, is five centuries old, but looks as if it were painted yesterday.I love the British aspects to this collection. On the one hand, Frick acquired the famous portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell by Hans Holbein (who wasn't Swiss, despite what the audio-guide tells you); then there is the dining-room, where all the pictures are by British artists, particularly two glorious full-length portraits by Gainsborough.Elsewhere, there are paintings by Frans Hals, Rembrandt, Turner, Constable, Veronese, Renoir, Goya, Guardi and Vermeer. I think that one of the Vermeers (I think they have three, altogether) is my favourite. There is some kind of conspiratorial theme. The gestures are perfect, with the mistress of the house facing away from the painter, while her maid is facing towards us. Did anyone portray the social hierarchy like that before Vermeer?

Don't Miss the Frick Collection. I loved the Frick Collection because it was small, intimate, and houses some great history. All the employees are very knowledgeable about the artwork. I would recommend a stop by here when in the city.
must see museum. gorgeous..beautiful art, lovely atmosphere...a must see when in NYC..so much to see..took my breath away....just loved it

Wonderful place!. This is just beautiful-anyone who likes art and architecture should visit! I especially love the children's room and the solarium. And don't miis the film that gives the overview of the house and collection!

A must!. Beautiful location, interesting exhibits. We did the Met one afternoon and here the 2nd day, much preferred this compact museum and it's location and personal stories of why each painting had been purchased.

Loved the Frick Collection. I loved this museum. The paintings are really beautiful, but what I love most about this museum is that it's not just about the art. It's a story of a man, a family, a building and his art collection. This was easily my fave museum in NYC. It's really intimate but not crowded. No cues for entry or compulsary cloakroom. Audio guide is $1 and a must!

Poor Reception. Wonderful paintings from the 17 to 19 th century, large area to walk and visit, you feel really in a private home.The museum has the poorest reception I've ever seen, the security staff is just polite if you seem to take a picture inside.So no picture inside the museum, you need to buy 60 $ the nice book with all the works of the museum.Also, for the price of the entry don't expect to visit the the second floor, it's closed for the public.

The absolute best. Don't miss this amazing collection. It is small and intimate but comprises many great works. If you choose to use the audio guide, you will find that almost every work has an audio explication. It is, without a doubt, my personal favorite gallery.

Spectacular. This is a place to visit more than once. The library is impressive. The collection of art, paintings, oriental rugs, porcelains are amazingIt needs more than one visit to absorb so much. The courtyard is so relaxing! Everything is fantastic. If you didn't see it yet ...go! You'll love it.

Self-perpetuating fame. Two Rembrandts, two Tizians, two Vermeers are perhaps worth a visit by themselves, but for me the main interest lied in seeing how the Frick family actually lived in this luxurious villa at the edge of Central Park, so in a way I found the Fragonard Room more convincing and immersive than the famed paintings. In many ways the Frick villa reminds me of the Isabella Stewart Gardner's "house" in Boston. On the other hand, way overpriced: for a $18 entrance fee, they could at least change the wall carpeting in the West Gallery which are scandalously dirty and worn out.

Impeccable!. This home and collection could definitely make a girl fantasize about having Mr. Frick as a sugar daddy ! The mansion has been created and built with no detail left to chance. This discernment can also be said of Mr. Frick's impeccable collection of art. Definitely worth the time to put this on top of your list!

Wonderful art experience. This is a hidden gem. Small art museum, very easy to walk around and enjoy and incredible art collection. I have visited MoMa and Metropolitan Art Museum and get overwhelmed with the size and scope. This museum is so relaxing and easy.

Classic, lovely collection in a spectacular setting. Enjoyed our most recent visit to the Frick tremendously. DO be sure to catch the short video that describes the life and times (and the art collection!) of Henry Clay Frick. Fascinating history. Also LOVED the book that I purchased in the museum gift shop, "Meet You in Hell," which describes the tumultuous relationship between Frick and Carnegie.

Top Notch Art in a Beautiful Mansion. The Frick Collection offers top notch art in a beautiful 19th century stone mansion on Fifth Avenue right near the Met. It has Vermeers, Rembrandts, Gainsboroughs, Romneys, whatever you like of the real classics. It's not overwhelmingly large like the Met, but concentrates quite a few wonderful paintings in a very compact space. What's not to like?

great for vermeer and rembrandt. some part of the collection are not so good, bt the 3 vermeer are a delight and so are a few memling and rembrandt...it's a great place to visit in newyorkif you are short time...
Fabulous Frick. A lovely museum in a lovely area of the city. Enjoyed the collection. Spent about 3 hours enjoying the museum.

The best small to medium museum in New York City. As I have said in other reviews, being a long-time resident of New York City, I love the smaller museums that are less famous and therefore less well-trod than the bigs like the Met. And the Frick is definitely in the top-5 if not the best of the smaller museums.Every piece in the collection is a gem, and the areas of specialty are just so interesting to me. For example, when my wife and I visited, we so enjoyed the many paintings of Thomas Gainsborough. His subject is often women of nobility, but there is a sensitivity to his way or portraying them. You can see the difference between a young woman who is still rather unsure of herself and the mature dutchess who looks out at us with attitude and just a touch of condescension. It is quite remarkable to see how the artist has captured his subjects so well.There is an exhibit of the Italian Renaissance painter Piero della Francesca at the Frick right now through mid-May, so we are certainly going to visit the Frick Collection again very soon!P.S. For people who like to hear concerts of classical music in a beautiful setting, the museum has a concert series - I haven't attended any concerts there yet, but am looking forward to doing that at some point.
Fabulous!. Run, do not walk, to the Frick. It is the best museum in NYC. Small. Fabulous (free) audio tour. Every time you turned a corner you saw treasures you only see in art history books.
Worth a stop.. Just read a review in the LA Times after just visiting it two days ago. Everything in the review was correct.

Gem of a Museum. This is an absolutely amazing museum. The collection here is not huge but is top rate. A museum like the Metropolitan can be almost overwhelming but this is small, concentrated and very manageable. For any lover of classical art this place is unmissable.

Interesting private collection. Located in a beautiful new york city building with a garden. It was a private collection- so includes a variety of artists. Entry is perhaps a bit expensive. They have a pay what you wish some days.

Superb collection. Although the size of the collection is nothing compared to the Metropolitan Museum, the quality of the art in the Frick collection combined with the fact that one can actually see it all in one visit - though it deserves a second and third visit - makes this museum without any doubt the better one.

Great Sunday opportunity. We joined in the Sunday "free admission" line and waited 30 minutes in the cold and windy February air. After surviving the cold and talking ourselves out of walking away for fear of frostbite we endured the wait for a very enjoyable one hour visit to the Frick. The building is fantastic and jammed full of marvelous art work treasures. We enjoyed, the art, architecture and the film shown about the interesting life of Mr. Frick.Definitely work a small donation during the 11 to 1 free admission period and if you are serious about art I would spring for the regular weekday admission and enjoy the art in less crowded environs.

Intimate, unique home/Museum. One of the worlds great museums located in a 5th Avenue 19th Century mansion. We have visited frequently over the last 50 years and never been disappointed. Major exhibitions are curated along with an outstanding in house collection. The home itself is worth the walk through.
Small. This is an architecturally interesting building in the heart of Manhattan, but the art inside is de minimus.

My favourite museum in New York. I have been to The Frick Museum many times and it never disappoints. The art is breathtaking....the Thomas Moore portrait is my favourite, and the building is stunning. This is a perfect museum to visit if you are by yourself in New York and have a few hours to kill between meetings!

Pound for pound my favorite small museum. I have been to small museums in Paris and Rome, but this is my favorite. For travelers without much time, this can be enjoyed in 30-60 minutes. In a real rush, even 15 minutes is conceivable. There is one room that contains about 20 paintings that represent the best artists of 3 centuries. I should also mention that everytime I have visited (about 4 times), it was not crowded--you are able to view the masterpieces in a calm environment.
Nice museum and worth a visit. Not a huge museum. We enjoyed the displays and took our time walking around. We would go back again and think most people would enjoy a visit.

The Frick needs a new staff. Let me start by saying that I have been visiting the Frick Collection for most of my life. I was 10 years old when I first visited and now I'm in my 60's. The museum building and its collection are first rate. No problem there. The problem (and this is recent) is the staff. My negative experience started at the coat check where the kids behind the counter were inattentive and seemed to dislike having their conversation interupted by someone checking a coat. So too, the Guards throughout were very unhelpful and rude. They engaged in small talk among themselves which did not enhance the visitor experience. One Guard (a man) was downright rude when I asked him a question (and I am assuming/concluding that answering visitors' questions is a part of his job). The Frick offers an introductory film in its Music Room. Outside the Music Room I asked this Guard: "When does the film start?". His curt response to me was "Read the sign". So, as directed, I looked for a sign and found it posted on the screen in the Music Room. The film is shown on a regular schedule. Could he not have told me the schedule rather than send me on a seach for a sign? Or if he felt I needed to see a sign, directed me to it in a polite manner? In short, the Frick needs to do some serious re-thinking about who it hires for its staff. Those I encountered reflect very poorly on this venerable institution.
Very interesting collection. We went there to see a special exhibit, but it's a very interesting collection. The house is magnificent.

Superb. It would be difficult to better this. Small enough to be comfortably digested in one visit while the consistent excellence of the art on display offers enough to want to go back again and again. Absolutely one of the glories of New York.

What's the Frick?. This little-known-to-strangers estate is not only noted for the architecture but has many notable and rare items in its well-kept halls. Atmosphere is stately and a certain gravitas pervades throughout. Well worth the trip for those who want a different gallery experience.
A great museum in NY. A NY mansion converted into a museum with a splendid collection. Do try and include it when visiting New York.

An incredible private art collection!. We were thoroughly impressed not only with the pure volume of artwork in the Frick Collection, but in the masters represented...from Rembrandt to Degas to Van Dyke to El Greco to Titian....the list goes on and on. The mansion itself is a work of art, as are the furnishings within it. Well worth a visit!

stunning. A beautiful museum. There is history- this is a magnificent "gilded age" mansion built for this collection to be shared. There is the collection itself, which is stunning. The only possible negative was the entry fee which was expensive, but this is a somewhat unique museum in a city blessed with so many amazing choices.
What a collection!. this super nice house contains so many masterpiece that you do not know where to look anymore, a nice place to stop in the upper east before a stroll in the park.

Very interesting. I loved the Frick, very nice to stroll around this magnificent house with amazing pieces of art. Music room showed a short film explaining the history which was interesting and the personal ear piece explained the history of the various works of art. Would recommend, beautiful architecture in the building and lovely stroll up 5th Avenue from Midtown and you can then go across the road to Central Park.

Amazing. I keep on forgetting what a gem the Frick is. Like the Isabella Stuart Gardner in Boston, a small museum with some amazing pieces: several Vermeers, and Rembrandts. It's not a comprehensive overview of world art, but a focused, perfect small museum with a definite personality.

A must see. Our son recommended that we visit the Frick Collection while visiting NYC. We went on a Sunday, when seniors are admitted "for whatever you want to pay". It's a fabulous art collection, covering a broad spectrum of countries, time periods, and artists (but very limited collection of American artists). The audio tour greatly enhances the experience. The atrium is peaceful and, unlike the Gardner in Boston, you can actually walk through it.

Beauty in a beautiful setting. The Frick is housed in a magnificent mansion on 5th Avenue. Not on every tourist´s agenda but well worth the effort to visit one of the finest and most eccentric collections in New York. The works are eclectic and beautifully shown in the grand manner. The furnishings and tapestries alone are worth the vist and the pictures look as though they were made for the building.

Amazing collection of Art. We visited the Frick Collection on a Sunday. Normally it costs $15 per adult, but if you go there at 11am on a Sunday you can get in for $1. Some of NYC's finest artwork is here so you can spend a good couple hours taking it all in. Well worth a visit.

The best small museum in N.Y.. That most oft he paintings actually belonged to Frick, and that he bought them because he liked them makes this place singular. There is one Renoir--Frick did like the Impressionists. There are no paintings depicting the horrors of war. There are no paintings that are at all erotic. He bought what he liked and bought them to look at them. A number were stealthily bought from the Soviets wen whey needed hard currency. The museum was once his residence and occupies the entire block on 5th Ave between E.70 and 71. Frick was said to often have trouble sleeping and would (could!) just get out of bed and spend a couple of hours looking at one of his amazing paintings--no need for a screen of any kind when the paintings on your walls were all things that you found thrilling.
Very interesting. The Frick collection is an art collection in a magnificent building. I recommend a visit to this museum and point out the beautiful winter garden (a must see during the visit).

Delightful small museum with an amazing collection. We loved the Frick Museum. Located in a former mansion on 5th Avenue, it's an impressive collection, beautifully displayed, and just the right size to see everything comfortably in an afternoon. I highly recommend it.

Unique place. Went on Sunday during free hours. Cool to walk along the park and go in here. The collection is good, and the house is fantastic. Too bad you can't take pictures at all so don't bother bringing a camera to carry. The audio tour is free and recommended. Spent a couple hours here before heading to the met. Great stop

Great collection, easy to digest. These galleries are in a beautiful setting and easy to take in. Not overwhelming, there are some works by the masters here like Titian and Rembrandt. Would highly recommend a visit. Pity no photography allowed, mainly to take some some snaps of the buiding and the interior courtyard- stunning.

Don't miss this gem!. What an amazing museum. The Frick Collection is incredible and housed in probably the only remaining mansion of its kind in Manhattan. The building, the furniture, the art are all world class. Do not miss this.

The Frick Gallery is a treasure.. When I was a kid, I'd 'run away from home' for the day, and sit in the sculpture garden and write in my journal. I knew, and know, the Frick like the back of my hand. One lingers in the library, admiring the leather bound books, the woodwork, the light from the windows. The Impressionist Renoirs offer a calming sensation. Then one can revel at the Turners in the main gallery. Don't forget to include time for the short film about Frick and the other barons of the time. You will never be disappointed by a visit or a pilgrimage to the Frick.

Time for One Gallery Museum, This Is It!. Spend lots of time in Museums and Galleries in many countries and this one is my new favorite. Housed in a gorgeous home constructed by Henry Clay Frick in the early 1900's and the house alone is worth the price of admission.Audio guide is included in ticket price, a very nice touch.The collection is magnificent and amazing. Monet, Titian, and just about every classical artist you've ever heard of are included. Sculptures, bronzes, paintings, clocks, an assortment of gorgeous treasures.We enjoyed every moment of this visit, and suggest you need at least two to three hours to get a taste of what there is to see. Whether you are going to visit every gallery in New York, or you only have time for one, I urge you to make sure you visit Frick House and The Frick Collection. It is wonderful.

Better than the MET :). It's an amazing collection of art from all over the world. It's very small but very special and rare. The entrance fee is relatively cheap and the staff is friendly. We have also been to the MET couple of times but in my opinion the Frick is better. Just an opinion

The collection stars alongside the building. The building which houses this collection is an added bonus. The collection is wonderful but the building that houses it is just remarkable. Make sure you catch the 10 minute film that explains the how the collection was housed in such a beautiful and unique building.

Best museum in NY. A gem. A beautiful mansion on the UES on Fifth Avenue and 71st street. The art collection is beyond outstanding. European art, furniture, painting and sculpture displayed throughout the rooms of Frick's home. This is a manageable museum that can be seen in one to two hours. Free on Sunday mornings. Classes are offered too.
Usually not crowded.

Achievable and beautiful. This is how I would describe the Frick Collection. I have been to visit New York 3 times and every time one of my first stops is this wonder collection. I tend to get information overload in large galleries and museums but the Frick allows you to meander around from one beautiful space to the next, to view what I see as one of the most achievable and enjoyable 'small' collections I have visited. You can spend as little as 1 hour or really take your time and finish by sitting in the glorious garden and reflecting on what you have just experienced.

Beautiful Building. Not only did I enjoy the Renoir collection on display at the time of my visit, but I enjoyed the building itself! It is located in a residential area off Central Park and actually has the look of a fine mansion inside and out. There are multiple places to sit and enjoy your surroundings and it has a warmth that makes you want to stay. This museum is worth visiting no matter what the display collection happens to be.

What a wonderful place to visit. WOW!!! I knew that the Frick Collection would be a great visit but I had no idea it was going to knock my socks off.The ticket sales and coat check area ran smoothly although it was not very clear (to us anyway) where to obtain the free speaking audio tour gadget and we sadly went without - I think this needs to be made clearer.The artwork and artifacts were amazing and the Picasso was wonderful to see - lots of great paintings by old masters and we enjoyed seeing paintings by Sir Joshua Reynolds was a real thrill.The inside atrium with its lush green plants and running water was just the spot to take in the surrounds of this amazing house.The gift shop is filled with books about the Collection and other things to take home with you.
Elegant collection. A beautiful setting, the Frick Collection offers a quiet & elegant view of fine art. Far from the maddening crowds, you will enjoy this very much.

A very manageable and gorgeous museum. What a treat for my wife and I. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Frick Collection because it was small enough to really enjoy and not overwhem us like some of the other museums do when we have limited time in visiting them.
One of New York's best kept secrets. so many different famous painter and master represented. Excellent viewin, one of the best collections around.
What a lovely space. Wonderful exhibits of art in such a beautiful building. I enjoyed looking at the art and being in the building. A nice warm spot on a cold New York morning.

Crowded but great art exhibit. It was unfortunately exceptionally crowded when we visited which made it a challenge but this is an excellent art exhibit and we enjoyed it. It was not the best mansion/museum I've visited but still worth it. It takes only an hour or so to go through unless you really want to linger - not possible in the crowds we were in.
Special Intimate Museum!. This is a great collection of art in a lovely setting. Spent a morning here but not long enough! Will return when next in New York and allow more time!

A gem to be cherished. This is a gem. Each painting is so special. The special exhibits are a plus but the permanent collection has some of the finest paintings in the world, displayed in this grand mansion from a different era. Since it is small, it can be enjoyed slowly and unhuriedly. Really a must.

Best museum in NYC. Great art, beautiful setting. Definitely take the audiotour which is very thoughtful. Sunday has a "pay what you can" entry fee. The Holbein paintings of Cromwell & Thomas More are showstoppers; Vermeer, Rembrandt, Turner...the list goes on. Don't forget the smaller rooms at the end which the series on paintings. Usually less crowded than MoMA & Met, a good place to relax and comtemplate things.

My favorite museum. The Frick is amazing because it gives you a chance to see how the ultra wealthy of the robber baron age lived. The house is, for the most part, kept the way HCF had it when he lived there. The art is beautiful, but the house is really the best part.
Really interesting art collection. Didn't expect this collection at this destination, so interesting And a beautiful building.Really beautiful interior/gardens

A must see New York experience. I have visited the Frick twice in the last few years and I recently took my husband and teenage son. They loved it as much as I. The impressive art collection is housed in the most beautiful building and entering is like walking into a sanctuary. A fantastic experience. The website provides a lot of information about the collection and each of the incredible rooms.

Best Gallery. If you can only go to one gallery in NY go to FRick. Its the best by far. to see the art in a home environment adds to the experience as opposed to the sterility of a gallery. Well worth the visit. Walk and enjoy the views over Central Park .

wonderful art collection. A unique and fabulous art collection in a great setting.The scale of the place is intimate, the crowds not oppressive and the art is divine. A great place to go with friends and family

Go for the architecture not just the art. The art collection at the Frick is definitely beautiful but the architecture of the home is what really impressed me. A gorgeous home and nice way to spend a few hours. Definitely don't miss it!

Favourite. This is my favourite museum in the world. It is not overwhelming. The excellent collection is displayed in a beautiful. peaceful setting. It is not usually crowded and there is a lovely garden atrium where visitors can sit and relax.

Delightful escape!. One of my favorite museums. So many hidden treasures around every wall. Small but excellent pieces and the house is interesting in and of itself. Very enjoyable for a short visit or a longer one.
Don't miss this mansion. The collection is amazing, worths the visit for itself. The building offers the unique opportunity of a glance at the way of living of true millionaires, one century ago.

I love the Frick and you will too.. The Frick Museum was once a private home and now houses a lovely collection of artwork and rugs and furnishings and it is a real treasure to see. It is not overwhelmingly large so you wont feel like you missed anything when you leave. There is a special feeling when you enter of serenity and peace. Check online before you go to see if there are any special exhibitions, concerts or lectures. The Frick is not like a regular museum because of the layout. It is a home which actually makes it less institutional and makes you feel happy to be there. If you have time while you are visiting New York, spend a morning there. You will not be disappointed.

Get a Glimpse of the Gilded Age. Rather than being overwhelmed by the major museums of New York, why not drink in the atmosphere, art and architecture of a private home - one that gives you a taste of what life was like for a selected few uberrich at the turn of the century. The art work is breathtaking and all the more sublime for being displayed in a palatial home with all the opulence and grandeur that went with ostentatious wealth - who isn't interested in the lives of the rich and famous? - especially when they had taste and discrimination. The Frick is chance to judge and reflect on the life and lifestyle of the owner while appreciating what money can buy. The Rembrandt self portrait alone is worth the price of admission.

A Must See. This building in and of itself is beautiful, the Art Collection is one that rivals any.. Exquisite is the proper term I believe.. You can spend the entire day and still not have your fill of beauty..

Love the intimate feel. I really like the homely intimate feel of the Frick Collection...it reminds me of the Cortauld Gallery in London, in Manchester Square. The sense of being in a private home (albeit a stately one) makes it an interesting experience.
Great gem. Lovely antique furniture and fabulous artwork housed in a mansion. Worth the time to visit. Make sure that you take the audio guide tour.

Great backstory to this Museum. The "Frick Collection" is located in what was once the residence of industrialist Henry Clay Frick. It contains an exceptional collection of Old Masters, French furniture and Limoges. The experience was more intimate than larger galleries and provided an insight into the life of a self-made man and philanthropist.

Awesome!. I loved the Frick Collection! This was recommended to me by a friend and I am so happy I stopped to see the mansion and all of the art. There was a Van Gogh painting, Portrait of a Peasant, on loan from another museum and that was very exciting to see! It is neat to see portraits of various Frick family members and learn about the history of the house. This museum is not crowded like other larger ones in NYC. If you have time, it is worth it to visit!

One of the best intimate museums in the city. The Frick is one of those places that takes you back in time and shows you the wealthy side of old New York and helps you to imagine what it was like to be among Frick, Vanderbilt, and JP Morgan. The building itself is a work of art never mind the collection inside. the library and the organ are two things that stand out in my mind beside the paintings themselves.
Love it!. Best Historic house in NYC. Must see the artwork, amazing to see in a home. Great location. Beautiful rooms and garden.
Beautiful small museum. An amazing private art collection in a beautiful once private home. Should not be missed. If you can't get to Europe, this is the next best place to see old world masters.

Gem. This is a private home and collection of widely varied art. Our Phila Art Museum Pass allows us admittance, so I don;t know anything about value for money, but it is a wonderful experience to walk this home and no kids, ever, so it is devoid of that screaming meemie buzz at larger art experiences.

A Gem of a Museum. The Frick Collection is world renown. The collection includes numerous artworks that are absolutely exquisite. The atmosphere is conducive to appreciating great art as it is within a luxurious, historic mansion bequeathed by the Frick family.
Anyone who has a taste for fine art should visit this unique museum.

One of the City's best kept secrets. Love museums, love architecture, love serenity, then this is the place to go. Once a private home, this small but amazing museum has an intensive collection of art. A beautiful atrium highlights the museum. During the year, you can hear Chamber Music musicians play while you stroll through the Frick's halls.

Free on a Sunday and well worth the visit. There was a line but it moved quickly and wasn't too crowded inside.
It was amazing to see inside such a beautiful house and the artwork was very good too. The courtyard was beautiful.

A gallery like no other in New York. We visited the Frick Collection on a winter Sunday afternoon for a string quartet concert in the music room and viewed their elegant galleries filled with old masters hung in domestic settings with no barriers. Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, Gainsboroughs, Van Dycks, a Vermeer, Goyas: it's amazing to see them so close and intimately. All this and 2 hours of beautiful music in a hallowed environment for $35.00. The most insane cultural value of our trip to NYC.
One of the best museums in the entire world. The building is remarkable: an American palace. The collection is truly outstanding. If you want to see Vermeers, don't go to Holland, go to New York.

Beautiful collection!!. Looking for a famous painter? name it they good it! From Da Vincci to Van Gogh!! they have it on their walls!! amazing for a private collection was worth the time!! you should be ready to spend the entire day here!!

One painting and many drawings. They currently have a famous Van Gogh paintingarid subjectson display. Very nice--you can get close and it is well lighted. Downstairs they have a drawing exhibit. Not what I expected. It is varied in media, some colored, some b&w, varied subjects. I am not a fan of this art, but my wife raved about it.

Top New York Museum!. A must to visit if you love museums, it makes a great change from all the huge museums that you don't have time to see everything in! And the collection is still fantastically awe inspiring. We went on a Sunday when you can pay as much as you wish instead of the flat rate....many people only pay a dollar which is fantastic value!
Beautiful!. I loved it. It was a very beautiful and luxurious collection of art. Very interesting pieces. Great museum for a girl's day out.

Our #1 highlight in New York. We loved the Frick collection. Fabulous small museum custom built to show the contents. Eclectic collection of art and design including furniture and ceramics, mostly European paintings, mostly 18th and 19th century, includes some very special items e.g. Hans Holbein, the Younger 1527 painting of Sir Thomas More - if you look up Thomas More on Wikipedia, this is the painting you see. The painting of the velvet is incredible - and you can get up really close to everything displayed. You could go round in an hour but we strongly recommend getting the audio guide and spending half a day there.

Best museum in NYC. If you love museums or really don't care for them, you will enjoy the Frick. It is small enough to not be overwhelmed like several others in NYC, yet has world class museum pieces to view. We have been to the Frick more than five times. Each time is a joy.
A bit disappointed. Mother in law wanted to go here.. With all the great places to see art in NYC I just wouldn't go out of my way. I would rather go to the Met
Fascinating collection. Went to Frick on recommendation and was not disappointed ....amazing building and exciting collection. Def worth a visit for any art lover.

Not to be missed. Beautiful! Saw the Master Drawings from the Coutauld Institute in London. Also the other galleries. Many years since I was here, and was amazed at the wealth of important art hanging here. Wonderful building, too. Nice items in the shop.
Unexpected and Surprisingly Rich. You will enter the house of Mr. Frick, with its patio and Pictures Gallery, and will fill yourself immersed in art.
A walk back to the guilded age. We loved the opulence of the mansion, the old masters, and don't miss the introductory film in the music room.

If you have time for only one art museum, make it this one. Fabulous art collection with a diverse sampling of european masters, displayed in a unique setting. Frick's personal passion for collecting art and his construction of a house optimized for the display of his treasures has left us all with a special art viewing experience. It is apparent from the first step into the garden court with plants and a large pool that this is not your ordinary or grandiose art gallery. This is a stroll through a fabulous art lover's mansion, with an opportunity to appreciate it as the collector intended. As you walk through the music room to the library and then through the converted drawing room (the Fragonard room, redone to display large panels that Frick acquired from the Morgan collection) and into the serene dining room, you can imagine this collector thinking about what his next acquisition should be and it's ideal niche in this "art gallery home". The context makes this a personal and very engaging art display.Admission rates are very reasonable for this unique experience (NYU students and active duty military get free admission - what's not to love!). Children are not admitted. Special exhibits are located on the lower level and in the "gallery" area - Van Gogh's colorful "portrait of a peasant" was on display. The upper floors are not open to the public but there is an astoundingly opulent staircase and pipe organ that visitors can admire and imagine what it was like to live amid this collection.
A secret. This wonderful and special museum is a secret gem. Enjoy the peacefulness and the beautiful art. I especially enjoyed the Reniorexhibit

Thomas Cromwell is here!. I went here on a cold morning after a walk in central park. The house is beautiful and on the Tuesday I went incredibly quiet which just doesn't happen in London anymore when looking at wonderful and famous pictures. I was stunned to see Thomas Cromwell over the fire place opposite Thomas Moore. The 18 dollars entrance was worth it just for that! Am a big Hilary Mantel fan and post card is now a book Mark for Bringing Up the Bodies.

One of the most beautiful museums in the country!. A jewel of a museum in the heart of the upper Eastside, the Frick is something special to me. Inside a most magnificent house/mansion is a truly breathtaking collection of art, perfectly hung inside this exquisite facility, which is never crowded. The works of art there are always something great, and you will never tire of being inside this facility. It is unlike any other museum you will ever go into, as it is small in it's actual sqaure footage, but what it lacks in size it makes up for in the depth and range of it's artistic works on display. I would say this is a MUST for anyone interested in art who visits NY and goes to see our museums.

one of the best - not cheap. The Frick has an interesting intimate collection. It is not a cheap ticket (is is $15 now? more?) but .... quality quality quality.IF you like this sort of thing you could spend hours.

A unique experience!. The ability to go into the home of Mr. Henry Clay Frick, to see his home preserved in much the way it was when he lived there--the astonishing collection of art from the masters to the well-known to the beautiful statues, all brought together with the finest furniture, unique objects, and furnishings...was a fantastic experience. The "collection", rather than a museum, lets one appreciate art in a unique way, by strolling through this lovely "home", you are transported to a different age and time...it is like observing an opera as it is being performed next to you rather than as part of an audience.Art galleries and museums attempt to create an atmosphere to frame the art of artists but they cannot achieve the effect the Frick collection can give to the displayed works.The atrium in the heart of the home welcomes you to a serene oasis in the middle of the city. The luxurious home allows you to feel at home, not as a guest but because you care for art, it seems to care that you are there and welcomes you as well....My sons and I thoroughly enjoyed the visit--we spent WAY too much time there, studying everything, enjoying the experience and atmosphere. Highly recommend a visit...

Great for fine art. If you like art, you will love this. This personal collection is very beautiful and filled with art that is not edgy or difficult to comprehend. It was collected to bring pleasure to the owner. That is why I loved it. Two Vermeers and countless art treasures. Not too big that you become overwhelmed. Just right.

Peaceful oasis. The Frick is an old favorite from my days living in Manhattan and I am pleased that it has only gotten better. The collection is outstanding although a bit eclectic and the building itself is worth a visit to get a feel for how the ruthless tycoons lived in the Golden Age. To visit is to step back in time and also it is a quiet respite from the hustle of the city. The collection itself is a compendium of many of the "old Masters" and is enjoyable from just that single perspective. The Frick also hosts visiting exhibits and has in house tours at different times throughout the day.

Fabulous art in comfortable setting. Amazing collections of "one of everything" that is great in Western art. The special attraction this visit was a wonderful Van Gogh painting on loan. Wonderful opportunity to study this portrait in detail.

Unique Collections! Gorgeous Mansion & Garden! Total Gilded Age Experience!. Great way to tip into the Gilded Age of New York by visiting the Frick. Utmost lavish mansion, unique and profoudn collection! Gorgeous Garden! Absolutely loved it!

A really lovely museum with some absolute jewels!. The Frick Museum is one of little jewels. The permanent collection is very impressive including the Holbein's of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell. Some wonderful Turners and the peasant farmer by Van Gogh. The fact it is so small means there's no cordoning off and you can get right up to the paintings to appreciate brush strokes as well as view from distance. It makes for an intimate art experience! There was a show of drawings including Leonardo, Picaso, Monet, Matisse and many others which was also fascinating. Many of them are preparatory works and drawings for other paintings. The setting is luxurious and you get an insight into the ego and character of Henry Frick who put together this most extensive and impressive collection in a building in a great location with amazing decor and architecture.

A jewel. This is a beautiful rather small collection of great master-peaces by some of the world's best artists. This private collection reminds me of Isabella Gardner's Museum in Boston. However, they cannot be compared with the abundance of paintings and other artwork in the biggest private collection I've seen-the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia. Frick displays works by some of my favorite artists-El Grecco, Fragonard, Vermeer and a couple of Titians and Rembrandts. I recommend visiting on Sundays when you can pay as you wish from 11am-1pm. I visited in September and the wait was about 20min to get in before 11am. The visit was highly pleasant and I plan to come again in April.

Great history. This is a very awesome museum to visit! There is more of a comfort in this museum compared to the big ones in the City. The audio tour is very informative and if you're already impressed with the collection, this will give you a keen description of each of the pieces. There are student discounts, also.

Hidden treasure of NYC. The Frick Collection is simply one of the best museums I've seen in my entire life. It is located in a genuine Fifth Avenue mansion built especially to house works of art. The permanent collection is breathtaking. This is not only about master paintings and Ming vases, the design of the rooms is a masterpiece in its own right. This museum is not for the faint of heart as there are not many places to sit down and take a break. You also have to borrow an audioguide if you want a description of the works as there are no panels, only small numbers allowing you to guide yourself through the works. The audioguide also provides a description of the design patterns of each room, which was probably my favourite part of the tour. The Fragonard room has got to be seen to be believed. The great thing about the Frick Collection is that you can forget about the audioguide if you want and just walk around all the rooms in 30 minutes. Or you can listen to it all and spend 5 hours, or anything in between (we actually visited The Cloisters in the same day and it didn't feel overwhelming). Not too crowded, not to pricey, just perfectly balanced!

A must for art lovers. Masterwork after masterwork in a setting that was once the Frick's home.Traveler's tip - on Sunday from 11A-1P it is 'pay what you want' to get in, just like the Metropolitan.One drawback. This is not a neighborhood of restaurants. You have to plan your meals accordingly.

best way to view art. I went to this museum on a Saturday during the holidays when NYC tourism is at its height; however this museum was not too crowded to enjoy the displays. The museum is quiet, located in a gorgeous house, and the artwork displayed varies from classicism to post impressionism; all the greats are here - just not their most famous works. At the time I visited, Van Gogh's "Portrait of a Peasant" was on display, and I was able to get up close and personal with this masterpiece!Also, the ladies' room is lovely and clean - something worth mentioning in Manhattan ;)Deducted one point because some of the employees were rude.

Nice and intimate museum. It has an impressive collection and the mansion itself is extremely beautiful! Its not too crowded which allows you to really take your time to appreciate and study each piece. One of the must-see museums when in Manhattan.

A mind changing experiance. This museum ( the Frick house ) has some of the great art in the world. It is in a small and accessible space that gives time to look at painting carefully. The portrait of Thomas More by Holbein is here. As you look at the works placed in some one home you get a sense of the art not merely the initellectual but the living. It also shows why most mordern is bad.
Awesome museum.. Small but very impressive. Spent about 1.5 hours. Art collection is beautiful as is the furniture and the mansion. Only wished that we could have taken a tour.

My favorite art museum. The quality of this collection is staggering and the setting is perfect. I've visited twice on the weekends and neither time was there a crowd. It is so nice to enjoy the old masters without jockeying for position and bumping in to others. I thought that the audio tour was ok, not great. There is no cafeteria, so eat before you arrive.

Glad we visited. The grand house in which the collection is exhibited, is lovely to see in its own right. It is really beautiful. We went early in the day and it was nice a peaceful. Great experience.

very impressive!. beautiful mansion with the largest private collection amassed by single collector. If you are interested in architecture the mansion is well worth a visit, let alone the collection of art and ceramics.

The Smallest Most Brilliant Art Collection.. This collection includes La Tour, Carraveggio, Manet, Monet and so much more. The museum is diverse in art, yet small enough for an intimate study of the works.
Top stop on our trip.. The museum is as interesting as the art. Exhibits are eclectic but well planned. There were a number of people there but it did not feel crowded. Will go back.

Hidden Gem. We took the bus uptown on a rainy Sunday morning in mid-December (pay what you wish morning). We loved the mansion, the architecture was amazing. The art collection was very enjoyable, great way to spend a rainy Sunday.

Best Museum in NYC. If you enjoy art and a smaller crowd of people, visit the Frick. This is the best eclectic collection in a gorgeous house on museum row you will find. I love to visit here and do so with every visit to NYC!

Never get tired of seeing the Frick. We took two friends who had never been to NYC. The Frick is one of our favorites and it always engages. We enjoyed a mini-tour with an excellent guide who introduced us not only to some of the rooms but the decisions by Mr. Frick of what paintings to acquire and how to hang them. Next time we'll plan around a full tour which seems to be held 2x per day. On a previous visit we were able to enjoy a violin and piano concert at the Frick so check in advance whether a music event, which is infrequent, would be available during your visit.

A gem loaded with European art. Second trip there and still need to go again, there is so much to see. The house is amazing then you add all of the amazing art. The board must be very smart because the place is well organized and run efficiently.

Awesome. It's no surprise what one can do with a few billion dollars and a little good taste. The Frick Collection is often on the "next time" list, but it should be seen. Room after room of incredible artwork and a building (originally, a Vanderbilt Mansion) that delights in every turn and nook. Self-guided tours are adequate unless you want to learn more about the paintings, sculptures and chinaware. Allow at least an hour, but you're close to the Metropolitan Museum of Art so you can make a day of it.

Impressed by this museum!. Our research of 'things to do' in NYC suggested this was a place worth visiting. We agree! The Frick Mansion is impressive; the collection of art items is varied and very interesting.

The BEST museum for European art in NYC. The Frick is for those who who love European art (Renaissance, etc - not contemporary). It's not a huge museum, but absolutely beautiful. Many New Yorkers consider this to be our 'gem' museum.

Mesmerising. One of my favourite collections. Went twice in three days. A very generous collection from a generous collector. A glimpse of how, not my, half lived. A stunning house showing wonderful master pieces. Powerful El Greco's. The guided tour though brief very informative.
New York highlight. Most outstanding gallery I have ever visited. A must for everyone visiting New York. only wish I had time to visit a second time during my stay.

Incredible history, experience education. Great to see how the Frick family accumulated and lived in this incredible castle like building.
Only downside was the whole house was not open on the day but the paintings the audio and the experience is something we would rate highly.
Would go again and again -
Nice museum. This was a very nice surprise. It was small yet filled with a wide variety of paintings and sculptures. Worth a look

Nice small museum. A nice collection that can be seen in a couple of hours. It is not well prepared for crowds and the exhibit downstairs was very crowded, making it hard to enjoy it. However, once the crowds disperse, the rooms are fairly empty and you can spend a while enjoying the works you prefer. I really like the way the collection was curated. Where most museums organize by style or era or location, the Frick is designed thematically and each room has a certain style. I liked that, because I tend towards certain types of art rather than necessarily work from Impressionists or work from the 1920s or Italian artists. I also really like that the sculptures were placed in the rooms on tables so the rooms felt "lived in" and not as much like an art museum.

Surprisingly Pleasant. I'm not much of a museum or art fan, but was very surprised to find the Frick Collection quite breathtaking. Not only the pieces of art, but the mansion itself is beautiful. Definitely worth going to.

Wonderful whole art experience. Do you like paintings? Furniture? Sculpture? Interiors? Then go to the Frick. A wonderful museum in Henry Clay Frick's Upper East Side Mansion. You can spend a couple of hours happily soaking up the atmosphere. Oh, and visit the restrooms. Very nice!

Well worth a visit. Great experience. This is a wonderful and eclectic collection spanning centuries of European art and including some notable works (ie the ones in the Art books!) such as the Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell. Beautifully presented in the sumptuous surroundings of the Frick mansion. A standout 'gallery' experience. By contrast I found the Met to be very crowded, with an overwhelming volume of exhibits and navigation confusing due to renovations in progress.

Amazing. What an amazing experience!A beautiful house full of old masters turned into a museum. Doesn't sound too exciting, but the art collection is tremendous; Turner, Constable, Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Titian, El Greco...and on & on.The house, particularly the garden courtyard, is serene and beautiful.Well worth a visit, not expensive either!

Lovely scalable collection in a beautiful mansion. I have been meaning to re-visit the Frick for years and finally got around to it on a recent visit to New York. The private collection includes some of the seminal works of art from just about every major European painter up until the early 20th century. The mansion itself is worth the price of admission and provides a lovely setting for the paintings. Henry Clay Frick seemed to have a special fondness for portraits and the collection includes several gems such as Hans Holbein's portrait of Sir Thomas Moore and Rembrant self portraits. I also like to size of the collection which can be easily enjoyed in an hour and a half. The Frick is a must see if you like fine paintings and you don't have to spend an entire day at a musuem. It's like the perfect nibble of something truly scrumptious. I won't wait as long to visit again.

Beautiful!. A small museum in New York which not many people visit...a must in my opinion! Beautiful settings of all the paintings..the "house" where the paintings are displayed is a museum in itself!
Interesting. Worth a visit - only if you are interested in that kind of art and objectis. I would have liked more time there. Interesting personal collection.
Beautiful art in lovely setting.. The paintings, sculptures, and setting were all beautiful and complemented one another well to create a relaxing, unhurried, contemplative experience.

Wherefore art thou Curator?. No real cohesion or logic to the displays and most information seemingly dependant upon a hand held talkie guide. Is there a curator there?
Please try to ensure that visitors are severely punished for using mobile telephones, perhaps by jettisoning their telephones in the fountain around which they apparently like to congregate to chatter.

this is a must.. What I really liked about it was that it was in house, and set up like you are walking in someone's house..not a gallery. And it is small enough so you don't get a brain strain. Lots of different art. Take the tour. This will be on my visit every time list.
Stunning. The gallery itself is as beautiful as the art. You have to check out this gallery. I doubt somebody of Fricks stature today would just give this to the public.

Small museum with a wonderful presentation. The building itself is a work of art, with wonderful carved woodwork, and the finest materials, the likes of which are rarely used today. The collection is very impressive. I especially like the French impressionists and the famous Gilbert Stuart portrait of George Washington.
beautiful building. a wonderful venue in which to view a very special art collection. worth the trip. go see. i wrote more than 50 characters. please take this review.

Near the Metropolitan Museum of Arts. We passed this many times while in the area and finally went in. It cannot compare to the Met, but if you are into museums, or have time to spare, it's worth a stop. Was a private home and private art collection - so that is interesting as well.

Okay. The art collection at the Frick doesn't hold together all that well, and the museum is very very expensive for the size and artwork. I went on pay want you wish Sunday and even at 10 dollars was disappointed.
Old New York. Interesting history of building. Once the private house of a millionnaire in pold New York. Beautiful collection of paintings by famous artists. Concerts held here/

Exquisite small collection. I have always loved the Frick collection for its intimacy and the beauty of the art work. It is a manageable space and you can spend time with the art without feeling overwhelmed at the end. I also found a print in their gift shop which I had been searching for over the years and could never lay my hands on. All in all, the Frick is at the top of my list for museum hopping in New York.

Well worth the stop. The Frick Collection is well worth visiting. This beautiful mansion has an incredible display of art and the building itself alone is amazing. We got there when it opened, and when we left there was a fairly long line to get in, so I'd recommend getting their early. It was a great way to spend an hour or so before heading into the City for the day. Would recommend seeing the video in the music hall, as it tells the great story of Mr. Frick and how the collection came to be.

Beauty in the Classics. After a disappointing visit to the Whitney, the Frick renewed my love of art and culture. I lucked out during my visit and had the opportunity to see Van Gogh's "Portrait of A Peasant" and an exhibit of drawings from the Courtauld Collection. If you love classic art, this is a must go to location. They have three Vermeer's (with plans for a special exhibit in October to include "The Girl With A Pearl Earring"), a handful of J.M.W. Turners and a variety of other classic works. I am definitely going back to the Frick on my next trip to NYC.

Incredible space and collection. Not only was the art varied and wonderful - from Da Vinci & Michelangelo to Vermeer (2) and Van Gogh, but the furniture, rooms, and especially the garden room made it feel like you were walking through someones house. The rooms were manageable and even during the holidays it felt intimate without being ridiculously crowded. An inviting and warm experience, unlike many of the larger museums.
Like visiting a wealthy person's private home full of art. Very well managed art collection set in quite the historic property. Not too crowded and very relaxing to wander around such a lovely home.
Must see. The Frick museum is a must see attraction. It has a wonderful collection, but mainly it is in such a wonderful location in NYC. The mansion is as nice to visit as the art collection.

Incredible Collection in Intimate Setting. Mr. Frick had a great eye for art. In this collection, he has 3 Vermeers, several Rembrandts, and countless treasures. The mansion is a perfect setting. In 2 hours, this is a manageable, worthwhile collection to visit.

Must see for art lovers. Excellent painting colleaction in intimate home settings. (The sculpture collection is not as good.) My favorate room is the one with an El Greco painting of St. Jerome above the fireplace, flanked by two Hans Holbein paintings of Thomas More and Cromwell. On the opposite wall are two excellent Titan portraits. Don't miss this room. Also, don't miss the great self portrait of Rembrandt--the best I have seen. If you need to take a lunch break (like we did), walk a few blocks to Lexington.
Gotta check it out. Snapshot of "robber baron" taste and lifestyle. Some great art and furniture. Opulent. A headset is probably in order.

Interesting collection and mansion but.... The mansion is beautiful and the way it has been set up too. But after about 20 minutes you feel like you have seen everything. Maybe it just wasnt my kind of thing but for art lovers it is definitely worth a visit

Amazing Collection in Astounding Space. This is my favorite kind of museum. One that showcases a personal collection in what was once a family home. Important to note: Some rooms are small & it can get quite crowded. Adjust your visiting times accordingly. Also during the winter - check your coat! If you don't, you have to wear it at all times & some rooms can be very warm. It's hard to enjoy art when you're physically uncomfortable. Finally, because of the way artwork is hung there may be viewing difficulties for those in wheelchairs.

free sunday morning. well, not free but you can offer a penny and that will be you in from 11 am - 1 pm. it will give you a glimpse of how wealthy families lived and accumulated art and treasures. this is one of my favorite museums. get the audio tour to really enjoy every corner of this mansion and its treasures. the story behind it is fascinating. it is on 5th avenue in the 70's so easy access as well. if you enjoy art and beautiful homes, this museum is for you.
Gem in midtown. Excellent tour for first timers; permanent collection as well as specials make it a more gentle alternative to the Met.
Do not miss!!. The Frick is a wonderful, peaceful museum choice. Easy to visit in 2 hours. Lots of great art and a little peek into the grandeur life of yesteryear in 1900 s New York.

Excellent gallery. Set in the beautiful house of a NY industrialist, the house is worth a visit alone. However, the art is often excellent with some great traveling exhibits and a solid permanent collection. Worth the visit.

A gem. Stepping inside the Frick is stepping into an oasis in midtown Manhattan. The collection is outstanding and the setting is quiet allowing the visitor to spend time with the art and reflect. A visit to the Frick is a glimpse at a bygone era in New York City.

A must see. This is unlike any other museum we have ever visited. The Frick was a private home and is largely as it was when the Frick family lived in it. It is like stepping back in time to see exactly how people lived in the 19th century.

Superb Collection. A wonderful collection of world famous masterpieces in a fantastic mansion. The audio commentary provides a fascinating insight into the lifestyle of one of the early 20th century 'robber barons'

Wonderful collection. I recall years ago wandering through the Frick all by myself. Today, there were so many people there I couldn't believe it. I was glad it was getting recognition but sorry it was crowded. A really nice exhibition of drawings by famous artists. Hard to categorize what their collections are categorized by but they have some of the best art around. The order of the galleries is more confusing than that of the Met which is far larger but it worked for me just to wander around and enjoy the art. Very nice personnel except for a nasty person at the admissions desk who should have taken a break instead of acting in a disgusting manner. But the supervisor was very kind and accommodating. Recommend highly and in a great location too.

Don't Miss This When Visiting NYC. The Frick is a true gem. Unlike the Metropolitan Museum of Art (which is also worth seeing), the pieces in this collection are for viewing up close and personal. Viewing them in the context of someone's home makes them more approachable. I recommend watching the short film about Frick that shows throughout the day as well as using the free audio guide. The guide gives you interesting tidbits about pieces and rooms in the house you would otherwise not know. (Unlike the Met, there are not a lot of informational displays throughout the house about the collection.) Not required (especially if you have limited time) but interesting also is the docent tour. Our docent was welcoming and informative. See the Met, but also see this wonderful collection while in NYC.
Totally unexpected. A wonderful collection by a private collector. The house that contains the museum is beautiful and overwhelming. A must visit when you are in the City.

Beautiful collection.. I like the fact that is a small museum. In the Met, there is too much to see and I get Museum burnout.
Not at the Frick...I could have gone through it again.

A Gem even with the high standards of New York--do not miss!. This is an incredible art collection, beautifully displayed. It ranges from Renaissance Masters like Rembrandt, Goya and El Greco, including 3 Vermeers (of 34 known in the world!) to Renoir, Whistler, and Sargent in more modern times. There was a very nice porcelain exhibition while we were there, and the drawing special exhibit was spectacular.You do need to know something about the art as the only information on the paintings or furniture are date/title and artist if known (latter not listed for much of furniture or porcelain)--there are no interpretive notes. We did not do the audio tour that is available (included in your admission price), which might have helped with those things. If you do that, you might have to spend a bit more time.I cannot emphasize enough that this is worth every penny you spend for admission. Of all the museums we have seen in New York, this is second only to the Met (and of a much more manageable scope and size). DO NOT MISS THIS!

Not what I expected, but so much better!. Our visit to the Frick was a second choice when we saw extremely long lines at the Guggenheim. What an unexpected delight! I was unaware of the truly amazing collection located in one of the few remaining Fifth Avenue mansions. Hard to fathom that someone actually lived in this building which was designed to house an art collection. I felt honored to stand in the same rooms with medieval and Renaissance paintings I had only read about. One of the treasures of our country.

Excellent, perfect-size, fine art museum and mansion. I have visited lots of "stately homes" serving as art museums and this one is among the best. One can easily see it in 1-2 hours, and the quality and variety of the art is superb. This combined with the incredible furniture, furnishings and decor make it outstanding. The free audio guide provided is excellent. It is absolutely worth a visit..

The Frick. A wonderful small museum - not crowded and well staffed. Once a private home with and outstanding collection of art, furniture. On SUnday afternoon 11-1 it is 'pay want you want' Well worth a 3 or 4 hour visit. Then walk across the street into Central Park and enjoy one of the wonders of NYC

Always elegant.. The home and art collection of Henry Clay Frick is a wonderful experience. We enjoyed the Rembrandts, the El Grecos, and the fabulous Fragonard panels. The gorgeous Garden Court in the center of the mansion is instant tranquility.

What a home. Not only is the frick home magnificent but the contents! Fur nurse silver art. Beautiful courtyards. Definitely worth a visit. Have a look at the wonderful Van Gogh and the exhibition of drawings

Wonderful House, Wonderful Art. I came here to see their 3 Jan Vermeer paintings and was not disappointed. I was very pleased to see that were part of NARM, the North American Reciprocal Museum plan so my High Museum membership was honored. The guards were very knowledgeable about all the art, which impressed me a lot.

Outstanding. Arrived just as they opened the door. Leave your coats as you are not allowed to take them off to carry. Each room was outstanding. The collection of Turners, Whistlers, Gainsborough, etc were unbelievable. The rooms were well arranged and we were lucky tosee a An Gogh on loan and an exhibition from the Courtauld in London. Do not miss this amazing collection of rooms, paintings, pottery,..

A wonderful small museum. The art collection (including ceramics) is top notch, but the building itself is also outstanding. The furnishings are also very interesting. However, some parts of the building are starting to show wear and tear.

Perhaps the BEST museum in America. This is a smaller museum with an amazing permanent collection. Right now has a show "White Gold" I would normally never go look at porcelains but stumbled into this room and enjoyed. They have some amazing European paintings in the permanent collection. Concerts. lectures, expand your horizon - check out the website for reservations and calendar before your trip

Excellent Collection. Set in the Frick home just off Central Park, an excellent collection of artwork staged as it was when the Frick's resided at this address. Thoroughly enjoyable afternoon. Reasonable price, and if you show up early on Sunday, its pay as you wish.
