The secret we tell each other. Guidebooks focus on the art - friends tell you about the building. a rare opportunity to step into a 5th Avenue mansion, almost as it was. Feel the gracious air, imagine the lifestyle, oh - and the art is lovely too.

Is this a billion dollars worth of art?. My first visit and what an amazing art collection, yes there are no kids under 10 allowed, yes there is no cafe, yes there is hardly any seats but wow walk into any room and recognise 5 or more serious pieces of art. If you like French rococo or Flemish art and no crowds and an amazing view of 1900's wealth, then this place is the top of the list. The audio guide is free which is good as for some amazing reason most of the more well known pieces are not explained. Also the rooms are not well numbered. Seating is only in about 20% of the rooms. But who needs a coffee when you can drink in heaps of El Greco, Fragonard, Turner, Reynolds and Reuben's.

THE museum to see in NYC. The fact that there are so many works of art is only half the story. The mansion, where Henry Frick lived, is phenomenal! You actually tour the rooms where he lived and each one contains so many paintings, sculptures, furniture, and other artifacts that make it more personal than a 'typical' museum.Although he was kind of a tyrant businessman, at least he used his money to buy precious works of art, and now through his foundation, shares them to the world. Don't miss this!
Beautiful setting. Wonderful art representing many artists. They have a nice gift shop. Great location next to Central Park.

Can't belive people realy lived here.. the house is amazing, the art, very classic, impressive, but not exactly to our taste. van goch is one of the most amzing works i have seen, and probably worth the visit just to see it.
Fabulous. Brilliant and do-able not overwhelming Paintings exceptionalGift shop lovely and not overpriced Wonderful and not crowded..not everyone knows about it
A favorite of ours. I like the fact that this was actually someone's home at one time. Just imagining living in such a wonderful home right across from Central Park is mindboggling.
Gorgeous art in a gorgeous setting. I have been to the Frick many times and I'm enchanted every time I go back. I feel like a welcome guest in an art lover's home. What a treat!

Classic artwork in a home like setting. We enjoyed the many works of art displayed in this home, made it feel like you were visiting a friend's home (a rich friend!) and viewing his personal art collection. Very worth the low ticket price ($18)
fabulous collection. make sure that you use the free audio. It really helps you learn more about this wonderful place and wonderful pictures.
A Gem. Mr. Frick may have done some terrible things, but he atoned by giving us all access his home and his art. The museum is especially an oasisi on a cold winter day.

Not my favorite but some interesting pieces. I love the building but this just isn't my favorite era in art or design. Interesting to see the whistler portraits. And they were showing a mostly unseen Van Gogh portrait when I was there. If you love 18th-19th century European and American art and furniture, you'll be in heaven.

No Creative Inspiration for Children here :-(. A treasure! You almost can't believe that you're looking at the original St. Thomas More portrait.Only complaint is no children allowed - we've taken our children to every art museum we visit as a family - they even enjoyed the Morgan Library.If the Frick is so concerned they should better monitor some of the adult visitors. Go visit Clayton in Pittsburgh for Mr. Frick's other home for a better experience that the whole family can enjoy.
Peaceful oasis. Great gallery to get away from the crowds of the other art museums and fascinating to see inside a 5th Avenue mansion

Small, but exquisite. Came here for about an hour before I had to go meet a friend elsewhere. I took the metro from Penn Station and walked across Central Park to get here.They provide free audio guides- which I recommend, otherwise if you don't already know about the art, you'll be wandering around just looking at pretty things. The stories behind them make them much more special and memorable.Lots of paintings from famous European artists (only ~2 American artists works are here). Most of the paintings are portraits. There are some landscape paintings and porcelain. Most of the rooms have fancy antique furniture too.It's really a gorgeous place and worth the visit. Since it's small, it shouldn't take more than 1.5-2 hrs or so to see. It's nice to visit a museum which isn't overwhelming.Children are not allowed here since there are no ropes around the art.TIP: Students get a discount with their ID. YES! There's also a free coat check.

Magnificent!. The is a fabulous mansion with lots of interesting things to see, especially art. The structure itself is amazing. Lots of fine antiques. I went here with a friend during the summer and we both really enjoyed it.

a real gem-do not overlook it!. The fact that this mansion was a family house is quite a big deal considering the collection within and this must reflect the massive wealth of the Fricks. The conllection houses some of the most impressive artworks in the world and it's a bit like eating a whole box of belgian chocs in one go! It's quite alot to take in in asingle visit as there is simply so much to savour. However there is a wonderful pool and atrium area where you can take a quiet break if your palate needs to be refreshed between

Masters of Art. An absolutely amazing collection featuring artists like Rembrandt, DaVinci, Picasso, Turner, Cezanne, Whistler, van Gogh, Matisse, Bernini, and even two Vermeer paintings. Such a rare collection filled with furniture, sculpture, busts, drawings, paintings, and antiques. No pictures are allowed. There is a free coat/bag check for your use and also a student discount (with ID).
First time, and. ...we really enjoyed it. Right sized.....good for a couple of hours which is pretty much my museum time limit.

Outstanding. Of all the places we visited in New York this was one of our favourites. I loved everything about it from the building, painting, antiques, gardening. The audio was excellent. The staff very friendly.
A must see if visiting New York.

Old Masters. Wonderful collection of old masters paintings in a elegant home setting. Loved everything about it other than they need more seating in the rooms so people can sit and enjoy the art if they have significant musculoskeletal problems.

Superb collection.... An amazing palace in the heart of 5th. Ave.The sumptuous and rarest collection of oil paintings,fine furniture,crystal and all sort of fine antiques.Such a glorious place was the property of one of the railroad and coal Baron Mr. Frick in the middle XIX Century.His wealth even for nowadays standards was amazing and the refinement in his choice of collectibles were even the envy of several Kings,Dukes and very wealthy Europeans.Mr. Frick possessed many Rembrandt an other first class painters renowned worldwide.Ormolu, lacquer,crystal,porcelains,carpets,fine woods, conferred ceilings brought from Europe,finest marble fireplaces,magnificent chandeliers,all sort of objects d'art andan amazing staircase leading to the second story still underinventory after almost a century.Highly recommended for lovers of the finer things in life.
Great little, (mostly unknown) museum. Personal collection of Frick family in their home. Very well presented - a beautiful home and great collection. Well worth a couple hours.

My favorite art in New York. A superb collection of mainly 17th - early 20th painting. There are virtually no duds on these walls. They are hung with care in one of Manhattan's few surviving old millionaire mansions. Just the right size for a 60-90 minute visit.
Frick is one of NYc jewels. Wonderful collection set out very well. not overwhelming. Some of the artwork is world famous and a must see

Frick Collection is unbelievable!!!. if you are an admirer of art and you are in nyc, you must see the Frick Collection on Fifth Ave. It is the only house (yes house....mansion) on Fifth Ave with a front lawn.
An amazing gem. I had been recommended to see this by other visitors and we were not disappointed. There are absolute gems everywhere.

You aren't allowed to MOVE in this museum.. The building itself and the collection are wonderful, but all three times I visited, one of the workers followed us around barking orders at us-- no drinking water, no "holding" a sweater (either wear it or check it), no photographs, no sitting on anything, no standing in certain areas, and the list goes on. Of course, I understand some of these rules. Others were bananas. This drastically took away from the overall experience, and ultimately I don't remember much of the art. I've been to every art museum in New York, and this is the only place like that-- it was like that on every visit. I'm a quiet person, so it wasn't just my group. Very stiff. Keep that in mind-- it's a little bit entertaining if nothing else.

Interesting art collection. The thing I liked best was getting to go inside one of the mansions of the men of the industrial revolution. It's his personal collection still hung in the places he designated. There was a beautiful Van Gogh on lone also.

Takes you back in time. the entrance fee is high $18 but a once in a lifetime experience--only wish it had a cafe--they give you a hearing piece so you can get detailed information on all the paintings and statues in the house--there are also guided tours and a movie on Frick himself

Frick Museum, unique and excellent pictures. I appreciated all that big collection of pictures Van Goght, all pictures he stooled, because that man had a special live. He gave all the collection to collectivity of the town of NEW YORK after dead.

Imagine yourself as a wealthy industrialist. The Frick Collection features a wonderful collection of art in a truly amazing setting. Like many of the industrialists of the last century, Frick gave back to society, and H.C. Frick's collection is a great gift to current and future generations. Whether you prefer renaissance art, portraiture, or post-impressionists, you will find something to enjoy at the Frick.

The home itself is a work of art . . .. and the art displayed inside is magnificent. It's as inspiring as the Met and a lot more manageable. Don't miss it. Sundays between 11am and 1pm you can pay what you wish.

hidden gem. Best part of this experience was being able to get close enough to the art work to appreciate all the details that went into the final product. You feel as if you are in someone's house, gazing at their walls - not in a cold impersonal museum. OH, that's right - it really is a house! Henry Frick had a purpose and focus to his collection - mostly women, all beautiful; the library and west wing contain some spectacular portraits. Most intriguing art gallery we've ever been too; well worth the 90 minutes. The only disappointing part was that the house was not decorated for the Christmas season, as described in many sourcebooks. We visited Dec. 5; perhaps we were too early.

World class museum. In my opinion, the Frick Museum is one of the finest museums in the world. It is beautifully designed and houses magnificent art collection. It is definitely a must when visiting NYC.
Wonderful old home. The current exhibit of drawings is really spectacular, and the setting and garden court are a welcome break from the bustle of the city.
Elegant. Beautiful, art, architecture, and garden. The Frick is a wonderful place to just be and absorb the aesthetics.

Always astounding. I'll be brief... There is no other attraction, museum or exhibit I've ever been to in Manhattan that offers more value, rarity and up-close delight than the Frick. Time after time, year after year, it draws me back and delights me again.
Money, money, money. Gems that only money could buy. And beautifully displayed in a home now open to the public. I could not live in such opulence but Frick could afford the best

A nice place to spend an hour. The Frick Collection is housed in a beautiful old home on the upper east side of Manhattan (E. 70th St.) The collection consists of very fine paintings and sculptures. Noted artists including Van Gogh ("Portrait of a Peasant") and Thomas Gainsborough and many others are displayed in the collection. I would definitely recommend a visit to the Frick Collection, it is well worth your time.

An Amazing Art Collection. The Frick Collection is a "must see" for any art lover. Located in the original Frick Mansion, every piece of art is a Masterpiece - from Rembrandt to Velasquez, Holbein to El Greco. The paintings, statues, furniture, sculptures, are ALL amazing and beautiful. So many beautiful masterworks all in one place. The short film shown gives a good background of Frick and how his collection came to be. The Frick mansion and its art are one of the nicest places to visit in Manhattan. Don't miss it!
Beautiful. Very enjoyable. Beautiful home and great pieces. Worth a visit. Nice to see the rooms, furniture of the Fricks.

Frickin' Fantastic. This is a beautiful, beautiful museum. The audio tour is very good. Special exhibits were beautiful. Staff is friendly. I so enjoyed it. We took about two hours going through and that was just about right. The special sketches exhibit was carefully staged and a joy to view.

Old world charm. Ah! one can feel like they are in Europe walking through the rooms of this magnificent building and seeing incredible art pieces. A beautiful courtyard that is so relaxing and beautiful!
Loved it!. One of the best things we did. The house is glorious & contents spectacular! If you only do one museum/art gallery - make it The Frick Collection!

Great building housing eclectic collection. Fortunate to arrive at 11am on a Sunday when one can just donate a coin as entry rather than the full entry price. Small yet interesting collection of a wealthy industrialist covering some interesting art, painting, sculpture, drawings etc. If you don't have time to visit the MET then this gallery would do nicely as an alternative. Just really amazing to see such a fabulous building taking up a whole block on Fifth Avenue!
Nice collection. I am by no means an art critic but this place has it all. Fantastic collection of all the major artists over 500 years.

one of New York's gems. magnificent and varied collection of art, sculpture and furniture. Housed in the great Frick mansion in New York City. Reasonable fee. Grteat part is the casual ambience as you go through the home, from room to room; totally unlike the sterile , rushed feel of larger museums.

Extraordinary Small Museum. Fantastic small collection focused on English painters and old masters. Three Vermeers. The small size of this museum, small crowds, free coat check, and lots of seating make this an ideal place to spend an hour or two.

I Visit Each Time I'm in NY. The Frick Collection is basically the Frick Home opened for you to visit and imagine life in the gilded Age---sitting in these rooms gazing at these amazing paintings. The museum is just the right size for a visit of an hour or two and the collection is superlative.

Great Collection!. This collection is a must see with pieces from many famous artists including works from da Vinci, Degas, Michelangelo, Durer, Rembrandt, van Gogh, and Picasso. The Frick Collection in NYC has reciprocal privileges with many of the other leading art museums in the US.

Loved the Picasso Drawings exhibit.. Don't miss the opportunity to explore this lovely gem on the upper East Side. The Picasso's were wonderful but there is are many other works that make visiting the Frick a good choice any time. Enjoy!

not just a house museum. It's interesting enough as the former Fifth Avenue home of a rich collector, who amassed wonderful art treasures: statues, paintings, porcelain, furniture, all now displayed for our pleasure.But this museum also houses an art reference library accessible free of charge (adults only) and offers an impressive array of lectures and talks, courses, guided tours, and even concerts.The entrance fee to the collection is $18 ($15 for students and senior citizens); please note children under 10 aren't admitted due to the fragility of many exhibits.

An exquisite house museum. Hadn't been to the Frick in years and what a joy it was to revisit it. The collection is simply marvelous and having a chance to see Van Gogh's "The Peasant" added to our experience.

Great. Forget the Guggenheim!. After a 40 minute wait to get into the Guggenheim to see a second rate exhibition it was great to walk in to the Frick with no queue & see a much superior collection.Downstairs is a superb travelling exhibition of drawings from the Courtauld gallery in London (until January 27, 2013).The main house is beautifully laid out with the collection of paintings, furniture, porcelain & sculpture, intelligently displayed & arranged within each room, & in logical sequence as you proceed through your tour of the house.The JMW Turners alone are worth the visit.

Beautiful setting for beautiful art. The mansion is a beautiful place to wander on its own merit, but the art, of course, is stunning. There is so much to see, and yet it isn't overwhelming as some of the larger museums can be. We spent a delightful afternoon at the Frick.

World-class art in a beautiful, unique setting. The Frick Collection is not to be missed on a visit to New York City! Famous works of art like Gainsborough's "Blue Boy" and Hans Holbein's "Portrait of Sir Thomas More" are here, among countless others, all in the beautiful setting of the Frick Mansion, which at one time was a private home. Closed on Mondays. Don't miss!

My first, but not last, visit to the Frick Collection. Awesome. If you only have a few days in NYC and get overwhelmed by large institutions, this is the place to spend a couple of hours. The Frick Gallery has the best collection of Masters that any one person could possibly absorb in one visit. The museum building along with its beautiful collection of furniture add to the enjoyment of the visit.I feel most fortunate indeed to have been introduced to this very special and unique collection and residence.

An excellent collection. We always find the Frick interesting, and they usually have good temporary exhibits. We were also happy to find that our membership in our local art museum got us free entrance!

Frick Collection. The Frick Collection has always been a favorite of our, as we have been 4 times over the years. Has a good audio tour and the setting is one of the best. A must see in New York for those who like good Art Collections. And it comes with a good American story of the Family that created it.

Like having a really rich friend who invites you over to look at his art..... The intimacy is on a rather grand scale, but the Frick is a friendly little gem in the heart of the city, just-right sized for an enjoyable hour or two. The interior is lavish in an austere sort of way; the collection is a mixed bag, with some really wonderful pieces amidst a lot of pretty good stuff. Not every museum has to be the Met; this kind of of place has its own charm and vibe, and is almost never crowded. Well worth the stop, particularly if you're looking for some contemplative time with art.

A very special collection. More than a museum, the Frick is a look back in time to another era. The 10 minute movie about Mr. Frick Is a worthwhile part of the visit. A very enjoyabe way to see some beautiful art work and decorative pieces. Sunday admission is pay what you like, so on Sunday there may be a wait to enter.

A Must visit for visitors to NYC. This museum is housed in a former house of one of New York's financial giants. That in itself makes it worth a visit. There is a beautiful central skylighted garden area with marble fountain. The art is beautifully displayed and there is just the right amount. Not overwhelming. One or two Vermeers. I think that is the Must See art museum in NYC.
Masters all over the house. This has to be one of the greatest galleries in NYC and the world simply stunning house and painting by the great masters all over the houses. Don't miss this collection .

Sit and enjoy the envoronment. In addition to enjoying the art at the Frick you can just sit and relax in one of the most beautiful buildings and gardens in Manhattan. The Frick is peaceful and beautiful...a great escape from the hustle of the city.
I need to go more often. One of the best places to visit. So much knowledge to absorb. Boggles the intelect and a must for a full life

House is outstanding, collection bit boorish. Plus = it is a quick tour and you get to see how the super rich lived when 5th Avenue was a row of mansions.Downside = didnt find the artwork to be that appealing or inspiring, then again I was there more for the residence itself
Great Museum in front of the Central Park.. A small and very beautiful museum. A must go in front of the Central Park. The House looks like a Castle.

GEM - Overwhelming in Quality not Quantity!. What a delightful visit! My husband is not a big art museum guy so decided after reading the reviews to try a small focused NYC gallery which he would hopefully enjoy. Getting there, was a short and pleasant walk parallel to Central Park from the Rockefeller Center area. The museum is easy to navigate and enjoy. There is a free audio tour included in the admission price which focuses on many of his prized collections and adds quite a bit of history as well. The collection is amazing – I am a huge fan of Titian whose art is rare to find and here were THREE in this collection, plus the Rembrandts! There is just so much to enjoy. Frick was not a big fan of American artists but the Whistler and Stuart art is outstanding. It was not overwhelming in size but definitely in quality. One cannot escape the fact that this was Frick’s personal home (excuse me, mansion) and collection – the 2% that the majority of us have no clue how they live. At least they bequeathed these collections to the public but I am sure at a huge tax advantage. Definitely recommend to all and my non-art lover husband thoroughly enjoyed it. GO! (p.s. research Frick and his relationship with Rockefeller etc - History Channel stuff!)

Wonderful Collection. It may be a conservative, rather unadventurous collection but, wow, there are too many masterpieces to mention. I tend to make a beeline for the Holbein portrait of Thomas More...exquisite. And the setting is stunning. An absolute must for visitors to New York.

Exquisite Collection. The Frick is my favorite art museum in New York. Henry Frick was an art connoisseur with exquisite taste and his collection of paintings and statuary is of remarkably high quality. The collection is housed in his grand but comfortable mansion on Fifth Avenue, and retains its intimate and domestic ambience. The garden courtyard is delightful place for a rest. My only regret is that the Frick does not have a cafe.

A Memorable Visit. My husband is somewhat new to viewing art collections but this small gallery was perfect. Having previously visited a gallery of modern art, we left feeling somewhat bewildered over what is deemed worthy of being called "art". What we found at The Frick was a jewel in the city; a lovely mansion and it's exquisite pieces were such a pleasure to view. To think that this was once a private home of a wealthy industrialist. I believe it was Mr. Frick; he would be so proud of his home today. There is a free day - just enquire.

Toto, you're not in Pittsburgh anymore!. We have a Frick museum and a Frick estate in Pittsburgh, but this dwarfs them both. It's more like a monument to opulence. The first floor has a large collection of paintings and sculptures and some furnishings and objects d'art. There is an impressive conservatory room with a fountain but that is the only place you can really rest your weary legs. And you can't go out on the closed in veranda, even though there are display cases on it. Still worth the visit.

Sometimes a forgotten gem!. NYC has many brilliant museums but the Frick stands alone because it's a house. A gorgeous house. Intimate and beautiful - their permanent collection is exceptional as are the special exhibits that come in.

We visited the Frick Collection, each year we are in NY. The Frick Collection is a private museum. It is known by havingn special art whiich are not available elsewhere. Grteat Amsrican Painters you can find there mixed with Foreign Painters.Very good taste to view it.

My favorite museum in the city. Awesome. What a place. The works of art aren''t all top draw, but most are. And the building is incredible. This is an incredible insight into the lives of the earliest tycoons in America. This is how they lived.
elegant house and Museum. A small mmuseum that was the home of a wealthy New Yorker. Besides the art collection, one gets a sense of how the 2% lived in another era.

Don't pass this one by .... This is, quite simply, one of the finest attractions in town! It is not expensive ... and these days that's important. Frick was a very interesting collector -- there's a HUGE variety of works of art on display in an atmosphere that is (honestly?) restful! It's very visitor friendly and I never hesitate to recommend it to friends and out-of-town visitors who are not familiar with The Frick -- some have never heard of the place! It's high rating and good word-of-mouth are absolutely well deserved!

Very nice place. Nice place to spend some quiet hours. On Sundays before 1.00 PM it is free admission (or you pay what you want) But be ready for a line up outside..... Remember that kids under the age of 10 are not permitted. I would absolutely recommend Frick Collection

Small and impressive. The mansion alone is worth a visit. The paintings, sculptures, furniture were all impressive. Included with the price of admission are audio guides. Do not pass these up. The guides included history into the Frick Family, the mansion as well as all the artwork.

Private Mansion - Intimate Museum. This museum is one of my favorites. I continue to stop by when in the neighborhood. It is small, but every inch a gem! Several periods of art history represented, but in the midst of a gracious home and interior. Not to be missed. Classical elegance and memories abound.

SMALL BUT GREAT. This is a wonderful museum to spend a few hours in. not only are their collections worth the visit, but they have an atmosphere that will envelope you and you will relax and enjoy your time here. Spend time in their indoor and outdoor gardens. If you have time they show a short film recounting the history, it is interesting. This is one of the beautiful mansions that grace old fifth avenue..Do not miss out.Jeremy T

Mansion from a former era. The history of the Building the family and of course the amazing art collection within.The actual reception and staff attitude very subdued and almost un happy??However magnificent position opposite central park on 5th Avenue a must see whilst in NYC!

Good, smaller museum. The museum is in the Frick mansion so you get an inkling the the grandeur of the early 20th century. Staff offer tours of the collection which are valuable as they not only highlight the collection but the history of the Frick family and foundation. Plan on about 2 hours. The audio-tour is complimentary with your admission fee.

Only went for the van Gogh. Had lots of paintings which you could happily have wandered past in any gallery. Plus points - The Van Gogh on show (I think called "The Peasant") was superb and the actual building is in itself a wonder

12 visits over several years - will return - it is beautiful!. Not so overwhelming as the Metropolitan Museum and has some gems you won't find anywhere else. The mansion itself is a museum - an amazing place to behold.

Great, but secondary. Frick is great. If you're staying longer in NY, it's a must see, but it doesn't come even near metropolitan museum. Many other attractions in NYC are preferable if you'll be in the city for just a couple of days. It's beautiful, but if you want art, the MET is the best. If you're interested in discovering NY, many other places come first.

Best small museum in New York. Unbelievable collection in a fantastic setting. The high point of any art lover's trip to NYC. So many masterpieces in one place. You can spend a lot of time here and still want to come back during your next visit.

Not bad. This museum was not huge and not overwhelming. Very easy floor plan to keep from getting lost. seemed to have a good balance with the art. I happen to love Franz Hall and there were sevedral of his paintings

Fantastic! A must see in NYC. So impressed by this private collection, every painting is a true masterpiece. While walking from one work to another in this tastefully decorated house was completely taken and amazed by the assembly of the names presented - Van Gogh, Matisse, Constable, Rembrandt, Turner, Van Dyck - the list goes on. Certainly one of the best private collections I've seen.
Superb collection. A visit to the Frick is always included in every trip I make to NYC. Timeless collection and quiet, top-quality changing exhibits.
Not to miss. One of the best private collectons i have ever seen. A very nice old house in upper manhattan, it is incredible.
Worth the time . Was not overwhelmed by this collection but enjoyed our visit. Most interesting aspect for us was the dimensions of the building and some of the paintings were also worth seeing.
Magical Experience. Loved learning about the Henry Clay Frick collection and viewing his personal belongings. I appreciated the beauty of the interior of his lovely home.

Great museum. Loved the place. Greatv collection in a building that is charming, not too big and not too small. Also, located across from Central Park so it's easy to enjoy the park before or after for a change of scene.

A gem of a "small" museum..... terrific art in a beautiful setting..... At this museum you feel as if you have just entered someone's gorgeous home while they stepped out..... the art is displayed in this Upper East Side mansion amidst the appropriate furnishings.... from wallpaper, to sconces, to china and silverware.... amazing! There is an orientation movie to give the background of the owner, the building and the collection. I would have liked to have been directed there first. They also have headsets to explain the collection. There are also some lovely interior gardens.
Wonderful hodge/podge of art. You are amazed at the variation in all the work. Very different thana gallery or museum where you investigate the work of one artist.
Great collection in a unique space. Really recommend this collection -- it's terrific and so is the space, the Frick mansion. Definitely worth a visit if you enjoy art museums!

Best Museum in NYC. I love this Museum, it never fails to lift my spirits. The beautiful rooms display amazing works in an intimate setting. I don't have that overwhelming feeling when a Museum is too large and you can't decide where to begin. An amazing array of artists. Who could think that such a small space would have Titian, Rembrandt, Brugel the Elder, Whistler Gainsborough and much much more. Delightfully hung amongst wonderful china, silver, and furniture. The fabrics , wallpapers, embroidery and lighting enhance the experience. The internal courtyard and gardens are just wonderful.

Such a beautiful place.... The Frick Collection is one of the most endearing museum in NYC. Compared to other places it is not overwhelming and one can enjoy its fabulous collection at a leasurely pace... The Fragonard paintings are superb...

Not my personal favourite but a good collection in a great space. . A beautiful home is used for the display of this collection. A really good collection of work on display. A good size - you can do this all well in 90 minutes.
Awesome collection of art in NYC. A must do whilst in new york, beautiful art and surroundings! Staff very friendly & a good place to get out of the cold for a while
Small but beautiful. Small by New York museum standards but absolutely beautiful building both inside and out with fascinating collection, must see.

Must see. You travel guide may have told you something about this small museum: that they have a wonderful Vermeer and a Rembrandt self-portrait. Trust me: you will be surprised by some items the travel book did not mention. You start by viewing some drawings - make sure to read the descriptions, they do tell you interesting stuff about the sketches and why they are there. Then you climb the stairs and get to see the paintings, some of which are impressive - especially if you also like El Greco and Vermeer. And Titian. And Rembrandt. And Velasquez. And Goya. And yes, all this in a small building you can visit in a few hours.
A jewel of a museum. This is a lovely small museum - you can tour it in an hour - but the xhibits and collection are good, and the building is fabulous!

Amazing collection in a NY mansion. Rembrands on every wall. An incredible collection of paintings, sketches, watercolours, sculptures and porcelaine. All in a beautiful home. Regular entry is $18pp but worth it. Plus opposite Central Park so enjoy both.

Sweet, manageable museum mansion. This mansion museum has always been a gem on the upper East Side of Manhattan. Full of gorgeous decorative arts, and not a few painting masterpieces, it's the perfect place for a rainy afternoon (or a sunny one).

One of the musts in this town if you at all like art.. A great historic rail baron's mansion full of the great art he managed to collect. So many masterpieces! Do not miss the portraits of Thomas More and Cromwell on both sides of the fireplace. Every other museum on Earth would kill to have them. Often interesting exhibits downstairs, not that seeing the permanent collection for the fifth time is boring!
Fantastic!. Great collection in an amazing building! Most tourists would of course first visit the Guggenheim and MoMa but this smaller museum is absolutely worth a visti.

Don't miss this little gem. Arrive on a Sunday morning @ 10:45 to get in for free. Grab a little phone tour and listen to the private tour for each painting and piece in the collection you would like to hear about.You simply dial in the # for the piece you want to hear about. Plan on 3 hours. Fall in love with the incredible mansion, incredibly paintings by Rembrant, Belinni, Matisse, Boucher, and Whistle to just name a few, but my favorite pieces were the chest and secretary owned by Marie-Antoinette. I hate stuffy museums. This one's a gem and worth your time. You won't be sorry.

A peaceful respite. The Frick was a wonderful experience. It was calm, quiet and easy compared to the MOMa You could actually enjoy the art work and the wonderful house. It was a real look into the past grandeur and the best part was nobody had an iPhone out taking terrible pictures of the paintings

The Frick: New York City's great townhouse museum. Having lived in New York, the Frick has been a familiar and loved place to visit. It is situated overlooking Central Park on Fifth Avenue, easily accessed by Madison Avenue uptown bus, Lex subway or by foot through the park on a nice day. I had not been to the Frick for a number of years, and returned there with friends last April. It is no longer free - that dates me! - but well worth the admission fee, and within the tranquil, beautifully furnished rooms remain a sublime setting for a great private collection of paintings. Bernard Berenson found many of the Old Masters for Henry Clay Frick, builder of the house, and Bellini's "St. Francis in Ecstasy" is alone worth a visit, not to mention the El Grecos. Allow no less than three hours for the visit, and then - if the day is nice - walk into Central Park for lunch at the Boathouse Restaurant.

A wonderful afternoon!. This is the perfect size for people who want to feel like they've really "done" a museum, but don't want to spend three days or strap on roller skates to get through all the galleries. Charming, nice staff, and you'll recognize some of the works! Great gift shop, too.
one of the best kept secrets in nyc. a trip back in time and one of the most wonderful art collections aroundthe courtyard is a sanctuary within nycthis museum shows the loving touches of the statff

amazing. A great storied collection put together by a careful, thoughtful magnate. The mansion was beautifully constructed and maintained. The narrations available with the earphone really pulled together the history and information on most of the pieces. It is a wow for me. I feel privileged to have the opportunity to enjoy.

Never Get Tired Of This. I love the Frick. I've been there 3 times and it's such a gem in a big city. Not only is the art collection superlative but the mansion that houses it is beautiful. If you're visiting the Frick, take in the surroundings as well as the art - you'll be impressed.

Wonderful museum. This is a great collection on the Upper East Side not far from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. There is more than art to see here. The house in very interesting as is the history of the collection. The historical video is well worth viewing as it provides a valuable insight into how the collection was created. Highly recommended.

GREAT experience. We loved our time at the Frick. Beautiful, private mansion full of amazing masterpieces. We were lucky to arrive in time for a brief docent led introduction to the collection. This was worthwhile, as he gave some good background information on the home and the artwork. We also each picked up one of their audio guide/remotes, which are included with your admission. Be sure to get one of these. There is a number next to each piece of art. You type the number into the audio guide and you are treated to a few interesting tidbits of information about the artist/work. Our visit would not have been nearly as interesting without the audio guides. This is a small "museum" and we appreciated the fact that we could see the entire collection in under two hours. A special treat during our visit was getting to see a temporary exhibit- an original self portrait of Van Gogh. You can get very close to it. Just stunning...

A visit in time.. From the moment you arrived in this gorgeous mansion that once was privately owed by Henry Frick, you are transported to another time and place. The reflecting pool and garden room are tranquil and beautiful, the collections world class selections of classic works, some of the finest I have enjoyed anywhere.It is a museum I visit often and never tire of its timelessness
Wonderful art in an Italian palazzo. Not a huge museum. One afternoon and some intense viewing can do it. Great collection and absolutely beautiful building in the heart of the Upper East Side.

After You Are Tired of the Met. As a frequent traveler to New York I have been to the Met on numerous occasions. This time we thought we would try the Frick collection as an alternative. We were not disappointed, The art and decorative arts on display are exceptional and well worth the visit. Besides enjoying the fabulous pieces it was nice to see the art as it was placed with the furniture at the time the Fricks lived in the home. Very few people were at the Collection when we visited (Thursday morning) so it was possible to linger and enjoy the pieces without the crowds. A nice alternative to the masses at the Met. If you are tired of the Met, this is an enjoyable couple of hours to savour the beautiful art. Don't forget to pick up the free audio tour near the front door and note that children under 10 are not allowed in the Collection. Also don't miss the video explaining the history of the Frick Collection which runs on a ten minute loop in the Music Room.

1900 Tycoon Mansion Museum in Manhattan. Unique 1900 Railroad Tycoon Mansion with best turn of century and old master's art--filled wall to wall. You will be overwhelmed--but best thing is on every Sunday: 11am to 1pm--pay what you wish to be a Tycoon for an afternoon. Right in middle of busy Manhattan!

A Wonderful, Smaller Museum with Great Works of Art. The Frick is a small museum compared with the others in New York, but this makes the relics easier to see in detail without the crowds and endless galleries to wander through. Being the private collection of a wealthy man, in his own home, makes this museum very personal. Well worth a visit.

Don't miss it. The Frick is right on 5th Ave, not far from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It is a very accessible gallery with some outstanding pieces. This was the home of Andrew Carnegie's right hand man and the home itself is worth the visit. But a very pleasant gallery to spend some time and not nearly as taxing as the Met.

Take your teen for their first collection experience!. I learned about this collection in college and have since taken many to see it. I feel its a bit my own secret art gallery that isnt known by too many. I first took my daughter when she was a rteen and now my adult daughter takes her special peeps too. A lovely grand mansion turned into a lovely afternoon of "seeing"...just take it in and enjoy. You feel a bit overwhelmed at first but take your time, you dont have to everything the first time.
Little Museum, Great Art. This small, private collection is wonderful and the home in which it is displayed is fantastic. I enjoyed the artwork as much as the architecture and book collection.
GREAT but avoid a weekend. Really wonderful example of a US Industrialist home on the Upper East Side and his art collection. However very crowded on the weekends
The Frick. Excellent collection in a museum that is not overwhelming. House is very interesting. Informative film as well.
A favorite NYC museum. If you see any museums in NYC, see this one and imagine life in the old days. I love this place. Not only great art but the house tells a story of the family.
Big Surprise. The art , but the inner gardens , the pond , everything was beautiful. tThe building, and it´s decoration.

Exceptional. One should visit this museum even if it were just to see the house where it's located. We also liked the scale of the museum: not to big, so you can take your time to visit all the rooms, listening to the very interesting commentaries on the audio guide. This is my favorite museum

Small and beautifully formed!. This is a bit of a hidden gem. Housed in one of the few original mansions left on 5th Avenue opposite Central Park is a stunning collection of art work. The interior of the house is equally fascinating. Very strongly recommended if you like looking around the houses of the historical mega-rich and enjoy eclectic collections of very fine art which reflect their owner's character and good taste just as much as their unimaginable buying power!

Small museums rule!. There is really nothing like the Frick for quality over quantity. Literally not a single piece on display there is substandard, and the average canvas you'll encounter there is a world-class masterpiece. Brueghel, Holbein, Vermeer, El Greco, Velasquez and Goya - all top of the line works. Of special interest for me was Rembrandt's Polish Rider, mentioned in Frank O'Hara's fine poem "Having a Coke with You":"I lookat you and I would rather look at you than all the portraits in the worldexcept possibly for the Polish Rider occasionally and anyway it's in the Frickwhich thank heavens you haven't gone to yet so we can go together the first time"

Where else would a Vemeer not hold center stage?. I wanted to visit the Frick to see the Vemeers hanging there. I had to hunt for them because a very nice Rembrant self portrait, and couple of large Whistlers held more prominent display locations. I did view the Vemeers and a lot of other great paintings and wondered that the building and the art could represent only a fraction of Frick's wealth. At least he showed good taste in art.

An oasis of calm in the, otherwise, frenetic NYC. I was told to visit this by a relative and I am so glad that I did. It is so calm and tranquil and one feels like one is visiting a home rather than a "collection." it was one of the highlights of my trip. Very interesting art collection beautifullly displayed in furnished rooms. Do call in en route to Metropolitan Museum of Art and Guggenheim; you won't be disappointed.
A must!. Simply fantastic. One to rival the Wallace collection in London and each time I am in NYC I have to get to the Frick. An amazing visiting exhibition from the Courtauld at the moment.
delightful museum. superb architecture of the actual museum - collection consistently of a very high standard - great access on museum mile

A small museum in its own building. The trouble with the huge museums like the Met or the Louvre is that their treasures require many visits to be appreciated. If you don't live in New York or Paris, you can do only bits at a time. That's the advantage of smaller museums that represent one person's collecting usually in certain periods or genres. The Frick has some beautiful pieces. Although I've been there numerous times, it is always a treat, and much easier than to take a breath and embark on a voyage in the Met which is impossible to manage in a single visit.

A must visit. The Frick Collection is one of the most diverse gatherings of art on exhibit in New York. There was a large collection of drawings on display many of which were created by artists before their actual paintings, some dating back to the 1500s. The masters were also well represented. The gallery itself was worth the visit. You quickly realize that this opulent home was built with the intent of collecting art and eventually leaving it as a museum for the public.

Quick Frick!. We popped in for a short visit to the Frick -- I have a card that got us in for free. It's an amazing building, with an incredible collection of art. A lot of the pieces weren't our cup of tea, as we prefer Impressionist and Modern, but we enjoyed our wander round the house, which is overstated in every way possible, and must have been a wonderful place to live when it was a residence. Worth a visit regardless of your tastes in art, but those who like pre-20th Century artists will probably enjoy it the most.

My Favorite Small Museum in the USA. The Frick Mansion is home to an exquisitely curated collection of painting, sculpture and china displayed in what once was Henry Clay Frick's beautiful home. The rooms with panels by Fragonard and Boucher are so heavenly it's hard to leave them but the Vermeers, Rembrandts and other masterpieces must be seen! Give yourself two or three hours to see this gem of a museum.

Small and near perfect. If you like art but the Met overwhelms you with its size then the Frick Collection is for you. The scale is manageable and every room holds a sublime blend of paintings and decorative arts. To see everything on offer and not feel exhausted afterwards makes it 'just right' by me. My only beef is with the rather officious staff who enforce the no photography rule with uncalled-for zealotry. Lighten up please!

"Not to be missed".. The Frick Collection is like a mini Metropolitan Museum of Art . The art works set within this beautiful house make for a memorable experience. The short film giving some background to the original owner Henry Clay Frick is well worth seeing.

Stories behind the collection are the draw. Henry Clay Frick's life, rise to incredible wealth and compulsive and quirky in its own way collection are the draw of this masters painting, drawing, ceramics furniture and sculpture museum in the former Frick Mansion. Over the top in turn of the century dollars, the works amassed by this entrepreneur and Carnegie cohort speak to Frick's ( I like what I like..and only two American artista made the grade) are truly unique in their individual and collective stories. even though some audio tours can be a bother, this one is not to be missed for its background stories...the mistress/wife witth the wandering eye, Frick's fascination with portraits of women ( an entire gallery room-full), his delight in purchasing companion pieces and reuniting sets) and nary a mention of his wife ( It's all about him. fascinating) But he did "allow" his wife to live on in the home for over a decade after his death, thanks hon. all the while preparing this home to live on as a museum.. With many $$$ left to accomplish just that) The setting is impeccible and lovely, and wished we could have spent more time. couple of tips: Room monitors are certainly " masters of their domain" and actually made me a bit nervous every time I leaned in to take a closer look. there are no barriers, and per the museum this is meant to make for a relaxed atmosphere, but there are definitely invisible borders that each rotating personnel in the room apparently decide. might be better just to have a rail to make the lines definite. Have been in other museums , i.e. the Getty, and they are much less jumpy there. also make note that the gift shop closes about 20 minutes before the museum closes ( and nary a announcement or posting re this fact as you enter) When I missed out on the opportunity to spend my money, and inquired about the closure, was told that the posting is INSIDE the gift shop.

Fabulous surprise.. This museum is not as heavily marketed as the Met, MOMA, or Guggenheim but it is just as fabulous. This collection is housed in a home (mansion) and holds artwork by some of the greatest European artists known. The Library is amazing. There is a huge collection of original works by many of the most well known authors ever. I noticed many people looked at the art on the walls and then moved on without noticing the books. Take the time to browse the shelves.It is worth it!

Fabulous Collection. This is definitely a must see museum in NYC. Lovely building and great collection. It is convenient to walk from Central Park to tour the Frick and continue exploring the upper east side.
Small. It is a small museum with out that much to see. It's not bad per se, just completely not worth the price given how little there is to see.

For Quiet Reflection. If you love museums, as I do, you will certainly enjoy the relaxed and peaceful aura of this small museum. I especially enjoyed the collection of paintings, such as the oil on canvas and the sculptures. Dress is casual and you can spend all the time you want just browsing.
museum must do. best museum to visit when you are only a few days in NY. A collection of Art to live with instead of the ordinary collections of musea.

a jewel not to be missed. You can get engulfed at the Met, but the art shines at the Frick. Where else can you experience the grandeur of a 20C mansion on 5th avenue replete with stellar works of art. Three Vermeers!
Loved it. Nice small size museum. You can take it in without feeling overwhelmed. Fun to imagine a family actually living in that house at one time.
Frick. Must see when it opens at 10am. Delightful personal collection of art, most purchased by Mr. Frick or his daughter.
current exhibit. Loved the drawings in the current show. The Frick is a beautiful little museum, easy to fit it into a busy day of sightseeing.

beautiful interiors, small but exclusive collection of art work. Unlike the mammoth Metroplitan museum of New York, a visit of Frick collection museum can be completed in 2hrs. The museum is housed in a mansion with lavishly decorated interiors. I love the hall with frescos illustrating the stages of courtship done in French Louis V style. There is also a hall featuring cherubs engaged in hobbies & adult occupations--very cute! Pls remember to use the audioguide. The augioguide provides info on the exhibits!If you arrange a visit to the museum between 11am to 1pm on Sundays, you can pay as you want & save on admission fee. Be ready for a queue though!
Best Art Museum in NYC. Beautiful setting, Great Art ... it was my favorite ...when I lived I lived Manhattan...Should plan a return visit soon.

A fine collection of European paintings and sculpture.. A relatively small collection (by museum standards) but quite exquisite. It features, among others, large paintings by J. M. W. Turner, a portrait of Sir Thomas Moore by Hans Holbein and an elegant sculpture of Diana the Huntress. It is set in a former residence, on the corner of 5th and East 70th, and was carefully put together by art connoisseur and then industrialist Henry Clay Frick. The residence and the indoor garden are beautifully kept and the portico gallery appears particularly radiant. I've been hearing about this collection for years so as soon as I had the opportunity to visit I did and enjoyed it immensely.
A small museum. The Frick collection is easily accessible and is a terrific example of one man's dedication to collecting a good array of material
A Gem. It is a different experience then the larger museums. The home itself is a beautiful historical site.
not a must see. when we visited there we were impressed by the story and the building,but not from the art.not a must see one.
Amazing Museum. The Frick is a must see. The house is amazing and the collections of art diverse. It is small enough to do in an hour, or two is you like to linger.

Absolutely stunning. I was stunned by the collection. There are multiple pictures from each Rembrant, Hals, Turner, Gainsborough, Reynolds, Velazquez, Goya, Monet, Whistler all under one roof. There is a sitting room with a El Greco over the fireplace and on each side there are the Holbein portrains of Moore and Cromwell facing each other. If you go to no other art museum in New York, go here.

The Frick on a Sunday morning!. One of the most beautiful places in NYC and on a Sunday between 11-1 it is "pay what you wish". We really enjoyed this lovely collection, and just sitting in the main hall was so peaceful and lovely. A must do on any trip to NYC

Frick = art & history. Words can't describe 100% Frick experience.. you can feel the house and Frick's familly history and live the story of new york in the '30'syou can admire paintings and the house itself.they also play a 10 minutes presentation of the collection and you also receive a free audio guide ( or let's say included in the entrance fee) you can't take pictures anywhere inside... that is the only minus.

WOW! Rudest Staff EVER!!!. My wife and I are on a global treasure hunt to see all of Vermeer's canvases, so we certainly have been to a gallery or two -- house museums, palace museums, huge masterpiece warehouses, etc. Never has a gallery's staff been so rude to my wife! Trying to get a better look at the master's usage of light, my wife drifted into what the guard considered the "danger zone" and he responded by, without warning, BODILY MOVING MY WIFE BACK! Realy? Perhaps you could say something before laying your hands on her. Needless to say, she rightly reacted as Charlton Heston did in Planet of the Apes and was in such a snit we decided to cut short our visit. Again, in all the galleries in all the world, this was the singular worst viewing experience we ever endured. Perhaps they should visit London's Kenwood House for some pointers on how to run a mansion / museum! It doesn't have to be this way.

Best Museum in the City. Don't miss this one. Small easy to see- it -all in a couple hours. Great audio tour (free) to carry and click on any room or art piece for detailed information. Peaceful, tranquil center fountain with benches to take a break and rest your tired feet. Free entrance on Sundays from 11-2

Pleasant Sunday morning spent at the Frick. Went to the Frick at 11am Sunday as it is pay want you want morning. Had a short queue which moved fairly quickly. Had a great time exploring the first floor of the house. Not allowed up the stair case! The architecture of the house is outstanding. The collection of art is amazing.

Superb !!!. I would say that visiting the Frick Museum would be a highlight of most everyone's vist to NYC. The magnificent paintings are by Renoir, Boucher, Whistler, Bellini, Van Dyck, Vermeer, Gainsborough, Rembrandt, Fragonard, Goya and Degas, to name a few. There are also sculptures and enamels. The building which was Mr. and Mrs. Frick's mansion is absolutely gorgeous. An audio guide is included with the admission fee. This museum is a must see!!!
great collection. Fabulous collection and just the right size too see it all. There was also a special exit from London which we enjoyed and didn't pay extra to see.

Fabulous. This is an absoloutly stunning collection in a fabulous house, it seems almost impossible to imagine that one man could be so wealthy that he could own all this wonderful art. It also seems almost wrong that most of this art comes from Europe and isnt American at all but having said that it was a very enjoyable afternoon.

Fantastic. It was surreal to see all these famous paintings away from their country of origin. I found it amazing to imagine people who had such wealth to be able to afford to live in this amazing house with all this wonderful art.

Beautiful Artwork. I have been to the Frick Collection 4 or 5 times during my life, both as a child and as an adult. I just love the artwork and the paintings. It is located near Central Park, so if you are planning to visit Central Park, or other mus eums nearby, it is convenient. It is not cheap, and children under ten are not admitted, unfortunately. But if you are an adult or teenager, you will probably love this museum! I was born and raised in the NYC area--Queens, Brooklyn, and Staten Island. I am no longer living in New York. I miss the culture, and museums.

Biggest bang for the buck and the mileage. If you want the Renaissance and Reformation's greatest hits, skit the Metropolitan Museum and come here, where a compact selection of the Very Best in painting is always on view.

A Jewel on Manhattan's Museum Mile. Manhattan's "museum mile" on upper Fifth Avenue is an art lovers paradise, what with the Metroppolitan Museum of Art, the incredible Guggenheim, the Cooper Hewitt, the Jewish Museum, and the Neue Galerie. But a real jewel is the Frick Collection with its rich treasures housed in the mansion built by steel magnate Henry Clay Frick. Small but imposing, the building contains works by Titian, Tintoretto, Bellini, Renoir, Degas and many more, all carefully chosen by Mr. Frick himself. Downstairs there is always a wonderful changing special exhibition. This is one of the special spaces in Manhattan and a must-see for anyone interested in art.
Silver Travelers. A gem. A small museum, with a great collection. Boucher, Fragonard, Whistler, Renoir to name but a few. Beautiful old building houses this lovely collection.
A surprising collection. We were very impressed by the range of masterpieces on display. The house itself is stunning and the garden areas are inspiring. A great experience.
Must Do. Two visits to the Met, one to MOMA, Nishi, - all of course a must do, and the highlight was The Frick.
A wonderful collection. Don't miss this important iconic museum with a magnificent collection.The paintings are brilliant and the building has a great deal of charm.
Great museum. Love the Frick, it is a small museum and you are actually enjoying the house and collection of art work together.

A perfect gallery. In a city of museums & galleries, the Frick is an essential experience for the real art lover - and even more for the art tyro. It's small, accessible and so easy to appreciate in one visit... and then it compels you to visit again because it just seems to draw you back.

A fair option when you don't have the time for a larger museum. My mother and I visited the Frick Collection this past weekend and were pleased with the variety of art that we viewed. The collection contains pieces from a broad range of time periods and spans a decent range of subject matter as well. The building itself is very beautiful and can be explored in a fairly short amount of time, which was all that we had. I'm glad that I experienced it, but probably won't return in the future.

What a jewel!. Thank you Mr Frick, it was a delight to be able to see such beautiful art in situ where it was meant to be seen rather than in a museum like setting. I loved the Fragonard room! Don't miss the short video presentation on how the collection came to be, see it first if you can for a better understanding of the concept.
A great little museum. It's always a pleasure to go to the Frick. It's got a lot to offer without being as overwhelming at the Met.
OMG what a treasure!. I loved everything about this museum! There we no crowds, and the setting and paintings were awesome, especially the Vermeers!

Worth a visit!. As a Brit who has visited NYC twelve times in the last 12 years, I visited this art collection for the first time in 2009. I did thoroughly enjoy the art and the building however if you are visiting NYC for a short time I would invest the time in visiting the cloisters. But it is definitely worth visiting if you are staying in the city for a longer period.
Wonderful Gallery!. If you have a limited time to see some world-class art, recommend the Frick Collection. The displays are arranged superbly and we got to see some very famous art collections.

Beauty on Fifth. See how a robber baron lived! Gorgeous art collection in delightful space. Don't miss the conservatory...some plant room! Feeds one's fantasies of appreciating beauty as the very rich once did. And, in Spring, you'll be "hysteria" for the wysteria!

A peaceful haven. and a bite sized chunk of culture for those that don't want to spend hours and hours tramping round a museum. The staff however are stiff and unhelpful - I've been 4 times in 5 years and each time they give off this attitude of 'we know you are here to do us harm and vandalise our precious objects'. I'm sure there are nut-jobs out there with that on their agenda - but 99.9% of people who bother to spend the time in museums like the Frick, who are prepared to pay the entrance fee are there to respect and enjoy the art. So a little welcoming smile would be much appreciated. (Please bear in mind that my comments are currently flavoured by jet lag)
Wonderful. The Frick has a wonderful collection of art. The house is great example of city life in the early 1900's. Very pleasant
marvellous. a beautiful building which contains a fantatastic collection of paintings and sculptures.. it is set out in a "home"setting rather than a museum as the national trust does in the uk

Major Phianthropist. I had no idea that there were wealthy people that would like to share with the likes of a middle class person like me. However, was I ever proven incorrect. The house and collection are magnificent. What a treat and pleasure that this is available for viewing. Truly grateful that this is here to experience and share. All the knocks against the wealthy are definitely sour grapes after being able to visit this exxquisite place. So glad that the family is willing to give back and share.Went on Sunday AM for reduced admission and am grateful that this option is available. Very generous of the foundation.Saw beautiful works of art by the masters as well as a grand look at the life of one of the true builders of what we know of today as one of the greatest societies to date. Thank |You. A great example of what a great dream and determination can accomplish.

Enjoyed this museum.. A nice little find.Loved the building and enjoyed seeing the sketches the best. There were sketches from a lot of the famous artists like Van Gogh and LaTrec. The grounds were pretty as well.

Easy to enjoy. The Frick Collection is amazing. If you are on museum mile it is a must. It does not draw the crowds that MET, MOMA or Guggenheim do and that is the best thing about it. You can wonder quietly around the Frick mansion to appreciate the once private collection.
Frick Gallery. Loved the beautiful old home used for displayed the magnificent art collection.The period furniture was exceptional.

Outstanding collection. This is a fabulous collection of classical art assembled by a wealthy family. The building used to be their home, it's amazing. It's also doable in one day, so you can in fact see every room in the museum in one visit.

A wonderful small gallery. The Frick is a New York treasure, housing a small collection of high quality works by European artists. We concentrated on the paintings, but there are also bronzes and other works of art. The painting collection focusses on portraits, and includes a number of pairs of portraits of subjects who had interesting connections (e.g. Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell). Audio guides are included, and the absence of obtrusive tour guides is much appreciated. Every art lover should visit the Frick.
Favorite museum in town!. Being a small museum makes your visit more enjoyable! There are so many artists exhibited in one place. The house itself is interesting as well. Close to other museums too.

Definitely worth a detour for. the Frick Collection was recommended to me and was definitely worth a visit. Situated in what was a private house, there is an amazing range of artwork on display from da Vinci to Renoir and everything in between. There is currently also a temporary exhibition of drawings and sketches which I found very interesting. The setting adds to the visit and there is a particularly lovely courtyard with a fountain which is a bit if an oasis.
Wonderful museum. Lovely small museum on the Upper East Side. Not a huge crowd like the MET but very beautiful. A great escape

Thanks for the Pinkertons. Went on a Sunday morning; it's free 11-1, and therefore, packed. Small but very interesting collection. Beautiful structure. All this beauty and all it cost was a few broken heads in Pittsburgh in 1892. Long live the rich!

Great selection of masterpieces. High quality collection compared to some other small museums that we have visited. Sometimes it's difficult to take your eyes off the collection to study the lovely building. Both are a thrill.
Wonderful on every level. The museum itself shows what the homes of the industrial millionaires were like. The collection is small but everything in it is wonderful.

Love it!!!. Its an amazing experience to visit a Museum where the art pieces are on the same place as it used to be when it was a house!!! Beautiful collection and very well displayed....The house is impressive....

Frick Collection. The setting in a grand old mansion designed as a museum gives you a very personal relationship to the art and enables you to really appreciate it without the masses in a large commercial museum

Reminds me of my own home in Bondi !. Its small enough to do in one hour. The rooms and presentation are first class.House You cannot take photos of anu of the work but the art here is 1st class.
Rembrants, Turner, Picasso,etc.
You wonder where all of Europe's gems ended !!

Off the beaten path. Lovely house and spectacular collection of european art. I loved the Turners, Constables, Gainsboroughs and more, there are also Renoirs, Goya and El Greco and many more. Sculptures, enamels, china, and so much more, all in all a place worth visiting.
Lovely Escape. This is a lovely museum to get away from it all. A real gem. Rest a bit in the enclosed atrium. Best Vermeer.

OUR SECOND VISIT. This was our second visit to the Frick. We originally went 4 years ago. What an amazing collection of paintings, furniture, and china. the house itself is stunning and was purpose built by Frick to showcase his artwork etc. So much more intimate than a museum, it is a joy to spend a few hours wandering through the rooms. The highlights for me are the two Holbein portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell. But there are so many fabulous paintings it is hard to choose a favourite. If we are lucky enough to return to New York again, I think we would probably return for a third visit. That is the highest praise I could give it.
Secret remarkable collection.. The Frick is an absolute “must-see” when in New York. It seems to be a little-known museum but the house and remarkable collection are marvelous and should be seen.

Great Collection. My husband wanted to see this, I really didn't want to go. But we both loved it. First the Frick collection itself is impressive, art, sculpture, books. But what we enjoyed even more was the mansion. The house that Frick built is beyond impressive. He built it to impress and it does. The people I tell about this have never even heard of it. If you have more than a few days in NYC definitely visit the Frick Collection

Plan on taking your time. This collection is wonder and very diverse. Everything from portraits to pieces of furniture. We went on a Sunday when you can pay what you want, so it was crowded! We also made the mistake of only allowing 1 1/2 hours to see everything, but it would have been nice to have twice that amount of time.
Wonderful collection. Beautifully displayed and an impressive collection. Fewer crowds than other museums. Well worth it. On Sundays you can donate whatever you want - great deal!

Amazilng. Was not sure what we would see but was well worth the visit. The interiors of the house were sumptuous but not over the top and the art collection was interesting. Make sure you see the 'copy and the original' in the room before the dining room.

A great museum that most tourists miss. What an amazing collection and it isn't crowded. You can get up close to many great works of are in an amazing mansion. If daddy Warbucks was real he would have had a place like this.Compared to crowds at MOMA and the Met the Frick is a joy.

Pretty and underrated. The Frick collection is a very nice museum, that unfortunately doesn't get a lot of attention due to so many other Museums in Manhattan. It's a beautiful interior and some famous artwork, with audio tours and a large mansion to wander about. It's an enjoyable experience for a Saturday, if you've already tried the other museums in NYC.

Unforgettable experience.. This is an amazing place. From the architecture of the building to the layout of the rooms with the beautiful furnishings and of course the breathtaking collection of art. We stopped in for a few hours on a rainy day and were so happy we did. If you appreciate art and beautiful things you should stop here if you have time.

Restrained and beautiful. This is a gem in the heart of NYC. The size, quality and restraint of the gallery is most pleasing. The guides are excellent, the shop small and filled with quality. No glitz here - just a fine art experiencehere. I will go again. Also it reminds me of the Wallace Collection in London with its scale.

beautiful architecture with incredible art. The entire building and collection can be seen in about 1.5 hours. Perfect after a Sunday brunch or walk in Central Park. The art was a complete surprise as well as the history of the man and collection. Well worth the visit.

a really really fine museum. not only is the place magic but it has the ability to delivery the finest quality of art there is. I suggest to visit in the afternoon when the light creates depth with the west wing.
Fantastic property. Beautiful surroundings, lots of paintings. Interesting story behind the collection. Gift shop but no coffee bar which we would have used as our feet were rather aching!

Not only for the Well-Heeled. The Frick Collection is unique. Well, all collections are - of course - but this was the gift of one man: William Clay FRICK (1849-1919) - immensely wealthy from coking coal out of Pittsburgh/a sometime partner of Andrew CARNEGIE - and a collector of art - furniture - porcelain - statuary - almost exclusively from Europe and from Far East Asia. It is reasonably priced ($18) for adults (no child under 10 permitted - because it is arranged without barriers - as it was when FRICK lived here) - but for those for whom that sum is too much there is an out! Those who enter between 11.00 am and 1.00 pm on Sundays may pay what they wish - I guess some pay only a dollar. My wife and I are doing our best to see as much of this great city as we can - we have some indulgences - but otherwise a strict budget - and so we took advantage of this consideration to proffer a mere $5 each to-day. So thank-you Mr FRICK - for your aesthetic sensibilities and for understanding that though we may not all have the wherewithal it does not preclude our own desire to see and appreciate the beautiful objets d'art which you gathered together. And thank you, too, to the foundation which manages your gift! By the way - though the line waiting from before 11.00 am may seem lengthy - it moves swiftly - 20 or so entering at time - depositing bulky backpacks - and paying - and picking up complimentary audio-phones - without a continual press of crowds from behind. Considerate. And the lines move quickly - you will find.

One man's vision inspires a national treasure. I am not one for mindless wandering in some museum that I know nothing about. This museum opposite Central Park changed my view. It was inspiring. So visionary, so very special and such an amazing way to see great artworks presented so brilliantly. My tip: put aside a couple of hours in NewYork to absorb the experience of a lifetime. It is not the Louvre, not the National Gallery in London, nor any other great place but it is unique and worth the visit.

Beautiful architecture, outstanding art. This former home is worth the wait to get in at holiday time. The art is lovingly displayed; fountains and gardens graciously situated. It is a little gem not to be missed.

Wonderful collection. We are not big museum buffs, but the Frick Collection was fantastic. It's a diverse collection with works of many of the great masters. It's also small enough that you can listen to the audio tour for each piece, see the entire collection, and still be done in a reasonable amount of time. Highly recommend!

An amazing collection well worth a visit. I read about their "Pay What You Want" special on Sunday mornings and leapt out of bed to make my way there. I would easily have paid full price for this museum. Having its roots in a private collection, it is not as extensive as some other museums. But it more than makes up for it in the quality of the art and the museum itself, firmly the home of the collector, Mr. Henry Clay Frick.Despite the special rate, the museum was not overly crowded and I really felt comfortable lingering over some of my favorite pieces (Holbein's Thomas More, e.g.). There are no explanatory plaques, so the audio guide is a must. However, it covers many (most?) of the pieces and adds a lot of commentary about the mansion as well. Despite the relatively small size, plan to spend at least 2 to 3 hours there.

ONE OF THE BEST IN NEW YORK. I always go to the Frick when I'm in NY. It is the former residence of the Frick family. This small elegant museum has the most beautiful and arresting art around. Since it's small, it's easy to navigate and one doesn't feel that they have to rush through in order to see everything. There are cozy areas to sit and headphone s for your convenience. Check hours before you go.
nothing like it. Mr. Frick sure knew how to live........and his Rembrants are the best........when I was in Law School, I read my torts book there and got up to look at "my pictures" more than I read

Small treasure of a museum.. The Frick Collection is a private house and is the former home of Henry Clay Frick, it was was designed by Thomas Hastings and constructed in 1913-1914. It is located at 1 East 70th Street, and what a home it is. It's a treasure trove of art and antique furniture, there are Whistler paintings and special exhibits that occur all the time. It's a bit of a walk from the Metropolitan Museum of Art but if your adventurous and don't mind a bit of a walk pay a visit, you will not be disappointed.

The best little museum anywhere. Don't miss the Frick. The art collection is fabulous - especially if you love the old masters - Goya, Rembrant, Turner, Reynolds, etc. And take time to enjoy the museum itself. The building is a treasure as well as the colllection. It is quiet and never seems crowded - no children under the age of 10 are allowed. A very special place right there on 5th Ave. and 70th street. Don't miss it.

Art in a mansion. The museum is one of the better ones I have been to. Its not too big and overwhelming. 2 - 3 hours in here are well rewarded for the quality of the art on display. You also get a feel of how a rich industrialist would have lived at the beginning of the 20th century.

Frick Collection. Frick's daughter said he collected art that he could live with. All the paintings are beautiful and pleasant to look at - a wide variety of styles and ages. The paintings are displayed in Frick's own home the way he hung them. The home itself is beautiful.

A wonderful gem!. A wonderful must-see in NYC. Beautiful worldclass artworks and furniture. The audiotour is very interesting and explain both artworks and brings you the feeling of the mansion. Fantastic book collection. Beautiful courtyard. Attentive helpful staff, a docent offered further explanations of an artwork upon request, a very nice gesture. Well worth the admission fee.

I loved the Frick. The collection itself does not have the daunting proportions of some of the larger galleries. What was there was all really great - with umpteen old masters sat side by side. The setting itself is wonderful with much of it looking as it did when the Frick family lived there in the early part of the twentieth century.

Small but worthwhile. Located in a nice building, the former Frick residence, this museum houses a nice collection. Easy to combine with the Guggenheim and other museums close by. We combined it with the Met as well, but that's really too much for a single day.
Not to be missed. More great masters beautifully displayed in the old Frick Mansion. If you like fine art this is a MUST.

Must go back!. I would have loved more time here to take in all the beautiful art, furniture and sculptures. There is also a lovely courtyard to rest in and soak up the peaceful atmosphere. A fascinating place to visit.
Wonderful surprise.. We heard about it from a friend and were really impressed with the amount of important art pieces and the Frick Mansion itself.

One of my favorite NY museums. I recently visited the Frick Collection for my third or fourth time. I see something new with each visit and am reminded of what an extraordinary art exhibit it is. The speaker phones with a description of the works of arts is offered at no additional cost. The gift shop is small but contains some very nice items

Just OK. Come here if you have already hit MoMA, The Met, Guggenheim and Museum of Natural History and you still need more museum. It is expensive, small and the staff is on you. I was called out twice because I was too close to a picture and I had my phone out. It is $18 to enter. We only spent about 30 minutes there is not much to see.
Fantastic Frick. Wonderful house and superb art collection, beautifully maintained. Its on the way to the Met so two visits can be combined in one day.

What a life!. The museum is the former home of a tycoon. You can just see the owners enjoying their collection of art. It is also quite easy to imagine the life in these rooms. The exhibits, both the permanent and special, are very good to excellent. It is wonderful way to spend an afternoon.
