Fabulous. Everything. Well layed out. So much to see. There was nothing to dislike about this experience. Fabulous displays
A Gem!. We always make a Haj to the Frick every time we are in NYC. You are sure to find something in the collection that will take your breath away and stop time for you.

Interesting art collection, uptight staff. It would be an interesting art collection to view, but our experience was tainted by the uptight and rude staff. We visited during the "pay as you wish" hours on a Sunday, they lady at the desk was not very discreet and was suggesting to people who didn't want to pay full price to pay at least dollar for admission and we could hear this clearly further down the queue. We did pay what we wished and set off to tour the collection. Next came the "free"audio guide which I nearly missed as the man was announcing something you paid for at that desk. So we set off with our audio guide, after the first room we were behind an old lady that put her hand on a piece of marble furniture in a hallway as she walked by, a member of staff spoke to her in a rude fashion about this. In the next room a teenager was texting, again another staff member was rude to them about it. I can understand why they felt they had to address these things, but there are ways of doing this kindly. All these staff episodes tainted our visit to view the collection. The staff overall seemed uptight, it must be how they are expected to work.Glad I had not payed the full admission price for this.
Usually missed. reaaly good collection, in my first visit to NY i didnt go because you usually go first to moma and gughengheim but you this beautiful mansion has amazing paintings.
Wonderful art exhibit. What a wonderful exhibit. A broad collection of Artists in a beautiful setting. What an awesome way to share a grand fortune with the public.

Our Favorite NYC Museum. The art in this museum is absolutely wonderful. Several paintings that are considered to be the top masterpieces in the world are here. The museum is quite. The staff are helpful and polite.

Don't Miss Frick. The Frick Collection is amazing and the setting in the mansion is just out of this world. We toured it on a Sunday and between 11:00 and 1:00 p.m. it is pay what you can give or free. What a deal especially in a city of wealth and prosperity. The area around the mansion is not as busy as the main thoroughfares in NY, and you can stroll around the area stopping to have a coffee in open front cafes. The art collection is wonderful and includes a number of Whistlers art.Don't miss it.
worth a visit. If possible, go and visit it. It is a good sample of a rich people's private house of older days. We learned thus on the people and could watch some art.

Very nice paintings. The best Museum we have visited in New York. Must-go museum and its quieter next to the park. They have a varieties of painitngs from different centuries, worth at least a 3 hours visit.

awesome. Really beautiful museum, with amazing 3 Vermeer. Also Monet, Degas, Rembrandt... all of this in a very peacefull place. They do not admitt children under 10, which makes the place much quieter. Nice staff, no waiting lines.

An absolute MUST. I visited the Frick Collection for the first time yesterday and know that I shall make it a point to return every time I go to New York. Much less overwhelming than a 'real' museum, this place nevertheless has breathtaking art pieces. A real treat.

avoid the MOMA crowds. Intimate experience seeing a 5th avenue mansion with such an extensive art collection. History of the steel magnate family and how this collection has evolved and is evolving still today.
Loved it.
a little gem. We visited the Frick Collection on a rainy spring day -- what a little jewel! Intimate and beautiful and interesting to see how this crazy rich man lived.

Small enough to not be exhausted. Amazing collection for a private collector. Setting was wonderful as it was not too big to have culture saturation. It was sufficient for each piece to have your attention. The 'wardens' could learn to be a bit more polite though. Incredibly rude and abrupt!

A little bit of Europe in NYC. The Frick Collection on 5th ave. in NYC is like taking a two hour break in Europe. The mansion itself is more like Italy than America and the walls are studded with some of the most significant examples of the masters you can find anywhere. The very best Vermeers, Rembrandts, Holbeins, Goyas, Bellinis, Turners and many more are all there in this intimate and accessible setting. This is a unique chance to be fully engaged with the greatest artists in the world without being overwhelmed. The docents are wonderful so find a tour if your schedule allows.
frick-one of my favorite museums in NY. it is a beautiful, small and intimate museum with a beautiful fountain that's perfect for reading, reflection and relaxation
Great House and wonderful Art. Loved the building itself and the art that was hung was stunnig. Definatley try and get yourself to one of the daily free tours. We learnt a lot for the main chap.

Even my husband...who is not an art junkie, enjoyed The Frick Collection!. A glimpse inside the life of the rich and famous early in the 20th century. A beautiful collection of art and a stunning setting. Very good guides, or take your own tour with the free and easy to use headsets.

Don't pass this one by. Last month in New York for 6 days.someone mentioned the Frick Collection, this was a fantastic experience. If you love art and antiques collected with passion this is for you. Set in gorgeous setting opposite Central Park. entrance fees I think 8 or 9 euros? All set up in beautiful rooms you can wander from room to room and amazing garden conservatory . this blew my mind how one man has such a unique collection, and we now can all enjoy. Great gift shop, very friendly staff. Great afternoon out. Check opening times
Frick. A very different kind of art gallery, it was easy to imagine the Frick family at home with their treasures.

Elegant but not Stuffy. One of my favorite places. Go there when you are sick of all other museums. Even on a crowded day, it exudes calm. Not a good place for little kids. It's an old Upper East Side mansion on the edge of Central Park with a stellar collection of great masterpieces and a fresh eye for new work too too, especially large-scale stuff. The new exhibits are on the upper floors and there is elevator access. Always memorable.

World class collection. We visited early September 2012. The quality of the experience is due to a combination of an excellent taste in the choices of the artworks by the collector, a perfectly designed building with artwork fitting perfectly the rooms, and ... no crowds. Obviously those who want to see contemporary art should abstain.

Not to be missed. An impressive collection of paintings and bronze statues including a Goya painting that defined the start of the Realism era. Also you get to see the inside of a 5th Ave. mansion and a glimpse of how the very well to do families lived at the turn of the 20th century.

Simply the best museum in America. Greatest Renaissance art in any single place. And what a palace it is. No museum experience in the US prepares you for this splendid mansion with the most exquisite art and furnishings.

My favorite museum in New York City!. I have been going here for years, and it remains my favorite museum in the city. An absolute jewel, filled with some of the most spectacular art you will ever see. Can be done in an afternoon, and not overwhelming like the big museums. Absolutely wonderful and very highly recommended.
Fascinating colection. Wonderfull setting in the Frick mansion and an incredible collection to view. Very mangeable to enjoy the entire collection in a morning.

Definitely worth visiting. I have been coming to the UES to visit family for 15 years and finally went to see the Frick. What a great museum! Beautiful paintings set in a unique environment, what used to be a private home. You will not be disappointed, even in a city like NY with all its major museums. Lovely gift shop as well.

Top-shelf paintings - all in one amazing house!. There are some amazing paintings here and they are all lit and presented superbly in perfect period rooms that are spotless. We wished we could have toured the gardens and also wished there were more seating opportunities, especially near the larger paintings. Also, photography was not allowed and that damped some of the enjoyment. But their book store is excellent so that makes up for it.
I go often, lovely and small enough to enjoy in a few hours. My favorite NYC museum. Small enough to see it all in a few hours, across from Central Park, and a short walk to 5th Ave. sites.

Astonishing, amazing, breathtaking. It's easy to forget the Frick Collection as you are wandering at the Museum Mile in NY. Okay, there is Guggenheim Museum and The Metropolitan so close, and they are so famous! But there is a beautiful manor house on a corner, with a small and sober garden facing 5th Avenue, that is a real precious gem. It was the residence of an art aficionado man, a really connoisseur. The Frick Collection is to feel a little bit of the ancient NYC charm, peacefully walking around the art collection as if you were at an elegant friend's home. Breathtaking! Don't miss!
A little jewel box in the City. The Frick Collection is a must-see for art or architecture lovers. The building is exquisite, and the collection is astounding. It's a very pleasant respite.

Wonderful way to spend a few hours. Had never heard of this place before I saw the Trip Advisor recommendation, but was glad I did. It's superb, the collection is incredible, particularly for fans of European artists (there are only 2 US painters included), and the setting is prefect; intimate and beautifully laid out. The inner courtyard feels like the perfect place to bring a book and spend an afternoon. A real gem in the city.
Worth a visit. Chance to see private art collection that will never be shown outside of this museum. Collection has a large collection of "old masters" and the Frick private home is interesting.

Wonderful gem. Most people don't put the Frick on their radar and they should. Wonderfully curated art and masterful architecture. I spent 4 hours there which is way more than I expected given the size.They include the information headset rather than stiff you an extra few bucks. This made it even more worthwhile. I would be nice to have more rich editorial on the painter vs. the subject but regardless, it enhanced the experience immensely.

Worth a Visit. The residence was built in 1913 and houses a vast collection of American and European art Mr. Frick collected over 40 years, plus pieces added since his death. Much porcelain and decorative art is also exhibited. Well worth a visit!
Good Place...!!!!!. Excellent place for visit and i also sent some time on those place.....!!! I enjoyed with my friends on Frick Collection....!!!!!
Great Museum!. Many wonderful paintings to view and interesting setting of New York City mansion. Lecture series and gift shop.

Incredible. The best summary to the Frick Collection is actually made in the audioguide, in a commentary to one of the masterpieces there: "You have probably seen this painting so many times you start wondering if this can be the real thing. It IS the real thing!" The collection does not take up too much space, but it's packed with masterpieces - you name the painetr, he's there. And these are not the less-known paintings you get to see, but the best-known ones. It won't take you longer than two-three hours to see the whole thing. If you're into paintings - a must-see.

So glad to finally visit!. When the large Renoirs were on exhibit earlier this year, I finally made my way to the Frick. What a delight! Of course I enjoyed the Renoirs, but the collection there and the building itself were so fabulous! It had a very different feel from other museums. It had been the Fricks' home and I really felt as if I were a visitor to a home. Go and enjoy it!

Manhattan Highlight. Was in NY on a short business trip with only 4 free hours so chose to use them for a first time visit to the Frick. For anyone who enjoys art or architecture and has limited time, the Frick is an excellent option. In about two hours of wandering leisurely with the audio guide, we decided that this may be one of the most expansive but approachable collections we've encountered. The collection is filled with masterworks of Europe with a modest number of Impressionist works collected toward the end of Mr Frick's life. In particular, the Vemeers are stunning and the Whistlers allowed us to appreciate his work more fully. While the infamous robber baron Henry Clay Frick did not have many admirable qualities by our 21st century sensibilities, we all benefit that he bequeathed this amazing house and the collection for the public benefit. We plan to return on a future trip and recommend it to those who have only limited time to devote to art.
Fine art, fine mansion. A real treasure of New York, indeed. Plenty of old masters, impressionists, and more. Doesn't feel crammed with photo-op tourists either.

Wonderful art collection in a wonderful building. We never get tired from visiting the Frick Collection. Beautiful art housed in a beautiful building. Greco, Rembrandt, Goya, Vermeer, frank Hals, Turner, the list is almost endless. The museum is small enough to be able to enjoy each piece. The accompanying (free) audio adds a great deal to the enjoyment of the visit

Stunning European Art. After the Metropolitan Museum, this may be the next best collection to see. Focusing on European art of all types, this is a place to lose yourself in the world of fine creations without the massive crowds of the Met.
Beyond Belief!. This is an absolute must for any art lover in New York. It is hard to imagine how an individual could have put together such a large collection of art from great masters.
The collection to see. Take the time to visit the Frick!It's quite fast to visit and it's surely one of the best collection of art in NYC!

An amazing collection and a spectacular building.. This Collection has been maintained extremely well over the years. The atrium area provides a peaceful moment or two (or more) in between viewing the wonderful works of art and furniture.

Simply Beautiful.... It was a rainy day in Manhattan, so I went for a walk down Fifth Avenue with full intention to spend some time in the Frick Museum, not really knowing what to expect.I loved every inch of this museum, from the superb collection of art, the gorgeous outdoor gardens to the indoor atrium. I could imagine a setting for a glorious wedding. So intimate and personable. I could have stayed for hours at a very relaxed pace.

Absolutely Stunning. After spending more than half a day in the Metropolitan Museum of Art my son and I decided to give the Frick Collection a look. We were very glad we did. Just a short walk south of the Met on the other side of 5th you'll find a mansion built by a 'robber baron' in the early 1900's. In that mansion he and his descendants and trustees have amassed the most magnificent private collection of art that I've seen. Give yourself at least 2 hours to wander through this magnificent house and see all the masterpieces. There are works by Bellini, Tiepolo, Rembrandt, Whistler, Turner, Constable, Gainsborough, Lippi, Titian, Veronese, Holbein, Vermeer, El Greco, Manet, Renoir, Degas, etc. The admission fee is reasonable with a student rate available. Included in the fee is a handy and easy to use audio guide. This is truly a spectacular collection. Only downside - no photos.
Great on Sundays!. Great place to visit on a Sunday when the entrance fee is by donation from 11-1. Make sure to watch the video about the history of how the Frick Collection came to be.

a must visit if you are in NYC area.... it is a great museum with a lot of history. it has paintings dating back the 16th century from Henry VIII's court, a beautiful house in itself.. tickets are $18 for adults but if you go on Sundays between 11am - 1pm, it is pay as you wish. Also, make sure you watch the 30 minutes video about the Mr. Frick, his beautiful mansion and his art collection... It is a must visit if you are in NYC, a MUST!!!

Excellent art on a human scale. Some people would like the decorative art and the porcelain collection, some others, the feeling of visiting a private house (albeit on a grand scale) rather than a huge palace like the Louvre or the Hermitage. The main collection of paintings covers many eras and styles and has the benefit of allowing one to spend more time with each picture than in a larger museum where it is natural to want to see more and to move faster.A great place.

Don't miss this exquisite museum. Having failed to visit on our first trip to NY (check the opening times), this was top of our list to visit the second time around. And we were very glad we did. The Frick Collection is housed in a beautiful town house right near the Met and contains a most interesting and slightly quirky collection. We were surprised to see the number of English paintings, for starters. The building is amazing and the inner courtyard is a delightfully tranquil place for contemplation. Definitely get the audio tour. They insisted I checked my bag in to their cloakroom so be ready for this if you usually carry a pricey camera.

Rich Collection. The Frick Collection is located at 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan. New York. This art museumis displaying some of the best-known paintings by the greatest European artists, major works of sculpture, furniture, porcelains, rugs, etc. It is housed in residential building of Mr. Frick, a wealthy man, who acquired these masterpieces from various sources, including from JP Morgan; and displayed them in about 20 rooms. Living Hall, Library, Dining Room, Music Room, Oval Room, Fragonard Room, East and West Gallery are showing some important paintings, which include "Harmony in Pink and Grey"; "Officer and Laughing Girl"; "Mistress and Maid"; "The Four Seasons";"The Forge"; and "Louise de Broglie"..You can have an audio tour which is included with the cost of admission. You can have a feel of how rich and wealthy people are living. We went on Sunday when the entry from 11 AM to 1 PM is on 'Pay as You Wish' basis.

Less attended but great art collection. The Frick is the private home and art collection of Henry Clay Frick a 19th century industrialist. It is located near the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but does not attract the crowds the Met does. The collection contains works by Rembrandt, Ingres, and other European master painters of the 17th to 19th century. Well worth your time to visit, especiallly if the crowds at the Met are overwhelming.

An Old Master. Set in a beautiful townhouse, around a lovely inner courtyeard, old master paintings including several Vermeers and Rembrandts make this a very worthwhile excursion. Special exhibits add to the allure. Less crowded and quieter than the Met, a peaceful oasis of art in the center of NY.
Frick Museum. the most elegant museum in all of New york City! delightful Garden, u can hear recitals in garden, just wonderful Art!

Takes you briefly to another era. Felt like i was stepping into the 19th century. All artifacts are well preserved. Not as mind bogglingly huge as the MoMa so it can be covered in a day. The audio tour is a must.

Best Museum in NYC. The collection is housed in the Frick Mansion so you have the feeling of viewing the art the way much of it was originally intended to be. The museum is also manageable in a way the Metropolitan Museum of Art isn't and is one of my favorite places to spend an afternoon.

A nice Friday afternoon. Walked over to The Frick Collection and spent a very nice afternoon enjoying the house and the art. The story behind the house and origins of the collection is almost worth the visit. The art collection is world class and my wife and I enjoyed it so.

A Wonderful Place. A super museum in a beautiful old home.
Frick was quite the collector.
Only one painting shows violence

beautiful and overlooked. this is a beautiful museum often overlooked by museum crowds, so you can stroll the museum at your pace and not feel the hassle of big crowds. Student get in at a discount ($10 with ID), $18 adults, $15 seniors and on Sundays you can pay what you want. The collection is comprised of european 18th c. paintings, scultptures, porcelain etc.

Frick Collection. I would rate this 4.5 stars, and the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars, is because the Metropolitan Museum of Art, et al, must be able to receive higher ratings.This was a surprise to my wife and I- we went with friends, and as an adult experience, it was very special.The mansion was stunning and varied, and the decorative arts, and collections, were really beautiful. The special exhibit we saw was good, but very small, but the overall experience was a treat, and worth a special visit.
Always on the Must Do list for a visit to NYC.. Perfect in every way. A superb collection in a beautiful building, and just the right scale to enjoy without being overwhelmed.

After the MMA head to the Frick Collection. "Why should we visit the Frick collection? There is so much to see in NYC..."That's what my European friends ask me when I put this museum just after the MMA on their list of things to do and places to see in NYC. But that's before they set foot in the first room of this 5th Avenue mansion which houses the personal art collection of the Gilded Age, Robber Baron, Henry Clay Frick. Then they thank me...profusely! Imagine the works of Fragonard, Rembrandt, El Greco and the most famous artists in the world displayed with exquisite taste over a mantle piece in a room designed to make the visitor feel the artists message and admire other objects from the same period. Check out the website, use the free audio guide, and appreciate the exquisite taste of this ruthless steel magnate and assistant of Andrew Carnegie who lowered worker's salaries when profits dropped and called in the Pinkerton guards to break up strikes. He gained the sympathy of the public when he was shot by an anarchist who had nothing to do with the strikes. Fortunately the mansion where he lived and his decision to leave his art collection to the public reveals a different side of his character. Not to be missed. Can only be compared to the collections of Gardner and Barnes.
Love this collection. I love those idear of the collection in a private house? It is like if the Frick family is going to come in the room!

Surely the best Private collection in NYC. Frick was a collector with a very refined taste. He spent time searching for good art and spent a fortune acquiring works coming mostly from France, Spain, Italy and Great Britain. He also acquired works by some of his Contemporary American artists.NOT to be missed Bellini's work S. Francis, which alone is worth a visit to this enchanting museum. Other jewels of the collection include some holbeins, gainsborough,ntitia, canaletto and Fragonard paintings. Although not too big, there is lots to see, so set aside at least 2 hours to enjoy a visit here.
Makes you Like the Rich. Small, wonderfully laid out museum/home. Some really fantastic art in a setting that is calm enough, uncrowded enough, to enable to fully enjoy it.
Excellent small museum. The Frick Collection is an excellent art collection displayed in a beautiful mansion. Take a break from the huge museums and visit this small beautiful one.

The Real Deal Says - this is the best hidden museum in the city. The Frick is the old wealthy family's home turned into a museum for their collection and additional ones that travel there. It is 19th Century luxury, beautiful architecture, stunning sight lines and great art. It is a wonderful jewel in a city of jewels.

Really cool in situ museum. There are some fantastic pieces of art at the Frick, many by famous artists such as Rembrandt, Van Gogh, Manet, Degas, etc. But for me that wasn't the major draw...NYC has some great museums where you can see amazing works of art, but they feel like museums. The cool thing about the Frick is that it is a 5th Ave mansion formally owned by a steel baron so it is laid out like an opulent home of the period with the art displayed much like it would have been back in the day. Its a very cool experience to wander around the home and see how the pieces tie together with the furniture and other decorations. It makes for quite an impression. They also have an excellent policy on children, children under the age of 10 are forbidden and children under 16 must be accompanied by an adult. This means you can enjoy the collection and the experience to full effect without screaming brats running everywhere, a huge bonus for me.

My dream oasis. Where else is NYC do you find a haven of art, beauty, solitude and good taste all in one place. The home of Henry Frick is a museum has always been a beautiful place and it never disappoints. My first visit was many years ago and I continue to visit because the rooms ar beautifully appointed and while the MET, MOMA, and Museum of Natural History are all magnificant, this smaller gem is a real oasis.

A great discovery. Never expected to find this on Fifth Ave. but here I was with a friend who suddenly said:"Want to see a Rembrandt"? and in we went...the collection is eclectic, rich and surprising in its quality. The good thing about living in the 19th. Century was that you could buy a Rembrandt for a small amount of money...Don't miss this great treasure.
way more than expected. wonderful collection in a nice home setting, great story, amazing array of artists. way more than I expected. young children not allowed

One of the great small museums of the world. A haven of blissful calm from the busy city with a drop-dead collection of old master paintings. This is a place to linger ion, to slow down, and to relish.
Nice collection. The Frick has a nice selection of artwork. It is not too large, so it is a manageable visit. This is a great alternative to the larger museums that could consume days of your time.

great art, great building. This is definitely worth a visit, partly because of the chance to see some great works of art, and partly for the chance to get inside a gilded age mansion to see how the robber barons lived. As an added bonus, the museum is rarely crowded, and the neighborhood pleasant to walk in.
Gem among gems.. If you only visit one museum in NYC make sure it's this one! If you visit it on Sundays it's pay what you wish (that means even 10c!)

Boutique Museum Manhattan. This small museum has an impressive collection that gives you an insight into the style and trend of the period.
Ask for the architecture tour given by the docents.
One of the best museum in NY. Frick is one of the best museum on the Museum Mile in New York. It's always worth a visit. It's one of our favorites!

One of My Favorite Museums. We loved the Frick Collection. I always visit on my trips to New York City. This is one of those manageable museums, where one is not overwhelmed by its size. I particularly enjoy the beautiful central courtyard here with its water feature and sculptures.
What a Jewel!. It's a small collection, sure, but it never travels and it is absolutely world class. Much less crowded than the nearby Met with nearly as much wow-factor.

Human scale, world class, museum. Of course you have to go to the Met and of course you will be worn out, dazed and confused if you try to go to even 1/4 of it. The Frick is a different experience. Lovely building with great art and you can get through it in just an hour or two or three and leave feeling like it was a success. Similar to the Borgese Gallery in Rome or the Isabella Gardiner in Boston, this was originally a home and is filled with their family art collection (not the typical family by any stretch).Imagine if the Met took some of their most loved pieces and put it in a Newport Mansion and then dropped it into Manhattan. That is the Frick.

A Mini Louvre. Housed in what was once a private mansion on 5th Avenue, this gem of a collection should really be in Europe but if you cant make it to Paris, it is an excellent opportunity to immerse yourself in rocco art.
NY Palace. Beautiful works of art. However no cameras allowed inside :( Still worth the visit, along with of course MOMA, Met and Guggenheim

Stunning collection of artwork, beautifully laid out. The collection was thoughtfully laid out with a great audio set to help explain each of the rooms and the many pieces of artwork. The inner sanctuary was a tranquil place to sit and think about living in such great surroundings.
Fabulous. Some of the best art anywhere: Titians, Turners, Rembrants, a Duccio. I especially enjoy Holbein's 'Thomas More.' Also, this is a mansion, so look around at the architecture.
Love the size and collection!. I love small museums that are accessible by size with interesting collections. The Frick is one of my favorites in NYC.

Truly brilliant. How lovely to see an incredible collection in such a brilliant space. Always so much more special to see art in its intended surrounds and in this case as it was purchased/acquired. How lucky for NYC to have such a jewel of a museum including the grand piece of architecture that houses it.
Fine Art in A Small Dose. Small, making it easy to see each piece of art. The headset describes what is shown for full appreciation.

If you're on a tight time schedule, come here!. Loved this place. We only had four days in NYC, and my husband isn't really interested in museums or art galleries, so I only had an afternoon. I chose the Frick Collection due to a recommendation of a friend who had been and loved it. The idea of having a house built to house your art collection, and building your art collection based on it being comprised of pieces you can live with... it was just wonderful. I completely, whole heartedly recommend the Frick Collection to anyone - make sure you take a little extra time to watch the movie about the history of the Frick Collection.

Amazing Collection. Had a chance to see the collection of this wonderful man Mr.Henry Clay. Frick, every room was amazing and please do take the handheld acoustical tour devices that is included in your fee of the museum,I saw many people not taking the device, perhaps people thought that there was fee for it...but there is none..check their website... is a wealth of information and you can go at your own pace as you walk around and look at each painting by and the full collection, it was the most helpful to press the number on the device accordingly to each each painting...At the moment the exhibition of Johann Christian Neuber every detail of the exhibit was unbelievable, the details of each box so beautiful, take your time and look at them carefully, the table with all the gem stones is so beautiful to just admire!! Do visit the museum, highly recommended and not to not miss here in NYC...even if you live here is a must go to see, being that is history that surround us that we miss by just walking by on the street and not knowing the history that holds inside of this exceptional man Frick and his passion...
"Free" Sundays. on Sundays, pay what you wish from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. The price of admission includes Acoustiguide audio tour. Admission is always free for Members.
Calmness in the City. This small museum is lovely. A great place to sit and meditate, appreciate art, and just get away from the city rush.

once a month chamber music for free to boot (call them). can't go wrong, one of the best personal collection in NYC. Call and ask about the music - you will need to write for tix and no kids under 12. it is free after a certain time too.
Nice NYC Museum to Visit. The cool part of this museum, is the collection is in the NYC Mansion. Very cool to walk around the mansion.

A must. After many visits to New York City I finally visited the Frick Collection which many friends had recommended throughout the years.It's a small museum. The collection is exceptional. It is nice to visit because of the human dimensions of the beautiful building in which it is located.

The best art collection in New York City. What makes the Frick Collection the best art museum in New York City is:1. The Fricks knew art and demonstrated excellent taste in their choice of purchase.2. The museum is relatively small, and allows the visitor a serene tour of its exhibits, without the rush required in big museums, without the feeling of being lost in the infinity of subjects and with no feeling of getting out of it energy-drained..3. The atmosphere is pleasant.4. One of the jewels of this museum is the building housing the collection. One word - beautiful!to sum it up - this is the place in NYC where one can enjoy most art in least time.Chaim Kropach
Great small museum. Great small museum. Not so large you get overwhelmed. Beautiful pieces, beautiful house, lovely garden. Very interesting history. Reminded me of the Rodin Museum in Paris.

Small but exquisite painting collection in a jewel box setting.. The Frick collection is a farily small museum that does not even try to be an encyclopedic collection like the Met or the Lourve, but what it has is one collector's view of the best of western painting. Nearly every picture is a masterpiece, and the private home setting seems much more natural a place to view art that most museums can manage. As I said, nearly every piece is very good, but for me the Bellini and the three Vermeers were enough reward to plan a trip. Definitely go - and leave enough time to linger with these exquisite masterpieces.

Fabulous , up close look at world class collection. This collection is fabulous. It's in a beautiful home on the edge of Central Park, price is reasonable and they give a student price that is almost half off. They also give you a free audio tour head phone set to go with it. that's unheard of. the class of artwork here is astounding and you get to be inches away from Rembrands, Renoirs, Degas and so many more. What an amazing place! you can easily spend 4 or 5 hours so go early and wear your walking/standing shoes. don't go in the afternoon like we did or you will be too tired to see all of it. Right on Central Park. Beautiful and peaceful.

Lovely art collection. Beautiful paintings and furniture by renowned artists, without the craziness of the bigger museums. This museum is set up as if Mr. Frick still lived there, which makes it more personable too...
Soak in fashionable life, even if you don't live it!. On the park, in a mansion, full access to the 1st floor (no access to upstairs). Even if you're not an art lover you will love this place!
Great taste on display. This robber baron may not have been the nicest fellow but he did have wonderful taste. Great art. Great rooms. Fantastic place to kill an afternoon in New York and dream.

Wow!. We have been to NYC several times but this was our first venture to the Frick. I'm not sure which impressed me more - the original section of the mansion or the collection. Just incredible and worth more time than we allowed. Plan to come back and revisit next trip as well. If you are on the fence - GO!!

What the 1% can give the 99%. No Museum or Gallery I have visited offers more great art per square inch or a more comprehensive view of world art ( allowing for the modest size of the collection) than this gorgeous palace built from the embers of Henry Clay Frick’s coke-production enterprise. Vermeer, Hals, Rembrandt, Titian, Holbein, Constable, Gainsborough --- to name only some of the principle contributors ---- are represented by several works apiece, all of the highest quality. Fine examples of the Siena school make up one of the rooms, and ravishing examples of French impressionist masterpieces liberally adorn the walls. Matching the stellar craftsmanship of the paintings are sculptures ( Gianbologna, Cellini, Houdon and Rodin), ceramics ( Meissen, Sevres, Limoges and other European schools as well as great works from the Orient), furniture, clocks, mirrors ---- all of which give a serene yet homely luxury to this magnificent once-domesticated home. Spectacular in effect and daring in execution are the two reconstructed rooms whose walls are made up of frescoes by Fragonard and Boucher. However for me, on my 4th visit, most memorable of all was a special exhibition of miniature caskets created by a German artist entirely unknown to me ---- Johann Christian Neuber. The exquisite skill with which he deploys woods, jewels and precious metals outclasses that of the great Faberge and is infinitely more varied. This treasure trove stands as a testament of how enormous wealth, when combined with generosity, can enrich the lives of lesser mortals.
Wonderful collection. Fabulous collection of art work in a small, manageable size venue.The house itself is worth seeing and a calm and relaxing place to visit.

A Jewel of a Museum. Among the awesome artwork is the original Gilbert Stuart painting of George Washington, Hans Holbein's portrait of Thomas Moore and Cromwell, and El Greco's Purification of the Temple.
Fascinating Collection for such a small space. The quality of the art in this once private collection is amazing. The organ pipes in the stairwell are gorgeous. A must see for art lovers.
Amazing. What a great museum. The collection is very accessible. House is warm and inviting. Staff was great. I spent 2 hours wandering and really enjoyed myself

A Return Visit To A Very Rich Friend. You will find many reviews celebrating this museum. Well they should.
If you like museums that express the personal taste of the collector then you will love the Frick. The choices he and his family made of world class old masters in rooms thoughtfully decorated with the best of design and materials of the era are stunning.
Incredidble Art. Words cannot express the experience of walking through a home that is graced with such beautiful art. Just stop and take in each room as it is presented. Do Not Miss this home.

Spectacular Collection. I was last at the Frick Museum in 2005. It combines an interesting history and a great piece of New York architecture with one of the great private art collections. It is also located not far from the Metropolitan Museum in Manhattan. This museum is remarkable for two Vermeers (only 34 in existence), two fantanstic Gainsboroughs, an imortant Holbein, Van Dykes, Rembrants, and many other important European masterpieces in the house that Frick built to house his collection. Paintings are throughout the house and in a special gallery at the back. The house and collection do have a certain cold monumentalism and are designed to impress. The Andre-Jacquemart House (Baron Haussman Road) in Paris provides a similar kind of house museum but is more beautiful and personal. It is designed to be impressive as well, but is warmer and more personal and more elegant, and conveys the owners love of art.

Wonderful old home and treasures. Unbelievable art and china. Felt as through Mr Frick was watching over it all. Loved going from room to room and everything was left set up just how it had been when the family lived there
Beautiful former private collection. The building's a jem, as is the collection. Despite it being well-known, it's still not overcrowded.
Wonderful collection. This is one of my favorite places to visit in NYC. The collection is exceptional. It is very easy to find, and it is truly a gem in the art world of New York.

Architecture meets Art!. Rembrandt, Rubens, Vermeer, Sargent, Van Dyck and Goya's are a quintessential way to start! This Museum is a serious classic and one of my boutique favorites in NYC as an artist. ENJOY:)

One of the top attractions in NYC.. A connoisseur 's delight. I try to go once a year. Every special exhibit I have seen has been absorbing.An intimate house museum with classic European art. Superb British portraits in the dining room. I'd like to be able to contribute enough to get invited for dinner.There are string quartets and other chamber music concerts in the interior courtyard.

Did anybody really live here?. Big, dark, and gloomy...just the place for the ultra rich and powerful to hang out in. But the art, mostly the paintings by the best in the west, were and are worth a visit. Yes, it's crowded; after, it's not the acres inside the Met. Still, a nice way to spend an hour seeing Rembrandt, Rubens, Vermeer, Sargent, Van Dyck, Goya, and many other luminaries only the unimaginably rich could afford. Thanks, Mr. Frick, we had a nice time at your home on East 70th Street in the Big Apple.
Small but lovely museum if you don't have the time for MOMA or the Met.. I enjoyed seeing the rooms, the artwork which one is amazed that a private person could collect in their lifetime...

Great Value. The Frick Collection is a great find. It is in a quintessential NYC location on the Upper East Side, and has a fabulous collection. The mansion housing the collection is in itself a work of art and contains many gems, such as Gilbert Stuart's portrait of George Washington. Beyond the paintings there are amazing examples of furniture, decorative pieces, Meissen porcelain and small bronze statues. The intimate setting means you can see all the pieces within a few hours, so you don't feel overwhelmed or like you missed something. Since the museum is meant to be enjoyed as it was when the Frick's called it home, there are minimal cases, ropes or barriers. An audio guide is included in the price of admission, which is so helpful! I've been to the MOMA, the Met, and the Guggenheim and I am so glad I chose to visit the Frick this time!

Wonderful museum in almost 100 year old mansion. This great museum is in the classic Frick mansion which was completed almost 100 years ago. Frick was a collector of art work and eventually wanted his home to be a museum. He lived there only 5 years when he died. After his wife died in the early 1930s the house was converted into a museum and over the years it has doubled in size, but is still a relatively small, easy to visit place.There is a 10 film about Frick and the house and museum which should be seen first. There are paintings, furniture and decorative art work in various rooms, some look like they did in the early part of the 20th century. There are quite a few paintings by certain well known artists--Whistler, Goya, Hals, Vermeer (3 paintings), El Greco, Rembrandt, etc. Make sure to visit the lovely enclosed garden to relax and enjoy.The museum is a member of the National American Reciprocal Museums (NARM) and membership in those museums allows for free admission. There is an audio tour of the art work which is an additonal cost, as well as a booklet, also an additional cost.This is a great location on Fifth Ave. and 70th Street right across from Central Park and is easily reached by bus.or subway.

I want to go to there!!!. Great, very doable, museum in a perfect Central Park neighborhood! What a delightful afternoon we spent at the Frick. So many beautiful works of art but not too many as to become overwhelmed. I sometimes get a bit boggled at larger museums, ending my visit in an over stimulated daze. This is not the case at the Frick! I could take it all in and not feel rushed or overwhelmed. In fact the whole mansion is very relaxing especially the central fountain area. I will definitely go back to enjoy again and again! The Frick is entertaining for family, teens, couples or solo. (ps- also had service dog with us and Frick staff was very respectful and accommodating)
Small Space with Big Impact. The museum is a must for anyone who wants to view great art in an intimate space. The newly renovated courtyard really enhances the already nice space.

I love to go there. Architecture, art, a place where you can see how people used to live and to miss old times. A Fine collection, a nice store to buy souvenirs. Love it... I go there every time I'm in NY
Great European art in a historic mansion. The Fragonard room is a must-see, and there is much more to see in this elegant and peaceful medium-sized museum. It is a pleasure to visit.
Nice time at The Frick Collection. Small home with a Renoir and a Monet. Nice scuplture special exhibit. Worth the tour through this home gallery.

Amazing art in a more intimate setting. The art here is as impressive as in the much larger Metropolitan Museum, with famous works by Rembrandt and Vermeer, but in a far more intimate setting - the art is arange among the rooms of what was once a private home.On a per square foot basis, this is probably the most impressive museum in the world.
Beautiful restoration and some nice additions. Haven;t been since they removated a few years ago but the lighting has really improved and they have other new things.
A Great in Manhattan. The collection is outstanding with a good deal of very important European and Impressionistic Art. The building is intreguing with a courtyard and pool that's very relaxing.

stunning building. fabulous collection of artwork and free audio which is a plus in this city!! Would of liked to of gone in the grounds as it had a stunning pond and seating area but not open to public
One of the best ever. collection is lovely..... but the real treasure is the building !!!! The atrium is beautiful. they don't allow photos , so be respectful.

Wonderful Introduction to European Art in a Small-Scale Setting. The Frick Collection has been getting steadily more popular for both New Yorkers and visitors, and one can see why. I wouldn't exactly call it an intimate space as Mr Frick's home is more like a mansion with some large additions built after his death. But if you don't visit on weekends - then you may be lucky to avoid huge crowds. The collection is fairly conservative but of brilliant quality. Almost entirely European (there are a few Whistlers, though) with a good bunch of British artists, the paintings are on display in mostly small galleries. A free audio guide is included in the admission and the commentaries are excellent. Be warned, though: if you listen to all the commentaries the tour of the Frick can easily take 4 to 5 hours. On Sundays- between 11.00 and 1.00 am you can pay what you can afford; $5-10 per person was what I saw most people paying. At other times entry costs $17 ($15 for senior citizens).

Best museum in Manhattan. I had an afternoon off during a business trip and spent it at the amazing Frick. It's not so large that you can't see it all in an hour and half. But the quality completely makes up for any shortage of quantity.

The frick collection. If you like a mixture of artworks from several periods and don't like large crowds, visit this gallery, it's small but packed with interesting collections. Renoirs particularly good. It has sculptures too and a small atrium to have a rest and do a bit of people watching.

Remarkable collection. Along with the Morgan, one of the truly great private collections of art spanning several centuries. You will see works that you have read about by some of Europe's premier artists displayed in an uncluttered, satisfying fashion.

lovely, quiet, small museum. This is a great place to spend an afternoon when you are not interested in the crazy New York scene. The Frick is a large, early 20th-century mansion filled with art and antiques - it is like visiting a spectauclar home, which it was at one time. It is a quiet, subdued museum.
Absolutely magnificent. Do not miss The Frick when in NYC!The mansion, the art, the entire experience is like none other.A must see.

A "hidden" treasure. I had noticed this place many times on earlier trips and just passed it by. I took the time to check it out this time and I am so glad that I did! It's hard to imagine that this was once the home of an early-day industrial giant. It's very grand, yet very charming and elegant. The art collection is well worth a visit in itself. The mansion has lots of beautiful spaces, especially a wonderful central court. It's so enjoyable just to "hang out" there for a while.
Amazing Collection. Don't miss it - this is a collection with the most amazing original works of art from Vemeer to Constable to Holbein etc etc

Wonderful gem. it is incredible how this man created his house and left it for us to bring us back at the beginning of 20 century in NYC very wealthy and art house. To sit on the a armchairs and look at the El Greco paintings make me feel amazingly. I was there when there is a temporary exhibition of Renoir painting and I enjoyed it so much. There were interactive explanation of creating the pictures and all the details which give you more wide view.

Wonderful art housed in an ideal environment. The lovely building housed many of the works of art in their original settings - eg Dining Room and Ballroom. There were many famous artists displayed and the mansion itself was wonderful to weander around. The gift shop was quite small and the restrooms were not so easy to find. The staff were very gracious and helpful.
Who Am I to Rate The Frick?. All I can say is this is small gem! A short visit is all it takes to see the entire collection and don't miss the film - it really is interesting
Beautiful home and collection. Perhaps the entry fee was a little steep but it is a lovely collection in a beautiful New York Ciy home. Glad we went during our recent visit.

A Surprising Treat. This museum was not on our initial list but after several people telling us about it we decided to visit on our way to the Met. We found there were 2 attractions on show here, firstly the amazing artwork collection and how it has been assembled and displayed around the various rooms of the house, secondly, the house itself is amazing. If you are visiting make sure you pick up an audio guide from the reception desk.

Always a Fascinating Experience. While The Frick has it's own collection of art, the small exhibition space is filled with well curated exhibits that shouldn't be missed by any true museum visitor. This ranks high in the esteem of the art world.

A magnificent small museum. NYC has so many great museums that it's hard to know what to visit after th Metropolitan Museum of Art, one of the very best in the world, but if you don't want to wade through crowds but see a small number of wonderful paintings, such as Gainborough's Lady Peyton Skipwith, this is the place to visit. You will see a few fine things and not come out with eye-fatigue,

Some of the World's Greatest Art Displayed Privately. It is, of course, open to the public. But the Frick Collection, in its setting and graceful authenticity, allows one to easily imagine being a private guest in this great house. On the first floor of the opulent private home of early twentieth century industrialist, Henry Clay Frick, visitors are able to intimately enjoy his extraordinary and unbelievably well-maintained art collection as he would have intended. My favorite thing about the museum is its small scale that does not overwhelm. When I visit I feel more rested and restored rather than exhausted. Though one can see the entire collection in an hour or so, plan more time and let your imagination wander. Bring a copy of "Time and Again" to read on a bench in the serene conservatory.
Lovely museum. Beautiful works of art in a gorgeous setting. The Frick collection is a perfect example of why New York is such a special place to visit.

Wonderful collection, beautiful setting.. We love art museums and this was one of our favorites in New York. The guide booklet for $2 was very helpful but the also have free audio tours. People were very helpful and knowledgable.

Makes me wish I was rich!. Wasn't expecting to make the Frick Collection a stop on my NYC tour, but the museum has free admission Sundays 11-1 so I dropped by. I was very impressed by the enormous collection and the beautiful mansion. The house alone would be enough to warrant a visit, with elegantly carved mantelpieces and intricate ceiling design. But you can't forget what's on the walls — Renoir, Bellini, Gainsborough, and hundreds more fantastic artists. If you have two hours to kill (it's not very big) and you want a more intimate atmosphere than the MET, it's definitely worth the trip.
go on sunday!. great collection, lovely grounds and nicely proportioned for the pay what you wish Sunday slot!
Magnificent House-Museum. The architecture is beautiful, it has a wide colecction of great master pieces, sculpturs, paintings,etc. It has very beautiful inside fountain garden.

Just exquisite. The Frick is an extraordinary collection of paintings and sculptures in the Fifth Avenue mansion once owned by Henry J. Frick. Frick was a ruthless businessman who treated his workers badly, but that's water under the bridge, alas. Now he's remembered for assembling this magnificent collection. This is a small, comfortably dowdy museum. Unlike the Met, MOMA or the Morgan, it's had no big renovations and that's part of its charm. It's refreshingly old-fashioned inside. It's the way all museums used to be before they started trying to attract mega-crowds with blockbuster shows. There's no cafe and only a tiny bookstore. The collection is just the right size, not too small and not so large that its exhausting. It's pay what you wish on Sunday mornings until noon.

Exquisite art in an exquisite setting. An incredible, charming old mansion houses an incredible collection that is not to be missed by any art lover. It feels like this mansion was built to house art, and there is enough to keep one enthralled for hours.
Great small museum on Fifth. Great collection of old masters on the Park on Fifth on the Upper East Side. The building is an old mansion that now houses the former occupant's art collection.
Hidden treasure. If you come to New York, you have to go to the Frick. It is the perfect, manageable collection. However, children under 10 are not permitted in the museum.
New favorite museum.. Fantastic collection with great audio tour.I cannot wait to return.
must see. I like to visit this small collection every once in a while . A superb art collection

Something a little different. We really enjoyed the Frick Collection mostly because of the building it was located in. Not only do you get to see great works of art, statues, carvings etc, but you get to walk through beautiful architecture of the building.
Gorgeous collection. Wonderful collection located in a beautiful buildin.

Gorgeous museum with a beautifully curated collection. I'm sure I'll spark a debate, however, if I could only choose ONE museum to visit in NYC because of time constrainst, I would likely select the Fricke Collection because it is an excellent collection set in a spectacular setting and an "absorb-able" size. Certainly the Met is awe-inspiring because of its sheer size but it can also be overwhelming. (Don't get me wrong, I also loved the Met!) At the Fricke Collection you can truly appreciate the individual masterpieces as well as the entire collection because the scale is more approachable. I also loved seeing the artwork in a more "residential" setting and I'm so glad we took the time to visit this collection. (For the casual visitor, you can experience the Fricke in 2-3 hours.)

most people miss this gem of museum. it's small and beautiful to visit..collection change..library room is the most beautiful place to sit . having a snack in this museum is also worth it. the store has wonderful christmas presents

Amazing experience. As a lover of architecture and all things art, this museum has become my favorite. A beautiful NYC mansion filled with one man's extensive art collection, turned into a museum. They had audio tours available, but I prefer to wander on my own. I spent several hours going from room to room, first admiring the wide range of paintings, sculptures and textiles, and then the architecture; the carved wood, the masonry and marble, and gorgeous pieces of period furniture,. The grounds and the garden court add to the ambiance and the experience. I have been back several times, which is made even more interesting with their rotating collection.
a wonderful museum. It is a wonderful museum with an extraordinary collection shown in a wonderful setting.

Beautiful Art in a 5th Avenue Mansion. The Frick Collection is housed in the mansion of Henry Clay Frick, famous American industrialist and robber baron. For those who enjoy art but who feel overwhelmed by taking in a large museum, this is the perfect museum to visit. Art from all decades---Medieval, Renaissance, 18th Century French and Spanish, to late 19th Century French and American art tastefully decorates this beautiful mansion. Visitors may stroll through this beautiful home and view the historic works of art that grace the walls and hallways of this former home. The collection is not overly large, so it's quite easy to take it all in without feeling overwhelmed. The museum also offers an audio guide for a small fee, so visitors who are interested in learning the specifics of each painting and artist may do so. The Museum is located on 5th Avenue, across from Central Park, on Museum Mile, so it's within easy walking distance of the Park and Midtown Manhattan. The Frick not only gives visitors a glimpse of beautiful art, it also allows visitors to glimpse the lifestyle of one of America's foremost industrialists and art collectors.
I want to live there. Who wouldn't. Great art. Amazing house. I want to meet a Frick and marry her.

Don't miss it. A little and digest collection, including lots of masterpieces, arranged according to the aesthetics sens of the former owner of the place rather than to the usual period and location classification.A wonderful place you don't want to miss. Sunday morning is pay-as-you-wish and there is a sketch session in the inner garden.

A haven of peace and beauty. The opulence yet intimacy of the place make this a really unique gallery. You are able to wander freely and observe the paintings without any barriers. The most incredible thing about this place is that it was one man's house and personal collection. You will not believe the range of paintings by such renowned artists, and displayed so accessibly.The free audio tour is really good, allowing you to choose which paintings you want info on and the info provided is so interesting.We had young teens with us and they loved their visit.I urge you to come and experience the calm wonder of this place.
A must see!. The family "home" of the Fricks turned museum. Not bad!!!!! Rotating shows, but the main collection is every bit as good. My favorite painting by Ingres is a mainstay.
Great museum. Excellent art collection in great surroundings. Well worth a visit.
Great place. What truly amazing art. The staff are also very friendly.
Amazing museum, not to miss.. Unfortunately it is not very well known by regular, a good thing if you don't want to be in a busy environment like other NY museums.

Simply one of the best private collections period.. Visitors are treated to a short movie on the history of the house's creator, his brief life history, and his amazing private collection from various (many now quite famous) artists with paintings he refused to loan out and thus you may never have seen any of them in even the best museums around the world. The home itself is a gorgeous place which was designed from the beginning to end up as an art museum. There is a decent gift shop with volumes of information on the art and the building. Even the Visitors seem more rare than those you might find at the Metropolitan museum or the Louvre. The fact that they even know about this place means they did their homework.
small and managable museum. Not a fan of museums in general but I went with my wife and we enjoyed the audio tour and walking around the gorgeous mansion as well as the art work.

Famous Paintings & Fabulous Art. Beside The Met, The Frick is one of the best museums in NYC. It is located in a mansion and is small enough that you can thoroughly enjoy all the art that is displayed. I was amazed to see some famous paintings that I have seen in books, etc. A "must see" for any NYC visit.
Most Unique. The collections are really unbelieveable and exciting. Be prepared for a very unique experience.

You can't miss this. The Frick is one of the most beautiful small museums in the world. You not only get to see a turn of the century New York Mansion in almost exactly the condition it was left - the wonderful entry, the rooms, the garden but also the art collection is just lovely, and the porcelains down stairs are fantastic. what I really love is how quiet and usually uncrowded the Frick is - a nice respite on a long day in New York and just pretty.
Absolutely gorgeous. My favorite art museum in NYC. Amazing art collection housed in a magnificent mansion. Such a treasure.
A great place to see fine art. A smaller museum that is very manageable and offers a superb collection of art. Love the home!

Amazing house & gallery. I was dragged along by my wife under sufferance, but as usual she was right. This is an amazing house built by the industrialist Frick in 1914. He filled it with magnificanet art works, and then on his death, donated it as a gallery, for which we should all thank him. It's one of the best New York has to offer. First, there is the grand house. This alone is worth the visit. Next, is his art collection which is truly amazing. Finally, what impressed me most was the foresight of Mr. Frick to build a beautiful house which appears to have been designed to one day be a museum, collect such wonderful works and then donate it so all could enjoy it forever.
great masterpieces. Pleasant and bright place, so many great masterpieces!!!

Amazing collection of art & furniture. Housed in a beautiful building, this collection includes a stunning art collection of European and American artists.Interesting to learn about wealthy industrialists and their attitudes to their workers !! At least he left his collection for succeeding generations to enjoy.

Must See for Art Lovers. An unbelievable collection in a beautiful setting. This makes for a very pleasant 1-2 hr visit. Be sure to watch the video and take advantage of the free audio guide. Be aware that children under 10 are not allowed.

Fantastic Suprise. I went to this museum mainly because it was so stinking hot outside I need to do something away from the heat. It was a great suprise. While a little expense at $18 (The Met Museum is $25 which is 20 times larger) the collection dispersed in a mansion directly out of the guilded age was fantastic. Too bad they didn't have more rooms opened.
Really worth a visit. Our 22 year old son advised us to go to the Frick and we were not disappointed. What a magnificent collection, we loved it!!

Former Frick Mansion. One of the world's great art collections is well presented in one of New York's grandest old mansions. Fashioned as an Italian Palazzo on the upper east side of New York, one can still imagine the lifestyle of the Frick family as one wanders through the large, elegant rooms of this enormous dwelling. As large as it is, only a portion of the building is open to the public as a museum, a surviving family member still occupyies a portion of the eastern side of the house.
Just right. The major NYC museums are not to be missed, but don't overlook this gem: the art, architecture, and history will inspire, and won't overwhelm and overtire.

One of the best museums in Manhattan and very manageable!. I have been living in the city for a few years and visited almost all the important art museums around. Frick Collection is by far on the top of my list. If I have friends in town for a short stay, I would always always recommend them visit that museum. One, it's manageable. Unlike the Met nearby, it's relatively smaller and takes about one or two hours while the collections is first class. Two, the museum itself is a well-preserved real mansion with real New York story. You will see how the rooms were arranged a hundred years ago and feel the life of this family. If you want to save some money, go there on Sundays during lunch time which is pay as you wish. The only downsides I can think of are that pictures are not allowed and second floor is not open to the public.I cannot recommend this museum enough. If you haven't heard about this museum, now you have! and please do visit.

A Gem of a Museum. Love this museum in the Frick Mansion on 5th and 71st Street.Small by comparison to the Met or others, but a real gem to visit, with beautiful gardens. It's a secret place for all who visit NYC.

Art and a glimpse of a unique titan. The Frick home and collection is the opportunity to see fine quality art in a couple delightful hours in a unique setting. In contrast to a regular museum the collection is select pieces purchased to enhance the home of one of America's early steel barons. The number of visitors was small and the relaxing rooms (probably 10-12 rooms and 50 paintings along with furniture and other art works) allowed our family to enjoy without feeling overwhelmed or becoming scattered.
Best private museum. Many monumental pictures is exhibited.No one can see outside of it .

Breathtaking. Astonishing collection set in a beautiful house, this brings to life the "gilded age" like nothing else. The artwork, collected by one man, is amazing, and in every room you'll see paintings that are familiar from browsing art books.

Smaller, intimate museum. Visited on July 6th during the heat wave. While the collection of paintings and bronzes is outstanding, the air conditioners could not keep up with heat. It was quite warm inside the house and I did wonder that the place was not cooler with all that beautiful art. The house itself is also worth viewing. Quite amazing to think people had lived here. We didn't get the taped tour and wished we had. The day we were there it was not crowded which made it easy to get up close or stand back to see the paintings.

Stunning. Frick was clearly a man of not only immense ambition and business acumen, he also had a discerning eye. Enjoy the great beauty assembled here. The house itself is a work of art and then the very personal and eclectic collection of painting, sculpture and more is a treat for the eyes. The brief film provides a good foundation for appreciating the Frick Collection. Take a few minutes to watch it.

Best Museum in town!. This is my third visit to the Frick Collection and I think it's the best museum in NY city. I love the paintings, the decoration, the house on itself, the sculptures, the garden. It captures NY golden era and I just wish the grand staircase could be open to people to take a peek on the second floor. This museum is a must-see, for art connoisseurs it's paradise!

Great collection, beautiful museum. Frick refined his collection down to only masterpieces. There are a some great Rembrandts and Holbeins. The museum itself is one of the few remaining gilded age mansions left in New York. For me, It is up there with the Met and MoMA. A definite must see.
As always amazing. This was someone's home. The art is awesome. Imagine waking up everyday in this house

Outstanding collection of a 19th-century railroad magnate. The location is superb -- 70th and Fifth Avenue, facing Central Park. The feeling is more intimate than New York's major art museums (the Met, MOMA) as it once was Mr. Frick's home. His acquisitions were world-class. How many museums own a Vermeer? The setting is serene, with a fountain at the core of the building. It has an excellent gift shop, and the staff are welcoming. It has an excellent resource library for scholars and surrounding grounds (modest in size but perfect for the setting). I cannot find fault with the place and I often include it as a short walk (12 blocks) south of the Met. After the grandeur of the Met's collection and setting, the Frick is an antidote of serenity. Definitely worth a trip.
new york treasure. outstanding art, great environment, lovely place to spend time and enjoy their exhibits
A beautiful museum. This place is very special. A nice mansion, beautiful rooms and a nice atmoshere. Not the typical museum to expect in New York. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful mansion and collection. This art collection is fabulous, 3 Vermeers in a private collection along with many other famous artists.The mansion itself is worth the visit.
An elegant museum. The headphones offered a pleasant, informative stroll through the museum. Took a break at a local restaurant and came back and saw the rest. The setting is lovely.

A treasure gem in NYC. What can I say about the Frick but felt priviledged and lucky to have such a little gem museum in the NYC. It is peaceful and calm in the court yard and the collections are first rate. People who visited the museum it has an automated quieting-down effect on them, they talked in hush tones while they admired the collections and you felt very civilized and satiated after you walked out there.
Excellent. A lovely museum to visit - well appointed and not overbearing.
SUPERB COLLECTION IN THE SETTING OF A SUPERB HOME. Liked most things, espcially the silver and the paintings. Only things we disliked were those that were not to our taste.

Hidden gem on Manhattan UES. When people think of museums in NYC they think of MOMA, MET and Museum of Natural History as I did for most of the years I lived in Manhattan. I walked past this museum so many time on my way to Central Park but one day I stopped in and all I can say was I was blown away by the artwork.The museum is in an old mansion, the last of the great 5th Avenue mansions and it in itself is a work of work but within each room you will discover classic artwork from over a 500 year period, both bought by Mr. and Mrs. Frick as well as their descendants once they turned that mansion into a museumSunday from I believe 10 or 11 am till 2 is pay what you can so if you’re in town I would take advantage of that.

Breathtaking art. One of the original Fifth Ave. mansions, this is not to be missed if you enjoy fine art. Beautiful masterpieces from Vermeer, Gainsborough, etc... a beautiful atrium with pool, exquisite furnishings, a museum lover's museum. Call for hours.

Privileged insight into a privileged life.. The Frick makes it crystal clear why normal art galleries can be so boring, so quickly. This is not a gallery but a mansion where a single visionary man bought and then hung great European masterpieces where he wanted to live with them. Here you can imagine sitting in a chair to contemplate a Turner or Vermeer, or dining surrounded by great portraits, just as hundreds of others did when it was private - and wasn't that what these pictures were painted for, for private enjoyment in houses?It was a wondrous shock to turn into a small ante room and to find an El Greco. It alone must be worth enough to buy a house for everyone else who was in the Frick that morning. I could imagine the smile of pleasure it gave Mr Frick when he walked past it. A formal gallery can't ever do that.So, if your taste for art galleries is minor, make this a major stopping point. As well as enjoying the amazing pictures it's worth taking time to sit, perhaps in the central water garden and imagine living with such privileged grandeur. I didn't use the audio guide as I wanted to pretend I was an invited guest (easy to do) but I could see great wonder and awe on the faces of many who did.The Metropolitan, the Guggenheim and the Neue Gallerie (an ex-Rockfeller Mansion that serves spectacular pastries and cakes with its turn of the century Austrian art, including a Klimt) are all on Fifth Avenue too. But whether you have a day or a week, even if just a single hour, the Frick will give you an astonishing insight into the life of rich New York and sate you with wondrous images that will never leave you. It's a privilege without comparison that I know.
Great choice of art pieces. If you like Vermeer - they have 3 excellent pieces, plus many other pieces, not just pictures, which worth to look at.

Some real wows. I am normally a bit so so about art, I find my legs and eyelids getting heavy after 30 mins. The frick is great though. It's very big for someone's house but quite small for a famous museum. And yet it has so many famous artists: Holbein, turner, degas, Goya, Monet, Manet, Rembrandt, Vermeer, Greco etc etc. holbeins picture of Thomas more was amazing and worth the entry fee alone. Recommended! 90 mins is enough to get round and listen to many of the notes on the audio guide which I definitely recommend and it comes free with admission anyway.
Art at your fingertips. Not only is the art here wonderful but the museum itself is enjoyable to look at. Great little art museum to go through in one afternoon in its entirety.

My favorite NYC museum. It's not as well known as other NYC museums but I love it. Fabulous collection, great experience overall. Love the inner courtyard. I always stop there to imagine what it would have been like in Mr.Frick's days living there.
Beautiful.. Hard to believe this was once a private residence, what a fantastic place to live! The collection is stunning and this is one of the nicest we have seen.
Best museum. If you only have time to visit one museum while in New York, make this the one! Fabulous private collection in a wonderful building.
It doesn't get any better than this!. One of the loveliest spaces I have ever visited. Not so large as to be overwhelming.
Amazing. What a visionary! From the collection to the mansion, It's truly an amazing place.
a must. great collection, not too big, all in a beautiful building, an excellent museum that doesn't take all day to explore, beautiful paintings of Rembrandt, Renoir, Ingres, Vermeer etc..

Wonderful bite-sized collection. Fabulous stately manor home with a great collection. Big enough to be interesting, but small enough to be able to cover it off in an hour or so and not feeling exhausted. Great story about Clay Frick and lovely pieces. Not being an avid art person, I actually loved looking through the home most of all!

Suprising & Rewarding Experience. Mr. Frick made his fortune in the coke/steel industry along side Andrew Carnigie. He build his home on 5th Avenue fully intending it to become a museum and filled it with masterpieces of art. A most totally unique place. The location, building, rooms, furniture and art all as Mr. Frick wanted you to see them in the 1920's. Art lovers and historians can enjoy a relaxing atmosphere in an intimate environment away from the crowds. Don't miss the Frick Collection.

Love love love. I love this musuem. This is a mansion with a beautiful chamber music room. Sunday's at 5 you can listen to beautiful chamber music performed live. It's $35 now (used to be free by lottery) but it is worth it. Claim is that it is the only chamber music room in a private home in the U.S.
A lesser known collection but the art and the architecture are worth seeking it out. This would be the major art museum in most cities. The architecture is stunning as well.

Very nice visit. It is always grreat to see art work hung the way they were meant to be . This is a very nice villa with numerous art work ( but not overstuffed) .the audio guide is very usefull (incl in ticket price)

good collection. BEAUTIFUL HOME. worth a visit. I have been to the MOMA and the met before. wanted to see what the frick collection offered. This is a quieter spot overall. Not too many people. The home itself was very beautiful. I spent as much time admiring the finishings,ceilings, furniture, decor as i did the paintings. Each room features a collection of paintings (collected by Mr. Frick) by an artist. very pleasing to the eye. the audio guides are very good.The only downside was that the staff did not really have an idea about the house itself. so if you need /want some additional information not provided by the audio guide you might have to look it up online.18$ for a visit which is also very reasonable in NYC

Delighful Museum. I was very impressed with the wonderful collection of art at The Frick. We visited in the afternoon and had a free tour given by a very knowledgeable docent. She told fun stories about Mr. Frick and about how the collection evolved. Amazing to see the home and the collection!
An intimate collection that always surprises. This is such a quiet temple to amazing art in the mayhem of New York. A must vist for anyone in New York
We return here every visit. Beautiful place , with beautiful paintings, after the clamour of new York , a haven.

My. Favourite museum in the world. It is amazing that one man could have had such good taste and collected so many masterpieces in one relatively small place. The intimacy and the eclectic range of paintings and other artefacts in this house should not be missed,especially on a Sunday 11am to 1 pm when admission is free.
A wonderful collection. very worthwhile and a place where you'll see painting that you've only seen in books. It's an intimate gallery with many great paintings.
I proposed here. 10 times less traffic than the Met or Guggenheim but no less impressive.

Must go more often!. I haven't been to the Frick in years except to cool off in the courtyard. However, they had a Renoir exhibit which called to me so off I went. The Renoirs were lovely, but the least of my visit. I had completely forgotten just how amazing the collection is, and how rich Frick was to have accumulated it. This is such a gem, and I won't overlook it next time I'm in the city.
A gracious reminder of old New York. The Frick is a small and charming museum with superb artworks.

A terrific art collection.. If you love old masters painting the Frick is not to be missed. The living room / ballroom of this beaux arts mansion is spectatular with a superlative collect of old masters. This is one of the great rooms you will ever see in terms of paintings. Do yourself a favor and spend an hour or so here. They also usually have special exhibits that are stellar as well.

Excellent Museum for Busy People. Here you get to see the personal art collection of the Fricks in their old mansion-turned-museum museum. If you get overwhelmed with gigantic museums with more art then you will ever have time to see, then you'll love the Frick (I said something similar in my review on the MoMA, but this is even more true here). One of the nice things about the Frick is that you also get to enjoy walking through the actual mansion and learning a bit about the history of the collection. Whenever I visit the Frick, I always think of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston. I guess it's that private collection/mansion feel. Both are very comfortable places to walk around and enjoy art -- not arranged historically or by artist, but completely aesthetically. Art is placed in spots and next to other pieces of art because they look beautiful there, and not for any other reason. I like that. :)
fantastic collection. Absolute must see, the mansion alone is worth a visit !Not as crowded as the more famous and larger museums, so makes visiting it a very relaxed affair.

Outstanding smaller museum. We visited the Frick Collection today spent almost two hours at this outstanding smaller museum. It includes a selective collection of 15th through late 19th century paintings , furniture, and sculpture.
