The museum has 3 of the only 34 Vermeer paintings in the world plus works by Hals, Hobbema, Rembrandt, and other Dutch masters. Art is set in beautiful surroundings of former Frick mansion.

My secret haven in NYC. I have been escaping into the Frick museum since I was in high school. The Frick not only has a wonderful collection of European art but also has the added advantage of being an actual house that a family lived in. Each room has it's special magic and it is a real treat to just sit in the inner courtyard and contemplate.They also have great lectures (free with admission) check out their website.
beautiful. loved ithave lived in NYC all my life and this was my first time there.Basically spent about 3 hours there.

My favorite museum. We love going to the Frick because it is big enough to have a great variety but small enough that you have the time to see and enjoy a good variety of art without being overwhelmed.
Show at the Frick wonderful. Love the way the art is displayed in the space. It allows one to imagine how Frick actually lived in this house. One of my favorite museums in NYC.

My favourite. The Frick Collection is my favourite museum/art collection of anywhere. It is unique because beautiful works of art are all housed in a mansion built by the industrialist Frick to be a family house but also hold his fabulous art collection in perpetuity when he passed away. I am a Tudor fanatic and the original Holbein paintings of mortal enemies Thomas Moore and Thomas Cromwell facing each other across the fireplace is truly entrancing and sends shivers down my spine.
Museum across Central Park. A beautiful museum with an outstanding collection.

perfect size. The Frick collection is the perfect museum. I don't know anything about art and yet felt it would be wrong to visit NYC and not go to at least one museum (okay also checked out MOMA as everyone says you have to). The collection is housed in a stunning home off 5th Ave. It is small enough to see it all, and listen to most of the commentary, in 2 hours. Even a "art for Idiots" person like myself recognized most of the artists names. I went early for opening and there was no queuing and not very crowded.
fascinated. Always fascinated with this place! I can't fathom a character like Fricks showing such a fine taste for Art!
Must see gallery. Great picture collection from Renaissance to eraly XXth century.

BEAUTIFUL Art at an exceptional location!. New York City is filled with museums for all interests but, what makes the Frick collection stand out is it's stunning location and intimacy. This beautiful NYC mansion is a hidden gem in a modern world.It's filled with unique works from Degas and Renoir, exquisite furnishings and the new wing filled with ceramics and sculptures. Most recently we attended the breathtaking Renoir exhibition and truly enjoyed it. Always worth a visit.
Beautiful. Beautiful collection of art that is a must during a trip to NYC!

Charming. It's a totally different experience from visiting the neighbor gigantic Metropolitan Museum. Frick is a small charming labour of love. Both the house and the collections show the dedication to the excellence of people in the golden days.It's not cheap and there aren't endless things to see but it's one of a kind in NYC.

Superb Collection of Artwork. Popped in on a rainy afternoon, and we were glad we did. Amazing house full of exceptional art from the world's best artists. Audio guide is free and helps fully appreciate the collection.
Don't miss it!. Great and surprising collection, beautiful house..

Very Special Museum. The Frick is a wonderful little museum that can be visited in a few hours. The building, both the inside and outside, are beautiful in their own right and in a lovely location. The artwork is a thoughtful and impressive collection that will delight art enthusiasts and art newbies. It's really amazing all of the pieces that are in this relatively small museum (at least compared to the National Gallery, Louvre, etc.). There's something for everyone to appreciate here.

Never disappoints!. The building itself is beautiful, so no matter what painings are on display you are bound to have a good time. This old fashioned building is an oasis in hectic Manhattan rhythm, cute place for art lovers or dating crowd :)
Mansion With Art. Terrific collection of art. A must for visitors to "the big apple"! Beautiful art in a beautiful setting!

A Wonderful "Home" Collection. This building was built with the intention to house the collection and it does so beautifully. The building is just as beautiful as the art itself. This is a must see for art lovers.
Overrated.. Beautiful old mansion but not worth the $18 to get in to view things not out of the ordinary.
Fantastic. Fantastic collection beautifully curated in a beautiful building. Make sure you watch the video about Frick in the movie theatre. Sunday lunch time is pay as you like.
I love this museum!. Very interesting - Henry Frick's home until he died in the 30's. His wonderful art collection. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
Most beautiful paintings. It is a place to go and see the most beautiful paitings and furnitures

A small jewel among the big museums. Everything about the Frick is special. The building is glorious and the collection is splendid. The location is great if you enjoy walking in the best part of the City. It's on your "don't miss" list for sure!

Wonderful Collection of Old Masters. Henry Clay Frick's collection of some of the world's most beautiful paintings is awe inspiring. In just six rooms of this beautiful mansion are displayed works by famed artists including: Bellini, Gainsborough,Turner, Ingres, Vermeer, Goya, Rembrandt, El Greco, Renoir and Holbein. Scupture, furniture, carpets and other collectibles are also beautifully displayed. Do not miss this wonderful museum.
More masterpieces per square foot than anywhere. This is the way to see great art, in the context of its original mansion, and as collected by someone with great taste for every era

Garden of Eden. I like everything about this museum. It is small in size, with one of the best collections formed by a private individual. The Vermeers are phenomenal, as are the Van Eycks, Rembrandt, El Greco, Holbein, Titian, Turner paintings. The particular paintings are curated very well. Each painting is a gem. Special collections are added periodically. Audios are available, but every painting, piece of furniture, or objet d'art is clearly labeled. I'm a member of the museum, and I also enjoy the musical programs that are scheduled throughout the year. The garden in the center is lovely and charming. This museum was once someone's home, and the place retains that intimate feeling. It's great for a romantic and interesting date.

The Perfect Small Museum Experience. When you are looking to spend an hour in a museum, but do not want to feel overwhelmed, this is the perfect place. Beginning outside with the beautifully elegant architecture of the building, this is a subtle treat for the senses.
Great building, great content. You need to go just to visit the building. Tight, cohesive collections. Not overwhelming. Great for novice museum visitors.
A wonderful collection in a beautiful house. Frick is better than a museum. It has a soul. It is a shrine to art in a house setting. Always my favorite in New York despite its high price ($18).
He really knew how to live. Henry Clay Frick had this incredible house and collection now with one of the best art libraries under the sun. Easy place to visit, manageable size. Perfect.

A break in your day, Art and a bit of History. The Frick Collection is really an enjoyable break in your day if you happen to stop by. Near the Central Park, I suggest that you go inside if the weather is becoming super hot.I'm not a huge fan of art and my knowledge about it is limited, but the masterpieces inside the Frick Collection are stunning. You learn a lot in your visit and you also feel that you see everything that has to be seen in this place in 1.5/2 hours which does not leave you with a feeling of missing something.
A walk back in time. The varied types of art on display in a mansion from the last century.

Taste life in the gilded age. A serene, undervisited museum in a great part of town. The garden court provides a pleasant spot to just sit and imagine life of the 1% at the turn of the century. Many of the paintings are so iconic, you can't believe they're in front of your eyes!

Must see museum in New York. If I had one museum to visit in New York I would go to the Frick. I time capsule of the robber barons of the 19th century. Come and see Zuckerberg and see what you can do with all that money.

A different museum. The house is very cool, especially the garden court. Was disappointed that the outside garden and the second floor were off limits. Wasn't really blown away by the art.
Probably won't go back, but it was worth a visit.
We love the Frick. It's a beautiful museum and we have seen wonderful special exhibitions there.

Great art in a grand domestic setting. Didn't see enough Vermeers at the Metropolitan Museum? Go to the Frick and see some more. This is a treasure house of great art displayed in the house of a very rich man - but you could easily see yourself living there surrounded by all these treasures, such is the scale of the rooms and the quality of the display. Interspersed with furniture, sculpture and other objets, thw works take on a more human quality. There are masterpieces galore: Holbein, Piero della Francesca, Rembrandt, Velasquez, Gainsborough, Goya. A must see.

Great gallery in a stunning house. The Frick is undoubtedly one of the underrated attractions in NYC. The quality of the art is tremendous, but best of all is the amazing Frick house- worth the entrance fee alone.

Grown-ups only- a peaceful art venue.. If you are in NYC and you really love art, the Frick is an essential stop.Henry Clay Frick was the quintessential "Coal Baron." Fabulously wealthy, he built a magnificent private mansion on Fifth Ave. and filled it with a superb collection of European paintings, decorative items and furniture. Mr. Frick left his home and collection as a gift to the public.  Visiting the museum is like touring the private home of a late 19th early 20th century "Robber Baron" who was posessed of the highest possible taste.  Mr. Frick's collection is displayed as though he were to walk through the door with Mr. Morgan and Mr. Gould to have a chat and a coffee under the Holbein, Rembrandt or Corot.  A major advantage of this museum is that children are neither seen nor heard, and, in general, the patrons are actually looking at the paintings and not checking off boxes on a "must see" list. The Frick has revolving shows, right now there are some exceptional Italian bronzes, but the collection and the setting are the real draw. When you get exhausted by the Met and its crowds, walk ten blocks south and visit the refreshing oasis of civility at the Frick.
Fantastic. Go for the Holbeins, stay for the house, the furniture, the fact that someone lived here on 5th Avenue!
A jewel. If you don't like to spend an entire day in a museum this jewel of a collection is a stand-out that can be vistied in 2 hours.
Def worth a visit. BEAUTIFUL old house. that alone makes it worth seeing in my opinion.

A Museum unlike the others. As others have mentioned, this museum actually was Henry Frick's personal home. I'm not sure what is more amazing -- that this was someone's personal residence, the superior quality of the collection, or that a place like this still exists today much as it did at the turn of the century. It truly is a museum like no other. Forget ropes, barriers, organization, and the formality of a traditional museum. This was Frick's residence and as such the artwork is displayed much as regular person would. No guides, no formal traffic pattern. If anything, this lack of formality is the magic of this collection and home. It's quite soothing. Rooms are still set up much as their original functions, such as the study and the dining room. By all means, pick up an audio guide. You're missing a lot of background information about how the collection and house were put together that enhances the experience. Also, do try typing in random #s into the audio guide similar to the #s you see posted. In doing so, you'll hit information about exhibits which aren't currently on display but are still quite fascinating. A few notes: To maintain the ambiance, attendance is limited and queues can be long at the beginning and ending of temporary exhibits. Even at peak times, the queue does move reasonably fast and the experience is worth the wait. Photography is NOT allowed under any circumstances (which is a shame, but I understand their reasoning).
Very nice. I wasn't sure what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised. I would recommend seeing this attraction.

The finest art museum that's not crowded. An extrarodinary art collection in a classic, private home. Near the museum mile yet less travelled, it's easy to visit and a special treat for art lovers. NYC's best kept art secret.
Perfect when you have a limited amount of time. Liked the size and appreciation of the variety of artists present. Enough to leave you in awe at a pace to soak it all in.
small. it was really small. the renoir exhibit that was so well-advertised and promoted was just a few pieces. very disappointing.
Wonderful attraction in NYC. Excellent alternative to the larger museums and galleries. Wonderful art and antiques with a glimpse into the way the Frick family lived. Highly recommend.
Beautiful surroundings and great art. Nice intimate setting to see a very high quality selection of art. Be sure to catch the short film describing the origins of the museum.

Small Gem with Magnificent Paintings. Take a half hour to an hour and visit this lovely mansion turned museum on 70th street with its pretty rose garden and green lawn. The paintings are fabulous. The house itself is somewhat dark and formal. You can only go through the first floor, but the view of the staircase and organ are superb!
Love the collection!!. A beautiful collection located in a lovely artistic environment
Gem of a small museum.. I have been going to the Frick since I was a student (over 50 years), and still enjoy it. Small enough to see in a short visit, but containing some wonderful art.
Love the Frick. Even though some pictures had been moved we renewed our love affair with the Frick and still find it one of the very best small museums in the world.
interesting collection. Surprising to see how much is there! A period of collecting history unveiled
Beautiful museum with a gemof a collects. The building alone is worth a visit, but the permanent collection is verycomprehensive and beautifully displayed.

well worth it. Loved this beautiful home-now museum. If you are easily overwhelmed by large art museums, this collection of masters is very manageable in less than two hours. The home itself is worth the visit.

beautiful but a little stuck in the past. the collection is magnificent, but I felt like the museum could do more to engage you with the collection. The map of the collection is pretty basic ... I would have liked to learn more about how the collection was built. Felt like some of the rooms in the museum were pretty shabby ... needs a little upkeep!
A real gem!. This is a must for all art lovers. Stunning collection in a beautiful home on Fifth Avenue. Take the audio guide!

upper east side - right at the entrance to central park at 70th and 5th avenue. the admission price is worth it just to see the architecture - rooms set up as if house is occupied - collection of art is over the top and arranged in a lovely fashion. Loved, loved the Whistlers

Best Museum in New York?. Small, intimate, with a fabulous permanent collection and ever changing special exhibitions. Don't miss it. New Yorkers should go a couple of times a year and out of towners should go whenever they're in the city. You can do the whole thing in a couple of hours (or less) and not end up with museum fatigue.

Three Vermeers Plus. This is the former home of the industrialist Frick and his family. The setting is across the street from Central Park and this is a lovely small museum. On Sundays from 11-1 you pay what you wish. There is also a film bio about Frick which is worthwhile.
Beautiful. Very beautiful and elegant interiors with some outstanding artworks. A blissful retreat from the hubbub of the city.

The cherry on top of the Big Apple. Escape the crowds heading for the mega galleries and enjoy the quiet ambience - and extraordinary collection - of the Frick. Perhaps this the one place in the City that gets that big isn't always best, the Frick is about the right pieces, hung the right way in a scale that is human, yet heavenly. The building itself is a work of art: not in a show-stopping Guggenheim kind of way, rather a more European elegance. It feels relaxing to walk the floor of the Frick, not like you're being harried by the next person keen to get a snap of whatever artwork you're enjoying, as is the case at some of the other galleries. Indeed, photos aren't allowed. A sensible decision: if you want to see a photo of a pic, go on line - you're here to enjoy the real thing, not through a viewfinder.Great collection. Great space. Find yourself here.
Surprising. Interseting house with superb art collection. History of property interesting.

Very nice museum. I visited this museum for the second time. Beautiful building and collection. This time I enjoyed the Renoir exhibition. It is worth going on Sunday between 11 and 1 (pay what you want). The queue was long but it did not take more than 20 min. to get in

The Jewel in the Crown. If New York is the Crown when it comes to museums, than the Frick Collection is the often overlooked jewel in the collection. The mansion itself, once home to collector Frick, is beautiful in and of itself, but the paintings inside testify to a man with an eye for art. There are two magnificent portraits by Titan, a superb Velazquez, a self-portrait by Rembrandt, and works by Bronzino, Goya, Ingres, Turner, and more. The rooms and their furnishings compliment the paintings--the Rococo Room decorated with murals by Fragonard boasts 18th century furniture and Sevre porcelain. There are no tours or docents so one can actually contemplate the art one is viewing and the beautiful loggia is so quiet one can hear the water gurgle.

Right size, right everything. A real oasis and great experience, mainly because it's a very personal collection. An astonishing collection of big-hitters on display - although a bit chocolate box at times - and the size of it (not too big or too small) makes it perfect for an end-of-afternoon experience.

Perfect NYC Museum When You Don't Have All Day". This is my one of my favorite places to take out of town visitors! Beautiful artwork, magnificent furnishings and a wonderful place to visit when you don't have all day to spend wandering around a museum. There are beautiful paintings in the permanent collection and it's set up as a home....much like it was at the turn of the century...hard to imagine living in such a place!

Beautiful small museum. The Frick collection is a beautiful museum of art housed in a former mansion. Unlike larger art museums, it is very manageable to see in an hour or two. The collection of classical works of art include the old masters: Renoir, Turner, Vermeer, to name only a few. All are displayed in their original setting in a Fifth Avenue mansion at East 70th Street. The interior of the mansion boasts an indoor courtyard where one can sit on a bench and enjoy the peace of a quiet garden surrounding a pool.
Wow. I was overwhelmed by the paintings, let alone thefurniture and statuary. Incredible!

Often Overlooked Top NY Attrraction....Frick Collection. As a native New Yorker I have seen almost everything the City has to offer. I have many favorite spots to visit but over the years, the most tranquil and culturally powerful place I have ever visited is the Frick Collection. In the lower 70's on the East Side it is situated right across from Central Park. It has an old museum look to it, with an incredible Victorian Mansion entrance and the best selected works of many of the world's greatest artists. Henry Clay Frick, the indistrialist and philanthropist collected many of the most incredible paintings his world had to offer. Constable, Vermeer, El Greco, Van Gogh and Velazquez are displayed to name just a few. The presentation and the flowing rooms allow an individual plenty of time and space to study the works in detail. The neighborhood that surrounds the museum is chic and inspiring, setting the scene for what one sees inside. It is economical and you are under no time constraints should you wish to linger at a painting! Don't miss this New York Treasure!!!

Fantastic Art Collection, in a lovely home. The Frick is my favorite museum in NYC. It's small enough to be manageable in a few hours, but every single piece is of high quality and beautiful. Mr. Frick's guide for collecting was that it had to make him feel good, and you can see that in the art. An extra treat is seeing the mansion Frick built. Don't miss the short movie in the music room for quick overview of Frick and his collection

Great little museum. If you like to see your fine art in bite size...versus the Met...this is the place. Not only is the art work beautiful but the building is beautiful too, as David H says. It's a must see gem if you are visiting NYC and want a 1-2 hour time to relax and enjoy the wonderful art.

Best small art museum in Manhattan. It's both the collection and the setting that makes the Frick a gem to be visited time and again. Astonishing Old Master collection, with gems by Rembrandt, El Greco, Velasquez, Bellini, Holbein, Van Dyke,Turner--and three Vermeers! Set in Frick's baronial mansion, one get's a sense of the Old New York of Henry James and Edith Wharton, and the indoor conservatory is restful. There are interesting small rotating exhibits, and no annoying commercial enterprises (just a small museum shop). A must-see for any art lover.
it's all about the building. It doesn't really matter what they're showing, but the building is an oasis of calm away from the noise of NY. Just lovely.

A small and nice to visit museum. Its a small museum in Central ParkIt has a nice collection of paintings and it's great for people that get tired or "lost" in big museums.You can visit the place in a little more than 1 hour.I recommend it
Great collection. Wonderful building and interesting collection, including paintings by one of my favourite artists, Vermeer. A little gem.

Small museum but worth the visit.. This museum has a nice permanent collection as well as different exhibitions. It is in an attractive setting and right by Central Park. It is easy to see it all in a reasonable amount of time.
Excellent Museum. The expansive display of old master paintings,namely rembrandt.
Nice. Nice place to go if you have a spare hour and working your way down museum mile.
worth a special trip. it is amazing to see what the robber-barons could buy at the turn of the centuryinclude this collection in your nyc plans

The art is ok, but the house!. Ah - the house... the exhibits are ok if not great (the scuptures were in my personal opinion the best part), but the pleasure of walking within this amazing house, with the original decoration... Worth the visit. Too bad one cannot visit the 2nd floor!

Small but packed with amazing artworks. Look up the history of this establishment before visiting so you get a sense of the quality of the amazing artwork and sculpture on display. Unlike the Museum of Art or MOMA, this is a smaller building with so many important works. Not to be missed.

Fascinating house and collection. Worth the $18 entry so don't bother queueing on sunday morning for the free time unless you have to. The free audio guide is a must. The garden atrium is not as good as Isabella Stewart Garnder's in boston but still impressive.

A Brilliant Gem. if the Met is too big, the beauty of the Frick is that it is just the perfect size for a one-time museum visitor. Fascinating to see the house, the objects and paintings, and learn a bit of the history of Frick (and Carnegie)

Great Renior exhibit at the Frick. Visited the Frick Museum on a recent trip to NYC. It is not too far away from the Met, so I was able to easily walk to the Frick after an earlier visit to the Met.Henry Clay Frick was an astonishingly wealthy guy who bought up a city block for his house and art collection. It was very interesting to walk through his mansion and see the various pieces of artwork that he collected. He must have been one very interesting guy. For me the highlight of the trip was a special Renior exhibit that was on display during my visit. One large salon of the mansion was dedicated entirely to Renior paintings that had been brought together from a wide variety of museums. So not only were the pieces excellent, having them all in one place at one time was extraordinary.Regrettably no photos were permitted anywhere in the Frick. Very enjoyable and very interesting. However I would scale back my high marks for the Frick if the Renior exhibit had not be there. Still worth a visit however. A real glimpse back in time to the early part of the 20th Century.

The Frick is a Kick. Probably one of my favorite museums in all of NYC because of the venue. See a fantastic art collection in one of the only surviving great homes of the robber barons. My only ethical problem is that Frick in real life was, well, it rhymes with his name.

Frick Worth the Trip. Lovely, small museum, where you can walk between rooms or rest in big foyer; many varied exhibits, small spaces and large. Make sure you read the history of this museum--one of the last Roaring 20's mansions still operating and maintained. Bathrooms easy to locate, small gift shop with great, reasonably priced books, postcards, etc..Great thing: You can buy tickets in advance and "do" this museum all in one day easily.

If you only have time to visit one art collection make this the one. An exquisite collection of the world's finest artists housed in impeccably elegant surroundings and minus the hordes of museum mile. There are finer works and in greater numbers elsewhere but the unity of this collection is unsurpassed. Bellini's St Francis, Holbein's Thomas More and Rembrandt's Polish Rider are the popular pieces but there are also works by Cimabue, El Greco, Goya, Hals, David and Ingres. My own favourites are a group of Turner's harbour views and a clutch of subdued Dutch landscapes which lose little in comparison with the Constables situated nearby. The sculpture collection is similarly tasteful; look out for the small Michelangelo casually placed on a viewing table amongst other works and minus the ubiquitous fanfare. In fact, when you appreciate the collection in its entirety even the preponderance of Boucher and Fragonard seems a forgivable lapse.

An eclectic collection of amazing quality and depth. Art lovers visiting New York City are spoilt for choice but this gem is one that deserves your time. Accommodated in a delightful early 20th century home located near Central Park, the Frick Collection was amassed by an industrialist of wide-ranging and exquisite taste in the visual arts. Because it is a much smaller collection than the vast assemblages of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and MOMA, it is comfortably viewed in a few hours, in a setting of domestic scale and ambience.Works include icons from the early Middle Ages,small bronzes, porcelains, ceramics and works by European masters and the Impressionists. The rooms of the home are all furnished and decorated with the same care and taste as charactersies the collection.

Surprisingly great!. Small museum which has an impressive collection of paintings, ceramics, sculptures. Highlights were the portrait of Thomas More by Hans Holbein the Younger and the self-portrait of Rembrandt. The rooms themselves are impressive. Definitely not to be missed!
quaint little museum. I really enjoyed this museum. I was actually charles fricks home. Great collection. Saw a band member from The Rolling Stones while we were there!

My favourite. Possibly my favourite galleries anywhere in the world: an exquisitely tasteful collection of top quality pieces by a broad variety of artists from a number of periods. Small enough to delight my eleven year old on his first visit too
A little gem!. Always wonderful. Building itself is worth the visit.

Disappointing. I was really looking forward to this, but it turned out rather dull and not at all what I thought gilded age robber baron house would look like. If you've seen the Versailles, the art here is a bit like a really poor version of it. The house is big, and... big.

One of the best museums. Don't miss this wonderful art collection housed in a magnificent turn of the century mansion. The art and architecture were equally amazing.There is so much to see and every turn of a corner has another feast for the eyes. I can't wait to return.

My favorite. I loved this museum. It was recommended by my nephew as a do not miss. My husband left at lunch, I went back and spent about 2 more hours. Not so large that you can't see everything you wish in one visit.
Old World Grace. There is no finer museum in NY City. The collection and the setting are superior. First class works of art.
Cool house great history.... An amazing collection of art and furnishings. Check out the indoor garden with lily pond.

Small but Top-Notch Collection. This is one of my favorite museum's It's mainly what one -very- rich man collected. There've been some additions since, and temporary exhibits. We saw some beautiful Renoirs that were passing through. But the Rembrandts, Grecos, the Turners, and even the other Brits were pleasing to the eye, and the mansion is has it own appeal, too. It's a collection that can be viewed in an hour or two; but you can also linger for much longer just relaxing and taking it all in.
Wonderful collection and house. The house itself is worth seeing. Wonderful " Old Master"paintings and decroative arts.

Beautiful, interesting and amazing collection of artworks in one building which is itself a work of art.. If you can visit on a Sunday from 11 am to 1 pm, pay what you wish, this is amazing value for the works you can view. Ladies especially, visit a restroom beforehand though, because there can be a long queue! The gift shop has many nice items too!

Beautiful home showcasing incredible collection!. Don't miss this! Small by museum standards but packed with history and an amazing collection of art. You can enjoy this on your own with great, free audio or have a docent guided tour.

Great collection in an unusual setting.. Varied and interesting collection displayed as if the building was still a private home. Particularly liked the Holbeins of More and Cromwell. Well worth a visit.
Good collection for a small place. Loved seeing specific paintings like Holbein's 'Thomas Cromwell' and 'Thomas More' and Manet's 'The Bullfight'.
Beautiful house. The art was wonderful but seeing the beautifully furnished mansion was better, Good view of Central Park.

Magnificent. Small (relative) but breathtaking collection of European paintings from all epochs in a wonderful building. Every single item on its own would be the envy of any major collection. Together they are all like a dream. Very calm atmosphere and no crowds.
A cultural oasis. A perfect combination of a mansion and an eclectic art collection. A calm alternative to the Met.

Quite a collection. We took in the Frick Collection during the 'pay what you choose" time on Sunday between 11am and 1pm. There was a 10 minute line to get in but once we were inside, we were able to view the collection without feeling crowded. The Mansion itself was spectacular.

Art within reach. The Frick Collection is warm and inviting; you can feel that this once was someone's home. The collections are smaller than other museums, but well worth the visit. It is art in an unpretentious display and atmostphere.
Tranquil. A beautiful house. Very tranquil and a lovely atrium to relax in.
A Great Experiance. Great Collection, very realaxing to walk around and view the works.
Outstanding art collection. A bit like a National Trust house, but the quality of the paintings exceeds anything I've seen in the NT.

Beautiful Building. This a gorgeous building to visit from the grand manor architecture.
You feel like you are in Europe but don't tell that to a European.

I never miss the Frick!. I never miss touring through the Frick mansion, interior gardens and exquisite art collection when I visit New York. Walking into the cool, high-ceilinged, marble-everywhere interior gives me goosebumps, as if I'm suddenly transported inside a European art gem. I never tire of getting up close and personal with the incredible Rembrandts, Vermeers, Franz Hals, de Goyas, etc.

An art oasis in the heart of Manhattan. The Frick is a sublime collection of art from all periods, housed in an awesome mansion just a few blocks south of the Met Museum. The paintings and art objects are not grouped chronologically, but reflect the tastes of the original owner, Henry Clay Frick. The portrait of Thomas More stands out for its realism (stubble on chin!) and insight into his character. Highly recommended for a cultural break from the noise and bustle of the city. The gift shop is understocked and overpriced.
quirky. great collection, gorgeous central courtyard, spend some time soaking it all up
A gem. A hidden gem! So easy to manage and a great Renoir exhibit.
What a surprize!. We saw a Renoir exhibit which is amazing. If it has left, still go. The Frick is across from Central Park in a big beautiful old house.

Blissful quiet in busy New York.. Housed in a beautiful former dwelling, this was a private collection in former times. The house used to have a courtyard bounded by buildings on three sides, and this has now been turned into a very attractive sitting area with a pool, fountain and plants. The rooms house the art collection, which has some vey notable pictures ~ a couple of Holbeins amongst them, and a Constable, which I was very proud to view, since I live in Constable country back here in England. I was surprised to find that you are given a free hand held talking guide, and each exhibit is numbered to correspond with the commentary, so you can view the artefacts (some sculptures and fine porcelein as well as paintings) in any order. The whole atmosphere is one of peace and tranquility. A superb little collection and well worth a visit.
A little known must see. Very worth while and across the street from Central Park. Took about 3 hours to go through.
Well worth the visit!. Lovely museum... Check out the exhibit... You will not be disappointed. if there in May the wisteria is wonderful... Take a picture for the memories!

What a gem!. Can you believe some people have never been here? Renoir, Constable, Vermeer, and more all tucked into a beautiful home on 5th Avenue. It is never too crowded to take your time and enjoy. Plus the museum is filled with beautiful furniture and other objects de art.

Very short visit. My husband wanted to see this. There was a free audio tour, and we seriously erred in not using it. But by the time we realized our error, we were tired from all the walking we had done that day.The building is beautiful and the artwork is gorgeous. I wish they allowed some photography, and entrance to the garden. I don’t think it was worth $18, though.
Europe in New York City. I felt as though we were in Europe! There is quite an interesting collection of French paintings

Unmissable. A jewel of a museum. I've been to NY twice in my life. I've visited the Frick twice. I love it. Such fabulous treasures. If you are going to see only one museum in NY, see this one. I waited all these years to finally see Holbein's Sir Thomas More looking down at me - it was worth the wait. Superb. Walk up the east side of Central Park to get there, to make sure you maximise your enjoyment of the visit.

Beautiful art in an intimate space. This seemed to be a low-key museum compared to the scale of the others in Manhattan but the collection was fantastic. The interior is lovely and the Garden Court particularly impressive.

Europe in New York. This is a fabulous "Boutique" museum. After visiting the larger museums in NYC it was so pleasant to go to The Frick and be taken back in time to a period of elegance and learning. The art collection is superb and wide ranging. From wonderful bronzes to seaside paintings by artists that I was not familiar with I was enthralled. Do not miss the three Vermeers that are there--very rare to have three paintings by Vermeer in a private collection. This collection is truly a gift to NYC. Admission is free on Sunday from 11-1. We tried to pay and the sweet girl charged us a "student" rate even though my husband and I were in NYC celebrating my 56th birthday.

Okay Collection. Not much here for the art lover except perhaps the Renoir collection. It's a dark place with some rather dark (meaning not enlightening) paintings. I suggest the Musee d'Orsa in Paris.

Very interesting - worth a visit. The Frick Collection is well worth seeing and is a very nice experience. We went on a Sunday before 1pm when it was free to enter but I would have been happy to have paid to see the collection.

Truly elegant. The collection here, in the former mansion of Henry Clay Frick, is relatively small compared to museums like the Met, but it is of high quality. Beautiful Renaissance and Impressionist paintings, furniture, sculpture and furnishings. It is not nearly as overwhelming as the larger museums, and can be taken in entirely in less than two hours. Even if the museum were empty of all the artworks, it would still be worth the visit for the beauty of the mansion itself. Would probably be No. 1 or 2 on the second tier of museums to visit in New York.

Nice but ordinary. In a sence everything is nice inside , but for those visitors coming from Europe this can be one of the thousants mansions found around Europe (without calculating the numerous palaces and castles) . Obviously in New York this is a rarity and atracts visitors. Especially the period we visited the place when a Renoir exibition was on. Nevertheless in " a rainy day" it is a good option.

Industrial Era Art Treasure. Step back into time and experience life during the Industrial Era. Mr.Frick did us all a favor by leaving his home and his fantastic art collection to be available to the public. If you are not already a fan of Whistler, I'll bet you will be after a visit to The Frick.
Renoir!. Great to see the Renoir, the Hans Holbein of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, Rembrandt, etc. Great collection and not as exhausting as Met.

Well worth a visit. If you've got a spare few hours and enjoy visiting museums and galleries, you should certainly check out the Frick Collection at the edge of Central Park.It's a beautiful house and it's lovely to see the art collection in situ amongst the furniture and stylings of the family who lived there....this makes it a bit different to just walking round an art gallery. I was amazed by some of the art that's there that I recognised as well. Frick amassed quite an impressive collection of a range of very beautiful pieces!I think it's good value. You get quite an all-round experience of the pieces of art themselves, the architecture and design of the house and the story of Henry Frick and his vision. You get a free audio guide which you would pay a extra for in most places. They did seem quite strict on enforcing the rules but why not... it's probably why it's been maintained so well!! It didn't take me long to get around - maybe a couple of hours at a very leisurely pace. It's quite nice to go somewhere a bit smaller and more manageable if, like me, you are also visiting the vastness of some of the other enormous museums and galleries in NY.

Very special place. Yes, there are a lot of really great museums and galleries in New York but this one is very special. I come here often with my kids (13, 14) and even and each time they love it. We stroll through the rooms, talk about the paintings and have a great time. I get a headache at the MET, it is really overwhelming, I can take it for a couple of hours tops. This feels like a visit to someone's home. The mansion itself is very beautiful, amazing that it is in the heart of such a busy city. Note that kids under 10 are not admitted. Great place to start your day and go for a walk and lunch in the park.

Outstanding Mansion and Art. One of my favorite tourist sites in NYC. Do you go to discover the lovely intricate architecture of the house or the outstanding collection of art? You decide! Either way, you're in for a treat. Many folks probably have walked by the Frick Mansion on the way to the MET and didn't realize that it was there. How unfortunate! This is one of the world's best "small collections" of art all of which are displayed in a house that will amaze you with the finest of architectual details. Visit between 11:00am-1:00pm on Sunday and the admission is free!

Old money into new joys for art lovers. Henry Clay Frick made his money in coke and still in Pittsburgh. BTW, there is a wonderful Frick house to visit there. Ill health had and union problems had him move to Manhattan. Upon his death, he left his house and his art collection to the public. There are some impressionist paintings, but the bulk of the collection is a joy for lovers of Dutch and Flemish art, located in a wonderful house with some of the original furniture. You will find yourself going back there over and over again. Admission is steep, but it's worth it.
hidden gem. saw a renoir exhibit that was lights out.great place and free audio tour

Great museum, Rude staff. The Renoir collection was fantastic. They advertised that they were going to be open until 6:00 the day we went due to the special Renoir showing. However, the staff started closing down early, and refused to let my wife take one last look at the Renoirs at 5:45. We were disappointed with their rudeness.

A Unique Art Museum. There's something for every art lover here: paintings galore (Rembrandts, Vermeers, and more) gorgeous Limoges pieces, antique furniture, vases and sculpture. There is even an indoor courtyard/pond with orchids.Sign up at the docent desk for a small group tour if it's available. The Renoir exhibit is stunning.
small but great. a very easily done museum with a gorgeous collection
A Gem. Just gorgeous, a special treat. Renoir collection on display. The art and home/furnishings are not to be missed.

My Favorite Museum in NYC. I love this museum! The fact that it is located in a once private home and is close the Central Park makes it all the more appealing. It is well maintained and the courtyard is beautiful. My daughters, both art history buffs, were amazed at the scope of the eclectic collection, with so many of the pieces in art history books. The presentation is flawless. The size is not overwhelming, making it an easy 2 hour visit. Mr. Frick was truly a visionary in creating this for generations to come.
A wonderful collection. Just small enough to enjoy without being saturated with excellence!
See the special Renoir exhibit. Currently (Spring 2012) showing a wonderful Renoir full-length protraiture exhibit. Worth the visit.

Wonderful Collection, Not Exhausting. As other reviewers have mentioned, three Vermeers and many other works that I've seen described in art history courses. The size is manageable and the crowd wasn't overwhelming. Perhaps I've been spoiled with less expensive museums in Europe - $18 seemed expensive. I might try the 'pay what you want' hours next time. There will definitely be a next time!
One of New York's Crown Jewels. This is a world class collection of old masters and other classic art housed in a palatial gilded age mansion. Don't miss it.
One word - Beautiful. This house/museum houses a true collection. While most museums have "theme" collections - Mr. Frick collected what he liked - a true collector.

Small, but perfect. What a grand house! Not a large museum, but full of treasure. A very rich mans pleasure dome.The highlight, for me, was to see the original Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell facing each other across the fireplace. So pleased to have seen the original, knowing that I'll never see them anywhere else.My only complaint (!) was that the single Renoir was not on view.

A mansion becomes a museum. An amazing collection in a classy old mansion. It was quite impressive, walking around the old home imagining someone actually living there. And although there were a lot of people crowding the space while we were there, we enjoyed exploring the collection.
My Favorite Museum. This museum has an outstanding collection that can be seen in a couple of hours.
elegant and accessible. I love this collection because it is small and well put together. I've been there several times this winter andenjoyed the special exhibits.

Excellent museum to visit in NYC. It is a little museum compared to the MET but that doesn't mean you should bypass it if you ever come visit NYC. It has a great number of exhibits and it is very quaint and pretty. It's almost like someone's big mansion. Really beautiful! Just beware that there's always a line to get in!
Fabulous Renoir show. See it if you can. And enjoy the opulence of the Frick and its many attractions.

loved it - much more than just art. My husband and I knew we wanted to go to the Frick, but figured it was just another art gallery. We had no idea it was his home turned into museum. The rooms are gorgeous - loved the garden area in the middle of the house. It was so beautiful and relaxing. Not only is the art fantastic, but the house, furniture, and atmosphere made for an absolutely enriching afternoon. We highly recommend a stop here. It is not a place for the young ones. Mature preteen/teens will be fine - even attending with friends or by yourself would be great.

Beautiful Collection. The Frick Collection was my first fine art museum that I visited in NYC and I was delighted! Besides the wonderful paintings, the furnishings and details of the beautiful mansion added considerably to the experience.

Like Home If You Were Filthy with Lucre. The Frick is the perfect museum - bite-sized so you are not exhausted after a visit, and yet replete with the greatest treasures you can imagine - three (!) Vermeers, good god! And my personal favorite painting in all the universe, Memling's Portrait of a Man.
Great museum. I loved all the masterpieces here and have been back several time. It's also nice that it is on the smaller size and you can see the whole museum in two hours or so

A gem of a museum in a gem of a building. After many visits to NYC and walking by it, visiting The Frick was a long overdue treat. The permanent collection is spectacular and the building is gorgeous and tranquil. The Renoir exhibit is well worth your time

Renoir Exhibit - wonderful. Have visited the Frick many times, and have always enjoyed visits there. There happened to be a Renoir show on, and we had seen some of the paintings in the exhibit, but not all. It was great to see all of them, and to revisit other pieces in the wonderful Frick. A jewel in New York

Frick is worth visiting. The Frick Collection is definitely worth seeing, and the audio comes with the price of admission. The bathroom situation, however, is deplorable. The lines are very long, especially for women, and because of the long lines our time actually viewing the collection had to be limited.
Beautiful, historical house with wonderful art. We didn't have enough time to see it all. Did enjoy the current Renoir exhibit and a quick walkthru of the house. WIll definately return!
Secret gem. I don't want to share this lovely private home collection. An oasis in the busy city
SMALL AND AMAZING. The house was stunning. It's like visiting a wealthy friend with an amazing art collection. Better than a large art museum on many levels.

Interesting, small and in a beautiful surrounding. I liked it very much, because it's not only interesting seeing the paintings but also the house, the huge residence and it's next to Central Park so great for a nice walking afterwards.
Well worth the time. Don't overlook this historic collection that reflects the great taste of an art-loving industrialist and the heirs who lovingly preserved his bequest to us all
My favorite NYC museum. A beautiful collection in a beautiful setting. While the collection is quite diverse, it is small enough to view everything in one visit.

My favorite painting in the world. Bellini's St. Francis is my favorite painting in the world and I visit him whenever I go to NYC. The old mansion that houses the Frick collection is the perfect size for an hour (or two) visit. No cafe, so eat and drink before you go. On Sundays, "pay what you want" between 11 and 1, so it's a bargain.
A Gem. Bellini's St. Francis is one of the greatest paintings of all time. The museum is a gem in NYC, and is an oasis of calm. Treat yourself.

Excellent collection in a beautiful building. A superb collection in a gorgeous old NY mansion. Just the right size for a couple of hours visit. Be sure to take the audio guide and watch the intro film.
I love the Frick Collection. Beautiful furnishings and art. Displayed in Frick's house near Central Park, the art is displayed in and interesting way.
Nice Collection. Very nice collection . The exhabition is nice The Rembrandt pictures are amazing

Always a joy. It is always wonderful to spend time in the Frick and never more than now with the room of Renoirs on display. The permanent collection is incomparable and the current show enhances the experience. A glimpse into a lost world that I would have loved.

Must visit!. A beautiful collection of artifacts and paintings by one person. Also very well preserved considering how old and precious some of the objects are. See Rembrandts, Reniors, porcelain, clocks, sculptures and much more close upfront and enjoy this collection, and if you go on a Sunday morning from 11-1 it is pay what you wish. Just be careful about the weather, if it is raining or cold, and people do not want to be outside like at Central park, there forms a long line at this collection and you might have to wait.
beautiful collection in a fabulous former home. the frick is fabulous. the house itself is amazing and the collection fantastic. catch it soon and you will see the renoir exhibit

Magnificent art collection in beautiful setting. If you want to go to an art museum that is not overwhelming in size or scope, this is it. You will see a collection of masters from around the world in an industrialist's home setting. Make sure you get the hand held audio device- it adds a lot to your knowledge with just the right amount of information.
Excellent museum. Very civilized place and an excellent range of art works in a lovely setting. Not a large museum so maybe an hour and a half. A minute away from Central Park so take a stroll after.

NY's most stately museum. An incomparable collection is a glorious home. If you can get over the fact that it was built on the backs of abused coal miners, it is one of NY's loveliest, most genteel experiences.
Beautiful!. We saw the Renior exhibit, which is just lovely and worth a visit if you like the style. The Frick is elegant and delightfully snooty!
Beautiful building and collection. a nice size museum for a morning visit. The Frick home is beautiful and his art collection varied

Nice Museum in Pretty Setting. We took a tour of the Frick Museum and enjoyed it very much. The setting in an old house is part of what makes it special. We also enjoyed the art itself and the stories about both the house and the pictures.

Fabulous and for me relaxing. I have enjoyed the Frick on several occasions. In the chaos that Manhattan can be this is a spot to slip into and enjoy the calm and serenity. Once inside you enjoy the beauty of the art collection, the home itself and for me I marvel each time at this spot of solitude and restful calm in the heart of such a bustling part of the city.

prepare to spend all day. there is nothing not to love about this place. no matter what your fancy from art to antiques to architecture, this place is amazing. the view into central park made me feel like a child again, i wanted to burst through the doors and play- very informative audio provided though pick and chose what you want to listen to or it will take days to get through this wonder

A small gem. For those who are overwhelmed by huge museums like the Metropolitan Museum of art, the Frick is more accessible, but still of very high quality in their offerings. They have a large collection of art which they continuously rotate so the art is always changing and interesting. In my opinion, one should see both museums, just devote more time, over several days, to the Met. You can do this one in one afternoon.

You won't be disappointed. An amazing art collection that grew out of a chapter of the "new" wealth of the American industrial era. Enjoy each work. Take it in. Walk slowly. Sit, rest and repeat. Definitely see, also, the film about Frick's business practices and how his fortune and the art collection were amassed.
Best Museum in Town. If you only have time to do one museum make it this one. Amazing art and antiques all in situ.

Superb!. A great way to spend a few hours looking at the antiques and artwork.... the house and gardens are also amazing. Visit on a Sunday and you can pay what you like, although visiting other days is only $18 which seems very cheap as other museums are a lot more expensive.

Finally, a doable in one day museum. Quaint in size but grand in stature, this was our first museum visit in NYC, on the recommendation of a family member, and it didnt disappoint - the audio guide is a must as it really brings the whole place to life. A wonderful feeling to walk out of a museum feeling like you really saw everything there was to see. Highly recommended

Take Advatage of "pay what you want on Sundays" from 11 am to 1 pm. While worth the expenditure, museaums in NYC are expensive, and probably cause some of our European firends to gasp. Sunday worked out very well with the "pay as you like" scheme. It's a great museum - but the reduced price (from $18.00) adds to the charm!

A Glorious Gem. The Frick itself is worthy of a visit and the collection is a bonus. The furniture, the sculptures and the paintings all demand attention. I fell in love with the Frick upon my first visit and returned again this year. MOMA, the Met are wonderful but the Frick makes you feel like a member of the Guilded Age!

Get To The Frick. This is one of the City's most amazing museums. The art collection is amazing; but, you mind will probably be consumed with thinking of how amazing this place was when it was a home. Now that was living!
Great art. Good to see an American collector's vision played out
Must see Rembrandts.. Great small museum with all the right artwork. Friendly and attentive staff. Well worth beating the crowds at other larger venues.

Beautiful Museum. Beautiful mueum, tour guides are friendly. Great option if you have already been to the big boys in town (Met, MOMA, Gugenheim). The mansion is beautiful, the art is lovely. Very nice way to spend an afternoon. Definitely not a full day type of museum.
Very nice. A lovely collection. $18 to get in which thought was a little expensive considering the price to get into the Met. A great Renoir collection.
great surprise. we went here on a tip from someone we knew and so glad we did, so intimate and beautiful, you will be surprised at the gems the Frick holds, worth the stop!

The best museum in Manhattan. This is a real gem and good value for Manhattan. It's quite small so if you are on a time schedule you can do the whole museum in about 2 hours including listening to the free audio guide. On this trip I only had time to do one museum and this was the one I chose.
a home museum!. you kind of forget you are in a museum as the art is displayed as it was when the place was the house of fortunate -literaly- Mr. Frick. my teenagers loved it!!!

One of my favourite places to visit in NYC. It's a very personal collection, set in what was formerly a private - and very grand! - home. Very manageable and not at all overwhelming. It was my third visit (over several decades) and didn't disappoint.

Renoir Exhibit and more. Full length Renoir paintings was our reason for visiting the Frick Collection, but there's so much more to see. In addition to multiple rooms of paintings from several different eras, visitors are welcome to visit the Frick home. Unfortunately, we had not left enough time to fully enjoy what the Collection and Home have to offer. We will return another time to see the house.
Fricking good!. Just loved it. Fantastic house, great paintings and so lucky to see the Renoir's full-size paintings - the best museum experience in NYC!
Excellent small collection in historic home. Wonderful small collection, great surroundings. Go.
A must go. Renoir exhibit is beautiful and to my surprise there were 3 Vermeer's there.

Great collection, excellent docents!. We visited on a Friday morning, just in time for the 11 am docent talk about the house. The talk was only 10 or so minutes long, but was very informative. We were invited to sign up for a private tour of the house, limited to 5 guests. The docent was Rory and he was excellent! It was great being able to see the house as part of a private tour. After, we retrieved free audioguides and spent more time visiting each piece of the collection. There is also a brief film about the collection that's worthwhile seeing. We had a great time and enjoyed the collection very much. They are very strict about backpacks, packages, coats, etc. I think they are 100% correct to be so strict. Many valuable pieces of Sevres porcelain are out on display- not behind glass or inside cases. So, it would be very easy for something to get bumped or broken. It was so nice being able to see these items out on display like they were meant to be instead of behind glass or inside a case.
Beautiful place. We loved the Frick Colletion. The house is wonderful. A great experience in NY.

Frick is a Intimate Museum. Beautiful collection of paintings in a millionaires private house on Fifth Ave. All furnishings are the way the family left them. Don't miss the living room with a El greco and a Rembrandt. The ladies dressing room with the beautiful Fragonard or Boucher wall panels.

NY's Finest Boutique Museum. This collection is what you want to share with those who have a limited attention span but want to see examples of some of the greatest art available. Pass into another era of privilege and see how the other half lived. Veteran museum goers will love the quality; less frequent visitors will marvel at how much they recognize. I take all my nieces/nephews who are older than 8 years of age here as their first foray into art. Don't miss the Holbeins.
a wonderful collection. the collection of the Frick family in its original home with new additions all the time: this month was Renoirdon't miss this very New York experience
Wonderful.. If you have enjoyed The Wallace Collection in London, you will love this as it is out of the same mould.Lovely atmosphere, beautiful house, wonderful displays......

Perfect museum. I just recently returned from a visit to NYC. I went to the Frick as they were displaying Renoir and other Impressionists in addition to their regular exhibit. It was great! And the best thing about it was that it is a perfect size for about a two hour visit. There was not so much on display that you couldn't take in the entire offering nor feel like you had missed anything. The Frick has Rembrandts, Turners, Renoirs, Desgas that are all displayed in a wonderfully elegant house that is truly one of the exhibits itself. This museum is a must-see in New York city"

Such a treasure for the architecture. The collection is good probably the drawings are the most exciting. But for me a k. The court yard is a must and to walk by the gardens facing 5th avenue in spring is very satisfying.

what a gem. I was so much looking forward to this small gem of NY Museum and wasn't disappointed. Located in a fantastic mansion with a wonderful peaceful inner courtyard one feels immediately transferred to 18th century NY. At the moment a stunning Renoir special exhibition. An absolute must see, as the mansion it self is so beautiful.

Wonderful little museum tucked into architectural gem. Ducked in here after 10 year absence while in Gotham visiting kids. What a delight. Don't miss. It's compact and quick but a beautifully curated collection in an equally beautiful home

Not like a museum. My aunt took me here when I was 18 years old and I have gone back five times already. It's not like a museum where the whole thing is roped off and behind glass. You actually feel like you are taking a tour of someone's home. I highly recommend it. Try to catch it when they have the organ player. Really awesome.
Brilliant. Liked everything, disliked nothing! Peaceful, tranquil and beautiful.

The Jewel in the Crown. The perfect museum for those who want some culture but not too much. This former private home of Robber Baron Henry Clay Frick still has elements of that history while providing outstanding examples of great fine art from the Renaissance to the 20th century. Easy to handle and easy to enjoy, not too big and not too small and in a wonderful location on Fifth Avenue. When the spring flowers are in bloom in the garden it's like a true jewel.
A perfect gem. The Frick is wonderful for being compact.Every item there is a wonderful example of its type.- Where else can you find three Vermeers.The current Renoir show is terrific.
Great variety, not a huge time commitment. Wonderful art museum, smaller, so much more manageable than the Met if you have limited time.

Like greeting old friends. What a wonderful place. After the hustle and bustle of MOMA this is a haven of peace and quiet (no children under 10 and no parties when we were there). The place seems to affect people positively - no-one stood in front of you when you were contemplating a picture and voices tended to be hush. The art is magnificent, with Vermeers, Turners, Constable etc, many familiar to all of us. The audio guide is excellent and not too lengthy. And you can walk in Central Park afterwards.

How the Other Half Lived and Collected. This beautiful mansion is full of the most famous paintings. The Fricks knew who and how to collect. Each room of their home on 5th Avenue and 70th Street is beautiful and filled with the finest art and furniture. The central garden court ,with its planting and fountain is a wonderful place to relax. Children under the age of 16(I think that is correct....please check on line) are not allowed. The good news is, if you are free on a Sunday morning, one can "pay what you wish" to enter this paradise.There is a small gift shop with an excellent choice of books and stationary.

Visit once. Wonderful piece of real estate. Insignificant collection. Lots of junk. The building should be preserved, but used for a different purpose. For instance this world class location could be used to house a better assembled collection of art and furnishings.
Sunday at the Museum. Very nice museum with a nice collection of work. Renoir exhibit was there and enjoyed seeing it again.
Lovely museum. Thoroughly enjoyed the Frick after hearing so many good things about it.

This Museum is a lovely gem. Lovely small museum, perfectly situated on the upper East side, not too far from the MET. Very lovely to tour since it is located in a former mansion. Definitely worth the visit
More Van Gogh, Renior, Rembrandt, etc.. Frick's will does not permit his art collection to travel. Therefore, you have to visit his beautiful house on Central Park to see a great art collection.

The house is the best part. Happy we went on Sunday between 11:00 and 1:00 so we could pay what we wanted. Had it not been for the house and the bonus Renoir exhibit I would have rated it lower. If you like religious art and portraits of marginally attractive people this is your place.
A small gem. This museum has the intimate atmosphere of a private home, which it once was. Try not to miss it!

Frick, apparently a bad guy, but has a really nice art collection. My fiancee and I spent about two hours in the collection this past weekend. It is pricey ($18) for how small it is, however, the collection is great. The famous portrait of Sir Thomas Moore was the highlight for me, as I have seen it dozens of times but never previously in person. There is a free audiotour which was very helpful in understanding the collection.
A good choice. I found this really interesting and the audios provided great information on many of the collections. Liked the fact that this had been someone's house.
wanna see the most expensive painting?. this is a great small and very sophisticated museum. you feel like you were invited to a private house of a very rich art lover
Small gem.. If you've been everywhere else, this makes for a very pleasant afternoon.

Frick exceeded expectations. Decided to visit the Frick Collection for a change from the usual large scale Museums. I'm so glad we did. The house itself is a work of art. And the collection is top notch. While we there, a special Renoir exhibition was the icing on the cake! Do the free audio tour. It makes a world of difference.

Not to be missed. I travel to NYC often but this last trip was the first time I made it to the Frick Collection. It is spectacular! The architecture of mansion itself is beautiful and the variety of art is quite amazing for the overall size of the building. There was a special Renoir exhibition during my visit that added to the wonderful experience.

The Best Museum Ever?!. We were recommended the Frick by so many people, who said that this is the one to have at the top of your list. We visited on a wet Saturday morning and found no queues, an excellent free hand held guide and an amazing collection. This is an truly very different museum, where you wander around this large mansion with all the works of art within easy reach and no ropes or barriers. You cannot fail but to be amazed. Allow a good 2 to 3 hours and you will never regret it.

It size is do-able; it's collection first class. This is a really user friendly art museum. It is not overwhelming in size. The quality of the collection is superb. I really enjoyed the video presentation of one of the works. It was the first time I had seen this approach.

don't miss it. This Park Avenue mansion holds awesome treasures in a polite and peaceful setting. Hans Holbein the Younger's portrait of Sir Thomas More is here, and many other very important art works and decorative arts.

Possibly my new favourite. Beautiful building, inside and out. Must check your coat (if you're not going to wear it) as well as backpacks and other large bags. Long line for tickets but it moved quickly (dont forget to use your uni ID if you have one!) Free audio tour on handheld devices provides interesting information that doesnt drag on. Differents forms of art (paintings, sculptures, furniture, etc) in different styles Italian Renaissance, French Impressionism, Baroque and so much more) many from famous artists that anyone would know. My advice to you would be to have Sunday brunch at st. ambroeus, head to Frick Collection for several hours (get in on the Sunday sketch action) and afterwards spend some time (window) shopping on Madison or strolling by the park.

This is a must-see small museum on your trip to New York. A beautiful collection of art and truly one of New York City's highlights, don't miss it. You can have a nice lunch in Manhattan and then go for an afternoon visit. Combined with a city stroll it is a relaxing way to spend a day in New York City.

Gilded Age mansion with awe-inspiring art. This gilded age mansion built by Henry Clay Frick, a 19th century industrialist, was designed to house Frick's magnificent art collection. It's hard to pick a favourite among a Rembrandt self-portrait, Van Dyke's portraits of Margareta and Frans Snyder, Bellini's St. Francis of Assisi. The list is endless and demonstrates Frick's determination to own the best. NOTE THAT CHILDREN UNDER 10 ARE NOT PERMITTED as the art work is not roped off and priceless works of art can be easily damaged.The mansion itself is a work of art. This is how the 1% lived in the pre-war era. A docent-led tour is well worth it. This museum is one of my favourites.

This opulent Fifth Avenue mansion holds an extraordinary collection.. At one time upper Fifth Avenue was studded with the mansions of New York society. The Frick mansion, as so many others, has been opened to the public and filled with priceless treasures. Here you can enjoy, in a home-like setting (albeit a splendid one) the works of the old masters, fine furniture, clocks, oriental carpets, textiles, porcelains and guilded mirrors. This is an atmosphere of slow savoring rather than frenzied viewing thus children don't do particularly well in this rarified ambience but adults find the space soothing. So if you like such artists as Bellini, Corot, Gainsborough, El Greco, Boucher and Whistler among others, spend some time in the thrall of the Frick.

Some of the World's Greatest Art in a Mansion Setting. You have seen some of the greatest art in the world from the Frick, but probably didn't even realize it.The Frick is housed in the mansion of essentially a steel baron from the turn of the last century. He used his vast wealth to build both the beautiful mansion and, far more importantly, acquire phenomenal artwork that formed the core of this museum after his death.This is not a large museum, as the art is in what were the dining room, living room, etc. of the house, but what there is is magnificent, and something for all tastes. There are the Holbein portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell displayed across from each other. Both are great in their own right, but the contrast is amazing. Even if your knowledge of that era is based on "the Tudors," you will awed at the characters displayed in these works.The other works include certainly one of the best Rembrandt self-portraits, and iconic paintings (you will recognize many of them) by El Greco, Renoir, Vermeer, Turner, and many others. There is also a great deal of sculpture and other decorative arts.There are times (such as Sunday morning) when you can get in at less than full rate, but it can get crowded.Grab one of the audio guides (they're free) when you come in. You simply punch in the number of whatever painting interests you and it will tell you 2-3 minutes about it. We found the descriptions to be very helpful and not laden with art appreciation jargon.Note that they don't allow children under 10 (I think part of it is the small statuary that is everywhere), but, frankly, young children probably wouldn't enjoy the Frick anyway. Young teens and older, however, should be fine.You can see the highlights of this museum in one to two hours. What distinguishes it from other attractions is that while it has many fewer pieces than other museums, what it has is all among the very best.
You can visit the Frick inside two hours. We have always liked the Frick - it is an easily manageable collection, and the quality of the art is very high.
An Art Gem. The Frick is a relatively little known, but absolutely superb museum in easy walking distance to its gigantic big brother up the street; The Met. Very strongly recommended.
Wonderful collection!. One of our favorite places in New York. Great art in a beautiful setting --don't miss the Frick!

Favorite part of my visit ~ hands down! Don't miss it.. Feel very fortunate to have visited the Frick; what a special place. Small enough to feel intimate yet still very impressive. My teenager came along as a courtesy and ended up loving the experience. Can't wait to return.
a small gem. don't miss this one! small and exquisite....home turned museum, always interesting exhibitions
FANTASTIC COLLECTION. If you like fine art, this is a not-to-miss gallery. Can be done in just a short time. Very well organized.
Amazing art. This is a wonderful private collection.Renoir Rembrant Turner Vameer Constable and many more all under one roof amazing !!! And the house is fantastic as well a must for art lovers.

Quality over quantity; an oasis of calm. Uncrowded, uninstitutional, and a real treat.
The audio guide is well done as is the welcome video which talks about (and lightly whitewashes) the history of the Frick fortune.
Mini Museum. One of my favorite, side adventures. Usually stop here on the way to or from the Met and Guggenheim, if I have time. It's a tiny jewel-box version of the National Gallery in DC.

An Art History Lesson in a Mansion. Whatever else you may think of the Frick Family, they have left us a legacy collection of 12th to early 20th century art that is second to none. They may not have a lot of stuff (walk up Fifth to the Met if you want to see a real lot of stuff) but every piece is perfect. And it is thorough. Interestingly, they have started to display paintings on a green background and the effect on the works is startling. Anyway, if you must go to one museum in NY, rank this one at the top of the list.
Fabulous!. This is a place I like to revisit. The Renoir exhibit currently on display is fantastic!

Nice Approachable museum.. A nce sized museum that is completely approachable. No overwhelming pretentsion that makes you uncomfortable. Some fabulous art work, with a periodic rotating collections. We visited during the Renior exhibition. Can be viewed in about an hour or so.
What a treat!. The combination of the architecture, inspiring interior decors (including stunning window treatments) made the display of beautiful artwork that much more enjoyable.

This was someone's house!. To think this gallery was some ones home at one time and now one of the most amazing collections of work that you most often see in art texts and coffee table books. If you have an appreciation for famous paintings and enjoy beautiful architecture and appreciate a bit of New York history, the Frick is for you. You will want to return again and again. I have visited the frick at least five times now and try to visit whenever I am in NYC. You do need at least three to four hours to really breathe in the ambiance and see some of the audio-visual presentations. Just to be in this marvelous mansion house is an experience itself. The foyer with it's fountains and folliage is a sight to behold.
A must see!. To think that this was somebodys home is amazing. What an exceptional collection of art and furniture in a truely beautiful setting- definately one of the best attractions in New York
A gem of a museum. A beautiful setting for some wonderful art. There is a Rembrandt self portrait and two Vermeers among other surprises. It was a small intimate place and we loved it.
Step back in time. Frick Collection is like stepping back in time and a window into another world! I wouldn't miss it for something a bit smaller scale in NYC and it's generally not too busy.
Don't miss. Loved this place, will go back next time in New York, make sure you take auto which is free. Allow all day to take it all in don't miss any of the auto.
Cultural NY and Old NY Grandure. Exceptional opportunity to see world-class iconic works of art and an exceptional home symbolic of 'old New York' grandure.

Fantastic collection, great history !. We visited last Sunday morning and we're delighted to learn they offer a "pay what you will" admission between 1am and 1pm ! I'd recommend to read some of the history prior to your visit, I dd so afterwards whne we returned home. While not comparable in scale to the Metropolitan, the Frick Collection has a most impressive collection of Degas, Monet, Turner, and many other favourites !
i hate this place. it's old lady art. i hate it. looks so promising from the outside. a lot of my friends love it though, so don't listen to me.

Why Didn't We Know About This Museum?. Our friends sugested we visit the Frick Museum but we had never heard of it. When they told us it contained three Vermeers my wife was sold on the idea. They also had a number of Renoir's, a Rembrandt and numerous other delights. I found a Dutch landscape painting by an artist named Hobemma that fascinated me and the Vermeers were stunning. It was a little pricey at $18 per entry, but well worth the visit. Each visitor was given a small pre-recorded tour to listen to; you accessed appropriate information based upon identifying number tags that were at the side of most paintings. It was so helpful, and if you didn't want to hear about any particular piece you just didn't enter its number. Sweet! There were a few rooms to be able to sit down when you got tired from standing. Those were especially nice for older patrons. Allin all, I would defintely visit there again.

my favorite museum. The history of the home, the (I forget how many) different types of marble, the paintings - and my favorite part is the atrium; you can sit and rest and listen to the fountains, and be transported. I visit this museum every few years and always find something new.

Radiant Renoirs. The Frick Museum in NYC is having a Renoir exhibit until May. It's only 9 of Renoir's full length paintings, but they are gorgeous. And the Museum is a fabulous place to visit for the other collections. What a beauty! If you go, get a ticket before and take the online view of the Renoirs. Very informative and you'll enjoy the collection much better. Also, when you get to the Frick, go the Media Room forst. It gives you some background on Henry Clay Frick.
a lovely smaller museum. I love the Frick. The building itself is so lovely, the amazing art is a bonus.

Nice setting, allows you to get fairly close to the works. I'm more of a modern or contemporary art fan, but how can one not be thrilled by some of the old masters?Well laid out space, I was surprised at how close you can get to the paintings. I think everyone will find their own moments and objects of fascination. I found two such things that totally enthralled me.Glad we went.

A great private collection in a fantastic setting. This is a must see for visitors to NYC. The collection of art is stunning and it is in a beautiful old home that has been very well preserved. Make sure you allow enough time to take it in.
Quaint collection. Great location and place to spend an afternoon seeing this lovely museum. Priced very reasonable.
Genteel, intellectual. Imagine living in an elegant mansion like this one! The art collection is well-curated.

Lovely morning at The Frick. Loved the combination of distinctive art in an unusual setting. Loved learning about the history of the home and the collector. A great "starter" museum for those not particularly fond of long visits to museums. Nice location near the park made for a nice walk, too.
