Wonderful!. Fantastic way to spend a day. For me, the Frick Collection leaves the MoMA in its dust! Everything is shown to best advantage. Relaxing, soul soothing transport to a world filled with beauty.

The house itself is worth the visit. My wife and I went to this museum on a quiet Sunday in February 2012. The art inside was incredible to look at, but I mostly enjoyed the mansion itself. This gilded mansion was worth the price of admission on its own and was the real star of the day.

Beautiful building and location. My first time at the Frick and it was really wonderful. The art collection is unbelievable and there's a wonderful garden in the middle to sit and relax. There was a wonderful Renoir special exhibit when we were there which made the experience even better. It's right across the street from the Park and an easy walk to the Boathouse restaurant before or after your visit. I can't believe that I've been to NY many, many times and only this last trip did I make it to this museum.

a most wonderful museum. It was a really lovely space and had some wonderful artifacts and the arrangement of the treasures was lovely as it was the way the collector had wanted. i loved the lack of a commercial ethos. No restaurant and the idea seems that if you want art come and enjoy if you want anything else go elsewhere

Terrific Experience. We spent several hours at this wonderful museum. Not only is the art worthwhile to see, the architecture also was fantastic. The period furniture was unique. I would highly recommend going here.
Renoir full portrait exhibit wonderful.. I love this place. There is so much to see. The Renoir exhibit was very good.

Wonderful Way to Spend a Morning. This was our first visit to the Frick; however, it won't be out last. We were fortunate to visit a special Renoir exhibit which consisted of 6 of Renoir's largest pieces. In addition, the entire house is filled with fine works of art including Matisse, Cassatte, Goya, and Hobein. The staff is eager to answer questions about the art and the house. This is a "must visit" when in NYC.

It is like walking about in your house looking at amazing ART. It is not a large mansion, but it feels like home, there is a courtyard and marble benches and yes a pond quietly nestled between everything else. Or am I imagining Pompeii's houses or the Getty mansion in Malibu. These are like fantasy homes and yet your eyes feast on the artistry of the ages. Beautiful collections surround you. Lovely to rest in Frick's home all that's lacking is a bit of tea and crumpets.
Maybe the best museum you haven't heard of. A small, intimate museum with a fabulous collection. Worth taking half a day (or a day) and visiting. The building architecture is worth the visit alone.
Enjoyable few hours. Just nice size for a visit, good collection. Enjoyable morning.

Well worth the visit. Good things come in small packages, and this is true of the Frick. You can get through here in an hour and really feel like you've had your dose of Culture. I saw the Renoir exhibition and while I've seen several of the pictures before, it was great to see 3 of the Dance series (City, Country and Bougival) side by side. Go on Sunday morning and pay what you can afford.

worth going. Frick has been closed for renovations so we were glad to go and see the Renoir exhibit which was beautiful. Frick has a great collection which we had fogotten and the building is really lovely.

A nice Sunday morning.... I had been before a few summers ago so I dragged the hubby here on their pay-as-you-wish morning. The highlight for me was the Renoir room, two of those were the most beautiful paintings I have ever laid eyes on. This is a small museum, as notable for the building as the collection, and you can see everything in about an hour. The audio tour and the video in the music room will really enhance your visit.

Frick: best kept art secret in NYC. 1. The Frick house is a museum by itself2. Frick standing art collection is worthwhile3. Look for special exhibits--like Renior in March 20124. Easy to get to, go early as it gets crowded

Go only for the paintings, not the experience. Went to see the Renoir exhibit at 2:45p today. Was kind of disappointed because it's only in one room (the East Gallery) and about 7 paintings. The Picasso exhibit was much bigger but fine, the works were beautiful. I sat down at the Garden Court at about 3:15p and was asked to leave because they were closing that portion for a special event. Then I noticed that the video wasn't available either. Come on! I paid the full price of $18 for 7 paintings and 45 min?? That's not cool so I asked the admissions lady if I could have a pass to come back another time. She was lovely and saw my point and turned to ask an older woman Isabel if she could. Haughtily Isabel commanded, "there are no paintings to see in the Garden Court and the video is on You Tube!" WOW!!! How unkind, un-accomodating! One thing is for sure....that is the LAST time I will pay $18 for admission. I'll be going on Sunday from 11a-1p and give a "pay what you can" of $1 because supporting ATTITUDE like that is worth much less!
Very nice museum. Really nice collection of paintings, furniture, bronze statuettes, etc. Small museum that you can do in a few hours and see everything, right on 5th Ave at Central Park.

GREAT NYC STOP!. Its located extremely convenient - on "museum mile" on the 5th Ave, but doesn't have usual crowds. The only place in NYC were you feel "real" - see how it actually was..How people actually lived. (oligarchs of old days.:) Building itself is amazing! Highly recommend.

A Lovely Museum. I'm not much of a museum lover but found the hour I spent here enjoyable. There were some interesting paintings. I very muched liked the architecture, French furniture porcelains, and Oriental rugs. The Garden Court was a lovely place to sit and quietly chat.
not too big. a nice small museum perfect for an hour or two.The museum itself has smaller proportions as it was oncea home, though it feels like a well-appointed castle.
Lived in NYC and had never visited...great find!!!!. What a charming museum housed in an old mansion. We enjoyed it very much!

A can't miss. This is a can't miss experience in NYC with a spectacular collection of art that is concentrated in a wonderful setting. A truly wonderful opportunity to view some of the finest art of the impressionist era.
ALJ. Very, very beautifull and full of history and style from a long gone time.

An impressive art collection displayed in a beautiful home setting. A friend and I really enjoyed our visit to the Frick Collection last Sunday. We chose to visit the Frick during our weekend in NYC over the Metropolitan Museum not only because of its more manageable size, but because the Frick currently has a special exhibit called Renoir, Impressionism and Full Length Paintings. On Sunday the Frick offers a couple of hours (11am-1pm) where they allow people to pay what they wish for admission, so there was already a line when we arrived a few minutes before 11 am, but it moved fairly quickly once the museum opened. We took advantage of the free audio guide which was very helpful, but be aware that not every item is described in the audio guide. We really enjoyed the lovely and impressive variety of art, sculpture and beautiful furnishings. Each room is exquisite, and you can tell Frick selected pieces that were "easy to live with" rather than being provocative. He was also known for reuniting the works of artists which had been separated and there are several examples of this in the collection. After perusing the permanent portion of the collection, we sat a while in the courtyard in the center of the gallery to rest our feet a bit, and then waited our turn to enter the room where the Renoirs are on display. Though there aren’t a large number of works in the Renoir exhibit, they’re quite beautiful--well worth seeing before the exhibit ends on May 13, 2012. We also took a few minutes to sit through the short film of Henry Frick’s life and how he acquired his collection, which was very interesting. Even the gift shop was worth a brief stop. I was able to pick up very affordable souvenirs: bookmarks ($3) with images of the full length Renoirs. The museum doesn't admit small children, and they require that large bags and coats be checked to minimize risk of damage to the furnishings and art. Though the museum is small, I would recommend allowing at least 2 hours to take everything in. I felt it was well worth the $18 admission.

Frustrated by a Sparse-Renoir "Exhibit". The Frick Collection had a much-touted Renoir exhibit that we visited, but were disappointed by the paucity of the work--only nine paintings! This is hardly an "exhibit" and certainly didn't justify the entrance fee ($18.00 for adults) that many people paid, basically to see just that exhibit. (True the fee entitles you to see other Frick holdings, but most visitors would not find many of them particularly noteworthy.) A visitor would have expected the Frick to flesh out the Renoir exhibit with some more Renoir works...or at least some more displays about Renoir's life and career.

Very nice museum. Excellent collection of Renoir paintings, and other paintings from French, Spanish, and other artists. The fireplace room with the painting of Saint Jerome, Cromwell, and Sir Thomas More is truly outstanding. This is the most impressive private collection of art I have seen. The location on 5th avenue is easy to get to on your way to the Met or the Guggenheim.

The BEst of the Best. The Frick Collection reflects one man's taste and what a taste it is. All the hard work is done for the visitor with only high quality paintings of the Masters of all ages on display. The living room is the ultimate with two Holbeins framing an El Greco and offset opposite by a Bellini nestling between two Titians.Just go and see what may be achieved by one man
Can't Bring Children. Always a beautiful place to view art. They can't take young children running about to spoil other patrons' experience.

A little gem -not to be missed. This is a stunning house/museum with the most fantastic collection of european art. Every room has the best paintings from every period of art -the Fragonard room is memorable. If you love art dont miss this little gem.
Fine art!. I liked the smallness of the museum, it was classy and quaint!

Great Art for those who know it all.. Don't go here unless you know everything already and are just refreshing your memory. Otherwise expect minimal assistance, and lots of being looked at like aliens if you ask the wrong people questions. You'll get no Fricking answers. Heres your synopsis: Rich people buy art, rich people show off art, rich people run out of money, need to get regular people to pay to see it, and they still resent it. Reality: its just a museum people..get over yourselves.
The Faberge egg of museums!!!. My favorite-small, intimate and exquisite. It's always a thrill walking through the doors.

Amazing personal art collection and great NY story. Went to see the Frick and the Renoir exhibit. Strongly recommend the video before viewing the collection. Absolutely beautiful home made into a museum.

A gorgeous gem. Want a world class experience without the crowds? Check out the Frick. It's completely doable in a few scant hours and is a beautiful and immersive atmosphere. Here, you can avoid the crowds that flock to the larger art institutions ands enjoy equally important gems, all in an unbelievably lovely building. I try to visit the Frick as much as possible, if only for an hour or so, to visit favorite paintings and enjoy the oasis in the middle of the city. If it is on view, don't miss the Bellini.

Fabulous paintings. This is a house preserved with paintings and furniture intact. Have coffee first as they is no cafe! However the paintings are lovely including a gorgeous Holbein. We were lucky to atend during a Renoir exhibition which was wonderful
Really Nice Little Museum. A really wonderful collection, and a smaller, more intimate complement to the mega-museum that is the nearby Metropolitan Museum.

Worth the time. If you at all appreciate art, go see this. T he portraits in particular are so beautiful.The owner most definitely had a very good , although untrained, eye for acquiring quality art.It is a very calming experience to visit this residence amid the relentless activity of NYC.
How to explan, beautiful. Going back in time, you feel like you leave the city behind, beautiful, could spend the day reading in the court yard, think I will next time.
Excellent. Liked - everything.Disliked - a little too many visitors.

A beautiful, elegant collection in pristine surroundings.... Definately worth seeing at least once! I'd recommend this collection more for art students and adults as there's not really much to entertain children here, unless your kids love art! :)

relaxingly defferent. this is not the 'run-of-the-mill art gallery, it's one man's grand home made to live as in the middle of a museum. Very grand, very quiet, and contains a high value catholic collection of paintings, sculpture and furniture. Well organised, easily reached, and recommended to see.

Greatest small gallery anywhere. If you visitNew Yorrk don't miss this fantastic art museum. It is small enough to see the total collection being set in a lovely mansion house on the east side of Central Park. The collection consists of some of the best works of many and varied famous artists, as well as porcelain and some furniture which is in situ in the house. Definitely one of the best days we spent in New York. And a gallery which is not as well known as the larger galleries-well worth a visit!
Renoir is short. Thernoir exhibit is nice but don't expect a large show. Go to see the rest of the frick
Renoir-Ooolala!!. A fabulous collection in a beautiful Museum. The collection was truly amazing and the narrative provided was most informative.

WOW!!!!. What an amazing experience!!! I thought I loved the Met & MOMA! This place is off-the-chart fabulous. Besides the phenomenal art work, the building is outstanding. Love how people really lived here & how there's period furniture.

Beautiful Setting; Great Collections. The Frick Collection is housed in a beautiful Guilded Age mansion built as a home by Mr. Frick, but with the expressed intent it serve as a showcase for his extensive art collection after his death. And so it has.The mansion is located along NYC's famous "museum mile" and backs directly onto Central Park. It is reminiscent of the Phillips (DC) and the Gardner (Boston); many small galleries, lavish settings, and a feeling that it is pretty much "doable" in one wonderful afternoon. And, the fees are a bit more reasonable than some of the larger NYC museums.Frick's main collection interests were portraits (especially of beautiful women!) and landscapes. The works span about the 17th - early 20th centuries. The collections have been added to since Frick's death, but with a careful eye to maintaining the sensibility of the original.Along with the original collection, changing exhibitons are shown. We saw a fabulous Renoir exhibit -- catch it if you can.A free audio guide is offered; we found it particularly informative. It descibes many features of the mansion as well as selected art works. There are also a couple of good introductory free films available in the "Music Room."Put The Frick on your "must see" list; you won't be sorry.

gorgeous setting for beautiful art. The Frick is in an old New York mansion from the glory days of New York society. Experiencing the mansion is a treat and on top of that, there is a wonderful collection of art there that is small enough to be taken in by a visit. The place is quiet and peaceful -- a nice break. There is a lovely museum shop -- but no cafe. And there are sometimes concerts. The web site has a lot of info.

A Very Pleasant Afternoon. I have visited the Frick Museum several times since the age of 10. It is a beautiful home filled with breathtaking art. You can walk right up to the paintings and take it all in. There is a Renoir exhibit now (through May I believe) that is remarkable.The amount of security staff they have is a bit off-putting (making you feel guilty for just wanting to enjoy the paintings), but in this day-and-age, I guess it is required in order to be this close to historical works.

Small but perfectly formed. Really loved this museum, much more manageable than some larger establishments. Great collection of art and artifacts and the audio guide was invaluable. Saw the Renoir exhibition which was a treat. Liked the fact it was in a former private residence and never felt rushed or crowded whilst going round.

Don't miss.... I love this museum, because the collection is a manageable size for me. Often I find other museums overwhelming with their huge collections. I can't focus after a couple of hours and that's usually never enough time to see the whole thing. However, with the Frick - the collection is housed within the Frick Mansion on E. 70th. Not only is the collection of Old Masters and Impressionists paintings impressive, but seeing all the art in the location it was purchased for is really special. Even my teenage daughter enjoyed the visit. Make sure to leave a little time to spend in the beautiful interior covered garden in the middle of the house - it's so serene. The audio guide is very helpful too! It's included in the admission.

My Favorite Museum in NYC. This collection is housed in the old Frick Mansion with some of the original furnishings. It is an amazing collection of some very famous pieces. You feel as if stepped back in time as you tour this beautiful house that is a work of art itself. Young children are not allowed here. Quite frankly I know it wouldn't appeal to my children but it is still my favorite museum in NYC.
A beauty. Somewhat off the beaten path of Museum Mile, if you have time you should go. Not as essential as the Met but still worthy of a look-see.
See how they lived in the gilded age. Worth admission simply to see the mansion but particularly if there is an interesting special exhibition on.

Inspiring! Favorite museum in NYC. I love this museum so much - it's very accessible in terms of appreciating art ... since its setting is in what used to be a private home (albeit - of a very wealthy man ... but, none-the-less, the art is displayed with the eye of an appreciator ... not a "professional"). AND what beautiful art it is! The collection is an incredible one. Check for special exhibits and concerts that frequent the collection. AND on SUNDAYS from 11am-1pm, it is pay-what-you-wish ... a great place to spend a Sunday right by the park as well! And if you're going soon - MUST see the Renoir collection! An impressive one ... unsure so many of his great works have been so readily available in one place!
Great small museum. It doesn't have a large collection or big exhibits but what they have is choice!

A GEM for KIDS. The paintings (masters like ElGreco) and artwork make this little museum a world class site. But for me the thrill was being in a real 'fancy' 5th avenue mansion, still furnished exactly how it was when Frick was there. This is a small museum, with an outdoor garden. FUN to do with kids.
Doent get better. our own gem in ny. can u imagine someone lived here. NY before income tax in the gilded age. amazing for just that. then the art. One of the Vermeers lives here...all good

A Wonderful Small Museum. The Frick Collection on Fifth Avenue is only a few blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It requies several exhausting days to see everything at the Met, and the effort will leave you suffering from artstic overload. It takes only a few hours to see everything at the Frick--and the quality of the exhibits is remarkable. The highpoint, for me at least, came with Holbein's portraits of Sir Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell, staring at one another across a fireplace. Both loyally served Henry VIII, and both died on the block as a result.

Three reasons to go. What I enjoyed about the Frick Collection is that it is like three museums in one. The house itself is stunning and a pleasure to see, as are the furnishings, and of course the art. It's a great way to spend an afternoon.
Small, but an incredible collection and building.. It's a very small museum, but both the collection and the building are glorious. I never go to New York without seeing the Frick at least once.

Favorite art museum. We love the Frick House. Even the house is a piece of art! The architecture and feeling of how they lived only adds the ambiance. Interior garden, library, and exceptional art. A "home" in NYC! On Sundays its "pay what you wish" admission, and they also don't allow young children. It is not overwhelming, and you feel very comfortable in the Frick home enjoying their art collection, wondering what it must have been like to live "here" back then.

Unique Collection. The mansion of Henry Frick, the coke-for-coal baron, is not the largest museum in NYC. However, it has the most Rembrandts you can see in NY, if you are a fan. Also the building is interesting for its history and style.

Some amazing art in an historic mansion on 5th ave. in New York?. Definitely worth a visit to see some exquisite Vermeer, Holbein, Goya, Rembrandt (the list goes on) - all part of the original Frick collection. A wonderful show of Renoir full length paintings happened to be here when we visited. The mansion itself gives you a pretty clear idea of what kind of place you can build when m.oney is no object.
Great small museum. Frick very strong on Vermeer (5), Turner, Piero della Francesca, Corot, Fragonard, Whistler, many others.

FRICK - WOW. I loved thye layout and each room transends iinto another period. Very relaxing vibe.Priceless artwork that makes you want to know more about your history. Well It did that for me. Life is Art and Life is so Good!

Small but impressive. This is a small museum with a varied display of art. It is easy to go through in an hour (unless you read every note). The building itself is interesting. Used to be someone's home.

Absolutely breathtaking!. Sunday from 11 to 1 - it is "pay as you wish". So, there was a bit of a wait to get in but it was nice to get in without the normal entrance fee. It is more than an art musuem because it is housed in the residence with beautiful furnishings, a library and such. You are free to walk around the rooms in any order that you wish. Just be sure to see it all. Wonderful collection and very rich experience.
Renoir Full-Length Paintings. A special exhibit of 9 full length compositions. Truly wonderful. Go early on Sunday for "pay what you wish" entry fee. Line up by 10:30 am to be sure you get in.
Favorite museum in NYC. Love the atmosphere. Great works of art. Stunning courtyard.

Wonderful Sunday Afternoon. The home of Mr. Frick is beautiful and full of decorative arts & paintings that the collector purchased during his life-time. Many will never leave the home. It is a great place to spend the afternoon observing fine craftsmanship in Art, architecture, design and decoration.

The best art in NYC. This is a must if you like atrt.There are only 40 Vermeers in the world, and this guy bought 2 of them!Along with Turners,Constabls, Gainsborough, the collection is outstanding, and displayed beautifully as the functioning house that it was, probably the best art gallery I have ever seen.
This is a wonderful collection!. Such a nice way to spend a few hours....very interesting collection!
Don't miss the Renoirs. What a chance of a lifetime to see the full length Renoirs.....really fantastic and gorgeous. Don't miss it!
Renoir. I like the Renoir exibet at the Frick. This is a samll, interesting musuem, highly recommend it!

Frick Museum - pay what you want on Sundays 11-1. Looking for a manageable and interesting museum on a Sunday in New York City? The Frick has a "pay what you want" approach on Sundays between 11-1. New Yorkers and tourists alike seem to know about it because the line stretched for 2 blocks. But once inside, you're treated to a great museum experience. Get yourself the audio guide so you can learn about paintings at your own pace. Or take advantage of the large art paper and pencils so you can do your own sketching. Right now, there is a Renoir exhibit. It's only 9 paintings but they are displayed so that you can really enjoy them. The polite guards make sure the room does not get too full (which means another line to get in) but worth the wait.
What a wonderful museum. Some of the greatest painting in the world are in the (for New York) modest museum. All visitors must go!
The Oasis on Museum Mile. Permanent collection full of gems. Rarely crowded. Indoor atrium with fountains and plants. Sit and reflect
Wonderful collection, incredible house. Fantastic collection that right now includes a Renoir exhibit. This house is almost as interesting as the art on the walls.

NYC Museum Gem. We had a wonderful visit; especially because of the Renoir exhibit which will continue through May 13, 2012. Its a converted mansion, every detail is perfect. There is an enclosed Garden which is in bloom, even in the Winter. A lovely and peaceful place.
A Gem. This is a fabulous small museum that was originally a home. Still contains original furnishings along with great art--3 Vermeers!

The best museum in New York. I first went to this museum when I was in college and loved it then. I have since returned with my wife and three grown kids. the setting is magnificent - a beatiful mansion, The collection is diversified. some of my favorites are Tomas More portratin and the St. Francis. It is a wonderful relaxing place unlike the met. and you simply enjoy the atmosphere and art without being overwhelmed.
Must see in NYC!. Been to NYC many times and this is an impressive place - give youself 2 hours, close to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Intimate museum and glimpse of life as a wealthy New Yorker. The Frick Collection is a must see on a visit to NYC. Ten blocks from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but a different world. Henry Clay Frick amassed an amazing collection of old world art. It is housed in the magnificent mansion that he built on Fifth Avenue. The collection contains many wonderful paintings by Vermeer, Degas, Hoblein the Younger, Fragonard, and Renoir plus lovely sculpture, furniture, and porcelain. Wandering around the museum gives you a glimpse of how the extremely wealthy lived in early 20th century NYC. The entrance fee is pricey, but it is still worth a visit. Be sure to use the free audioguide.
Greedy robber baron. But well he has an exquisite taste> A must see in NYC
quiet special place. love the building and the variety in th ecollection. Went to see the new Renoir exhibition which was very small. The collection i sspecail and in beautiful surroundings.
Renoir. The nine pictues were overwhelming and inspired all who9 saw them.

Don't Miss It. We planned a Sunday visit to the Frick, and arrived to find it was "pay-whatever-you-want" day, so the line wound around the corner. It was zero-degrees wind chill, but worth every moment of waiting in line. The Frick Collection (aside from the special Renoir, full-length portrait exhibit) is absolutely amazing. The free, self-guided recorded tour includes engaging and well-written/read commentaries on almost all of the pieces, and the scope and quality of the art is breath-taking. In the main hall, you get up close and personal with Degas, Rembrandt, Constable, Vermeer, Velasquez, Whistler, Hall, Turner, and can enjoy an intimate, unhurried master class in great painting. Don't miss it!

Back in the 1800s. The Frick is a very interesting collection of pieces from very different periods. Being Italian I'm spoiled in term of art and collections. What I found most amazing about this place is the atmosphere of this house (palace I should say). If its not too crowded you can really fill the past, the way wealthy people lived in the 1800s. Library and dining romm are very interesting. Chinese porcellana is worth noting.

So so. There were so many angry guards every which direction you turn to. I didn't feel relaxed cuz I was being watched the whole time. It's too pricey compared to what were presented. There are other museums I could enjoy a lot more such as the Cloister.
disappointed. It was a lovely house with some great pieces on display but it was smaller than we imagined and not very good value.

The collection is as impressive as the building. The collection, while being relatively modest, is of rather interesting pieces of work.I was gladly impressed by both the artwork and the building itself. Beautiful architecture and decor.
A wonderful display of Impressionists. If you love art and particularly Impressionism visiting his mansion on the upperet side is one of the best afternoons in NYC.

A jewel box of a museum. I have always preferred small, intimate, well-curated museums over the larger monolithic establishments and the Frick Museum does not disappoint in this regard. A stunning Mansion on Fifth Avenue hosts an eclectic and beautifully arranged collection of the Fricks' finest purchases. Be sure to go see the short movie on the history of the museum - fascinating.

A joyous experience for art lovers. A perfect museum, especially for visitors with limited time. The museum has nothing but masterpieces and it is manageable because it is relatively small. You will rarely see more great art in a single room than in the main gallery. The building itself, formerly Henry Clay Frick's mansion, is interesting and is filled with beautiful furniture and objects. The one caveat is that you have to some interest in Old Master art -- no pop art here -- but who doesn't like Rembrandt and Vermeer?

The home is as impressive as the art!. Great art collection, but even better was being able to tour a historic home that has been preserved as it was when Frick built it. Steep price, but it's New York. Everything is.

Living the high life. Having just visited the Picasso Museum in Barcelona not long ago, I loved the perspective that the Frick home gave us about his work. It was also a wonderful way to exhibit the family's treasures and showcased the way these people lived their opulent lifestyle.
a quiet display of breathtaking works. My wife and I chose to visit the Frick Collection without the kids, which I highly recommend...

Beautiful house, a must see!. The art was great but the house is the reason to go! So amazing! If you are short on time, you can still see the highlights of this place. Make sure you get the audio tour so you can hear about the history of the house.
a favorite. I'm reviewing from my trip last year. love this museum, easy to do the whole thing, fab vermeer, history of house and architecture really one of a kind museum experience

Amazing concerts. Appart of a rich art collection there are those amazing after brunch Sunday concerts. Best classical music on best location! Please check on the dates and extend your stay if you have to not to miss it.

Fine Art in an Hour. If, like me, you want to 'do' a bit of art and culture while in NYC, but don't want to spend a lot of time doing it, this is the place for you. An amazing old mansion, beautifully restored, and cram-packed with old masters. A must-see! Oh, and if you happen to be 'active duty' military with an ID card, you get in for free (even UK Forces!).

a visit to the Frick Collection...a private home and art collection. excellent...very worth while if you are an art lover
beautiful home
A digestible museum visit. You won't feel overwhelmed. It's a great collection but remember the guy who collected this stuff did it by abusing his workers.
Frick. My first Vermeer, deepened my regard for Whistler.
World class museum. Incredible artwork in a NYC mansion of a bygone era.

Great little museum. So, you have seen the Met, the Guggenheim, MoMa and Whittney. Where do you go now? Try the Frick collection. The art is well curated and well displayed. The quality of collection can stand against any other museum in NYC, even those listed above. It's a small musuem but worth seeing.
Exquisite and very complete. All the pieces have a nice flow, and unlike other exhibitions, they match. Highly recommend to visit
Take advantage of what the robber barons left for u!. If you like golden age art go, if you don't know what you like go!
beautiful. outstanding collection in very nice and charming manson in the middle of the 5th avenue

A step back in time surrounded by classic beauty. A magnificent home with beautiful furnishings, architecture and so many paintings you will recognise from the art books. Enjoy the free audio and the entry fee is well worth it

great art and great building. its really interesting to see the artwork displayed in a home setting. you have to make 2 trips around each room - 1 for the artwork and another to look at the architecture.
peacful. lovely to walk in quiet after lunch IF this art is your thing ... It's a little stuffy and they are very particular about not stepping off the rug.
Outstanding. Not a picture I wouldn't have given a home to... A small, exquisite and intimate gallery. Probably my favourite gallery anywhere.
historic 5th ave mansion. I find this type of art boring (medeival, degas) but thats a matter of taste, the setting is fantastic .
Worth the visit for the Turner. Beautiful collection of paintings and sculptures in an often missed museum
Excellent gallery. intimate and good audio guide. No young kida allowed so nice and quiet!
one of my favorites. if you are truly interested in art and architecture this is the museum to go to. i often visit, walk around and peacefully read.
Tasteful oasis near Central Park. Great old "robber baron" city house with a fabulous art collection. Very peaceful.

Perfect gallery, museum for an afternoon filled with other obligations.. We visited the Collection on a Sunday when you could pay what you want. It was very busy, but this did not take away from the overall experience. We used the audio info handsets and were able to hear about anything that interested us at the collection. I would recommend the collection to anyone that is in NY for a weekend and doesn't have the day or more the Met would take to tour. The only negative we had was an entire section was closed for an exhibit opening next week. Hopefully when we go back, we can see the rest. It is a wonderful old mansion filled with antiques, and paintings by old masters. There is so much for anyone to see and enjoy.

Quality museum. To see a museum which was also someone's home is so interesting. And most of the art never leaves, so it must be seen here. The self portrait Rembrandt was esp. interesting as I had never seen it before. The Fragonards are breath taking.
Very impressive. An impressive, eclectic collection. It probably merits seeing only once, or at least only every few years, but it is well worth the price of admission.

Magnificent collection of Old Master paintings in a beautiful setting. Anyone who loves art should spend an hour or two wandering among the splendid paintings, sculptures, and decorative objects displayed in Henry Clay Frick's mansion. Not only is the art collection superlative, but it is rarely crowded and just a joy to visit.

Amazing Collection. I love this mansion museum full of the choicest art, sculpture, and furnishings. The home itself is stunning and the collection amazing in scope and quality. I enjoyed the new enclosed portico devoted to a collection of Meissen porcelain.
The Best!. We couldn't believe our eyes. The collection is absolutely amazing!
Excellent small museum. Worth a visit. Building is fantastic and the art is just wonderful. What a fabulous collection.
the most romantic museum in NYC. I can stand for hours in front on my favorite painting by Ingres - the one on their brochure. They also have a charming garden, and occasional concerts.
Beautiful. Smaller very manageable museum in a gorgeous mansion. the quality of the art is outstanding.

Frick Collection: New York's Most Peaceful Museum. I have been going to the Frick Collection since I was a child growing up in New York. It is different from most museums: the masterpiece collection of one man's taste and genius, in his home on the Upper Eastside as it was in his lifetime. There are so many masterpieces of European art up through the Impressionists that are world famous and reproduced in so many art books that a visitor forgets that their home is here instead of the Met. The inner courtyard with its fountain is a great place to rest one's feet and back. The self audio guide is just the right length for each picture and it's free. An oasis of art no visitor to New York who loves painting should miss.

great hidden gem. most people visitng the city miss seeing this private collection- if you truly love art make certain you visit the Frick- the Fragonard room alone is worth the visit as well as the cental atrium seating are; lovely.

A cozy museum in the big city. Great collection of very fine and precious arts, few people around in a sunday morning, nice villa in the UES. Love it! You can spend 2 hours there in a very classical atmosphere, you will appreciate the great job done by Mr. Frick by donating his personal and private collection to the world eyes. The villa is beautiful by itself with a nice small garden around. Sculptures and pictures inside will drive you in the past years.
A wonderful, accessible museum. Great exhibitions, intimate and easy to view the entire museum without being overwhelmed.

Wonderful Way to Spend the Day. The Frick not only has a wonderful art collection but it is located in the Frick mansion. Anyone who is a lover of buildings should treat themselves to a trip to the Frick.

Amazing art collection in a former private home. This art museum is a display of the work acquired by a private collector. it is in his former home on Fifth Avenue (and close to the Metropolitan Museum of Art). It is a rare look at a former private home in NYC left with its furniture in place and gardens maintained on a busy street. The new Portico Gallery is a wonderful addition.
Eclectic collection in a home enviroment. My favorite art museum in New York...Great art collection in a beautiful home, just the way it was meant to be, A must see for any for any art lover.

Beautiful atmosphere!. I always go to the Frick when in NY. The home is lovely, and it just as interesting as the collection. That said, the collection is amazing. It is not an overwhelming museum like the Met. Spend a leisurely two hours, before or after lunch.
Frick Collection. This "museum" is all-too-often overlooked. If you are an artist or have an interest in art, don't miss the Frick. Quite a beautiful collection.

A great stop. If you're on the UES, you might as well stop in at the Frick. A grand home once owned by an industry magnate, it has since been converted into an art gallery to display the works the owner collected during his lifetime. I was pleasantly surprised to spot a Renoir, though I admit I am only of average art intelligence and am just happy to spot anything I recognize.

Hidden Gem. Most tourists don't make it here because they head to the Metropolitan or the Natural History Museums. But this is a small and hidden gem that was once a NYC mansion and now houses a lovely collection. Both the collection and the facility are worth the visit. Go!

Give yourself a slice of art heaven!. This art museum is a great delight to begin to enjoy comfortably in a morning or afternoon. It is located in the mansion on 5th Ave built for Mr. Frick and his varied art collection. The building has its own unique charm and the art offered is a slice of art heaven. Take your time without rushing and you will want to return to enjoy being in the Frick again to experience its variety, quality, beauty and richness. There are music recitals scheduled in the hall throughout the season which add to the depth of offerings at this unique and memorable art museum.

Give yourself a couple hours on a Sunday to enjoy. 11am-1pm on Sundays are "pay what you wish" and I took advantage of that to spend just 1 hour in the museum since our other plans fell through. Unique experience since you're walking through a decorated house-- feels much more historical than a regular museum.
Beautiful place. What struck me most is the intimacy of this place, you really enter the house of Mr Frick. And he did have good taste.

An Absolute MUST SEE!. The Frick is simply amazing. And do-able. It's not at all overwhelming; I think that's what I liked best. You can thoroughly enjoy the museum at a relaxed pace, and leave having seen it all, in just two or three hours.

Some great art in the Frick. The Frick contains some great art. My wife is the artist so I just tagged along, but I enjoyed the experience. Unlike the Met there are no placards giving details about the art but they do have an audio tour system. For art lovers, this is a great place to spend a couple of hours.

Lovely Museum, wanted to live there. This is a beautiful building, be sure to ask about it's history. The space holds very nice art that is easy to admire. Employees were very nice and filled with lots of info about the art.
Frick Museum. Such a unique "museum" experience! Movie explaining the history was good and the art is wonderful.
Eclectic but First Rate. A shrine to the lost art of the private collector. This and the Morgan Library are superb examples.
Hidden Gem. Not many out of towers know of the wonderful little museum. In the spring and summer, the outdoor gardens are gorgeous. It's worth the visit.

Lots of rules but a lovely place. The Frick is housed in one of the most amazing mansions in New York. Take the docent tour to find out about the fascinating history of the family and the house. The audio is great too. However, shame on any museum that does not allow kids. How are we going to develop a new generation of responsible museum goers?

Excellent Museum. Coming from Boston, I am spoiled by the Gardner Museum. The Frick is just as intimate and beautiful. The exhibits are great but the actual building is the best part. Such a beautiful place.
Not your typical museum. Amazing display of art in a mansion that people actually lived in.

Old New York and stunning!. It's set in a wonderful building, it isn't too large and gives it a feeling as if you're visiting someone's home that has great art! It's a great way of seeing some of the American art history and the location is great too! It's off Museum mile and next to great eateries!

Eye-boggling..... An amazing collection of art works that dazzles the eyes, and where you can spend some time of day resting between "cultural takes" in the covered courtyard, where the fountain splashes quietly in the background. Tip: do a couple of rooms at a time, and then take the weight off your feew - the Frick may not be as vast as the Metropolitan across the way, but it is as intense in colour and variety. Good little shop, as well, and be sure to ask for concessions at the ticket point.

Finest Small Museum in New York City. Funny that a Pittsburgh robber baron from the coal industry could create this absolute gem of a museum, but there you are. A breathtaking collection of Old Master paintings in a private home setting that will not leave you fatigued.
Wonderful Museum In Mansion. This is a wonderful museum in what appears as a former private mansion. It is a must see for anyone who loves art.

A beautiful building and a nice collection. A small museum that is not child friendly. They may even have a rule that no children under 12 are allowed. Guards are definitely sensitive to skipping and sudden movements. In an old mansion that is worth visiting for the building alone, but the special exhibitions are worth going out of your way for. Across from Central Park.
A mansion and famous artwork. There are some amazing paintings, which surprise you even if you have seen them in art books. The interior of the mansion itself is worth the visit.
just go. tastefully collection of old masters, beautiful grand house and no crowds!

A real opportunity. A museum in one of the few remaining Golden Age mansions on Fifth Avenue. A magnificent venue with a great collection, but you have to like art of the periods that Mr. Frick liked. Nothing contemporary here.

A Gem of a Museum. As much as I love the grand museums of the world, I think I enjoy smaller gems like the Frick even more. I happened to catch the last day of a Picasso exhibit, but the permanent collection is well worth taking in as well.
oasis of calm. loved the vermeers, and the calmness after the crowds at MoMA. worth a detour if you are not in the area.

A wonderful small museum in a grand home.. We had two excellent docent tours with Ms. Finklestein who made both the art and the building come alive for us. At present there are small (limited to 5) docent tours being offered—we recommend taking one.

An oasis of beauty and civility. The Frick is a great small museum. Practically every painting or object is a masterpiece, and the ensemble, housed in a grand mansion built for the collector, evokes the vanished age of the great robber barons of the late 19th/early 20th century. A small basement space is devoted to exquisite temporary exhibitions -- the rest of the house is mercifully and magnificently permanent.
Beautiful Exhibition. Great Paintings in an intimate setting.beautiful way they exhibit their paintings,wiyh waterfalls and a garden setting.
Best afternoon in NY!. An amazing collection - in a gorgeous setting. A must see in NYC!

On Museum Mile- worth seeing once. I go to the Frick Collection about twice a year with friends and family visiting New York. We always combine it with a visit to two other museums- The Met and the Guggenheim or depending on the exhibit the Whitney. You need about sixty to ninety minutes to just get basic feel of the place. If I only had a chance to go to one or two art institutions, the Frick would not be on the top of my list but if you have never gone, a it is a wonderful building filled with beautiful furnishings, and art treasures. To really appreciate the galleries, first sit and watch the film, join a guided tour, and take time to sit in the inside garden/ fountain area. They also have special events so if you are interested in going, check out their site ahead of time. My ninety two year old mother loved the museum and didn't understand why she really did not know about it as she is a regular at art museums. Just goes to show you, that you can always find something that you have missed in New York.
Just the Right Size. You can take it all in within a two-hour visit. Just the right size to enjoy, historic building and near the other museums.

Picasso exhibit is over get the headphones for the tour. A gem in the heart of Lenox Hill area, on the Museum Mile, wish they would make people speak in lower tones and TURN OFF their CELLS Rude Rude New Yorkers !
Wonderful collection of art. The Frick is wonderful for an afternoon of browsing some amazing artworks

For Someone Who Doesn't Usually Like Art Museums--This was a delight!. OK I admit it, I usually don't like art museums. The Frick is different. Because the entire collection is housed in essentially one big house, it is not so big as to be overwhelming. And the fact that the Frick is actually housed in Mr. Frick's house lends a special touch not found elsewhere. The architecture alone of the house is worth the visit. Check out the books in Mr. Frick's library--amazing! And the paintings! There are no clunkers.
A tiny museum full of treasures. You can tour this gem in a couple of hours. The only drawback is the steep admission fee: to avoid this visit on Sunday during the "pay what you want" hours.
Amazing collection. It is a beautiful house and the docents were very informative

Excellent collection, but small. The charm of the Frick is the same as the challenge of the Frick: the setting is small. This offers a degree of intimacy, but challenges the museum to offer reasonable value to match admission prices, and makes visiting exhibitions difficult. We visited most recently during the exhibition of a Velazquez portrait of Phillip IV. While most exhibitions advertised up and down Park Ave. consist of dozens of paintings, this exhibition was a single portrait. While the portrait was undoubtedly marvelous, we were in and out in about an hour, building in time to see the rest of the Frick collection. The Frick is fantastic for those days when you do not have enough time to go to a museum as engrossing as the Met or MOMA, or even the Guggenheim or Whitney, but still want a dose of world-class art.
Frick. Well worth the time. Massive collection presented in a lovely house.
CHARMING !!!. A delightful gem tucked away on Fifth Avenue. The museum itself is so important to see, not to mention its collections! A must see for visitors!!

Picasso, Renoir and more make the Frick a lovely visit. My family and I were here in early January, and have been several times before. We continue to be charmed by its pleasant intimacy and divine collection of art. When we went, we saw a great exhibition on Picasso's drawings and browsed the lovely permanent collection, as well as sat in the beautiful daylit solarium. Highly reccomended!

Under the radar gem.. NYC has so many amazing museums and galleries that perhaps it isn't odd that the Frick seems under-populated. It should, however, be a not-to-miss destination of any art lover. In addition to the marvelous architecture and serenity of the building itself, with it's lovely sitting areas and beautiful setting on 70th and 5th Avenue, the collection is breathtaking. There are 3 Vermeers that would be worth the trip alone, but they are in the good company of multiple Rembrandts, Van Dykes, Turners, and others. The current special exhibitions include a splendid Picasso exhibit and an enchanting exhibit of porcelain. The museum is also a perfect size: it is possible to see the whole collection, have a restful "sit down" in between, and not be surrounded by crowds as is often the case at the Met.

perfect size. I enjoyed this museum much more than I thought I would. It's smaller size made it much more accommodating for mere mortals, yet the collections were significant. Centrally located on 5 th Ave across from Central Park, it's easy to get to.
a Treasure. beautiful collection in a classic building.Free for several hours on Sundays.Art work is stunning.

Liked the self guided tour. I've been to this museum severals times. You are given an device that has recorded descriptions of each work of art. Stand in front of one that interests you and enter the 3 digit number to hear a short description.Also interesting to imagine how Mr. Frick live when this was his personal residence.
Delightful gallery in new york. A FANTASTIC EXPERIENCE - the house is simply fantastic and the art displays wonderful

The best of the best in European arts, all in a few rooms. Last time I visited the Frick, an amazing collection of portraits and landscapes, decorative arts and furniture, all housed in a sumptuous turn-of-the-20th-century 5th Ave. mansion, I was a newlywed. Now I returned decades later on the last day of 2011 with my teenage daughter, who was as delighted and impressed as I had been. One after another, the paintings are what you find in textbooks, but with the vividness and warmth of real life, in real rooms. Admittedly the rooms are not exactly what we'd have at home, but most are furnished spaces, not galleries. Every visitor has his or her favorites: mine is Frick's own sitting room, with Hans Holbein's "Sir Thomas More" and Bellini's "St. Francis in Ecstacy" as well as two exquisite Titians. My daughter loved the over-the-top Fragonard room, finding it delightful and really funny on close inspection. They also often have impressive special exhibitions: we saw one on Picasso's drawings. Very worthwhile visit. Note: children under 10 are not admitted, due to the many precious and breakable objects around the building.

Little haven in the city. There's something different about the collection; it's unlike anything else in the city that I've experienced it's so small scale but interesting. I wouldn't recomment it for your first or only trip the the Big Apple but if you return it's a small haven in a quieter corner of the city providing an insight into how a rich man lived

Jewel Box Museum. The Frick offers paintings by the greatest European artists, sculptures, eighteenth-century French furniture and porcelains, Limoges enamels, as well as special exhibitions in small rooms downstairs that can be exquisite but crowded. I come to visit the Fragonard and Boucher paintings. The permanent collection is rarely crowded and is in a period setting. Note that you may not bring children to the museum. The Frick is not to be missed.
Not my thing. While this isn't my favourite museum, the people i went with absolutely loved it. Still worth a look.

A lovely small museum. I love the size and and intimacy of this museum. A beautiful mansion which is now a museum. Not a huge collection, but some very nice pieces! We went on Sunday during the "pay what you want" time. Really enjoyed the visit. one of my favorite museums in NYC

Hidden gem. Frick Collection is small enough to really appreciate the beautiful artwork, interior decor, furniture and other artefacts contained in it. Save money and go Sunday morning when it is 'pay what you wish' but it is well worth the money even if you pay full price.
The House and the art are both outstanding. Not a broad collection, but each piece is a blockbuster. The house is an architectural gem.
FRICK OK. We were a little disappointed in that the mansion is a little like walking through some-ones home and not allowed to go up-stairs which were cordened off.

Small, interesting, pretty building. Lovely gallery, much smaller collection than I had been led to believe, artwork wonderful. I thought there would be a lot more furniture which is what drew me here but I was disappointed.

My favorite in New York. I love this museum. The artwork is unparalled and the home is magnificent. Frick's biography is also very interesting. We were there for a special Picasso Exhibit which was excellent. I have visited 3 times and love it everytime I go.

beautiful building with gorgeous art. some of the rooms are set up just as Mr Frick would have had them when he lived there, with paintings where he placed them. The paintings are beautiful but my favourite thing about was imagining the family that once lived in such a gorgeous house.

Great art in a lovely Fifth Avenue Mansion. It's hard to beat the combination of wonderful art treasures beautifully presented in the confines of one of the last mansions standing on Fifth Avenue. The scope is small enough that you can take it all in without being overwhelmed by the sensory overload of top quality masterpieces.

My favorite museum. I love this museum and am fortunate to live in the city and get to visit it whenever I want. It's small enough that you get to enjoy every single area of it in just a couple of hours. The experience it offers that takes you back to the gilded age of New York with its wonderful 'rich' family such as the Fricks, enables you to take a look at the ways of life and social status of this magnificent family and its collections of art, furniture and sculptures. A treat for all.

Amazing city mansion and fab collection. My interest in the frick was more that I wanted to see a turn of the century tycoons mansion than for the exhibition - not that I'm not interested in the arts, but having not long spent a couple of weeks in Paris and having been a week in NYC, am feeling a bit galleried out. However, have to say, not only was the property as impressive as expected,but the collection is delightful. The sensation of viewing the works in a private home is such a privilege, I won't forget it
great quiet museum. Low key quality museum, very helpful staff, great special exhibit included in cost

A gem. What a gem! I've worked and lived in New York for a few years and only discovered this exquisite museum on my recent trip back to the city. Simply amazing; the art is stunning, let alone the house itself (even more impressive). If I got only time for two museums in New York, it would be the Met and the Frick.Love it!
probably the best museum in NYC. It's probably the best museum in NYC. We just loved it so much!
Superb. Fantastic museum, well worth the trip inside the Frick!

A beautiful, elegant Museum. My favorite museum. It's exquisite and low key. You can sit around the indoor fountain and take it slow. This was Frick's home. His art collection is wonderful. Really worth the price of admission

Amazing!!!. I `m in love with this place!!!! the paintings, furniture, decoration everything is so nice, you can go there, sit and enjoy them for some time...Something else...the electronic guides are for free!!! ( I don`t remember the name of those things) I want to go back!!

Great Small Museum. What a fascinating collection and beautiful home that displays it! The audio guide provided interesting snippets of information about the collector, his home and the pieces on display.

Sublime art collection. The art collection in this museum is small(when compared to the Metropolitan) but amazing. In addition you get to see how the really wealthy lived along fifth avenue in the glory days of New York. The ability to see a mansion relatively intact is unique and worth the visit. On tis trip a small speciAl collection of Picasso drawings was an added highlight.
Small gem. This is a small museum that was a private home. A top collection of fine European art including a Vermeer. Don't miss it.

The wonderful personal collection of a true benefactor of the arts. From the grandeur of the beautifully renovated mansion to the gentle way the layout leads you in and around this wonderful collection, you can't help thinking of the massive contribution Frick has made to the enjoyment by successive generations of significant pieces of art and sculpture. And what a pity he did not live much beyond the completion and installation of this masterful personal collection. It is really awesome.

Picasso Exhibit. I made a point of visiting the Frick for the current Picasso exhibit that is going on until early January. While the Picasso's were wonderful to look at, what was most impressive was the museum itself. Formerly a residence and now a museum it is truly a magnificent building. I would have loved to gone upstairs to explore the home and see the rooms. Be sure to watch the video that is ongoing in I think the Music Room that details the history.

Wonderful Collection. An art collection and house tour that is an excellent value. Unlike similar museums, the Frick Collection exercises a bit of crowd control so that you can enjoy the art and house without being constantly pushed and pulled. Seeing just one Vemeers was worth the price of admission, but there are three. Unfortunately, like most museums, they permit baby strollers, but that is my only complaint.
Not for teenagers. My husband an I enjoyed the history and beauty but our teenagers were bored, despite our attempts to get a bit of culture into them.

A rare treat. The superb collection of old masters is almost outdone by its surroundings - a magnificent opulent mansion in a superb location. The commentary on the (free) handsets is extremely well done. The Picasso exhibit was a bit of a disappointment, but go for the permanent collection. Go early, before noon, as the place gets crowded!

Stunning collection in a unique setting. I've visited The Frick many times over the years and wholeheartedly tout it to visitors to NYC for a number of reasons. Let me dispense with with its few negatives first-none that should prevent you from going: 1) Children under 10 are banned from the lovely premises 2) The 15 dollar admission (at most hours)is rather steep. 3) The guards are one multi-headed scowl who impart nothing to the experience. Admittedly a warped domestic terrorist attempted to kill Mr Frick at his business offices but that was 125 years ago and we art afficinados are unarmed-honest, guys<g>Now for the positives. The converted mansion is a lovely setting with comfortable public seating around a lovely fountain where the strains of a luncheon piano recital soothingly play from a nearby room. The rest may not be necessary because the Collection is a perfect blend of incredible masterpieces and a lovely, manageable setting that can be traversed in 2-3 hrs. at a leisurely pace. This allows the tourist a charming respite, a short stroll through Central Park across the street and still time for dinner and a play. Seeking art emersion? The Met and the Guggenheim are both less than a 15 minute walk straight up the street to augment this must-see stop. The stunning St Jerome by El Greco, Bellini's St Francis of Assisi, several extraordinary Vermeers with coquettish young ladies and ardent visitors,Two Holbeins "with a story" Rembrandts, early Turners, Goya, Velasquez, Chardin, lovely ladies portrayed by Whistler, lovelyill-fated Lady Hamilton by Romney, a charming Renoir are just a few of the selections that show off Mr Fricke's flawless taste in rooms large and small. However, note that it is all representative art. Nothing later than the Impressionists.However, MOMA, The Guggenheim, the Whitney all represent the various schools of modern art and are within walking distance. Dont miss The Frick-a most unique and memorable NYC gem!

A must see. I really enjoyed the Frick Collection which also currently has an exhibition of drawings by Picasso. This is an amazing collection set out in a beautiful building and a must see in New York.

Great smaller museum. This is a jewel of a museum - especially nice because a real family lived here! The rooms are wonderful and the audio allows you to listen about the pieces you are interested in - and you have a great deal of freedom to move around the collection and examine the pieces that appeal to you. Small so not crowded with tourists! Great location.

Small museum, Crowded, A lot of fun. The building itself drew more of our interest than the paintings within.A good museum with some nice artwork and a fantastic interior.Free Audio guides were nice to hear about rooms and the art.It was extremely crowded at 11AM on a Wednesday with a line out the door... and it did get crowded in small corridors a little but it was still okay.I may not suggest this museum for a NYC first timer, but if it's your second or third visit and you want something different and smaller to do - check it out!

Lovely. This is a beautiful collection in the former residence of Mr. Frick. How wonderful he had the foresight to purchase such wonderful works of art and to build a lovely house to display for all to see. Spend the nine minutes to view the show and then enjoy the amazing displays of artvv
Must See!!!. I lived in NYC for years and this was a favorite go-to place for me and for visitors. It's a diverse collection of art, set in a beautiful NYC mansion. Well worth a visit!
Very pleasant!. I enjoyed this art collection. It is a very nice exhibit. It is beatifully displayed and has a lot of interesting works inside the collection!

A gem on 72nd. Wow, if you haven't been, make the trip. A real gem of a museum...be forewarned..no children under 10 admitted. Beautiful history and collection...ala Isabelle Stewart museum in Boston. Enjoy.
Favorite NYC Museum!. The Frick is smaller and less busy than its larger museum neighbors (Met, MOMA) but what it lacks in quantity, it more than makes up in quality. Highly recommended!
My favorite NYC museum. I love going here and seeing a nontraditional approach to hanging art. Excellent collection and beautiful setting.

The best gallery in the world. If you could only ever choose one museum/ art gallery in the world to visit, choose the Frick. The collection covers most of the major periods of world art and is superbly displayed in a lavish domestic setting
most beautiful museum in NYC. perfect place to visit. beautiful building and gardens and one of the best portrait collection .
Heaven. Great collection, minimal walking. Perfect if you want to see all wonderful things in less than an hour.

An Extraordinary Museum whih Displays the Power of Money. The collection is housed in the mansion of Henry Clay Frick (the industrialist, financier, and robber baron) and it epitomizes the power of money. The collection contains extraordinary works by the old masters. As you walk from room to room, you immediately recognize works of art that you know of but had no idea that they had been part of one man's collection. If you are tired of the crowds at the Met, stroll ten blocks south on 5th Aveune and enjoy the setting and the collection of the Frick Museum.

Excellent Art Collection Owned by Prominent New York Family. The Frick started its life as the private collection of a wealthy industrialist Henry Clay Frick, a prominent steel magnate from Pittsburgh who later moved to New York City. Like many other captains of industry turned philanthropist, Frick founded a museum and donated his art acquisitions to the public upon his death. The building itself is right near Central Park and other prominent art museums such as the Met.The museum has an excellent collection of Rococo furniture and paintings. Like the earlier Baroque, this style includes great attention to light, darkness, color and detail but adds more sensuous colors in paintings and creamy pastel ornaments in architecture and interior decor. Among the highlights are many thematic works of the 18th century French painter Francois Boucher such as the Four Seasons and the Arts & Sciences series featuring classical allegories of various disciplines. The paintings, furniture and decor blend together in an organic manner to create a cozy, convincing environment in which the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.Other prominent exhibitions include works by Van Dyck, British portrait artist Gainsborough and Italian Renaissance master Veronese. The museum contains enough unique works by great masters to make it is well worth at least one trip despite the presence of a far larger collection a few blocks away.Admissions is a reasonable $15.00 for the general public $5.00 for students.

A hidden gem. The Frick Collection is not typically regarded as one of NYC's landmark museums but it is certainly worth a visit. The space itself is wonderful, particularly the calm and elegant courtyard, which is perfect for some light reading. The Collection is varied and interested too.

One of NYC's most peaceful places. This is truly my favorite museum and I've been to many museums. There is more to look at than just art. The building itself is just an amazing work of art. It's hard to believe that was once someone's residence. It's really a breathtakingly beautiful home. There are so many beautiful rooms within the building. It really is a must see.
Awesome collection, great museum. Awesome collection, great museum. The building is really beautiful.
A gem of a museum. A small art museum in a beautiful old mansion. Great way to spend an hour. Admission is high compared to other museums for length of time you will spend there/

A private home turned museum. Besides the great art collection inside the Frick, you also get to see what it was like to be truly rich at the turn of the century. The home is a showcase even with the art.
Lovele museum. I am a born and raised NY woman and they rates right up their with MOMA, and the Metropiliatn Museum of Art.Another NYC gem!
Gem of a Small Museum. Great building, great collection, beautifully displayed. The Frick lets one pretend she is living in a grand 5th Ave. Mansion.

Fantastic. If you miss this you haven't seen New York.. Beautiful and well appointed, this museum is the only one really worth visiting in New York. Although its much smaller than many of the other larger and more well-known museums, it is a positive delight to stroll around the old Frick mansion without fear of large crowds or children and/or tourists running into you. I only with that I could live there! Alas, I will have to settle with visiting whenever I am in town. If you are not a member, I encourage you to become one. Its well worth it.

Great collection and you can see the whole place in half a day.. Very nice collection of paintings, sculpture and furnitures..and the buidling architecture itself worth a visit. It is a small place comparing to the Metropolitan Museum of Arts. Paintings include works by Monet (Vertheuil in Winter), Renoir (Mother and Children), Manet (Bullfight), and many other works by Rembrant, Degas, Vermer, Turner and Whistler.
One ofmy favorite museums. You can see a superb collection in an intimate space.
Vermeer. Go if you love Vermeer and you would like to see how the great American imper ialists lived t the turn of the century.
Always a good experience. This is just a fulfilling experience-an accessible collection and the right scale make this a wise choice for museum lovers.

A Glorious Museum in a "Private" home!. The Frick Collection is a gorgeous art collection in what was formerly the Frick's private home. It is a smallish museum with BIG things to see. Not only do you enjoy the glorious pieces, but you get to walk around in this gorgeous "home." I like the FRICK because its so manageable. One never feels overwhelmed here. You can study paintings in your own good time because of the size. It really is remarkable in so many ways.

"Frick"-in' Great Collection!. It's hard to believe that I lived in Manhattan for over 15 years and never went to the Frick Collection until yesterday--17 years after I left! We spent the day in NYC and started off at the Frick. Located on Fifth Avenue and 70th Street, in a mostly residential area--it is just slightly off the beaten touristy track--which is certainly a welcome change. We went on a Saturday, getting there before noon. Lo and behold, the street parking in this area is pretty decent. We were fortunate enough to get a parking space and noticed there were quite a bit of open spaces, just around the corner from the entrance.The Collection is amazing. A nice mix of different painters. Vermeer, Boucher, Ingres, Renior...just to name a few. Rooms are a beautiful and tasteful mix of different periods. My favorite was a room that was done in Louis XV, brought me back to my visits to Versailles! A collection of Picasso drawings was on display and, even if you aren't a huge fan of Picasso, it was worth going to see because it gives you a chance to see what a remarkable artist he really was. Not ALL of his works are abstract--which was a pleasant gift for those of us not enthralled by abstract art. Visiting the Frick makes for an extremely relaxing way to view some beautiful art and objects d'art. Also...if you aren't a fan of overwhelming and crowded museums, the Frick gives you a chance to enjoy great art at a slower and less crowded pace. It kind of reminded me of the National Gallery in DC--only at a more personal level. You don't need multiple trips and all can be covered in a couple of hours! If you like art--but just don't feel like dealing with the crowds at the Met (on weekends), by all means, check out the Frick Collection. It is a wonderful look at a private collection (even though some of the works are on loan from other museums) and just a nice pleasant couple of hours. A nice way to while away some time!Thank you for reading my review. I hope if you are in NYC, you really take some time to enjoy this collection.

'Buy me two of the best of everything'.. Frick is said to have said to his major domo, to purchase the best example of all aspects of art. His Fifth Avenue mansion is now filled with what can only be said is the most exquisite collection of furniture, sculpture and paintings anywhere outside a major museum. Indeed better than most. The great advantage is that being in a 'house' however grand, the steps from room to room bring one into contact with all types of clessical art. The paintings by Vermeer and Ingres always inspire us, yet the Gainsborough's bring the golden age oF England to the fore.

The last of the Gilded Age. The Frick is one of the last remaining Gilded Age NYC palaces and the only one that is a museum. It's beautiful and interesting. I recommend going on Sunday when it's pay what you'd like.
A great museum!. I love everything about the Frick, usually small excibits with incredible things

A hidden gem of NYC. This museum is sooo special because it has retained all of its quality as a home of a ridiculously wealthy man from 100 years ago. The ART is awesome, but its HOUSE is even better.
Wow!. Attended a private event at the Frick and wandered around. Impressive!

A unique and friendly museum. I went to the Frick collection with a friend to view an exhibition of the early years of Picasso's work. The exhibition is really fantastic (is about to move to another location), but what made the experience even more wonderful is the venue - this charming museum on the upper east side of Manhattan. The place is worth visiting at any time, even with no big name artists on display.

Another Gem in the Apple's Crown. If you get to Central Park then get to the Frick. And if you want to be sure, try the virtual tour on line first. You won't be disappointed with the collection or the history of the collection.
This is a wonderful place. The Frick has a beautiful collection of old masters in what was the Frick mansion and now is an art muesum. The venue is outstanding and the collection is truly marvellous.

Excellent way to spend a few hours. Excellent museum, not as overwhelming as the Met. However, you can't take photos inside. Every Sun between 11-1 you can pay what you want. It's an excellent way to visit the museum without spending a lot of money.

Wonderful intimate gallery that sadly doen't like babies. Had a wonderful afternoon browsing the Frick -Like visiting your very wealthy aunts house and looking at her paintings. Only off putting thing was they didn't allow babies in prams. As a mother of three (now grown) I spent may happy hours in galleries with my children. I understand the need not to infrige of others viewing pleasure with screaming infants but surely this can be worked around. Worth a visit for the intimate homely feel and great works of art.

A wonderful respite..... We had just a brief amount of time to fill between seeing the 9/11 site and getting back to the hotel for our evening events. This fit the bill perfectly. Not overly crowded and small children are not allowed. The artwork extends to the building itself as it is a grand old mansion and awesome in its own right. We were lucky enough to view the special exhibit that was there which were the works of Picasso!! Wonderful. The remaining rooms were lovely and the artwork well worth seeing. I would definately put this on your itinerary. We spent about 1 1/2 leasurely hours there which was perfect. They also provide a coat check which was convienient and quick.

Go here if you wish to be treated like rubbish!. I went on 'pay what you wish' day which meant there was no assigned ticket price; I just want to make it clear that I do not begrudge giving them some money in order to pay for the upkeep of the house and artwork but when I presented the lady at the desk with a 20 dollar bill after already getting a snotty look from her, it was snatched out of my hand and accepted with a comment of "Is that all?" (Bearing in mind that normal ticket prices are only 5 dollars more).Besides this I was adamant to stay and look at the art work and the house, which was quite lovely however at one point I was standing a good couple of feet from a window in one of the rooms and instead of one of the staff members asking my politely to move if this was a problem I was promptly clicked at like a dog. Was not happy.Overall, beautiful house and nice artwork but the staff ruined the day for me.

Picasso drawings exhibition fantastic. The Frick is a stunning museum, with the building itself - the former residence of Henry Clay Frick on 5th Avenue over looking Central Park, the main exhibit. We saw a temporary Picasso exhibition, which was thrilling, but the old masters in the permanent Frick collection will take your breath away. And on certain days of the week (I think we were there on a Sunday morning when this applied), you pay what you can afford, so it offers an excellent opportunity for budget travellers to experience one of the great private art collections of the 20th century.

Only visit if you like rude people!. I visited on Sunday 11th December during a 'pay what you wish' period. The normal entrance fee is $18 and I had intended to pay $15 - I offered the pay clerk a $20 bill (not having any other change). This was taken without asking if I intended to pay the full $20 with a look that was so intimidating that I didn't dare ask for change!The Frick has a bizarre rule that if you remove your coat for any reason, you have to check it in. I arrived on a cold morning and combined with that and a massive line for coat check, I kept my coat on. During my visit, I became warm and draped my coat around my shoulders - during the one minute that it took me to remove it and then put it round my shoulders, I was shouted (and I mean shouted) at by two members of staff to put my coat on or check it! If the rule is to prevent people with coats over their arm stealing property and concealing it beneath their coat - maybe they should ask that rucksacks are checked in (rather than banging into other visitors all the time!)I asked another member of staff for directions to the rest room - I was given a look that would cut glass and was disdainfully pointed in the general direction; she did not have the courtesy to speak to me!The final straw was in one of the rooms - I was standing approximately 2 feet from a window, admiring the view into the garden. There were no exhibits within arms length yet one of the attendants decided to tell me to move away from the window by snapping his fingers at me! Not having the manners to speak to me to ask me to move, he decided to treat me as a pet dog!The house is beautiful and the exhibits interesting but my visit was ruined by rude and ignorant staff. I would never return there and would not recommend anyone else to do so it they have any shred of self-respect!

A Great Place to Visit. The Frick is one of my favourite places in New York. The variety of the collection combined with the quality of the artifacts and that they are all in one house makes this a wonderful place to spend some time.
Very special collection of art. Probably the finest private collection i the U.S. Worth going twice.
low-key but great museum. one of my fave museums in the world! the facility itself is a piece of art! definitely worth a visit; less people and crowds
a must for New York. included in the entrance ticket, you are receiving very helpfull headphones, changing your visit to be a " private guided tour ".
Disappointed. crowded, half closed for private function, expensive and this is an art gallery not a stately old home, very aggressive security guards.
One of best museums in the world!. Best art, best atmosphere, wonderful shows. One of NYC's treasures!
