Beautiful mansion and small, nice museum. This museum is worth a visit, it used to be the private manion of Frick, right on 5th Avenue. Sitting by the indoor fountain is a real respite from the frenetic city, a small haven.
one of the world's great museums. This is an oasis of elegance and pleasure in the middle of New York City. The collection is as good as it gets and the atmosphere is wondrous.
Gorgeous collection. Go on Sunday before 1 when it is free. It is expensive otherwise. Not that it isn't worth it, it is beautiful.

How the other half lived!. My husband and I loved this museum. It was originally the home (well, mansion) of Henry Clay Frick and it is thought that he purposely designed the building so that it could function as a museum after his death. The collection is impressive and includes some important European paintings and sculptures, as well as bronzes, enamels, furniture and rugs. You get to see many of the works exactly as Frick had placed them. It took us about two hours to see everything. I liked that it was small and you could see some great artworks without taking up most of the day.

Small Collection, but Big-Time Artists. The Frick is not a museum; it is an experience. You get to view a wide and rich range of European paintings (representing the Middle Ages to late 19th Century), as you soak in the ambiance of the Neo-classical period furniture and architecture. The setting is intimate, but the collection is expansive in terms of representing so many masters: Fragonard, Gainsborough, El Greco, Fra Filippo Lippi, Renoir, Titian, Whistler, Ingres . . . and not just 1 Vermeer painting, but 3! My experience at the Frick was personal, non rushed, and visually and emotionally stimulating. A hidden gem!
Paintings are exqusite. Beautiful collection of paintings and sculptures.The exhibition on Picasso was very informative from the layman's point of view.
Brilliant. Makes you realise just what it must have been like to be living the high life in NYC at the start of the 20th Century. Fantastic!
Wonderful museum in a charming old mansion. I love this museum! So peaceful, especially on weekdays and wonderful art. Love the indoor courtyard too!
Best small museum in NC. The Vermeers are amazing, but the Giovanni Bellini "St. Francis in Ecstasy" is one of the top five paintings in the USA.
Less than expected. The building is great, but the collection is kinda random

Our favorite museum in NY city!. This is our most favorite museum in NY city. It is small enough to go around in 2 hours yet world class museum. It is not overwhelming like MET. Our son just became 10 years old and was able to enter with us. It was his first visit and he really enjoyed listening to the audio headset. Must see in NY city.
Loved the Picasso!. Great intimate museum right across from Central Park! Loved the Picasso exhibit.
Wonderful small museum. Get tickets in advance, small elegant collection, easy to do from Metropolitan arae, quiet and uncrowded

Talk about the "1%"!. For an appreciation of the true differences between the "haves" and the "have nots" a visit to the Frick is a wonderful way to spend a couple of hours. True, a portion of the "home" has been added post-Frick to display the precious art collection, but the evidence of lavish living is still ever present and obvious. The grand mansion, its exquisite furnishings and one-of-a-kind art collection should be a "must visit".

Excellent. As I do not live in New York, It has been many years, of my
last visit to this magnificent place. A beautiful house, well kept, and
a wonderful collection. Worth the visit, I advised visitors to go to this
"small" museum. At the moment there is a very interesting "Picasso"exhibition.
Outstanding small museum. This is a beautiful small museum in a former private home. It includes an extensive private collection of European masters.

I'm an art snob. This is the place to go!. I have visited here regularly over the past 42 years. It is not a place for kids either, but if you want to see painting -- yes, real painting, not modern art, and see them in a setting where they were meant to be seen, so not in a warehouse, try this one. It is all on one floor, and unlike the MET does not seem at all like grand central station.
A Magnificent Echo of Bygone Lifestyles. The building alone is worth the entry and the collection is fabulous. Periodic exhibits are always first rate and well worth your time.

What a wonderful collection!. Most people go to the Frick to see the fantastic colletion of paintings by Veermer, Rembrant, Franz Hall, Goya, Velasquez, and other masters, but pay also attention to the furniture, clocks, bronzes, porcelains, enamels, rugs, and the many pieces Frick collected. As a small museum it rivals the Mauritshuis Museum in The Hague. The audio guide is mildly useful but is free.

The best bite-size museum anywhere. The Frick Museum not only has a world class art collection, but displays it as the Fricks lived with it. The museum exhibits small temporary exhibitions, but I return annually just to revisit the permanent collection.

Small but Interesting!. The Frick museum is right near the Metropolitan Museum of Art but is is a fabulous home that has been dedicated to being a museum...it was even built to house all of the Frick's art. It is a fun home to see and the art is wonderful...several famous artist's work...takes about an hour and I liked seeing a glimpse into the life of the very wealthy of New York and how they lived.
Love this little museum. What a great little museum - worth the $10. Such a little jewel. If you like Klimt, this is a must see.
Surprising Collection. Both my husband and I were thrilled to see works of art we had only previously seen in books. Beautifully staged in a stunning home.

Beautiful house, amazing collection. Definitely get to this one if you love art. The house is amazing near Central Park and is relatively small but a wide variety of artist. Gorgeous. I didn't have time to see Picasso's drawings as the lines were long. I'm not sure if this is the case all the time or just when I went - as I went on a Sunday between 11-1 when you pay what you want instead of the $18.

Picasso, the first 30 years. We came here specifically to see the Picasso exhibit, the first 30 years. It's on the lower level. I had seen the drawings in Art History books from college but to see them up close and personal was a wonderful experience. The museum used to be the personal residence of Mr. Frick who had always planned to turn the house into a museum after his death. After we saw the Picasso exhibit, we walked around and saw the rest of the collection, many large portraits from the masters. Visitors can enjoy the collection of paintings, sculptures, furniture and architecture all in one location. I would highly recommend this museum for anyone visiting the city.

Don't miss this little gem. From the exquisite house and gardens to the impressive and beautiful art collection, this is a NYC sight I am glad not to have missed. Particularly if you are limited in terms of time, then this is a wonderful option and a worthwhile way to spend a morning or afternoon. Its location across the road from Central Park make for a good day out. This is a really special collection of cearfully selected furniture, ceramics and paintings that will feed your soul.
A Time Capsule from the Gilded Age. One of the few remaining NYC mansions from the robber baron era, this is well worth a visit.

Delightful mix, emphasis on portraiture, amazing collection. This museum is well worth a visit. Calling it charming risks leaving the impression that the collection is less grand than it is, yet it manages to be both charming and grand all at once. The building is a delight all by itself. The artwork is diverse and pleasing and largely reflects the tastes of a man who was drawn to neither the jarring nor the abstract. The next time I go, I will find a day that the museum is sure to be less crowded so that I can linger longer. Rooms are a little small for the number of items displayed and can feel overcrowded. But even on a busy day, the Frick is treat.

Worth seeing. I found out about the Frisk Collection from a woman I sat next to at a coffee shop. I'm so glad I went. A wonderful Picasso exhibit was showcased when I visited, and I gained a new appreciation for his talent. The movie they show gives a great overview of the history of the collection (and it's a nice opportunity to rest your feet!). I only had a couple of hours to see the collection, and would like to go back again in the future to see more of it.

Small magnificent collection of art. What a small but superb collection of art! It is housed in a perfect setting--the house itself is a work of art with exquisite woodwork, interior courtyard, and a garden designed by Russell Page. If you go on Sunday between 11 and 1, you can give whatever donation you like.
museum. for a small museum , it is a diamond in the rough, . what a find!!

My New Favorite Museum in New York City. I adore the Metropolitan Museum of Art, have a great time at MOMA (the Museum of Modern Art) and the Guggenheim and the other NYC museums, but I have to say that my new favorite is the Frick Collection. I had been there years ago and loved it back then, but honestly had forgotten about it until recently. The current Picasso Drawings exhibit brought me there this time, but its permanent collection housed in structural masterpiece is totally unbelievable and well worth any visit! The Frick Collection is located in a superb mansion built by the controversial industrialist Henry Clay Frick (1849-1919). Though he was a questionable character, his taste in art was impeccable. There are 16 galleries of paintings by some of the world's greatest masters including Vermeer, Rembrandt, El Greco, Titian, Degas, Goya, Turner Van Dyke, Gainsborough and Renoir. The Rembrandts and Vermeers were truly out of this world! Each room at the Frick is magnificent but somehow intimate as well, giving you the feel that you are in someone's real home. At every turn is another take-your-breath-away surprise, including the serene Garden Court where you can pause and listen to the soothing fountain and look up towards the skylight.The Frick is just off of 5th Avenue and across from Central Park, and is a perfect respite from a busy day and a great place to whisk you back into time where you can pretend that you are a wealthy magnate with one of the most amazing art collections in the world.
A gem. This is truly one of the most beautiful private collections in the world. I love the small bronzes!

Fabulous collection. Where else can you see so many pictures you've only seen in books. The Holbeins of More and Cromwell were a special treat, as were the Turners and Gainsboroughs. The special Picasso exhibit was also worth a visit on its own.

The Frick - awesome collection and not overwhelming. Liked: Docent tour- learn about Mr Frick and how he got his collection.
Disliked: Checking my large purse

Amazing!. The Frick collection is a must for lovers of art, especially art from the Renaissance to the19th Century. While a small collection it includes paintings by Rembrandt, Bellini, Holbein, Gainsborough, Constable and many other renowned artists. In addition, it exhibits furniture, porcelain, sculpture, etc. The mansion and most of the art were donated to New York by Henry Frick. Portraits of Thomas More and Thomas Cromwell by Hans Helbein are situated on opposing sides of the same wall representing their relationship in life. Be sure not to miss this wonderful collection.TIP: Use the free recording device which provides interesting information of selected pieces.

After the MET, a great small museum to visit. Tough choice deciding to go here or the Neue for a couple of hours. The collection here is more diverse, and you get an interesting look into a grand mansion from that period. A good mix of art and history ready to be appreciated.
Worth seeing. Visited this fantastic museum and we were never bored. Great staff and beautiful display of art. Look forward to visiting again.
Like an art museum in a Mansion.. Don't miss it....$18 for adults, $10 for students with IDs. Catch the movie also.
The biggest surprise of our trip. Both the collection of paintings and sculptures and the house was a pleasure to experience. It is definitely a friendly museum.
Outstanding. If you find big museums overwhelming this is the place for you. A beautiful setting, wonderful collection. Just right.

Marvellous. The good thing about this museum is that the quality of every painting and work of art is outstanding. Obviously the collectiion is not comprehensive, but it's pure class and you won't get overwhelmed by the number of galleries and periods like you do in the Metropolitan Museum. The building itself is rather fine too. A must see attraction.
Beautiful museum. Wonderful art collection-one of the best and in a fantastic venue. A must see when in NYC.
Worth a trip. Great Rembrandt exhibit, beautiful old building, not too overwhelming, wonderful pieces
The fab. Frick. Always as great way to spend an afternoon. The building alone is worth the admission.
Wonderful collection of art. There's currently a fantastic exhibit of Picasso's work. Beautiful environment in which to spend an afternoon.
Picasso @ FRICK. Exhibit of Picasso drawings worth a visit, along with tour of Frick's remarkable collection

Go. See. Impress your friends. This is one of the lesser known and visited museums in NYC; not unknown, but less busy, less frequented and equivalent to the Musee De Orsay in Paris. Great place to impress someone with your knowledge of NYC beyond the most obvious places.

Small and perfect. A great place to go if you don't have a great deal of time, like we went before flying out in the afternoon. Knocked out by the many portraits but especially loved seeing the REAL Sir Thomas More painting in the flesh so to speak! Go early if possible to avoid the crowds.
Grand Master overload!. What a collection! Wonderful works of art, mostly big-hitting grand masters, in a gorgeous setting.

A must see in NYC. A local New Yorker that I met recommended the Frick Collection and I'm so glad he did as it was my favourite attraction in NYC. The Frick Collection allows you to experience the personal art collection of an incredibly wealthy NY figure in the home he lived in. There is also a video about his life that gives you an insight into him and his motivation for putting the collection together to share with the public.

Great art museum. Visited with my wife. Amazing collection of art in a unique architectural setting. You can view the entire collection in an afternoon, so it is not as overwhelming as the nearby Met. Spend a few hours, it is well worth the visit.
Inexpensive and accessible. A beautiful building! A smaller museum that you don't have to spend all day in...

hurray for the robber barons!. The museum/mansion itself is as awesome as the artwork in it (Rembrandt's self portrait). Guidebooks say it's free on Sundays from 11AM to 1PM, but that's not true, although one can make a reasonable "donation" to get in. Well worth it.
Fantastic Collection of Art. Loved the building and all the works of art. Dont miss it
Interesting art in a former home. Look at art without spending a whole day, also my daughter (13 years) liked it. A bit expensive though.

Be sure to use audio-guide. The Frick has become perhaps our favourite of all the museums in all the countries we have travelled in. We felt we were in with a mix of people who had come because they love great art, not because they were in a rush to collect the names on the walls, which is how we had felt at the Met. Very impressive selection of pictures. We do recommend you use the audio-guide.
Best art gallery in New York. Loved The Frick. Seeing Vermeers, Rembrandts and Renoirs in a gallery are one thing; seeing them in this setting is something else!

Unbelievable. This collection was recommended to us several years ago. The manor is unbelievable and the works of art stunning. You just don't know what to look at first. A must if you are going to NYC.

Fascinating glimpse of the past. We visited on a Sunday morning when it is "pay as you wish" and although there was a short queue outside, it moved quickly, and didn't seem too crowded inside. Very interesting exhibition of Picasso drawings downstairs at the moment. Loved the old rooms and wandering around the house, taking in all the old masterpieces and beautiful antique furniture. Children are not allowed and you get the impression that you are being watched all the time by the very assiduous 'museum' attendants! Guess they are just protecting the heirlooms but you did feel you had to be on your best behavior as you were being closely monitored! Some people might not like this atmosphere.
Don't miss this gem. If you are into museums and want to do something else than MOMA or Metropolitan for a chance, go to Frick, a small but exquisite museum near Metropolitan Museum of Art

How the One Perent Lived. The Frick Collection is interesting because it is not only a museum with fine works of art, but also the house of Henry Clay Frick , an early 20th Century industrialist. Frick was not born to money, but worked his way up from a clerk to the owner of coke mines in Western Pennsylvania. As coke was used in the manufacture of steel, he went into business with Andrew Carnegie and became extremely wealthy. After a bitter strike and a breakup with Carnegie, he moved to New York and became an art collector. The house at 70th Street was built not only as a home, but also as a gallery to house a pretty spectacular art collection. It was always Frick's intention to turn his house into a museum after his death. And an impressive collection of art it is. But the nice thing about it, is that it is manageable. You can spend a very pleasant couple of hours viewing art in comfortable surroundings, and not be totally overwhelmed, like at the MET. Definitely a little gem and worth your time.

An old Manor in NewYork. Loved the Museum. you feel how the family lived during their time in NY and view their collections and their home. The watergarden is really lovely and quiet. sitting here and listening to the water gush in and out of the fountains is beautiful.

My favorite museum in NYC. Love this gorgeous home, preserved as if Henry Clay Frick was due home at any minute. Budget at least two hours, and you wont want to leave. The art is stunning, the furniture a treasure. Great staff, nice gifts store, and wonderful concerts.Free/discounted early on Sundays

How the other half lived. Well worth the stop on the hop-on hop-off bust tour. The Frick has an astounding collection of paintings and furniture, all exquisite and beautifully presented. You can really get a feel of what it must have been like to have been very very rich in New York in the early 20th century.
Outstanding Collection. Set in a beautiful mansion: a setting of a time gone by. This beautiful collection can be enjoyed in this excellent venue.

Magnificent - Especially for Free on Sunday. It's actually "Pay What You Wish" between 11:00 am and 1:00 pm on Sundays. So I paid a dollar. The ticket seller didn't even blink an eye. And it isn't as if you're only allowed to stay for those two hours. As long as you're in by 1:00pm you can stay until closing. We arrived around 12:45 and simply walked in. No lineups whatsover. The other great things (from a financial viewpoint) is that checking your coat is FREE, and the audio guide is FREE. And that audio guide is one of the best I've ever encountered. Easy to use and full of useful but not too fancy information. You just walk around and punch in the number of the artwork you want to see, and presto - a one minute explanation in simple English. Oh, and did I mention that the artworks are fabulous? All the great masters are here, and wonderfully displayed. This is taking over as my favourite New York Museum.

a MUST in NYC. This really is a very nice art collection. I liked the intimate atmosphere. I prefere this museum over the bigger ones in NY, just because you don't feel like being lost between all the artpieces.. You can really visit the museum very well in about 2 hours. (or even less). I really really loved it!
Gorgeous. Transport yourself back in time and enjoy the art and opulent surroundings as if you were a guest in this magnificent home.

A Jewel. ALways worth finding time to visit the Frick. A personal as opposed to an institutional collection of fine art in a wonderful house right by Central Park. Great Picasso Exhibition on at present. Go!

A great surprise. A little treasure, a boutique museum I would say. Forget the huge and noisy rooms of the big NYC museum when you enter here and wander around the rooms of Mr Frick's amzing house. Every room is full of astonishing art treasures, precious paintings above all and then furniture, vases and so on.It is quite small and it took less than an hour to visit it so you will not get bored or tired.

Given a few hundred million, this is how I'd spend it.. What an education in art. Artists I'd never heard of, just simply the best of the various genres. Beautifully displayed and an excellent shop with very good assistants. We had the lat 5 minutes before being thrown out but the assistant after what must have been a long day too, still took the trouble to advise us. Great advice too. We couldn't see the central courtyard as Tiffanies were having some party on; a shame and arguably could have provided us with a discount from the steep entrance fee, but the whole place was too good to complain and time was better spent soaking it all up. Simply have to return one day.

always loved this museum. once a house filled with treasures, still a house filled with treasures. A little expensive considering some of the galleries had missing pieces or were closed off this visit, but still pleasurable, off the beaten track; 13th century art pieces quite special

Our favourite museum in NY. Small, beautifully laid out, exquisitely furnished and decorated, and the art contained there - just wonderful. The two pictures by Holbein (Moore and Cromwell) either side of the fireplace were particularly noteworthy - they are in the popular conscious of the English, but actually seeing them "in the flesh" was awesome. Worth visiting New York just to see this collection! Stunning.

A Gem!. I can't believe I'd never visited this beautiful museum before. The building itself is worth the price of admission, but the art is spectacular and it's a pleasure to see it in such an intimate setting. It's a very manageable museum experience--not overwhelming like larger museums can be. I look forward to going back. (Nice gift shop, too!)

Frick was interesting. The museum was a private home converted to a museum. we went on a Sunday morning and it was "pay what you want" time. It occurs once a week I believe. We got there on the Red Hop on -Hop Off Bus.They told us about the discount time period.
The building was beautiful and has lots of art to see.
Love this museum. A small intimate museum. Always take the time to check out the new exhibits.

Step into glorious art and architecture at The Frick. A mansion filled with 16 galleries of art from Rembrandt to Renoir, antiques and treasures. Try to see the intro film first. The Frick Collection includes some of the best-known paintings by the greatest European artists, major works of sculpture (among them one of the finest groups of small bronzes in the world), superb eighteenth-century French furniture and porcelains, Limoges enamels, Oriental rugs, and other works of remarkable quality.A true delight to visit.

The art collection is simple awesome & the house is incredibly elegant.. This museum is a quiet respite from the busy streets of Manhattan. You enter and feel like you are a guest in the Frick's incredible mansion . What a gift it was to us that they made sure their collection would always be shared with the public. It is fabulously broadbased.......furniture, porcelain, rugs, clocks, sculpture and French, Dutch, Spanish, American, etc. masterpieces. A feast for the eyes. The Garden Court is a lovely spot for a meditative rest.

Not my Favorite. After visiting Th MOMA the day before, the Frick was a big letdown. But it is primarily older art and I prefer more modern stuff. But still there are jewels to find here. Bellini, Vermeer, El Greco, Rembrandt, Frans Hals, de la Tour and Fra Filippo Lippi all are a pleasure. Not so much the fluffy, sickeningly saccharine Bouchers and Fragonards. There was a Picasso exhibit that was small but excellent, even though I am not crazy about Picasso. But the museum was disappointing in several other ways. Unlike at the MOMA, you had to pay extra for an audio device and there was a dearth of information offered. One quarter of the main gallery was denuded. It was darkish. It really is not that large.

Fantastic. The number and quality of old masters is astounding! To think this was once a private collection is unbelievable. There is an introductory film explaining Mr. Frick and his art but we only stumbled upon it and there is no posting of when or how often it is shown. That would have been a help. From now through January there is also an exhibition of early Picasso, an added bonus. Well worth it for the art lovers.
Spacious old home which is now a museum. Not to be missed, great collection....lovely interior courtyard. Not as crowded as the other museums

Art without suffering a Museum. If you hate the large and souless type of museum/gallery presentation then the Frick is for you.A beautiful mansion setting opposite Central Park allows visitors to enjoy a private art collection in a peaceful and relaxed style and in hour or two.If time is short in NY then this should be a MUST for art lovers The shop also sells very well priced gifts

Great collection - lousy staff. I'd been looking forward to my visit to the Frick Collection for years and years and the art didn't let me down. But the attitude of the cloakroom staff, who seem to think that all visitors are potential terrorists and therefore should be treated with rudeness and a total lack of care, set a very poor tone for the rest of my visit. I know that all attractions need to be very security conscious but this doesn't mean that visitors have to be regarded as something that's been picked up on the bottom of the staffs' shoes.

Lovely Museum in a Unique Environment. Great museum and relatively unique given it is located in an old residence! I like this aspect of it, as it makes it much more interesting, because it is a different environment than you would find in a normal museum. Great collection of works and a good size, not too overwhelming.

Amazing Art. Three of us went to the Frick Collection on a Saturday afternoon. We spent a very pleasant three hours at the museum and could have stayed for another two hours. The art is remarkable and arranged in a different and interesting way. We liked the size of the museum. We walked through it using the audio guide and then went back to our favorite rooms. Be sure to watch the video - explains the building and a little about the Frick family.
Excelent collection in a perfect setting. I got this tip from colleagues and absolutely loved it - such a variety in the collection and such nice setting. I will go again, for sure.

My Favorite NY Museum. A perfect gem of a place. Several gorgeous Vermeer's on view. Small scale, exquisite touches. Rooms give a good sense of what life was like for some during the Gilded Age. Small children are not admitted, which makes it a good get-away if you're in hiding from your own children!

I loved this place. I quite like art galleruies but am not a fan of the big crowds galleries in the major cities of the world attract. Last year while I was in Paris I decided to visit a couple of the smaller galleries and found the collections superb so on my trip to New York this month I thought I'd do the same and bypass the big museums and have a look at some smaller ones like the Frick. The art was mesmerising and the size of the collection was perfect as I find that after 3 or 4 hours looking at paintings i lose a bit of perspectice and don't really sak it in and that didn't happen here. There was plenty to see but not so much that it loses meaning. I've since read a bit about the Mt Frick who establised the collection and it turns out he wasn't a very nice guy at all but hats off to his selection of art works as he and those who have furthered the collection since his death have done a great job.

We did not want to leave!. This is our second visit to this fabulous museum. It was as fabulous the second time as the first. It is remarkable that so many important pieces of work were acquired by one man. It is truly a must see when visiting NYC!

Make sure you go here!. This collection is wonderful. It is a private collection so the art has wide appeal. The collection is the perfect size for you to appreciate each piece and you can start to see patterns or trends in what was collected. One of the highlights of our New York trip.

Make the time. The Frick was fabulous. It is a mansion with great works of art in it. I felt like I experienced, for a couple of hours, what it would be like to actually live with such wonderful treasures. The story of the man behind the money and his taste for art was also interesting. It's a gorgeous property that Mr Frick bought in the early 1900's for 5 million to give you an idea of it's lavishness.

Large enough to spend 2 hours. This museum was larger that I thought, but still intimate enough to be able to take my time. There are a few iconic pieces and great portraits. The interior of the mansion was fabulous. The free audio tour was very handy and did not drone on. We took a cab down 5th from the Guggenheim. It cost $5 and was well worth saving our feet for the museums.
One of the most Beautiful Museums/Galleries we have ever been to!. The Frick Collection is a beautiful. I love touring mansions with lovely furnishings, and art galleries. The Frick has both!

Awesome Art Gallery. This is a wonderful art gallery in a former mansion. I was pleasantly surprised at the artists works that were on display there. Lighting was much better than in other museums I have been to. Staff very pleasant and helpful. Would highly recommend!

Amazing collection in a stunning building. Despite being a horrid businessman Mr Frick left an amazing legacy to the world both through his house and art collection. It is truly stunning but has the advantage of great intimacy for the viewer. One of the great galleries of the world.Not good for little kids but the audio players which are included in the price are really good. They also have short films explaining the history of the Frick as well.

Top Ten in the World. Having seen many of the best musuems in the world, the Frick Collection, was a delight. Much like the Borghese or Mauritshuis, this collection is the vision of one man and remains in the impressive 5th avenue mansion he built to display his art. The collection is world class, from the 3 Vermeers to a whole room by Fragonard. Truly a gem and a must do.

Amazing artwork and furnishings, very accessible.. When choosing among the myriad activities in NYC, the Frick Collection is on the top of my list. An example of outstanding townhouse architecture, this home is full of beautiful paintings, sculpture, and furnishings. It can be toured in a minimum 1 l/2 hours, but 2-3 hours would be great. The location on Central Park East also makes it an excellent activity before Sunday brunch/lunch at the Central Park Boathouse. But be aware that early admission to the Frick is by voluntary donation on Sunday mornings, so it can become busy. If you admire Old Master paintings, as well as European masterpieces by Turner & Gainsborough, you must visit the Frick Collection.

Some of the very best in art and architecture. The Frick Collection may be the best small art museum in the United States. The museum, formerly known as the Henry Clay Frick House, was the New York City residence of steel magnate Henry Clay Frick. The neoclassical mansion was built between 1913 and 1914 and was designed by Thomas Hastings. Wandering about you will find gardens, fountains, exceptional woodwork, fine furniture, decorative items, and Oriental rugs that weave a wonderful tapestry of how the super-rich of the Gilded Age lived. The furnishings of the mansion impart a sense of beauty and craftsmanship seldom seen today. I often find myself staring at the walls and ceilings of every room marveling at the wonderful woodwork and trim. The west side of the mansion faces Central Park and creates a sense of dignified and quiet solitude that belies its presence in one the busiest cities in the world.While the mansion is opulent and beautiful the artwork it contains is even more precious. You will see some of the very best works by some of the very best old master painters; El Greco, Goya, Holbein, Van Dyck, Velázquez, and Whistler just to name a few. Every painting is lovingly arranged and every room has a character and life of its own. While the mansion is hardly small, it feels intimate and can be reasonably appreciated in a couple of hours.

Art for the Serious Admirer. Banishing children and providing limited explanatory texts on its wall, “The Frick” aims at more serious art aficionados relative to other general exhibitors elsewhere in the city. Like the J.P. Morgan Library and Museum, The Frick used to be sumptuous private digs and with its indoor fountain garden and grand, gilded rooms, it is quite the sight to behold. This serious space focuses on serious works particularly 15th century Dutch masters and their darkly rendered large scale portraiture. The solemnity of the collection is such that a brightly-colored Renoir of a mother and two daughters comes as a welcome relief as guests encountered it in a hallway (not quite the place of honor). The impressionist master does better than Rembrandt, however, who finds his many, many, many self-portraits hung in the crowded, small, airless lower floor (cellar?). Those holding MFA’s or otherwise knowledgeable about art or fans of interiors will love The Frick but the more general museum-goer will be better served elsewhere.
Beatiful Museum!. It is a very nice little museum, beautiful furniture, great paintings, lovely patio and the Museum Shop have excellent and unique gifts!
Dont miss it!. 2nd visit, small, mind blowing, perfect. What's to say. Great guide service free...hand held monologue free

Wonderful collection for the casual art appreciator, too. Even though I lived in NYC for 5 years, I never made it to this museum. I went on my last visit to NYC and can't believe it took me so long to get there! The collection is outstanding, and as a non-art historian, I particularly enjoyed recognizing many of the artists from my school days--JMW Turner, El Greco, Goya, Ingres, etc. It was not as overwhelming as the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and much less crowded. We arrived just in time for the 10-minute introduction to the house, which is certainly not a must but was helpful in framing our visit. We did not get the recorded tour, but I would next time.

A great little museum. Firstly this museum is free on a Sunday afternoon. That is when i went.With that in mind it is excellent value. If i was paying the usual entry fee i would definitely feel it was too expensive.It is a lovely museum to walk around though sadly we couldn't get to the gardens. Many of the finest British artists are on display here such as Constable, Turner and Gainsborough. A certain Mr Renoir will enchant you with 1 painting on display.It won't take you long to go around this museum. 2 hours maximum. There is a short video telling you about the history of the museum which is interesing and informative.If money is tight and you can't see it on a Sunday afternoon then i would consider avoiding this and going to the incredible Metropolitan Museum of Art which is close by.

So great - one of our favorite sites in Manhattan. We were so pleased with our trip to the Frick Collection! It is a spectacular collection but is still a reasonable enough size to see all the pieces well in a day or even half day. The audio tour that comes with your entrance fee really gives interesting details on the rooms and pieces. Plus it has a whole other demension to the collection by being in the Frick House, which is so beautiful and gives a wonderful sense of old, grand New York. It was a big highlight in our trip! We loved being able to really appreciate all the pieces and will be back again forsure!

A gem of a small museum. New York has some big museums. You "DO" the Metropolitan Museum of Art and come away with sore feet. You visit and enjoy the Frick -- and make it a point to come back each time you are in New York.The Frick, on the east side of Central Park is just the opposite of the Met. The home of robber baron Henry Clay Frick, it is a house like other wealthy people had in the 1890's. Fifth Avenue was THE address. Only the Frick home has remained -- as a museum. The side facing Fifth avenue was the old entrance and you can see where the horse drawn carriages would pull in to drop people at the old front door. The collection is simply what he liked -- and he liked the best. There is something here for everyone: from Hans Holbiens in the 1500's, to El Greco to the frou frou Fragonards to a charming Renoir in the late 1800's.. The gift shop is a great place to shop for holiday gifts -- lovely unique note cards, etc. If you have limited time and limited ability to "endure" big museums, DO see the Frick.

Art gallery with a difference. The Frick Collection is well aware of its own distinctive character, but as yet not many people appreciate that uniqueness. This is one man's collection sited in the home he built to house it. The paintings and sculptures are wonderful. The provenance of each item, the design and construction of the mansion, and the trustees' subsequent decisions all go to make an enthralling and instructive journey. A hour or two in the tranquil setting of the Frick Collection is not only an art history joy, but is also a great insight into the lives of the ruling magnates of US industry, and the NYC tycoons of the late 19th century.

A beautiful, quiet oasis near noisy, crowded Central Park. On a recent very hot Saturday afternoon when all of NYC was out and about and filling the streets and the Park, we stumbled into the Frick looking for an escape. What a find it was! The collection is located in the gorgeous home of Mr. Frick, who had a keen eye for art. There are several world-renowned works by the great masters, instantly recognizable to the art collector and the novice alike. Visitors are allowed to come quite close to the art and to enjoy it up close and personal. Our brush with fame while there... Yoko Ono and Sean Lennon walked in just behind us!The home itself is stunningly beautiful, as breath-taking as the artwork.Although the entry fee is high, it is more than worth the expense.

Way too expensive. If you visit, be sure to check in adance that the entire museum is open. I visited in September 2009. Considering half of the collection was not available at the time (it was either loaned out or in the process of being changed),you would think that they would discount the ridiculous $18US entry charge.Even if the entire museum was open $18 is still too expensive condidering what the other much larger museums charge.

Art in a beautiful New York Mansion. The Frick Collection – New YorkOn holiday in New York and interested in paintings, porcelain and furniture? Then take a trip to the Frick Collection at 1 East 70 Th Street and Fifth Avenue opposite Central Park.This amazing collection was formed by Henry Clay Frick (1849 – 1919), a well known industrialist, and is housed in his New York home, a mansion in the European style of the 18th century. The rooms remind you of English & French interiors of this period.You enter the building via the main door on East 70th Street. This brings you into a beautiful entrance hall and then into a Reception Hall, where you can leave your coat and pick up a guide to the House, there is also a Museum Shop right next door. There are twenty rooms to visit in all, including a Garden Court, which is really a Winter Garden with a pool and fountain, a nice place to relax when you need a rest. There is a suggested order to visit the rooms, but you can in fact visit them in any order, they are all on the ground floor. Most of the rooms contain important paintings, furniture, clocks and porcelain and have the names and functions from Mr Frick’s time. I started out in the Hall and walked through to the Boucher Room, named after the French 18th Century painter. This room contains eight large paintings by Boucher arranged round the room with a theme of Arts & Sciences. Apart from the paintings there is a spectacular writing table by Jean – Henri Riesener, one of the best cabinet makers of the 18th Century. There is also some very fine Sevres porcelain and the overall feel is like being in a wonderful French chateau. After visiting the Boucher room, I moved on to the Dining Room, here all the paintings are English by Hogarth, Reynolds, Gainsborough and Hoppner. In contrast to the Boucher Room, where the feeling is of a French room, this room is very English and typical of a grand Country House. As I moved from one room to the next, a feeling of excitement grew and I was not disappointed.I cannot cover all the rooms in this article, however one other room you must see is The West Gallery as it is without doubt the most amazing room of all. There cannot be many rooms in a Private House anywhere with such a spectacular collection. I marvelled at one great painting after another, you can see Corot, Van Dyck, Van Ruisdael, Turner, Hals, Hobbema, Constable, Lorrain, Veronese, David, Rembrandt, De la Tour, Goya, Cuyp, Vermeer, Velazquez and El Greco. Another good reason for visiting the Frick is that you can visit the collection in a relatively short time, say an hour and a half, whereas a visit to the Metropolitan Museum takes considerably longer even if you are only seeing part of the collection. Do go, you will have a great time, I guarantee it!

Don't overlook this one.. The Frick Collection is a bite-sized art lover's dream. The building was made to lovingly house the collection, and is a work of art itself. Vermeer, Rembrant, David, Manet, Velasquez, J.M.W. Turner, Holbein, Boucher, Engres, Gainsbourgh, Titian, Van Dyke - so many heavy hitters represented here - even Ducchio and Cimebue! (drop over spring of '10 after you see the Bronzino drawings exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum to see a second full-sized Bronzino portrait) If you have only 2 hours, and love Painting and sculpture from the pre-Renaissance period to 1860ish this is more doable than the Met - and just down the street.

Great Expectations Exceeded. The Frick is a gem! The mansion itself is a work of art , and the furnishings and paintings are simply incredible. I only wish the store sold books showing the works hanging in their respective homes. Their surroundings truly added to the beauty like nothing I'd ever seen before. Be sure to pick up the free audio tour for fascinating details. Don't go hungry though...not many places to eat nearby. I had read it would take approximately 1 1/2 to 2 hours and I was there nearly 4 and still didn't see it all. Also, you're near an entrance to Central Park, so go in and enjoy nature as well. PARENTS -- Do not try to bring your kids. It's well publicized that they are not allowed and they do not make exceptions. Please don't hold up the line arguing with the staff.

Real gem of art collection in New York. This is a really nice place to visit that although popular is not overcrowed. the collection is impressive and a must for art lovers. As a student i got a good discount. You could easily spent a good amount of time taking in the Frick collection. One of the top things to do during a visit to New York

Best small museum in the city!. I love the Frick Collection. It's got an amazing array of art of the building itself is beautiful. One caution would be that the regular admission price is insane. I recommend going early on a Sunday when you can pay what you want.

Most enjoyable museum in New York. Having just trashed the Morgan Library, I shall shower praise upon what I believe to be one of the world's two best small museums (the other is the Wallace Collection in London). Though far smaller than the Met, the Frick boasts a far higher average quality of painting. Nearly everything in it is a masterpiece or a near miss.Better still, because a single man assembled the vast majority of the collection, the individual works create a cohesive whole that elevates the emotional impact of the works. This museum has an individual personality that no mega-museum assembled by hundreds of curators can match. And that personality belongs to Henry Clay Frick.Apparently Frick was a hard and ruthless man of business, but he clearly had a soft and joyful side that expresses itself in his collection. You'll find almost no art of hardship and privation at the Frick. Instead, you'll see work after work designed to remind you how joyful life can be. The women are beautiful. The men are dashing. The landscapes are elegant.And then there's the building that houses the collection, which served as Frick's private residence and has been largely preserved as he left it. It is an astonishingly beautiful place and as you wander about it, you can imagine what life might have been like for a turn-of-the-century Robber Barron.One complaint I've seen leveled against the Frick here is that it's expensive ($18 as of December, 2009) but I will point out that admission includes a very good audio guide that costs and extra $7 at most museums. If that's too rich for your blood, go on Sunday mornings and pay what you wish for admission and audio guide. One warning: If you go on Sunday morning, expect crowds.
Small and interesting collection. Collection was reasonably small but had some excellent works (in my humble and untrained opinion) with the surrounds positively adding to the experience.

Small but very interesting and quite an experience. The Frick Collection might not be your usual awe-inspiring, dazzling collection of art with huge rooms full of paintings. Rather, it's the collection of a private man who bought art and decided that after his death his house should be a museum, so already when he built the place he had a museum in mind. I liked the way the house itself is lovely to visit, but the art that is in there is certainly worth an hour or so of visit - however, the admission price is a bit expensive, but then you are supporting this unique museum.
Dont waste your time. I felt that the price of $18.00 for admission was totally wasted as the collection was very limited and not worth the visit. Visit the Metropolitan where you are welcome
Fine Art without crowds / Free on Sundays, 11am - 1pm.. This beautifully preserved mansion is an attraction in itself and the collection is outstanding. I do not recommend this museum for children.

Excellent, intimate museum!. My dad, husband and I made a trip to NYC this past Memorial Weekend. My dad is almost 70 and has some trouble walking around, so I wanted to take him to a smaller museum where he could enjoy the art without feeling too overwhelmed. We went to the Frick Museum on Sunday morning and really, really enjoyed the experience. I love how very famous paintings are located in such an intimate setting. We saw works by Titian, Degas, Renoir and more. The free audio guide is amazing and really adds a important dimension to the viewing experience. My dad was initially hesitant to try the audio guide but later told me that he was so glad that I persuaded him to try it. If you have only 2 hours to see a museum and are looking for a place where you won't feel overwhelmed, check out the Frick. I'm so so glad that we went. Also, Sunday morning is "pay as you wish", so you don't have to pay full price if you cannot afford to do so.

An intimate art viewing experience. I love art, and I love big museums. The Frick Collection was one of my first experiences with the joy of a little museum. The combined experience of viewing these masterpieces and touring the period home makes for a great few hours. Where else can you see a Vermeer in someone's hallway or a Hans Holbein over someone's mantle? I just loved this intimate setting for major masterpieces. Leave about 2-3 hours to do the collection in detail, along with listening to the commentary from the audioguide. If you're really interested in Henry Clay Frick, you may want to check out a book called "Old Masters, New World," which has a great chapter on him and puts his life and art collecting into historical perspective.

The first thing you should do in NYC. I would go back a million times.. If you only want to go to one museum/art gallery, this is the one!Feels like you're in Versaille. Absolutely beautiful building, a welcome contrast to the modern and sometimes ugly architecture of NYC. A breath of fresh air.The collection is very personal and so emotive. The free audio in English is a must and i would have paid 100 dollars to see this collection. It's world class.I paid 15 dollars i think but on Sunday, it's pay what you like, so you could get in for 1 dollar.If i ever life in NYC, i will spend all my weekends in this magical place... and i don't even like Art Galleries that much...Everyone will love the Frick collection. Massive highlight was the Thomas Moore portrait (can't remember artist) and the Whistlers.DO IT DO IT DO IT!!!!!

Beautiful venue and great collection. We were recommeded this museum because it gives you alook at the grand homes of old New York. We were so impressed with the building and beauty but were also thrilled by the quality collection to be found within its impressive walls.

A must for Art Lovers. This is a gem of a museum. The colllection here is fabulous and although the museum is small, there is a lot to see and it is all without exception of the best quality. The added bonus here is the setting, the collection is housed in the Mansion owned by the collections owner and hung beautifully in graceful rooms. If you love art, don't miss this collection!

what a fabulous Collection. when i think that these works of art were collected by one Family, it is something exceptional. In Paris also the André Jacquemard Collection is impressive and both are presented in particular hotels having belonged to the Family. What an emotion. If you can, go to the Frick Collection on sunday morning, between 11am and 1pm, you pay what you want ....

Simply Stunning. I have been to NYC several times, but this was my first visit to the Frick. The collection is amazing, even if you are not an art expert, you can appreciate the beauty and talent. That it's housed in a restored mansion is an extra bonus. No photography inside is the only negative. Will definitely go back next time I'm here with a 'non-museum' person.

A Great New York City Experience. My favorite New York City art museum is the Frick.I like its outstanding quality of paintings and its cozy atmosphere.This smaller New York City art museum has splendid collections of paintings by Vermeer,Boucher,Fragonard,Van Dyck,and Whistler.It has a fine collection of early Italian paintings(Duccio,Piero Della Francesca,Cimabue).It has a fine collection of French Limoges enamels(Leonard Limousin).It has delightful British portraiture(Gainesborough,Reynolds,Hogarth).Personal favorites were;Cimabue's"Flagellation",Constable's"Salisbury Church",and Monet's"Vethieul in Winter".So enrich yourself at this less discovered New York City gem.

Do not miss this stunning museum. I visited the Frick last Tuesday with my two teenaged kids. They're reluctant museum goers so I wanted to go someplace that wasn't overwhelming and had heard the Frick is a manageable size. It's also about the only opportunity you have to see a Gilded Age mansion. Fifth Avenue was lined with sumptuous homes then, the "real" homes as opposed to the "cottages" you see in Newport, RI. But real estate on Fifth Avenue was too valuable for many of them to survive so this is a chance to see the works of art within and the work of art that houses them.The museum is beautifully laid out, the rooms gorgeous, the painting and sculptures well displayed. The audio guide (free with admission) is excellent, offering interesting backstories for most of the works. While we were there the Collection's three Vermeers were hung together so you can truly appreciate his genius in full.My kids didn't want to visit a museum and only went because we had agreed to do "something for everyone" - shopping, Spamalot, etc. But they were very impressed with the museum and seeing these incredible works of great masters up close. And just when your kids would get sick and tired and overwhelmed with a museum you're through the Frick and back out into its gorgeous courtyard.My kids zone out in vast museums like the Met, but they talked about what they'd seen in the Frick a lot afterward. It's a very palatable dose of culture for teens and a wonderful art fix for their shopped-out parents!

Arguably the best museum in New York. Friends had urged me to visit this place at all costs, and it really is well worth spending half a day in this opulent former mansion to appreciate one of the greatest personal collections of fine art in the world. If the Metropolitan Museum daunts you by its sheer scale, the intimacy of the Frick comes like a breath of fresh air.

Magnificent collection - Strictly for art lovers. No crowds and much beauty to enjoy. Be warned though, this is not the run of the mill visit for anyone who is not seriously into art. If you don't know what a turner is then got go. However if you are serious about your art ..... this collection will take your breathe away.

Highly recommended - definitely worth a visit. This is great little gallery which I would highly recommend. If you are not planning a particularly cultural trip but would quite like to visit a gallery this is one not to be missed. The collection is contained in a beautiful house with an indoor garden area where you can sit afterwards and reflect upon what you have seen. I personally thought the collection itself is a great size - not too big so you can properly appreciate all the artworks - good if like me the larger galleries leave you feeling slightly overwhelmed. There is a free audio guide which works on the system by which each painting has a number adjacent to it - you key this number into the guide it tells you about that particular piece. This is great because it leaves you explore the gallery at your leisure. I paid the very reasonable student rate of $5 dollars but it is definitely worth a visit at the full price of $15 and on Sundays from 11.00 till 1.00 you can visit and pay what you wish. As for the art wok there are Gainsboroughs, Constables, and Whilsters to name but a few and all tastefully displayed in the ornate rooms. Go see it!!

Mixed feelings. The collection is interesting, but don't expect seeing too many pictures or statues. It's 1 floor only. The 2nd floor was closed. I felt $15 for this was just too much. Also, it was strange they charge you $1 if you want to get 1 print-out to read more about he museum - it's usually completely free at other museums. They have audio guides in French, Italian etc., but not in Russian. Russian is one of the top world languages, far more important than French or Italian nowadays, so I don't understand why it was not available. (I am not Russian, I can speak 7 languages so it's not a problem for me to get another language version, it was just strange for me). Another con - very limited # of seats in the galleries - just couple of chairs - it is very difficult for pregnant women or elder people to stand all the time. You can see antique chairs all over the place, but of course you can't use them, however, for $15 there should be more seats available. Yes, you can sit down in the garden hall, but there only are marble benches that are very cold. Well, I would not return to this museum although I liked the art shown there, the whole house, however, was not inviting at all. Didn't get a good impression overall.

Best Art Collection in New York City. If you have only a limiterd time in New York City and want to view some of the best art in the world, the Frick Collection is the place to go! Everything from Rembrandt to Whistler. And an audio guide is included in the price of admission. It is a small collection and can be visited in about an hour, but you can well spend more time. Well worth the admission and the time.

Most amazing private collection in the USA!!. I have been to private collections/museums all around the USA and Western Europe. By far, this is one of the most impressive yet unique collection of old European artists---Renoir, Vermeer, Velasquez, Goya, Boucher, Ruebens, Van Dyck, etc...The free audio tour is incredible too. A 20 minute movie at the end of the collection complements the entire experience. This is a must see in NYC!!

a nice collection. The Frick has a very nice collection which you can easily peruse in a couple hours. While I agree that the staff is very unfriendly and stern, I do believe the security people all over the musuem are necessary to ensure visitors can continue to enjoy the relaxed, home-like feel to the collection (Instead of putting everything behind glass.) The house is beautiful, the art interesting and covering a wide variety of movements. Go on a Sunday between 11 and 1 and you can pay what you wish to enter.

The Magnificent Mansion. Visitng the Frick is like going to visit your old friend's house. This friend has great taste in art, and a beautiful mansion in possibly the prettiest part of New York! It unlike a typical musem in that one need not be an intellectual art "appreciater" to get the effect of the magnificence of htis collection. I reccommend it to all adults.

Fabulous small museum. You MUST take the time to visit this small museum while in New York. Your visit will take only about an hour and the old master paintings are some of the best to be seen in America. The building is the former residence of Mr. Frick and is typical of a millionaire's residence at the turn of the last century- plenty of polished marble and wood. It would cost a fortune to build this today!

THE FRIGID FRICK. About two weeks ago I visited The Frick Collection. The atmosphere seemed to me as chilly as that morning's cold gusts across Central Park! I acknowledge our troubled times, but it seemed the security guards within were unpleasant, superfluous and overbearing and definitely tainted my visit. I made the mistake of carrying my jacket on my arm, and in a very brusque manner, was told to carry it on my shoulders by one attendant. I suppose someone must have once walked off with one of their ugly bronzes. (Perhaps if they are so concerned about this they could glue them to the pretentious Louis IV bombes?) I felt the weight of the "guards" constantly looking over my shoulder and spent much less time at this gallery (and money in the gift shop) than I had intended. I'd advise tourists to visit the Met instead and avoid the Frick until they realize patrons would rather be welcomed than frowned upon.

Frick Mansion, Boat House Restaurant Central Park. While browsing thru the Beautiful Grand Central Station, we met a Gentlemen who should have been a tour guide. He was Life Insurance Salesman who always goes to the Grand Central Station for lunch. He explained the history of the Station and led us to the Frick Mansion on East 70th and 5th Avenue. The owners live upstairs and shair the downstairs beautiful art collection. We as seniors paid $8 and enjoyed the original's. Even Rambrant's works. We then walked across Central Park and had a wonderful lunch at the Boat House Restaurant. What a great day!!
